lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Merkel Signals That Tension Persists Over U.S. Spying
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Embargoes and Sanctions', 'Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods']
abstract: At a White House meeting meant to mend fences, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany said it was too soon to return to “business as usual” with the United States following disclosures that the N.S.A had eavesdropped on her phone calls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama tried to mend fences with Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany on Friday, calling her “one of my closest friends on the world stage.” But Ms. Merkel replied tartly that Germany still had significant differences with the United States over surveillance practices and that it was too soon to return to “business as usual.”

headline: On Court or Off, He Savors Assists
abstract: Mr. Rodriguez, who plays a gangland son who infiltrates police ranks in “Gang Related,” coming to Fox, talks about the men who helped him at crucial points in his younger years.
lead_paragraph: In “Gang Related,” Ramon Rodriguez portrays Ryan Lopez, the adopted son of a crime lord who infiltrates the Los Angeles Police Department to help his family keep ahead of the law. But while Mr. Rodriguez’s real life doesn’t have the heart-stopping close calls, underworld gore or angsty divided loyalties that riddle this new Fox series, starting May 22, his childhood was a textbook example of how a father figure — or three — can help put a troubled boy on the right path.

headline: Spring Vegetable Stew With Artichokes and Fennel
abstract: The inspiration for this dish is a Sicilian stew called fritteda that can be served with pasta or other grains as a main course.
lead_paragraph: This is inspired by a lush Sicilian springtime stew called fritteda that also includes peas and fava beans (and much more olive oil). This one is simpler, but equally sweet and heady because of all the fennel and the spring onions. I like to serve it with bow-tie pasta and a little Parmesan as a main dish, or with grains as part of a meal in a bowl. It also makes a delicious side dish with just about anything.

headline: Inequality Has Been Going On Forever ... but That Doesn’t Mean It’s Inevitable
abstract: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long that it has come to seem inevitable. It doesn’t have to be.
lead_paragraph: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long — in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones — that it has come to seem inevitable. It is no longer news that the affluent did better than everyone else during the booms of the 1980s and ’90s and through the mediocre growth of this century’s first years. Or that the rich have recovered from the financial crisis far better than the rest of country.

headline: Baked Frittata With Yogurt, Chard and Green Garlic
abstract: A spin on the Provençal chard omelet called truccha, good to eat hot, warm or cold.
lead_paragraph: Inspired by the signature Provençal chard omelet called truccha, this beautiful baked frittata incorporates thick Greek yogurt and lots of green garlic. It will puff up in the oven, but then it settles back down. Use a generous bunch of chard for this – green, red or rainbow – and save the stalks to use in the chard stalk and chickpea purée that I’m also posting this week. I like to serve the frittata at room temperature, or I grab a cold slice for lunch. It’s a wonderfully portable dish.

headline: Timeless Papua New Guinea
abstract: Vikram Gandhi, a “Vice” correspondent, says that despite the country’s rapid development, certain regions “feel like a land lost in time.”
lead_paragraph: When the newsmagazine “Vice” made its debut on HBO last year with fast-paced segments on child suicide bombers in Afghanistan and Dennis Rodman in North Korea, some critics cried sensationalism.

headline: Quinoa Bowl With Roasted Artichokes, Spring Onions, Peas and Garlic Yogurt
abstract: This dish in a bowl mixes sweet and bitter edges.
lead_paragraph: There’s a lot going on in this springtime meal in a bowl – the onions and peas are sweet, but the onions also have that lovely bitter-edged char, as do the artichokes, from roasting. I first roasted artichokes for a bulgur salad not too long ago, and now I’m roasting them all the time. Roasting intensifies their flavor. Bulgur is also a great grain choice for this bowl.

headline: A Mystery Endures in Beijing’s Old Legation Quarter
abstract: Decades after the murder of a young British woman in what was then Peking, artifacts of the time remain even as the crime remains unsolved.
lead_paragraph: On a freezing January morning in 1937, the mutilated body of a beautiful 19-year-old British woman was found lying at the base of Fox Tower along old Peking’s Ming dynasty protective wall. Her heart had been ripped out, her face slashed with a knife. Her head lay to the west, her feet to the east. Strangely, there was little blood.

headline: Squid: Make It Tender, Make It Quick
abstract: If you are a calamari fan and you also care about choosing sustainable seafood, look no further.
lead_paragraph: If you are a calamari fan and you also care about choosing sustainable seafood, look no further. Get thee to a fishmonger and buy some squid. It won’t set you back much; a pound of squid costs only a few dollars. By rights, something that tastes so good should cost a lot more.

headline: Solo in Paris
abstract: There is a version of the city that deeply rewards a traveler willing to explore it alone.
lead_paragraph: Some go to La Coupole, the 87-year-old Art Deco brasserie in Montparnasse, to commune with friends; others, to dine with ghosts — Picasso, Piaf, Sartre, all former patrons. I went alone, to live in the present.

headline: Stir-Fried Baby Turnips With Spring Onions, Green Garlic and Tofu
abstract: Juicy springtime ginger, onions and green garlic elevate this stir-fry featuring baby turnips and their bitter greens.
lead_paragraph: The fresh ginger I’m finding at springtime farmers’ markets is new and juicy, like the spring garlic and onions. I’m sure this is going to be just one of many springtime stir-fries, but right now it’s a favorite. It’s inspired by an irresistible bunch of baby turnips I bought at a Sunday farmers’ market. The turnips were no bigger than a small round radish, but their greens were lush – I had about 6 cups of leaves after I’d stripped them from the stems. Sweet spring onions and green garlic contrast beautifully with the bitter flavor of the turnip greens.

headline: Chard Stalk, Chickpea, Tahini and Yogurt Dip
abstract: An economical dip that is a cross between hummus and the classic Middle Eastern dip called silq bil tahina.
lead_paragraph: When you’ve bought a bunch of Swiss chard and used the leaves for another dish, like an oven-baked frittata with yogurt, Swiss chard and green garlic, save the stems. Then you can make this dip, which is a cross between hummus and classic Middle Eastern dip called silq bil tahina, made with chard stalks and tahini. I’ve added lots of yogurt to the mix. I love to use some red chard stalks because they give the dip a beautiful pale pink hue.

headline: Billions Not Required for Angel Investing
abstract: A new book argues that more people can and should become angel investors, but that they must expect plenty of failures along with the rare big win.
lead_paragraph: JUST about every major tech success — from Facebook to LinkedIn to Instagram — started with angel investors taking a chance. These risk takers ended up being richly rewarded for their early investments, and no doubt they have inspired would-be angels to search for the next big thing.

headline: See It, Feel It, Touch It, Be Healed
abstract: Lygia Clark is not well known in the United States, a circumstance that should be corrected by a new exhibition at the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Though she was one of Brazil’s most celebrated artists of the post-World War II era, Lygia Clark (1920-88) is not well known in the United States, a circumstance that should be corrected by “Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988,” beginning Saturday at the Museum of Modern Art. Clark started out as a maker of geometric abstractions under the influences of Klee, Mondrian and Léger. In the 1960s she was associated with Neo-Concretism, the Brazilian movement that insisted on the sensual and material — as opposed to intellectual — properties of paintings and sculpture, sometimes encouraging viewer interaction with objects and installations. After 1966, Clark claimed to have abandoned art. She shifted her approach away from creating conventional forms and toward a kind of art therapy that involved the application of materials and devices directly to the people’s bodies. Art was treated as a form of psychological healing. Her late works should be of particular interest to fans of socially engaged and otherwise participatory types of art making. (Through Aug. 24, 11 West 53rd Street, 212-708-9400, moma.org.)

headline: Two Generations of New-Music Stars
abstract: A new-music great and a rising star both have tantalizing concerts on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: A new-music great and a rising star both have tantalizing concerts on Saturday. The pianist Peter Serkin, 66, fresh off a recent Bartok triumph with the New York Philharmonic, arrives at the 92nd Street Y with a characteristically varied program. Stretching from the early Baroque composer Jan Pieterszoon Sweelinck to three recent works by Charles Wuorinen, the evening also includes Carl Nielsen and Beethoven. (8 p.m., Lexington Avenue at 92nd Street, 212-415-5500, 92y.org.)

headline: In the Footsteps of the Founder
abstract: Since its founding in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa has been a home to, and champion of, brash and venturesome artists.
lead_paragraph: Since its founding in 1961 by Ellen Stewart, La MaMa has been a home to, and champion of, brash and venturesome artists. This month, that East Village theater presents its annual La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival, now in its ninth year, featuring more than 50 local and international artists (through May 25). In the first week, the festival hosts a benefit concert, “Dancing for Japan 2014” (Wednesday), to support victims of the 2011 Tohoku earthquake and tsunami. Next, Miki Orihara, a longtime dancer for the Martha Graham Dance Company, will perform “Resonance,” a series of solos by modern-dance pioneers and contemporary choreographers (Thursday through May 11).

headline: Onstage in Harlem, a Week of Jazz
abstract: The Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival, in its fourth year, rallies around a sense of place and the past, from a vantage that feels convincingly like the present.
lead_paragraph: The Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival, in its fourth year, rallies around a sense of place and the past, from a vantage that feels convincingly like the present. Running from Sunday through Saturday at more than half a dozen locations, it finds common ground for concert premieres, tributes and academic talks. On Monday at Minton’s, for example, a 7:30 p.m. conversation about the bebop progenitor Charlie Parker, with the critic and biographer Stanley Crouch and the scholar Farah Jasmine Griffin, will be followed by a 10 p.m. jam session led by the alto saxophonist Antonio Hart, one of Parker’s many heirs.

headline: In Estate Planning, Family Isn’t Always First
abstract: Older people without children, stepchildren or grandchildren are choosing to donate to organizations they have ties with.
lead_paragraph: WHETHER it’s treasured pearl earrings or a vintage camera, a house or what’s left of your life savings, deciding who should inherit your worldly goods means making sometimes wrenching choices. For older people without children, stepchildren or grandchildren, the decision can be even more complex.

headline: Dirty Dancing Encouraged Here
abstract: Who needs two tickets to paradise when a spicy shimmy will do?
lead_paragraph: Who needs two tickets to paradise when a spicy shimmy will do? Mario Lopez, the Season 3 runner-up on “Dancing With the Stars,” and his wife, Courtney, a Broadway hoofer, are proof. Their chemistry ignited while performing in a revival of “A Chorus Line.” Now the Lopezes are testing their theory in “Love & Salsa,” a new dating competition produced by him and hosted by her and having its debut Tuesday night at 10 on NUVOtv.

headline: Springtime at Carnegie Hall
abstract: The Spring for Music festival at Carnegie Hall will include orchestras from New York, Cincinnati, Winnipeg and other cities in North America.
lead_paragraph: Spring for Music, the annual weeklong festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, begins and ends with requiem settings: the New York premiere of Christopher Rouse’s Requiem, performed by Alan Gilbert and the New York Philharmonic on Monday, and a little drama built around Mozart’s Requiem, performed by Manfred Honeck and the Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra on May 10. Whether that framing came about by happenstance (unlikely, given the jesting proclivities of the festival’s chief executive and artistic director, Thomas W. Morris) or by design, it is, alas, all too appropriate. Spring for Music, in only its fourth season, is evidently a goner.

headline: A Choreographic Cross-Pollination
abstract: Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas features talks, publications and dance around New York.
lead_paragraph: Sophie Claudel was living in Paris and working at the Pompidou Center when France Moves took over New York City. “I heard a lot about it,” she said over coffee, referring to the 2001 dance festival of French choreography. Her eyes widened with curiosity. “I always thought, why shouldn’t we try to do something?”

headline: Rivka Galchen on Comic Strips, Lucille Ball and What She’s Reading Now
abstract: The celebrated young author, whose new short-story collection is out May 6, discusses a few of her favorite things with T.
lead_paragraph: Rivka’s Galchen’s 2009 debut novel “Atmospheric Disturbances” was filled with pleasurably twisty sentences and casually engaging intellectualism, earning her effusive praise and comparisons to Jonathen Lethem, Thomas Pynchon and Jorge Luis Borges. Her new book, “American Innovations” (out May 6 from Farrar, Straus and Giroux) gathers 10 short stories — each written from a female perspective in response to a canonical work like Gogol’s “The Nose” and Borges’s “The Aleph” — that are sharp and rich, astutely observed and wildly imaginative.

headline: A Great War Reading List at PEN World Voices Festival
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'World War I (1914-18)', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: Geoff Dyer, Liesl Schillinger, Justin Go and Janne Teller discussed the literature of World War I at an event on Wednesday night.
lead_paragraph: July is the centenary of the outbreak of World War I, but publishers got a major jump on the anniversary last year. Christopher Clark’s “The Sleepwalkers,” Margaret Macmillan’s “The War That Ended Peace,” Max Hastings’s “Catastrophe 1914” and Sean McMeekin’s “July 1914” were just four of the hundreds of books to mark the moment a year early. The deluge continues in 2014, with, well, “The Deluge” by Adam Tooze (coming in November), David Reynolds’s “The Long Shadow” and many more.

headline: Car Bombs in Central Syria Kill at Least 19
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Civilian Casualties', 'Bombs and Explosives']
abstract: The bombings came even as a cease-fire deal was reported in the battered city of Homs. The budding agreement would allow the last remaining insurgents in the Old City to flee.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In the latest strike in a rapid-fire series of bloody attacks on children and other civilians in Syria, two car bombs exploded in the central province of Hama on Friday, killing at least 19 people, including 11 children, Syrian state news media reported, blaming insurgents.

headline: Readers Get to Weigh In on Apologies
abstract: Apology Watch is introducing surveys to allow readers to share their views and evaluate the authenticity of apologies, Dov Seidman writes.
lead_paragraph: When Andrew Ross Sorkin and I came together to start “Apology Watch,” our goal was to elevate the conversation about authentic apologies. In that vein, we are introducing an “Apology Metric” survey to give readers an opportunity to share their insight. Through these surveys, we hope to change the shortsighted lens through which apologies are typically viewed. People review them as theatrical performances for a few days and quickly forget about them. Instead, as I’ve argued before, we ought to track the apologizer’s behavior over time to see whether he or she has genuinely committed to a new course of action, which is why we are offering these surveys.

headline: G.M. Talks to Families With Claims Over Defects
abstract: The number of cases, attributing wrongful death or personal injury to an ignition defect, suggest more victims than the company has acknowledged.
lead_paragraph: The lawyer hired by General Motors to explore compensating victims of cars with a defective ignition switch met on Friday with a representative of hundreds of people and their families who say they were affected by accidents involving the vehicles.

lead_paragraph: Slouching over the defense table in the stained, gray sweat clothes he wore throughout his trial, David Tarloff finally got a chance to speak on Friday in the Manhattan courtroom where his sanity had been debated for weeks.

headline: On Kentucky Derby Weekend, a Tea Party Julep for Mitch McConnell
abstract: In addition to being a symbol of conservative activism, tea also pairs well with bourbon.
lead_paragraph: If Senator Mitch McConnell has to hear one more ad saying he has “betrayed Kentucky’s conservative values,” he’ll probably want a drink. Fortunately, in addition to being a symbol of conservative activism, tea is also an infusion that pairs well with bourbon. At least, that’s what we heard from Sachin Hasan of Manhattan’s Pierre Hotel, who discussed tea-bourbon drinks with T Magazine back in January.

headline: Penguins Discuss Line Strategy and Tiring Out the Rangers
abstract: Ahead of Game 1 on Friday, Penguins Coach Dan Bylsma said he might use his star centers on the same line, as he did last series, and would try to exploit the Rangers’ lack of rest.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — For an N.H.L. coach, the Pittsburgh Penguins’ Dan Bylsma is refreshingly open about tactics.

headline: Listen Up | A Ghostly Hymn From Your New Swedish Obsession
abstract: The lo-fi songstress Alice Boman debuts a new track from her forthcoming “EP II.”
lead_paragraph: Alice Boman wrote and recorded her new song, “Over,” alone in her apartment in Malmo, Sweden. “I didn’t know it was going to be released,” she says of the hauntingly spare recording, which will appear on her new release, “EP II,” out June 3 via the Control Group. This intimate, lo-fi approach is characteristic of the soft-spoken singer-songwriter’s work. Her first EP, last year’s “Skisser” (Swedish for “sketches”), earned raves for its minimal arrangements and simple, heartbreaking lyrics. She tried to capture the same magic with “EP II,” cutting more tracks at home and, at one point, holing up in a cabin in the Swedish woods to record her ethereal sounds. The rustic setting — Boman says she had to trek to a neighbor’s to fetch water each day — proved a fitting backdrop for the 26-year-old’s elegiac, if oddly uplifting, tunes. “It was beautiful,” she says.

headline: Book Review Podcast: Ayelet Waldman’s ‘Love and Treasure’
abstract: Ms. Waldman discusses her new novel, which tells a multigenerational story set in Salzburg and Budapest.
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Catherine Taylor reviews Ayelet Waldman’s new novel, “Love and Treasure.” The book features the so-called Hungarian Gold Train, which held property requisitioned by the Nazis from Hungary’s Jewish citizens. Ms. Taylor writes:

headline: For This Wedding, the Roundtable Reconvenes

lead_paragraph: When Shaun Cherewich, a retired high school teacher and coach, says he’s old-fashioned, he’s not talking raccoon coats and jitterbugging. He’s talking about going way back — all the way to Europe’s medieval period.

headline: Taking a Spin: Everything Comes Up Republican
abstract: Months before the election, the only certainty is uncertainty, as this week’s look at the Senate model makes clear.
lead_paragraph: My inaugural weekly spin of the wheels on The Upshot’s Senate model, named Leo, gave Democrats a dream outcome: 54 Senate seats. In perhaps the surest indication of the uncertainty that remains at this early stage, my spin this week yields the exact opposite result: 54 seats for Republicans.

headline: The Gun Report: May 2, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: This week, a firearms investigation unit of the N.Y.P.D. and a unit from the Brooklyn district attorney’s office shut down a weapons pipeline from Georgia to New York. Among the hundreds of guns seized were an AR-15, a MAC-11, two TEC-9 semi-automatic handguns and a Taurus .380-caliber semi-automatic pistol.

headline: Hip-Hop’s New New York
abstract: In the city’s rap community, many artists have created something of a family.
lead_paragraph: When I ventured into the underground rap world of New York City, I discovered a tight community, a new wave of artists, the New New York. Many of them performed on the Beast Coastal tour. They grew up together or met through hip-hop and have now created something of a family. Their sense of brotherhood inspired me to start photographing rap shows.

headline: Hundreds of Afghans Are Killed in Landslides
abstract: As many as 2,500 people were said to be missing in the disaster, one of the worst to hit the country in at least a decade.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Huge landslides caused by heavy rainfall buried hundreds of houses in a remote area of northeastern Afghanistan on Friday. As many as 2,500 people were said to be missing in the disaster, one of the worst to hit the war-torn country in at least a decade.

headline: Memos to Hollywood
abstract: Five years after first trying it, two critics again offer advice to everyone involved in the making, distributing and watching of movies.
lead_paragraph: Summer is sequel season, when the movie studios celebrate their lack of imagination by disguising it as populism. Why should movie critics be any different? Five years ago, we published the first installment of our “Memos to Hollywood,” in which we presumed to give advice to everyone involved in the making, distributing and watching of movies. And now we’re back with another spectacular, game-changing, blockbuster episode. This time, they’ll pay attention.

headline: A Long and Questionable Record in Sales
abstract: Michael Forman, 72, whom a parole official once told he “could have made millions as a salesman,” was recently released from prison and is again accused of taking money under false pretenses.
lead_paragraph: The sign on the door of the building on Eighth Avenue hard by Pennsylvania Station reads “Vigilant Hotel.” It is handwritten on cardboard. The Vigilant is a men’s-only, single-room-occupancy dwelling, the sort that lined the Bowery and its skid row a generation ago. Rooms go for $150 a week.

headline: On the Market in New York City
abstract: This week’s properties include a West Village loft; a Gramercy Park one-bedroom; and a Clinton Hill studio.

headline: How Not to Pick Judges
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls', 'Minorities', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: The current selection process is biased against women and minorities.
lead_paragraph: ROCHESTER — RESEARCH has long shown that female judges vote differently from men on issues of sex discrimination, harassment and sentencing, while black judges vote differently from whites on issues involving civil rights and affirmative action.

headline: Singing an Ode to the Naked City
abstract: In John Carney’s new film, “Begin Again,” he has tried to shoot in parts of New York that are recognizable to residents, not tourists.
lead_paragraph: In 2006, while the Irish writer-director John Carney was promoting his indie musical film “Once,” he fell hard for New York City. Literally. “Cycling around, going the wrong way down one-way streets, I got the feel of living here,” Mr. Carney said, adding that when he crashed that bike, he admired the efficiency with which New Yorkers stopped “for the minimal amount of time to make sure I wasn’t dead.”

headline: Naismith’s Choices on Race, From Basketball’s Beginnings
abstract: James Naismith had strong feelings against segregation and was a mentor to a student who became the first black coach in professional basketball.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a week in which the Los Angeles Clippers owner Donald Sterling became, for a moment, the most talked-about man in basketball, let’s rewind the historical videotape and remember the Canadian-born farmer-chaplain-physician who invented the game. Here is James Naismith in 1928, holding a peach basket for his wife, Maude, to make a shot. Naismith seems now like an anachronistic figure, yet even nearly a century ago he too had to make serious choices about issues like race and money in basketball.

headline: Big Ticket | For $26.6 Million, a Penthouse in SoHo With a Lawn on the Terrace
keywords: ['Balconies and Terraces', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Real Estate Brokers']
abstract: A five-bedroom penthouse that was owned by the artist Charles Ross was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A SoHo artist’s studio that underwent a radical transformation from an airy but spartan loft to a sybaritic 7,200-square-foot luxury penthouse sold for $26,580,000 and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: Weekend Reading: Targeting Big Banks. No, Not Those Big Banks.
abstract: The news this week that criminal charges were nearing against a French bank and a Swiss bank received a mixed reaction from a public weary over the mantra that Wall Street is “too big to jail.”
lead_paragraph: The news this week that federal prosecutors were nearing criminal charges against a French bank and a Swiss bank received a mixed reaction from a public weary over the mantra that Wall Street is “too big to jail.”

headline: The Peripatetic Physician
abstract: Dr. Bernt Nesje, 67, has two guidelines for taking on patients: They must live in or around Greenwich Village, and they must be older than he is.
lead_paragraph: Dr. Bernt Nesje, 67, says he has two guidelines for taking on patients: They must live in or around Greenwich Village, “and they have to be older than me.”

headline: Think Like a Doctor: 18-Year Rash Solved!
abstract: Readers solve the case of a 40-year-old woman with a rash on her hands that persisted for nearly two decades.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, we challenged Well readers to figure out why a 40-year-old woman had a rash on her hands for nearly two decades. I thought this was a really tough case. Apparently, so did my readers. Nearly 300 of you wrote in with some very thoughtful suggestions, but only five were able to make the diagnosis.

headline: Inequality Is Not Inevitable
abstract: We have decades of evidence telling us how to lift living standards for the middle class and the poor.
lead_paragraph: We have been living with rising income inequality for so long — in good times and bad, under Republican presidents and Democratic ones — that it has come to seem inevitable. But inequality is not inevitable. Many societies, including the United States, have found ways to reduce inequality and lift living standards for the middle class and the poor.

headline: Small and City-Smart, Microvans Proliferate
abstract: Small cargo vans, like the Ford Transit Connect, have become a familiar sight in American cities. The latest entry in the class is the Chevrolet City Express.
lead_paragraph: If Americans found the arrival of the Ford Transit Connect in North America in 2009 a bit unsettling, by now they have become accustomed to its upright and somewhat ungainly shape. In just a few years, small cargo vans have become a familiar sight in American cities — and Ford’s competitors are taking notice.

headline: Consider It a Sequel to a Hit From the ’90s
abstract: The Audi A3, which evokes the 1996 A4 that single-handedly hauled the company back from oblivion, is the cheapest Audi and the Audi that’s easiest to love.
lead_paragraph: Reruns are comforting. Gilligan always screws up the rescue, Lucy gets smashed on Vitameatavegamin every single time, and no characters on “Seinfeld” remain masters of their domain. At some point it’s not about laughing at all the jokes, it’s the satisfaction of knowing all the jokes.

headline: More Pickup Buyers Opt for V6s
abstract: For the first time in about 50 years, many big-truck customers no longer consider a 6-cylinder engine to be a downgrade.
lead_paragraph: It’s much too soon for a retirement party, but the V8 engine seems to be losing its clout with buyers of full-size pickup trucks. For the first time in about 50 years, many big-truck customers no longer consider a 6-cylinder engine to be a downgrade.

headline: Her True Colors, in Plain View
abstract: A Long Island woman has customized her beloved 1951 Ford Club Coupe into a rowdy, rumbling ride. “I like to take it down to Ocean Parkway and open it up a bit,” she said. “It’s my therapy.”
lead_paragraph: EAST MEADOW, N.Y. — Over a lunch of grilled cheese sandwiches at Panera Bread on Hempstead Turnpike here, Kim Schreier told the stories behind the tattoos that, she said, covered some 60 percent of her body.

headline: The New Firefox Is Fantastic. So Is Every Other Web Browser.
abstract: The major web browsers have become equally fast, stable and useful, which makes selecting among them a matter of subjective preference.
lead_paragraph: Mozilla has just released the latest upgrade to Firefox, its popular open-source browser. We’re at version 29 now, which as software goes is pretty long in the tooth.

headline: A Teachers’ Contract for New York
abstract: Though imperfect, the agreement is a good deal for the city and its students.
lead_paragraph: There was no snarling at City Hall when Mayor Bill de Blasio and the teachers’ union announced a very significant labor agreement on Thursday. Dispensing with the unproductive tension that tarnished the Bloomberg administration, the two sides showed that real progress can be made — on both the fiscal and the educational sides of the contract — when there is good will instead of disdain. On the whole, the agreement represents a good deal for the city and its students, though there were several missed opportunities and unanswered questions.

headline: Friday Night Music: Alison Krauss
abstract: In memory of Jerry Goodman.
lead_paragraph: Too busy to post much. But on Wednesday there was a lovely memorial event for Jerry (George W) Goodman, aka Adam Smith, that among other things highlighted his love of music, and included performances of some of his favorites — including this piece.

headline: Now Screening | A Comedy Director Gets Serious
abstract: Watch our exclusive clip of Richard Ayoade’s new film “The Double,” which hits theaters next week. Jesse Eisenberg plays two identical-looking characters with opposite luck and temperament.
lead_paragraph: In Richard Ayoade’s film, “The Double,” the quiet, self-conscious office clerk Simon James (played by Jesse Eisenberg) is struggling through a work day when he is suddenly confronted with his doppelgänger: exact in physique, but opposite in temperament. Arrogant, suave and irresistible to women, James Simon (also played by Eisenberg) glides into Simon’s life, throwing light on his weaknesses and self-loathing, and preying on his love interest Hannah (played by Mia Wasikowska). Nothing ever seems to go right for Simon, while everything is perfect for James. Based on Fyodor Dostoyevsky’s novella, the story delves into questions of identity, psychosis and self-preservation with absurd and sometimes agonizing humor. A seasoned comedian, the British director can draw a link between Dostoyevsky’s piercing insight and Larry David’s brazen style: “He’s really willing to go to un-noble places in people.”

headline: Outdoor Trips With a Fitness Focus
abstract: Reebok Fitness Vacations by Austin Adventures will include hiking, trail running and kayaking.
lead_paragraph: Travelers who can’t sit still have a new outings option. Two high-profile brands in the active lifestyle and fitness worlds are teaming up to offer Reebok Fitness Vacations by Austin Adventures.

headline: A New Benefit for Heart Failure Patients
abstract: Medicare now pays for cardiac rehabilitation for heart failure patients. But will they use it?
lead_paragraph: The number of older heart failure patients who qualify to enter a cardiac rehabilitation program paid for by Medicare has just been vastly expanded. About two million people are newly eligible, Medicare officials estimate.

headline: Suspenseful Last Note for a Tribute to Britten
abstract: Carnegie Hall’s Britten festival came to a close with the Atlanta Symphony Orchestra and Chorus’s presentation of his “War Requiem.”
lead_paragraph: Last fall Carnegie Hall commemorated the centennial of Benjamin Britten’s birth with a substantive festival highlighted by an inspired concert performance of the opera “Peter Grimes.” That event, featuring an outstanding cast of singers and David Robertson conducting the St. Louis Symphony, took place on Nov. 22, 2013, the 100th anniversary of the composer’s birth.

abstract: Employing myth and hip-hop, Marcus Gardley’s “The Box: A Black Comedy” looks at the life of the incarcerated.
lead_paragraph: We’re No. 1! We’re No. 1!

headline: Sass of a Blues Mama, the Skill of a Stage Star
abstract: Lillias White is offering blues standards and Broadway tunes in her cabaret show at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: As her big eyes widen, and her lusty voice peels away protective layers of pop decorum, Lillias White expresses the drive and critical intelligence of a 62-year-old dynamo who needs extra space to reveal her full, complicated self.

headline: Revenge, My Lovely
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Psychology and Psychologists']
abstract: Our desire for payback isn’t just a pointless instinct. It exemplifies our capacity for abstract thought.
lead_paragraph: OSLO — I WAS lying in bed thinking about how I tortured the man who had raped my partner, how I made sure he didn’t die at once but still experienced some of the fear and physical suffering he had inflicted upon this innocent woman beside me, who had escaped by the skin of her teeth. Half-asleep, I smiled, warmed by the duvet and the glow of revenge and slept like a baby. The latter, I hope, because there had in fact been no rape, no rapist, no torture.

headline: Now That ‘Sugar Man’ Is Found, Lawsuit Focuses on Missing Royalties
abstract: Rodriguez, the subject of “Searching for Sugar Man,” was a star in South Africa, though he didn’t know it. A former producer asks where those royalties went.
lead_paragraph: The documentary “Searching for Sugar Man” tells the story of Rodriguez, an obscure singer-songwriter from Detroit whose albums were commercial flops when released in the early 1970s, but — unknown to Rodriguez and everyone around him — later became gigantic hits in South Africa.

headline: Selling a Fake Painting Takes More Than a Good Artist
abstract: A wide network of professionals and industry practices help conspirators coat fake works with a veneer of credibility.
lead_paragraph: The recent arrest in Spain of two brothers accused of passing off forged paintings as the work of America’s greatest Modernist masters has refocused attention on the people behind an art fraud that has lasted 15 years, garnered $80 million and helped bring down New York’s oldest gallery, Knoedler & Company.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Seasoned
abstract: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature.
lead_paragraph: Fashion is unfolding, just like nature. The spring coat has disappeared, replaced with the short jacket. Most popular is the biker style, worn with fluid trousers or distressed jeans. No fashion trend dominates, but the haberdasher’s look, with a masculine hair style, left, is strong. Black remains popular with city women, but light pastels have their own fashion force. The parks are spectacular with flowers, and trees with leaves as fresh as new grass.

headline: Evening Hours | Dodging the Raindrops
abstract: A wet spring couldn’t slow down the whirl of parties.
lead_paragraph: A wet spring couldn’t slow down the whirl of parties.

headline: Summer Movie Release Schedule
abstract: Listings of this summer’s releases.
lead_paragraph: Yes, Scarlett Johansson wakes up with superpowers and takes no prisoners, but the season isn’t totally about would-be action blockbusters. Philip Seymour Hoffman gifts us with two posthumous performances, as a blue-collar American loser and as a powerful German spy. Documentaries explore a dizzying range of topics, including legal marijuana, the war in Afghanistan, breast-feeding and the Koch brothers. And climate change rears its plot-driving head, ready to replace midcentury nuclear testing as the villain in sci-fi and futurist fantasies.

headline: Under Cover: Body Language Tells the Story
abstract: Ryan Pfluger, a photographer in New York City, took dual portraits of students from two different high schools for a photo essay in this week’s Money Issue, which focuses on inequality. Recently he discussed his photo shoot.
lead_paragraph: This week’s cover features two students from schools that are located in the Bronx but exist worlds apart.

headline: Taking Fares, and Writing in Between
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers']
abstract: Though he drives a cab in Chicago six days a week to make ends meet, the exiled writer Osama Alomar has hopes of becoming a distinct American literary voice, as well as a Syrian one.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — In the Arab world, the Syrian writer Osama Alomar has a growing reputation as the author of short, clever parables that comment obliquely on political and social issues. But here, where he has lived in exile since 2008, he spends most of his time as the driver of Car 45 at the Horizon Taxi Cab company.

headline: Cruelty, Class and Corruption
abstract: Ugly is as ugly does, and ugliness is everywhere in Anurag Kashyap’s new film, which opens the New York Indian Film Festival on Monday.
lead_paragraph: Ugly is as ugly does, and ugliness is everywhere in Anurag Kashyap’s new film, which opens the 14th-annual New York Indian Film Festival on Monday. With “Ugly,” part of last year’s Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes, Mr. Kashyap, an interesting if uneven director, delivers a damning, noirish tale about the corruption that comes after a 10-year-old girl’s kidnapping.

headline: Torch Solo, Then Jammy Time
abstract: After their respective runs in “Matilda” and “Grinch,” Milly and Abigail Shapiro, 11 and 13, add cabaret to their résumé.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, a little girl with a big voice grew too tall to be Matilda on Broadway anymore.

headline: A Concert for Characters
abstract: The New York Philharmonic, conducted by David Newman, plays scores from Pixar’s animated films.
lead_paragraph: A rat who dreams of cooking haute cuisine. A more or less silent robot in a post-apocalyptic wasteland. A grumpy old widower nursing a demented notion. These are just a few of the improbable heroes that Pixar, the animation studio, has brought to astonishing, and astonishingly profitable, life since its first full-length picture, “Toy Story,” in 1995.

headline: Hey, Jack, You’re Back! Anything New?
abstract: After a four-year hiatus, Jack Bauer and “24” are returning to Fox, but the show’s groundbreaking style now seems dated.
lead_paragraph: There is a Persian custom that could probably improve television.

headline: First U.S. Case of MERS Virus Is Found in Indiana Man Who Visited Mideast
abstract: The virus, which is similar to SARS and has killed more than 100 people in the Middle East, was found in a health care worker who recently returned from Saudi Arabia.
lead_paragraph: A virus that has killed more than 100 people in the Middle East has been found in the United States for the first time, in an Indiana health care worker who recently returned from Saudi Arabia, federal health officials said on Friday.

headline: Art Bound by Its Time
abstract: The Limón Dance Company brings two of its signature works and two new pieces to the Joyce Theater.
lead_paragraph: One of the most pervasive issues in modern dance is relevance. How does a company formed in 1946 find meaning in today’s world? The Limón Dance Company, created by José Limón and Doris Humphrey, is an integral part of American dance history, yet the troupe, performing at the Joyce Theater on Tuesday, is trapped in another age.

headline: Done In by Décolletage and Defeatism
abstract: In “Walk of Shame,” Elizabeth Banks plays a TV newswoman who applies for a job in New York, assumes she did not get it and goes out on a night on the town that leads to a run of bad luck.
lead_paragraph: A beautiful woman leaves a bar and goes home with James Marsden. And that is just about the only thing that makes sense in “Walk of Shame.”

headline: Vying for Bragging Rights, Prancing Pros and Amateurs
abstract: Bounce Ballroom in Brooklyn, part of the Red Bull Music Academy festival, blurred the lines between professional and amateur, while recalling an illicit rave.
lead_paragraph: As the famed house music D.J. Todd Terry was playing Thursday night, it was difficult to know what direction to look in. On one part of the floor of the Brooklyn Night Bazaar, a circle of people watched dancers working quick, smooth routines before ceding the floor. Nearby, another circle oohed and aahed over a man who made a lighted cigarette disappear and reappear in his mouth.

headline: How the Poll Was Conducted
abstract: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States.
lead_paragraph: The latest New York Times/CBS News Poll is based on telephone interviews conducted April 30 and May 1 with 1,054 adults throughout the United States. Of these, 534 said they were interested in following professional basketball.

headline: Sinn Fein Leader’s Time in Jail Is Extended, as Party Sees Political Motives by Police
abstract: Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, remains under questioning about a gruesome 1972 murder, as his political party said that the police were playing politics.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The Northern Ireland police were granted permission on Friday to keep Gerry Adams, the leader of Sinn Fein, in custody for another 48 hours for questioning about a gruesome 1972 murder. His party claimed that the police were playing politics before the local and European parliamentary elections this month.

headline: Defining an Online Phenomenon: Virtuoso or a Wedding Band Star?
abstract: Lindsey Stirling, who popularized her dubstep violin in videos that got millions of views, is tough to classify as a musician.
lead_paragraph: One of the most unlikely music phenomena of recent years has been Lindsey Stirling, whose classical-meets-dance music has catapulted her to huge online popularity, with her videos having been viewed hundreds of millions of times. This week Ms. Stirling released her second album, “Shatter Me” (Lindseystomp). In an email exchange, two critics for The New York Times — Jon Caramanica, whose specialty is pop, and Zachary Woolfe, whose area is classical — discussed Ms. Stirling, her gifts and where she fits into the music world. Here are excerpts from the conversation.

headline: Oakland: Brooklyn by the Bay
abstract: Emerging from the shadow of San Francisco, Oakland has found its own style, shopping and food. But gentrification is a growing concern.
lead_paragraph: OAKLAND, Calif. — On a recent Tuesday afternoon, a group of well-dressed and soon-to-be well-groomed men sat patiently in the sun outside Temescal Alley Barbershop waiting for $25 haircuts and $30 straight-razor shaves. Some idly pecked at their phones, while others wandered into Standard & Strange, a men’s clothing store that stocks rugged-looking American-made apparel and accessories as well as some carefully selected items from overseas like Tender jeans, which are handmade and dyed by one guy in Britain and sell for $350. (A leather belt thick enough to harness a thoroughbred, also from Tender, will set you back $240.)

It occurred on the last day of the Norman Kay Platinum Pairs during the Spring North American Championships and was described by the victim, Sartaj Hans from Australia (South).

lead_paragraph: In the kitchen of a 1940s-era diner in Jersey City, the rapper known as Le1f swayed beneath ancient photos of Sylvester Stallone and Mike Tyson.

headline: Life Is Streaming Past You
keywords: ['Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Books and Literature', 'Social Media', 'News and News Media', 'Consumer Behavior', 'Media', 'Social Conditions and Trends']
abstract: The freedom to binge on all media anytime. See a problem ahead?
lead_paragraph: When Beyoncé released, without warning, 17 videos around midnight on Dec. 13, millions of fans rejoiced. As a more casual listener of Ms. Knowles, I balked at the onslaught of new material and watched a few videos before throwing in the towel.

headline: The Piano, More Than a Partner in These Dances
abstract: New York City Ballet’s 21st-century choreographers festival continued on Thursday with works by Liam Scarlett, Benjamin Millepied, Mauro Bigonzetti and Richard Tanner.
lead_paragraph: Ballet companies usually like to tuck contemporary work safely between some tutus, carefully sheltering their audiences’ delicate sensibilities. Not New York City Ballet. (Hooray.) Program 3 of the Festival of 21st-Century Choreographers on Thursday was fairly austere, notable for its impressive musical range, with several scores commissioned by City Ballet.

headline: Does ‘Sperm Donor’ Mean ‘Dad’?
keywords: ['ARTIFICIAL INSEMINATION', 'Families and Family Life', 'Law and Legislation', 'Parenting', 'Child Custody and Support', 'In Vitro Fertilization']
abstract: A very public feud with his ex-girlfriend has turned the actor Jason Patric into an unlikely standard-bearer for those seeking parental rights for sperm donors.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — He is a movie star who shot to fame on a motorcycle in “The Lost Boys.” She is a California massage therapist from a prominent East Coast family. Four years ago, with his sperm, her eggs and the wonder of in vitro fertilization, they produced a child.

abstract: Calling something “blessed” has become the go-to term for those who want to boast about an accomplishment while pretending to be humble, fish for a compliment, or purposely elicit envy.
lead_paragraph: Here are a few of the ways that God has touched my social network over the past few months:

headline: Subversive, but Colorfully So
abstract: The work of Eli Sudbrack will be on view in SoHo this week.
lead_paragraph: The phantasmagorical works created by the Brazilian-born installation artist Eli Sudbrack, who goes by the acronym AVAF (for Assume Vivid Astro Focus), are dense with connections: sexual, geographic, macroeconomic, social and political.

headline: A Divided Country
abstract: As the separatist movement in eastern Ukraine grows, the divisions within Ukrainian society become deeper as both sides prepare for a potential confrontation.
lead_paragraph: As the separatist movement in eastern Ukraine grows, the divisions within Ukrainian society become deeper as both sides prepare for a potential confrontation.

headline: Our Lonely Home in Nature
abstract: Mother Earth doesn’t actually care about you at all. So save yourselves.

headline: Michigan: Retirees Agree to Cuts
abstract: Leaders of a group of retired Detroit workers have agreed to accept pension cuts, officials said Friday.

The cuts were smaller than the city had initially proposed.

headline: The Brady Quadroons
abstract: “The House That Will Not Stand” at Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven serves as something of a lesson in the custom of plaçage, in which black, American Indian or Creole women were “placed” into marriages, of sorts, with white men.
lead_paragraph: Oh, look, it’s Masha, Olga and Irinia. The first time the three sisters in Marcus Gardley’s “The House That Will Not Stand” retire together to their upstairs Louisiana bedroom, those Russian sisters may come to mind. But Mr. Gardley has not written a Chekhov drama. Those who know “The House of Bernarda Alba” may think of Angustias, Martirio and Adela. And Mr. Gardley was indeed inspired by that Spanish drama, written by Federico García Lorca in 1936. But as the new work, having its world premiere at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven, unfolds, the young women may seem more like Marcia, Jan and Cindy.

headline: What’s On Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) WE’RE THE MILLERS (2013) A drug dealer (Jason Sudeikis) in trouble with his boss (Ed Helms) recruits a stripper (Jennifer Aniston) and a couple of street urchins (Will Poulter and Emma Roberts, above, with Mr. Sudeikis and Ms. Aniston) to impersonate an all-American family known as the Millers. Their mission: to transport a few tons of marijuana from Mexico to Denver in their camper. And in no time at all, they’re caring about one another more than they want to admit. “ ‘We’re the Millers,’ a loose, halfheartedly raunchy, occasionally hilarious new comedy, is about a lot of different things; it’s the usual grab bag of jokes about drugs and body parts,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “But what really drives the movie is its own search for something to make fun of, and for a comic style that can feel credibly naughty while remaining ultimately safe and affirmative.” Nick Offerman and Kathryn Hahn play the Fitzgeralds, R.V. enthusiasts with a teenage daughter who “are beyond square, which is to say that they are stranger, kinkier and more interestingly individual” than the Millers — and funnier as actors, too — Mr. Scott added. “A movie about the Fitzgeralds would have been more rewarding than ‘We’re the Millers,’ and also much riskier.”

But what is normal now in the garden? One week I’m sweating, the bees are buzzing, buds are breaking; the next, the birdbath is frozen and there’s snow on the ground.

Depending on what part of the brain suffered, strange things might happen. Parents couldn’t recognize their children. Normal people became pathological liars. Some people lost the ability to speak — but could sing just fine.

The world sometimes seems as if it is flying apart, with Mr. Obama unable to fix it. Through a combination of a few significant missteps, circumstances beyond his control, unreasonable expectations and his maddeningly bland demeanor, Mr. Obama has opened himself to criticism that he is not articulating a strong, overarching blueprint for the exercise of American power and has not been able to bend authoritarian leaders to his will.

headline: Standing with the Kidnapped Girls in Nigeria
abstract: The backdrop on my column about the kidnapped Nigerian school girls
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about the girls kidnapped from their school in northeastern NIgeria nearly three weeks ago. I wrote the column partly to apply more pressure on the Nigerian authorities, who seem uninterested in the case, to try to rescue these girls, and partly because I’m offended by the contrast between the global media focus on the missing MH370 flight and the uninterest in the even greater number of missing schoolgirls in Nigeria. It’s also important to note that what’s at stake isn’t just these girls: If they’re not recovered soon, then no parents are going to send girls or boys to school in the area again. And the area, where as it is only half of adults are literate, will slide into greater illiteracy, economic difficulty and backwardness. Education isn’t just about building schools, it’s also about ensuring security so that parents feel safe sending their children to school.

headline: Groggy Yankees Lean on Tanaka Until Their Offense Ends Its Slumber
abstract: Mark Teixeira’s two-run home run helped the Yankees starter Masahiro Tanaka extend his regular-season unbeaten streak to 40 games after a shaky start against the Rays.
lead_paragraph: When Masahiro Tanaka left Yankee Stadium in the second inning of Friday night’s game, he could not have known how important his job would be Saturday.

headline: A Barnlike Haven for Meat Lovers
abstract: The South Shore BBQ Company, an easygoing barbecue joint in Patchogue with a pit master who has won competitions, offers a menu that should please carnivores.
lead_paragraph: The South Shore BBQ Company looks just as it should: a casual place with wood-plank and brick walls, sturdy wooden chairs and bare wooden tables holding rolls of paper towels and squeeze bottles of assorted barbecue sauces. The barnlike spot, which opened in Patchogue in March, also resembles the sports bar it replaced. A big U-shape bar with 28 stools and 16 overhead TV screens dominates the restaurant.

headline: Joined Sides
abstract: Mary Lou Guizzo returns to join us.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — Hands up if you’ve ever had a RAMOS gin fizz. Neither have I. I’ve had a sloe gin fizz, which also fits, not that I’m bitter. I’m not sure I’d want to try a RAMOS gin fizz because the recipe calls for an egg white, which I typically eschew in my adult beverages for the slime factor. In my head, eggs belong on a plate, fizzes belong in a glass. And no, I’m not a nog drinker either.

headline: Call of Nature Becomes a Call to Arms in Hong Kong
keywords: ['Social Media', 'Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Customs, Etiquette and Manners']
abstract: As Hong Kong braces for demonstrations over voting rights, its relations with mainland China have been overshadowed by a more pedestrian issue: how to react when toddlers relieve themselves on the street.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — A mainland couple’s decision to let their child urinate in public last month set off a video-recorded tussle on a street here, igniting a social media uproar that became a proxy battle for a larger question: Is Hong Kong, a former British colony, now being colonized by mainland China, whose visitors increasingly flood the territory with their money and alien manners as Beijing seeks to impose its political control?

headline: Lebanese Comfort Food on a Budget
abstract: Owned by two electrical engineers, Kibberia Restaurant and Cafe in Westport offers food well-suited to snacks or a light lunch or dinner.
lead_paragraph: Kibberia Restaurant and Cafe opened in Westport in late August 2013. This modest Lebanese place, more of a cafe than a restaurant, fills a need for falafel, hummus, kibbe (the ground meat and bulgur wheat patty from which the cafe derives its name), kebabs and other Mediterranean and Middle Eastern favorites — all while keeping prices low enough to entice families on a budget.

headline: Coming From Humble Beginnings, a Favorite Defies the Odds
abstract: California Chrome, whose owners scraped together $10,000 to breed him, became the first California-bred horse to win the Kentucky Derby since 1962.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — There are few rules in racing, but one that is considered inviolable is never to turn down a suitcase full of cash. Steve Coburn and Perry Martin understood that, but two months ago, when one of the sport’s far wealthier owners offered them $6 million for 51 percent of the first horse they had bred, the offer just did not sit well.

headline: Embrace of Atheism Put an Indonesian in Prison
abstract: The case of Alexander Aan, who was imprisoned after posting commentaries online, is part of a rise in persecution connected to freedom of religion in Indonesia in recent years.
lead_paragraph: JAKARTA, Indonesia — Growing up in a conservative Muslim household in rural West Sumatra, Alexander Aan hid a dark secret beginning at age 9: He did not believe in God. His feelings only hardened as he got older and he faked his way through daily prayers, Islamic holidays and the fasting month of Ramadan.

headline: Dumplings to Sip From
abstract: At Shanghai Bun in Princeton Junction, dim sum means ordering from the regular menu rather than flagging down carts.
lead_paragraph: You’ve got to be looking for Shanghai Bun to find the place, set unobtrusively in the far corner of a modest strip mall in spitting distance of New Jersey Transit’s Princeton Junction station — unless you are in the market for bath fixtures, and stumble upon it. In that case, lucky you.

headline: Winter Survivor, Sunbathing
abstract: One of only a few adult butterfly species that survive the winter, the mourning cloak is also one of the earliest butterflies to be seen gracing the spring woods.
lead_paragraph: The dark maroon wings of the mourning cloak butterfly match the vast and subtle browns of the early spring woods. Velvety and saturated with color, the wings are bordered with a warm yellow band and dotted with a row of unexpected iridescent blue spots. This butterfly is both handsome and cryptic; while resting or feeding, it folds its wings to create a gray, ragged-edged silhouette — the perfect imitation of a dead leaf.

headline: In Azerbaijan, Carlsen Wins When It Counts
abstract: Magnus Carlsen took the title at the Shamkir 2014 tournament in a last-round victory over Fabiano Caruana, who had bested him earlier in the event.
lead_paragraph: In winning the Shamkir 2014 chess tournament in Azerbaijan, Magnus Carlsen was able to exact revenge in the last round against Fabiano Caruana, one of two players who defeated him earlier in the event.

headline: On Top at the Derby
abstract: At the Kentucky Derby, outrageous hats are as much of an attraction as the horses.
lead_paragraph: At the Kentucky Derby, outrageous hats are as much of an attraction as the horses.

headline: Gerald Guralnik, a ‘God Particle’ Pioneer, Dies at 77
abstract: Mr. Guralnik is one of six pioneering physicists who in the 1960s came up with a theory that would lead to the discovery of a subatomic particle.
lead_paragraph: Gerald Guralnik, one of six pioneering physicists who in the 1960s came up with a theory that nearly 50 years later would lead to the discovery of a subatomic particle that helped explain a perennial mystery about the universe — why it contains life and diversity — died on April 26 in Providence, R.I. He was 77.

headline: Rabbi Myer Kripke, Early Buffett Friend and Investor, Dies at 100
abstract: Mr. Kripke lived modestly in a $900-a-month apartment despite making more than $25 million through investments.
lead_paragraph: When they were younger men, Rabbi Myer Kripke and Warren E. Buffett belonged to the same Rotary Club and lived a few blocks from each other in the Happy Hollow neighborhood of Omaha. They played bridge together with their wives. The Buffetts would invite the Kripkes over for Thanksgiving.

headline: When Hitting ‘Find My iPhone’ Takes You to a Thief’s Doorstep
abstract: Using GPS tracking apps, more people are taking the law into their own hands to recover stolen smartphones, a trend that has law enforcement officials concerned.
lead_paragraph: WEST COVINA, Calif. — After a boozy Saturday night, Sarah Maguire awoke the next morning to find that her iPhone was gone. Her roommate’s phone was gone, too. Were they at the bar, she wondered, or in the cab?

headline: Video Notebook: Game 7 for Nets-Raptors
abstract: Alan Anderson talks about the expectations of the Nets playing the Raptors in Toronto for Game 7.
lead_paragraph: Alan Anderson talks about the expectations of the Nets playing the Raptors in Toronto for Game 7.

headline: At Berkshire Annual Meeting, Questions for Buffett About Coca-Cola and Deals
abstract: Warren E. Buffett answered roughly six hours’ worth of questions – including pointed queries about his opposition to a controversial executive pay plan at the Coca-Cola Company.
lead_paragraph: OMAHA – Every spring without fail, tens of thousands of investors flock to Berkshire Hathaway‘s annual meeting here, hoping to ask just one question of its famed chief executive, Warren E. Buffett.

headline: In Cases of Smuggled Cellphones, Few Prosecutions
abstract: A Texas Tribune investigation has found that few inmates or correctional officers face legal consequences for smuggling cellphones.
lead_paragraph: Armed with shovels, corrections officers at a prison in East Texas last summer unearthed a cache of hundreds of smuggled items, including 45 cellphones and 52 chargers. Nearly a year later, no arrests have been made in the elaborate trafficking attempt.

headline: Rangers, Stuck in 0-for-25 Drought on Power Play, Consider Lineup Changes
abstract: The Rangers’ lackluster power play in the playoffs may lead to a personnel change in Game 2 against the Penguins on Sunday night.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Although a productive power play is not mandatory for victory in the playoffs, it certainly helps. With that in mind, Rangers Coach Alain Vigneault said Saturday that he might change the personnel on the team’s lackluster power play despite a Game 1 win over the Penguins.

headline: Music Shift Fuels Effort to Preserve a Tradition
abstract: Dale Watson, the Austin singer, has been buying old venues to keep styles of music like honky-tonk, outlaw, rockabilly, and western swing alive as pop country grows popular.
lead_paragraph: One recent Sunday afternoon, Dale Watson, the Austin country singer and guitarist with a signature white pompadour, zipped along winding wooded roads near Dripping Springs in his 2012 Mini Cooper.

headline: For Legislators, Race Correlates to Party, Mostly
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'Elections, House of Representatives', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Most black and Hispanic legislators are Democrats, while white legislators are Republicans — a result of political maps drawn and demographic changes started more than a decade ago.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Dominant Stretch and Touch of Bravado Bring Mickelson Close to Ending Drought
abstract: Phil Mickelson will enter the final round of the Wells Fargo Championship in third, two strokes behind J. B. Holmes, after shooting a nine-under 63 on Saturday.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — Phil Mickelson and his caddie, Jim Mackay, have a telepathy that comes from having spent 22 years — nearly half their lives — working together. So Mackay assumed he and Mickelson were thinking 6-iron Saturday for a downwind, 216-yard tee shot on the par-3 13th during the third round of the Wells Fargo Championship at Quail Hollow Club.

headline: Some Time Away Helps the Old Teixeira Return
abstract: Back from a trip to the disabled list that began on April 5, Yankees first baseman Mark Teixeira has hit five home runs in eight games.
lead_paragraph: When Mark Teixeira squarely makes contact, his swing appears tight and compact, and it often sends the ball high and far. He looks like the old Teixeira and not like an old Teixeira.

headline: Easily Dismissed, Democrat Who Criticizes Obama Runs On
abstract: Kesha Rogers, who says that President Obama should be impeached and Wall Street bankrupted, remains a factor in the Democratic primary runoff for the United States Senate.
lead_paragraph: Addressing a group of veterans recently in El Paso, David Alameel spoke like a candidate with only one opponent: United States Senator John Cornyn, Republican of Texas. It was only after Mr. Alameel was asked about Kesha Rogers, his opponent in the May 27 Democratic primary runoff, that he spoke directly about her.

headline: Scenes From the Finish Line
abstract: The race favorite California Chrome won the 140th Kentucky Derby on Saturday. He is the fifth California-bred winner of horse racing’s most prestigious event.
lead_paragraph: The race favorite California Chrome won the 140th Kentucky Derby on Saturday. He is the fifth California-bred winner of horse racing’s most prestigious event.

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 3, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Hibbert Goes From Scoreless to Relentless, Helping Pacers Win Game 7
abstract: Roy Hibbert, held without a point for two games, was aggressive in scoring 13 points for Indiana, which beat eighth-seeded Atlanta, 92-80, to advance. The Thunder and the Clippers also won Game 7s.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Roy Hibbert wanted the ball early in Game 7. Hibbert camped out in the post, his arms in the air to signal to his teammates. Then he yelled at them for the ball, and they obliged.

headline: Coors Field Lifts the Rockies’ Already Potent Lineup
abstract: Entering Saturday night’s game against the Mets, the Rockies were a game out of first place in the National League West and led the major leagues in multiple offensive categories.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — Opposing pitchers have always dreaded, in some cases even feared, taking to the mound at 5,280 feet above sea level at Colorado’s Coors Field.

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: Please, Let’s Not Imagine the Worst
abstract: In a fairly disturbing scene, a drugged Helena is an unwilling participant in a marriage ceremony with Henrik.
lead_paragraph: For this week’s recap of “Orphan Black” on BBC America, let’s fast forward to the last part of the episode, where, in a fairly disturbing scene, a drugged Helena (Tatiana Maslany) is an unwilling participant in a marriage ceremony with Henrik (Peter Outerbridge), the leader of the Proletheans. After the two characters are joined in matrimony, Henrik carries Helena over the threshold to an unknown room, with the tone of the scene strongly suggesting she is about to be raped or violated in some way.

headline: Teenager Who Fell Asleep on Subway With Gun Visible Is Arrested, Police Say
abstract: Demarrius Jackson, 19, was sleeping on a Brooklyn-bound N train when a woman saw a weapon tucked into his waistband, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A teenager was arrested on Saturday morning after a woman saw him holding a handgun while asleep on a subway train in the Times Square station, the police said.

headline: Derby Winner Gives Co-Owner a Birthday Gift to Remember
abstract: Steve Coburn turned 61 on the day his horse California Chrome won the Kentucky Derby.
lead_paragraph: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — Steve Coburn’s co-workers held an early birthday party for him a week ago. There was pizza and a cake, which bore the words “Happy Birthday” as well as “California Chrome, 2014 Kentucky Derby.”

headline: League Is Set to Appoint a C.E.O. for the Clippers
abstract: The league’s deputy commissioner met with employees of the team Saturday to soothe tensions amid uncertainty about the future of the team’s leadership.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The N.B.A. announced Saturday that it would soon appoint a chief executive to oversee operations of the Los Angeles Clippers in an attempt to create stability in the wake of the Donald Sterling scandal.

abstract: The jockey Victor Espinoza rode the favorite to a convincing victory on Saturday in the 140th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.
lead_paragraph: The jockey Victor Espinoza rode the favorite to a convincing victory on Saturday in the 140th Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs.

headline: A Ninth-Inning Blast Trumps the Mets’ Powerful Night
abstract: Colorado pinch-hitter Charlie Culberson hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth to hand the Mets a loss on a night when they had season highs in hits and runs.
lead_paragraph: DENVER —  After two lifeless losses to open their four-game series against the Colorado Rockies, the Mets endured their most deflating defeat this weekend at Coors Field, watching a 6-0 lead turn into an 8-6 deficit and two late rallies go for naught as pinch-hitter Charlie Culberson hit a two-run homer in the bottom of the ninth to give the Rockies an 11-10 victory Saturday night.

abstract: The video was a flop — except that it doubled our revenue.

headline: Reasons for Hope While Applying to College
abstract: There are fewer spots for American students at many top colleges. But the market has expanded in other ways.
lead_paragraph: The bad news for students applying to selective colleges is that getting accepted to any one of them really is harder than it used to be. Many colleges have reduced the number of American teenagers they accept (in order to globalize their student bodies) at the same time that the American teenage population is growing, as I wrote last week.

headline: As Traffic Deaths Fall, Pedestrian Deaths Do Not
abstract: There has been a disturbing exception over the last decade to the sharp nationwide decline in motor-vehicle deaths.
lead_paragraph: The decline in vehicle-accident deaths in recent years has been nothing short of remarkable. But there is one disturbing exception to the trend: pedestrian deaths.

headline: Lackeys of Youth Soccer, That ‘Arrogant’ Sport
abstract: Outside the United States, soccer is a working-class sport. Our club charges $2,200 per child per year.
lead_paragraph: The edict from my daughter’s soccer team manager arrived Monday morning: A state cup match had been rescheduled for 2 p.m. Sunday in Vancouver, Wash., a two-and-a-half hour drive from our home in Seattle. Families were expected to travel and check into a hotel Saturday night. Players were required to appear at a breakfast and pregame strategy session with the coach at 9 a.m. on Sunday.

headline: Incumbent’s Party Loses Presidency in Panama
abstract: Vice President Juan Carlos Varela, who broke with the governing party in a rancorous falling-out, was declared the president-elect, capturing 39 percent of the vote.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Panamanians, enjoying one of the fastest-growing economies in the hemisphere but wary of corruption and growing executive power, rejected the governing party’s choice for president on Sunday — on a ticket with the president’s wife for vice president — and instead hewed to tradition by electing an opposition candidate.

headline: Clippers Regroup After Tough Series and Off-Court Maelstrom

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The buzzer had not sounded. There was still two seconds left, but the Golden State Warriors needed more than one basket, so Los Angeles Clippers Coach Doc Rivers finally let loose. He stood near midcourt and shook his fists. He waved his arms. He smiled.

headline: U.S. Urges Congo Leader Not to Run for Third Term
abstract: Amid speculation that President Joseph Kabila might have the Constitution amended so that he could run again, Secretary of State John Kerry asked him “to put the country on a continued path to democracy.”
lead_paragraph: KINSHASA, Democratic Republic of Congo — Secretary of State John Kerry on Sunday publicly urged the president of the Democratic Republic of Congo to respect his nation’s Constitution and not run for another term in 2016.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Discovery) EVEREST AVALANCHE TRAGEDY On April 18 an NBC News team waited at the base camp on Mount Everest as it prepared to produce “Everest Jump Live,” a special about the climber Joby Ogwyn’s attempt to make the first wing-suit flight off the 29,029-foot summit of the world’s tallest mountain. That morning an avalanche struck the Khumbu Icefall, killing 13 Sherpa guides and leaving three missing — the highest death toll in a single day in the mountain’s history. This documentary covers the weeks leading up to the tragedy and the subsequent rescue and recovery efforts through real-time film footage and witness accounts. Among those interviewed are Mr. Ogwyn, above; Garrett Madison, the expedition leader; and Todd Burleson, the president of Alpine Ascents International, which lost five guides. It also pays tribute to the Sherpas and their families; the network will make a contribution to the American Himalayan Foundation’s Sherpa Family Fund, from which all donations will flow to relatives of the deceased. In “Bear Grylls: Man vs. Everest,” leading in at 8, Mr. Grylls presents stories of the greatest Everest attempts, using archival footage and interviews with climbers and support crews. In “Bear Grylls: Everest After the Avalanche,” at 10:30, he draws on his own experience — scaling the peak in 1998 at the age of 23 —to explain the allure of the mountain, and the danger.

headline: Stranded for Hours in Hudson, Cruise Ship Docks at Manhattan Pier
abstract: The Norwegian Breakaway reported a problem with part of the steering and propulsion system around 7:45 a.m. Sunday and was helped ashore by a tugboat about 10 a.m., the Coast Guard said.
lead_paragraph: A cruise ship that was stranded in the Hudson River for several hours made it to shore on Sunday morning, docking at Pier 88 on the West Side of Manhattan, officials said.

headline: Young Blood May Hold Key to Reversing Aging
abstract: After scientists found that blood from young mice rejuvenated the muscles and brains of old mice, experts said the research could lead to treatments for illnesses like Alzheimer’s disease.
lead_paragraph: Two teams of scientists published studies on Sunday showing that blood from young mice reverses aging in old mice, rejuvenating their muscles and brains. As ghoulish as the research may sound, experts said that it could lead to treatments for disorders like Alzheimer’s disease and heart disease.

headline: No Charges as Leader of Sinn Fein Is Released
abstract: Gerry Adams was freed after four days of questioning into the 1972 murder of a widow, but the police said they would hand over potential evidence against him to British prosecutors.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gerry Adams, the leader of the Irish political party Sinn Fein, was released from police custody without charges on Sunday after four days of questioning into a gruesome 1972 Irish Republican Army murder of a widow with 10 children. But the police will hand over a file of potential evidence against him to prosecutors, police officials said.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Gov. Rick Perry of Texas on Sunday sent some of his clearest signals of interest in a 2016 presidential bid, joking wryly about his “botched” run in 2012 but then adding that “I think America is a place that believes in second chances.”

headline: Can You Hear Me Now? Turn That Thing Off!
abstract: The magnificent concert that the Philadelphia Orchestra gave on Friday night at Carnegie Hall was spoiled by an unwelcome sound.
lead_paragraph: Despite continuing efforts to ward off the problem, the intrusive ringing of cellphones at concerts has become almost commonplace. Institutions do what they can to remind audiences to turn the things off. I am usually reluctant to mention a cellphone incident, since I don’t want to suggest that a passing disturbance can ruin the overall experience of a great performance.

headline: Insanely Pursuing Love, Be It Opera or Reality Show
abstract: The farce and mayhem of Haydn’s “Orlando Paladino” unfold in a modern setting in a production by the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater.
lead_paragraph: To a listener familiar with Haydn’s opera “Orlando Paladino” only from recordings — a 1977 Philips release conducted by Antal Dorati and a 2006 Deutsche Harmonia Mundi release led by Nikolaus Harnoncourt — it has never been clear exactly how well the opera could be made to work onstage. A new production by the Manhattan School of Music Opera Theater, which opened on Wednesday evening in the school’s John C. Borden Auditorium, does little to provide answers.

abstract: Eight of the performers fell during a Ringling Brothers “hair hang act” and landed on a dancer below during a show in Providence, officials said.
lead_paragraph: As thousands of parents and children watched, eight women dangling high above a ring at a Ringling Brothers and Barnum & Bailey circus performance in Providence, R.I., on Sunday crashed some 30 feet to the ground when the harness from which they were hanging suddenly collapsed.

headline: They’re Really Into Dylan, Maybe a Little Too Much
abstract: “The Dylanologists” is David Kinney’s look at archivists and others who have been obsessed with Bob Dylan.
lead_paragraph: Bob Dylan said it best, in a 2012 Rolling Stone interview timed to the release of his “Tempest ” album: “Why is it when people talk about me, they have to go crazy?” More than 50 years after he first started attracting fanatical followers, Mr. Dylan was facing down a more brutal and dangerous species of devotee than he had seen before. The fans had social media, and the scholars had computers; en masse, they could track every move he made and every word he wrote, said or sang. “Dylanologist,” once a derisive term for the self-styled expert who sifted through the Dylan family’s garbage cans, was now a word with wide colloquial meaning, if not yet a dictionary definition.

headline: What’s the Deal With This Puzzle?
abstract: What’s the deal with today’s puzzle by Lynn Lempel?
lead_paragraph: MONDAY’S PUZZLE — I have a long-standing theory that for all experiences in life, there is an equivalent “Seinfeld Moment.” Anything you might go through has probably been covered at least once in the sitcom “Seinfeld.” The only exception I can think of is solving a puzzle about NOTHING that is clued to the sitcom itself. That’s way too meta even for the television show.

headline: What Do Guns Say?
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests and Riots', 'First Amendment (US Constitution)', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Gun Control', 'Second Amendment (US Constitution)']
abstract: The guns brandished by Cliven Bundy’s supporters at the standoff in Bunkerville, Nev., blurred the line between expressing ideas and making threats.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this month, in Bunkerville, Nev., representatives of the Bureau of Land Management withdrew from a tense standoff with supporters of Cliven Bundy, a rancher who owes the federal government over $1 million in unpaid fees for allowing his cattle to graze on public land. The hundreds of self-appointed militia and “states’ rights” activists who flocked to support Bundy, many in full tactical gear and openly carrying assault rifles, blockaded a federal interstate and trained their weapons on B.L.M. employees who sought to negotiate with the rancher and his family. Fearful of a pitched gun battle, the B.L.M. departed, leaving Bundy and his supporters to celebrate, emboldened, with a barbecue.
