headline: Manning or Leaf? A Lesson in Intangibles
abstract: The wildly divergent paths of the top two picks in the 1998 N.F.L. draft have become shorthand for the frustrating process of identifying character traits that lead to success.
lead_paragraph: Say the name Bobby Thomson and before long someone is sure to bring up his 1951 partner in baseball history, Ralph Branca. Ever since the 1986 World Series, Mookie Wilson and Bill Buckner have gone together like a hot dog and a beer (or perhaps more like oil and water, if you’re a still-mournful Boston Red Sox fan). Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa are forever joined in grace by their 1998 pursuit of a home-run record, and in disgrace by their reliance on performance-enhancing drugs. And what figure-skating fan can hear about Nancy Kerrigan without thinking of Tonya Harding, the two being linked by a bizarre episode of attempted kneecapping in 1994?

headline: Let Slip the Dolphins of War
keywords: ['Dolphins and Porpoises', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Since cetaceans are so smart, we should ask if they want to serve.
lead_paragraph: SOUTHAMPTON, England — Fifty years ago, at the New York World’s Fair in 1964, the science-fiction writer Arthur C. Clarke spoke of things to come. He foresaw a 21st century that would witness “the development of intelligent and useful servants among the other animals on this planet, particularly the great apes and, in the oceans, the dolphins and whales.” Clarke saw this as a way of solving “the servant problem,” although he also imagined that the animals would form labor unions, “and we’d be right back where we started.”

headline: We Need Al Capone Drug Laws
abstract: Criminal sentences should be determined by the defendant’s role in the operation rather than the weight of the narcotics.
lead_paragraph: EDINA, Minn. — AFTER a ruinous 30-year experiment in harsh sentences for narcotics trafficking resulting in mass incarceration, policy makers are having second thoughts. Many states, including Texas, have reformed their laws to shorten sentences. Congress is giving serious consideration to the Smarter Sentencing Act, which would do the same. The United States Sentencing Commission has just adopted a proposal to revise federal guidelines.

headline: Finally, Some Optimism About Obesity
abstract: We moved much more slowly to confront the dangers of smoking.
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this year, we got what seemed like the first good news on obesity rates: A study in JAMA found that there had been a 43 percent drop in the obesity rates of 2- to 5-year-old children in the last decade. But then, last month, that news was contradicted by researchers at the University of North Carolina who used the same data to find that obesity rates had remained flat after all.

Oliver Koppell has spent four decades in politics, serving in the State Assembly, on the New York City Council and as attorney general for a brief stint at the tail end of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo’s final term. Through it all, he has been a Democrat — and a liberal one at that — with Republicans as his usual adversaries.

headline: Hearing Help in Theaters
abstract: Three theater organizations have agreed to provide listening devices, like headsets or hearing loops, to audience members with hearing loss.
lead_paragraph: Attorney General Eric T. Schneiderman of New York announced on Sunday that three theater organizations — the Manhattan Theater Club, the Atlantic Theater Company and the School of Visual Arts Theater — have agreed to provide listening devices, like headsets or hearing loops, to audience members with hearing loss. As part of the Americans With Disabilities Act, theater companies that use microphones or have amplified sound during performances are to grant equal access to those who are hard of hearing, but the attorney general’s office received complaints from individuals and disability rights organizations that some Off Broadway theaters were not following those guidelines. An investigation by attorney general’s Civil Rights Bureau found that the three theater companies were not providing listening devices, and the bureau is working with other theaters to ensure their compliance with the law.

headline: No Regrets for the Founder of Tumblr After Yahoo Sale
abstract: While conceding he was “terrified” going into the deal, David Karp says he is happy with the autonomy the microblogging service has under its new owner.
lead_paragraph: When Yahoo bought Tumblr for $1.1 billion a year ago, it sent a ripple of excitement — and anxiety — through the tech industry. headline: Now Screening | Catching Up With the Original Punk Rock Girl of Film
abstract: The Brooklyn Academy of Music is offering a monthlong program celebrating the cinema of rock ‘n’ roll’s greatest female rebels. Here, T checks in with the long-off-the-radar Linda Manz, the feisty star of Dennis Hopper’s 1980 classic “Out of the Blue.”
lead_paragraph: Starting May 7 at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, a series called “Punk Rock Girls” will showcase the women of the movement in all their pierced, ripped, hairsprayed glory. “The theme is so resonant,” says the programmer Nellie Killian, who conceived the monthlong event as a valentine to the era. “Especially for female viewers, it’s so important to have these types of girl characters, and we wanted to put in the lineage of movies of girls carving out a space for themselves within alternative culture.” Highlights will include a rubber-braceleted, Danceteria-era Madonna brazenly appropriating the Port Authority hand dryers (“Desperately Seeking Susan”); Diane Lane and friends, in slashes of scarlet eye shadow and skunk-striped hair, stepping up to the mike (“Ladies and Gentlemen, the Fabulous Stains”); and Robin Johnson and Trini Alvarado hurling TV sets off Manhattan rooftops (“Times Square”).

headline: Document | About a Boy
abstract: A nightmare for most parents, the photographer Dean Kaufman actually loves when his son gets lost in a museum.
lead_paragraph: For nearly two years, the Brooklyn-based photographer Dean Kaufman has relished the simple pleasure of watching his son lose himself in a work of art. He began this series when Leo was 4 and started toting a small notebook on family trips to New York art museums. Leo would plunk down near whatever caught his eye and begin to sketch, while his father stealthily captured the moment. Kaufman says the activity — whether sprawling out in front of a Jasper Johns painting at the Whitney Museum of American Art (middle left), or carefully copying Chris Burden’s tower of concrete bags at the New Museum (bottom center) — has nurtured Leo’s love for drawing. Still, he hesitates to interpret the 5-year-old’s curiosity as a sign of future art stardom. “He’s got a limited attention span,” Kaufman says. “He does the drawing and then he says, ‘Let’s go have lunch.'”

The guitar, which bears Mr. Wylde’s distinctive bull’s-eye design, and which Mr. Wylde valued at $10,000 at the time of the theft, was recovered on Friday after a pawn shop owner began to suspect that the instrument was probably worth more than the $50 he paid for it.

lead_paragraph: IF I may take a somewhat long way around the barn to make a point, a horse fell on me last year.

headline: Hollywood Charities Boycott Hotel to Protest Brunei’s Adoption of Shariah
abstract: The Beverly Hills Hotel is owned by an investment fund controlled by the sultan of Brunei.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The response here to the planned imposition of Islamic law in Brunei, with extreme penalties for adultery and gay sex, has become more pointed in recent days as two Hollywood-related charities moved events from the Beverly Hills Hotel, which is owned by the Brunei Investment Agency.

headline: Learning to Laugh Through the Pain
abstract: Mr. Rooney, a health and fitness expert who frequently travels as a motivational speaker and trainer, says language barriers are rarely an issue among athletes.
lead_paragraph: I’VE been traveling for business for about 15 years. I’ve always been involved in sports training. I have degrees in physical therapy and exercise science, and have worked with many professional athletes, like football players or mixed martial artists. I was even a member of the United States bobsled team. When I developed my strength and conditioning program, called Training for Warriors, my travel schedule became insane. I’ve been to 25 countries so far doing motivational speaking, training or some combination of both.

headline: Michelle Obama Joins in a Salute to Anna Wintour
abstract: The first lady attended a dedication ceremony at the Metropolitan Museum of Art for the newly renamed Anna Wintour Costume Center. “Two first ladies in one room at the same time,” Marc Jacobs observed.
lead_paragraph: On Monday morning, from the Temple of Dendur at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, the Vogue editor Anna Wintour proved yet again that she can get the entire fashion world to show up.

headline: Ralph Rucci’s Continuing Homage to Charles James
abstract: The designer, who penned the introduction to the Met’s catalog for James, says he and the late couturier were cut from the same cloth.
lead_paragraph: Charles James was one of American fashion’s first couturiers, as well as one of its most influential designers and most notorious perfectionists. His contemporaries, such as Christian Dior and Mainbocher, venerated him; Balenciaga famously called him the world’s best and only dressmaker, and both Elsa Schiaparelli and Coco Chanel wore his designs. Tonight, The Costume Institute of The Metropolitan Museum of Art will pay tribute to the late master’s 30-year career with the gala for “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” which opens to the public May 8. Nearly 75 of the 200 designs ever completed by James will be on display at the newly christened Anna Wintour Costume Center and first-floor Special Exhibition Galleries. And to accompany this retrospective, an eponymous book has been written by its curators Harold Koda and Jan Glier Reeder, cataloguing the work on view.

headline: Financial Data Company Markit Files for I.P.O.
abstract: Markit, a challenger to Bloomberg L.P. and Thomson Reuters, is backed by some of Wall Street’s biggest names.
lead_paragraph: Markit, a financial data company, has been a behind-the-scenes player on Wall Street since its founding roughly a decade ago. Now, it is preparing to make its public market debut.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 2-4, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last Monday, 14-year-old Endia Martin was shot and killed in the Back of the Yards neighborhood of Chicago. She and a former friend, a 14-year-old honor-roll student, were in a dispute over a boy, and what started as a Facebook fight erupted into a brawl. The confrontation drew 20 people, some of whom were armed with pipes and bottles.

headline: Ackman Urges Allergan Board to Begin Deal Talks With Valeant
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: The hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman sent a letter to the board of the Botox manufacturer Allergan on Monday, urging the company to begin talks to sell itself to Valeant.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after unveiling an audacious partnership with Valeant Pharmaceuticals to take over Allergan, the maker of Botox, the hedge fund billionaire William A. Ackman is getting to work.

headline: Red in the Face
abstract: People who turn red after drinking alcohol most likely have an enzyme deficiency that prevents the full metabolism of alcohol.
lead_paragraph: Q. After I have had a glass of wine, my face heats up and turns bright red. This also happens to my siblings. What is going on?

headline: Crocodile Tears Hit the Spot for Butterfly and Bee
abstract: Tear-drinking in the wild may be common, but isn’t seen often, says an aquatic ecologist in Costa Rica who witnessed just that.
lead_paragraph: A butterfly and a bee were seen, above, sipping the tears of a spectacled caiman (Caiman crocodilus) along the Río Puerto Viejo in northeastern Costa Rica. The insects were probably seeking protein and salt. Tear drinking in the wild may be common but not often seen, said Carlos de la Rosa, an aquatic ecologist at La Selva Biological Station in Costa Rica who witnessed the event.

headline: Helping Small Companies Go Big in China
abstract: Expanding into China can be daunting, but without a sales strategy that includes Asia, companies risk missing many opportunities.
lead_paragraph: When I encounter other American companies that do business in China, I am often surprised by the relatively small size of their operations in the United States. Many had less than $500,000 in annual sales when they decided to open operations in China.

headline: A 9,000-Year-Old Hunting Cabin, Underwater
abstract: In Lake Huron, 120 feet down, researchers discovered a stone structure used to capture caribou. Charcoal was found nearby, so cooking may have been involved.
lead_paragraph: A 9,000-year-old stone structure used to capture caribou has been discovered 120 feet beneath the surface of Lake Huron. Researchers say it is the most complex structure of its kind in the Great Lakes region.

headline: Dialogue: Nate Lowman and Devon Welsh
abstract: The artist Nate Lowman discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh of Majical Cloudz in Lowman’s TriBeCa studio.
lead_paragraph: The artist Nate Lowman discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh of Majical Cloudz in Lowman’s TriBeCa studio.

headline: Woman Found Guilty of Assaulting Officer at an Occupy Wall Street Protest
abstract: A jury decided that Cecily McMillan, a volunteer labor organizer, intentionally elbowed Officer Grantley Bovell in the eye at a demonstration in 2012.
lead_paragraph: A trial that had become a rallying point for many Occupy Wall Street activists ended on Monday with a jury finding a protester guilty of assaulting a police officer at Zuccotti Park in Manhattan in 2012.

headline: Less Air in Latest Internet Bubble
abstract: For all the hype, the current mania for Internet stocks pales in comparison to the late 1990s, writes Robert Cyran of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: The latest Internet bubble is a mere shadow of the excesses that came crashing to an end in 2000. Sure, even though the run-up may have paused, the feverish signs are unmistakable. Dozens of companies are in line to go public, hubris is rampant, oddball valuation metrics abound, and revenue-free start-ups are still worth fortunes. Even nerd culture has somehow become hip. The latest boom is as absurd as the last, but it’s far smaller.

headline: Film Festival Moves to New York With ‘Think Like a Man’ Sequel and Spike Lee Film
abstract: The American Black Film Festival is moving from the Miami area for its 18th edition.
lead_paragraph: The 18th edition of the American Black Film Festival will make its New York debut next month with films directed by Tim Story and Spike Lee bookending the June 19-22 event, organizers announced Monday.

headline: After a Heart Attack, Eat Your Fiber
abstract: It is never too late to increase your intake of dietary fiber, a new study suggests.
lead_paragraph: It is never too late to increase your consumption of dietary fiber, a new study suggests.

headline: Nate Lowman and Majical Cloudz’s Devon Welsh Talk Creativity and Music
abstract: The new high-end headphone brand Master & Dynamic introduces a video series pairing artistic talents together, the first episode of which makes it debut here.
lead_paragraph: To commemorate its launch tomorrow, the new high-end headphone brand Master & Dynamic commissioned a series of videos that pair two artists from different disciplines together to discuss the influence of sound on their work. The first, making its debut here, offers a firsthand look inside the artist Nate Lowman’s TriBeCa studio, where he discusses the creative process with the musician Devon Welsh, frontman of the indie duo Majical Cloudz.

headline: A New Women’s Issue: Statins
abstract: An increasingly vocal group of cardiologists argue that many women are taking the cholesterol-lowering medications unnecessarily.
lead_paragraph: Should so many women be taking statins?

headline: Deutsche Bank Hires Consumer M.&A. Adviser
abstract: Jeff Rose, a managing director in the mergers group focused on consumer and retail at Bank of America Merrill Lynch, will join Deutsche Bank as head of its consumer and retail investment banking coverage in the Americas.
lead_paragraph: Deutsche Bank announced Monday that it had hired Jeff Rose as a managing director of its global consumer and retail mergers and acquisitions group, and the new head of its consumer and retail investment banking coverage in the Americas.

headline: Taking Aim at 12-Step Programs
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Addiction (Psychology)', 'Alcohol Abuse', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: A polemical book about addiction favors psychodynamic therapy over Alcoholics Anonymous and similar 12-step programs.
lead_paragraph: Did you know that the most widely accepted treatments for alcohol and drug addiction — Alcoholics Anonymous and similar 12-step programs — rest on the flimsiest of scientific evidence? I didn’t.

headline: One Million
abstract: An average glass, left to sit quietly (no sipping!) will produce a million bubbles in four hours, a physicist estimates.
lead_paragraph: Champagne and other sparkling wines owe much of their appeal to their bubbles. They don’t just set the mouth tingling; bursting bubbles at the surface also help propel the aromas toward the nose.

headline: More Blight for the Palisades?
abstract: Officials in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., are considering a master zoning plan that would allow even more high-rise developments of up to 150 feet in the area near the LG headquarters.
lead_paragraph: LG Electronics USA has been facing a growing outcry about the company’s plan to build a 143-foot tall headquarters along the Palisades Park in New Jersey. That tower, which will stretch far above the tree line, will permanently deface the view along a once-protected stretch of the Hudson River. Politicians, environmentalists, architectural critics, outraged citizens and even potential LG customers have appealed to the company to lower this tower to the traditional limit of 35 feet.

headline: Boko Haram Leader Releases Video
abstract: The leader of Nigeria’s terrorist group Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau, said his group was fighting to reinstate a medieval Islamic caliphate in northern Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: The leader of Nigeria’s terrorist group Boko Haram, Abubakar Shekau, said his group was fighting to reinstate a medieval Islamic caliphate in northern Nigeria.

headline: Box Office Bump for Top Tony Nominees

lead_paragraph: Last week was one of the best yet for the Broadway musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder,” with sharp increases in both weekly box office grosses and advance ticket sales following its 10 Tony Awards nominations, the most of any Broadway show.

headline: A Central Banker of a Different Color
abstract: Forget California Chrome. For the serious name bettor, it’s hard to go wrong with Central Banker or Carried Interest. What, no Proxy Battle?
lead_paragraph: On Saturday afternoon in Louisville, Ky., a central banker was under scrutiny. Investors with deep pockets were watching his every move, weighing odds on how he would perform under pressure.

abstract: When his photo career stalled, Robert Larson took a nightclub job – where he discovered new faces and scenes in the blur of action between the kitchen and the club.
lead_paragraph: When his photo career stalled, Robert Larson took a nightclub job – where he discovered new faces and scenes in the blur of action between the kitchen and the club.

abstract: If we know sauvignon blanc, it’s easy to assume we know Sancerre, which is made from the sauvignon blanc grape. Yet a grape is only part of the story.
lead_paragraph: Updated | June 2, 2014

headline: Apple-Samsung Jury Sticks With Original Total for Damages
abstract: The federal jury in the latest patent trial involving Apple and Samsung returned to court on Monday to recalculate some of the damages Samsung owed to Apple.
lead_paragraph: The federal jury in the latest patent trial involving Apple and Samsung returned to court on Monday to recalculate some of the damages Samsung owed to Apple. After making the changes, the jury came to the same overall figure: $119.6 million.

headline: Outside Spending Enters Arena of Judicial Races
keywords: ['Elections, Courts and the Judiciary', 'Political Advertising', 'Campaign Finance', 'Political Action Committees', 'Supreme Courts (State)']
abstract: A costly and fierce primary shows how the revolution in financing political campaigns has entered what was the quieter arena of judicial elections.
lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The ad first appeared on television the Friday before last, a black-and-white spot charging that Justice Robin Hudson coddled child molesters and “sided with the predators” in a North Carolina Supreme Court dissent. It has run constantly since.

headline: In Store | Bonpoint Arrives in SoHo With a Capsule and a Collaboration
abstract: The chic children’s wear retailer toasts its new New York flagship with a limited-edition collection — and an Aurélie Bidermann-designed bracelet that both kids and adults can wear.
lead_paragraph: Bonpoint, the Paris-based purveyor of chic children’s wear, will debut a new flagship store in New York’s SoHo tomorrow. In celebration of the opening, the brand’s creative director Christine Innamorato has designed a special “SoHo 2014″ capsule collection, which includes Liberty-print dresses — the designs for 12 of which were sourced from the Bonpoint archive — and bags, brooches, swimsuits, as well as soaps and candles that come packaged inside Liberty-print bags. And as an added incentive for the parents of chic tykes, Innamorato teamed up with the jewelry designer Aurélie Bidermann to create a limited-edition 18-karat gold and lacquer bracelet, featuring Bonpoint’s signature cherry logo, that adjusts to fit both children and adults. A portion of the profits from sales of the bracelet and capsule items will be donated to New Yorkers for Children.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Afghanistan and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Afghanistan, South Africa, Ukraine and Romania.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Afghanistan, South Africa, Ukraine and Romania.

headline: A Goal to Combat Malaria With the Help of a Robot
abstract: An American company is starting a crowdfunding campaign to help it build a robot able to dissect mosquitoes to remove the key ingredient of its malaria vaccine.
lead_paragraph: In its effort to develop a unique malaria vaccine, the American company Sanaria wants to build a robot that will do what now requires a line of trained humans with microscopes: dissecting half-frozen mosquitoes with tiny needles to extract their salivary glands.

headline: King Cotton and His Bloody Surrogates
abstract: “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts and Context in the Civil War,” at the New-York Historical Society, makes clear that textiles were at the heart of the conflict.
lead_paragraph: At first glance, this exhibition might seem a bit quaint, its subject — textiles and the Civil War — evoking Americana more than American history. But this show, “Homefront & Battlefield: Quilts and Context in the Civil War,” which opened last month at the New-York Historical Society after originating at the American Textile History Museum in Lowell, Mass., does much more: It turns Americana back into history.

headline: Pan-Latin Rhythms, Percussive to Sultry
abstract: Carlos Santana’s new album, “Corazón,” hosts mostly Pan-American all-stars and Latin-rooted Americans, mainly singing in Spanish.
lead_paragraph: Throughout its 45-year recording career, Santana — led by the great Mexican-American guitarist Carlos Santana — has been synonymous with Latin rock. Yet “Corazón” is the first Santana album with nearly all of its lyrics in Spanish. Gathering much of the album’s material from outside the United States, Mr. Santana now embraces the Pan-American rock and pop that he heralded.

headline: Denny Hamlin Wins at Talladega; Marc Marquez Takes Fourth Race in a Row
abstract: It was Hamlin’s first victory at the Alabama track, coming in the 300th race of his career in the series.
lead_paragraph: Denny Hamlin passed Kevin Harvick for the lead on the penultimate lap and then received the checkered flag when a multicar wreck on the final lap froze the finishing order in the Nascar Sprint Cup race Sunday at Talladega Superspeedway in Alabama.

headline: Lonely-Hearts and Action Tales
abstract: “Swing & Beowulf,” paired one-acts at the Irish Arts Center, both come from the Dublin Fringe Festival, but that’s all they have in common.
lead_paragraph: “Swing & Beowulf,” paired one-acts at the Irish Arts Center, both come from the Dublin Fringe Festival, but that’s all they have in common. “Swing,” a portrait of lovelorn Dubliners in a dance class, is rooted in Ireland’s recessionary present. “Beowulf: The Blockbuster,” a phantasmagorical conversation between a father and son, jumps through space and time. O.K., the plays share one more thing: They are both very worth the trip.

headline: Met Opera Contract Talks Stumble to a Start
abstract: A Metropolitan Opera union and management almost did not begin their contract talks on Monday after labor invited reporters to attend.
lead_paragraph: After an unusually stormy overture, the curtain went up Monday on the first round of contract talks between the Metropolitan Opera and the American Guild of Musical Artists, the union representing its chorus, dancers, singers and stage managers.

headline: Mississippi Chefs to Protest State Law on the Eve of Annual Picnic
abstract: A group of chefs upset over the Mississippi Religious Freedom Restoration Act plan a protest dinner in New York.
lead_paragraph: Every June for 35 years, hundreds of New Yorkers and displaced Mississippians have gathered in Central Park to eat catfish, listen to the blues and praise the virtues of that Southern state.

headline: When Playwrights’ Fancies Turn
abstract: “The Spring Fling: First Love” is a collection of plays by writers with impressive credentials.
lead_paragraph: Attention struggling playwrights: Should you need inspiration, avoid Shakespeare, Molière and the like. Their skills could frustrate you. Instead, see “The Spring Fling: First Love,” six short plays so tedious that they may actually serve a purpose: You’ll find yourself thinking, “If that can get staged, my work must have a chance.”

headline: Still Counting Gulf Spill’s Dead Birds
abstract: New studies suggest that geographical circumstances may have hidden the extent of the bird kill caused by the BP oil spill in the Gulf of Mexico, though the effort also illustrates the imprecise science involved in quantifying the toll.
lead_paragraph: After the Deepwater Horizon oil rig blew out in the Gulf of Mexico some 50 miles from the nearest land, responders were left to cope with a search area of nearly 40,000 square miles, as well as wind and currents that kept evidence of damage away from the more easily searchable coastline.

headline: An Artist’s New York Moment
abstract: Christian Rizzo, a well-regarded figure on the European cultural scene whose works have been sparsely seen in the United States, has two pieces in the Danse festival.
lead_paragraph: Most choreographers have had a long, thankless slog on the way to professional status. (Never mind success.) First come many years of training to be a dancer, then more years performing for others, trying to find time and money to create work, and get it onstage.

headline: Confronting the Inevitable, Graphically
abstract: Using cartoons, texts and photographs in “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?,” Roz Chast writes about her parents and dealing with their decline.
lead_paragraph: Roz Chast feels — and draws — our pain. Our neurotic worries and genuine fears, our mundane and existential anxieties, our daydreams, nightmares, insecurities and guilty regrets. Or, rather, she does such a funny, fluent job in her New Yorker cartoons of conveying the things that keep her up at night that many readers are convinced that she is somehow mapping their own inner lives.

headline: The Animals of Chernobyl
abstract: Biologist Timothy Mousseau has been studying the lasting effects of radiation on the flora and fauna of Chernobyl, Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: Biologist Timothy Mousseau has been studying the lasting effects of radiation on the flora and fauna of Chernobyl, Ukraine.

headline: At Chernobyl, Hints of Nature’s Adaptation
abstract: A study of the Chernobyl fallout area has found that some bird species have adapted to the radioactive environment by producing more protective antioxidants, with correspondingly less genetic damage.
lead_paragraph: NOVOSHEPELYCHI, Ukraine — The clicking sound from Timothy Mousseau’s radiation detector slowly increased as he walked through the forest here, a few miles west of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.

headline: New Election Model Machinery: A Look Under the Hood
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Elections, Senate', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: A forecasting model at The Washington Post gives the G.O.P. a far better chance of retaking the Senate than our model does. What accounts for the difference?
lead_paragraph: John Sides, Ben Highton and Eric McGhee of The Monkey Cage have started Election Lab, a Senate forecasting model at The Washington Post. Their model gives Republicans more than an 80 percent chance of retaking the Senate; that’s much more than the 54 percent chance that Leo, The Upshot’s Senate model, gives the G.O.P.

headline: A Composer Attuned to the Earth’s Swirling Motion
abstract: John Luther Adams talks about the genesis of “Become Ocean,” to be performed on Tuesday at Carnegie Hall, and other environmentally themed works.
lead_paragraph: John Luther Adams has never been inside the main auditorium of Carnegie Hall. It’s not a fact that distinguishes him greatly in his hometown, Fairbanks, Alaska, where he has lived for four decades. There Mr. Adams, now 61, was first known as an environmental activist who helped secure passage of the Alaska Lands Act in 1980, before dedicating himself full time to music and building a small but fervent following as a composer of hypnotically immersive musical landscapes. But when Mr. Adams attends his first concert in Carnegie Hall’s Stern Auditorium on Tuesday, he will be in the unusual position of doing so as a newly minted Pulitzer Prize laureate hearing his winning work, “Become Ocean,” played there for the first time.

headline: In Search of a Lost Wonder, Off the Rivers of Babylon
abstract: The Hanging Gardens of Babylon, as an episode of the PBS series “Secrets of the Dead” investigates, may have actually been in Nineveh, in modern-day Iraq.
lead_paragraph: This is the time of year when weekend gardeners peer into the neighbors’ yards for confirmation of their own superiority or inadequacy. But practically every gardener will feel unworthy upon viewing Tuesday’s episode of the PBS series “Secrets of the Dead.”

headline: Punched Out in Hard Times
abstract: “Cherry Smoke,” staged by the Working Theater company, describes the hard lives and limited options facing a boxer and his girlfriend in western Pennsylvania.
lead_paragraph: In James McManus’s overwrought “Cherry Smoke,” Fish (Vayu O’Donnell) is an amateur boxer with what his brother, Duffy (Patrick Carroll), describes as a “serious lunatic streak.” On a set — sandbags, red stucco, ruined tires — resembling an apocalyptic desert but meant to suggest western Pennsylvania, Fish cycles from back-alley bouts to prison stints to riverside encounters with his guileless girlfriend Cherry (Molly Carden). An exploited child-woman, she is prone to statements like, “There useta be a bluebird in my heart, but it flew away.” She also describes a form of birth control so violent it provokes laughter.

headline: To Honor a Master, One Day Won’t Do
abstract: For four days, the Sarasota Ballet performed works by the British choreographer Frederick Ashton.
lead_paragraph: SARASOTA, Fla. — The Sarasota Ballet’s four-day festival honoring the superlative choreographer Frederick Ashton that ended on Saturday was a triumph of courage, enterprise, enthusiasm, artistic importance, stylish dancing, but, above all, choreographic felicity. Visiting Ashton dancers from the 1950s to the ’70s spoke with awe of how well this young Gulf Coast company reminded them of what they had loved years ago and had thought lost.

headline: Were Ayaan Hirsi Ali and Condoleezza Rice ‘Silenced’?
abstract: There’s a difference between not wanting controversial public figures to speak, and not wanting to honor them.
lead_paragraph: In 2009 a Catholic advocacy group said it was an “outrage” for Notre Dame to select President Barack Obama as its commencement speaker and give him an honorary degree, arguing that it was wrong for a Catholic university to honor a politician whose views on abortion contradicted those of the church.

headline: Critics’ Circle Names ‘Fun Home’ Best Musical
abstract: The New York Drama Critics’ Circle honored “Fun Home” as best musical and “The Night Alive” as best play.
lead_paragraph: The critically acclaimed “Fun Home” picked up another award for best musical of the New York theater season on Monday, this time from the New York Drama Critics’ Circle, an association of theater reviewers. “Fun Home,” the story of a lesbian cartoonist and her memories of childhood and her father, who committed suicide, also won the Lucille Lortel Award for outstanding Off Broadway musical on Sunday night. headline: From the Design Curator Murray Moss, a Book of Unexpected Juxtapositions
abstract: Murray Moss, the man behind the now-shuttered Manhattan design boutique Moss, has embarked on an unexpected side project in which he pairs vintage press photos that suggest bizarre new narratives.
lead_paragraph: For the veteran design entrepreneur Murray Moss, 2012 was a year of turning points. It saw the closing of his fabled SoHo boutique Moss, and it was also the year he was diagnosed with Parkinson’s. He soon discovered that his medication had a number of side effects. “They keep me up late at night,” he says, “and they increase my already compulsive nature.” He sought to turn these new traits to his advantage by combing through hundreds of vintage press photos in the wee hours, and combining them to create surprising, often funny visual conversations. “This is what I used to do, literally daily, for 18 years, with the objects I displayed at the store,” Moss says. “Now I exercise this obsession with juxtapositions I make with press photographs instead of objects. It’s like making a movie and filming multiple endings.” His efforts are showcased in his new book, “Tertium Quid” ($75), due out later this month in a limited print run.

headline: Inside Elena Arzak’s Kitchen
abstract: In an exclusive video interview, the chef discusses Basque cuisine and the importance of family.
lead_paragraph: Last week we introduced readers to Elena Arzak, one of only two women chefs named to the 2014 World’s 50 Best Restaurants list for her family’s restaurant, Arzak, which she runs with her father Juan Mari Arzak. Here, Elena invites T into her restaurant, perfectly located, she says in the above video, in the seaside town of San Sebastián. Step into her beautifully orchestrated kitchen as she discusses Basque cuisine, the creative and modern influence El Bulli had on her regional cooking and the importance of family — from her secret to working seamlessly with her chef father to the value of a balanced and lip-smacking staff meal. “The staff meal or family meal is really important,” she says. “It has to be very well made, very well cooked, no different from what goes out to the restaurant.”

headline: South Korea: Ferry Diver Dies
abstract: One of the civilian divers searching for victims of the South Korean ferry disaster died on Tuesday after losing consciousness underwater, officials said.
lead_paragraph: One of the civilian divers searching for victims of the South Korean ferry disaster died on Tuesday after losing consciousness underwater, officials said. The diver, identified as Lee Gwang-ok, 53, was employed by a salvage company that worked with Navy divers in the now three-week-old effort to recover bodies from the 6,825-ton ferry Sewol, which capsized and sank off southwestern South Korea on April 16. The divers have struggled against strong currents and poor visibility to reach the ship and then make their way through a dark maze of corridors and cabins clogged with debris. As of Tuesday, 39 people remained missing, with 263 confirmed dead.

headline: What’s On Tuesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Starz Cinema) ANIMAL KINGDOM (2010) A bleached-blond mama lion (Jacki Weaver, above, with Sullivan Stapleton) with piercing blue eyes and a glinting smile and her brood of armed robbers and drug dealers (Luke Ford, Mr. Stapleton and Ben Mendelsohn) take on rogue cops in Melbourne in this directorial and screenwriting debut from David Michôd. But then a police sergeant (Guy Pearce) on the right side of the law interrogates her grandson (James Frecheville), who has been thrown into the fray after his mother dies of a heroin overdose, and plants the seeds of distrust that force him to fight to save himself. “The film’s depiction of the raw fear lurking below the brothers’ braggadocio is the most pronounced emotion in a movie whose focus on the personalities of its criminals suggests an Australian answer to ‘Goodfellas,’ minus the wiseguy humor,” Stephen Holden wrote in The New York Times. “The relative absence of gun battles and car chases helps ‘Animal Kingdom’ build and sustain a mood of deepening dread. It goes out of its way to deglamorize the criminal life and portray its family of crooks as warped psychopathic thugs in a losing enterprise.”

headline: Radio Killed the Political Star
abstract: A generation of politicians is saying goodbye to the “celebrity political class.” And making a killing in the media instead.
lead_paragraph: Mike Rogers keeps telling me how fed up he is with all of the “brand identity politicians” he is serving alongside in the United States Congress. And by this, the Republican from Michigan means those colleagues who would rather raise their profiles and get into the media and “do that celebrity thing” than, say, pass bills or help constituents or win the respect of peers. “They are all about their brand,” Rogers laments, drawing out the word with an extra disdainful beat: “BRAAH-und.” This, of course, is one reason that Rogers has decided to cede his chairmanship of the House Intelligence Committee, and all the loudmouths in the People’s Chamber that come with it, for his very own talk-radio show. In March, he announced his decision to leave behind the “whole celebrity political class in Washington, D.C.” for what is expected to be a nationally syndicated gig with Cumulus Media.

lead_paragraph: This 1947 photograph (by Gordon Parks, for Ebony Magazine) may look simply like a child being observed at play, but, in fact, it reveals an experiment that helped lead 60 years ago this month to the Supreme Court’s monumental decision in Brown v. Board of Education, demanding the racial integration of American public schools.

headline: Even With Maturity, Paul’s Inner Defiance Flourishes
abstract: Los Angeles Clippers point guard Chris Paul is, in the estimation of many, the best point guard in the N.B.A., but, at heart, he is still looking for a seat at the grown-ups’ table.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Do not let the clever commercials with his alter ego fool you. And those bright, expressive eyes? They are not the windows to this soul.

headline: Capus, Once Head of NBC News, Moves to CBS Evening News
keywords: ['Television', 'News and News Media', 'Appointments and Executive Changes']

lead_paragraph: CBS News announced on Tuesday that Steve Capus, the former president of NBC News, would become the executive producer of its evening newscast, anchored by Scott Pelley.

headline: Plans for Barenboim-Said Academy in Berlin Unveiled
abstract: The institute, which will occupy a former warehouse space of the Staatsoper Unter den Linden, is an extension of the West-Eastern Divan Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The Barenboim-Said Academy unveiled the architectural model for its new headquarters at a news conference on Tuesday here and announced an official opening date of October 2016.

headline: A Merging of Movement Cultures and Subcultures
abstract: An exploration of the voguing tradition moves dance back from the barre and closer to the bar.
lead_paragraph: There is no chief curator, no unifying aesthetic and no central headquarters for Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas. This citywide undertaking, led by the Cultural Services of the French Embassy, is willfully, delightfully heterogeneous.

headline: Two Ensembles Step Into the Other’s Shoes
abstract: The ensembles Loadbang and Mivos performed work written by each other during the Cutting Edge Concerts festival.
lead_paragraph: It’s not unusual for ensembles to have a composer or two in their midst, although it’s certainly more uncommon for all members to be performers and composers. And it’s surely a first for a group to feature a trombone, trumpet, clarinet and baritone, the combination that makes up the ensemble Loadbang.

headline: Today in Small Business: Credit Cards for Small Businesses
abstract: Understanding why you are always so busy. Becoming a better negotiator. And introducing the “Zuckerberg tax.”
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Scent Messaging Wafts In
abstract: Users of oNotes will be able to deliver olfactory delights to be produced by a device, the oPhone, via text, tweet or email.
lead_paragraph: Tuesday begins the slow rollout of oNotes, a so-called “scent messaging platform” from which all sorts of olfactory miracles are supposed to unfurl, including a device, out in early 2015, that will deliver scent messages (via text, tweet or email) and play olfactory “tunes.” Don’t scoff: the oPhone is no overpriced Febreze dispenser. One of its inventors is David Edwards, a bio-engineer at Harvard and the founder of Le Laboratoire, a celebrated “collaboration” hub in Paris, who has been exploring the far edges of food and technology with products like edible packaging and inhalers that deliver shots of taste and aromas. He’s a bit of rock star, or to mix imagery, Willy Wonka with lots of venture capital.

headline: Sotomayor Finds Her Voice Among Justices
keywords: ['Race and Ethnicity', 'AFFIRMATIVE ACTION', 'Colleges and Universities', 'ADMISSIONS STANDARDS']
abstract: Justice Sonia Sotomayor has emerged as an increasingly confident figure on the Supreme Court, staking out positions that have led to testy exchanges with colleagues across the ideological spectrum.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “I am a lawyer’s judge,” Justice Sonia Sotomayor said last year. “I write very technically.”

headline: Why Are We Moving Again?
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Moving and Moving Industry', 'Parenting']
abstract: Our family is moving from Jerusalem to Rockland County, leaving almost everything and everyone familiar to our 6- and 2-year-olds behind. I am afraid for our family and our finances, and craving Doritos.
lead_paragraph: I added up the expenses for our move: the trans-Atlantic move itself, health insurance, house rental and car. I considered the amount, went to the kitchen and opened a bag of chips. My husband, Matt, came in. We usually work at night after we put our two children to bed and then meet in the kitchen for snacks.

headline: The American Scholar Crowdsources a Sonnet
abstract: The public is invited to complete a sonnet that begins like this: “How like a prison is my cubicle.”
lead_paragraph: Statisticians and late-night dorm-room bull session partisans have long debated whether a monkey banging away at a typewriter for an infinite amount of time would inevitably tap out the complete works of Shakespeare. But can a swarm of people on the Internet write a plausible sonnet in 14 weeks?

headline: Jessye Norman Talks About ‘Stand Up Straight and Sing!’
abstract: The opera singer discusses her new memoir.
lead_paragraph: “Stand Up Straight and Sing!,” the memoir by the soprano Jessye Norman that came out on Tuesday, takes readers from her close-knit girlhood community in Augusta, Ga., to Carnegie Hall and beyond. Ms. Norman talks about her childhood in a supportive but segregated world, singing for Rosa Parks, befriending Marian Anderson and “growing up” as an artist. Ms. Norman spoke about her book and her life during a recent interview at Carnegie Hall. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation:

headline: Morgan Stanley Fined $5 Million Over I.P.O. Work
keywords: ['Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority said Morgan Stanley did not follow proper procedures in the initial public offerings for 83 companies, including those of Facebook and Yelp.
lead_paragraph: The Financial Industry Regulatory Authority has fined Morgan Stanley $5 million, saying that the firm did not follow proper procedures in the initial public offerings for 83 companies including Facebook and Yelp.

headline: G.M. Recalls 56,000 Saturn Auras for Gearshift Cable Defect
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The automaker had resisted a recall, despite having recalled 426,000 other models for a similar problem.
lead_paragraph: After resisting federal regulators for about three years, General Motors is recalling about 56,000 Saturn Aura sedans from the 2007-8 model years because a transmission shifter cable could break, which would keep the driver from being able to shift the transmission into park.

headline: New Kidnapping Reported in Nigeria as U.S. Offers Help
keywords: ['Kidnapping', 'Women and Girls', 'Terrorism', 'Muslims and Islam', 'Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots']
abstract: The abduction of at least eight more girls came as the Obama administration announced that it had offered to help find and prosecute those responsible for the mass abduction last month, claimed by the Boko Haram extremist group.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — A second kidnapping of schoolgirls in Nigeria’s northeast by Islamist militants put new pressure on the country’s troubled government, which had been hoping to showcase its emergence as Africa’s largest economy this week but instead has been forced to confront its failure to contain a growing insurgency in its north.

headline: A Conversation With Roz Chast
abstract: The New Yorker cartoonist has written a sort of graphic memoir about caring for her ailing parents.
lead_paragraph: How did you pull this off, Roz Chast? How did you document the last eight years of your parents’ lives, in your distinctively doodle-ish drawings and candid prose, and make the story highly specific to their escape-from-the-Cossacks pasts in Brooklyn and, simultaneously, so universal? And how did you make this memoir — tellingly titled “Can’t We Talk About Something More Pleasant?” — both heartbreaking and snortingly funny?

headline: SAP and VMware Head for the Future Together
abstract: SAP is offering much of its enterprise software and Hana, used for data analysis, on VWware’s cloud computing platform. EMC and Oracle have made their own announcements. More is expected.
lead_paragraph: The big incumbents in enterprise computing are doing a lot of keeping up with the times this month.

headline: A Lost Mendelssohn Song Surfaces
abstract: A song by Felix Mendelssohn whose whereabouts were unclear for more than 100 years has turned up in a private collection in the United States and will be auctioned.
lead_paragraph: The manuscript of a lost song by Felix Mendelssohn that was known to scholars only by its title – “Des Menschen Herz ist ein Schacht” (“A Man’s Heart Is Like a Mine”) – has turned up in a private American collection. Its whereabouts had been uncertain since the late 19th century, when it was listed in Leipzig auction catalogs in 1862 and 1872. It is about to be auctioned again, on May 24 at Christie’s in London. The house’s online catalog gives its expected sale price as £15,000 to £25,000 (about $25,000 to $42,000).

headline: Strolling Through Paris, Solo
abstract: A reporter who has made solo travel part of her beat is assigned the dream trip: Paris in the spring.
lead_paragraph: “It was easy in Paris to surrender to the moment,” Stephanie Rosenbloom wrote in the Travel section this weekend. “But why? What alchemy transmuted ordinary activities, be it a walk across a bridge or the unwrapping of butter, into a pleasure?

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 37
abstract: Honduras on Tuesday unveiled its 23-man squad for the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Missouri Republicans Hand Defeat to Governor Once Called ‘Purplish’
abstract: After a battle over a tax-cut measure, animosity has come to characterize relations between Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, and the Republican-controlled Legislature.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON CITY, Mo. — Last September, Gov. Jay Nixon, a Democrat, pulled off a political long shot: He lobbied so successfully against a tax-cut bill championed by the Republican-controlled Legislature that the lawmakers were unable to override his veto.

headline: The Most Daring Red-Carpet Ensembles From Last Night’s Met Gala
abstract: At the Anna Wintour Costume Center’s annual event, some stars openly flouted the Charles James-inspired theme, to stunning results.
lead_paragraph: Last night, the Anna Wintour Costume Center at the Metropolitan Museum of Art held its annual gala to commemorate the work of the midcentury couturier Charles James. While the red carpet boasted no shortage of on-theme voluminous ball gowns and opera gloves — as worn by Sarah Jessica Parker in Oscar de La Renta, Karen Elson in Zac Posen and Suki Waterhouse in a stunning Burberry — the most interesting looks of the evening deviated from that formula. From Star Wars prints and exposed midriffs to brocade cigarette pants and austere minimalism, T salutes the women who politely declined the dress code and instead demonstrated what a fashion red carpet is really all about.

headline: Ask Well: Polio Vaccine
abstract: Do you have a question about the polio vaccine? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.
lead_paragraph: Do you have a question about the polio vaccine? Ask Well. Your question may be answered by our reporter, Donald G. McNeil, Jr.

headline: Major Research Groups Are Given Low Marks on Disclosing Donors
abstract: A survey conducted by a group called Transparify has caused ripples in the think tank world before its official release, with some organizations disclosing more information on donors.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The conservative-leaning Hoover Institution, based in California, and the liberal Center for American Progress, based in Washington, are polar opposites in terms of political leanings. But according to a first-of-its-kind survey of the world’s most prominent research organizations, the institutions share an important trait: a relatively poor record of disclosing the sources of their financing.

headline: A Singing Nun for a Reality TV World
abstract: Sister Cristina Scuccia has become a sensation on the Italian version of the talent show “The Voice.”
lead_paragraph: ROME — A true if unlikely tale: Young woman enrolls at a drama school sponsored by nuns, where the artistic director is a former Italian erotic film actress who redirected her career after a religious awakening. The students are selected to perform before the pope at St. Peter’s Square, but during rehearsals the young woman fractures an ankle.

lead_paragraph: Witnesses recalled moments of chaos after a knife attack at a railway station in China’s southern city of Guangzhou wounded six people.

lead_paragraph: PARIS — Nearly two months after a Malaysian jetliner disappeared, Europe’s aviation safety agency on Tuesday formally proposed a series of new measures aimed at improving the chances of finding the flight recorders of aircraft that crash at sea.

lead_paragraph: Jennifer Taub is an associate professor at Vermont Law School. Her book “Other People’s Houses” will be published on May 27 by Yale University Press.

headline: Ex-Christie Aide, Testifying in Bridge Inquiry, Portrays a Highly Political Office
abstract: Christina Renna gave a firsthand account of how the closing of access lanes to the George Washington Bridge turned into a scandal.
lead_paragraph: TRENTON — Providing a vivid, firsthand account of how the George Washington Bridge lane closings exploded into scandal in Gov. Chris Christie’s office, a former aide to the New Jersey governor testified that the woman he cast as the central villain in the scandal was not “a decision maker,” and that she did not believe that woman had planned the closings.

headline: A Mysterious Republican Committee in the Virgin Islands
abstract: Raising lots of money, and using it to raise more money through direct-mail campaigns, is a hallmark of the group’s treasurer, Scott MacKenzie.
lead_paragraph: There are a few things you should know about the Virgin Islands Republican Party: It has no full-time staff, has not had regular meetings for nearly two years, and only about 4 percent of the $200,000 it has raised since last fall has gone to party coffers.

lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO —  A tribute to the  record-setting cross-country motorcycle journey by  Erwin G. Baker, known universally as Cannon Ball, 100 years ago is underway, with a group of enthusiasts retracing Baker’s 11-day ride, May 3-14, from San Diego to New York City.

lead_paragraph: Raymond Pettibon, American artist and counterculture prophet whose drawings for the band Black Flag helped define punk culture, takes on Iris Apfel, style icon, interior designer and self-proclaimed “geriatric starlet” who will return in June to HSN, where she sells her Rara Avis line of chic and affordable accessories. (A new book of Pettibon’s work, “Raymond Pettibon: To Wit,” was just released.) See the chart.

lead_paragraph: Rap Genius, a popular website that compiles annotations of song lyrics, has reached a licensing agreement with music publishers after being accused of using the lyrics of thousands of songs without permission.

headline: Americans Are Outliers in Views on Climate Change
abstract: Residents of most other rich countries — and those in many poor countries — see climate change as a bigger threat than Americans do.
lead_paragraph: As President Obama sets out to convince the public that climate change requires immediate attention, he has his work cut out for him.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — An Oscar-winning screenwriter, a billionaire film financier and a well-known magazine editor have come together to form a movie and television company built on a journalism foundation.

headline: French Set Conditions for G.E. Takeover of Alstom
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Foreign Investments', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures']
abstract: French leaders said they would approve G.E.’s bid only if the deal could be completed in a way that protected French workers and the French industrial base.
lead_paragraph: PARIS – The French government, caught between concern about jobs at home and the nation’s reputation abroad for meddling in the economy, is plunging more deeply into the takeover offer for Alstom, one of France’s premier companies.

headline: Netflix Redesigns Logo — Sort Of
abstract: As Netflix has grown beyond offering physical DVDs and now streams video on screens and shapes of all sizes, the company appears to have redesigned its logo to adapt.
lead_paragraph: When Netflix created its first logo — which is black and white and red all over — the company was going for a LOOK AT ME design.

headline: Canny Taste Buds and a Nose for Sleuthing
abstract: In Ruth Reichl’s first novel, “Delicious!,” a young woman lands a job as an executive assistant at a food magazine.
lead_paragraph: There’s only one recipe in “Delicious!,” Ruth Reichl’s first novel, but it’s a keeper. You have to flip to the back to find it. It’s for a gingerbread cake enlivened by orange zest and fresh ginger and black pepper and cloves and cardamom. It’s for grown-up taste buds.

headline: Missouri Keeps Tumbling Rightward
abstract: The state legislature had no trouble passing a big tax cut today over the veto of Gov. Jay Nixon.
lead_paragraph: The Missouri legislature had no trouble passing a big tax cut today over the veto of Gov. Jay Nixon. As a Missouri native, I’m probably more irritated by this than most Times readers are, but my state is only one of many that have been sharply pulled to the right in the last few years. What’s happening in Jefferson City is already familiar to residents of Wisconsin, Michigan, Kansas, North Carolina, and many others.

headline: Travel Companies Boycott Brunei-Owned Hotel Group
keywords: ['Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Shariah (Islamic Law)', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Travel companies are boycotting the Dorchester Collection of hotels, owned by Brunei, to protest that nation’s criminal code, which will allow for homosexuals to be stoned to death.
lead_paragraph: Travel companies are boycotting the Dorchester Collection of hotels this week after Hassanal Bolkiah, the sultan of Brunei, the small, oil-rich country on the island of Borneo that owns the hotel group, began implementing a new criminal code that will allow for homosexuals and adulterers to be stoned to death.

headline: The New Wave of Oyster Bars
abstract: With year-round supply and insatiable demand, American chefs are inspired to innovate.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — On the surface, Connie & Ted’s is the sort of hot new restaurant you’d expect in West Hollywood. Its chef and co-owner, Michael Cimarusti, is an established culinary star. Its imposing building looks like a ski chalet outfitted with repurposed NASA parts. The busy valet-parking attendants see few economy cars.

headline: The Garden, Both Muse and Oracle at L’Arpège
abstract: Alain Passard has taken the cooking of vegetable dishes into a new, inspirational realm.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Dinner started with a plate of leafy radishes followed by a small cabbage turnover, and ended with a garlic crème brûlée whose burned-sugar shell had been liberally spritzed with lemon confit. In between came a dozen courses made from turnips, carrots, peas, beets, cauliflower and potatoes. Two see-through bands of lardo on grilled white asparagus and, down at the bottom of vegetable minestrone, some bits of chorizo that would have fit into a gum wrapper were the only visible signs of animal flesh.

headline: You Won 50 Games, Coach? Your Job Security’s Still Zero
abstract: Continuing an N.B.A. trend of teams firing coaches after successful seasons, the Golden State Warriors fired Mark Jackson, ending a three-year tenure in which the Warriors vaulted into one of the better, more entertaining teams in the league.
lead_paragraph: Last year, it was George Karl, Lionel Hollins and Vinny Del Negro. This year, so far, it is Mark Jackson.

headline: Watching North Carolina for Clues to the Senate
abstract: The crucial question is whether the state’s Republicans, who are holding their primary Tuesday, can avoid a potentially damaging runoff.
lead_paragraph: Over the last two cycles, the Republican nominating process cost the party critical Senate seats in states like Missouri, Delaware, Indiana, and probably in Colorado and Nevada as well. Similar mistakes in 2014 could easily cost Republicans the chance to take control of the Senate.

headline: How Bayer’s Buy Makes Sense
keywords: ['Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions']
abstract: Bayer’s $14.2 billion acquisition of Merck’s consumer care business makes strategic sense and sizable tax breaks will help, writes Olaf Storbeck of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Bayer’s $14.2 billion acquisition of Merck’s consumer care business is less pricey than it looks.

headline: In a Wheelchair, Honing a Defiant Stand-Up Act
abstract: Having survived a horrific accident in a subway station, the young comedian Liza Dye is using the experience as material for a comic routine.
lead_paragraph: Can a calamity plus a couple of months at Bellevue Hospital Center equal comedy?

headline: Judge Voids Murder Convictions for 3 Half Brothers Linked to Brooklyn Detective
keywords: ['False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The men were exonerated after questions were raised about the repeated use of a central witness by a retired Brooklyn detective, Louis J. Scarcella.
lead_paragraph: The decades-old murder convictions of three half brothers whose arrests were facilitated by a now discredited homicide detective were vacated in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn on Tuesday, as prosecutors acknowledged that the men had been deprived of fair trials because of a questionable witness.

headline: Twitter Plunges as More Shares Hit Market
abstract: An analyst says insiders are selling shares as a lockup period comes to an end after the stock’s public offering last November.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Shares of Twitter went into free fall on Tuesday as early investors became eligible to sell their shares on the market for the first time. The company’s shares dropped 17.8 percent, to close at $31.85, their lowest level since the company’s initial public offering of stock in November.

headline: An Artist Who Let His Ideas (and Others) Do the Work
abstract: Chris Teerink’s eye-catching and informative new documentary about the American conceptual artist Sol LeWitt is much more about his work than the man himself.
lead_paragraph: The central action in “Sol LeWitt,” Chris Teerink’s eye-catching and informative new documentary about that great American conceptual artist, is the execution of one of his pieces — “Wall Drawing 801: Spiral” — on the interior wall of a vast, bell-shaped room at a Dutch museum.

headline: Tiny Mouths to Feed, a Path Often Fraught
abstract: “Breastmilk,” an agenda-free documentary by Dana Ben-Ari, observes the nursing journeys of five new mothers in New York City.
lead_paragraph: Whether spraying or leaking, massaged by hand or pumped by machine, the breasts of the young mothers in “Breastmilk” are arguably more active than the infants they nourish. Cheerfully exposed or decorously veiled, the functioning of these workhorses may be life-sustaining, but, as Dana Ben-Ari’s admirably agenda-free documentary reveals, it can also be shockingly stressful.

headline: Reports on Alibaba’s I.P.O.
abstract: Investors are salivating over the initial stock offering of Alibaba Group, the giant Chinese e-commerce company.
lead_paragraph: Investors are salivating over the initial stock offering of Alibaba Group, the giant Chinese e-commerce company.

headline: A Portrait of the Outsider Artist, Older and Still Unfiltered
abstract: Llyn Foulkes, now 79, comes across in this film as a mostly lovable, cranky and brilliant outsider with a chip on his shoulder about not getting his due.
lead_paragraph: In more ways than one, Tamar Halpern and Chris Quilty’s documentary “Llyn Foulkes One Man Band” is about not knowing when to stop. The filmmakers are blessed and cursed with a subject who seems to lack the usual filters. We in turn witness Mr. Foulkes in action, at length — revamping his works, railing against the art world and speaking his neurotic mind.

headline: Sterling’s Right-Hand Man Is Placed on a Leave of Absence
abstract: The N.B.A. said on Tuesday that the move would “provide an opportunity for a new C.E.O. to begin on a clean slate and for the team to stabilize under difficult circumstances.”
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — The N.B.A. took another step in trying to clean up from the Donald Sterling scandal, announcing Tuesday that Andy Roeser, the Los Angeles Clippers’ president and Sterling’s longtime lieutenant, had been put on an indefinite leave of absence.

headline: G.E.'s Bid for Alstom Units Puts Siemens in a Bind
abstract: By trying to counter a G.E. deal with the French industrial group, Siemens has entered a battle in which it has much more to lose than it stands to gain.
lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — If the American industrial giant General Electric has a corporate doppelgänger in Europe, it is the German company Siemens. Both are global conglomerates that make trains, medical scanners and — most notably at the moment — the turbines and other equipment that generate and transport much of the world’s electricity.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Monica Lewinsky says she became reclusive during Hillary Rodham Clinton’s campaign for president in 2008 for fear that she would be used for political purposes and that she feels “gun-shy” even now as Mrs. Clinton considers another run in 2016.

lead_paragraph: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce on Wednesday is releasing new 30-second television ads for 10 House Republican candidates, in a more than $3 million buy that will last for two weeks and is intended to support candidates who the group believes can win in November.

headline: Knee-Jerk Revivals and Other Punch Lines
abstract: “Forbidden Broadway Comes Out Swinging!,” the latest incarnation of the long-running satirical revue, addresses signs of a theater season notably lacking in fresh material.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long, bleary season on Broadway, a burnt-out case ducks into a hole in the wall off Times Square, looking for a little sympathetic companionship. Soon enough, he finds it in a woman perched on top of a piano, wearing a little beret and an air of infinite jadedness.

headline: The Stock Market, in Six Charts
abstract: Some ways to think through the risks and rewards of investing in stocks at this particular point.
lead_paragraph: Recently on The Upshot, we explained why the stock market looks expensive. No doubt some stock traders and analysts will disagree and offer highly technical arguments to the contrary. I’ve often found the debate around stock market valuations can be confusing. So below is a step-by-step guide, with some charts, to help to make sense of the current stock market outlook.

headline: Chinese Giant Alibaba Will Go Public, Listing in U.S.
abstract: The e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork in the U.S. to sell stock to the public, a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:04 p.m. | The Chinese e-commerce behemoth Alibaba Group filed paperwork on Tuesday in the United States to sell stock to the public for the first time, in an embrace of the global capital markets that represents a coming-of-age for China’s booming Internet industry.

headline: Text to Text | President Johnson’s ‘Great Society’ Speech and ‘50 Years Into the War on Poverty, Hardship Hits Back’
abstract: In this Text to Text, we pair President Johnson’s “Great Society” speech with an article by Trip Gabriel describing the new face of poverty in rural West Virginia.
lead_paragraph: President Johnson announced 50 years ago this month his vision for a “Great Society” during two speeches — first at Ohio University and then at the University of Michigan. In those speeches he detailed his grand vision for America, which included not just ending poverty and racial injustice, but also a plan to build the Great Society “in our cities, in our countryside and in our classrooms.” A centerpiece of President Johnson’s Great Society was to free all Americans of the “crushing weight of poverty.” In this Text to Text, we pair President Johnson’s “Great Society” speech with an article by Trip Gabriel describing the new face of poverty in rural West Virginia.

headline: Fanwood, N.J.: A Future Coupled With Transit
abstract: A Union County community recognized for its transit-oriented downtown, and appreciated by its residents for its affordability and walkability.
lead_paragraph: Every morning, Arbi Zadorian, a software programmer, walks a few blocks into town where he joins scores of other commuters at the Fanwood station to catch trains to Newark or New York. Built in 1874, the Victorian station is the oldest in Union County. It is also what has come to define this borough’s past, present and future.

headline: Where to Find Serious Coffee in New York? Everywhere
abstract: Painstakingly prepared coffees, made to order, are moving into neighborhoods not known for patience.
lead_paragraph: If you want to see just how much has changed in New York’s coffee scene in the last few years, stop by Gregorys Coffee.

headline: The Gun Report: May 6, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, the Supreme Court declined to consider a challenge to a New Jersey law that prohibits residents from carrying guns in public. It would have been the most significant gun control case since the District of Columbia v. Heller decision in 2008, which upheld the right to keep handguns at home for self-defense.

headline: The Curious Case of Milwaukee’s Suburban Voters
abstract: Democrats have made huge gains in the suburbs since the Reagan years, but they haven’t made any progress in the areas around Milwaukee.
lead_paragraph: “The most polarized part of a polarized state in a polarized nation” — that’s how Craig Gilbert of The Milwaukee Journal Sentinel describes the Milwaukee metropolitan area in the masterful first article of a four-part series on the region’s politics. The region is just as polarized as Mr. Gilbert suggests.

headline: Commute for Subway Art Is Three Years, Door to Door
abstract: Ralph Fasanella, a labor organizer and self-taught artist, celebrated the working class in his paintings.
lead_paragraph: Ralph Fasanella’s painting “Subway Riders” has not budged since 1995, when it became the first oil painting to be installed in a New York City subway station. Now it is heading out on the road.

headline: ‘Frozen’ Helps Lift Profit for an Energized Disney
abstract: The movie and its hit soundtrack contributed to a 27 percent increase in net income for the company’s second fiscal quarter.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — The stunning success of “Frozen,” surging theme park spending, strong merchandise sales and higher fees for ESPN combined to deliver quarterly results for the Walt Disney Company that were nothing short of spectacular.

lead_paragraph: The e-commerce company has seized investor and public interest to an extent that is unusual for a company that does much of its business in China.

headline: An Uncoupling, but the Band Plays On
abstract: At Coldplay’s show on Monday night at the Beacon Theater, the divide between new and old material could be marked with a decibel meter.
lead_paragraph: Last month, word of the impending dissolution of the marriage of Chris Martin, frontman of Coldplay, and Gwyneth Paltrow arrived with an emphatic thud on her website, Goop.com. “It is with hearts full of sadness that we have decided to separate,” the brief statement began. The post was credited to “Gwyneth & Chris,” but it did not have the feel of a shared reveal. It ended with a plea: “We have always conducted our relationship privately, and we hope that as we consciously uncouple and coparent, we will be able to continue in the same manner.”

headline: Another Idiot With a Gun
abstract: A man accidentally shot his 11-year-old nephew.
lead_paragraph: One of the many problems with the growing normalization of gun ownership is that a growing number of idiots will want to buy and keep guns for no particularly good reason, and a subset of those idiots will go on to kill people.

headline: European Financial Trading Tax Moves Forward, Despite New Pockets of Resistance
abstract: Germany, France and eight other European Union members plan to tax the trading of stocks and other securities, even as others oppose the move.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An effort by some European countries to tax financial transactions met new resistance on Tuesday, as Sweden, Denmark and the Netherlands voiced reservations.

headline: After Huge Alibaba Payday, a Test for Yahoo Executives
abstract: Marissa Mayer, chief of Yahoo, will have to prove to Wall Street that she has a plan to save the company after it sells its stake in Alibaba.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — For Yahoo, the initial public offering of stock in the Alibaba Group will unlock the door to a giant trove of cash. Depending on the price of the deal, Yahoo most likely will receive $10 billion to $15 billion for the 9 percent stake in the Chinese e-commerce company that it is required to sell in the offering.

abstract: Christie’s joins several other art-world institutions in agreeing to return to Cambodia statues that were looted from a Khmer temple.
lead_paragraph: Yet another ancient statue looted in the 1970s from a single remote temple in the jungles of Cambodia has turned up in the United States, this time at Christie’s, which is voluntarily paying to return it to its homeland.

headline: Leave ‘Organic’ Out of It
keywords: ['Organic Foods and Products', 'Genetic Engineering', 'Sustainable Living', 'Factory Farming', 'Food', 'Agriculture and Farming', 'Health Foods']
abstract: To be more effective, food activists should steer clear of buzzwords that only confuse the issues.
lead_paragraph: The ever-increasing number of people working to improve the growing, processing, transporting, marketing, distributing and eating of food must think through our messages more thoroughly and get them across more clearly. I don’t pretend to have all the answers, but I can say that a couple of buzzwords represent issues that are far more nuanced than we often make them appear. These are “organic” and “G.M.O.'s” (genetically modified organisms).
