keywords: ['Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Conflicts of Interest', 'Foreign Investments', 'Initial Public Offerings', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Taxation']
abstract: Several risks that Alibaba outlined in its prospectus reflect a different set of corporate governance standards than those at many American firms.
lead_paragraph: The planned initial public offering of Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce behemoth, has Wall Street buzzing. But investing in the tech behemoth carries a number of risks.

headline: Laid-Back English Country Retreats
abstract: A spate of new English countryside hotels contradict their reputation for being overly formal and stuffy.
lead_paragraph: English countryside hotels have sometimes had a reputation for being overly formal and stuffy, but that may change with several new properties that can be described as laid-back. The trend started in 2009 with the opening of Lime Wood (rates from £255 a night, about $428), a 29-room 18th-century hunting lodge turned upscale getaway in Hampshire, about 90 minutes southwest of London. Instead of the antique décor typical of country retreats, the furnishings are contemporary and eclectic with touches like free-standing bathtubs in the middle of guest rooms. The hotel welcomes travelers in jeans and has a 20,000-square-foot spa and an Italian restaurant with its own smokehouse.

headline: Whispers From Fed Could Lead to Wild Swings, Internal Critic Says
abstract: Jeremy Stein, a member of the Federal Reserve board, said the Fed’s attempt to calm markets may have the opposite effect.
lead_paragraph: Jeremy Stein is in the final weeks of his role as the Federal Reserve’s most important internal critic, and Tuesday night in New York he renewed his warnings that the Fed’s retreat from its stimulus campaign may yet roil financial markets.

headline: Kara Walker on Aerobics, D’Angelo and Her Favorite Hair Haunt
abstract: The artist, whose installation at the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Brooklyn opens this week, shares a few of her favorite things.
lead_paragraph: This week, the artist Kara Walker will unveil a major new public artwork at at the decommissioned Domino Sugar factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, presented by Creative Time, the elaborately titled “A Subtlety, or the Marvelous Sugar Baby, an Homage to the unpaid and overworked Artisans who have refined our Sweet tastes from the cane fields to the Kitchens of the New World on the occasion of the demolition of the Domino Sugar Refining Plant.”

headline: Driver Detained After Following Obama Daughters’ Motorcade
abstract: The White House was locked down and a car was stopped by Secret Service agents after the driver followed Malia and Sasha Obama through a security checkpoint near the White House on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A driver followed a motorcade carrying the Obama daughters through a security checkpoint near the White House on Tuesday afternoon, leading the complex to be locked down as the car was stopped and searched in a restricted section of Pennsylvania Avenue.

headline: Alibaba, by the Numbers
abstract: No matter which way you slice it, Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, is big. Here is a look at some of the numbers in the company’s filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
lead_paragraph: Alibaba, the Chinese e-commerce company, is big. And from its user numbers to its valuation, everything about the company is growing.

headline: The G.O.P. Can’t Ignore Climate Change
abstract: It’s bad politics not to address the challenges we face.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — “TO waste, to destroy our natural resources, to skin and exhaust the land instead of using it so as to increase its usefulness, will result in undermining in the days of our children the very prosperity which we ought by right to hand down to them amplified and developed.”

headline: A Name Pronounceable in Nearly Every Language
abstract: Alibaba’s website offers clues to the origin of the company’s name.
lead_paragraph: In a world of two-syllable Internet company names, Alibaba stands out.

headline: U.S. Chamber of Commerce Begins Ad Blitz for G.O.P.
abstract: The agency released 30-second television ads on Wednesday for 10 Republican candidates for House seats in a campaign that will cost more than $3 million to run and last two weeks.
lead_paragraph: The U.S. Chamber of Commerce released 30-second television advertisements on Wednesday for 10 Republican candidates for House seats in a broadcast campaign that will cost more than $3 million to run and will last two weeks. The ads will run in the districts of six incumbents — Andy Barr of Kentucky, Dan Benishek of Michigan, Mike Coffman of Colorado, Chris Gibson of New York, Joe Heck of Nevada and David Valadao of California — and in support of the candidates Bob Dold in Illinois, Stewart Mills in Minnesota, Doug Ose in California and Richard Tisei in Massachusetts. The chamber is changing its strategy to focus on the general election.

headline: Paying Homage to Bin Laden, Mosque Re-emerges as Bastion of Militancy
abstract: Long a citadel of Islamist revolt, the Red Mosque in the Pakistani capital is enjoying a revival as the government fails to offer an alternative vision of the future.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Rising from the heart of Islamabad, the Red Mosque has long been a barometer of militant Islam in Pakistan. In the 1980s it funneled fighters into the anti-Soviet jihad in Afghanistan. In the ‘90s its leaders made an awe-struck pilgrimage to visit their hero, Osama bin Laden, at his farm outside Kandahar.

headline: Second Top Runner Is Signed by Skechers
abstract: Kara Goucher, a two-time Olympian, is the only top professional runner to represent two major sponsors, one for shoes and one for clothing.
lead_paragraph: Two weeks after Meb Keflezighi won the Boston Marathon in Skechers, the brand added another distance star, Kara Goucher, to its sponsorship roster. The deal gives the shoe line, more commonly known for its fashion footwear, two of America’s most established and popular distance runners.

headline: Can a Pope Help Sustain Humanity and Ecology?
keywords: ['Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Population', 'Religion and Belief', 'Sustainable Living']
abstract: The two science academies under Pope Francis hold a rare joint meeting to chart paths to sustainable development.
lead_paragraph: VATICAN CITY — For four long days, several dozen physical, environmental and social scientists hunkered here with theologians, philosophers, economists and a poverty campaigner to explore ways to balance human ambitions with the planet’s limits. The rare joint meeting of the Pontifical Academy of Sciences and Pontifical Academy of Social Sciences — “Sustainable Humanity, Sustainable Nature, Our Responsibility” — helped demarcate where science leaves off and the rest of society, including organized religion, plays a role in shaping the quality of human life and environmental conditions in this century.

headline: Vatican Tells of 848 Priests Ousted in Decade
keywords: ['Priests', 'Sex Crimes', 'Reparations', 'Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: The Vatican presented itself as a model of reform before a United Nations committee reviewing the Holy See’s compliance with an international treaty prohibiting torture.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Vatican has dismissed more than 800 priests for sexual abuse of children in the past decade and paid billions of dollars in compensation, senior Vatican officials told a United Nations panel on Tuesday, presenting the Roman Catholic Church as a model of reform but drawing the ire of victims’ groups that said it still seeks to dodge responsibility for the harm that priests continue to inflict.

headline: Alibaba Investors Will Buy a Risky Corporate Structure
abstract: When investors buy shares in an American offering of Alibaba, what exactly will they be buying? asks Steven M. Davidoff in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: Shareholders have been willing to take a lot of risk in their lust for Internet initial public offerings, but Alibaba’s I.P.O. may take that risk to a whole new level. The reason: Investors in the offering won’t have title to most of Alibaba’s Chinese assets because of Chinese prohibitions on foreign ownership.

headline: Georgia College Seeks Return to Calm After Shootings Taint End of Academic Year

lead_paragraph: AUGUSTA, Ga. — After two days of gunfire at Paine College, Tuesday brought a grim and uneasy silence here.

headline: Nigeria’s Stolen Girls
abstract: The administration of President Goodluck Jonathan has been shockingly slow and inept at addressing the mass kidnappings of scores of schoolgirls.
lead_paragraph: Three weeks after their horrifying abduction in Nigeria, 276 of the more than 300 girls who were taken from a school by armed militants are still missing, possibly sold into slavery or married off. Nigerian security forces apparently do not know where the girls are and the country’s president, Goodluck Jonathan, has been shockingly slow and inept at addressing this monstrous crime.

headline: Stanford to Purge $18 Billion Endowment of Coal Stock
keywords: ['Endowments', 'Coal', 'Mines and Mining', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Stanford became the first major university to lend support to a nationwide campaign to rid endowments and pension funds of fossil fuel investments.
lead_paragraph: Stanford University announced Tuesday that it would divest its $18.7 billion endowment of stock in coal-mining companies, becoming the first major university to lend support to a nationwide campaign to purge endowments and pension funds of fossil fuel investments.

headline: Graying of America Is Speeding, Report Says
abstract: The number of Americans 65 and older is expected to nearly double by the middle of the century — to 83.7 million — a trend hastened by declines in fertility and mortality rates, a Census Bureau report said.
lead_paragraph: The number of Americans 65 and older is expected to nearly double by the middle of the century when they will make up more than a fifth of the nation’s population, according to a Census Bureau report released Tuesday.

headline: Mocked on Internet, Diet Coke Alters Ads

lead_paragraph: A CAMPAIGN for Diet Coke carrying the theme “You’re on,” which the Coca-Cola Company introduced in North America only three months ago, is being turned off after being mocked in social media.

headline: Jimmy Ellis, a Boxer Long in Ali’s Shadow, Dies at 74
abstract: Mr. Ellis, a former sparring partner for Muhammad Ali, captured the heavyweight championship after it had been stripped from Ali for his refusing military induction.
lead_paragraph: Jimmy Ellis, the onetime sparring partner for Muhammad Ali who captured the heavyweight boxing championship after it had been stripped from Ali for his refusing induction into the armed forces, died on Tuesday in Louisville, Ky. He was 74.

headline: Go Big, Get Crazy
keywords: ['Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Oil Sands', 'Energy and Power', 'Keystone Pipeline System']
abstract: President Obama has a legacy opportunity in Ukraine if he would only act on it.
lead_paragraph: Up to now, Russia’s president, Vladimir Putin, has been playing a weak hand in Ukraine very well. I mean, how strong are you when your allies insist on wearing masks? But Putin thinks he knows his adversaries better than they know themselves. He thinks the Americans will never be serious about energy, that the Europeans will never be serious about sanctions, that the Ukrainian reformers will never be serious about governance, and that he can control the separatist forces he’s unleashed in eastern Ukraine and dial them up or down as he pleases.

headline: In Speech and Essay, Chiara de Blasio Details Her Depression and Addiction
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s daughter accepted an award from the former health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, for serving as an example of hope to other young people.
lead_paragraph: Taking on an unusual role for the child of a sitting mayor, Chiara de Blasio, 19, the first daughter of New York City, traveled to Maryland with her parents on Tuesday to accept an award from the health and human services secretary, Kathleen Sebelius, and published an emotionally raw essay online about her struggle with depression and addiction.

headline: Titles, Not M.V.P.s, Define the Greats
abstract: By winning the M.V.P. award, Kevin Durant has separated himself from the pack — and set himself up for criticism should his team fall short of the title.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Welcome, Kevin Durant, to LeBron James’s world. Enjoy yourself, while being mindful of every competitive stumble. Someone is liable to knock you over, kick you when you’re down.

headline: U.S. Sought Delay of Morsi’s Ouster, Egyptian Leader Says
keywords: ['Elections', "Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'United States International Relations']
abstract: The leader, Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, said he had rebuffed the request from American ambassador Anne W. Patterson who asked him to hold off “for a day or two” before ousting the freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Abdul Fattah el-Sisi, the former general who is poised to be elected Egypt’s president in next month’s elections, said in an interview broadcast Tuesday night that the American ambassador had asked him to hold off “for a day or two” before ousting the freely elected president, Mohamed Morsi of the Muslim Brotherhood, last July.

lead_paragraph: With its rows of two-family homes and its corridors of auto repair shops and storefront churches, East New York sits far away from the heated debates over density and building height that have roiled other, more sought-after Brooklyn neighborhoods like Williamsburg and Park Slope.

headline: U.S. Imposes First Sanctions in South Sudan Conflict

headline: Pakistan: Province Bars Entry to Those Not Vaccinated for Polio
abstract: One Pakistani province said Tuesday that citizens from anywhere else in the country would not be able to enter it without proof that they had been vaccinated.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of World Health Organization travel restrictions imposed on Pakistan to stop it from spreading polio abroad, one Pakistani province said Tuesday that citizens from anywhere else in the country would not be able to enter it without proof that they had been vaccinated. According to the news service Dawn, the health adviser to the chief minister of Punjab Province said vaccination booths would be set up at airports and all roads leading into the province, which includes the country’s second-largest city, Lahore. While many countries impose vaccine requirements on foreign visitors, vaccine requirements within a country’s borders are almost unheard-of. Almost all of Pakistan’s polio cases occur in the northwest frontier areas, where resistance to vaccine is high. Travel restrictions were also imposed Monday on Cameroon and Syria; they must ensure that anyone leaving their borders is vaccinated against polio.

headline: Art and Fashion Are at It Again
abstract: For the upcoming art and design fairs in New York and the sixth annual Monumenta art exhibition in the Grand Palais in Paris, art-inspired designs make for obvious outfits.
lead_paragraph: Last October, in Paris, Karl Lagerfeld transformed the Grand Palais into a white-walled art gallery filled with Chanel-themed paintings and sculptures for his spring/summer 2014 runway — a motif which seemed to officially set up this year’s warm-weather fashion landscape as one intertwined and imbued with art. And now that the season has arrived, the connection is undeniable. As fashion editors gear up for art and design shows opening both here and there — New York’s Collective 2 design fair on Thursday and Frieze Art Fair on Friday, and Paris’s Monumenta art exhibition at the Grand Palais on Saturday — obvious outfit choices abound, from artist’s-sketch-covered separates to sculptural bangles fit for a ceramist’s studio.

The first is Collective 2, the second annual collectible design fair, which was started last year by the architect Steven Learner. It opens tomorrow at Moynihan Station.

headline: Masala Dosa to Die For
abstract: How the founder of one of the world’s largest vegetarian restaurant chains got away with murder.
lead_paragraph: Saravana Bhavan doesn’t look like a house of secrets. Its dining room at the corner of Lexington Avenue and 26th Street is clean and bright and often attracts a line out front. It doesn’t advertise because it doesn’t need to; the fact that it’s one of the world’s largest chains of vegetarian restaurants — 33 in India, another 47 in a dozen other countries — is considered too obvious to its core clientele of Indian expatriates and tourists to be worth trumpeting. In a city overwhelmed with underwhelming north Indian food, Saravana Bhavan is the standard-bearer of the delicacies of the south, but it makes no effort to educate the uninitiated. If you don’t know what a dosa is or how to eat it, you’re on your own.

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 2:50 P.M. (Starz Cinema) FAREWELL, MY QUEEN (2012) Sidonie Laborde (Léa Seydoux, above left, with Julie-Marie Parmentier), the reader to Marie Antoinette (Diane Kruger) at Versailles, watches as the French monarchy falls in this drama directed by Benoît Jacquot from a novel by Chantal Thomas. Noémie Lvovsky portrays the queen’s lady-in-waiting; Virginie Ledoyen is the woman rumored to be the queen’s lover. “If the rules and the players of this continuing, increasingly dangerous court intrigue remain obscure, it’s because ‘Farewell, My Queen’ is told through Sidonie’s eyes,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. “Tapping her palace sources, notably an archivist (Michel Robin) and a dressmaker (Anne Benoît), Sidonie learns of news known only to the nobility and their trusted stewards: that the Bastille has been seized.” Mr. Jacquot, she added, “has always been a sensitive director of actresses, his sympathies evident in his caressing, sometimes ogling camerawork and the time and space he gives women and their stories. That sympathy is evident here too, though crucially, while he doesn’t demonize Marie Antoinette, he doesn’t turn her into a spurious feminist martyr.” In French, with English subtitles.

headline: Feeling For | Decadent Cashmere Blankets With a Planet-Friendly Pedigree
abstract: Just in time for Mother’s Day, the natural dye guru Jane Palmer and the artist Christy Matson have collaborated on a new series of luxurious — and socially and environmentally virtuous — home accessories.
lead_paragraph: Just how much good karma can be packed into a single home accessory? Quite a bit, as evidenced by a new series of limited-edition cashmere blankets made by Jane Palmer of Noon Design Studio — the fashion industry’s eminent natural dye house, which is also known for its popular indigo kits and decorative housewares — and the artist Christy Matson. Carpet-thick yet feather-light, the blankets are hand-loomed by Matson in Los Angeles on the same jacquard machine she uses in her fine-art practice. The lofty cashmere yarn is not only hand-twisted by members of a women’s cooperative in Afghanistan, but also — two degrees of virtuousness — sourced directly from fashion houses that would otherwise have discarded it. The rich, variegated colors are hand-dyed by Palmer using flowers, leaves and minerals; the jet-black hue comes from a dye recipe of roots, bark and indigo that dates back to medieval times. Each is one of a kind; custom designs are also available by special order. Palmer and Matson have set aside a small number of the blankets for T readers, and can ship overnight — just in time for a (very decadent) last-minute Mother’s Day gift.

headline: An Incubator for Creativity in Savannah, Ga.
abstract: New galleries, shops and cafes have taken root in the city’s increasingly vibrant Starland district.
lead_paragraph: The Savannah that most visitors encounter is confined to the historic district between the Savannah River and the trees of Forsyth Park draped in Spanish moss. But several blocks south of the park, beyond the sun-dappled squares and canopied streets, is the increasingly vibrant Starland district. The neighborhood, whose name comes from the defunct Starland Dairy factory it surrounds, has in recent years emerged as an incubator for creativity that overflows from the nearby Savannah College of Art and Design (SCAD). Now a clutch of new shops, galleries and cafes has taken root here, providing a refreshingly rough-around-the-edges respite from Savannah’s polished, Old South charm.

headline: Restaurant Report: Florería Atlántico in Buenos Aires
abstract: Wander into a flower and wine shop, then through a refrigerator door to discover this underground home to inventive cocktails and original shareable plates.
lead_paragraph: The air at Florería Atlántico, in the Retiro neighborhood of Buenos Aires, is decadent with the scent of fresh flowers. Some pedestrians may wander in looking for a bouquet for an aggrieved girlfriend or wine for a dinner party, but those in the know are aware of what lies beneath the unassuming flower and wine shop. Inside, a hulking refrigerator door swings back to reveal the entrance to a subterranean chamber. This in-vogue restaurant and lounge is underground in every sense of the word.

headline: Street Style in Berlin
abstract: “In Berlin, people practice more understatement with their clothing,” said Ron Dietze in a vintage handmade leather coat.
lead_paragraph: The central Kreuzberg neighborhood has evolved from one of the poorest in Berlin to one of the trendiest. It is where Ron Dietze (with his wife and two daughters) was walking along the graffiti-lined streets on the way to dinner. Dressed in a fitted black suit, a black turtleneck and a cherry-red leather trench coat, Mr. Dietze said he usually wore more color, higher heels and even the occasional skirt. On this day, however, he said he wanted to dress “a bit classier” for his daughter’s birthday celebration. This interview has been edited and condensed.

headline: What Health Insurance Might Do
keywords: ['Conservatism (US Politics)', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Medicaid', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A new study strengthens liberalism’s health care case.
lead_paragraph: Alert (or at least health-care-obsessed) readers have no doubt been following the coverage of a new study on mortality in Massachusetts in the years following Romneycare’s coverage expansion, the gist of which — the authors found a striking, Massachusetts-specific decline in death rates for the non-elderly — tends to confirm liberal assumptions about the benefits of health insurance, and undercut the conservative and libertarian argument that insurance doesn’t have the impact on health and mortality that most people expect. The study’s findings are an almost-diametrical reversal of the results from Oregon’s Medicaid experiment, which were much discussed around this time last year (here’s my contribution), and which seemed to strengthen the conservative critique of Obamacare’s pursuit of comprehensive coverage. So now it’s liberalism’s turn to claim vindication, and to press Obamacare’s critics to give ground in the debate.

The family and supporters of the publisher, Yiu Mantin, has said the charges were a political vendetta brought on by his plans to publish a book condemning the Chinese Communist Party leader, Xi Jinping.

headline: Can You Tweet Like Ruth Reichl?

headline: Feeling For | Beauty Products to Whisk Mom Off to the Beaches of Sicily
abstract: Sue Townsend’s Italian line of scented luxury products, Ortigia, is ideal for Mother’s Day gifting.
lead_paragraph: Sue Townsend, one of the original founders of Britain’s Crabtree & Evelyn, lives in a 15th-century palazzo in Florence and creates handsome-smelling products under her luxury beauty label Ortigia. Unlike Townsend, everything about the line is truly Sicilian, from the indigenous, natural ingredients to the scents, which evoke the Mediterranean landscape. Some embody local flora — the slightly stringent yet delicate Zagara, infused with orange blossoms, or the Sicilian Jasmine, distilled from local white flowers — while others transport, like the musky but honeysuckle-sweet Ambra Nera, infused with patchouli and vetiver and evocative of a warm, amorous night on the island. The calming Fico D’India scent is inspired by the cactus of the same name that grows wild along the beaches of Sicily.

headline: Short Stories That Riff Playfully on Some Enduring Forebears

lead_paragraph: The stories in “American Innovations,” the new collection by Rivka Galchen, the author of the 2008 novel “Atmospheric Disturbances,” don’t behave like typical short stories. Though Ms. Galchen favors misdirection and indirection, her writing is skillful, imaginative, often funny.

abstract: Much of the high-end market today is in business-class travel, where airlines have spent huge sums to compete.
lead_paragraph: If you fly a lot, you have heard the nostalgia about a long-gone Golden Age of air travel. During this fabled time, which is said to have occurred as commercial aviation expanded through the 1950s into the jet age of the 1960s, passengers dressed up to fly on airplanes where glamorous stewardesses wearing white gloves served beef bourguignon on fine china.

headline: Sotheby’s to Reimburse Loeb $10 Million
abstract: The auction house spent $5.7 million in a long proxy battle with Daniel S. Loeb. It also said it planned to pay Mr. Loeb $10 million to reimburse him for his troubles.
lead_paragraph: Sotheby’s campaign to fend off attacks by the billionaire activist Daniel S. Loeb has proved costly. But playing nice with Mr. Loeb may be even costlier.

headline: Alibaba’s Acquisition Strategy: Focused Largely on China and Mobile
abstract: One of the less-appreciated elements of Alibaba’s voluminous prospectus is its mergers and acquisitions strategy.
lead_paragraph: When Alibaba Group’s prospectus finally hit Wall Street on Tuesday, analysts and prospective investors eagerly tore into their fullest look yet at the company.

headline: For Wearable Computing, Software Must Be King
abstract: With a flood of wearable gadgets now on the market, Forrester Research warns that companies need to create better software for consumers to give them feedback around their daily routines.
lead_paragraph: Over the last few years, we have heard that there will be wearable devices for almost every part of the body, from face to feet. But people have paid little attention to the software that accompanies these gadgets.

headline: The Gun Report: May 7, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, 26-year-old Stephen Guillermo had just returned from a night of drinking when he tried to enter the fifth-floor apartment he shared with his mother and two younger siblings in the South of Market neighborhood of San Francisco. But he mistakenly got off on the third floor, and the apartment he thought was his belonged to Amisi Sudi Kachepa, a 68-year-old retired security guard, who shot Guillermo to death.

headline: A Familiar Refrain: Cut Calories
abstract: Americans may have heeded the call to drink fewer martinis, but they have consumed more calories than necessary since the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: The Times is converting all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “A Cut in Calories Urged for Nation” appeared on May 7 and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: Footage of Teenage Stowaway
abstract: Hawaii transportation officials released video of a California teenager hopping from a jet’s wheel well on April 20 after stowing away for a flight to Hawaii from San Jose, Calif.
lead_paragraph: Hawaii transportation officials released video of a California teenager hopping from a jet’s wheel well on April 20 after stowing away for a flight to Hawaii from San Jose, Calif.

headline: By Design | Neuehouse Brings Its Artisanal Aesthetic to Frieze New York
abstract: The young co-working space in Gramercy Park, which has quickly become known for its jet-setting entrepreneurs and its innovative cultural events, partnered with the art fair on its V.I.P. lounge this year.
lead_paragraph: One of the chief appeals of Frieze New York is its buzzy restaurant partners, which for this weekend’s edition include Roberta’s, Mission Cantina and Frankies Spuntino. This year, the fair adds a different kind of lifestyle partner in the clublike co-working space Neuehouse, which has become a hot location for start-ups and cultural programming since opening its David Rockwell-designed office on 25th Street last year. For Frieze, Neuehouse created the V.I.P. tent, an oasis in the middle of the fair’s whirl of activity on Randall’s Island. “Part of the exploration here is that the place that one works, the place that one creates should be stimulating visually and emotionally, and art is a very important part of that,” says the Neuehouse co-founder Joshua Abram of the decision to partner with Frieze.

headline: Piling On the Luxury
keywords: ['Business Travel', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Luxury Goods and Services']
abstract: To compete for high-value business travelers, airlines are engaged in an amenities arms race, investing in better seats, private terminals and hosts of other perks for their premium passengers.
lead_paragraph: For most travelers, flying in style may be a thing of the past, but airlines are determined to bring back some glamour to air travel, at least for those sitting in the front of the plane.

headline: Pictures of the Day: South Africa and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from South Africa, India, Washington and Spain.
lead_paragraph: Photos from South Africa, India, Washington and Spain.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Busy day? Catch up on the stories that grabbed our attention.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Confections of History, Lovingly Decorated
abstract: New York City Ballet brings back four Balanchine works that recapture their time and reflect on earlier eras.
lead_paragraph: The ballets of George Balanchine are fascinating layer cakes of history. The four that returned to New York City Ballet on Tuesday night were choreographed between 1947 and 1975, and they still capture the moments in which they were made.

headline: From Mystical Bells to a Hungarian Folk Duo, the Joys of the Unfamiliar
abstract: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center performed a revelatory Kodaly Duo, selections from Schumann and Brahms, and the American premiere of Zhou Long’s “Tales From the Nine Bells.”
lead_paragraph: As a rule I do not expect to leave a concert of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center thinking about Donald Rumsfeld. But after Tuesday evening’s brilliant “Music From Three Centuries” at Alice Tully Hall, I was put in mind of the former defense secretary’s most famous dictum about those known knowns, known unknowns and, crucially, unknown unknowns in life: “the ones we do not know we don’t know.”

headline: Feeling For | A Fashion Magazine Without the Gloss
abstract: Bare, a new specialty style journal created by a bi-continental trio, takes an intimate, unretouched approach to the genre.
lead_paragraph: “Looking at countless blogs and Tumblrs, the images that we were sharing were much more raw and personal than what I typically see in fashion print,” says the creative director Claudia Bruno, a co-founder of the new fashion and culture magazine Bare. Seeking to strip away the artifice of traditional fashion media, Bruno teamed up with her longtime friends, the writers Emily Lundin and Courtney Saunders, to found a fashion magazine for what Bruno calls “women like us — smarter, intellectual people who aren’t slaves to fashion, but creators of it.”

headline: Nursing a Half-Empty Tankard, the Nebbish Returns
abstract: Artfully balancing misery and laughs, “Maron” returns for a second season on IFC.
lead_paragraph: What does it say about me that I almost always like shows in the micro-genre of comedians playing themselves — “Seinfeld,” “Curb Your Enthusiasm,” “The Sarah Silverman Program,” “Louie,” “Legit”? That I have a taste for low-stakes misanthropy? That I enjoy other people’s misery and embarrassment?

headline: Out of the Northwest, Through Sea and Desert
abstract: John Luther Adams’s hypnotic “Become Ocean,” which won the Pulitzer Prize, was the centerpiece of the Seattle Symphony’s concert at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Among its many impressive aspects, the concert by the Seattle Symphony on Tuesday night at Carnegie Hall, part of the Spring for Music festival, was a publicist’s fantasy.

headline: Fight Over Guggenheim’s Legacy Roils Her Palazzo
abstract: Descendants of Peggy Guggenheim have filed suit in a Paris court, arguing that the handling of the museum she founded in Venice is crassly commercial and violates her wishes.
lead_paragraph: VENICE — The battle now raging over the Peggy Guggenheim Collection started with just a few words written in brass letters above the sculpted lions that guard the 18th-century palazzo turned art museum here.

headline: Garance Doré: A Half, but Whole
abstract: With her street-style photography, words and sketches, the style blogger Ms. Doré has come into her own to become an influential voice in fashion.
lead_paragraph: Garance Doré is a mistress of the slow reveal. Alongside the fetching fashion sketches and street snaps that she posts on her popular namesake style blog, she spins just enough of her charmingly addictive personal musings to keep her followers engaged and clicking on for more.

headline: A Team in Need Gets a Fourth
abstract: In the final of the Bermuda Bowl world team championship last year, Italy defeated Monaco.
lead_paragraph: In the final of the Bermuda Bowl world team championship last year, Italy defeated Monaco by 210 international match points to 126 over 96 boards.

headline: June Festival Adds to New York’s Lively Early Music Scene
abstract: The Early Music Festival: NYC will focus on performers who live and work in New York City.
lead_paragraph: The latest addition to New York’s flourishing early music scene is a festival meant to hold up a mirror to the field: Early Music Festival: NYC, a new festival that will run from June 13 to 19, will focus on early music performers who live and work in New York City. Most of the performances will be free.

headline: A Sweet Celebration of Kara Walker’s Giant Sugar Sculpture
abstract: Luminaries from the worlds of art and fashion trekked out to Williamsburg, Brooklyn, for a seated dinner at the Domino Sugar Factory to celebrate the artist’s new work.
lead_paragraph: WhoKara Walker was the guest of honor at last night’s Creative Time benefit to celebrate the artist’s 75-foot-high white sphinx sculpture made of sugar in the decommissioned Domino Sugar Factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn. More than 700 guests, most from the worlds of art and fashion, including Chuck Close, Jenna Lyons, Theaster Gates, Solange Knowles, Chloé Sévigny, André Leon Talley and Walker’s 16-year-old daughter Octavia, dined in its shadow.

headline: Bank of America Shareholders Press Officials After $4 Billion Error
keywords: ['Boards of Directors', 'Company Reports', 'Shareholder Rights and Activism']
abstract: Bank officials said they were conducting a “third-party review” of how the problem happened, but declined to name the firm conducting the review.
lead_paragraph: CHARLOTTE, N.C. — This year’s annual meeting was supposed to be a victory lap for Bank of America, with many of its mortgage problems receding and its deposits and credit card business growing.

headline: Infidelity Runs Amok, but the Party Never Stops
abstract: “The Fabulous Miss Marie,” a 1971 play revived by Woodie King Jr., features a former showgirl married to a parking valet, and a prodigious amount of drinking.
lead_paragraph: As the title character of Ed Bullins’s “The Fabulous Miss Marie,” Tonya Pinkins wears a series of dresses cut low and slit high. One gown has leopard spots, another tiger stripes. (Perhaps her ocelot frock is at the dry cleaner’s?) Ms. Pinkins slinks around the Castillo Theater stage, yowling and purring as she sips Ambassador Scotch. When she sees a handsome young man, she toys with him for a while. Then she pounces.

headline: Motorcyclist Deaths May Have Decreased in 2013
keywords: ['Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'States (US)', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: The Governors Highway Safety Association said that motorcyclists deaths are down, but the weather probably kept riders off the roads.
lead_paragraph: Based on preliminary data provided by the highway departments of all 50 states and the District of Columbia, motorcyclist deaths in the United States appear to have decreased 7 percent in 2013, according to an analysis released Tuesday by the Governors Highway Safety Association, a nonprofit organization. But motorcyclist safety has not improved over all in the last 15 years, the group said.

headline: Guys, Please Take It Outside
abstract: Dip-dyed knitwear gives you an early start on fall dressing; Filson is opening an East Coast store; Salvatore Ferragamo designs its first swimwear collection for guys and more.
lead_paragraph: One highlight of the Bottega Veneta fall 2014 runway show was its dip-dyed knitwear: luxurious sweaters with cuffs or hems stained in a contrasting color, as if by happy accident (shown here). Bottega Veneta’s colors are autumnal — rust orange, burgundy, forest green — but it’s easy to get a jump on the fall look with any of spring’s array of dip-dyed goods, these in seasonally appropriate nautical colors.

lead_paragraph: One is accustomed to seeing celebrity profiles beginning with avowals that the subject is wearing “no makeup,” and rolling one’s eyes. Yet, for a few seasons, either on the catwalk, sidewalk or information superhighway, a no-makeup look seems to be emerging as the gold (or beige?) standard.

headline: Facts & Figures: What Aliens Have to Do With MH370
abstract: A CNN poll found that nine percent of Americans think space aliens played a part in the plane’s disappearance.
lead_paragraph: Now we know what percentage of people believe, or at least what percentage are willing to tell a pollster they believe, that space aliens had something to do with the disappearance of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: 3 Singers Return, Reflecting About Life
abstract: The singer-songwriters Natalie Merchant, Tori Amos and Sarah McLachlan have new albums.
lead_paragraph: “Pushin’ on, pushin’ on, isn’t that what I’m supposed to do?” Natalie Merchant sings on her self-titled new album, a set of dark, brave, thoughtful and serenely startling songs that is her first album in 13 years with her own lyrics. Ms. Merchant, 50, had million-selling albums in the 1980s with 10,000 Maniacs and in the 1990s on her own before turning away from a routine pop career after her somber 2001 album, “Motherland.”

headline: A Romp in Gossamer, 8 Tons’ Worth
abstract: “The Houston Impenetrable,” a shimmering kinetic installation at the Museum of Fine Arts, Houston, is as full of logistical challenges as aesthetic delights.
lead_paragraph: The ceiling has been reinforced. The guards have been retrained. Touching is allowed. Swinging like Tarzan is not.

headline: Club Echoes, in Sounds and Moves
abstract: Cecilia Bengolea and François Chaignaud borrowed sounds from D.J.’s and some moves from the club scene in their work for the Danse French-American festival.
lead_paragraph: When the doors opened at the Kitchen on Saturday night, the party had already started. Off to one side of the stage, the London D.J.s Elijah and Skilliam were in the midst of spinning what would turn out to be a fabulous, fierce set of Grime music — intriguingly unstable beats with enough bass to make your seat shake whether you wanted it to or not.

headline: Tear Down ‘Deadbeat’ Dams
keywords: ['Levees and Dams', 'Fish and Other Marine Life', 'Environment']
abstract: For most, their environmental costs are not worth it.
lead_paragraph: VENTURA, Calif. — OF the more than 80,000 dams listed by the federal government, more than 26,000 pose high or significant safety hazards. Many no longer serve any real purpose. All have limited life spans. Only about 1,750 produce hydropower, according to the National Hydropower Association.

headline: After-Parties: The Gala Was Just the Start
abstract: After the Met Museum event, what else? After-parties.
lead_paragraph: Some 90 minutes after the Met Gala let out on Monday night, a stream of celebrities with enough wattage to rival an Oscars after-party converged on the Top of the Standard in the meatpacking district.

headline: More Hugs Please, We’re Chinese
abstract: The act of hugging, once a rarity in China, is becoming more commonplace as increasing exposure to less physically reserved cultures lowers resistance to warm embraces.
lead_paragraph: Of all the changes to sweep China since the death of Mao Zedong in 1976 — stock markets, private cars, fashion — one thing seemed not to have changed: No hugging. Chinese were physically reserved.

headline: Art Matters | At Frieze New York, Mixing Pleasure with Business
abstract: The third edition of the art fair imported from London hits Randall’s Island this weekend, and features a host of compelling programs inside the tent and out.
lead_paragraph: The third iteration of Frieze New York, which opens to V.I.P.s on Thursday and to the general public on Friday with more than 190 contemporary art galleries from 28 countries, is one of the world’s epicenters of pleasure for profit. So perhaps it’s fitting that this year the fair’s organizers embraced the pursuit of leisure via the complementary programming installed in and around the tent. “We wanted to interrupt the rhythms of the fair, going from booth to booth,” says Cecilia Alemani, the curator of Frieze Projects, the annual array of artworks commissioned for the fair, and Frieze Sounds, a series of audio works looped in the fair’s V.I.P. shuttles. “It is a marketplace, and we wanted to create a platform where what could be exchanged was also ideas.”

headline: Islamist Militants Kill Hundreds of Civilians in Northeastern Nigeria
abstract: The Boko Haram militant group descended on the town of Gamboru Ngala this week, firing indiscriminately, torching houses and killing at least 336 people.
lead_paragraph: ABUJA, Nigeria — Islamist insurgents have killed hundreds in a town in Nigeria’s northeast this week, the area’s senator, a resident and the Nigerian news media reported on Wednesday, as more than 200 schoolgirls abducted by the militants, known as Boko Haram, remained missing.

abstract: Meet Alexandra Chemla of ArtBinder, an iPad app that lets art galleries showcase works and keep track of inventory.
lead_paragraph: AGE 27

headline: The Met Gala: By the Labels
abstract: Who wore whom to the ball this year? A sampling.
lead_paragraph: On a night when the Metropolitan Museum of Art was honoring Charles James, a designer known for his dramatic, structurally inventive ball gowns, it was not surprising that many of the guests, including two of the evening’s hosts, Sarah Jessica Parker and Aerin Lauder, chose to wear Oscar de la Renta, a designer whose work seems all but ready for a museum retrospective of its own. Or that Marchesa and Zac Posen, both operating in the less-is-never-more school of fashion design, would be well represented. But who would have guessed that Stella McCartney would come close to stealing the night with a posse of young stars, Rihanna and Reese Witherspoon among them, who turned the red carpet into their own personal party, or that the British retailer Topshop would have as many red-carpet credits as Prada? A selective look at who wore what on Monday night.

headline: Can Hashtag Activism Save Kidnapped Nigerian Girls?
abstract: A campaign to draw attention to a terrifying crime in Nigeria prompts reflections on the limits of hashtag activism.
lead_paragraph: As my colleague Adam Nossiter reports from Nigeria, President Goodluck Jonathan’s government is under intense pressure to respond to the mass kidnappings of hundreds of schoolgirls by Islamist militants over the past month. Public outrage over the abductions, and the apparent inaction of the authorities, first expressed in small street protests, has been greatly amplified on social networks, where more than a million messages have been tagged with the simple demand: #BringBackOurGirls.

headline: It’s the Viral Season
abstract: To create buzz with a web video, all you need is a candidate, a camera and a pet.

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — A couple of years ago, Deena Varshavskaya, the founder of a social shopping site, went through what she called a “Steve Jobs phase,” wearing a single T-shirt: a lightweight, cotton J. Crew V-neck in different colors.

headline: Norway’s Leaders Snub Dalai Lama in Deference to China
abstract: Tibet’s spiritual leader in exile began a visit to Oslo to commemorate the Nobel Peace Prize he was awarded 25 years ago, but the trip was overshadowed by an uproar over the government’s refusal to meet with him.
lead_paragraph: The Dalai Lama, Tibet’s spiritual leader in exile, began a visit to Norway on Wednesday to commemorate the Nobel Peace Prize he received there 25 years ago, but the trip was overshadowed by an uproar over the government’s refusal to meet with him in deference to an increasingly assertive China, which considers the Dalai Lama an unrepentant separatist.

headline: In College, Nurturing Matters
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Gallup Poll', 'Polls and Public Opinion']
abstract: In terms of future happiness at work, the kind of school experience you had is more important than where you had it.
lead_paragraph: I was a college freshman at Grambling State University in Louisiana. It was the middle of the night, the day before a personal essay was due for a writing seminar. I had put it off for days. I had nothing — nothing but writer’s block.

headline: Pictures on the Street? It’s Complicated
abstract: Mark Cohen has found that his love of taking up-close of pictures of strangers isn’t always requited.

headline: All Angles and Curves
abstract: Reissued furniture by Oscar Niemeyer and Jorge Zalszupin will soon be available in the United States.
lead_paragraph: Starting next week, furniture by Oscar Niemeyer and Jorge Zalszupin, two of Brazil’s most-celebrated architects, will be available in the United States, through Espasso, a design gallery in TriBeCa. The re-editions include items that Mr. Niemeyer, who died in 2012 at the age of 104, designed in the 1970s with his daughter Anna Maria Niemeyer, including the Rio rocking chaise ($38,400), and Alta armchair and ottoman ($28,450 for both). Espasso will also offer 20 pieces designed in the 1960s by the now-91-year-old Mr. Zalszupin, including his Circa bench ($17,800) and delicately curving Brasiliana armchair ($10,250). The pieces will be displayed at Espasso from May 14 to June 3, and will be for sale, then and after, along with a new monograph, “Jorge Zalszupin: Design Moderno” ($80), by Maria Cecilia Loschiavo dos Santos. Espasso is at 38 North Moore Street (Hudson Street). Information: 212-219-0017 or espasso.com.

headline: Damien Hirst Plants a Flag in SoHo
abstract: Other Criteria, a shop that sells designs by the artist and his peers, just opened in New York.
lead_paragraph: Damien Hirst has brought his ebullient gestures to New York, with the Tuesday opening of Other Criteria, the retail arm of the British arts-based publishing company of the same name. The two-level 3,500-square-foot SoHo boutique was designed by Michel Schranz and is the first Other Criteria shop to break out of Britain (there are two in London, and one in Devon). Jason Beard, the creative director, said SoHo was chosen over other neighborhoods because: “It feels like London. It feels like home.” The shop features versions of Mr. Hirst’s spin art applied to rugs ($66,700), skulls and guitars. It also sells works by 35 other artists, including Gary Hume, Sarah Lucas, Peregrine Honig and Thomas Scheibitz. Offerings extend from tourist bait like key chains to prints, jewelry and artist-designed wallpaper and vases. A dollar will buy you an “I spot DH” pin. 458 Broome Street (Mercer Street). Information: 646-762-0123 or othercriteria.com.

headline: A Classic (Again) Ripe for an Update
abstract: “Goodnight Nanny-Cam” pokes gently fun at the anxieties of modern parents.
lead_paragraph: Lizzy Ratner is a contributor to the Nation, reporting on serious subjects like politics, education and the economy. Jen Nessel is also a journalist, a former political organizer and the communications coordinator at the Center for Constitutional Rights. They are the mothers of Elias, 4, and Oscar, 8, and the authors of “Goodnight Nanny-Cam,” a new parody of the much-parodied children’s book (remember “Goodnight Keith Moon”?) that was first born as an essay in The New Yorker two years ago to skewer the affectations and anxieties of modern parenting.

headline: New Fairs Add to Design Mix
abstract: Industry City/Design and Sight Unseen Offsite are two new additions to the New York design scene in May.
lead_paragraph: Happily for New York designers, the entity once known as New York Design Week now stretches over a goodly part of May. Helping to fill the time are two new design fairs. From May 10 to 20, Wanted Design, an annual furniture show in Chelsea organized by Odile Hainaut and Claire Pijoulat, will open a separate exhibition in the 30,000-square-foot Industry City complex in Sunset Park, Brooklyn. The show, called Industry City/Design, will have three sections: one about objects, like Italian TobeUs cars made from wood salvaged from Hurricane Sandy; one about processes, like the creation of Alpi Group’s decorative woods, and one devoted to local design organizations.

headline: Your Hand in Marriage
abstract: For those intent on doing it themselves, a wedding offers the ultimate challenge.
lead_paragraph: When Lisa Bayne married the first time, her friends baked a wedding cake topped with bride-and-groom cookies. This being 1976, in Berkeley, Calif., the cookie couple was nude, though the same could not be said of Ms. Bayne and her then-husband, who wore his-and-hers tunics that the bride had sewed by hand from vintage fabrics.

headline: Redefining a Beach Share
abstract: One family buys the land, the other builds the house, and they agree to split the rest.
lead_paragraph: A few years ago, Chad Oppenheim, an architect in Miami, received a run-of-the-mill phone call from a potential client. Debby Lawn, a retired elementary school counselor from San Francisco, had recently bought waterfront property in the Bahamas with her husband, Richard, a semiretired molecular biologist, and the couple, who are in their 60s, wanted Mr. Oppenheim to design a house there.

headline: Old, Good Things Seen Anew
abstract: Recently named a National Design Award winner, the architecture critic Witold Rybczynski reflects on his attachment to the past.
lead_paragraph: A rarity among authors who focus on the relentlessly forward-looking profession of architecture, Witold Rybczynski is generally considered something of a conservative. Born in Scotland, educated in England and Canada and residing in Philadelphia, Mr. Rybczynski wrote in the introduction to his most recent book, “How Architecture Works: A Humanist’s Toolkit” (Farrar, Straus & Giroux), “I consider history a gift, rather than an imposition.” While a few of his 18 books are set firmly in the past, most, like the 1986 best-seller, “Home: A Short History of an Idea,” use a broad historical perspective to better frame the present. His writing has a patient, deliberate quality that is rare at a moment when the dominant medium of architectural discourse is Twitter. Perhaps this is why Mr. Rybczynski, despite himself, is suddenly all the rage. On May 1 he was named a “Design Mind” by the Cooper-Hewitt, National Design Museum in its annual National Design Awards, an honor generally bestowed on visionary thinkers. On the same day he attended the National Magazine Awards as a nominee for three columns he wrote for Architect magazine in which he revisited significant buildings and neighborhoods that were completed many years ago to see how they’ve stood the test of time. (This interview, which was conducted by phone and email, has been edited and condensed.)

lead_paragraph: Anna Wintour and Beyoncé lured the eyes of the fashion world to the shimmering Costume Institute gala at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, but they did not hold exclusive rights to the society spectacle that unfolded Monday night along the perimeter of Manhattan’s common backyard.

headline: Furnishings With Geometric Patterns

headline: A Soldier Fights Off the Cold
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: PTSD never goes away. On bad days, it’s so close you can’t breathe. On good days, it’s off in the distance like a gathering storm.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — On Aug. 4, 2004, while in my Stryker combat vehicle battling insurgents for control of a street in Mosul, Iraq, I was struck by a rocket-propelled grenade. The core of the rocket, a solid piece of metal only a few inches long, sliced open my stomach from right to left, filled my legs and face with shrapnel, tore my intestines, lacerated my liver, destroyed my spleen, punctured my diaphragm, flattened my lungs, shattered my ribs and ruptured discs in my back. As I struggled to remove my smoldering body armor, I watched my stomach tear open and my intestines begin to push their way out.

lead_paragraph: When I was a kid I loved Mother’s Day. I got to make breakfast in bed for my mom. As I got older I started to resent it. I would tell her: this is between us — not you, me and Hallmark. Every day is Mother’s Day. More than gifts, what she always wanted was time. Time with me, with my brothers, with her grandchildren, with my father (may he rest in peace), the guy who made her a mother to begin with. The gift of time always trumped stuff.

headline: Mondelez and Dutch Firm Aim to Create a Coffee Powerhouse

lead_paragraph: Mondelez International, the maker of Cadbury chocolate and Chips Ahoy cookies, is carving out its coffee business to combine it in a joint venture with a Dutch company to form a global coffee seller with more than $7 billion in annual revenue. The joint venture will join Mondelez International’s coffee portfolio with D.E Master Blenders 1753 of Amsterdam, giving the combined company control of coffee brands including Gevalia, Tassimo, Senso and, outside the United States, Maxwell House. The new company will be called Jacobs Douwe Egberts and will be based in the Netherlands. After the combination, Mondelez International, which was spun out of Kraft Foods in 2012, will receive about $5 billion in cash and a 49 percent equity stake in the joint venture.

headline: Sikorsky and Lockheed to Build New Presidential Helicopter
abstract: Sikorsky Aircraft and Lockheed Martin won a $1.24 billion contract on Wednesday to begin building a new presidential helicopter.
lead_paragraph: Sikorsky Aircraft and Lockheed Martin won a $1.24 billion contract on Wednesday to begin building a new presidential helicopter. The companies were the only bidders in the latest phase of a decadelong effort to begin replacing the aging, white-topped helicopters that alight from the White House lawn. An earlier program run by Lockheed Martin and AgustaWestland of Italy collapsed in 2009 because of technical difficulties and billions of dollars in cost overruns, with President Obama complaining that it was “an example of the procurement process gone amok.” Industry officials said that AgustaWestland, Boeing and Bell Helicopter did not bid this time because they believed that the specifications favored a version of Sikorsky’s S-92 helicopter, which is smaller than most of its rivals. The new contract will cover the development of six aircraft. The Navy, which runs the program, is likely to eventually buy 21 helicopters. Sikorsky, which built the current presidential helicopters, is a unit of United Technologies. It will assemble the new aircraft in Stratford, Conn. Lockheed will install the mission systems in Owego, N.Y.

abstract: “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” a landmark exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, reveals an artist interested in extremes but with a classical, architectural mien.
lead_paragraph: So much for the debate about whether fashion can be art. “Charles James: Beyond Fashion,” a landmark exhibition at the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Costume Institute, proposes that this perennial question, which sprang up in the 1970s, was asked and answered in the late 1940s and ’50s. That’s when the Anglo-American couturier Charles James was at the height of his powers, making coats, suits, cocktail dresses and especially ball gowns, creating a sartorial sublime similar to the vaunted abstract sublime of the Abstract Expressionist painters working at the same time.

headline: Big Hands, Small Colleges and the N.F.L. Draft

headline: Charlie Chaplin’s Home in Switzerland to Become a Museum
abstract: A mansion above the shores of Lake Geneva is to become “Chaplin’s World,” a museum dedicated to Charlie Chaplin.
lead_paragraph: Charlie Chaplin spent the last 25 years of his life in Corsier-sur-Vevey, above the shores of Lake Geneva in Switzerland. In an 18th-century mansion on a 35-acre estate he gardened, made films, composed music, wrote books and spent time with his wife, Oona Chaplin, and their eight children. Now three of those children — Michael, Eugene and Victoria Chaplin — have announced their partnership in a new museum, called “Chaplin’s World” in their former family home, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Vaccine Opponents Can Be Immune to Education
abstract: Trying to correct misperceptions about the dangers of vaccines can lead to even deeper misgivings.
lead_paragraph: Vaccines will prevent the deaths of tens of thousands of children born this year over their lifetimes. So why are potentially dangerous numbers of parents in some states opting out of one of the great achievements of modern medicine?

headline: ‘Pinocchio Rex,’ China’s New Dinosaur
abstract: Scientists have discovered a new species of dinosaur, a relative of the ferocious Tyrannosaurus rex, a scientific paper says. It was found in a construction site in Ganzhou in southeastern China in 2010, stuffed into bags and assembled two years later, according to local media reports.
lead_paragraph: Scientists have discovered a new species of dinosaur, a relative of the ferocious Tyrannosaurus rex, according to a report in Nature Communications. The story of the discovery of the 30-foot-long Qianzhousaurus sinensis, which began more than three years ago in a construction site in southeastern China, is one of drama and luck, as well as science.

headline: Classical Playlist: Pavarotti, Berio, Shostakovich and More
abstract: Times classical music critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: BELLINI: ‘I Puritani’Joan Sutherland, Luciano Pavarotti, Piero Cappuccilli, Nicolai Ghiaurov; Richard Bonynge, conductor; London Symphony Orchestra, Chorus of the Royal Opera House, Covent Garden(Decca; three CDs)There has been almost a mini-festival of bel canto opera taking place at the Metropolitan Opera of late, with the return of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” and revivals of two Bellini works: “La Sonnambula” and “I Puritani.” In anticipation of “I Puritani,” I took out the 1973 recording featuring Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti, with Richard Bonynge conducting the London Symphony Orchestra. I can hardly stop listening to it. No matter one’s taste in the art of bel canto, no matter one’s passion for Maria Callas (which we all share), Joan Sutherland and Luciano Pavarotti are thrilling exemplars of the tradition. This recording captures them in their glory. (Anthony Tommasini)

headline: Dan Colen, Art World Bomb Thrower, Gets Respectable. Sort Of.
abstract: The artist, who became notorious for his downtown New York shenanigans in the last decade, surveys his career so far at the Brant Foundation in Greenwich, Conn.
lead_paragraph: Thirty four is hardly old, but Dan Colen has done a lot of growing up since bursting on the art scene a decade ago, after earning a degree in painting at the Rhode Island School of Design. Colen came to prominence as a member of the Irak crew, a posse of graffiti writers, artists, pranksters and drug users that also included Ryan McGinley and the late Dash Snow. Those formative years are central to “Help,” Colen’s new retrospective at the Brant Foundation in Greenwich, Conn., which opens this Monday. “There’s been an arc in my work and an arc in my life,” says Colen, who still maintains a punkish air, but is now a monied property owner (of a fully operational farm in Pine Plains, N.Y.) with close relationships to art-world power players like Peter Brant, Charles Saatchi, Jeffrey Deitch and Larry Gagosian. The exhibition, he says, is an opportunity “to look at the old work and the new work, and really for the first time to consider what ties it all together.”

headline: Chuck Berry and Peter Sellars Win Polar Music Prize

The prize, announced on Thursday by the foundation that administers it, is essentially a lifetime achievement prize and carries a cash award of one million Swedish krona ($153,725) and a touch of royalty: though it not a government prize, it is given to the winners by King Carl XVI Gustaf of Sweden at a banquet in Stockholm. This year’s ceremony is on Aug. 26.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Magazine Article on Geithner and the Financial Crisis
abstract: In interviews with Andrew Ross Sorkin, Timothy Geithner discussed his tenure in government and his prescriptions for solving financial crises.
lead_paragraph: Timothy F. Geithner is finally going public. Since Mr. Geithner stepped down as Treasury secretary last year, he has remained largely out of the public eye. Now, with the publication of his book, “Stress Test: Reflections on Financial Crises,” to be published next week, Mr. Geithner is breaking his silence. I caught up with him last month as he was putting the finishing touches on the book. We discussed — and debated — his tenure in government and his prescriptions for solving financial crises. During a series of interviews, he was surprisingly frank. The result of those interviews — and an early look at his book — appear as the cover story in the coming issue of The New York Times Magazine.

headline: 36 Hours in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam
abstract: Take a tour on a vintage Vespa, pair a cocktail with a view and peer through a window to the past in Vietnam’s largest metropolis.
lead_paragraph: Buzz, buzz, buzz. Whether it’s the roar of motorbikes, the near constant opening of bars and restaurants, the chatty nature of its inhabitants, or the abundance of great coffee, there’s just something invigorating about Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam’s largest metropolis. It’s no surprise that Saigon, as most locals call it, exudes a youthful, inventive energy — after all, over half of its eight million dwellers are younger than 35. This dynamic spirit shines through in quirky cafes, innovative cuisine and boutiques selling homegrown fashion. And when you need a breather from all that’s new and fabulous, it’s easy to steal quiet moments in crumbling colonial buildings and contemplative art spaces.

lead_paragraph: Banksy, the mercurial street artist, typically keeps clear of the disputes that break out when his graffiti artworks are removed from the walls and doorways where he painted them — and sometimes later sold for enormous prices.
