lead_paragraph: Oklahoma on Thursday delayed the execution of Charles F. Warner by six months, to allow time for a review of lethal injection procedures that was started after a bungled execution last week left a prisoner writhing in pain before he died of heart failure.

headline: Yankees Will Retire Torre’s No. 6
abstract: Besides retiring the number worn by Joe Torre as manager, the team said it would honor Rich Gossage, Tino Martinez and Paul O’Neill with plaques in Monument Park.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — The Yankees announced Thursday that they would retire the No. 6 worn by the former manager Joe Torre, something they had informally said they would do. They also said that they would put plaques in Monument Park for Goose Gossage, Tino Martinez and Paul O’Neill, and that Bernie Williams would be honored in 2015.

headline: Richard Ayoade Narrates a Scene From ‘The Double’
abstract: The director discusses a sequence from his film featuring Jesse Eisenberg.
lead_paragraph: In this video, the director Richard Ayoade narrates a sequence from his film “The Double,” featuring Jesse Eisenberg as an office worker who encounters his doppelgänger.

headline: Enter ‘the Strange City’ of the Artists Kabakov
abstract: For the sixth annual Monumenta, which opens Saturday, Ilya and Emilia Kabakov filled the nave at the Grand Palais in Paris with eight structures that represent spirituality.
lead_paragraph: Each year, on the occasion of the annual art exhibition called Monumenta, the sprawling nave in the Grand Palais in Paris becomes a blank canvas for an internationally-renowned artist. In years past, large-scale installations like Anish Kapoor’s enormous balloon sculpture and Christian Boltanski’s mountain of clothing have filled the room. And this Saturday, the Russian-born, Long Island, N.Y.-based artist couple Ilya and Emilia Kabakov will unveil “The Strange City” there for the show’s sixth iteration, which will be on view through June 22.

headline: Hearing Held for Health Services Nominee
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: A Senate committee held a confirmation hearing for Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee to become the next secretary of health and human Services, succeeding Kathleen Sebelius.
lead_paragraph: A Senate committee held a confirmation hearing for Sylvia Mathews Burwell, the nominee to become the next secretary of health and human Services, succeeding Kathleen Sebelius.

headline: Last Minutes on Everest
abstract: Footage captured minutes before April’s deadly Everest avalanche highlights the Sherpas’ pride and resilience, which support not only Western expeditions but also the Sherpas’ families far below.
lead_paragraph: Footage captured minutes before April’s deadly Everest avalanche highlights the Sherpas’ pride and resilience, which support not only Western expeditions but also the Sherpas’ families far below.

headline: An Afternoon at the Improv
abstract: Out of the minimalist space of El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette on the Lower East Side comes mostly comfort food, unobtrusively finessed.
lead_paragraph: There is no falafel on the falafel plate at El Rey Coffee Bar and Luncheonette. This is not an error. What appears instead could be described on the menu (but thankfully isn’t) as “evanescence of falafel,” and may be the most low-key — and satisfying — example of culinary deconstruction in the city.

headline: The Making Of | A Camera Bag Designed to Keep Photojournalists Safe
abstract: The designer Miguel Hurtado created his new bag line Able Archer to allow photographers to carry equipment into the field without looking like a target.
lead_paragraph: The designer Miguel Hurtado’s a-ha moment took place one afternoon five years ago during a visit to Bahia, in northern Brazil. He was snapping pictures at Carnival when a young boy ran up to him and grabbed his camera. The kid wasn’t a thief; he was trying to telegraph a warning to Hurtado that there were some bad guys in the area and that he should put the camera away because he was about to be robbed. Immediately, Hurtado stashed his gear in his potato-shaped canvas Domke, a camera bag that advertises to the world, “I am currently in possession of a very expensive camera.” “Right there I started to wonder, why does a camera bag have to scream luxury?” Hurtado recalls. “Why does it have to make you a mark?”

headline: Kellogg Agrees to Alter Labeling on Kashi Line
abstract: The agreement to drop the terms “all natural” and “nothing artificial” from some products is included in a settlement of a class-action lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: The Kellogg Company, maker of some of the country’s most familiar breakfast cereals, said on Thursday that it had agreed to drop the terms “all natural” and “nothing artificial” from some products in its Kashi line as part of a settlement agreement ending a class-action lawsuit.

headline: A Case for Rejecting Pfizer’s Bid for AstraZeneca
abstract: AstraZeneca’s board would do well to evaluate whether the company’s progress will continue under Pfizer’s management, Bill George, a professor at Harvard Business School, writes in the Another View column.
lead_paragraph: Bill George is professor of management practice at Harvard Business School, former chairman and chief executive of Medtronic and author of “True North,” a book about authentic leadership. He serves on the boards of ExxonMobil, Goldman Sachs and the Mayo Clinic. In the past two years, he has taught custom leadership programs at Harvard for AstraZeneca executives and consulted with the company in 2012-13.

headline: Why Are American Nuns Under Vatican Scrutiny?
abstract: Progressive orders like the Sisters of St. Joseph, who revolutionized the treatment of imprisoned women in New York, received particular scrutiny.
lead_paragraph: The 57,000 American women who are working among the needy as Catholic nuns received some words of encouragement this week from a German cardinal, dubbed “the pope’s theologian” because of his close friendship with Pope Francis. “I am also considered suspect!” Cardinal Walter Kasper, an outspoken liberal church writer, said at Fordham University on Monday. He was alluding to a Vatican investigation into “the quality of the life” at women’s religious institutes — code for Rome-appointed busybodies probing nuns for feminist influences and traces of heresy.

headline: A Mother’s Instinct, a Daughter’s Need
abstract: My mother’s unexpected appearance at a moment when I needed her more than I knew was more than luck.
lead_paragraph: A little over a decade ago, I made the mistake of taking my mother out to dinner on Mother’s Day. The restaurant’s high ceilings contributed to its poor acoustics, and the servers ran around with a frenetic energy typical of the other days of the year I avoid restaurants, like Valentine’s Day and New Year’s Eve. The clanging of dishes interrupted us midsentence, and occasionally, a baby wailed from the other side of the room. It was the type of environment my mother and I avoid with precision, and yet, there we were, regaling in Mother’s Day splendor with all the other people who mistakenly felt obligated to eat out.

headline: Clip: ‘Rosemary’s Baby’
abstract: A scene from “Rosemary’s Baby,” with Zoe Saldana and Patrick J. Adams.
lead_paragraph: A scene from “Rosemary’s Baby,” with Zoe Saldana and Patrick J. Adams.

headline: ’Tis Pity She’s a ... Busy Young Professional
abstract: “Irma La Douce” brings the City Center Encores! season to a close, with Jennifer Bowles in the title role and Rob McClure as the young law student who adores her.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps a small Pernod would help. Or maybe a large draft of absinthe?

headline: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
abstract: A photographer is aghast at how her photographs taken in Guinea-Bissau were used – without permission – to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: A photographer is aghast at how her photographs taken in Guinea-Bissau were used – without permission – to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.

headline: Man in the Kitchen Is Hungry for Love
abstract: In “Chef,” the director and writer Jon Favreau plays a high-end Los Angeles chef whose rise to gastronomic stardom is abruptly ended by a restaurant critic.
lead_paragraph: Food, glorious food! Whatever else it does or doesn’t do, “Chef,” Jon Favreau’s good-natured culinary comedy, works as an appetite stimulant. And where there’s delicious food — plenty is shown being prepared, served and devoured — there’s life.

headline: Kurt Masur’s Son Named Assistant Conductor in Boston
abstract: Ken-David Masur has been appointed assistant conductor of the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
lead_paragraph: Besides getting a new music director when Andris Nelsons takes up his duties at the start of the 2014-15 season, the Boston Symphony Orchestra will have a new assistant conductor as well. The orchestra announced on Thursday that it had appointed Ken-David Masur to the position. In that capacity Mr. Masur will make his subscription debut during the 2015-16 season, the second year of the two-year position, but he has already led the orchestra in a non-subscription program, at Tanglewood in 2012. On that occasion, he split the conducting tasks with his father, Kurt Masur, the former music director of the New York Philharmonic.

headline: The Gun Report: May 8, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: The attack on prospective smart-gun purveyors continues.

headline: Warren Buffett, Joe Nocera and ’Fessing Up to Readers
abstract: When a critical column is built on a faulty premise, the writer needs to tell his readers what happened and why.
lead_paragraph: Mistakes are inevitable. So, too, are newspaper corrections, since newspapers are full of those pesky things known as facts and are produced by human beings, who have a tendency to get things wrong sometimes.

headline: Wine Time in Nantucket
abstract: The Nantucket Wine Festival will feature more than 600 wines — and 25 sommeliers.
lead_paragraph: The warmer weather may still be holding out, but pourers at the Nantucket Wine Festival won’t be.

headline: A Poker-Faced Nihilist, Stoically Slumming
keywords: ['Poker (Card Game)', 'Books and Literature', 'World Series of Poker']
abstract: Colson Whitehead’s new memoir, “The Noble Hustle,” recounts his adventures at the annual World Series of Poker in Las Vegas.
lead_paragraph: Colson Whitehead’s poker memoir, “The Noble Hustle,” is a throwaway, a bluff, a large bet on a small hand. You can sense that he’s half embarrassed to be writing it. His language is so loose and sarcastic that reading it is like watching a guy try to toss playing cards into a hat.

headline: House Panel Advances Bill on N.S.A. Collection of Phone Data
abstract: The Intelligence Committee embraces a Judiciary Committee bill that would replace the N.S.A.’s program for collecting bulk records on phone calls.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Intelligence Committee unanimously passed a bill on Thursday to replace the National Security Agency’s program that is systematically collecting bulk records about Americans’ phone calls.

headline: Grand Hotel Reopens, but Only for 4 Nights
abstract: “Al’s Grand Hotel,” a 1971 installation by Allen Ruppersberg that converted a house into a fully functioning hotel and performance space, is being restaged by the Frieze New York art fair.
lead_paragraph: OVER the last two decades, artworks conceived as participatory events — people eating, sleeping, walking and talking, staring across a table, and doing other real-life things — have become so commonplace in contemporary museums and galleries that a bit of a backlash has set in.

headline: Territorial Disputes in the Waters Near China
abstract: China has recently increased its pursuit of territorial claims in nearby seas, leading to tense exchanges with neighboring countries. A map of some of the most notable disputes.
lead_paragraph: China has recently increased its pursuit of territorial claims in nearby seas, leading to tense exchanges with neighboring countries. A map of some of the most notable disputes.

headline: Shamus, That’s the Stuff That Wedgies Are Made Of
abstract: “Samantha Spade, Ace Detective” has in its arsenal a parody of a scene from “The Maltese Falcon,” as teenagers at summer camp search for a “Maltball Falcon.”
lead_paragraph: Noir will become much more than a French vocabulary quiz word for adolescents who see “Samantha Spade, Ace Detective: The Case of the Maltball Falcon,” at Tada! Youth Theater. This wry new family musical, starring the talented, mostly teenage members of the Tada! ensemble, successfully tackles a challenge that would furrow even Bogie’s brow: creating a colorful adventure about a black-and-white world that its audience may never have heard of.

headline: A Sherpa’s Final Moments
abstract: The Sherpas climbing Mount Everest April 18th were young, strong, healthy men. They were also, it is clear from the video that one of them shot that morning, a little nervous.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The Sherpas setting off up the Khumbu Icefall on the morning of April 18 were young, strong, healthy men. They were also, it is clear from the video that one of them shot that morning, a little nervous.

headline: Holding Auditors Accountable on Reports
keywords: ['ACCOUNTING AND ACCOUNTANTS', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Company Reports']
abstract: New rules in Britain require auditors to comment on particular risks companies face and to say what they did to deal with those risks, as well as discuss how much of the company they actually audited.
lead_paragraph: Rolls-Royce — the jet engine maker, not the car company — used estimates and assumptions in its financial results that resulted in “mildly cautious profit recognition” in an important part of its business. On the other hand, the company was “mildly optimistic” in other assumptions, “resulting in a somewhat lower liability being recorded than might otherwise have been the case.”

headline: Yellen Testifies on U.S. Labor Market
abstract: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a Senate Budget Committee hearing that the long-term labor participation rate had declined substantially.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen, the Federal Reserve chairwoman, said at a Senate Budget Committee hearing that the long-term labor participation rate had declined substantially.

headline: Apollo Seeks a Bigger Role in Europe’s Banking Sector
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Private Equity']
abstract: Apollo Global Management says it was actively looking at buying components of banks, though it would probably stop short of buying a bank in its entirety.
lead_paragraph: Barclays’ pain could be private equity’s gain.

headline: New Jersey, Once a Rogue State, Is No Longer
abstract: New Jersey was on a select list of places where residents were banned from participating in National Geographic Traveler’s photo contest.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to pariah states, some places spring to mind. North Korea. Iran. Syria.

headline: Election Commission Votes to Allow Bitcoin Donations
abstract: The commissioners, in a unanimous ruling, also set a cap on donations of the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Election Commission on Thursday voted to allow political committees to accept Bitcoin donations and outlined the ways that the virtual currency can be used by federally regulated campaigns.

headline: 12 Ways to Learn Vocabulary With The New York Times
abstract: Twelve ideas for teaching with The Times about language — from the new SAT to slang, clichés, root words and more.
lead_paragraph: One of the winners of our 2017 15-Second Vocabulary Video Contest.

headline: V.A. Officials Subpoenaed for Inquiry Into Wait List
abstract: The subpoena steps up scrutiny of the agency amid allegations that secret waiting lists were used to cover up long delays for doctors’ appointments.
lead_paragraph: A House committee voted Thursday to subpoena the head of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, and other top department officials, stepping up scrutiny of the agency amid allegations that secret waiting lists were used to cover up long delays for doctors’ appointments.

headline: Rauschenberg, Before Fame Struck
abstract: A show at the Craig F. Starr Gallery features 15 works that delve into a formative period when Robert Rauschenberg was in his late 20s and moving fast.
lead_paragraph: Scratch an art dealer, and you’ll often find a curator. That’s the case with Craig Starr, who seems to operate in the secondary art market mainly to support his persistent curatorial itch. For nearly a decade, he has been mounting sharp-focus shows of historical works by prominent American postwar artists in his jewel-box gallery on the Upper East Side.

headline: This Time, Tappan Zee Bridge Project Proceeds With Neighbors in Mind
abstract: The new Hudson River crossing is being built with more sensitivity to the needs and feelings of people living nearby, unlike when the current bridge went up in the ’50s.
lead_paragraph: SOUTH NYACK, N.Y. — This village on the west bank of the Hudson River has never forgotten the original sin: the destruction six decades ago of more than 100 homes and the community’s entire commercial hub to make way for the Tappan Zee Bridge.

headline: Ingredients of Nerve Agent Still in Syria, Official Says
abstract: The United Nations official overseeing the destruction of chemical arms said it was not yet safe to remove the remainder of materials.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The last of the chemicals to be shipped out of Syria contain the ingredients needed to make sarin, the lethal nerve agent used in the attack on a Damascus suburb last August, the United Nations official who is coordinating the arsenal’s destruction said on Thursday.

headline: The Real Story About the Wrong Photos in #BringBackOurGirls
abstract: A photographer who worked in Guinea-Bissau to show the dignity and resilience of its people is aghast at how her photographs were used – without her permission – to represent girls kidnapped in Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: A Twitter campaign using the hashtag #BringBackOurGirls has focused global attention on the plight of some 276 Nigerian schoolgirls kidnapped by the Islamic militant group Boko Haram. Three photos of girls have been posted and reposted thousands of times, including by the BBC and by the singer Chris Brown (who himself has had issues with anger management and violence against women).One problem: The photos are of girls from Guinea-Bissau, more than 1,000 miles from Nigeria, who have no relationship to the kidnappings.

headline: Living With Cancer: Careless Care
abstract: Getting mad at cancer is pointless, but now I have another target for my anger: the negligent care my friend received.
lead_paragraph: When I consider what happened to an esteemed friend and colleague, I fume at the mayhem that ovarian cancer wreaks and at the deficient care she received at a university hospital in another town. Do instances of medical negligence sometimes go unnoticed because patients are so debilitated that they cannot testify — especially if they are still in treatment?

headline: Sotheby’s Sales Feature a Mondrian and a Bacon
abstract: Now that the first week of the big spring auctions is over, Sotheby’s is wasting no time touting its sales in London next month.
lead_paragraph: Now that the first week of the big spring auctions is over, Sotheby’s is wasting no time touting its sales in London next month, hanging highlights in its York Avenue galleries for collectors to peruse during the contemporary-art previews this weekend.

headline: Ukrainian Separatists to Hold Referendum
abstract: Pro-Russian separatists in the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Luhansk and Slovyansk said they would hold an independence referendum despite Russian president Vladimir V. Putin’s request to postpone it.
lead_paragraph: Pro-Russian separatists in the Ukrainian regions of Donetsk, Luhansk and Slovyansk said they would hold an independence referendum despite Russian president Vladimir V. Putin’s request to postpone it.

headline: China Presents Its Side in Vietnam Clash
abstract: Chinese officials offered their side of the story in the dispute with Vietnam over an oil rig operation in the South China Sea.
lead_paragraph: Chinese officials offered their side of the story in the dispute with Vietnam over an oil rig operation in the South China Sea.

headline: Darkness Visible
abstract: The paths of a blind French girl and an orphaned German boy converge in this novel set around the time of World War II.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Cradle of Civil Disobedience
abstract: In South Africa, Gandhi forged the philosophy and strategies that would steer India to independence.
lead_paragraph: At the end of the 19th century, Mohandas Gandhi was a young lawyer living in Durban, South Africa. He left his house in Beach Grove every morning for an office on Mercury Lane, where he spent much of the day helping his fellow Indian immigrants navigate the onerous colonial bureaucracy. He kept meticulous records, including a logbook of correspondence — from an English missionary and local planters, and a series of letters exchanged with the Protector of Indian Immigrants about the treatment of indentured laborers. In January of 1897, and again a few months later, he heard from another lawyer who was, like him, a Gujarati who had studied in England and then struggled to establish a practice in Bombay. The contents of these letters are unknown. In a remarkable new biography, “Gandhi Before India,” Ramachandra Guha gingerly speculates about what they might have been. Expressions of support for Gandhi’s nascent activism? Or perhaps “explorations of interest in a possible career in South Africa”? Guha wisely stops there. What is not in doubt is the name in Gandhi’s logbook — “M. A. Jinnah,” Muhammad Ali Jinnah, who would become the founder of Pakistan. “All we now know is that, a full 50 years before partition and the independence of India and Pakistan, the respective ‘Fathers’ of those nations were in correspondence.”

headline: Recovering From a Short Sale
abstract: Short-sellers are branded as higher-risk borrowers, so new loans won’t come quickly or easily.
lead_paragraph: Borrowers who owe more than their homes are worth can sometimes get out from under by negotiating a short sale with their lender. But short-sellers are branded as higher-risk borrowers, so new loans won’t come quickly or easily.

headline: Pledges of Allegiance
abstract: Competing visions of the American dream collide in this account of a post-9/11 hate crime and its unlikely reverberations.
lead_paragraph: Ten days after 9/11, self-professed “Texas loud, Texas proud” Mark Stroman walked into a Dallas mini-mart, pulled out a gun and asked the brown man working behind the counter where he was from. The hesitation in the clerk’s reply was enough to unleash Stroman’s hatred for Muslims, whom he referred to as people with “shawls on their face.” Stroman pulled the trigger, but his victim, Raisuddin Bhuiyan, an enterprising immigrant from Bangladesh — and a Muslim, indeed — would survive. The other two victims from the fortnight’s vigilante shooting spree, immigrants from India and Pakistan, would not. So begins Anand Giridharadas’s “The True American,” a richly detailed, affecting account of two men bound, as it turned out, by more than just an act of violence.

headline: A Surreal Dream, Dark and Deeply Melancholy
abstract: For the first time since 2010, New York audiences had the chance to take in work by Christian Rizzo, at the French Institute Alliance Française and at the Brooklyn Academy of Music.
lead_paragraph: Christian Rizzo last presented his choreography in New York in 2010, and the afterimage of that ravishing experience, at least for me, remains firmly etched. In “b.c, janvier 1545, fontainebleau,” Mr. Rizzo created a stark black-and-white landscape in which a series of repetitive angled positions grew into a hypnotic movement meditation for the sleek, high-heeled dancer Julie Guibert. Mr. Rizzo, as an interloper or part of the set, wore a rabbit mask.

headline: Sugar, Come Out With Your Hands Up
abstract: In “Fed Up,” a documentary investigation into why people are getting fatter, the filmmakers explore who’s killing our health.
lead_paragraph: If you are interested in learning the latest on fighting what’s called the obesity epidemic, you may want to avoid the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention’s website. There, in a section about balancing calories (“Healthy Weight — it’s not a diet, it’s a lifestyle!”), amid tips on reducing and exercising, you can read that “a calorie is a calorie regardless of its source.” The page also features a graphic of a scale with the words “calories in” and “calories out,” as if all calories were equal. The American Beverage Association, as it happens, pretty much says the same thing on its website: “Quite simply, overweight and obesity are a result of an imbalance between calories consumed and calories burned.”

headline: With a Change of Heart, California Senate Approves Smartphone ‘Kill Switch’ Law
abstract: The California Senate on Thursday voted to approve a state measure requiring smarter antitheft security on smartphones, even though it had decided last month to reject the bill.
lead_paragraph: The California Senate on Thursday voted to approve a state measure requiring smarter antitheft security on smartphones, reversing its decision last month to reject the bill.

headline: An Ohio Troupe Returns, With a Boy-Needs-Girl Story and a Rock Star’s Songs
abstract: Cincinnati Ballet visits the Joyce Theater with three premieres, including “Hummingbird in a Box,” choreographed to a score by Peter Frampton.
lead_paragraph: Are you a fan of Peter Frampton, the British rocker behind such late-20th-century hits as “Baby I Love Your Way” (1975)? If so, you might fare reasonably well during “Hummingbird in a Box,” one of three New York premieres that Cincinnati Ballet is presenting at the Joyce Theater. If not, there is unfortunately little to recommend this bafflingly vapid work, choreographed last year by Adam Hougland, the company’s resident artist, to a commissioned score by Mr. Frampton. Fandom is key to keeping the viewer afloat.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Busy day? Catch up on the stories that grabbed our attention.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: On View | Seven More Temporary Art Destinations During Frieze Week in New York
abstract: A guide to the many satellite fairs taking place around New York this weekend.
lead_paragraph: The third installation of Frieze New York is the city’s main cultural attraction this weekend, but there are also plenty of satellite fairs in Manhattan (and one in Brooklyn) to sate your appetite for art. Below, the top destinations to check out.

headline: Glare of a Gilded Age
abstract: Rana Dasgupta examines Delhi’s recent growth spurt and the expanding elite class it has fostered.
lead_paragraph: The financial heart of India has long been Mumbai, but it is Delhi, increasingly, that seems to be driven by money, galvanized by it, besotted with it. Delhi is India’s capital. It is where the nation’s networks of crony capitalism converge, where money seeks license to earn more money. Delhi talks to itself about money — about what money can buy, about the cabinet minister pocketing kickbacks, about the suburban swatch of land that a lawyer’s untaxed, all-cash fee has purchased and, in near-reverential tones, about the ingenious and illegal ways more money can be made. This last subject, in particular, exercises the city’s soul enormously. Delhi is flatulent with greed.

headline: Competing Against a Doppelgänger Who Spells Trouble
abstract: In “The Double,” Jesse Eisenberg wears his persona (who has a double) like a reversible coat, switching from loser to charmer by adjusting his posture and the angle of his brows.
lead_paragraph: In “The Double,” Richard Ayoade’s energetically stylized adaptation of a Dostoyevsky novella, Jesse Eisenberg plays Simon James, a man so unassuming that he barely exists. The security guard at his workplace demands his ID every morning, and a co-worker cheerfully describes poor Simon as “a bit of a nonperson, really.” His boss (Wallace Shawn) has a vague idea of who he is, as does Hannah (Mia Wasikowska), a fellow employee as well as a neighbor. Simon is hopelessly in love with her, in a creepy way that is also kind of sweet.

headline: Wanting a Child in the Worst Way
abstract: The NBC mini-series “Rosemary’s Baby” reimagines the 1968 Polanski movie in Paris, where a sophisticated French couple befriends two young expatriates.
lead_paragraph: People moving into new apartments in New York City dread brash, nosy neighbors. In Paris, the nightmare next door is more likely to be an elegant, worldly couple with irreproachable manners.

headline: Bedeviled Anew by a Pregnancy
abstract: The new “Rosemary’s Baby,” directed by Agnieszka Holland, aims to be psychologically complex, focusing on the loss of control of pregnancy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — “Rosemary’s Baby,” Roman Polanski’s 1968 horror film about a woman impregnated by the devil, may seem somewhat campy in retrospect, but it has influenced scores of filmmakers and spawned innumerable imitators. Now, it has given birth to a remake — set in contemporary Paris, made for television and directed by the esteemed Polish-born director Agnieszka Holland.

headline: The Unkindest Cut
abstract: The effects of the 1947 partition of India and Pakistan loom over this new history.
lead_paragraph: Some historical events have such utterly catastrophic consequences that no amount of “what if” counterfactuals can yield a more awful result. World War I, for example, resulted in an enormous number of fatalities, largely entrenched the imperialism that initiated it and paved the way for both Nazism and Stalinism. How could a different path have been worse?

headline: Time Warner Sets Date for Time Inc. Spinoff
abstract: A securities filing says that what is now Time Warner’s magazine division will become a separate, publicly traded company on June 6.
lead_paragraph: Time Warner has officially approved the spinoff of Time Inc. into a separate company and set a date of June 6 for the transaction to become effective, according to a filing dated Thursday that was made with the Securities and Exchange Commission.

headline: Pearls of Regret
abstract: A collection of stories set around the time of partition and written with an aching longing for Bombay.
lead_paragraph: Saadat Hasan Manto has a good claim to be considered the greatest South Asian writer of the 20th century. In his work, written in Urdu, he incarnated the exuberance, the madness, the alcoholic delirium of his time, when the country he loved cleaved into two and set upon each other, brothers of all religions murdering their infant nephews and raping their sisters-in-law.

headline: Communing With an Arctic People
abstract: An exhibition opening on Saturday at Scandinavia House explores the past and precarious future of the Sami, an indigenous people of the Arctic regions of Sweden, Norway, Finland and Russia.
lead_paragraph: This winter was especially rough on a Southern expat like the Miser, whose moods seem perilously pegged to the thermometer. So he can only marvel at the example of the Sami, who have thrived in the Arctic region for centuries, fishing, farming and forging a vibrant culture in spite of the climate.

headline: Uneasy Inhabitants
abstract: A biography of Patna, the capital city of Bihar.
lead_paragraph: One night two summers ago, I was in a car speeding across the border into the eastern Indian state of Bihar. The unlit, pitch-black freeway didn’t deter traffic from barreling forward at breakneck speeds. In the inevitable accident, a young man was shredded by a truck. A politician showed up, but instead of taking charge, he distracted the police with laughter and gossip.

headline: Heeeeeere’s a Tribute From a ‘Tonight’ Veteran
abstract: Marilyn Maye, now 86, is performing songs by Sondheim and Hammerstein and Kern in a tribute to Johnny Carson at 54 Below.
lead_paragraph: It’s no small feat when a performer, without even trying, makes time stand still. But that’s what the 86-year-old vocal powerhouse Marilyn Maye did on Tuesday evening at 54 Below, despite abundant evidence that the years are speeding by at the usual breakneck pace.

headline: A Glimpse of Léger, a Good Look at Lalique
abstract: The Calder Foundation has bought a sketch of Fernard Léger, done by Alexander Calder around 1945. And the work of René Lalique is being exhibited at the Corning Museum.
lead_paragraph: JUST BEFORE LÉGER

headline: Upper West Side Facade Snatchers
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Shopping and Retail', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'ARCHITECTURE']
abstract: Broadway on the Upper West Side is now a retail strip. But it began as a strictly residential boulevard.
lead_paragraph: It goes without saying that Broadway on the Upper West Side is a commercial street, a cacophonic corridor of delis, shoe stores, locksmiths and coffee shops. But what is now a retail strip began with quite different aspirations, as a boulevard of residential refinement, which in the early 1900s certainly meant no stores. Big chain stores and huge garish signage overtook this once domestic idyll after World War I, but in the last two decades the Age of Preservation has brought commerce to heel.

headline: Apple Publishes Expanded Report on How It Handles Government Data Requests

headline: Putting a Face on Pinot Blanc
abstract: The phantom grape raises many questions, but from the right place and in the right hands, it can make distinctive, delicious wines.
lead_paragraph: If it were possible to probe the collective consciousness of wine drinkers for their impressions of pinot blanc, you would be left with little of consequence. Few love it, few hate it, few give it much thought. It’s not the dominant grape in any particular region. An even closer examination reveals pinot blanc to be a phantom grape and wine, a cipher that offers few answers but raises many questions.

headline: A Teenage Tone Poem, Balancing Fear With Rash Impulses
abstract: “Palo Alto,” Gia Coppola’s feature film debut, portrays a group of Northern California teenagers awkwardly drifting toward adulthood.
lead_paragraph: The kids in Gia Coppola’s “Palo Alto” move as through a dream. It’s a drifty, appealing story, set in the Northern California city that gives the movie its title, about that twilight period between childhood’s end and the start of young adulthood. Here, under wavering palm trees, teenagers slip through homes and streets with the vagueness that comes with certain visions of adolescence. These aren’t the tireless achievers cramming for tests, and preparing for college and the conformity to come. They are instead the anxious children who have — since the likes of Holden Caulfield and James Dean’s rebel — defined American adolescence as a state of poetic confusion.

headline: Unorthodox, Maybe, but Scarcely on the Fringe

lead_paragraph: The Outsider Art Fair has officially outgrown its name. Once held in a Midtown office building during the doldrums of January, it relocated last year to the far more visible Center 548 in Chelsea, the former home of Dia Art Foundation, and also started a Paris edition. And this year, the show occupies a plum spot on the calendar, participating in the glut of early-May events known as Frieze Week — “a high holiday for the New York art world,” as Andrew Edlin, the art dealer and organizer of Outsider Art, writes in his introduction to the catalog.

Walking through the building, you might take it for a well-kept hotel, until you notice the handrails lining the hallways, the nursing assistants in the common areas and the people pushing walkers in front of them rather than pulling luggage carts behind them. For the sixth year, buyers can browse new and used bicycles and accessories, as well as clothing, collectibles and other items offered by vendors from across the country. Guests can talk shop with representatives from the Bicycle Messenger Foundation; the environmental organization Times Up!; and We Bike NYC, a biking group for women. They can even take a potential purchase out for a spin. (This is the first of three such planned events in Brooklyn; the others will be in Red Hook on June 1 and Park Slope in the fall.) From 10 a.m. to 4 p.m., Old Stone House at Washington Park, Third Street, between Fourth and Fifth Avenues; nybikejumble.com; free. Squeaky wheels are welcome. (Anne Mancuso)

lead_paragraph: Young Concert Artists, which has been fostering the careers of gifted musicians since 1961, mostly presents the winners of its auditions in recitals, including a popular series in New York. headline: India Explains Itself
abstract: Suketu Mehta discusses the recent boom in vital writing both from and about the Indian subcontinent.
lead_paragraph: This week we review several new books on the Indian subcontinent. The last decade has seen a bounty of vital writing both from and about the region. Suketu Mehta’s “Maximum City,” a dense, fast-paced account of life in Mumbai, published in 2004, was arguably the advance scout of this movement. In an email interview, Mehta said the boom in “the country explaining itself to itself” is due to a few significant factors: “Publishers can make money off it (my own book continues to sell well in India, a decade after it came out), the rise of English speakers (20 percent of the population) and the huge crowds at literary festivals” like the one in Jaipur.

headline: The Venting Process
abstract: Addressing a need to blow off steam, issues with a neighbor, friendly reminders and unwanted comedy routines.
lead_paragraph: I was in a store today, and two people were served before me — out of turn. It happened so quickly, I didn’t say anything; they were already in the middle of their orders. When I got back to my car, I told my husband how annoyed I was. He said, “Maybe you should speak up for yourself.” This made me doubly annoyed, and I lost my temper with him. I’ve asked him many times not to give me advice unless I ask for it. Now I’m asking for yours.

keywords: ['Mortgages', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Foreclosures', 'Minorities', 'United States Economy', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Hispanic-Americans', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: A lot of Americans are still underwater, but the problem is solvable.

headline: First a Killing, Then a Code of Silence
abstract: “God’s Pocket,” a star-studded drama set in Philadelphia, is the actor John Slattery’s feature film directorial debut.
lead_paragraph: The occasional narrator of “God’s Pocket” is a Philadelphia newspaper columnist and Jimmy Breslin type who is the beloved voice of the city’s blue collar class. Describing the residents of the rough, seedy South Philadelphia neighborhood that gives the movie its name, this local celebrity, Richard (Richard Jenkins), muses out loud with barbed affection: “Everyone here has stolen something from someone else, or when they were kids, they set someone’s house on fire. They know who cheats at cards and who slaps their kids around. The one thing they can’t forgive is not being from God’s Pocket.”

Still, the film’s set-piece journey through China Country, ruled over by a tiny, haughty, porcelain princess (a delightful Megan Hilty), is a highlight, the picture of a self-absorbed royal hamlet with its own rules and wigs.

headline: California: Agreement on Rainy Day Fund
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown and state legislative leaders reached a deal to place a revised plan for a rainy-day fund on the ballot this fall; it would create a cushion against future economic downturns and allow the state to use extra cash to pay down long-term debt.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Jerry Brown and state legislative leaders reached a deal Thursday to place a revised plan for a rainy-day fund on the ballot this fall; it would create a cushion against future economic downturns and allow the state to use extra cash to pay down long-term debt. Mr. Brown, who is running for his fourth term this fall, has been pushing for the measure, which he says is the only way to bolster the state’s finances for the long term. Under the plan, spikes in money collected from capital gains taxes would be diverted to the fund, with some money set aside for debt payments on pensions. The Legislature would also be required to set aside 1.5 percent of general revenue for the fund each year, and money could be withdrawn from the fund only if overall revenue did not meet historic spending levels. The Legislature is expected to approve the proposal next week so that the measure can be placed on the November ballot.

abstract: Pamela Paul discussed the decisions made on a weekly basis at The Times’s Book Review, and the thinking behind this week’s cover.
lead_paragraph: One of the biggest decisions we make every week at the Book Review is: What will be on the cover? Most weeks, there is a standout novel or work of nonfiction or an extremely commanding review by a prominent author or critic that demands attention. Stephen King on Donna Tartt’s “Goldfinch,” for example. Barbara Kingsolver on Elizabeth Gilbert’s “Signature of All Things.” Or we group a few books together, as we did last week with three biographies about James Madison, John Quincy Adams and Louisa Catherine Adams.Occasionally, we run a theme issue, like one we did in April on money or one last year that looked at writing about sex. This week, we did something slightly different. While we didn’t create an entire issue around a theme, we decided to highlight six new books on the cover that took on the subcontinent as their subject matter. These spring releases really stood out: Rana Dasgupta’s “Capital,” John Keay’s “Midnight’s Descendants,” Ramachandra Guha’s “Gandhi Before India,” Saadat Hasan Manto’s “Bombay Stories,” Anand Giridharadas’s “True American” and Amitava Kumar’s “Matter of Rats.”

headline: Three Walls in Search of a Ball
abstract: Ireland’s abandoned handball alleys.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, handball was one of the most beloved sports in Ireland, its typical three-walled alley, or court, a fixture in villages and at crossroads. But these were “more than just places where people came to play handball,” says the photographer Kenneth O Halloran, who visited nearly a hundred abandoned courts in Ireland and Northern Ireland last year. “People came to socialize, to dance.” After the game moved indoors around the 1950s, many courts that were not demolished became places for parking or storage. There is little nostalgia among the Irish for handball alleys, O Halloran says. “I don’t think people would value them the way they value a traditional cottage, old crosses or ancient ruins,” he says. “A lot of people see them as eyesores.” Julie Bosman

headline: Addict. Informant. Mother.
abstract: Caught between the dealers and the cops in Hazleton, Pa., is a woman with a bad habit.
lead_paragraph: One day last summer, Ann and her husband, Tom, walked two and a half hours to reach Hazleton, a onetime mining town in eastern Pennsylvania. They had lived there until July, when they were evicted and moved in with Ann’s mother in Sugarloaf, a more affluent township nearby. There was not much to miss about Hazleton, with its decaying downtown and its fading homes spotted with satellite dishes, but to Ann and Tom the town held a shimmering appeal: It had heroin, a lot of it. They had called the usual friends for a ride, with no luck, and their own car had been repossessed. So at midday, the two left Ann’s mother’s condominium by foot and followed the asphalt out of the valley all the way to Hazleton. Eventually they turned onto Alter Street, where, especially in summer, heroin dealers greeted customers outside a packed barbershop and a busy pawnshop, clustering around them, competing for business. Sometimes Ann and Tom joined other users they knew behind a building, where someone had left a tattered couch. Sometimes they got high in an abandoned garage on a side street. Though the walk that day to Alter Street was long, it was worth it to them both: Tom, especially, loved heroin, and Ann loved Tom, and the march to Hazleton was as much about need as it was about love.

headline: Unfrozen
abstract: An ailing woman, her fiancé and his brother wrestle with love, loss and hope in Michael Cunningham’s novel.
lead_paragraph: “Meteorology is not superfluous to the story,” W. G. Sebald advised the students in one of his final fiction-writing classes. It’s an observation that has never seemed lost on Michael Cunningham. Consider how he introduces Virginia Woolf’s last afternoon on earth in the opening sentence of his Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, “The Hours”: “She hurries from the house, wearing a coat too heavy for the weather.” And his 2010 novel “By Nightfall” ended with some rather Joycean evening snow tapping at the bedroom window of an affluent, troubled Manhattan husband, a man about to have a reckoning with his own self-centeredness. (Another excellent tip from Sebald: “I can only encourage you to steal as much as you can.”)

headline: Captive Rites
abstract: In this debut novel, a woman faces a kidnapping in Haiti and a father unwilling to pay her ransom.
lead_paragraph: Contemporary tellings tend to mask the real horrors of the original Brothers Grimm stories and their ilk. We remember the princess and the happy ending. We’d rather forget that a passing stranger raped Sleeping Beauty as she lay unconscious, or that Snow White’s jealous stepmother not only called for her death but wanted to eat her liver and lungs. Roxane Gay’s striking debut novel, “An Untamed State,” is a fairy tale in this vein, its complex and fragile moral arrived at through great pain and high cost.

lead_paragraph: Update | May 14, 2014: We have added a contribution from 230 girls and their teachers at a school in Panama City, Panama. Scroll to the bottom of this post to see it.

headline: Rebel Prince Shines a Harsh Light on Morocco
abstract: Prince Moulay Hicham has long been estranged from his royal family, and his new book offering political criticism along with the inside scoop is causing a stir.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — HE sat in the car, frozen with fear, as gunmen pointed rifles at his pregnant mother in the driver’s seat beside him. They were rushing to the king’s birthday party because they had heard there was a commotion. It was the summer of 1971, and the Moroccan Army killed over 100 party guests in its attempt to overthrow the monarchy. The gunmen spared the pregnant woman and her 7-year-old son. Later that day, the coup failed.

headline: Today in Small Business: Birth of a Food Fad
abstract: How to beat the big chains. How to brainstorm the perfect name for your company. And the best-selling products of all time.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Guilty as Sin
abstract: In Philip Kerr’s “Prayer,” an F.B.I. agent investigates the curious deaths of some prominent atheists.
lead_paragraph: Bernie Gunther, the sardonic German detective in Philip Kerr’s historical crime novels, survived World War II with life, limb and integrity intact. But Bernie was only up against the entire Nazi high command. In PRAYER (Putnam, $26.95), Kerr introduces us to Gil Martins, an F.B.I. agent with the domestic terrorism unit in Houston who seems to be doing battle with Almighty God himself — or whoever is murdering prominent atheists in his name. As an ex-Catholic and wavering evangelical Christian, Martins is an avid consumer of what he calls “atheist porn” by writers like Richard Dawkins. And when his friend, the worldly Bishop Eamon Coogan, asks him to look into the curious deaths of some prominent atheists, he’s drawn into a mystery that defies both faith and logic.

headline: Patients and Fortitude
abstract: What doctors are learning from the experience of two men in Germany who appear to have been cured of AIDS.
lead_paragraph: For the deadliest medical conditions, “cure” is a word even the most optimistic doctors try to resist. Oncologists have seen too often how a few metastatic cancer cells can endure every poison medicine throws at them, chemical or radioactive, only to lurk silently for years before staging a triumphant return. No wonder pharmaceutical companies prefer to ­describe their state-of-the-art cancer drugs in terms of five-year survival rates, with no promises about what happens in Year 6.

headline: Ford Recalls 1.4 Million Crossovers; G.M. Recalls 9,000 Sedans

lead_paragraph: In two actions, Ford is recalling nearly 1.4 million vehicles from the 2013-14 model years for an air bag malfunction and door handles that may not latch properly, the automaker said Friday. The air bag issue covers about 692,500 Escape and C-Max models, including 591,000 in the United States, about 78,000 in Canada and almost 19,700 in Mexico.

headline: A Mother in Absentia
abstract: A novel recounts a parent’s descent into mental illness.
lead_paragraph: In her wrenching new book, a memoir camouflaged as a novel, the prominent French writer Delphine de Vigan sets out to “write my mother,” tracing the life of the woman she calls Lucile Poirier from her early childhood just after World War II to her suicide in 2008 at the age of 61. Woven into this dark tale is the equally absorbing story of a daughter’s quest to research and imagine an elusive woman in order to get close to her, even though her very essence embodied distance: “For all of us, Lucile — her gentleness and her aggression — remains a mystery.” The difficulty de Vigan has in describing her mother, she confesses, “is not so far removed from the distress we felt as children and teenagers when she disappeared.” Which she did, dramatically, in a series of manic episodes, beginning in her early 30s.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Greg Iles, whose thriller “Natchez Burning” enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2, reworked the novel after a car crash that left him in a coma for eight days.
lead_paragraph: Life’s Too Short: Greg Iles’s thriller “Natchez Burning,” about racism and murder in the Jim Crow South, is his first new novel in five years. That’s a long time between books for a writer whose previous best sellers arrived as regularly as the Olympics, every two years or so. But Iles has a good excuse. In 2011, when he was putting the finishing touches on an earlier version of “Natchez Burning,” he was in a car crash that tore his aorta, left him in a coma for eight days and resulted in the loss of his right leg below the knee. The accident, along with the death of his father a year earlier, inspired him to have another go at his novel. “I realized that life was too short to pull any punches,” Iles told The Greenville News in South Carolina earlier this month. “I decided there was no room in this book for formula and fluff. The story had to be handled with appropriate gravitas. I had to deal with it not only the way it deserved but in a way that would make my father proud.” The reworked “Natchez Burning” — which enters the hardcover fiction list at No. 2 — clocks in at almost 800 pages, and is the first of a planned trilogy. Among other things, it explores the role of social elites in allowing racism to thrive. “The white lower middle class and lower class did not commit those acts of violence in a vacuum,” Iles told The Greenville News. “They had been given tacit approval by the upper levels of white society.” Nor, he said, is such racism restricted to the past. “Look at the scandal over the comments by the Clippers’ owner,” he said, referring to Donald Sterling. “The legacy of slavery is the greatest psychic wound in the American character. We still haven’t fully dealt with it, and I think it’ll take another lifetime to deal with it.”

headline: All Year Round
abstract: Three picture books send children off on a journey through the four seasons.
lead_paragraph: The seasons of the year tell a tale that resonates deep inside us. No matter where you start in the calendar, the passing of the seasons presents a beginning, middle and end that is hard-wired to our emotional metabolism. This applies equally to adults and children. A year is a drama in four acts. With a plot like that, you don’t even need a story.

headline: Grand Experiment
abstract: Can “Betty Cornell’s Teen-Age Popularity Guide” get you through the eighth grade? Maya Van Wagenen gives it a try.
lead_paragraph: When you’re in middle school, you’re a mess. It’s a world of boys with wispy mustaches and bro-tanks revealing an absence of armpit hair. They make comments like “Damn, that girl is sexy” in cracked voices stuck in the transition between too high and too deep. It’s even worse for girls. The moment they get to middle school they start putting on makeup, and they put it on wrong. Growth spurts make them tall and goofy; acne arrives along with a period they are not sure how to manage. At that exact moment, they develop a dream — more of an obsession, really: to be popular. This is when the pain begins.

headline: Fantasy Island
abstract: Four teenagers enjoy summer on a private retreat until a mysterious accident changes everything.
lead_paragraph: A patrician New England clan decamps to their private island off Martha’s Vineyard for the summer. Of the dozen or so Sinclair family members in residence, “No one is a criminal. No one is an addict. No one is a failure.” Three lies, the first of many, provide an irresistible premise for this ticking bomb of a novel by E. Lockhart.

headline: An Update on 4 Students After a College Year
abstract: Last year 66 seniors shared their college application essays that addressed class and money, and four were published. Here’s where the four students are now.
lead_paragraph: In response to a request from Ron Lieber, the Your Money columnist, asking high school seniors to share their college application essays that covered the subjects of money, class, working or the economy, 66 students last year submitted their work. We picked four to run online. Here’s an update on the students we featured in the column last May.

headline: Out-of-Body Experience
abstract: After a premature death, a teenager returns to life when his cryogenically frozen head is transplanted.
lead_paragraph: As far as I can recall — and it’s been a while — being a teenager is confusing. You have to wrestle with all sorts of ­issues related to your identity, and the biggest struggle is simply feeling comfortable in your skin. That’s why the premise of John Corey Whaley’s young adult novel “Noggin” — outlandish as it is — has such wonderful resonance. It takes the idea of being alienated from your own body and makes it literal.

headline: Heart of a Champion
abstract: Basketball-playing twins find challenges to their relationship on and off the court in Kwame Alexander’s verse novel.
lead_paragraph: Josh and JB are twins, double trouble on the basketball court, almost 13 years old. When we first encounter them in Kwame Alexander’s beautifully measured novel of life and lines, “The Crossover,” they are deep into a year when everything changes. The story is written in verse, but have no fear: Here, poetry is in service to the interior and exterior worlds of Josh, who plays forward to JB’s shooting guard. Besides being an inch taller and the one with dreadlocks to his neck, Josh is also the brother with the larger vocabulary — by the novel’s end, he will define 12 important words and terms.

headline: Slumber Party
abstract: From lullabies to tall tales and animal menageries, these books explore the magic and mystery of nighttime.
lead_paragraph: I don’t know about yours, but my bedtime reading does not generally — ever, actually — include books about falling asleep. This should seem strange only to young children, for whom the provision of books about sleeping and not sleeping has captured a large slice of the picture book market. Dr. Robert Needlman, who revised and updated Dr. Benjamin Spock’s “Baby and Child Care,” once told me that the purpose of bedtime stories is to give the imagination a kind of way station between wakefulness and sleep that facilitates an easier slip into unconsciousness. (We were talking about young children, but I think this goes for all of us.) So books for bedtime, sure. But why about? Four new books, swaddled in practically identical shades of sleepy-time blue, attempt to make a case for the genre. Some do a better job than others.

headline: Little Sister, Big Plans
abstract: A sociable girl tries to help her older sibling overcome her shyness in this middle-grade novel.
lead_paragraph: In literature, as in life, sisters are always compared with one another. There’s the smart one and the pretty one. The shy one and the one who gets invited everywhere. Older sisters are supposed to know better, while younger ones are usually up to something. Little sisters tend to feel left out. Who can forget Amy March tossing Jo’s manuscript into the fire because she wasn’t invited to the play? Or Ramona Quimby baking her doll into ­Beezus’ birthday cake?

headline: Seeing Reds
abstract: In a middle-grade novel, two friends search for Communists rumored to be living in their town.
lead_paragraph: The year might be 1953, but in Megan Frazer Blakemore’s “The Spy Catchers of Maple Hill,” Hazel Kaplansky has to put up with the same baloney that many a contemporary fifth grader faces. She’s sick of dealing with mean-girl bullies and getting stuck playing the triangle in music class. The brainy and impulsive girl thinks that if she exposes the new town gravedigger as a Communist, everyone from her inattentive parents to Senator McCarthy himself will recognize her as the heroine she’s meant to be.

headline: Collapse of Ad Giants’ Merger Deals Blow to Moelis

lead_paragraph: When Moelis & Company began wooing prospective investors for its initial public offering earlier this year, one of its main talking points was its presence on big deals.

headline: While the Battle Rages On
abstract: Evacuated from London during World War II, L. M. Elliott’s young heroes endure the culture shock of life in rural America.
lead_paragraph: The experiences of children evacuated from London to rural England during the Blitz are familiar to fiction readers, thanks in large part to C. S. Lewis’s Narnia chronicles and, more recently, Michelle Magorian’s “Good Night, Mr. Tom.” Less well known is the story of the thousands of children who were sent across the ocean to live with American families. L. M. Elliott brings these reluctant immigrants to our attention in “Across a War-Tossed Sea,” an engaging but uneven tale of two English brothers, Charles and Wesley, who find themselves dispatched to a Virginia farm in 1943.

headline: Where There’s Smoke
abstract: Fire-breathing dragons, stirred up by human industry, terrorize a small town in this young adult tale set in modern-day Ontario.
lead_paragraph: Listen! Long have we known of the dangers of carbon emissions. But even those of us who believe human activity is forever damaging the climate find it difficult to change our everyday behavior, because the real cost of a short drive to the grocery store just doesn’t register.

headline: One Morning in June
abstract: Rick Atkinson adapts his best-selling account of the Normandy invasion for readers in the middle grades.
lead_paragraph: On the morning of May 5, 1944, 146 Allied generals, admirals, officers and staff members filed past military policemen into the chilly auditorium of St. Paul’s School in London. German bombs had blown out 700 of the school’s windows; its students had been evacuated to the countryside. The military men sat on hard benches with overcoats buttoned, blankets on laps. Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower, standing before a 30-foot-wide plaster relief map of the coast of Normandy, announced that if anyone saw a problem with the plan the group was about to hear, he should speak up. “I have no sympathy with anyone,” he said, “whatever his station, who will not brook criticism.” Then the “wiry, elfin” British Gen. Bernard L. Montgomery began, “in his reedy voice, each word as sharply creased as his trousers,” to describe the invasion intended to mortally wound Hitler’s Third Reich.

headline: At Evangelical Colleges, Leadership Is Often the Family Business
abstract: Descendants tend to succeed founders as president of some of the more prominent Christian institutions.
lead_paragraph: During the past school year, several leading American universities, including Yale, Princeton, Dartmouth and Carnegie-Mellon, welcomed new presidents. These men were leading scholars, and they were experienced administrators; in some cases, they held degrees from the universities they now lead. And none of them — not one — inherited the job from his father or mother.

headline: Grief Lessons
abstract: The process of recovering from the death of a sibling is explored in two young adult novels.
lead_paragraph: When a friend in high school told me “The Catcher in the Rye” was the funniest book he’d ever read, I picked up a copy — and sobbed my way through it. To my friend, Holden Caulfield was a hilarious smart aleck; to me, he was a bereft sibling, falling apart after his younger brother’s death.

headline: That Amherst Belle
abstract: In two middle-grade verse novels, Emily Dickinson serves as a source of inspiration and adventure.
lead_paragraph: In the daily lives of most American children today, poetry has gone missing. Almost entirely absent from elementary school curriculums, rarely chosen as bedtime reading by parents, poetry — formerly a joyful accouterment of youth, an inexhaustible gift — seems forgotten. Yet poetry and children belong together. And who, among the great American poets, could be more appropriate for childhood than Emily Dickinson?

lead_paragraph: ODDS AGAINST TOMORROW,  by Nathaniel Rich. (Picador, $16.) In Rich’s apocalyptic second novel, an earthquake has leveled Seattle and a brilliant, neurotic mathematician named Mitchell Zukor spends his days calculating worst-case scenarios for a shadowy consulting firm that indemnifies corporations against potential disasters. Mitchell suffers from visions of nuclear fallout and modern black plagues, but his prognostications acquire near-mythic status after a storm engulfs New York City.

headline: A Plan Built on Assumptions
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Affordable Housing']
abstract: Mayor Bill de Blasio’s 10-year housing plan relies on a rate of housing production higher than anything we have witnessed in a long time.
lead_paragraph: This past week, on a day when fast-food workers gathered in front of a McDonald’s in downtown Manhattan to announce that they would strike again on May 15 to demand higher wages, clergy members from various denominations around New York joined hundreds of laborers for a service and pray-in at Riverside Church, calling on state legislators to allow cities to set their own minimum wage. The economic realities of life in New York City so often seem to require holy intervention. According to the Fiscal Policy Institute, a research group, more than 1.25 million residents, 37 percent of all workers living in the city, make less than $15 an hour. More than half of workers who live in the Bronx subsist in this category; in Brooklyn, which has one of the most competitive housing markets in the country, the figure is 41 percent.

headline: Memories of the Paradise Garage, From Those Who Danced There
abstract: This weekend, the Red Bull Music Academy is throwing a street party in memory of the legendary Varick Street club, which operated from 1977 to 1987. Here, some of the Garage’s regulars share their memories of the era.
lead_paragraph: The Paradise Garage crashed onto New York’s nightlife scene like a tidal wave. When it opened in 1977, the dance club, housed in a former parking garage on 84 Varick Street, offered a counterpoint to its glitzier uptown cousin, Studio 54, where the rich and fabulous went to be seen. The Garage, which did not sell alcohol and wasn’t open to the general public, was strictly about the music. For a decade, until the club’s closing in 1987, it was a utopia for New York’s increasingly liberated black and Latino L.G.B.T. communities, who went there to dance until sunrise (and often beyond) to the cutting-edge sounds of disco, soul, funk, R&B, new wave and an emerging genre that would eventually be known as house music.

headline: A Regiment Redeemed

Sherman’s Union army group — formed a line of battle in a clearing in north Georgia. It was the fourth day of a campaign that would culminate four months later with the capture of Atlanta. The division commander, Brig. Gen. John W. Geary, rode to the front of the line and addressed the soldiers. He ordered them to take the mountain looming ahead of them, which was reportedly held by a couple of regiments of Confederate cavalry. “If you take the hill,” Geary closed, “it will be a feather in your cap.”

lead_paragraph: I’ve long been aware of the term “probiotics” (is there anybody who watches television who hasn’t seen Jamie Lee Curtis touting them in those old ads for Activia yogurt?), the beneficial microbes in our guts, and also in fermented foods like miso and kimchi, that some experts believe play a significant role in gut health and in keeping our immune system robust. But I’d never heard the word “prebiotics” until I attended a talk by the Stanford nutritionist Jo Ann Hattner, who has written (with Susan Anderes) an interesting guide called “Gut Insight: Probiotics and Prebiotics for Digestive Health and Well-Being.”

headline: Three’s a Trend | They’ve Got Legs, They Know How to Use Them
abstract: At Frieze New York this weekend, several works make art out of disembodied gams.
lead_paragraph: An art fair is first and foremost a playground for the senses, but for any visitor pacing Frieze New York’s 1500-foot-long SO-IL-designed tent erected on Randall’s Island today — or any gallerist standing by to explain their inscrutable wares — these long days are as much about lower-body stamina as they are about the eyes or mind. A trio of works found around the fair render legs — the pivots on which all this weekend’s deals depend — as art. At Galerie Jocelyn Wolff, Guillaume Leblon’s pair of ceramic appendages truncated at the knee are poised for action, existentially tensed upon a gnarled, painted clay blanket. Adam McEwen’s anatomical gypsum sculptures peeking out of the wall at the Modern Institute look more like hunting trophies; the feet are tucked into bright plastic buckets. And the showstopping, kinetic piece by Jonathan Monk at Galleri Nicolai Wallner takes a page from the Rockettes with candy-colored, mechanized gams that kick for the pleasure of those who choose to cool their heels there.

headline: A Working Vacation on an Umbrian Farm

I was watering the patch of artichoke and tomato seedlings that I’d painstakingly planted the day before, when a farmhand named Brad walked by with a cow. I wanted to get Brad to acknowledge my efforts, but my Italian is limited to ordering and waxing enthusiastic about eggplant Parmesan.

headline: Taking Advantage of Sorrel’s Brief Life
abstract: Sour, grassy and bright, this herb, melted into a pan full of seared scallops, slaps you out of your wintry potato doldrums.
lead_paragraph: I’m not much of a gardener, but when tiny green sorrel shoots start inching up from the pots on my deck every spring, I feel an undue sense of accomplishment. That this perennial herb is weedlike and nearly impossible to kill doesn’t matter. I take pride in its vigor. And then I gleefully eat it up.

lead_paragraph: This is the current state of play in the high-stakes world of morning TV.

headline: Students, Please Welcome … Jeff Bezos?
abstract: The chief executive of Amazon is known for being selective about his public speaking engagements, speaking in front of few groups. Now elementary and middle school students have joined the club.
lead_paragraph: Some children get visits at their schools from firefighters and police officers. Some get time with zookeepers bearing marsupials and iguanas.

headline: Hairy Days Onstage
abstract: If ever there were a season to begin handing out Tony Awards for best wig, from the big hair in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” to a frumpy comb-over in “Rocky,” it’s this one.
lead_paragraph: If ever there were a season to begin handing out Tony Awards for best wig, it’s this one. There’s big hair, like the Tina Turner meets My Little Pony explosion in “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” (with its showstopping “Wig in a Box” number). But there are also scores of modest but evocative hairstyles, like the frumpy comb-over worn by a loan shark in “Rocky.”

headline: A Battery Warranty With a Warning
abstract: Gradual loss of battery capacity is not covered under the ELR’s standard warranty.
lead_paragraph: If you’re considering the purchase of an electrified vehicle, you’re likely to wonder about the warranty coverage for its battery pack, which can cost thousands of dollars to replace.

headline: The Future Will See You Now
abstract: The i8 is BMW’s sci-fi, ultralight showpiece, a plug-in hybrid that has a range of about 20 miles in E.V. mode. But good luck folding yourself into the driver’s seat.
lead_paragraph: MALIBU, CALIF. — Good luck, America, with your efforts to pigeonhole the BMW i8.

lead_paragraph: Cadillac makes good on the promise of Art & Science.
