lead_paragraph: On Friday night, the bar cars on Metro-North’s New Haven line will take their last ride.

headline: Silence Is Golden, and Priced Accordingly
abstract: The 2014 Cadillac ELR is unique, beautiful, efficient, serenely comfortable and electronically avant-garde, but at $76,000, it’s also bracingly expensive.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — In explaining the new ELR plug-in hybrid, a Cadillac spokesman offered this rationale: “Mercedes-Benz doesn’t have anything like this.”

headline: The Time of the Tummy
abstract: The bared midriff is everywhere you look, thanks in part to the rage for crop tops.
lead_paragraph: “Seven Nation Army” by the White Stripes was pulsating through the dimly lit Ab Attack class at Crunch gym near Union Square on a recent morning. Jewlie Williams, 25, a fashion stylist who lives in the East Village, was in front of the packed room, wearing a tank top and leggings and following the instructor in a 30-minute nonstop sequence of standing crunches with high knees, planks and toe touches with legs raised: all exercises focused on developing the muscles of the midsection.

headline: Globetrotting Ambitions, With a Raw Bar
abstract: The menu at 100 Steps draws inspiration from the Mediterranean, Latin America, Eastern Europe and America.
lead_paragraph: In an era of market-tested menus and copycat cuisines, there’s usually a warm welcome awaiting any restaurant that’s willing to branch out.

headline: For the Love of Being ‘Liked’
abstract: For social-media users, a mass anxiety of approval seeking seems far more suited to a high school prom than a high-functioning society.
lead_paragraph: Walking through an airport newsstand this year, I noticed a novelty. The covers of Inc., Fast Company and Time all had female executives on the covers: Sara Blakely, Angela Ahrendts and Janet L. Yellen. I quickly snapped a photo and sent out a tweet to my modest list of followers: “Women on the cover. Not just for girlie magazines anymore.”

headline: New Twists in Turning Hot Air Into Horsepower
abstract: The turbocharger, the engine component that uses the exhaust’s hot air to increase horsepower, is performing new tricks. It is now also producing electrical power for hybrid systems.
lead_paragraph: In the half-century since it first appeared under the hood of production cars, the turbocharger has gone from a silver-bullet amplifier of horsepower to a device so widely used it seems on its way to becoming a fixture of every new model.

headline: How Powerful? Go Figure
abstract: How much power drives the Cadillac ELR? It depends on what you mean by power. And by drives.
lead_paragraph: How much power drives the Cadillac ELR? It depends on what you mean by power. And by drives.

headline: For Dior’s Cruise Collection, a River View
abstract: Dior’s cruise collection was shown at the Brooklyn Navy Yard.
lead_paragraph: First came the glass condo towers, then came Whole Foods, and now here’s Christian Dior.

headline: A Shiny New Toy From Cadillac, Battery Included
abstract: The Cadillac ELR is an intriguing engineering effort and a striking piece of modern automotive art. Whether it inspires buyers remains to be seen.
lead_paragraph: The Cadillac ELR is an intriguing engineering effort and a striking piece of modern automotive art. Whether it inspires buyers remains to be seen.

headline: File Under ‘Uncategorized’
abstract: The 2014 Honda CTX1300 is an amalgam of several types of bikes — sport-tourer, weekender, commuter — without fitting neatly into a single category.
lead_paragraph: DOME, ARIZ. — “You’re not going to take that bike down that road, are you?”

headline: Owners Who Are Happy When the Engine Doesn’t Start
abstract: Many people who own the Chevrolet Volt try to outwit the car’s computer so they seldom burn a drop of gas.
lead_paragraph: It started at the 2014 Portland Auto Show in Oregon with Dave Barthmuss of General Motors’ West Coast communications office mentioning offhandedly, yet with definite pride, that he had bought a Chevy Volt early last summer — and nine months later, he was still on the first tank of gas.

headline: League Races in European Soccer
abstract: Several top leagues have crowned their champions, and the rest will do so in the next week before clubs send their best players home to pack for Brazil.
lead_paragraph: European soccer brings out its best silverware every May, but this year — because of the World Cup and a few impressive performances — the table has been set early. Several top leagues have crowned their champions, and the rest will do so in the next week before they send their best players home to pack for Brazil. Here’s a look at the status of the title races in Europe’s big-five leagues:

headline: The House of D.I.Y.
abstract: In Brooklyn they do drag a little differently, as Stephanie Keith found out when she shot the second annual Mr(s) Williamsburg competition, a nine-week extravaganza where anything goes.
lead_paragraph: The drag balls of Upper Manhattan are known for their celebrations of elegance, realness and high-end designers. In Brooklyn they do things a little differently, as Stephanie Keith found out when she shot the second annual Mr(s) Williamsburg competition, a nine-week extravaganza where anything goes. “Brooklyn is very D.I.Y.,” Ms. Keith said. “You don’t have to look like a girl to compete. These are people with a graduate degree from SUNY Purchase who are already performance artists. They’re taking drag to a new place it’s never been before.”

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Busy day? Catch up on the stories that grabbed our attention.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Still Feeding the Herd
abstract: Max Burger, now celebrating five years of serving up prime ground beef at pared-down prices, satisfies the masses in its carnivorous, frontierlike world.
lead_paragraph: The long, hard winter at last recedes, the heart springs up, and the mouth hungers for the foods of summer. Burger, anyone?

headline: Week in Pictures for May 9
abstract: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the unveiling of the mayor’s housing plan, the exoneration of three men convicted of murder, and the aviary at the Queens Zoo.
lead_paragraph: A slide show of photographs of the past week in New York City and the region includes the unveiling of the mayor’s housing plan, the exoneration of three men convicted of murder, and the aviary at the Queens Zoo.

headline: Nicolas Ghesquière’s Designs in Monte Carlo, Charles James’s Return and the Brooklynization of Dior
abstract: Plus, makeup inspired by Marge Simpson, updates on West Hollywood’s ban on selling fur and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Ike? They Liked
abstract: Imagine a time when White House photographers not only had access to the president, but also honored his skills with a camera.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a time when White House photographers not only had access to the president, but also honored his skills with a camera.

headline: On South Shore, the Lure of the Outdoors
abstract: Reel, once the Fishery, has a post-Hurricane Sandy renovation, a deck on a canal and a new menu.
lead_paragraph: In many places, waterfront dining conjures images of beachfront spots and vast expanses of water. On Long Island it often means a deck on a canal, as it does at Reel in East Rockaway.

headline: Water, Flour, Yeast and Salt: A Love Story
abstract: David DiBari has very specific ideas about how the mixture of water, flour, yeast and salt should look and feel, and his oven is his restaurant’s focal point.
lead_paragraph: If there is such a thing as a genius of dough making — and why shouldn’t there be? — David DiBari would certainly seem to qualify.

headline: In the Air | Tribal Beauty
abstract: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing design, art and fashion.
lead_paragraph: The glories of African design, from vibrant patterned prints to regal embellishment, are yet again influencing design, art and fashion.

headline: Cellist With a Feel for the Contemporary
abstract: The Juilliard cello student Jay Campbell steers toward contemporary composers in a concert at the Italian Academy at Columbia University.
lead_paragraph: The cellist Jay Campbell is part of a generation of young musicians with a fresh center of gravity in its repertory. At this point in Mr. Campbell’s career — he is a master’s student at the Juilliard School — he should, by all traditional rights, be focusing on Beethoven, Brahms and the like, with perhaps a polite nod here and there to modern and contemporary music.

headline: Orchestra Welcomes a Longtime Collaborator
abstract: Bernard Haitink, in his 60th year of conducting, is leading the Philharmonic in a program of Webern, Berg and Beethoven’s “Eroica.”
lead_paragraph: Few doubt the skill and experience of the eminent maestro Bernard Haitink, celebrating the 60th anniversary of his conducting debut this season. But there is evidently some question about his consistency.

headline: Pictures of the Day: Russia and Elsewhere
abstract: Photos from Russia, Central African Republic, Syria and South Africa.
lead_paragraph: Photos from Russia, Central African Republic, Syria and South Africa.

headline: Obama Delivers Energy Speech at Walmart
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Energy and Power', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: President Obama wrapped up a week promoting energy policy at a Walmart in Mountain View, Calif. The speech focused on energy efficiency and renewable energy initiatives.
lead_paragraph: President Obama wrapped up a week promoting energy policy at a Walmart in Mountain View, Calif. The speech focused on energy efficiency and renewable energy initiatives.

headline: Seems Like a Nice Guy. So What if He’s Dead?
abstract: The British show “In the Flesh,” which is up for a British Academy television award, shifts to the political and religious in its second season.
lead_paragraph: You probably shouldn’t draw conclusions about a country’s national character from how it approaches zombie stories. But it’s interesting to note that while the American hit “The Walking Dead” is about sheer survival, the British show “In the Flesh” is about acceptance and reconciliation, themes it shares with the French series “Les Revenants.” In America, zombies just want to chow down on you; in Europe, they want to get reacquainted with you and work through all your unresolved issues.

headline: Paul Diverges From His Party Over Voter ID
keywords: ['Voter Registration and Requirements', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'Identification Devices']
abstract: Senator Rand Paul broke with fellow Republicans by saying that the focus on stricter voting laws to crack down on fraud alienates African-Americans and hurts the party.
lead_paragraph: MEMPHIS — Senator Rand Paul of Kentucky broke Friday with fellow Republicans who have pushed for stricter voting laws as a way to crack down on fraud at the polls, saying that the focus on such measures alienates and insults African-Americans and hurts the party.

headline: Colorado Lawmaker to Accept Donations in Bitcoin
abstract: The same day that the F.E.C. said that it would allow Bitcoin donations, Jared Polis’s office announced that supporters could use the virtual currency.
lead_paragraph: Jared Polis may be the first politician to accept campaign donations in Bitcoin.

headline: Meteorite Falls on Car, Car Becomes Artwork
abstract: The Los Angeles artist Mark Hagen’s new solo show at Marlborough Chelsea uses a Chevy Malibu damaged by a falling asteroid chunk as the centerpiece for a meditation on making the familiar strange.
lead_paragraph: In 1992 in Peekskill, N.Y., a 4.4-billion-year-old, 26-pound asteroid chunk fell on a 1980 Chevy Malibu. The car soon became famous in meteorite-collecting circles (yes, they exist) and has since traveled all around the world. It will go on view tomorrow for the first time in a fine-art context, at Mark Hagen’s self-curated show at Marlborough Chelsea, “Guest Star,” a title that slyly evokes both the rock that did the damage and to Hagen’s own status in New York (the Los Angeles-based artist is unrepresented in the city). “I love the fact that it’s a man-made object that’s been sculpted by alien hands,” Hagen says of the car. “I believe in alien life.”

headline: Philip Roth Says He Has Given His Last Public Reading
abstract: Roth, who announced two years ago that he would never write fiction again, has now announced that he will give no more public readings.
lead_paragraph: Philip Roth made headlines a year and a half ago with the announcement that he had stopped writing fiction.

headline: Fairy Tale Romances, Real and Staged
keywords: ['Weddings and Engagements', 'Chinese-Americans', 'Photography', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Couples visit studios to act out romantic fantasies in what has become a trend in New York, just as it is in China.
lead_paragraph: Kiko Zeng and Eric Cheng’s courtship plays out like something out of a storybook. It is love at first sight. Their first touch is a shy, slow-motion handshake, with neither wanting to let go, until friends pull them apart.

headline: In a Mosh Pit, or Maybe a Revolution
abstract: The French choreographer Maud Le Pladec presented “Democracy,” a work laced with percussion and special lighting effects, at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: One by one, they arrived: nine people armed with sticks and facing off as if for a rumble. Rather than striking one another, though, they struck the cymbals on the four drum kits arrayed on the stage and kept striking them. Maud Le Pladec’s “Democracy” started not with one bang but with many.

headline: For Better Credit Score, Max Out Payments, Not the Card
abstract: Major credit agencies are increasingly reporting the amount of borrowers’ payments, which experts say could soon be used in calculating credit risk.
lead_paragraph: CREDIT reports, which track your management of credit cards and loans, increasingly include more details about when and how you pay your debts over time. Whether that extra information will eventually have a broad impact on your credit scores — the three-digit numbers that summarize your credit report and are used by lenders to size you up — remains to be seen.

headline: Letting an Ensemble Complete Him
abstract: Christian aTunde Adjuah, formerly known as Christian Scott, brought a 10-piece band and a new sound to the Harlem Jazz Shrines Festival on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Christian aTunde Adjuah has a firm, cold flash of a trumpet sound, like the glint off a brandished switchblade. For what seems like the entirety of his playing career, since his anointed adolescence in New Orleans, he has deployed that sound with an effortful assurance: rallying support with it, building bands around it, making it the base currency of his brisk economy of style.

headline: Pass the Bong, and Tune Up the Berlioz
abstract: Prominent musicians offer their programming suggestions for the Colorado Symphony’s so-called Cannabis Concerts, which the city of Denver wants canceled.
lead_paragraph: When the Colorado Symphony announced recently that it would hold a series of bring-your-own-marijuana fund-raisers, called “Classically Cannabis: The High Note Series,” sponsored by the state’s newly legal cannabis industry, the orchestra got laughs on late-night talk shows and was featured in publications that rarely cover classical music, including High Times.

headline: Big Opera’s Den Mother Moves On
abstract: Sarah Billinghurst, the second in command at the Metropolitan Opera, recalls her journey from New Zealand to the New York backstage.
lead_paragraph: At the end of a long week of work one recent Friday, Sarah Billinghurst worked some more.

headline: His Psyche Lurks Inside His Scripts
abstract: “Penny Dreadful,” a Showtime series set in the Victorian era, is the first television project for from the stage and film writer John Logan.
lead_paragraph: Three books sit on a side table at John Logan’s hotel suite on Central Park South: Mark Harris’s “Pictures at a Revolution: Five Movies and the Birth of the New Hollywood,” a history of the best picture nominees at the 1968 Oscars; a collection of English Romantic poetry; and a novelization from the 1984-96 TV series “Murder, She Wrote.” Together, they represent the breadth of this dramatist’s interests.

headline: Swamp Pop and Old Faves in the Countryside
abstract: The British singer Lily Allen, who named her new album “Sheezus,” has eclectic taste in music, including Loretta Lynn, Bob Dylan and Beyoncé among her favorites.
lead_paragraph: The British singer Lily Allen was at her home in the English countryside, baking a carrot cake, complete with marzipan carrots. “This is like my third one with these particular carrots, and I’ve kind of got it down,” she said by telephone. “I’m quite pleased.” She posted a photo of the perfectly turned-out cake, frosted and dusted with powdered sugar, on her Instagram account, with the hashtag Sheezus, the name of her new album. For Ms. Allen, 29, domestic bliss can align with pop stardom.

headline: Top of the Line
abstract: Glimpses of life in the corps de ballet at American Ballet Theater, which opens its spring season Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House.
lead_paragraph: At American Ballet Theater, where international stars zip on and off the stage like point shoes on a conveyor belt, there is gratification in knowing your corps de ballet. Along with the soloists, these dancers constitute the heart of the company, which opens its spring season Monday at the Metropolitan Opera House.

headline: Today, in the Role of Flower Girl: Grandma
abstract: Some couples want to include their family members in the wedding, but not in a traditional way.
lead_paragraph: Like many good ideas, it started in jest.

headline: The Spring Foursomes in Stratford-upon-Avon
abstract: Top tennis players travel the world to compete in tournaments. Now the best bridge players do, too.
lead_paragraph: Top tennis players travel the world to compete in tournaments. Now the best bridge players do, too.

headline: The Changing of Ethiopia, in Photos
abstract: From rural villages and urban centers, Michael Tsegaye has been showing how his homeland has been changing, even if outsiders’ perceptions have not.
lead_paragraph: From rural villages and urban centers, Michael Tsegaye has been showing how his homeland has been changing, even if outsiders’ perceptions have not.

headline: Concerts of Mystery and Imagination
abstract: Juxtapositions are instrumental in the Spring for Music program at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: Spring for Music, the annual festival of North American orchestras at Carnegie Hall, was created in large part to encourage adventurous programming and has in its four years produced odd juxtapositions within concerts, typically with some thematic goal in view. But when it comes to juxtaposing whole programs, anything goes, and the results can be mind-bending.

headline: The Older Cling to Jobs, Crowding Out the Younger
abstract: Factors conspiring to make retirement difficult if not impossible, including low interest rates and fewer defined-benefit pensions, are keeping workers over 62 at their jobs.
lead_paragraph: THE proportion of Americans with jobs fell sharply during the Great Recession, and has barely begun to recover, according to overall figures.

headline: Events in Connecticut for May 11-17, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: A Storied Rivalry Touching Familiar Bases
abstract: In “Damn Yankees, the Red Sox Version,” a reboot in East Haddam of a Tony-winning musical, a baseball fan makes a deal with the devil.
lead_paragraph: There’s a clever new offering at the Goodspeed Opera House’s concession counter these days — boxes of Cracker Jack. They help put audiences in a suitable frame of mind for “Damn Yankees,” the wonderful 1955 musical that won a slew of Tonys and taught the world that “you gotta have heart.”

headline: Literary Help Sending a Shiver Down Your Spine
abstract: A new niche for horror TV, this time with a literary bent, in Victorian England, on Showtime. The first episode is free online.
lead_paragraph: Television is clogged with lurid supernatural fare these days — “Salem,” “The Walking Dead,” “American Horror Story,” “The Originals” — so staking out a distinctive place within the genre isn’t easy. “Penny Dreadful” tries to do so with a combination of literary allusion, fine acting, patience and fearlessness, which, at least for the first two episodes, clicks deliciously. Oh dear; another show to add to our ever-growing guilty-pleasure lists.

headline: A Hotel With Spirit From 1971
abstract: A reporter spends a night at “Al’s Grand Hotel,” an art installation at this weekend’s Frieze art fair. It is a revival of Allen Ruppersberg’s 1971 Los Angeles piece.
lead_paragraph: A hotel is an imitation of home, a home once removed. So what would it feel like to spend the night in an imitation of a hotel? And what if that imitation hotel was really a kind of artwork based on an older imitation of a hotel that was itself partly based on a hotel that existed only in a movie?

headline: Simple Pleasures
abstract: In our latest travel issue, we celebrate rarefied places and exquisite experiences.
lead_paragraph: This issue might seem to have little to do with style: walking in nature, swimming in the ocean, eating supper under the stars or setting out to a distant locale.

headline: Who Is That Lady in the Painting?
abstract: Making its first trip to the United States more than four centuries after its creation, Parmigianino’s renowned, beguiling portrait of a turbaned woman will go on view Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Making its first trip to the United States more than four centuries after its creation, Parmigianino’s renowned, beguiling portrait of a turbaned woman — known since the early 18th century as “Schiava Turca,” or the Turkish slave, from 1531-34 — will go on view Tuesday at the Frick Collection, bringing along the question that has long trailed it: Who was she? Almost certainly neither Turkish nor a slave, an identification that came about in error because of her exotic costume. Some have wondered whether the woman was real at all or maybe just a feminine ideal dreamed up by the painter. But Aimee Ng, a research associate at the Frick and the show’s curator, has a new theory based on subtle clues in the portrait: that she might have been Veronica Gambara, an accomplished poet in Parmigianino’s circle.

headline: Still Elusive: Brahms, in Concert
abstract: The master pianist Emanuel Ax will focus on different dimensions of Brahms in a Carnegie Hall recital on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Brahms is naturally grouped with composers from the Romantic era, but many historians speak of Brahms the Classicist, who strove to reconcile the forms and genres of Viennese classicism with the experiments of the mid-19th century. Then again, Schoenberg titled an influential essay “Brahms the Progressive,” analyzing the Brahms who explored daring harmonic paths and, in his late works, even anticipated the breakdown of tonality.

headline: Joyce Theater Goes to the Dog
abstract: In a new initiative, Joyce Unleashed, the theater is expanding its reach, presenting work that doesn’t square so neatly with the trappings of a traditional stage
lead_paragraph: Dance at the Joyce Theater tends to stay at a safe distance, the fourth wall intact. But through a new initiative, Joyce Unleashed, the theater is expanding its reach, presenting work that doesn’t square so neatly with the trappings of a traditional stage. So long, Chelsea. The Joyce is heading to Brooklyn.

headline: Two Singular Sensations
abstract: Creativity brings disorientation — or vice versa? — in the music of two songwriters and sonic experimenters in town this week.
lead_paragraph: Creativity brings disorientation — or vice versa? — in the music of two songwriters and sonic experimenters in town this week: Son Lux and Chad VanGaalen. Ryan Lott, who records as Son Lux, has collaborated widely with musicians like Sufjan Stevens and Lorde. In songs that lean toward the reflective — “What will we do now?/We’ve lost it to trying,” one goes — his music encompasses pinpoint orchestral arrangements as well as electronics that can be glitchy, glossy and dizzying. Son Lux appears Tuesday, sharing a bill with the guitarist Rafiq Bhatia as part of the Undead Music series. (8 p.m., Le Poisson Rouge, 158 Bleecker Street, near Thompson Street, Greenwich Village; 212-505-3474, lepoissonrouge.com.)

headline: In a Blaze of Confusion
abstract: Documentaries don’t come more disturbing than this examination of the confrontation between the police and the radical group MOVE in Philadelphia.
lead_paragraph: Documentaries don’t come more sparse or more disturbing than “Let the Fire Burn,” Jason Osder’s examination of the disastrous confrontation between the police and the radical group MOVE in Philadelphia in May 1985.

headline: Grids and Steel Spanning Great Divides
abstract: “Jennifer Bartlett: History of the Universe — Works 1970-2011” features 26 artworks at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill.
lead_paragraph: The grid was one of the reigning motifs of 20th-century American art, but few artists have treated it with as much versatility as Jennifer Bartlett. Ms. Bartlett came of age in the ’70s, following minimalist artists for whom the grid was a kind of talisman, a model of mathematical consistency that cut through the existential drips and heroic angst of the Abstract Expressionists. Ms. Bartlett added some things that made the grid pleasingly weird, however, several of which are apparent in the 26 works in the grandly titled “Jennifer Bartlett: History of the Universe — Works 1970-2011” at the Parrish Art Museum in Water Mill. (“History of the Universe” is also the title of Ms. Bartlett’s autobiographical novel, published in 1985.)

headline: Hot Ice: The Tortuous Tale of the Pear-Shaped Diamond
abstract: A 7.35-carat diamond that was in the possession of a New Jersey family for nine years had actually been stolen from a jeweler in 2003 by a stylist who pawned it.
lead_paragraph: The thought struck Steven Zaretsky during a party two years ago, when he looked over at his wife and the 7.35-carat, pear-shaped diamond hanging on a thin chain around her neck. It had been a gift from her father to her mother, and later, to her. What was it insured for? When was the last time it had been certified and appraised?

headline: A Second Union, to a Commune and Each Other
abstract: In their second union, the groom has to win over more than just the bride.
lead_paragraph: GUILFORD, Vt. — For Verandah Porche, there was never any question about where the wedding would take place. “This is home,” she said, waving an arm to encompass the rambling house, the rickety outbuildings, the steep fields and the gnarled orchard that make up Packer Corners, the storied commune that Ms. Porche helped found in 1968. It was also the site of her first marriage to the groom, Richard H. Coutant, in 1979.

headline: D.J. Whoo Kid: A Social Media Butterfly
abstract: The host of the Sirius XM satellite radio program “The Whoolywood Shuffle” spends Sundays on social media, and eats Frosted Flakes at night.
lead_paragraph: D.J. Whoo Kid got his start making mixtapes, so long ago that he actually made them on tapes. He has D.J.’d for 50 Cent and G-Unit, and is currently the spicy-tongued host of the Sirius XM satellite radio program “The Whoolywood Shuffle,” where he interviews rap stars and entertainers as far afield as Willie Nelson (he asked the octogenarian Mr. Nelson whether he still got groupies). Born Yves Mondesir 42 years ago in Queens, he lives in Battery Park City and regularly spends time in New Jersey with his estranged wife and two teenage sons. “I haven’t been called by my real name in 20 years,” he said.

headline: Celebrating Old Times With New: A Premiere
abstract: Justin Peck’s new “Everywhere We Go” was a highlight of the season-opening gala of New York City Ballet, which celebrated its 50th anniversary in what is now the David H. Koch Theater.
lead_paragraph: New York City Ballet’s spring gala on Thursday at the David H. Koch Theater was, for many reasons, exciting. Above all, it celebrated the company’s 50 years at Lincoln Center. And the evening reached its climax with a sensational world premiere: Justin Peck’s 42-minute new ballet, “Everywhere We Go,” a work both diffuse and brilliant whose rich supply of configurations, phrases and rhythms often (if not always) suggests that young Mr. Peck can do anything he wants with choreography: a virtuoso of the form.

headline: Summer Travel Issue
abstract: T’s summer travel issue highlights the power of simplicity.
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s the design of a hotel suite, the search for a perfect pair of swim trunks or the everyday act of getting around on foot, T’s summer travel issue highlights the power of simplicity. We start in Todos Santos, Mexico, a laid-back surf town whose hippie vibes and reliable waves make it easy to pack light — a bathing suit and a few summertime knits should do. We visit India, where the bohemian designer Loulou Van Damme has channeled her effortless style into a guesthouse in the scenic Palani Hills. And in New York City, we step inside the Greenwich Hotel, where the renowned Belgian antiques dealer Axel Vervoordt has introduced modest luxury by way of a three-story penthouse created in his own wabi-sabi aesthetic. Elsewhere, the ladies of the Ferragamo dynasty line up for a special multigenerational portrait; the MoMA PS1 director Klaus Biesenbach parties with friends in Rockaway, Queens, where he’s become the community’s loudest champion; our critic at large Andrew O’Hagan writes about the transformative power of swimming while searching for the holy grail of trunks; and a trio of artists make time to break bread with their staffs. See all stories from the issue >>

headline: South Korea: Victims’ Parents Assail President Over Government’s Response to Ferry Accident
abstract: Parents of high school students killed in the capsizing of a South Korean ferry marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in Seoul on Friday as prosecutors continued to try to determine who was responsible for the accident that killed hundreds of people.
lead_paragraph: Parents of high school students killed in the capsizing of a South Korean ferry marched on the office of President Park Geun-hye in Seoul on Friday as prosecutors continued to try to determine who was responsible for the accident that killed hundreds of people. The parents, holding photos of their children, said they had come to ask for a meeting with Ms. Park to demand an inquiry into accusations that a slow and ineffective response by her government drastically increased the number of deaths. Two senior presidential aides met family representatives while hundreds of parents and their supporters staged a sit-in for 12 hours near the presidential palace. Meanwhile, prosecutors said Friday that they were seeking to arrest Kim Han-sik, the head of the Chonghaejin Marine Company, which operated the ferry, on charges of ignoring the overloading of the vessel. They were also looking into a family that owns a company that controls Chonghaejin Marine.

headline: Italy: Berlusconi Begins His Community Service

lead_paragraph: Dodging a scrum of reporters, former Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi of Italy on Friday began serving his sentence for tax fraud at a nursing home outside Milan. Mr. Berlusconi, 77, was ordered to serve a year of community service, and he will spend four hours a week assisting Alzheimer’s patients. He did not stop to speak with reporters, slipping in and out of the nursing home, which is in Cesano Boscone. On Thursday, he told a radio station that he was certain that he would be able to help “those in need” and that the experience would enrich him. He also said that he had been studying the latest treatments for Alzheimer’s.

headline: Afghanistan: British Military to Investigate Photo of Soldier Cavorting Next to Dead Insurgent
abstract: Britain’s Defense Ministry said Friday that it had begun an investigation after graphic photos surfaced appearing to show at least one British service member posing next to the corpse of a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2012.
lead_paragraph: Britain’s Defense Ministry said Friday that it had begun an investigation after graphic photos surfaced appearing to show at least one British service member posing next to the corpse of a Taliban fighter in Afghanistan in 2012. In one of the photos, a member of the military is kneeling next to a body and giving a thumbs-up sign, recalling some previous images of Western personnel in Afghanistan and Iraq that caused widespread offense in those countries. “This type of behavior is unacceptable and will not be tolerated,” said a statement from the Royal Air Force. A defense official confirmed news media reports in Britain that the incident took place after an attack by insurgents on Camp Bastion, the main British military base in Afghanistan’s Helmand Province. The photographs surfaced first on a website called Live Leak and were reproduced on many British newsweb sites with people’s faces concealed.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Remembering Charles James
abstract: The designer Charles James (1906 to 1978), the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, rose to prominence after World War II.
lead_paragraph: The designer Charles James (1906 to 1978), the subject of a sumptuous new retrospective at the Metropolitan Museum of Art, rose to prominence after World War II during what could be deemed the twilight of splendor, with the height of his career roughly from 1948 to 1957. There was never a question that he was a master couturier. A lone eagle in a world of commercial dressmaking, he was an architect and a sculptor whose medium happened to be cloth. He may have been known for his majestic evening dresses, but his real genius was in coats; he even came up with the first puffer coat.

lead_paragraph: How did Hitchcock make cinematic gold out of the demons of his private dreams? David Rudkin’s “The Lovesong of Alfred J. Hitchcock” pries the lid off Hitchcock’s psyche, the better to peer in and consider the ghosts and ordeals that Mr. Rudkin sees as the fuel of his art.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (HBO) PRISONERS (2013) Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman), a grief-stricken father in a small Pennsylvania town, contemplates the torture and murder of the man (Paul Dano, above right, with Mr. Jackman) he believes has kidnapped his daughter and her friend in this thriller, directed by Denis Villeneuve. Maria Bello plays Dover’s wife, submerged in despair; Viola Davis and Terrence Howard are the other girl’s parents, whose doubts about Dover’s means of extracting information strike him as weak and irrational; Melissa Leo is the suspect’s aunt, intent on shielding her mentally disabled nephew; and Jake Gyllenhaal is the tormented cop determined to solve the case. “ ‘Prisoners’ is the kind of movie that can quiet a room full of casual thrill-seekers,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “It absorbs and controls your attention with such assurance that you hold your breath for fear of distracting the people on screen, exhaling in relief or amazement at each new revelation. By the end you may be a little worn out, and perhaps also slightly let down by the fussily clever revelations that wrap up the story, but in the meantime you are a willing captive, unable to tell the difference between dread and delight.”

headline: 1914: Lillian Nordica Succumbs to Pneumonia
abstract: The New York Herald remembers the opera singer Lillian Nordica who passed away in 1914.
lead_paragraph: BATAVIA, Java — Mme. Nordica was on board the steamship Tasman when that vessel ran ashore in the Torres Straits of the Gulf of Papua on December 27 of last year. The liner got off and proceeded to Thursday Island, which was reached on December 31. All were well on board, with the exception of the prima donna, who was then suffering from nervous prostration. Finally, on reaching Java, it became evident she could go no further for some time to come. After remaining at Batavia for several weeks, she has succumbed in consequence of her determination.

headline: Craft Brewers, Finding a Better Seat at the Bar

lead_paragraph: There’s a great moment in Steve Hindy’s shaggy little history of the craft beer industry, “The Craft Beer Revolution,” in which Jim Koch, the sharp-elbowed maker of Samuel Adams, loses his temper at the author, himself a brewer of note. It comes after a 1993 industry meeting in which Mr. Hindy and others circulated a petition that questioned Mr. Koch’s marketing claims. As Mr. Hindy describes it, Mr. Koch accuses him of trying to subvert his business, shouting at him over and over and using far more colorful language than I am allowed to relate here.

abstract: Standing more than 7 feet tall and weighing more than 500 pounds, the professional wrestler Andre the Giant is the subject of a new graphic novel by cartoonist Box Brown.

That is not the case with “Andre the Giant: Life and Legend,” an illustrated biography published this month by First Second. The cartoonist Box Brown has woven his love of comics and wrestling to tell the life story of Andre Rene Roussimoff, better known as Andre the Giant.

headline: Young Minds in Critical Condition
abstract: Our best college students are very good at being critical. But that’s not enough.
lead_paragraph: It happens every semester. A student triumphantly points out that Jean-Jacques Rousseau is undermining himself when he claims “the man who reflects is a depraved animal,” or that Ralph Waldo Emerson’s call for self-reliance is in effect a call for reliance on Emerson himself. Trying not to sound too weary, I ask the student to imagine that the authors had already considered these issues.

headline: More Chopsticks, Please
keywords: ['Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'International Relations', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: Traveling from Kiev to Hanoi within a matter of days was extremely revealing.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — BY an accident of scheduling, I’ve visited Kiev and Hanoi in the last couple weeks, and it’s been accidentally extremely revealing. Ukraine is a middle power living next to a giant bear, and Vietnam is a middle power living next to a giant tiger. Ukraine is struggling with how to deal with a declining Russia that is looking for dignity in all the wrong places — like in Crimea — and Vietnam is struggling with how to deal with a rising China that is looking for oil in all the wrong places — like in Vietnam’s territorial waters. Russia’s attitude toward Ukraine has been: “Marry me, or I’ll kill you.” And China’s toward Vietnam has been a variation of that line from “There Will Be Blood”: “I have a long straw, so I think I’ll drink my milkshake and yours.”

headline: Real Goal of Abortion ‘Limits’: Bans
keywords: ['ABORTION', "Women's Rights", 'Law and Legislation', 'Roe v Wade (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Editorials', 'States (US)']
abstract: New restrictions in Republican-led states are making it increasingly difficult, if not impossible, for women to get safe and legal reproductive care.
lead_paragraph: Anti-abortion groups that saw a chance to get state legislatures to restrict women’s reproductive rights piously declared that all they wanted to do was to make women safer. This argument had little credibility then, and it has even less now. What has actually happened is that in state after state, with the enthusiastic support of Republican lawmakers, it has become increasingly difficult, if not impossible, for women to get safe and legal abortion care.

headline: With Malice Toward Nuns
keywords: ['Nuns', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'ABORTION', 'Birth Control and Family Planning', 'Discrimination', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Is Pope Francis losing his cool?
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — SO much for all the cozy hugs and soothing cold calls and fun selfies and humble gestures and talk of mercy, love, inclusion, equality and justice.

headline: The Toxic Brew in Our Yards
keywords: ['Pesticides', 'Hazardous and Toxic Substances', 'Gardens and Gardening', 'Lawns', 'Water Pollution', 'Endocrine Gland']
abstract: Chemicals used on lawns and gardens are linked to cancer and endocrine disruption, and many are considered unsafe for farmworkers.
lead_paragraph: IN much of the country, it’s time to go outside, clean up the ravages of winter and start planting. Many of us will be using chemicals like glyphosate, carbaryl, malathion and 2,4-D. But they can end up in drinking water, and in some cases these compounds or their breakdown products are linked to an increased risk for cancer and hormonal disruption.

headline: A Health Care Showdown in Virginia
keywords: ['Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Medicaid', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: State Republicans are so determined to keep low-income people from getting Medicaid that they may copy their national counterparts and shut down the government.
lead_paragraph: In Virginia, there are 400,000 low-income people who can’t afford health coverage but don’t qualify for federal insurance subsidies. If they lived across the state line in Maryland, West Virginia or Kentucky, which have expanded their Medicaid programs, they could get the coverage they need. Terry McAuliffe, the Virginia governor, campaigned on bringing an expanded Medicaid program to Virginia, too.

headline: Of Humans and Nature
abstract: A metaphysical discussion of our place in the universe and the future of humankind.
lead_paragraph: A metaphysical discussion of our place in the universe and the future of humankind.

headline: Lost Booksellers of New York
abstract: Literary merchants reigned once upon a time, but not happily ever after.
lead_paragraph: IN the fall of 1965, I arrived in New York City, flush with somebody else’s oil money, to purchase books for a bookshop I was managing in Houston. The shop was called the Bookman and had several eccentric features: Our safe was the boll of a Louisiana gum tree; there was a room full of rare tobaccos, though smoking was forbidden; and there was even a young Asian man to serve sherry to such bewildered hicks as straggled in from time to time.

headline: Rape and the College Brand
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Sex Crimes', 'Corruption (Institutional)', 'Ethics and Official Misconduct']
abstract: The corporate university doesn’t want to hear about sexual assault.
lead_paragraph: IN last week’s column, I wrote about the connection between college social life and socioeconomic stratification, and the way the party scene at many universities, oriented toward heavy drinking and hooking up, creates distinctive challenges for working-class students, whether they’re attracted to its thrills or alienated by its excesses.

headline: What’s So Scary About Smart Girls?
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Kidnapping', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Education (K-12)']
abstract: The greatest threat to extremism isn’t an army. It’s girls reading books. Want to stick it to Boko Haram? Help educate a girl.
lead_paragraph: WHEN terrorists in Nigeria organized a secret attack last month, they didn’t target an army barracks, a police department or a drone base. No, Boko Haram militants attacked what is even scarier to a fanatic: a girls’ school.

headline: The Marriage Plot
abstract: My complicated relationship with “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette.”
lead_paragraph: BOY meets girl. Boy and girl fall in love. Boy and girl marry, etc., etc., etc. Or. Boy (Girl) meets 25 girls (boys). Boy and girl perform falling in love in front of video cameras, producers and millions of television viewers. It is spring, the feverish time when people fall in love, when people who have fallen in love promise their lives to one another — blushing brides, nervous grooms, extravagant weddings, compressed versions of the overproduced rituals of television shows like “The Bachelor” and “The Bachelorette.”

headline: Daniel Jurafsky
abstract: A linguistics professor on mysteries, drumming and serving Chinese pickles at Passover.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Jurafsky is a professor of linguistics and computer science at Stanford. He teaches a popular freshman seminar course called “The Language of Food,” which is also the title of his forthcoming book.

headline: Lessons in Catholic Judgment
keywords: ['Teachers and School Employees', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Private and Sectarian Schools']
abstract: Despite the pope’s gentle words, parochial school teachers confront a harsh litany of “thou shalt not.”
lead_paragraph: “WOULD Pope Francis Sign the New Catholic Teacher Contract?” That’s the question spelled out on a dozen billboards that have gone up around Cincinnati over the last week or so.

headline: The Benefits of Mixing Rich and Poor
abstract: Head Start succeeds when all children are enrolled.
lead_paragraph: Whenever President Obama proposes a major federal investment in early education, as he did in his two most recent State of the Union addresses, critics have a two-word riposte: Head Start. Researchers have long cast doubt on that program’s effectiveness. The most damning evidence comes from a 2012 federal evaluation that used gold-standard methodology and concluded that children who participated in Head Start were not more successful in elementary school than others. That finding was catnip to the detractors. “Head Start’s impact is no better than random,” The Wall Street Journal editorialized. Why throw good money after bad?

headline: Rhode Island, a State Sized Just Right to Contain Its Pride
abstract: A Gallup poll of all 50 states found that Rhode Island was least appreciated by its own residents. Some residents think the economy and a history of corruption are still hindrances.
lead_paragraph: PROVIDENCE, R.I. — A lot of people here say that Rhode Island suffers from being the smallest state in the country. Jimmy Saccoccio, manager of the Olneyville New York System, a popular diner, agrees.

headline: Saving Striped Bass
abstract: Overfishing, disease and pollution are taking a toll.
lead_paragraph: MONTAUK, N.Y. — AS summer approaches, the view from Long Island’s easternmost point transforms at dawn as anglers casting for striped bass begin taking their places along the surf. By June, the fish will be racing through these waters on the way to coastal New England as part of their northern migration, a biological spectacle akin to the movement of salmon on the West Coast.

headline: Battles for the Crease Exact a Toll in the Playoffs
abstract: Screening the goalie in the playoffs is a tough job that can be a key to success, but it results in a lot of abuse for forwards.
lead_paragraph: Boston Bruins forward Jarome Iginla knows the playoffs can be a painful experience. In every game, he is poked, slashed, crosschecked, shoved, punched, tripped, sworn at repeatedly and thrown to the ice.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 11
abstract: The 2012 attack on an American diplomatic compound in Benghazi, Libya, continues to dominate the conversation after House Republicans formed a committee to investigate the attacks this week.
lead_paragraph: Speaker John A. Boehner appointed seven Republicans to a 12-person committee charged with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, that killed four Americans. Representative Trey Gowdy, Republican of South Carolina, was tapped to lead the investigation and will appear on “Fox News Sunday,” along with Representative Xavier Becerra, Democrat of California, to debate the new committee and whether Democrats should participate.

headline: Advice for a Troubled Teen
keywords: ['Education (K-12)', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'Mentors', 'Teenagers and Adolescence', 'Tutors and Tutoring', 'Children and Childhood']
abstract: An ex-gang member gave the eighth grader I mentor some valuable help.
lead_paragraph: THE eighth-grade boy I mentor had been suspended for calling his substitute teacher a bitch, loudly enough that a teacher’s aide heard. Until this incident, he had been making real progress with his behavior problems in school. He had vastly improved since sixth grade, when suspensions were a regular part of his life. He disrupted class, taunted boys and hit girls. In seventh grade, his behavior, if not his schoolwork, had slowly improved.

headline: When Music Was Strange
keywords: ['Music', 'Radio', 'Social Conditions and Trends', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Art', 'Audio Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: In the Internet age, how do we discover the new?
lead_paragraph: BELGRADE LAKES, Me. — IN 1975 it was my friend Daryl — one of the very few African-American students in my mostly white prep school — who was the champion of the new. “Boylan,” he said one day after school. “You have to check this out.” Then he put Miles Davis’s “Bitches Brew” on the turntable.

headline: Why the Kidnapped Schoolgirls Matter
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the bang for the buck from educating girls worldwide.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column looks at the kidnapping of the NIgerian schoolgirls by Boko Haram, and the similar attacks on girls’ education by the Taliban and other militants, and asks why extremists are so afraid of a girl with a book. The basic answer is that nothing can be more transformative for a society than educating girls and then moving those educated women into the formal labor force. And just as Boko Haram and the Taliban are right to fear girls’ education, those of us appalled by extremism should be investing in girls’ education. That’s the way to stick it to Boko Haram.

headline: The Rise of Antibiotic Resistance
abstract: The pharmaceutical industry must be encouraged to develop new drugs to supplement those that are losing their effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: The World Health Organization has surveyed the growth of antibiotic-resistant germs around the world — the first such survey it has ever conducted — and come up with disturbing findings. In a report issued late last month, the organization found that antimicrobial resistance in bacteria (the main focus of the report), fungi, viruses and parasites is an increasingly serious threat in every part of the world. “A problem so serious that it threatens the achievements of modern medicine,” the organization said. “A post-antibiotic era, in which common infections and minor injuries can kill, far from being an apocalyptic fantasy, is instead a very real possibility for the 21st century.”

headline: Russia Ratchets Up Ukraine’s Gas Bills in Shift to an Economic Battlefield
abstract: Executives at the Russian gas giant Gazprom now say Ukraine owes them more than $22 billion, adding economic pressure to the military presence along Ukraine’s eastern border.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Gazprom, the natural gas giant 50.01 percent owned by the Russian government, keeps ratcheting up the bill for Ukraine, increasing the economic pressure on Kiev in tandem with military pressure along Ukraine’s eastern border.

headline: Stowaways Are Stranded in Mexico by Train Ban
abstract: Facing a lawsuit over violence on board its trains heading to the United States border, a railroad is no longer turning a blind eye to migrant stowaways.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — Hundreds of Central American migrants trying to make their way to the United States have been stranded in Mexico in recent weeks after the freight-train line they ride — labeled the Beast — began enforcing a ban on stowaways, migrant advocates say.

headline: Disease of Pakistan’s Poor Now Worries the Affluent
abstract: A World Health Organization recommendation that travelers not leave Pakistan without a polio vaccination certificate has sowed confusion.
lead_paragraph: KARACHI, Pakistan — Until recently, polio was considered a poor man’s problem in Pakistan — a crippling virus that festered in the mountainous tribal belt, traversed the country on interprovincial buses, and spread via infected children who played in the open sewers of sprawling slums.

headline: In Indian Candidate, Hindu Right Sees a Reawakening
abstract: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh, an ideological group whose fortunes have ebbed and flowed with the influence of the Hindu right in New Delhi, has thrown its weight behind Narendra Modi.
lead_paragraph: VARANASI, India — Shortly after dawn in the village square here each day, two dozen boys and men dress up in crisply laundered khaki shorts and fall into military-style formation behind a saffron-colored flag, brandishing bamboo sticks as if they were rifles.

headline: Against Penguins, One Line Clicks for Rangers
abstract: The Rangers’ Derick Brassard, Mats Zuccarello and Benoit Pouliot have provided the bulk of the scoring in the playoff series against the Penguins.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers’ 5-1 victory over Pittsburgh on Friday was very much about Martin St. Louis and the way his teammates rallied around him after the death of his mother. But among the Rangers who touched helmets with St. Louis as they came off the ice were the three forwards who were perhaps most responsible for prolonging the Eastern Conference semifinal series: Derick Brassard, Mats Zuccarello and Benoit Pouliot.

headline: Going Home With Kenny G
abstract: In China, Kenny G’s instrumental “Going Home” has been used for years as a way to tell people to leave.
lead_paragraph: In China, Kenny G’s instrumental “Going Home” has been used for years as a way to tell people to leave.

headline: Methodology on Supreme Court Analysis
abstract: How Lawrence Baum of Ohio State University crunched the numbers on partisan polarization in the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: Accompanying Adam Liptak’s article on the Supreme Court’s partisanship is a chart showing every court since 1953. The justices are shaded based on the party of the president who appointed them. They’re arrayed left to right based on their ideology.

headline: Merkel and Hollande Send Russia a Warning
abstract: In a joint statement, Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany and President François Hollande of France warned Russia that it would face tough sanctions if it did not help defuse the crisis in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: STRALSUND, Germany — Chancellor Angela Merkel invites only the most select of visitors to this pretty Baltic Sea port, the center of her parliamentary constituency and a rich symbol of Germany’s centuries of trade with Russia and the country’s revival after the fall of the Berlin Wall almost 25 years ago.

headline: When Politics Approach the Bench
abstract: The Supreme Court has long included justices whose voting was often at odds with the views of the presidents who appointed them. That mix, including conservative Democratic appointees and liberal Republican ones, ended in 2010.
lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court has long included justices whose voting was often at odds with the views of the presidents who appointed them. That mix, including conservative Democratic appointees and liberal Republican ones, ended in 2010.

headline: China Says Goodbye in the Key of G: Kenny G
abstract: For years, Kenny G’s saxophone instrumental “Going Home” has been piped into shopping malls, schools, train stations and gyms in China as a signal to the public that it is time, indeed, to go.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — There are many things about modern China that defy easy explanation: parents posing their children next to live tigers, the sight of grown women wearing furry cat-ear headbands while shopping, the performance-art-like spectacle of strangers napping together in Ikea display beds.

headline: The Polarized Court
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Liberalism (US Politics)', 'Conservatism (US Politics)']
abstract: The partisan split reflects similarly deep divisions in Congress, the electorate and the elite circles in which the justices move.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When the Supreme Court issued its latest campaign finance decision last month, the justices lined up in a familiar way. The five appointed by Republican presidents voted for the Republican National Committee, which was a plaintiff. The four appointed by Democrats dissented.

headline: A Contest Shifts From Ideology to Résumés
abstract: The campaign for Texas attorney general bears a resemblance to the 1998 race in which the leader also had a daunting advantage until his qualifications were questioned.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a column for The Tribune.

headline: A Degree Goal: To Close a Gender Gap That Favors Women
abstract: As women in higher education continue to outperform men, particularly Hispanic and black students, there is growing concern in Texas and nationwide.
lead_paragraph: When Victor Sáenz, an education professor at the University of Texas at Austin, began to focus his research nearly a decade ago on the plight of men in education, he experienced some pushback, even from fellow academics.

headline: For Mother
abstract: A lovely gift from Peter A. Collins.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — First and foremost, if you’ve ever been important in the life of a child or a companion animal who depends on you, Happy Mother’s Day.

headline: A Big Spender Aims to Push State Politics Further Right

lead_paragraph: Shortly before the primaries in March, voters in Amarillo, Midland and Odessa received a two-and-a-half page letter in the mail from Tim Dunn, a wealthy local oil and gas developer.

headline: Antiques and ‘Ink Master’ Play Roles in Renaissance of Fading Fraternal Order
abstract: The Waxahachie lodge of the Independent Order of Odd Fellows is defying a national trend of declining membership in fraternal organizations, offering other chapters hope of revival.
lead_paragraph: WAXAHACHIE — Standing in a doorway of their 123-year-old brick lodge, four members of the Waxahachie Odd Fellows welcomed their brothers to a Monday night meeting. In their 30s, the four men were bearded and tattooed and wore black T-shirts that contrasted with the button-down dress of past members whose pictures adorned the lodge’s portrait wall.

headline: In Historic Pick, Rams Take Michael Sam in Final Round of Draft
abstract: Sam, a defensive end from Missouri, was selected by the St. Louis Rams in the seventh round, becoming the first publicly gay player to be drafted by an N.F.L. team.
lead_paragraph: Over seven rounds of the National Football League draft, teams chose more than 200 players, from surefire stars to kickers and all-but-anonymous players from tiny Division II programs.

headline: At 11, New Master Breaks Record Older Than She Is
abstract: Annie Wang qualified as a master after winning the National Junior Chess Congress, but she might not hold the record for long.
lead_paragraph: An 11-year-old Californian in March became the youngest American girl to ever become a master, breaking a record that had stood for 18 years.

headline: New York Police Recruit Muslims to Be Informers
abstract: The Police Department’s anti-terrorism unit combs the city’s jails for Muslim immigrants to see if any might be persuaded to become police informants.
lead_paragraph: One man was a food cart vendor from Afghanistan, arrested during an argument with a parking enforcement officer over a ticket. Another was an Egyptian-born limousine driver, picked up in a prostitution sting. Still another was an accounting student from Pakistan, in custody for driving without a valid license.

headline: Houston Is Next for a Nomadic Quarterback
abstract: Tom Savage of Pittsburgh, who played for three programs in five years, was selected by the Texans. A punter who went to the Bears was the first special-teams player picked.
lead_paragraph: Several notable quarterbacks came off the board during Day 3 of the N.F.L. draft Saturday, including Tom Savage of Pittsburgh, who went in the fourth round to the Houston Texans (135th over all). A few years ago, it would have been tough to imagine Savage’s being drafted, as he was in the middle of a meandering five-year career in which he played for three programs.

headline: Spieth Avoids Bogeys to Claim Share of Players Lead
abstract: Jordan Spieth finished the third round at TPC Sawgrass under par for the day, his one-under 71 giving him a share of the lead, at 12-under 204, with Martin Kaymer.
lead_paragraph: PONTE VEDRA BEACH, Fla. — For Jordan Spieth, golf-course etiquette extends to how he refers to his elders, which includes everyone in this week’s Players Championship field. Grouped in the final twosome Saturday with the 29-year-old Martin Kaymer — or, as Spieth was tempted to call him, Mr. Kaymer — Spieth, 20, was as patient as a hunter in a deer blind.

headline: With ‘Clean’ Picks, Giants Look Beyond Talent
abstract: Picking seven players with no history of off-the-field scandals or insubordination, the Giants are hoping for immediate and enduring contributions from their draft selections.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Five of the Giants’ seven 2014 draft picks were team captains in college. Two were National Honor Society members. One is an academic all-American who spent an off-season building homes in Haiti’s poorest neighborhoods. Another graduated from college early and is writing a book.

headline: In Las Vegas-Style Spectacle, Cher Flaunts Strength, Staying Power and Physique
abstract: The singer, who is 68 this month, unleashed feathers and glitter at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: No one has to put Cher on a pedestal. She did it herself to start her show at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn on Friday night, as part of her D2K (for “Dressed to Kill”) tour. When a curtain dropped, there she was on a pillar in a giant feathered headdress and a silver-and-sheer dress that flaunted her flanks. “I’m strong, I’m strong enough to rise above,” she sang in her 2013 single, “Woman’s World,” and no one who’s heard Cher repeatedly ascend the pop charts since the 1960s would doubt it.

headline: What’s On Sunday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (NBC) ROSEMARY’S BABY In this two-part remake of the 1968 Roman Polanski thriller, the director Agnieszka Holland transfers the setting from the Dakota on Central Park West to the Eighth Arrondissement of Paris, where Rosemary Woodhouse (Zoe Saldana, above) has moved with her husband, Guy (Patrick J. Adams), a writer with a teaching stint at the Sorbonne. Ms. Holland also transforms the dotty older couple next door, first played by Ruth Gordon and Sidney Blackmer, into French sophisticates (Carole Bouquet and Jason Isaacs) who offer the Americans their friendship and a spare apartment. This being Paris, they discuss the transaction in an elegant sex club. And when Rosemary, eager to get pregnant again after a miscarriage, visits an OBGYN, the examining room looks like the rare-books section of the Académie Française. “ ‘Rosemary’s Baby’ bends to current fashions, and, accordingly, is more straightforward and much gorier than the original film,” Alessandra Stanley wrote in The New York Times. “But partly because the story has been so altered, it still has mystery and suspense. And because it’s Paris, it is possible to wonder, at least for a while, if maybe the problem is Rosemary, not her neighbors, who seem so serenely superior and all knowing.” Part 2 will be shown on Thursday at 9.

headline: A Soundtrack Made of Muscle
abstract: Works performed by David Wampach and Claudia Triozzi at Abrons Arts Center focused as much on bodily sounds as they did on movement.
lead_paragraph: Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas is eclectic by design. Each of the institutions taking part in this citywide series has made its own programming choices. For the double bill it presented on Tuesday, Abrons Arts Center gravitated toward the outer edges of conventional definitions of dance. Both of the works — one by Claudia Triozzi, the other by David Wampach — were as focused on the sounds the body makes as on how a body might move. Both began with an open mouth, stretched as in the Munch painting, ready to scream.

headline: Paying Homage, Vivaciously and Somberly
abstract: The pianist Michael Brown’s evening at the DiMenna Center devoted to the compositions of George Perle included Perle’s “Toccata” and “Six Celebratory Inventions.”
lead_paragraph: “Toccata in D” may sound like an innocuous title, but not for a work by an atonal composer like George Perle, who died in 2009 at 93. After a colleague told him that such a title would be “inflammatory,” Perle removed the offending letter. (Atonal and Serialist composers do not write in any particular key.)

lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — Vietnam’s prime minister, Nguyen Tan Dung, accused China on Sunday of “dangerous and serious violations” in a territorial dispute that has raised anger toward China here to the highest levels in years.

lead_paragraph: Three spunky grandmothers stole the show as bridesmaids in their granddaughters’ weddings.

lead_paragraph: If you’re still looking for something special for Mother’s Day, remember: Until this year, there has been no crater love.
