headline: Front-Runner in Afghan Election Secures a Key Ally
abstract: The presidential candidate Abdullah Abdullah won the endorsement of the third-place candidate, Zalmay Rassoul, for the runoff vote next month.
lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Abdullah Abdullah, the front-runner in Afghanistan’s presidential election campaign, announced Sunday that he had won the endorsement of Zalmay Rassoul, the third-place candidate, as part of his effort to gather enough support to win in the next round of voting.

headline: Ukraine Vote on Separation Held in Chaos
abstract: Separatists in Donetsk and Slovyansk cast early ballots in support of local autonomy, but the U.S. and Europe condemned the vote and said they would not recognize the results.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Separatists in two provinces of eastern Ukraine conducted chaotic and sometimes violent plebiscites on Sunday that offered voters just one question about self-rule, while raising many more about where events in the region were headed.

headline: African Rivers May Heighten H.I.V. Peril
abstract: Gynecologists working in Africa suspect that women there are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of waterborne parasites. An ambitious research project aims to revolutionize treatment for young women.
lead_paragraph: Gynecologists working in Africa suspect that women there are more vulnerable to H.I.V. because of waterborne parasites. An ambitious research project aims to revolutionize treatment for young women.

headline: Protest of Planned Incinerator Turns Violent in Chinese City
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Waste Materials and Disposal', 'Factories and Manufacturing', 'Chemicals']
abstract: At least 10 demonstrators and 29 police officers were injured on Saturday in one of eastern China’s biggest cities.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI — A huge demonstration against a planned waste incinerator in one of eastern China’s biggest cities turned violent on Saturday with protesters overturning and setting fire to police cars, leaving at least 10 demonstrators and 29 police officers injured, according to Xinhua, the official state-run news agency.

headline: The Premier League Standings if Only Goals by English Players Counted
abstract: What would the standings look like in a hypothetical league in which a goal does not count unless it is scored by an English player?
lead_paragraph: What would the standings look like in a hypothetical league in which a goal does not count unless it is scored by an English player?

headline: Samsung Leader Stable After Heart Attack
abstract: Lee Kun-hee, 72, has previously been treated for lung cancer and pneumonia, and his latest health problem will almost certainly renew calls for a concrete succession plan.
lead_paragraph: The chairman of Samsung Electronics, Lee Kun-hee, who helped transform the business into a technology giant, was in stable condition Sunday after suffering a heart attack, the company said.

headline: Manchester City Stands Tall in a Season of Dashed Hopes
abstract: Not to diminish Manchester City’s mastery, but the Premier League season will be better remembered for opportunities brutally lost than ones artfully seized.
lead_paragraph: The institutional memory of sports is typically built one highlight at a time. That is the way we remember players and games and seasons — by what goes right. It is more pleasant that way.

headline: Hamilton Holds Off Rosberg at Spanish Grand Prix
abstract: Lewis Hamilton took off from pole position on Sunday at the Spanish Grand Prix and stayed ahead of his Mercedes teammate Nico Rosberg for a fourth consecutive victory.
lead_paragraph: Barcelona, Spain — On Saturday, after scoring his fourth pole position of the year and the 35th of his career, Lewis Hamilton said he had never driven a car that was so much faster than those of his immediate competitors.

headline: Podcast: Spiders With Personality
abstract: Spiders in the Kalahari desert develop personalities that are affected by their spider peers, just like teenagers.
lead_paragraph: Spiders in the Kalahari desert develop personalities that are affected by their spider peers, just like teenagers.

headline: Sabathia Put on Disabled List
abstract: Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia will be out 15 days because of a fluid buildup in his surgically repaired right knee.
lead_paragraph: MILWAUKEE — C. C. Sabathia had swelling in his right knee after his start May 4, but he did not mention it to anyone because the Yankees’ rotation had already been hit with so many injuries. When he felt more pain in his knee in Saturday’s game against the Milwaukee Brewers and encountered more swelling, he spoke up.

headline: ScienceTake | Unlocking Spider Secrets
abstract: A new look at the social organization of some eight-legged predators.
lead_paragraph: A new look at the social organization of some eight-legged predators.

headline: Hagel ‘Open’ to Reviewing Military’s Ban on Transgender People
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Transgender and Transsexual']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said the armed forces should “continually” review its prohibition, calling into question whether the ban may eventually be lifted.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel said in an interview broadcast on Sunday that the military should “continually” review its prohibition on transgender people in the armed forces, calling into question whether the Pentagon’s ban may eventually be lifted, as was the ban on gay men and lesbians in the military.

headline: Rubio on a Presidential Bid, and Climate Change
abstract: Senator Marco Rubio said that he would wait until the end of the year to consider running, and that he did not believe humans were responsible for “dramatic changes” in the climate.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Senator Marco Rubio on Sunday said that he was ready to be president, becoming the second potential Republican candidate recently to drop big hints about 2016 as he vies for early attention in a crowded field of maybes.

headline: The Lives of Sociable Spiders
abstract: A new study suggests that predictable social lives accentuate individual quirks and personal styles in spiders that live in groups.
lead_paragraph: Of the world’s 43,000 known varieties of spiders, an overwhelming majority are peevish loners: spinning webs, slinging lassos, liquefying prey and attacking trespassers, each spider unto its own.

headline: Seconds That Last an Eternity
abstract: Fouls, commercials and timeouts can prolong games like the one May 4 between the Nets and the Raptors, in which the final 60 ticks of the clock took nearly 18 minutes.
lead_paragraph: The seventh game of the playoff series between the Nets and the Toronto Raptors on May 4 was about two and a half hours old and seemingly just about finished.

headline: Rebuilding a Neighborhood, but Not a Community
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Evictions', 'Affordable Housing', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: Families displaced 47 years ago worry that they will not be able to afford housing in a new development being built on the site of their old tenements.
lead_paragraph: Like relics from a past civilization, tiny chunks of cracked tile and smashed bricks rest in the dirt of parking lots or empty lots along the south side of Delancey Street, near the corner of Clinton Street. They attest to a community on the Lower East Side of Manhattan that vanished 47 years ago, when some 1,800 families, mostly poor and Puerto Rican, were uprooted and their tenement homes demolished in the name of urban renewal.

headline: Austrian Singer Wins Eurovision Contest
abstract: Conchita Wurst was the runaway winner of this year’s 59th annual Eurovision Song Contest in Copenhagen.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — With a shimmering golden gown, trim dark beard and voice made for Broadway, an Austrian drag queen, Conchita Wurst, was the runaway winner of this year’s 59th annual Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday in Copenhagen.

headline: ‘Neighbors’ Tops Weekend Box Office
abstract: The No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada over the weekend was an R-rated comedy that rode strong reviews and a well-oiled marketing campaign to an astounding $51.1 million in ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: Sorry, Spidey. A raunchy fraternity just threw a bong through your web. The No. 1 movie in the United States and Canada over the weekend was “Neighbors,” an R-rated comedy that rode strong reviews and a well-oiled marketing campaign to an astounding $51.1 million in ticket sales, trampling “The Amazing Spider-Man 2.”

headline: Growing Up Without the One Who Delivered You
abstract: In the HBO documentary “The (Dead Mothers) Club,” Rosie O’Donnell, Jane Fonda, Molly Shannon and three noncelebrities talk about coming to terms with the early death of their mother.
lead_paragraph: Mother’s Day weekend can’t be easy for people who lost their mothers at a young age. Many no doubt just lie low, keep quiet and wait for it to be over. But the documentary “The (Dead Mothers) Club,” Monday night on HBO, gives voice to at least a few such people, and their stories will surely resonate with many others.

headline: Newsletter of the Hurt and Lonely
abstract: In “The Few,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, a publication editor and her eagerly awkward assistant react differently to the arrival of an old friend.
lead_paragraph: Matthew, the chronically anxious 19-year-old played with consummate skill and grace by Gideon Glick in “The Few,” a new play by Samuel D. Hunter, moves with the herky-jerky rhythm of a puppet whose strings are being pulled by someone a little woozy. His long arms end in hands that are forever darting around like little birds, making expressive gestures that suggest Matthew’s inability to fully articulate his feelings.

headline: Chamber Orchestra Works, From Intense to Zany
abstract: Susanna Malkki led Ensemble ACJW on Saturday at Zankel Hall in a portrait of the chamber orchestra over the last 100 years.
lead_paragraph: Part of the pleasure of hearing Ensemble ACJW, the group of young professionals formed under the auspices of Carnegie Hall and the Juilliard School, is considering the myriad options that lie before its members. Will they end up as soloists, orchestral players, educators, entrepreneurs?

headline: Traveling Back in Time to Dance Her Case
abstract: Miki Orihara explores the links between modern choreography and older works in a solo concert.
lead_paragraph: For nearly 30 years, Miki Orihara has been a stalwart member of the Martha Graham Dance Company. Such dedication is an implicit statement of belief in the continued relevance of classic modern dance. But in the program notes for “Resonance,” the solo concert she performed at the La MaMa Moves festival Friday, Ms. Orihara was explicit, arguing for the timelessness of older works and their connections to present-day choreography and concerns. With five short pieces, she danced her case in chronological order.

headline: Raging, Vaguely, Against the Machine
abstract: E M A performed new music at Rough Trade NYC, venting about eerily intrusive big corporations, big government and big data.
lead_paragraph: A bunch of years ago, Erika M. Anderson made it out of South Dakota to California. Eventually, recording under the alias E M A, she released an album, “Past Life Martyred Saints,” that captured the mood of the move — the terror, the pathos, the relief. A change in place saved her, sort of.

headline: Sugar? Sure, but Salted With Meaning
abstract: With her stinging, site-specific installation at the former Domino Sugar compound in Brooklyn, Kara Walker raises the bar on an overused art-spectacle formula as well as her own work.
lead_paragraph: With her stinging, site-specific installation at the former Domino Sugar compound on the edge of the East River in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, Kara Walker expands her imposing achievement to include three dimensions and monumental scale. In the process, she raises the bar on an overused art-spectacle formula as well as her own work. And she subjects a grand, decaying structure fraught with the conflicted history of the sugar trade and its physical residue to a kind of predemolition purification ritual.

headline: A Music Festival Dies, and an Orchestra Mourns
abstract: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra played the final offering of the visionary Spring for Music festival.
lead_paragraph: The Pittsburgh Symphony Orchestra ended the 2014 Spring for Music festival on Saturday night at Carnegie Hall by playing works that shared the theme of spirituality, but of a grim sort, touching on martyrdom, apocalyptic scenes and death and containing an element of gallows humor. This was not just the sixth and last concert of this year’s festival, but the final offering of the whole visionary venture.

headline: Playing on Mother’s Day After His Mother’s Sudden Death, St. Louis Buoys Rangers
abstract: The father and the sister of Martin St. Louis, whose mother unexpectedly died Thursday, will be in attendance as the Rangers face the Penguins in Game 6.
lead_paragraph: When Brad Richards learned Thursday that the mother of Martin St. Louis, his Rangers teammate and longtime friend, had unexpectedly died, his instincts were not about hockey.

headline: Albert Dormer at the World Senior Pairs in 1990
abstract: A few bridge players have better reputations than they deserve.
lead_paragraph: A few bridge players have better reputations than they deserve. Perhaps more are underrated; one was Albert Dormer, who died at 88 on March 18 in Scotland, where he had moved upon retirement.

headline: A Director’s Tasting Menu Shows Off a Ballet Company’s Strengths
abstract: At the Pennsylvania Ballet, a Director’s Choice program included works by Christopher Wheeldon and Robert Weiss and a world premiere by Trey McIntyre.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — The Pennsylvania Ballet, celebrating its 50th anniversary this season, is in transition. Last weekend it presented what it called a Director’s Choice triple bill, which had been announced last year. Two weeks ago, the company said its artistic director, Roy Kaiser, would step down at the end of the season.

headline: Walter Isaacson to Deliver Jefferson Lecture
abstract: The best-selling biographer and president of the Aspen Institute will deliver the 43rd annual Jefferson Lecture on Monday night at the Kennedy Center in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Walter Isaacson, the best-selling biographer and president of the Aspen Institute, will deliver the 43rd annual Jefferson Lecture on Monday night at the Kennedy Center in Washington. The lecture is sponsored by the National Endowment for the Humanities and considered the federal government’s highest honor in the humanities.

headline: Driven to Accumulate and Dancing Till Nothing’s Left
abstract: A shared program by the dancers Ashley Chen and Dylan Crossman at the Club at La MaMa on Friday was partly sophisticated and partly sophomoric.
lead_paragraph: The sidewalk in front of the Club at La MaMa on Friday night was teeming with people needing a fix of Merce past. The lure was a shared program featuring Ashley Chen and Dylan Crossman, two much-admired former members of the Merce Cunningham Dance Company, in a dual presentation by Danse: A French-American Festival of Performance and Ideas, and La MaMa Moves! Dance Festival. Before the house opened, Mr. Chen joined the crowd to smoke a cigarette; as he put it, “It’s the French warm-up.”

headline: Dance Lineups Announced
abstract: Dance companies from France, The Hague and Denmark will appear in the Joyce Theater’s fall and winter lineup.
lead_paragraph: Dance companies from France, The Hague and Denmark will appear in the Joyce Theater’s fall and winter lineup, said Joyce officials, who recently announced that the National Ballet of Canada would open the season on Sept. 9 with Christopher Wheeldon’s “Alice’s Adventures in Wonderland.” The schedule will also include Pacific Northwest Ballet performing works by Mr. Wheeldon and Alejandro Cerrudo (Oct. 8 to 12), the all-male company Les Ballets Trockadero de Monte Carlo (Dec. 16 to Jan. 4), and Royal Danish Ballet principals and soloists (Jan. 13 to 18). The French-Argentinean tango group Cia Unión Tanguera will perform from Sept. 23 to Oct. 5 as part of its “Nuit Blanche” North American tour, and the flamenco dancer Soledad Barrio is slated to bring her company, Noche Flamenca, to the Joyce from Oct. 29 to Nov. 9.

headline: A Memoir From the Eye of a Financial Storm
abstract: Timothy F. Geithner, the former Treasury secretary, recounts his view of the financial crisis in “Stress Test.”
lead_paragraph: One afternoon in the summer of 2008, as the financial system was careening toward the abyss that would send the United States into the worst economic emergency  since the Great Depression, Timothy F. Geithner — then president of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and later, President Obama’s Treasury secretary — tried to lighten the mood in his office with “an impromptu contest for the best metaphor for what was happening.”

headline: A Night of Gospel, Spanning Generations
abstract: The daylong annual McDonald’s Gospelfest at the Prudential Center in Newark included many of the greatest living female gospel singers, preceded by a national singing competition.
lead_paragraph: NEWARK — Consider Erica Campbell, at the McDonald’s Gospelfest Saturday night at the Prudential Center. She’s got the No. 1 album on the Billboard gospel chart, and co-stars in a successful reality show, “Mary Mary,” on We TV. She’s a personage in this precinct, a cross-media star, from whom you’d expect some kind of show. She brought one: herself.

headline: Stepping Up to a Host Spot
abstract: Larry Wilmore, a seasoned television writer and producer and “Daily Show” regular, prepares to lead his own commentators on “The Minority Report With Larry Wilmore.”
lead_paragraph: Larry Wilmore, named on Friday as host of “The Minority Report,” the show that will fill the 11:30 p.m. slot on Comedy Central, thought the time had passed for him to receive his own late-night show.

headline: Factory Conversion Moves Forward
abstract: The effort to turn a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into an acoustically sound concert hall, recording studio, nightclub and center for composers is moving ahead.
lead_paragraph: The effort to turn a century-old sawdust factory in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, into an acoustically sound concert hall, recording studio, nightclub and center for composers is moving ahead, with organizers saying that they have raised the $16 million needed to finish construction. The space on North 6th Street, called the Original Music Workshop, has already drawn respected musicians and celebrities inside its weathered brick walls for concerts, even before it had a roof. Now its founder, Kevin Dolan, said that he had lined up what he called “philanthropic investors” to put up the money needed to finish construction. It is an unusual arrangement. Mr. Dolan said that the investors would become part owners of the building, which they would allow the Original Music Workshop, a nonprofit, to use rent-free. In the future they could then give their shares to the workshop, sell them to the workshop, or sell the building. Mr. Dolan, 62, said this would reduce the risk to people who might be reluctant to put money into a new organization without a long track record. He added that the space could open as soon as the fall of 2015.

headline: A New York Premiere for a Scottish Play
abstract: “The Events,” a drama by the Scottish playwright David Greig, will have its New York premiere at New York Theater Workshop next winter.
lead_paragraph: “The Events,” a moving drama by the Scottish playwright David Greig, about the aftermath and community response when a tragedy takes place in a small town, will have its New York premiere at New York Theater Workshop next winter, the theater planned to announce on Monday. The show, directed by Ramin Gray, was first presented at the Edinburgh Festival Fringe last summer, where it drew critical praise and won several awards, including the Carol Tambor Best of Edinburgh honor. In Edinburgh, a different local choir was featured at each performance, providing a musical element while also aiding the plot in other ways, much like a Greek chorus. New York Theater Workshop plans to take a similar approach. “The Events,” which makes its United States premiere in June at the International Festival of Arts and Ideas in New Haven, will come to New York in February. The show rounds out the previously announced New York Theater Workshop season.

headline: Protect Our Bats
abstract: The insect hunters are being killed by disease and wind turbines.
lead_paragraph: DISEASE and heedless management of wind turbines are killing North America’s bats, with potentially devastating consequences for agriculture and human health.

headline: Thailand’s Dilemma
abstract: The country runs straight into a fork in the road.
lead_paragraph: The country runs straight into a fork in the road.

headline: Follow the Money, China-Style
abstract: The economy's mystery of surplus currency yet low inflation may be a result of the piles of cash hoarded by corrupt officials.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — Since China introduced a floating exchange rate on July 21, 2005, the Chinese yuan has consistently risen in value against the United States dollar, from a low of 8.28 yuan to the dollar in July 2005 to a high of 6.06 in January of this year. But the appreciation of the yuan has failed to convince ordinary Chinese people that their money buys more; on the contrary, they feel it’s worth less.

headline: Mets Finally Bring a Runner Home and End a Five-Game Skid
abstract: Ruben Tejada’s run-scoring hit in extra innings ended the Mets’ five-game losing streak and snapped a stretch in which they had stranded 36 runners.
lead_paragraph: The only encouraging thing about the Mets’ play recently was that they had been able to put runners on base, which had somewhat tempered the panic of their losing ways.

headline: The Dark Shadow of Agent Orange
keywords: ['AGENT ORANGE (DEFOLIANT)', 'Veterans', 'Vietnam War', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The use of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese.
lead_paragraph: The use of Agent Orange during the Vietnam War continues to cast a dark shadow over both American veterans and the Vietnamese.

headline: Agent Orange’s Long Legacy, for Vietnam and Veterans
abstract: More than 40 years after the American military used Agent Orange in the Vietnam War, the chemical still casts a long shadow over the Vietnamese and the American veterans who fought there.
lead_paragraph: Britain was the first to use defoliants as a war tactic in Southeast Asia. That was in the early 1950s in Malaya, then a British colony, before it became the independent Malaysia. British planes sprayed Malayan jungles with chemicals to strip trees bare and deprive communist guerrillas of cover. They also destroyed crops that the insurgents relied on for sustenance. A decade later, in what was then South Vietnam, United States armed forces resorted to precisely the same methods on an enormous scale in their long struggle against Viet Cong and North Vietnamese fighters.

headline: Party Chief’s Downfall a Central Act in Tiananmen Drama
abstract: Zhao Ziyang, the embattled Communist Party general secretary, appeared to have misread treacherous political currents and was outmaneuvered by Deng Xiaoping.
lead_paragraph: In mid-May 1989, Zhang Gang was among a group of Chinese officials and scholars seeking to defuse the student protests that had filled Tiananmen Square for a month. They had been trying to coax concessions from the government and the demonstrators to end the volatile confrontation and protect the embattled Communist Party general secretary, Zhao Ziyang, who was increasingly at odds with the party patriarch, Deng Xiaoping.

headline: A Discussion of the Danger and Promise of Tech
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Wearable Computing', 'Careers and Professions', 'AIRLINES AND AIRPLANES', 'Labor and Jobs']
abstract: Could artificial intelligence lead to the end of mankind, as Stephen Hawking recently suggested? That was one of the topics as readers looked into the future with our experts.
lead_paragraph: Claire Cain Miller of The New York Times recently conducted a series of interviews with seven people who helped provide a glimpse into the not-too-distant future. Last Monday, two of them — Sebastian Thrun and Clara Shih — joined her and readers in a chat on Facebook. Mr. Thrun is a co-founder and chief executive of Udacity, an inventor of driverless cars and a founder of Google X; and Ms. Shih is a founder and chief executive of Hearsay Social. The following are excerpts from the exchange, condensed and lightly edited.

headline: Show Us the Drone Memos
keywords: ['Targeted Killings', 'Constitution (US)', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Drones (Pilotless Planes)', 'Appeals Courts (US)']
abstract: We must see the legal case for executing a United States citizen without a trial.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — I BELIEVE that killing an American citizen without a trial is an extraordinary concept and deserves serious debate. I can’t imagine appointing someone to the federal bench, one level below the Supreme Court, without fully understanding that person’s views concerning the extrajudicial killing of American citizens.

headline: HUD, New Jersey and Sandy
abstract: The state’s recovery plan was bungled from the start.
lead_paragraph: The Department of Housing and Urban Development’s new review of New Jersey’s mismanaged Hurricane Sandy recovery effort uncovered no violations of federal law. But the report raised troubling concerns about the program’s lack of transparency. And while it could have made the point more forcefully, it did warn that the state could end up violating civil rights regulations if it did not take sufficient steps to ensure that poor and minority households got a fair share of post-Sandy aid.

headline: Secret Pension Fund Deals
abstract: How could the multibillion-dollar state pension industry be more transparent and less prone to influence and corruption?

headline: A Lesson in Farming, Classroom to Cafeteria
abstract: In Hagerstown, Ind., high school students will be making their own burgers from scratch — raising cattle to supply cheaper food for their cafeteria.
lead_paragraph: HAGERSTOWN, Ind. — Beyond a stack of hay bales, past the site of Indiana’s first soil-judging contest, high school students in this tiny eastern town stroll down a grassy slope to reach their newest classroom: a fenced-in field of cud-chewing cattle.

headline: Trailing by 22, Clippers Rally to Tie Series
abstract: The Clippers survived 40 points from Kevin Durant and their own slow start to storm back in the final minutes and beat the Thunder, 101-99.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Arriving fashionably late, as the actor Mark Wahlberg, the singer Rihanna and the boxer Floyd Mayweather Jr. did to their courtside seats Sunday, is a very Los Angeles thing to do. They were, in a way, very much like the basketball team they came to see.

headline: Its Ratings Sliding, Fox Looks for Hope in a Gotham City Before Batman
abstract: The network, whose prime-time audience has fallen about 17 percent, is under pressure as it prepares to present its fall schedule to advertisers.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Batman saves Gotham. Can he do the same thing for Fox?

headline: Questions About N.F.L. Draft’s Future Involve Location, Date and Length
abstract: After a cramped event at Radio City Music Hall, the N.F.L. is considering other locations, as well as the addition of a fourth day and other changes.
lead_paragraph: If the 2014 N.F.L. draft was the event’s swan song at Radio City Music Hall, it was quite a number. From the hysteria around Johnny Manziel on opening night to Michael Sam’s selection near the end of the third day, it was one of the most memorable of the nine consecutive drafts held at Radio City, the venerable theater in Midtown Manhattan.

headline: A Devotion to Language Proves Risky
abstract: Last August, three men were arrested and accused of “illegal fund-raising,” charges that stemmed from their effort to finance a Uighur-language school in Xinjiang, China.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — A poet, linguist and globe-trotting polyglot, Abduweli Ayup had a passion for the spoken word, notably Uighur, the Turkic language spoken in his homeland in China’s far northwest. In 2011, soon after finishing his graduate studies in the United States, Mr. Ayup returned home to open a chain of “mother tongue” schools in Xinjiang, the vast Central Asian region whose forced marriage to the Han Chinese heartland has become increasingly tumultuous.

headline: Warnings Along F.C.C.’s Fast Lane
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Net Neutrality', 'Law and Legislation', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Time and again, when the government tries to insert itself between the Internet and its users, it gets clobbered. This could end up the same way.
lead_paragraph: The next time the loudmouth in the next cubicle interrupts you with yet another recap of his weekend, just start talking about “net neutrality.”

headline: Democrats Look Dubiously at Joining Benghazi Panel
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates', 'Benghazi Attack (2012)']
abstract: They’re not expecting an unbiased investigation from the Republican-led committee, and are torn between lending it more legitimacy and letting it proceed unchecked.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — House Democrats on Sunday made it clear that they do not expect fair proceedings from the Republican-led panel newly tasked with investigating the 2012 attack in Benghazi, Libya, but offered no definitive answer on whether they would appoint any of their own members to participate.

headline: Charles Marowitz, Iconoclastic Director and Playwright, Dies at 82
abstract: Irrepressible and opinionated, Mr. Marowitz led an unusual theatrical life in England and the United States as a director, playwright, teacher and critic.
lead_paragraph: Charles Marowitz, who brought a thorny iconoclasm to a versatile theater career as a director, playwright, teacher and critic, died on May 2 in Agoura Hills, Calif. He was 82.

headline: A Triumph of Enlightenment ... Eventually
abstract: The selection of Michael Sam by the St. Louis Rams late in the final round of the N.F.L. draft may have saved the league from another public relations problem.
lead_paragraph: By the time I arrived at Radio City Music Hall in Manhattan on Saturday, the sixth round of the N.F.L. draft had started, but Michael Sam had still not been selected.

headline: European Candidates See Opportunity on Extreme Edge
abstract: Parties outside the mainstream are expected to win as many as a quarter of the 750 seats in the European Parliament, as far-right leaders portray the European Union as a gateway for illegal immigrants and a threat to national sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The campaign  advertisement in the Czech Republic begins with a snake slithering out of a red European Union flag and a montage of pictures of supposed threats to Czech identity, including a 500-euro note, an Israeli flag and a gathering of Orthodox Jews.

headline: Patrick J. Lucey, Governor and Vice-Presidential Candidate, Dies at 96

headline: Rarified Perfume: The Perks of Membership at MiN New York
abstract: The indie apothecary is accepting applications for access to Scent Stories, a new collection of 11 unisex scents that include notes like pencil shavings and ozone.
lead_paragraph: As the co-curators of the indie apothecary MiN New York in NoLita, Chad Murawczyk and Mindy Yang take a simple approach to stocking their shelves: “If we can’t find something we want, we make it,” Murawczyk says. So far, that’s lead to such varied creations as atmospheric candles gilded in precious metals, high-performance skin-care creams and hand-ticked silk scarves depicting photographs of Havana shot by Murawczyk himself. The latest addition to the MiN oeuvre: a series of abstract fragrances, called Scent Stories, debuting this week. Composed of notes that normally don’t land in eau, such as pencil shavings and ozone, the collection of 11 unisex scents took a year to develop with a master perfumer in Grasse, France. “The idea was to make each scent like a chapter or a short story: it would be vivid, visceral and disconnected from the others, but take you somewhere,” Yang says. Indeed, many of the fragrances were inspired by the pair’s own memories and journeys. Dahab, for example, evokes the deserts and deep seas of Egypt where Murawczyk spent time. “It’s incense-y, smoky and mysterious,” he says of the saffron-, cumin- and nutmeg-laced blend. Yang, who is also a trained reiki healer, is particularly drawn to Shaman, describing it as a “futurist nomad” scent, with a “mystical air.” The violet leaf note is especially nuanced, she says, and conveys “a sense of clairvoyance.”

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 6:45 P.M. (Cinemax) MAMA (2013) In this modern fairy tale directed by Andy Muschietti, the uncle (Nikolaj Coster-Waldau) of two feral sisters (Megan Charpentier, above, and Isabelle Nélisse), abandoned by their father in the woods, moves them into a home with his goth girlfriend (Jessica Chastain). Then a grotesque figure the girls call Mama appears in the shadows and begins to wreak havoc on their lives. But is the monster simply a coping mechanism for dealing with tragedy? Or is Mama the essence of the girls’ dead mother? “Instead of delivering buckets of guts and gore, this ghost story offers a strong sense of time and place, along with the kind of niceties that don’t often figure into horror flicks, notably pictorial beauty, an atmosphere throbbing with dread and actors so good that you don’t want anyone to take an ax to them,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times. And while the director Guillermo del Toro, “the reigning godfather of motion picture horror,” is only an executive producer on the film, she wrote, “it fits with the more successful movies he’s signed on to. Mr. del Toro understands that nothing says terror like a home that’s become a rattling cage.”

headline: Why I Play the Mom Card

But minutes later a fellow food-policy advocate, a woman with two advanced degrees and a book to her name (but no children), tweeted back archly: “Congrats. Does having a cat count?”

headline: An Electronic Double Bill to Shiver the Timbers
abstract: The Haxan Cloak and Robert Henke shared an electronic concert on Saturday as part of the Red Bull Music Academy Festival at Brooklyn Masonic Temple.
lead_paragraph: The electronic music double bill on Saturday night at the Brooklyn Masonic Temple was a superb clash of aesthetic extremes. The Red Bull Music Academy Festival paired the United States debut of the Haxan Cloak (the English musician Bobby Krlic) with the German musician Robert Henke and his laser project, Lumière. Mr. Henke’s music and light show were crisp, bright, geometric and propulsive, a calibrated barrage. The Haxan Cloak performance was amorphous, ominous and immersive, a transcendent plunge into darkness and overwhelming pressure. Earplugs were available at the door.

headline: Had Enough of Handel’s ‘Messiah’? Try Eric Idle’s
abstract: In its 2014-15 season, the Collegiate Chorale will offer “Not the Messiah (He’s a Very Naughty Boy),” an oratorio with a text by Eric Idle of Monty Python.
lead_paragraph: When the annual parade of “Messiah” performances winds through New York’s concert halls in the weeks leading up to Christmas, even devoted Handelians who are fascinated by the many variant scorings and ways of presenting this great oratorio can get a bit fatigued. The Collegiate Chorale’s solution is to offer a parody, “Not the Messiah (He’s a Very Naughty Boy),” an oratorio based on Monty Python’s 1979 film, “The Life of Brian.” The oratorio has a text by Eric Idle and music by John Du Prez (who was one of the musical contributors to “Spamalot”). Mr. Idle will be among the performers in the Chorale’s shows, at Carnegie Hall on Dec. 15 and 16.

headline: Suvir Saran’s Mushroom and Farro Burger
abstract: Potatoes, roasted and mashed, are the binder for these hearty patties.
lead_paragraph: When I was introduced to these burgers, a creation of the chef Suvir Saran, I was struck by the brilliant idea of using sweet potatoes as a binder. I’ve struggled to find ways to hold my burgers together, and this solution was perfect. Try to find light-fleshed sweet potatoes; they are drier, and a little less sweet than orange yams. I also love all the textures in these hearty patties. I have made some changes to Suvir’s recipe, roasting the potatoes rather than boiling them, and I use less oil.

headline: Potato and Pea Patties With Indian Spices
abstract: Whole spices give these burgers amazing flavor and texture.
lead_paragraph: This is another one of Suvir Saran’s ideas, which I have adapted. The whole spices in this mix contribute not only amazing flavors, but texture as well. I used a combination of light-fleshed sweet potatoes and red boiling potatoes: I loved the sweetness of the sweet potatoes with the spices, but the mix needed something starchier to hold it together, so I added some red potatoes.

headline: Mollie Katzen-Inspired Potato and Broccoli Burgers
abstract: These patties are coated in ground walnuts and include finely chopped broccoli.
lead_paragraph: The famed vegetarian cookbook author Mollie Katzen has a whole chapter devoted to burgers and savory pancakes in her beautiful new cookbook, “The Heart of the Plate.” Before I’d looked carefully at the chapter I’d bought a bunch of broccoli with the idea that specks of broccoli would be beautiful in a burger. Mollie, with her delicious Walnut-Coated Broccoli-Speckled Mashed Potato Cakes, was way ahead of me on that idea. I loved her idea of coating the burgers with ground walnuts and barely cooking the finely chopped broccoli before incorporating it into the mix. I’ve made a variation on Mollie’s burgers, using red potatoes and sticking with the Indian seasonings I’ve been using in other burgers this week.

headline: Suvir Saran’s Spinach and Potato Patties (Palak Ki Tiki)
abstract: These spicy burgers are a striking green from the spinach.
lead_paragraph: These are adapted from Suvir Saran’s potato patties called palak ki tiki, from his lovely cookbook “Masala Farm.” They are a striking green because of all of the raw spinach that gets packed into them. The big, spicy burgers are incredibly easy to put together and to cook. Suvir serves them with chutney, either green or tamarind, but we both agree that they’re delicious with plain old ketchup. I made a quick raita to serve with the burgers by stirring sweet pickle relish into plain yogurt.

headline: Sweet Potato, Quinoa, Spinach and Red Lentil Burger
abstract: These burgers have a Mediterranean flavor, with feta and mint in the mix.
lead_paragraph: You can use blond or black quinoa for these delicate burgers. Black will look striking against the sweet potato’s orange when you cut into the burgers. The red lentils pale to yellow when you cook them; they contribute texture and flavor. The burgers have a decidedly Mediterranean flavor, with feta and mint included in the mix. But I still like to serve them with raita or chutney; a more Mediterranean condiment would be yogurt seasoned with puréed garlic and mint.

abstract: The depletion of large parts of the ice sheet in West Antarctica is almost certainly unstoppable, with global warming accelerating the disintegration, two groups of scientists reported Monday.
lead_paragraph: A large section of the mighty West Antarctica ice sheet has begun falling apart and its continued melting now appears to be unstoppable, two groups of scientists reported on Monday. If the findings hold up, they suggest that the melting could destabilize neighboring parts of the ice sheet and a rise in sea level of 10 feet or more may be unavoidable in coming centuries.

headline: Pay Dispute Threatens Some High-Cost Legal Cases in Britain
abstract: A British court ruling in a fraud case could end up shifting some cases involving cross-border violations to the United States, Peter J. Henning writes in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: A ruling from a British court about the inability to find lawyers for a group of defendants charged with fraud calls into question whether the British authorities will be able to pursue complex white-collar crime prosecutions without paying more for lawyers to take such cases. The decision could end up shifting some cases to the United States, which does not face the same issues as Britain in paying for legal defense.

headline: General Barlow and the Bloody Angle
abstract: Within a 24-hour period during the Battle of Spotsylvania, North and South wracked up more than 15,000 casualties.
lead_paragraph: After being mauled by the Army of Northern Virginia in the Battle of the Wilderness, which took place in the dense central Virginia woods from May 5 to 7, 1864, Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant pushed his troops southeast toward the small hamlet of Spotsylvania Court House, intending to get between the Confederates and their capital. But Robert E. Lee’s men won the race to the village, thwarting Grant’s designs and setting the stage for the Battle of Spotsylvania, which would rage for 12 days, one of the longest and bloodiest engagements of the war.

headline: When Kids Would Rather Play Computer Games Than Code Them
abstract: Coding is growing as a kids’ activity, but as trendy as it is, it’s not easy. Most children won’t seize on coding games with the same enthusiasm as they did Minecraft. To engage kids in what’s happening behind the screen takes work.
lead_paragraph: Coding is trending. In schools. Twenty thousand teachers from kindergarten through 12th grade have introduced coding lessons, according to Code.org, a group backed by the tech industry that offers free curriculums. Thirty school districts, including New York City and Chicago, have agreed to add coding classes in the fall, mainly in high schools but in lower grades, too. At home, parents are downloading programs that promise to teach children coding basics, and toys that can be coded in various ways are lining up for the next holiday season.

headline: Listen Up | Sylvan Esso’s Quirky, Caffeinated Synth-Pop
abstract: The duo, featuring former members of Megafaun and Mountain Man, releases its first album tomorrow. An exclusive remix of their single “Coffee” is available here.
lead_paragraph: “Is it the kind of coffee that makes you feel like a crazy person?” asks Amelia Meath, one half of the Durham, N.C.-based electronic duo Sylvan Esso. The inquiry is directed toward a server at Café Stella, a Silver Lake bistro popular with the indie set (members of the bands Warpaint and the Afghan Whigs have also been known to dine there). “I have a problem with certain coffees,” Meath clarifies. “One sip and I know it’s going to turn me into a terrible person.”

headline: A Slow-Tech Approach to Tracking Spending
abstract: Forgo the automated apps for a month and see whether manually entering transactions sharpens your awareness of your budget, a financial planner suggests.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, I tracked every penny of our family’s spending. That’s good, right? Over time, however, I lost sight of why I was doing it and eventually stopped. Recently, I decided to try it again, and I find myself having the same mental conversation every time I sit down with my receipts.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Another Mercedes 1-2 Finish in Formula One

Daniel Ricciardo, in the Red Bull Infiniti, came in a distant third, followed by Sebastian Vettel, his teammate and the defending series champion.

Venture capitalist Marc Andreessen justifies some high price tags in technology deals, in part, with the idea that huge companies are able to “attach” the products of smaller ones, making them worth far more than traditional analysis would suggest.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 9-11, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last March, when Facebook promised to crack down on gun advertising by deleting posts from people looking to buy or sell guns without background checks, it was heralded as a victory by some gun-control groups. Others, however, hoped for the outright ban of gun ads, à la Craigslist and eBay. Instead, the social network said it would hide posts peddling guns from minors and remind users to follow local gun laws.

headline: Republican Moderates and the Minimum Wage
abstract: Once again, the G.O.P.’s moderate wing is missing an opportunity.
lead_paragraph: One of my first columns for the Times was a non-requiem for Arlen Specter’s career as a moderate Republican, in which I argued that the G.O.P. desperately needed “a better sort of centrist” than the Specter-esque, “socially liberal, fiscally conservative” northeasterners to whom the label has usually been applied. One theme in that piece, which has run through my commentary on the Republican Party ever since, is that a moderate wing of the G.O.P. that just imitates the Democrats on a few issues where the liberal line is popular isn’t necessarily doing either its party or the country any great favors. To be truly constructive in their moderation, the G.O.P.’s centrists should be advancing alternatives to popular liberal ideas — trying to create a different center of political gravity, in effect, rather than just looking for ways to take some losing issues off the table.

headline: Miles Davis Way to Be Unveiled
abstract: A sign is to be unveiled on May 26 naming a block on West 77th Street in honor of the jazz trumpeter.
lead_paragraph: Before he left office, Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg signed a bill naming a block of West 77th Street in honor of the jazz trumpeter and composer Miles Davis. The block, between West End Avenue and Riverside Drive, will be called Miles Davis Way. Mr. Davis, who died in 1991, had an apartment in a brownstone at 312 West 77th Street, and lived there for about 25 years, until the mid-1980’s. Now the new street sign is ready, and will have a public unveiling on May 26, the 88th anniversary of Davis’s birth, at noon. Two of Davis’s children, Cheryl Davis and Erin Davis, as well as Vince Wilburn, Jr., his nephew, will be on hand for the ceremony, which will include a block party sponsored by the Far West 77th Street Block Association.

headline: Q. and A. | Sterling Ruby on Making It in L.A., His New Show in New York and the Power of the Art Market
abstract: The multidisciplinary star, whose new show opened at Hauser & Wirth last Friday, reflects on his place in the art world.
lead_paragraph: Numerous New York galleries and museums synced their best shows to Frieze weekend, including Hauser & Wirth, which opened a much-anticipated new exhibition by the Los Angeles polymath Sterling Ruby at its newly renovated West 19th Street space last Friday. It’s Ruby’s first solo show in Chelsea since he parked two menacing, rectilinear forms (a bus and a big brick of human-size cages) inside the Pace Gallery four years ago. This new show, entitled “Sunrise, Sunset,” presents a dense cross-section of recent works the prolific and controversial artist has produced in his fabled studio-cum-industrial-complex on the outskirts of Downtown L.A. — where only weeks ago, a Mack truck veered off the road and through the wall of the building, destroying a number of mammoth spray paintings and Ruby’s studio manager’s car (fortunately, no one was injured). Though the accident was a setback, the grandiose, unexpected destruction of the incident aligned well with Ruby’s expansive practice. The exhibition is full of charged objects, including Corinthian columns dripping with lustrous red polyurethane, a super-size canary-yellow electric chair, infernal stoves and bleached fabrics that evoke everything from Rorschach tests to the American flag. Here, the artist reflects on his intentions for the show and his place in the art world.

headline: Reading Landai in New York
abstract: Eliza Griswold will read from “I Am The Beggar of the World,” a book of landai by female Afghan poets, in New York on May 12, 2014. Griswold wrote for the magazine about young Afghan women for whom writing landai served as a vital, and in some cases sole, link to a wider world.
lead_paragraph: Today, Eliza Griswold reads at the Culture Project in New York from ‘‘I Am the Beggar of the World,’’ a book of landai by Afghan women. Griswold’s translations of the landai — two-line folk poems typically about love and grief — are accompanied by photographs by Seamus Murphy, with whom she traveled to Afghanistan in 2012, a trip that also led to an article for the magazine in April of that year. Griswold wrote about young Afghan women for whom writing landai served as a vital, and in some cases sole, link to a wider world. These young women were often confined to their fathers’ homes in the rural villages where they lived; they would sneak calls to a Kabul-based poetry hotline to read their poems and exchange ideas with other Afghan women — parliamentarians, doctors, professors — whose lives they could only imagine. One young woman, Zarmina, stood out. Her poems were distinctive in their language but also in their fearless questioning of God’s will. headline: Science vs. Taxes

lead_paragraph: In the United States, most of the controversy over Pfizer’s $101 billion bid for AstraZeneca has been about the potential tax consequences. Last year, Pfizer paid an effective tax rate of about 27 percent. But if it were to succeed in taking over its British rival — and so far, at least, AstraZeneca has shown zero interest in the idea — it would be able to conduct a maneuver called “inversion,” becoming a British company and paying the British corporate tax rate of 20 percent. It would also be able to access cash that resides overseas, which would be taxed at the American rate of 35 percent if it were repatriated into this country.

headline: Spain: Provincial Council Leader Shot
abstract: A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend campaigning.
lead_paragraph: A regional politician from Spain’s governing Popular Party was shot dead in the northern city of León on Monday, prompting the country’s main parties to suspend campaigning ahead of the European parliamentary elections this month. Isabel Carrasco, the head of the provincial council in León, was shot at least three times as she crossed a bridge in the city’s downtown, according to local news media reports. Ms. Carrasco, 59, had been running the provincial council in Léon since 2007. The shooting in broad daylight was a shock in a country that has only recently emerged from decades of terrorist bombings and political killings by members of ETA, the Basque separatist group that declared a cease-fire in 2011. An unidentified woman arrested in connection with the crime, according to local news reports, is believed to have recently been fired from her council job.

Mr. Beecroft’s Iraq post, in turn, will be filled by Stuart E. Jones, the United States ambassador to Jordan, the White House said. Mr. Beecroft will take up his post in Cairo during a tumultuous period. Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, who led the ouster last year of the elected government in Egypt, is expected to be elected Egypt’s president next month. The Cairo post has been vacant since Anne Patterson left in August to become the top Middle East official at the State Department.

headline: Uruguayan Leader Meets With Obama to Talk Trade and Human Rights
abstract: President José Mujica’s visit to the White House came as the South American country seeks new markets for its commodities exports.
lead_paragraph: URUGUAY — President José Mujica of Uruguay met with President Obama in Washington on Monday, pointing to the strengthening ties between the United States and the South American nation, which is advancing an array of socially liberal legislation, including the legalization of same-sex marriage and abortion. True to his laid-back style, Mr. Mujica, a 78-year-old former guerrilla who has farmed chrysanthemums for a living, did not wear a tie to the White House. The leaders discussed opportunities to expand trade as Uruguay, a small ranching nation of 3.3 million people, seeks new markets for its commodities exports. Mr. Obama also referred to the influence of Mr. Mujica in connection to human rights issues in Latin America. Curiously, the two leaders did not publicly refer to Uruguay’s pioneering legalization of marijuana, a sweeping measure that went into effect last week. Focusing on common ground between Uruguay and the United States, Mr. Mujica, a former livestock minister, said, “I embrace all agriculturalists of this nation.”

lead_paragraph: Cory Arcangel keeps his laptop perched on a small elevated desk in his Sunset Park, Brooklyn studio. Lately, he’s been trying to stand up while he works — not because it’s physically healthier, but because it helps curtail time-wasting. “I find that when you’re standing, there’s a certain threshold for browsing,” says the 35-year-old technology-based artist. “You don’t go on Facebook. There’s something about having to use physical energy. I’m trying all these techniques so that I don’t fall into a dangerous hole that I’m prone to, that I’ve been prone to for 20 years.”

headline: Finding Old Ireland in Handball Alleys
abstract: Kenneth O Halloran talks about photographing handball alleys in Ireland, where scores of abandoned courts in various states of disrepair dot the landscape.
lead_paragraph: The most recent Look features handball courts, or alleys, in Ireland. For hundreds of years, outdoor handball was a popular sport there, but now scores of abandoned courts dot the landscape in various states of ruin. The pictures were part of the photographer Kenneth O Halloran’s M.F.A. thesis at the University of Ulster last year. It’s the latest in a series of his personal projects with Irish themes, including Tales From the Promised Land, which documented the collapse of the country’s real estate market. The magazine has featured O Halloran’s pictures of dancers at the World Irish Dancing Championships and, most recently, from his trek up Croagh Patrick. Recently I asked him about this latest project of his.

Observers say the results could be momentous, with polls suggesting that voters are fed up with slow economic or political progress and favor decisive change — even at the risk of upsetting the nation’s fragile balance between its religious and social groups.

The setting was the opulent subterranean boîte the Diamond Horseshoe, which hosted its annual benefit for the not-for-profit performance space P.S. 122, which has been staging amazing and bizarre shows in the East Village for more than 30 years, with performers ranging from Eric Bogosian and John Leguizamo to Annie Dorsen and Young Jean Lee.

Had he not been recorded, Sterling would have received a lifetime achievement award from the N.A.A.C.P. The victim of his remarks was himself: Sterling managed to (further) trash his own reputation. No one else was really injured. Is purity of thought the expectation for team owners? MARK ALEXANDER, ST. LOUIS

lead_paragraph: As far as Southern California festival style goes, the Echo Park Craft Fair is a long way from the bare midriffs and hippie posturing of Coachella. The biannual design and food festival, which celebrated its fifth anniversary last weekend, has evolved from an intimate backyard bazaar into the see-and-be-seen happening for a certain swath of the L.A. creative class. In a city without much pedestrian activity, the fair — which, despite its name, takes place in Silver Lake — generates plenty of it. And with all that foot traffic comes a uniquely Angeleno sort of fashion parade, one with a distinctly spiritual vibe.

Still, it’s amusing to think of the online personals ad its hero, Colm (Patrick Fitzgerald), might have written: “Single, virginal fisherman on remote Irish island seeks woman for conversation, companionship and whiskey tippling. headline: Road to Civil Disobedience Began in South Africa
abstract: In “Gandhi Before India,” Ramachandra Guha explains how the experiences of the young Mohandas K. Gandhi in South Africa primed him for his calling as the leader of the Indian independence movement.
lead_paragraph: When the young Indian lawyer Mohandas K. Gandhi set sail in 1893 for Durban, the main port in Britain’s colony in Natal in southeast Africa, he expected his assignment to last no more than a year. Having found it difficult to establish a legal practice in his hometown in Gujarat, he had accepted a short-term commission to assist a Muslim merchant in Durban who was in a financial dispute with another Muslim merchant in Pretoria, capital of the neighboring Boer republic of Transvaal.

headline: A Renaissance in Rapid City, S.D.
abstract: In recent years, the once-seedy downtown area in this city near Mount Rushmore has developed a surprising eco-sensibility and a thriving art scene.
lead_paragraph: In the shadow of monumental Mount Rushmore, Rapid City might suffer from a slight inferiority complex. But this city has always brimmed with resilience. After a devastating flood in 1972, the city landscaped the floodplain with a 10-mile-long bicycle and walking path. In recent years, its once-seedy downtown area has developed a surprising eco-sensibility and a thriving art scene. Along an alleyway, boldly hued murals and graffiti bracket building facades. Main Street Square, the downtown cultural hub, is the site of a newly commissioned public sculpture project. A car-free Memorial Park Promenade will open in June.

headline: Larry McMurtry on the Power of the Plains
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Writing and Writers', 'Cowboys and Cowgirls', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: The Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “Lonesome Dove” talks about how the plains have affected him and reflects on the lonely landscapes that surface in his fiction.
lead_paragraph: For Larry McMurtry — the Pulitzer Prize-winning author of “Lonesome Dove” and co-author of the Oscar-winning screenplay for “Brokeback Mountain” — one of the most interesting, and overlooked, aspects of life in the Old West was just how profoundly isolating the “westering” experience could be. “Those plains, those mountains, those deserts were empty, except for the Indians, who didn’t make the settlers less lonely,” said Mr. McMurtry, 77.

headline: Georgia Senate Race Becoming Less of a Long Shot for Democrats
abstract: A strong showing by Michelle Nunn in recent polling is part of the reason our election model now gives Democrats a 52 percent chance to retain Senate control.
lead_paragraph: New polling from NBC/Marist and The Atlanta Journal-Constitution mixed things up in our Senate model, with our forecasts in Arkansas and Georgia moving in a Democratic direction. The national outcome remains a coin flip, although the new data tipped our forecast from a 54 percent chance that the Republicans will take the Senate this fall to a slightly better than even chance (52 percent) that the Democrats will stay in power.

headline: Miller Theater Season
abstract: The Miller Theater at Columbia University will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths in its 2014-15 season.
lead_paragraph: The Miller Theater at Columbia University will continue to emphasize its traditional strengths — new music, early music and provocative combinations of the two — in its 2014-15 season. It will open Sept. 18 with “Heart and Breath,” a production by the new-music ensemble Eighth Blackbird in which the musicians play commedia dell’arte roles and perform 17th-century Italian music filtered through 21st-century sensibilities. The hall’s signature series, Composer Portraits, will offer overviews of the works of eight living composers, four of them women, representing an expansive array of contemporary styles. The series begins with an evening of recent works by Chou Wen-Chung, performed by the ensembles for which he wrote them — the Brentano String Quartet, Talujon and the New York New Music Ensemble. The International Contemporary Ensemble, with Steven Schick conducting, will devote a program to the Israeli experimentalist Chaya Czernowin, and the string quartet Ethel will perform the world premiere of a new work by Missy Mazzoli on a program that also includes her “Harp and Altar,” a paean to the Brooklyn Bridge. Other installments of Composer Portraits include programs devoted to Bernard Rands, Keeril Makan, Stefano Gervasoni, Augusta Read Thomas and Anna Clyne. The Miller’s program also includes a jazz series and occasional pop-up concerts (with free beer), which will announced closer to the performances. The full schedule is at millertheatre.com.

headline: Kick-Starting a Season With Frolics and Feats
abstract: American Ballet Theater’s spring gala, which opened its eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House on Monday, brought off several feats.
lead_paragraph: Slowly, cautiously, tentatively, American Ballet Theater is improving its spring gala, the motley extravaganza with which it annually opens its big eight-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House. Until a couple of years ago, this celebration had settled into a rut: a few too many nonerotic bedroom pas de deux; dozens too many fouetté turns from one ballerina after another; and curtain speeches that sounded like shopping lists. Everything onstage encouraged the idea that ballet was the tritest and most predictable of all art forms.

headline: Seeing God in Snakes, Strippers and Tattoos
abstract: Aram Garriga’s documentary “American Jesus” samples the outliers of Christianity in the United States.
lead_paragraph: It’s not clear what Aram Garriga thinks he is accomplishing in his simplistic “American Jesus,” but he’s not accomplishing much. Whatever hopes you might have had that this Spanish filmmaker would be able to do for American Christianity what another outsider, Alexis de Tocqueville, did for America as a whole are dashed as soon as the snake-handling minister shows up.

headline: A Look Back at a Year of Top Voices
abstract: The Metropolitan Opera’s 2013-14 season has established that singing still comes first in this art form and that while the staging of new works is important, a director’s bold vision is often the key.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Opera’s season closed on Saturday with a matinee of Rossini’s “La Cenerentola” and an evening performance of Bellini’s “I Puritani.” On this final day, the Met presented two of the three reigning bel canto tenors who had such success at the house this spring: Juan Diego Flórez as the prince in “Cenerentola,” and Lawrence Brownlee as Arturo in “Puritani.”

headline: Without a Hit Wallet, Square Tries Another Approach
abstract: Even after scoring a big partnership with Starbucks Coffee and offering a futuristic app that let people pay for things just by saying their name, Square’s mobile wallet gained little traction.
lead_paragraph: Square, the mobile payments start-up, is a testament to how tough it is to sell people on the idea of a mobile wallet. Even after scoring a big partnership with Starbucks Coffee and offering a futuristic app that lets people pay for things just by saying their name, Square’s mobile wallet gained little traction. Now the company has stopped offering its wallet app in favor of a new approach.

headline: Where Hope Is Scarce, Terrorism Takes Root
abstract: In “Horses of God,” poverty and hopelessness turn Morocco into a breeding ground for terrorists.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Sidi Moumen, a sprawling shantytown on the outskirts of Casablanca, Morocco, live in tin-roofed shacks without electricity, running water or modern sewage disposal. The area sits atop a garbage dump where boys run wild in packs and engage in fierce soccer matches that often explode into violence. Aerial shots depict this slum as a fetid, desiccated wasteland, in which the pickings are thin, even for scavengers. To sell oranges in a market for a pittance, you must fight for space.

headline: Bearing Witness, Losing Her Life

headline: Videos Said to Show Force-Feeding of Detainees at Guantánamo Bay
abstract: The military has made videotapes of military medical officials force-feeding detainees on hunger strikes at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a court filing on Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: The military has made videotapes of military medical officials force-feeding detainees on hunger strikes at the prison at Guantánamo Bay, Cuba, according to a court filing on Tuesday. The filing asks a judge to issue an emergency order to the military requiring it to preserve the tapes. In 2007, it came to light that the C.I.A. had destroyed videotapes of its interrogation sessions showing the use of the suffocation technique called waterboarding. The military’s practice of force-feeding detainees has been a major issue in habeas corpus lawsuits. The procedure involves strapping a detainee into a restraint chair and inserting a gastric tube through the nose and down the throat, through which liquid nutritional supplement is poured into the stomach. In February, a federal appeals court in the District of Columbia ruled that the courts have jurisdiction to hear challenges of the conditions of confinement at Guantánamo as part of habeas corpus lawsuits.

headline: The Hague: Court to Review British War Crime Inquiry
keywords: ['Prisoners of War', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court said she had reopened a preliminary investigation into accusations that British officials were responsible for the abuse of Iraqi prisoners.
lead_paragraph: The prosecutor at the International Criminal Court, Fatou Bensouda, said Tuesday that she had reopened a preliminary war crimes investigation into accusations that British officials were responsible for the systematic abuse of Iraqi prisoners by Britain’s military from 2003 to 2008. A similar investigation was closed in 2006, but Ms. Bensouda said she would review whether new information she received in January justified reopening the case. Although Iraq has not signed the Rome Statute, which governs the court’s proceedings, Britain has, and its citizens can in theory be prosecuted for crimes committed in Iraq or elsewhere. However, the court, which is based in The Hague, can proceed only if the allegations are not being properly investigated by the British authorities themselves.

headline: How to Arrange Flowers, the Brooklyn Way
abstract: In this exclusive video for T, the co-owners of the Little Flower School share their tricks to create a seasonal arrangement that looks as effortless and chic as an unruly garden.
lead_paragraph: Given the Brooklynization of the world, it’s no surprise that when the Little Flower School made its way from Brooklyn to London last month, formally trained florists from as far north as Scotland and as far south as Cornwall made the trek to learn how to craft the stunning, free-form arrangements coveted by New York’s creative elite and fashion set. Sarah Ryhanen and Nicolette Owen hosted the two-day immersive workshop to help British florists “break out of the dome” (think: those compact bridal bouquets). An old courtyard filled with 5,000 cut flowers set the scene for Ryhanen’s opening lecture, in which she challenged their 14 pupils to ditch the flower foam, show no fear and let their imaginations run wild with the bucketfuls of foxgloves and peonies before them.

headline: A Fresh Hub for Young Talent at New York Design Week
abstract: Sight Unseen Offsite, a shoppable two-story exhibition in SoHo, brings the carefully curated vision of the design website Sight Unseen to New York Design Week.
lead_paragraph: If locals have one complaint about New York Design Week, it’s that the city can seem over-reliant on foreign brands and ho-hum showrooms for content. In 2010, Monica Khemsurov (a T contributor) and Jill Singer of the online magazine Sight Unseen founded the NoHo Design District to counteract that problem with a neighborhood-wide festival of quirky installations, events and pop-ups that ran during Design Week. The duo, known for their knack for identifying new talent, originally looked to create the same neighborhood feel they had experienced when attending other global design weeks in London and Milan. However, by last year, the trials of securing real estate in a booming market had become overwhelming. “In the end, it proved so difficult to find those spaces that we spent 80 percent of our time doing that, and zero percent curating,” says Khemsurov. “The only way for us to evolve was to let go of Noho and become nomadic.”

headline: Easy Blue-and-White Stripes

lead_paragraph: With Memorial Day just around the corner, the promise of prolonged mornings spent luxuriating in pajamas and warm afternoon naps beneath a cool summer breeze is enough to inspire a wardrobe reinvention. And perhaps nothing says summertime more than stripes — but instead of the usual maritime take, we’re looking to swaths of pale and azure blues, in varying widths, contrasted with ample amounts of white. The effect is reminiscent of the parasols that pepper the beaches of the Italian Riviera. With light-as-air fabrics and loungewear-inspired designs, these little patterned numbers are as easy to wear as neutral basics — and will keep you feeling, and looking, cool all season long.

headline: Where the Twin Towers Stood
abstract: Architecture and artifacts from the Sept. 11 memorial and museum.
lead_paragraph: The Sept. 11 memorial and museum’s location at ground zero in Lower Manhattan is one of its most notable features, according to Steven M. Davis, a partner at Davis Brody Bond, the lead architects for the museum. “If you think about the notion of a traditional museum as an icon which contains exhibits, here we have the inverse,” Davis says. “These are exhibits that are in fact the icon.” The museum opens to survivors and victims’ families on May 15; the public can visit starting May 21. In designing the space, which extends 70 feet below the memorial plaza, Davis says he wanted the experience to be physical — visitors enter by descending a ramp, as if drawn by gravity — but also heavy with symbolism and emotion. How does he hope people will feel when they leave? “Optimistic about the future,” he says. “That we have the wherewithal as a society to create positive results from negative events.” Julie Bosman

headline: What’s On Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 7:30 A.M. (FX Movie Channel) STANLEY AND LIVINGSTONE (1939) In the first of two African adventures directed by Henry King, Henry Stanley (Spencer Tracy), a reporter for The New York Herald, travels to Zanzibar in search of the long-missing British missionary Dr. David Livingstone (Cedric Hardwicke). Writing in The New York Times, Bosley Crowther called the lavish production — which helped to immortalize the famous greeting “Dr. Livingstone, I presume” — “intelligent and restrained and dignified.” In “The Snows of Kilimanjaro” (1952), at 9:30, adapted from the short story by Ernest Hemingway, an author (Gregory Peck, above with Susan Hayward) seriously wounded in a hunting accident reflects on the love (Ava Gardner) he lost and the novel he never wrote. Mr. King and the producer Darryl Zanuck “have made a picture that constantly fascinates the eye and stimulates the emotions in small, isolated ways,” Mr. Crowther wrote in The Times. He added: “The shots of wild animals in Africa — elephants, lions, rhinoceroses, giraffes and all manner of lesser creatures — are as magnificent and exciting as any yet, and the atmosphere and beauty of a safari under the snowy peak of Kilimanjaro are superb. Especially one sequence in close-up of a swimming herd of hippopotamuses goes down in this reviewer’s notebook as the best one of game we’ve ever seen.”

headline: Anger Grows in Vietnam Over Dispute With China
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Offshore Drilling and Exploration', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'Ships and Shipping', 'International Relations']
abstract: The dispute has unleashed some of the worst civil unrest in recent years in Vietnam and has prompted what appears to have been a news media blackout by the government.
lead_paragraph: HANOI, Vietnam — Thousands of workers rampaged through an industrial area in southern Vietnam on Tuesday in what reportedly began as protests against China’s stationing of an oil rig in disputed waters off of Vietnam’s coast.  The riots were some of the worst civil unrest in recent years and appear to have prompted  restraints on the local media by Vietnam’s authoritarian government. An article about the protests that was posted online by a Vietnamese state newspaper on Tuesday was removed by Wednesday morning.  The Chinese Embassy in Hanoi issued a notice on Wednesday that urged Chinese living in Vietnam to “minimize unnecessary outings.”  A staff member at the Chutex Garment Factory north of Ho Chi Minh City said 8,000 to 10,000 workers were involved in the rampage at his factory.  “They burned the office,” said the staff member who agreed to speak on condition that his name not be used. The rioters “burned everything, all of the materials, computers, machines.”  Police units and fire fighters arrived at the factory Tuesday and “disbanded,” the rioters, he said. On Wednesday morning police “captured” around 15 to 20 men who were attempting to loot the premises, he said.  The Chutex factory, located in Song Than Industrial Park 2 in southern Binh Duong Province, is described on its web site as one of the largest garment exporters in Vietnam. Chutex International, the parent company, was founded by a Taiwanese garment executive.  It is unclear why rioters targeted a factory linked to Taiwan. Media in Hong Kong said  workers might not have been distinguishing between mainland China and Taiwan, a self-governing island which also has claims to territory in the South China Sea.

keywords: ['Breastfeeding', 'Guinea Worm Disease', 'Third World and Developing Countries', 'Water']
abstract: Changing behavior isn’t easy, but carrying out good health practices in communities for all to see can be contagious.
lead_paragraph: When we hear that someone succumbed to peer pressure or conformed to group expectations, we are inclined to think about it in negative terms. We imagine a young person smoking his first cigarette or an adult parroting the consensus of her community. We know that these social forces can cause people to act in ways that are harmful to themselves and others; but every day we are discovering more ways that they can be harnessed to solve problems in health, education and other areas. This is crucial. For decades, development organizations have spent billions of dollars developing medicines, installing wells, or building clinics or schools that people have not fully used, if they have used them at all.

headline: Seventy Years Ago Next Month Came Fury and Death on D-Day

abstract: Four U.S. Army Rangers, like their comrades, were penned up in British camps before they were marched onto claustrophobic landing crafts and unleashed on the Nazis.
lead_paragraph: Here is a rare color photograph from World War II. Taken 70 years ago next month, it reveals American warriors from E Company, Fifth Ranger Battalion, aboard their landing craft on Weymouth Harbor, Dorset, England. They are setting out to fight the Nazis on Omaha Beach on D-Day — June 6, 1944, one of the pivot points of the 20th century. In the foreground, they are, clockwise from far left, First Sergeant Sandy Martin, Technician Fifth Grade Joseph Markovich, Corporal John Loshiavo and Private First Class Frank Lockwood, with their Bazooka, Garand rifle, 60-mm mortar and Lucky Strikes.

He made his Broadway debut in “Scapino” in 1974, won a Tony for “Barnum” in 1980 and later appeared in the long-running hit “Me and My Girl.” More recently he was in the revival of Athol Fugard’s “Road to Mecca.” But did you know that Mr. Dale also wrote the lyrics for the title song of “Georgy Girl,” which won him an Oscar nomination in 1967?

A few hours later, and about 20 miles north, he walked onstage at the Mark Taper Forum to portray the singer Paul Robeson, Robeson’s wife, the Soviet filmmaker Sergei Eisenstein and 40 or so other characters in “The Tallest Tree in the Forest.” After his performance — Mr. Beaty has all the speaking roles in the show, which he also wrote — he met with a couple from Omaha to discuss bringing his youth workshops there. headline: The Language of Autism: Disease or Difference?
abstract: The debate over whether autism is a disease to be cured or a variation to be celebrated is an abstraction, utterly disconnected to our day-to-day experience. To describe that, I cannot avoid the lexicon of illness.
lead_paragraph: I first wrote about my son, Finn, shortly after his autism diagnosis: his limp, bony body, the distracted doctors and the unrelenting paperwork. And, of course, our grief. But it wasn’t writing so much as keening, a scrawled lamentation that I wouldn’t have shared with my friends, much less the public. Then in 2012 a friend asked me to write an essay for Money magazine on the unique financial burden of raising an autistic child. My research revealed two facts: First, special-needs children pose enormous, long-term challenges to all but the wealthiest of parents; second, my wife and I were utterly unprepared to meet those challenges.

headline: Your Evening Briefing

lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: Dylan Records a Sinatra Hit
abstract: A new track by Bob Dylan, “Full Moon and Empty Arms,” was a hit for Frank Sinatra nearly 70 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Is Bob Dylan channeling his inner Sinatra? Or is it his inner Rachmaninoff? On Wednesday, Mr. Dylan’s website, bobdylan.com, posted what appears to be the cover of the singer’s forthcoming album, “Shadows in the Night,” as well as a single track – a gently sung cover of “Full Moon and Empty Arms,” in an ensemble dominated by a country-tinged steel guitar part. The song, written in 1945 by Buddy Kaye and Ted Mossman, is based on a theme from the third movement of Rachmaninoff’s Piano Concerto No. 2, and was a hit for Frank Sinatra in 1946.

headline: ‘Now That’s What I Call Music’ Ends ‘Frozen’ Soundtrack’s No. 1 Run
abstract: The 50th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!” unseated the soundtrack to Disney’s “Frozen,” which spent 13 weeks atop the album chart.
lead_paragraph: After spending two straight months at the top of Billboard’s album chart, Disney’s “Frozen” soundtrack has finally been bumped from No. 1. The new champion: the 50th volume of “Now That’s What I Call Music!,” a compilation series that has been coming out in the United States like clockwork — and regularly scoring high on the charts — for 16 years.
