lead_paragraph: When an underinsured office temp from Staten Island and her entitled billionaire boss die in an elevator accident in “Under My Skin,” the new body-swapping comedy at the Little Shubert Theater, an angel from Eternal Affairs restores them to life, each in the other’s physique.

lead_paragraph: The trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship in India continues through Sunday in Phoenix. Sixteen teams entered. The bottom 13 seeds played a two-day round robin to eliminate two teams.

headline: Fleeting Game Says Investing Is Rigged
abstract: Make It Rain: The Love of Money, which hit No. 1 last week on the App Store chart for free downloads, shows a world rigged in favor of the rich.
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, committing to a video game was a costly decision, made deliberately. Largely because of the price, you were going to play only a few games a year, and you were going to spend scores of hours with each one. It was as if Netflix were charging $60 every time you wanted to start bingeing on a TV series.

headline: A Haunting History Lesson With Your Hip-Hop
abstract: The Roots offered conundrum, provocation, history lesson, ritual, chamber recital, jazz concert and elegy at the Public Theater in advance of their new album, “... and then you shoot your cousin.”
lead_paragraph: Conundrum, provocation, history lesson, ritual, chamber recital, jazz concert, elegy — the Roots’ performance at the Public Theater on Tuesday night was decidedly not a standard kickoff for a hip-hop album. That was clear when, near the beginning of the show, balloon animals were dropped onto the stage, covering it knee-deep; for the rest of the performance, each entrance and exit was accompanied by balloons popping underfoot like gunshots. Dozens of nooses also hung overhead.

headline: R.V. Life: Getting Kicks at Age 66
abstract: Many are trading traditional homes for lives of mobility, freedom and spontaneity.
lead_paragraph: Jim and Jaylene Myers knew exactly what they wanted to do when they retired in 2008: Go wherever whim and chance might take them in their 45-foot recreational vehicle.

headline: Classics That Throw Time Out the Window
abstract: On Friday, a New York City Ballet program of Jerome Robbins classics offered reminders that ballet does not need to be new to be contemporary.
lead_paragraph: It’s an auspicious time at New York City Ballet, with new choreographic voices multiplying. Along with Justin Peck’s well-received premiere last week came the announcement that he and two other young choreographers — the corps member Troy Schumacher and the Royal Ballet’s Liam Scarlett — will create new pieces for the company next season (a first for Mr. Schumacher).

headline: Philharmonic Transformation, From Members to Mission
abstract: Even as it faces the challenge of renovating its hall, the New York Philharmonic confronts the need to replace five of its signature musicians.
lead_paragraph: The New York Philharmonic is playing musical chairs in reverse these days, as retirements and a couple of unexpected departures have left it with more seats than players — and the most turnover of principal players, or section leaders, since World War II.

headline: A Funny Name, a Serious Sport. Pickleball, Anyone?
abstract: Nearly half a century since its creation, the tennis, table tennis and badminton hybrid is growing in popularity among baby boomers.
lead_paragraph: GAINESVILLE, Va. — MAYBE it was the whimsical name — pickleball — that got baby boomers to try the game. A hybrid of racket and paddle sports, it was not notably new. Pickleball began on Bainbridge Island, Wash., where legend has it that Pickles, the resident cocker spaniel, would chase the errant ball. It was Pickles’s ball, thus the name.

headline: When Singing the Blues Is a Performer’s Pleasure
abstract: Carole J. Bufford, originally inspired by Bessie Smith, brings the blues to the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: The singer Carole J. Bufford’s love affair with the blues began when she was 13 years old and discovered Bessie Smith on a two-disc set, she recalled last Thursday at the Metropolitan Room. She has immersed herself in the genre ever since. And this supremely confident performer has brought her accumulated know-how to her new show, “Shades of Blue.”

lead_paragraph: Like many people who were in any proximity to the events of Sept. 11, the artist Spencer Finch often thought later about the color of the sky that day, the kind of crystalline blue that pilots and meteorologists call “severe clear.”

headline: A Country Lament Sinks Into Despair
abstract: Sturgill Simpson’s “Metamodern Sounds in Country Music” is a triumph of exhaustion, one of the most jolting country albums in recent memory.
lead_paragraph: Sturgill Simpson is a top-notch miserablist, from the lyrics that pick at scabs to his defeated vocal tone, leaky even when he’s singing at full power. His second album, “Metamodern Sounds in Country Music” (High Top Mountain), is a triumph of exhaustion, one of the most jolting country albums in recent memory, and one that achieves majesty with just the barest of parts.

headline: Q & A: Leta Hong Fincher on ‘Leftover Women’
keywords: ['Domestic Violence', 'Marriages', 'Men and Boys', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Women and Girls', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: In her new book, Leta Hong Fincher argues that gender inequality is growing in China and identifies a key area where that can be seen — property ownership.
lead_paragraph: After the 1949 Communist revolution, Mao Zedong declared that “Women hold up half the sky.” It was a phrase that caught the imagination in China and the world. Yet as socialism has crumbled and a Leninist state, married with elements of a market economy, steers the country, women’s position is slipping, as Leta Hong Fincher examines in her new book, “Leftover Women: The Resurgence of Gender Inequality in China.”

headline: Street Style in Minneapolis
abstract: Wearing a leather jacket, slim-fit pants and combat boots, Qais Munhazim, 29, said he paid attention to the cut of his clothes.
lead_paragraph: In the Uptown section of Minneapolis, young professionals enjoy happy hour, motorcycle gangs hang out at sober coffee shops and true “uptowners” cling to the past with their punky aesthetic. Qais Munhazim, 29, moved there from Afghanistan five years ago to study political science. Wearing a leather jacket, slim-fit pants and combat boots, he said he pays attention to the cut of his clothes. This interview has been edited and condensed.

lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Behind the dancing fountains of the Bellagio Hotel, hedge fund titans mingled with wealth managers at the Hyde nightclub on Tuesday night.

headline: Volunteers Provide Backup to the Uniformed Ranks
abstract: Retirees perform tasks for the Civil Air Patrol, Coast Guard Auxiliary, state militias and police departments, taking risks and shouldering at least some of the costs.
lead_paragraph: DELRAY BEACH, Fla. — BERNARD ZARETSKY, 82, co-coordinator of the Delray Beach Police Department’s Volunteer Program, devotes about 100 hours a month to preventing discord in the resort community, but his duties have the added benefit of keeping the peace in his nearly 60-year-long marriage.

headline: Eyeing the Prize
abstract: Are competitions for young designers the best way to make it in the high-risk fashion business?
lead_paragraph: In late February, on the second night of Paris Fashion Week, the corporate fashion giant LVMH hosted a cocktail party at its Paris headquarters on Avenue Montaigne to celebrate the LVMH Prize, a new award for young fashion designers. Over flutes of Champagne, fashion world notables like Karl Lagerfeld, Nicolas Ghesquière, Raf Simons, Anna Wintour and a recent Vogue cover subject, Kanye West, were stalking the atrium-turned-designer-showroom. The 30 semifinalists for the award were tucked away in jam-packed booths, accompanied by a rack of clothes, a model or two and a slight sheen of sweat.

headline: Off-Kilter, Off the Racks
abstract: Massimo Giorgetti founded his label, MSGM, on a few key principles: color, youth and energy.
lead_paragraph: The current middleweight champion of bombast in Milan is a young designer named Massimo Giorgetti, who founded his label, MSGM, in 2009 on a few key principles: color, youth and energy. His bright, lavishly printed sweatshirts, T-shirts and dresses went wide fast. Label recognition is still on the rise (the mouthful name, the initials of the four founding partners, may not help), but the collection is available in some 500 stores worldwide, including Bergdorf Goodman and Kirna Zabête in New York.

headline: Autodesk Unveils Open-Source 3-D Printing System

headline: A Swirl of Duality and Dueling Identities
abstract: An interplay of mirror images infuses Zoe/Juniper’s “BeginAgain Installed,” a New York premiere at 3LD Art & Technology Center.
lead_paragraph: You had to watch where you stepped as you entered Zoe/Juniper’s “BeginAgain Installed.” A thick layer of soil covered the floor of the cryptlike space at 3LD Art & Technology Center. Planted in the middle, sprouting out from one wall, was what looked like a massive glass chamber, a sort of triangular aquarium whose walls turned out to be both reflective and transparent. The floor inside was bare, more pristine than its outskirts. The audience sat on either side of this structure, two groups facing each other, just one of many mirror images that appeared over the next hour.

headline: The Trade-Offs of Relocating North to Canada
abstract: The relatively few Americans who move to Canada often find that they enjoy the country’s more liberal policies and free health care, though there are adjustments to make.
lead_paragraph: IT’S a nearby country where most natives speak English and there are few major cultural differences from the United States. Yet the number of Americans choosing to head north to retire in Canada has remained low — reaching a high of 1,675 in 2008 (for immigrants older than 49), then dipping to 1,060 in 2011, and rising again in 2013 to an estimated 1,565.

headline: Laid-Back Summer Fashions

abstract: Phoebe Philo’s “uniform,” the Céline way; a Sophie Hulme bag that’s nautical and fresh; Yoox releases a collection of sweatshirts for the World Cup and more.
lead_paragraph: In a recent article on Phoebe Philo and the mythology of Céline, the “uniform” of the trendsetting label was characterized this way: large, slouchy trousers; a collarless shirt; flats; a tuxedo jacket. And that collarless shirt — modern, minimal — looks sharper than ever, a perfectly cut everyday top to match with tailored pieces and laid-back weekend wear. The stylist Marina Muñoz had the right idea, effortlessly pairing her oversize tunic-like top with black trousers. Wear the longer styles with boyfriend jeans and loafers, the cropped versions with high-waist skirts and printed pants. And any of them, of course, the Céline way.

headline: Italian Glass, for Your Bidding
abstract: Twentieth-century classics by Napoleone Martinuzzi and others will be auctioned next week in Chicago.
lead_paragraph: One of the most comprehensive collections of 20th-century Italian glass is on view in New York just as it is being dispersed. As a preview for a sale next Tuesday in Chicago, Wright auction house has packed its Manhattan showroom at 980 Madison Avenue with glass vessels and sculptures consigned by the photo stylist and art director Dimitri Levas. He’s been acquiring them since the ’70s, focusing on celebrated makers and designers like Venini, A.V.E.M., Gio Ponti and Carlo Scarpa. Many are from the foresighted store Fifty/50. A few belonged to Robert Mapplethorpe, Mr. Levas’s former collaborator. A 1920s globular blue vase by Napoleone Martinuzzi is estimated at $20,000 to $30,000; an Ercole Barovier mosaic cylinder from the same decade, $25,000 to $35,000. Information: 212-585-0200 or wright20.com.

headline: Reaching Back for Its Design Cred
abstract: Umbra’s new Shift collection features jaunty, mostly handmade furnishings.
lead_paragraph: Umbra is going back to its roots. This Toronto-based company, which started 34 years ago selling chic window shades to small, independent design stores, has grown into a $130 million global business. But Les Mandelbaum, Umbra’s chief executive, keenly missed its design cred. “You get rich, but you lose your soul,” he said. So Mr. Mandelbaum and the company’s design director, Matt Carr, came up with Shift, a brand of goods being introduced this weekend at the International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York that are jaunty, relatively affordable and in many cases handmade. The new line includes whimsical works like Philippe Malouin’s wood folding chair with a built-in hanger ($250 each), Harry Allen’s Coiled stool with a thread-wrapped rattan tractor seat ($250) and Paul Loebach’s Cup lamp, a combination desk lamp and pencil caddy ($180). “These are all things we actually want to take home,” Mr. Carr said. Information: 800-387-5122 or umbrashift.com.

headline: She Says ‘God Bless You’
abstract: An allergy sufferer tests the Blueair Sense air purifier.
lead_paragraph: If you’re like me, the majority of your spring is spent red-eyed, runny-nosed and violently sneezing. For those seeking allergy relief indoors, the Blueair Sense ($479), a sleek air purifier, promises to eliminate 99.97 percent of airborne irritants like dust, smoke and pollen.

headline: Open Cover; Insert Brilliance
abstract: Plumb notebooks were designed by artists to “maximize creativity.”

headline: Don’t Force Google to ‘Forget’
abstract: But it does need to change how it searches for personal names.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — THE European Court of Justice ruled on Tuesday that Europeans have a limited “right to be forgotten” by search engines like Google. According to the ruling, an individual can compel Google to remove certain reputation-harming search results that are generated by Googling the individual’s name. The court is trying to address an important problem — namely, the Internet’s ability to preserve indefinitely all its information about you, no matter how unfortunate or misleading — but it has devised a poor solution.

headline: Ganges River: Revered, Soiled and Symbol of an Indian Election Campaign
abstract: Narendra Modi, the front-runner in the race for prime minister, has made the cleanup of the river that flows through Varanasi a metaphor for his campaign as he seeks to stamp out corruption.
lead_paragraph: VARANASI, India — For centuries, Hindus have brought their dead to banks of the Ganges River in this ancient city, with the promise that if their bodies are burned on the riverfront, their souls will escape the constant cycle of rebirth and attain moksha, or salvation. Transporting their souls is the goddess of the river, whose ebbs and flows have run through thousands of years of civilization.

headline: The Kidnapping of a Country

In this northeast Nigerian village, where more than 300 teenage schoolgirls were kidnapped by the militant Islamist separatist group Boko Haram on April 14, their stunned families were still waiting this week for them to come home.

But a new analysis of state arrest data by a nonprofit called the Marijuana Arrest Research Project, which studies police policy, suggests that the de Blasio administration is on track to equal the more than 28,600 low-level marijuana arrests that were made under Michael Bloomberg in 2013. The administration needs to review Police Department policy to make sure these arrests are necessary and being fairly made.

headline: Britain: Former Editor Testifies on Hacking of Royals
keywords: ['Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods', 'Royal Family']
abstract: Clive Goodman, former royalty editor of The News of the World, said that he had listened to the voice mails of the former Kate Middleton, Prince William and Prince Harry.
lead_paragraph: The long-running trial of the former tabloid editors Rebekah Brooks and Andy Coulson heard testimony on Wednesday that The News of the World had hacked the cellphones of the royal family and its closest associates. Clive Goodman, former royalty editor of the newspaper, which is now defunct, said that before his arrest and conviction for illegal eavesdropping in 2006 he listened to the voice mails of the former Kate Middleton 155 times, of Prince William 35 times and of Prince Harry nine times. Prince William is in line to become king, and Ms. Middleton, now his wife, was then his girlfriend. Mr. Goodman is charged with conspiring to pay officials for royal phone directories, and he said he had not previously disclosed his hacking of royal telephones because the police had never asked him. Earlier in the trial he testified that he had hacked only aides working for the royals, and he has been promised by the prosecution that he will not be further charged for hacking.

headline: Saudi Arabia: 5 More Deaths From Virus Reported
abstract: The Saudi Health Ministry said the latest fatalities from infections caused by the virus known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome brought the total in that country to 157.
lead_paragraph: Saudi Arabia reported five more deaths on Wednesday from a mysterious respiratory virus that first appeared there two years ago and has since spread to at least 16 other countries, including the United States. The Saudi Health Ministry said the latest fatalities from infections caused by the virus, known as Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, brought the total in that country to 157. Saudi Arabia accounts for the vast majority of the 171 deaths and 571 infections from the virus globally. The Saudi announcement came as the World Health Organization said in a statement that its concern about MERS “had significantly increased,” but that there was still “no evidence of sustained human-to-human transmission” of the virus.

headline: South Korea: Murder Charges in Ferry Disaster
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Ferries', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The captain and three other crew members of the ferry that capsized off the southwestern coast of South Korea in April were indicted on murder charges Thursday, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: The captain and three other crew members of the ferry that capsized off the southwestern coast of South Korea on April 16 were indicted on murder charges on Thursday, prosecutors said. The indictments were among formal charges leveled against 15 crew members of Sewol, the 6,825-ton ferry, after weeks of investigations into the causes of the sinking. As of Thursday, 281 people had been found dead and 23 remained missing. All 15 crew members had previously been arrested on various criminal charges, including accidental homicide. But on Thursday, prosecutors brought the more serious murder charges against the captain, Lee Jun-seok, and three others. They were accused of failing to try to rescue people on board and fleeing the vessel even though they knew that people were in danger and would die without their help. If convicted, the four could face death sentences.

headline: The Hot Seat
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Books and Literature', 'Subprime Mortgage Crisis', 'Banking and Financial Institutions']
abstract: Former Treasury secretary Timothy F. Geithner’s memoir offers an inside look at the government’s response to the financial crisis.
lead_paragraph: He’s written a really good book — we might as well get that out of the way, as so much else about Timothy F. Geithner remains unsettled. Geithner served as president of the New York Federal Reserve from late 2003 to 2008 and secretary of the Treasury from 2009 to 2013, and so sat near the center of the American financial system as it prepared to self-destruct. He then had a courtside seat to the global catastrophe. He has rich material to work with, and he has contrived to preserve its freshness. His inability as Treasury secretary to explain himself, or his actions, or the financial crisis, or his beliefs about financial reform, to the wider public will leave many readers, I suspect, feeling they are hearing his voice on these subjects for the first time.

headline: Still Radioactive and Spoiling for a Fight
abstract: Godzilla, everybody’s favorite skyscraper stomper, returns in a remake directed by Gareth Edwards, and he’s showing some familiar generational traits.
lead_paragraph: Godzilla shows up fairly late in the new movie that bears his name, and he also shows his age. Though this gigantic monster is, within the film’s own mythico-scientific terms, the long-slumbering reminder of a primordial, prehuman age, by the calendar of popular culture, he’s a baby boomer. And now, roughly 60 years after he first appeared (as Gojira in the still unsurpassed, recently restored Japanese original), everybody’s favorite skyscraper stomper is exhibiting some familiar generational traits. He seems grumpy and underslept, as well as thicker around the jowls and midriff. And though he arrives dragging the usual heavy allegorical baggage, you can detect a trace of wistful worry in his rampages, as if he had begun to doubt his own relevance.

headline: Rearranging Warhol’s Legacy
abstract: The reorganized Andy Warhol Museum dedicates as much attention to Warhol’s role in pop culture as it does to his celebrated art.
lead_paragraph: PITTSBURGH — Andy Warhol was, chronologically and by his own description, a nose picker, a pimp and a water guzzler. He was also (or therefore) one of the most various, complex and impressive talents the art world has produced. All those claims, however unlikely, can be confirmed by a visit to the Andy Warhol Museum here in his hometown. In honor of its 20th anniversary, the museum has been rethought from top to bottom, and the results are now being revealed to the public. There may not be another museum that digs as deep into a single artist, and gets as much out of the excavation.

headline: Classical Playlist: Beethoven, Shostakovich, Tigran Mansurian and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: SHOSTAKOVICH, KHACHATURIAN: Violin Concertos and QuartetsJames Ehnes, violinist; Melbourne Symphony Orchestra; Ehnes Quartet(Onyx) The Armenian composer Aram Khachaturian composed his Violin Concerto for David Oistrakh. James Ehnes conveys its lighthearted mood, folk elements and virtuosic passages with sweet tone and technical aplomb, deftly accompanied by the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra and the conductor Mark Wigglesworth. Shostakovich’s String Quartets No. 7 and 8, which Mr. Ehnes performs with his quartet, offer a stark contrast in mood — particularly their searing rendition of the Eighth. (Vivien Schweitzer)

abstract: Risk aversion prompted by instability in Ukraine, among other things, has encouraged investors to seek safe havens like U.S. Treasury bonds.

The Federal Reserve was pulling away from its program of pumping money into bond markets. The era of cheap money seemed to be coming to an end after all these years.

headline: Evil Stalks the Stage: It’s Curtains!
abstract: Theater and gory horror movies have long been strange bedfellows. Here is a sampling of films set in the cutthroat world of theater.
lead_paragraph: Ghost lights. Traps. Bombs. “You killed it.” Hang around theater people long enough, and you might think the industry is a living slasher film. Theater and horror movies have been strange bedfellows since European filmmakers of the silent era incorporated Grand Guignol dramatics and expressionistic stage techniques into early movies like “Waxworks” and “The Hands of Orlac.” More recently, theater makers have tapped into the horror movie canon to concoct stage versions of “Night of the Living Dead” and “The Exorcist.”

headline: Car Bomb Kills More Than 40 at Syrian Border Crossing

It appeared to be the latest instance of civilians bearing the brunt of clashes between Islamist groups in insurgent-held territory.

headline: When Your Teenager Wants a Car: The Money Conversations

lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, most teenagers dream of owning a car, and unless you live in a place with terrific public transportation, you’ll probably entertain the idea of letting them have one. One of the biggest questions, then, is who should pay for it?

headline: The Cadets at New Market
abstract: How a corps of Virginia Military Institute students found themselves on the front lines in the Shenandoah Valley.
lead_paragraph: On the evening of May 10, 1864, on the first anniversary of the battlefield death of Gen. Thomas “Stonewall” Jackson, who had been a professor at the Virginia Military Institute before the war, some 300 V.M.I. cadets paraded the lush grounds in full dress while bands played and nearby townsfolk came to pay their respects. “Groups of girls in filmy garments set off with bits of color came tripping across the sod; and children and nurses sat about the benches at the guard-tree,” one cadet recalled.

headline: After European Court Decision, Google Works on a Tool to Remove Links

abstract: A basic online tool for people to ask Google to take down potential harmful links would be in place in about two weeks, a top German regulator said.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Google will announce by the end of the month a mechanism for consumers to request that links to information about them be removed from the company’s search engine, a leading European regulator said on Thursday. It was one of the first signs that Google was working through how to operate after a court ruling said consumers could make such requests.

headline: Two New Murder Charges Brought Against Hernandez
abstract: The former New England Patriots tight end Aaron Hernandez, who was in custody on one murder charge, has been indicted in a 2012 double homicide.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — The 2012 New England Patriots were an offensive force, setting a record for first downs in an N.F.L. season while scoring 557 points. Tight end Aaron Hernandez was a big part of that offense, catching 51 passes for 483 yards and scoring five touchdowns. He had 15 more receptions in the playoffs as the Patriots advanced to the A.F.C. championship game.

headline: Happy in a World of Quirk

lead_paragraph: For Mike Myers, it is not the least bit humbling to go from making comedies for millions of viewers to performing for an audience of one, assuming that person is his 2-year-old son, Spike.

headline: Art Matters | The Art World Eyes a New Destination: Gwangju, South Korea
abstract: The lineup for this fall’s Gwangju Biennale has just been announced, putting the city — and the event’s curator, Jessica Morgan of the Tate Modern — on the map.
lead_paragraph: Throughout most of the past week, Randalls Island seemed the most far-flung art destination anyone in the New York art world was paying attention to. But a dinner at the West Village club Norwood held during Frieze New York shifted attention to a locale halfway around the world. The curator Jessica Morgan of the Tate Modern in London announced the artists participating in her edition of the Gwangju Biennale in South Korea this fall, which runs Sept. 5 though Nov. 9. Founded in 1995, the event is South Korea’s most important international exhibition, and arguably Asia’s as well, and has put the nation’s sixth-largest city on the map.

lead_paragraph: Some of New York’s best dance companies will be part of Victory Dance, a series over the summer that will provide free dance performances and classes to children in New York City Department of Education day camps and programs. The lineup, between July 16 and Aug. 1, includes Ballet Tech’s Kids Dance, Lil Buck, Michelle Dorrance, Doug Elkin, Full Circle Souljahs, Gallim Dance, Ballet Hispanico, Keigwin & Company, Lava, Monica Bill Barnes & Company and Ronald K. headline: Held Hostage in Sudan with Gabriel García Márquez
abstract: A woman captured by militants recalls how a book kept her alive.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four years have passed since I was kidnapped and held hostage for 105 days while working to bring education to the children of the war-torn region of Darfur, Sudan. In some respects my captivity seems all but a distant memory. The passage of time, however, will never diminish my fond recollections of my only trusted companion during those long, death-defying days—Gabriel García Márquez. With his recent passing, all of the harrowing and heart-tugging memories of our time together came flooding back.

headline: Now Screening | Takashi Murakami Makes a Movie
abstract: T debuts an exclusive clip from the Japanese artist’s first film — tickets for a June 1 screening in New York go on sale today.
lead_paragraph: Takashi Murakami is one of the few artists alive who might genuinely be considered a household name. The Japanese maestro’s hard-edged, big-featured monsters, beauties and flower-faces — famously executed by a vast network of studio assistants, some of whom have spawned their own cult iconographies under the umbrella of his art production and artist management company Kaikai Kiki Co. — are the progenitors of the self-explanatory art movement known as “Superflat,” which has long since exploded beyond the walls of galleries and onto Louis Vuitton bags, Supreme skate decks and any niche product that can be refashioned as a postmodern canvas.

In one marsh after another, lush stretches of cordgrass disappeared, replaced by bare ground. The die-offs were wiping out salt marshes in just a few years.

Women tend to speak up less on topics they aren’t well versed in, whereas men comfortably hold forth on topics they have little expertise on.

headline: Error at IBM Lab Finds New Family of Materials
abstract: The materials, called thermosets, are unusually strong and light, exhibit “self-healing” properties and can be easily reformed to make products recyclable.
lead_paragraph: As a research chemist at an IBM laboratory, Jeannette M. Garcia spends her days mixing and heating chemicals in pursuit of stronger and more easily recyclable plastics. Recently she followed a simple formula that required mixing three components in a beaker. Somehow she missed a step, leaving out a chemical. She returned to find her beaker filled with a hard white plastic that had even frozen the stirrer.

headline: As Barbara Walters Retires, the Big TV Interview Signs Off, Too
abstract: Ms. Walters has been the queen of the TV celebrity “get.” But stars and politicians no longer need the networks to reach their public.
lead_paragraph: On a Wednesday night in early March 1999, Barbara Walters invited a small group of friends and colleagues to her Manhattan apartment to watch her two-hour interview with Monica Lewinsky. During a commercial break, Ms. Walters stood by the window, looking out over Central Park, and noticed something peculiar. “There’s no traffic on Fifth Avenue,” she observed.

headline: Close, Lithgow, Plimpton To Star in ‘Delicate Balance’ on Broadway
abstract: The revival of Edward Albee’s 1966 play will be Glenn Close’s return to Broadway after 20 years.

The producer Scott Rudin announced the casting and performance plans on Thursday. The director will be Pam MacKinnon, an Albee expert who won a Tony last year for staging a revival of his classic “Who’s Afraid of Virginia Woolf?”

lead_paragraph: Mel Patton, who overcame a badly broken leg as a child to become known as “the world’s fastest human” in the 1940s and win two gold medals in the 1948 London Olympics, died on May 9 in Fallbrook, Calif., near San Diego. He was 89.

lead_paragraph: A day after The New York Times announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, its first female executive editor, after only 33 months on the job, its publisher was denying reports that her removal was related to complaints about unequal compensation in comparison with her predecessors.

headline: Workers Seize City in Eastern Ukraine From Separatists
abstract: Pro-Russian militants melted away as steelworkers and miners, armed only with protective clothing and hard hats, began patrols in the city of Mariupol.
lead_paragraph: MARIUPOL, Ukraine — Thousands of steelworkers fanned out on Thursday through the city of Mariupol, establishing control over the streets and banishing the pro-Kremlin militants who until recently had seemed to be consolidating their grip on power, dealing a setback to Russia and possibly reversing the momentum in eastern Ukraine.

headline: Ousted Director Rejoins GrafTech Board
abstract: Investors in GrafTech, the small steel company at the center of a corporate governance debate, have reinstated Nathan Milikowsky and two allies to the board.
lead_paragraph: Investors of GrafTech, the small steel company at the center of a corporate governance debate, have re-elected an ousted director to the board, along with his two of his allies.

headline: Rolls-Royce Aims ‘Into the Blue’ With the Waterspeed Collection
abstract: Rolls-Royce says it will create 35 hand-built cars that draw their inspiration from a record-setting ’30s-vintage speedboat.
lead_paragraph: A limited-edition, deep blue Rolls-Royce Phantom Drophead Coupé, commemorating a 77-year-old world record speed run on water, will be unveiled to the public May 23-25 at the Villa d’Este Concorso d’Eleganza at Lake Como in Italy.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 1
abstract: Some players’ fantasy stock increased drastically when they were drafted into a great situation with ample playing time.
lead_paragraph: Success in fantasy football has as much to do with a player’s talent as it does with the state of the team’s roster. The most talented players often earn the best opportunities, but sometimes that takes time.

headline: New York Revives Talk of Hosting the 2024 Games
abstract: Government officials have held “very preliminary” talks about the possibility of New York City bidding for the 2024 Summer Games, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo said this week.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s bid for the 2012 Olympics ended badly. Might the city’s political leaders try again?

headline: The Right Price for AstraZeneca’s Stock
abstract: A new Reuters Breakingviews calculator shows why investors seem to believe that a $100 billion-plus acquisition by Pfizer will probably happen.
lead_paragraph: Investors are putting a lot of faith in Pfizer succeeding in its $100 billion-plus quest to acquire British pharmaceuticals rival AstraZeneca. The right price for the target’s share price can be seen as the weighted average of two possible outcomes – a sale to Pfizer or a standalone future. A new Breakingviews calculator shows why the market seems to think a transaction will probably happen.

headline: Convicted of Felonies, Banks Are Allowed to Stay in Business

lead_paragraph: Two large international banks — Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas — are expected to plead guilty to criminal charges within the next few weeks. If that happens, they will pay large fines and officially be felons.

headline: Impossible? Only Until You Prove Otherwise
abstract: The head of a marketing company is out to prove the impossible is possible, whether beating a rare cancer or landing a client thought unattainable.
lead_paragraph: This interview with Rob Gough, president of Eckim, a marketing company, was conducted and condensed by Adam Bryant.

headline: Created by Hand: Lock, Stock and Barrel
abstract: The guns Joseph Kindig collected, which will be on exhibit at the Reading Public Museum in Pennsylvania, were each the work of a single artisan.
lead_paragraph: The antiques dealer and collector Joseph Kindig Jr. never fired a shot with any of his hundreds of American rifles made around 1800. He was not a hunter; he was a vegetarian who did not like to kill anything. At his store in York, Pa., he would refuse to sell his gun inventory to buyers who seemed snobbish or ignorant. He believed that the firearms represented the first major American artistic innovation.

headline: One Singular Thai Sensation
abstract: In Elmhurst and Long Island City, sampling two versions of a simple Thai chicken-and-rice dish.
lead_paragraph: This is it, the only dish on the menu, the reason the restaurant exists: chicken over rice on a paper plate, white on white on white. Pale-skinned moons of cucumber lie to one side, a lone stem of cilantro on top.

headline: France Asserts It Has Authority to Block Mergers
abstract: The government has formally given itself the power to block foreign takeovers on strategic grounds as it seeks to sway the outcome of a battle between General Electric and Siemens for Alstom.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The French government has formally given itself the power to block foreign takeovers on strategic grounds as it seeks to sway the outcome of a battle between General Electric and Siemens for Alstom, one of France’s industrial crown jewels.

headline: California Chrome Coughs, but Trainers Say He Is Fine
abstract: California Chrome, the winner of the Kentucky Derby and the 3-5 favorite to win the Preakness Stakes on Saturday, was deemed to be fine despite coughing after his morning gallop.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — It is more a tickle than a hitch. At least that is how the trainer Art Sherman characterized the cough California Chrome came up with Thursday morning.

headline: Prehistoric Skeleton in Mexico Is Said to Link Modern Indians to Earliest Americans
abstract: DNA in the bones of a teenage girl in an underwater cave in the Yucatán show that she has an Asian-derived genetic lineage, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Most geneticists agree that Native Americans are descended from Siberians who crossed into America 26,000 to 18,000 years ago via a land bridge over the Bering Strait. But while genetic analysis of modern Native Americans lends support to this idea, strong fossil evidence has been lacking.

headline: La Scala to Fire Incoming Director After One Season
abstract: Alexander Pereira was to begin his six-year tenure at La Scala in Milan in October, but the board voted to honor his contract only until 2015.
lead_paragraph: MILAN — In what Mayor Giuliano Pisapia described as an agonizing decision, the board of La Scala on Thursday voted to dismiss that opera theater’s incoming director general at the end of his first season, amid charges of a conflict of interest.

abstract: Give me a brisk, strong defense of something I disagree with.
lead_paragraph: It’s commencement season, cellphones off please, no texts or tweets. Even with a hangover from debt, alcohol or regret, grads across the land may be lucky enough to hear something on the Big Day that actually stays with them.

headline: U.S. Mines Personal Health Data to Find the Vulnerable in Emergencies
keywords: ['Medicare', 'Privacy', 'Medicine and Health', 'Disasters and Emergencies', 'Data-Mining and Database Marketing']
abstract: A Medicare pilot program aims to use vast volumes of government data to direct assistance to potentially vulnerable people, but it has raised privacy concerns.
lead_paragraph: The phone calls were part Big Brother, part benevolent parent. When a rare ice storm threatened New Orleans in January, some residents heard from a city official who had gained access to their private medical information. Kidney dialysis patients were advised to seek early treatment because clinics would be closing. Others who rely on breathing machines at home were told how to find help if the power went out.

lead_paragraph: Considering James Madison

headline: The Funeral Buffet and Other Existential Issues
abstract: In William Burke’s “the food was terrible,” at the Bushwick Starr in Brooklyn, the discussion in a bar revolves around people who died and the services for them.
lead_paragraph: A man in a wrinkled sport coat perches on a bar stool. “I was at your daughter’s wake,” he tells the bartender (Evander Duck). Let’s hope the customer (Noel Joseph Allain) likes that sentence. He’ll say it more than 20 times in William Burke’s brief, oblique “the food was terrible,” at the Bushwick Starr.

headline: The Gun Report: May 15, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Whenever a child opens fire at a school, wounding and killing classmates and teachers, we want to know why. If the shooter commits suicide during the rampage, all we can do is guess.

headline: Life Could be a Dream (if Your Name Is Alice)
keywords: ['Movies', 'Video Releases (Entertainment)', 'DVD (Digital Versatile Disc)', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Jan Svankmajer’s “Alice,” and Ken Loach’s “Black Jack” are released on DVD.
lead_paragraph: “Alice in Wonderland” has been adapted as an all-star Paramount production (1933), with Cary Grant as the Mock Turtle; as a British puppet animation (1949), eclipsed by the Disney animated musical (1951), later embraced as a head film by the drug culture of the late ’60s; as Dennis Potter’s meditation on the old age of the real Alice (“Dreamchild,” 1985); and as Tim Burton’s 3-D extravaganza (2010) starring Mia Wasikowska as a 19-year-old Alice. None, however, is stranger than “Alice” (1988), made by the Czech animator Jan Svankmajer, newly remastered and reissued on Blu-ray by First Run Features.

headline: The March to War
abstract: Two books explore the run-up to World War II in the United States and Japan.
lead_paragraph: In February 1933, President-elect Franklin Roosevelt was nearly murdered in Miami by a gunman whose errant fatal shot struck Mayor Anton Cermak of Chicago. Cermak gallantly told Roosevelt, “I’m glad it was me instead of you.” Today’s Americans should not disagree. Had Roosevelt been killed, the 32nd president of the United States would have been his running mate, Speaker John Nance Garner of Texas, a neophyte in foreign and military affairs, isolationist by instinct and deeply rooted in a Congress determined, notwithstanding the growing threats from Hitler and the imperial Japanese, to keep another president from repeating what a majority of its members considered to be Woodrow Wilson’s catastrophic mistake of needlessly dragging the nation into a distant “foreign war.”

headline: All the Way
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Civil Rights and Liberties']
abstract: The Civil Rights Act of 1964 was passed through the efforts of political operatives, liberal activists — and Lyndon Johnson.
lead_paragraph: Over the past century, Congress has passed only a handful of truly transformative pieces of legislation. The Social Security Act comes to mind, as do the G.I. Bill, the Marshall Plan, the laws that created a mammoth military and laid down a web of highways, and the reforms that reopened the nation to immigration. Visionary laws — each and every one — meant to achieve policy aims of striking originality.

headline: Russian Businessman Under Sanctions Fires Broadside at West
abstract: Vladimir I. Yakunin, the head of Russian Railways and an associate of Vladimir V. Putin, made the remarks at a forum he hosted in Berlin.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — The president of Russian Railways, Vladimir I. Yakunin, a longtime associate of President Vladimir V. Putin, is persona non grata to Washington. Sanctioned by the United States in retaliation for support of Moscow’s annexation of Crimea, he has been banned from entering the country and any assets there have been frozen.

headline: Rand Paul’s Hard Road
keywords: ['Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The pitfalls of an idiosyncratic candidate’s unusual presidential path.
lead_paragraph: It is fair to say, I think, that Rand Paul is one of the most interesting major contenders for the Republican nomination in 2016, and by extension for the presidency. (That’s why everyone at this newspaper keeps writing about him!) It’s also fair to say that his path to both destinations would be unique, at least by the standards of modern G.O.P. presidential contenders: There are no obvious recent historical models for the kind of coalition Paul would need to put together to win either the nomination or the presidency, and there isn’t even a recent near-miss candidate (his father, for all his grassroots success, was just a “miss,” with nothing near about it) whose almost-success he could try to build upon.

headline: Russia Tells Ukraine: Cash in Advance for Gas
abstract: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia, in a letter, said that Ukraine’s gas debt had ballooned in the last month.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — Russia said on Thursday that it would stop supplying gas to Ukraine at the end of the month unless the country paid for it in advance, increasing the pressure on Kiev’s financially pressed government as it struggles to contain a growing rebellion in the country’s east.

headline: Bonding Through Time, on Film and in Life
abstract: Cédric Klapisch, whose series of films has been tracking the lives of four characters, explores their evolutions as they near 40 in “Chinese Puzzle.”
lead_paragraph: Shortly after arriving in New York from France to study film, Cédric Klapisch, then 23, was interrogated by a roommate: “Where do you think you’ll be in 10 years?” Though he knew he wanted to direct, Mr. Klapisch, now 53, recalled: “I couldn’t really answer that question. I knew that my life was ahead of me, and didn’t know what my life would look like.”

headline: As Maman Lay Dying, Her Spirit Became Art
abstract: “Rachel, Monique,” Sophie Calle’s installation at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest, examines her mother’s life and death through photographs, diary entries and a deathbed film.
lead_paragraph: Wandering into the sumptuous neo-Gothic chapel of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest on the Upper East Side of Manhattan, you might think you’d come upon the lovingly arranged setting for a funeral. You’ve actually walked into a work of art by the French conceptualist Sophie Calle, an installation called “Rachel, Monique.” It’s an elegiac but frustratingly oblique meditation on the life and the death of Ms. Calle’s mother, Monique Sindler. (The Rachel in the title was another name by which she was known.)

headline: A Song of the Country With Frog Chorus
abstract: Offstage, the actors Audra McDonald and Will Swenson retreat to Westchester.
lead_paragraph: After 9/11, Audra McDonald no longer felt safe living in New York City. “I had recently given birth, was still quite hormonal and, like everyone else, I was frightened,” recalled Ms. McDonald, now 43, and a Tony Award nominee for her starring role in the Broadway show “Lady Day at Emerson’s Bar & Grill.” “And I kept saying to my husband ‘we have to leave the city, we have to leave the city.’ ”

headline: At Least You Don’t Have to Buy a Gift
abstract: Addressing questions of feeling snubbed, a snoring passenger, a canceled wedding and group texts.
lead_paragraph: The son of a very close friend is getting married. My husband and I were not invited. My friend claims that the young couple is paying for the wedding themselves, that money is tight and that even relatives had to be excluded. But I know my friend invited some of her college friends. I have let her know that I will be hurt if I am not included. She seems embarrassed, and I don’t think she wants to lose my friendship, yet I remain uninvited. I’m afraid that I won’t feel the same about her after the wedding. What’s the best way to handle this?

headline: 36 Hours in Washington, D.C.
abstract: From flowers to fried oysters, shopping to shakes, spend a weekend exploring in the shadow of the Capitol.
lead_paragraph: While most Americans associate Capitol Hill with Congressional misadventures and general dysfunction, thousands of people — senators, reporters, congressional aides, artists, working-class long-timers and young families — call it home. Amid the charming rowhouses and grand federal buildings, Capitol Hill is dotted with restaurants and night spots. Its history is vibrant and largely accessible, from the United States Capitol to the Navy Yard, where the banks of the Anacostia River were once lined with military ships, to dynamic H Street, the site of riots after the 1968 assassination of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. And don’t forget baseball. Take in a Nationals game, if possible, among cheering fans and very good stadium chow.

headline: British Cede Le Brun Portrait to the Met
abstract: After a battle with the British, the Metropolitan Museum of Art has successfully purchased an important 17th-century portrait by the French artist Charles Le Brun.
lead_paragraph: In 17th-century France, Charles Le Brun was as hot as any artist could be. He created work for the Cathedral of Notre-Dame in Paris, for the Galerie d’Apollon in the Louvre, for Hôtel Lambert on Île St. Louis, for the Château de Vaux-le-Vicomte and for much of Versailles. Louis XIV declared him “the greatest French artist of all time.” Whatever he produced made an impact.

lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Two young Palestinian men were killed Thursday in clashes with Israeli security forces during a demonstration for Nakba Day, which commemorates the destruction of Arab villages in battles that led to the establishment of the State of Israel in 1948.

headline: Love, Sex, Marriage and Schopenhauer’s Ghost
abstract: “Chinese Puzzle,” the third film in a trilogy, centers on a womanizing Frenchman who follows his ex-wife to New York.
lead_paragraph: “The next Proust” is the dubious marketing tag applied to Xavier Rousseau (Romain Duris), a flighty, footloose novelist, by his editor in “Chinese Puzzle,” the French filmmaker Cédric Klapisch’s airborne romantic comedy. So what if there is nothing remotely Proustian about Xavier, the womanizing charmer with an idiot grin from two earlier films — “L’Auberge Espagnole” and “Russian Dolls” — also written and directed by Mr. Klapisch. Xavier, like the other returning characters from those movies, is about to turn 40. But in his carefree attitude, he might as well be 25.

headline: Robert Heinecken, Master of the Photographic Juxtaposition
abstract: The late artist, who created compelling, thought-provoking abstractions from existing imagery, has a new show opening at Petzel Gallery to complement his in-progress exhibition at MoMA.
lead_paragraph: Robert Heinecken is having a posthumous resurgence. The artist — who founded the UCLA photography department and famously described himself as a “para-photographer,” generated photographic images without using a camera — has an exhibition called “Object Matter” at MoMA through Sept. 7, his first since his death in 2006. A second show, “I Am Involved in Learning to Perceive and Use Light,” opens tonight at Petzel Gallery and runs through June 21. The title is taken from a 1974 essay by the artist, which the gallery offers in lieu of a press release. In it, he discusses his intentions, methodologies and views on aesthetic value systems. “My basic tenet is relatively simple,” he explains. “To relate the former to the future, the last to the next.” Heinecken carries out this philosophy quite literally in one of the best known strands of his practice, a related series of double exposures made from the 1960s to the 1990s, in which he culled current events and women’s magazines to find individual pages containing two faces that made unforgettable figurative abstractions when overlaid.

headline: Life in the City as a Jazzy Medley of Movie Themes and Show Tunes

lead_paragraph: A thematically organized social history of New York City told through several decades of movie songs is the concept of Joanne Tatham’s tourist-friendly cabaret show “Soundtrack New York,” heard at the Metropolitan Room on Tuesday evening.

headline: Illuminating and Elevating What Is Familiar
abstract: The violinist Krista Bennion Feeney consistently brought color and depth to the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble’s program at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday.
lead_paragraph: Eight members of the St. Luke’s Chamber Ensemble played at the Morgan Library & Museum on Wednesday evening, but one kept catching the ear: the violinist Krista Bennion Feeney. Keen throughout, she followed the intermission with a riveting rendition of the Sonata in C from Jean-Marie Leclair’s “Quatrième Livre de Sonates.”

headline: A Mischievous Half-Smile, Cloaked in Mystery

lead_paragraph: In the midst of a frantic week of art fairs and auctions, a splendid Renaissance portrait made a quiet and dignified entrance at the Frick. Parmigianino’s “Schiava Turca,” a painting of an unidentified woman with twinkling hazel eyes and a mischievous half-smile, invites us to settle in for a restorative session of close looking.

headline: The Internet Isn’t Just for the Young
keywords: ['Documentary Films and Programs', 'Movies', 'Elderly', 'Computers and the Internet']
abstract: The documentary “Cyber-Seniors” chronicles a program, developed by Canadian teenagers, to teach elderly retirees how to use the Internet and social media.
lead_paragraph: Early in the documentary “Cyber-Seniors,” you might find yourself saying, “Ugh, are they really going to make me watch octogenarians poke fruitlessly at laptops for 75 minutes?” But the film soon stops that torture and becomes a likable intergenerational tale with a bit of unexpected pathos.

headline: Astorino, at G.O.P. Convention, Vows ‘Fight to Save New York’
abstract: The party designated Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, to run against Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo.
lead_paragraph: RYE BROOK, N.Y. — Rob Astorino, the Westchester County executive, accepted the Republican Party’s designation to run for governor on Thursday and painted a bleak picture of Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo’s tenure as marked by economic doldrums, stifling taxes and a lack of political courage.

headline: Tilting at Genres
abstract: Dan Fogler stars in “Don Peyote,” which he wrote and directed with Michael Canzoniero.
lead_paragraph: DON PEYOTE

headline: Musicians on Speed Dates
abstract: Featuring 17 musicians from a range of native styles, “A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets,” at Town Hall on Wednesday, unspooled as a continuous, overlapping succession of pairings.
lead_paragraph: James Carter, a wildly charismatic tenor saxophonist, and Petra Haden, an equally irrepressible vocalist, had a moment halfway through “A Night of Improvised Round Robin Duets,” at Town Hall on Wednesday. It started almost songlike, with a haunting, wordless vocal melody answered by a limpid saxophone obbligato.

headline: Mirror Images, From Real Life or Fun House
abstract: Five new art books offer unusual reflections into American life, using everything from family photographs to tattoos.
lead_paragraph: The idea is often dismissed today, but one mandate of art is to reflect how we live. I’m not talking about the flat mirrors of nostalgia polished and perfected by Norman Rockwell and Andrew Wyeth — a jagged shard of broken glass is just fine to gaze into — but rather art we can stare in the eye and say, “Yeah, that kind of looks like me.”

headline: Should Young Children Learn Coding?
abstract: Readers respond to a front-page article, “Reading, Writing, Arithmetic and Now Coding.”

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Major Deal for Denis Villeneuve Film
abstract: Paramount pays a reported $20 million for distribution rights for the sci-fi film.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — In the first major sale at this year’s Cannes Film Festival, Paramount Pictures announced on Thursday that it had acquired distribution rights to “Story of Your Life,” a science-fiction blowout directed by Denis Villeneuve and starring Amy Adams as a linguist hired by the military to determine the intentions of alien spacecraft that have landed on Earth.

headline: Grandes Dames of the Gardens
abstract: “Groundbreakers,” an exhibition at the New York Botanical Garden, pays tribute to the women who designed and photographed the great American gardens of the early 20th century.
lead_paragraph: If you start your sojourn through the New York Botanical Garden’s multipart “Groundbreakers” exhibition as you are meant to — looking at a show about photography in the gallery next to the library — then when you finally reach the conservatory displays, you will feel overwhelmed by a mosaic of color, texture and pattern, a fragrant allée of floral extravagance.

headline: Bringing the Wisdom of Middle Age to Punk
abstract: The punk band Off! delivered a rousing 50-minute, 22-song set on Monday night at Asbury Lanes in Asbury Park, N.J.
lead_paragraph: ASBURY PARK, N.J. — “Life’s rotten,” reasoned Off!’s frontman, Keith Morris, small and bothered, crease-faced, dreadlocked, pacing. This was somewhere around the middle of a 50-minute, 22-song set on Monday night at Asbury Lanes, a bar and bowling alley here with low ceilings and focused sound. And this was his version of crowd riling: bad news first, then a suggestion. “So” he continued, “while you’re out there being abused, used, being treated unfairly, have fun and enjoy yourselves.”

headline: She’s Just Off the Boat. He’s the Wrong Man.
abstract: “The Immigrant” tells the story of a Polish woman’s arrival in New York in 1921 and the complicated scoundrel who forces her into prostitution.
lead_paragraph: In American popular culture, and in the private lore of millions of American families, the immigrant experience of the late-19th and early 20th centuries is often presented as a chronicle of struggle and triumph, a parable of dreams come true. In “The Immigrant,” James Gray (who directed the film and wrote it with Richard Menello) tries to push through this rosy nostalgia and recapture some of the terror and strangeness of the journey from the Old World to the New. The first shot is of the Statue of Liberty shrouded in harbor mist, and the film unfolds in the gap between the promise that lady embodies and the harsh realities a newcomer encounters once she gets off the boat.

headline: See Me. Feel Me. Maybe Drool on Me.
abstract: “Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988” is a comprehensive survey of this influential Brazilian artist and therapist.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Modern Art’s sprawling survey of the work of the influential Brazilian artist Lygia Clark has a singularly unpromising title: “Lygia Clark: The Abandonment of Art, 1948-1988” signals something of a letdown, especially if you like art. But once you’ve worked your way through this up-and-down massing of some 300 works, equally fitting and less stark alternatives may come to mind, including “the expansion of art” and “the internalization of art.”

headline: Critical Thinking, From Socrates to the Ivory Tower
abstract: Professors respond to a Sunday Review article, “Young Minds in Critical Condition.”
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

abstract: William Milczarski and Peter Tuckel, professors at Hunter College, discuss their research results on New Yorkers who ride against traffic.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Electricity in New York
abstract: Judith Rodin of the NYS 2100 Commission explains the benefits of smart-grid technology.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Edie Falco: Meditate. Then It’s Time to Play.
abstract: On Sundays, Ms. Falco, star of the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie,” enjoys “free-floating time,” and maybe a show, with her two children.
lead_paragraph: For Edie Falco, star of the Showtime series “Nurse Jackie,” Sunday is a day for “free-floating time” with her son, Anderson, 9, and her daughter, Macy, 6. The children’s godfathers may pay a visit. There may be a movie or a play. There’s usually a meditation class. Ms. Falco, 50, has won four Emmys, one for “Nurse Jackie” and three for her role as Carmela Soprano in “The Sopranos.” A single mother, she lives in the West Village with her children and the family’s rescue dog, Sami, a Brussels griffon. Ms. Falco often rides around town on her electric bike.

headline: Charging Into the Minefield of Genes and Racial Difference
keywords: ['Genetics and Heredity', 'Books and Literature', 'Race and Ethnicity']
abstract: In “A Troublesome Inheritance,” Nicholas Wade argues that races evolved differently, and that scientists should pursue studies of the biological and genetic differences between them.
lead_paragraph: Few areas of science have contributed more to human misery than the study of racial difference. In the 1920s, eugenicists from top American universities promoted the sterilization of the unfit and later praised Hitler’s racial codes while advocating laws that would exclude thousands of Jews from our shores.

headline: Ideology and the Court
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Courts and the Judiciary']
abstract: A reader responds to a Sunday Review article about the Supreme Court.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Pace University to Start Performing Arts School
abstract: The new Pace School of Performing Arts will be Manhattan’s first new such school in nearly 50 years, the university said.
lead_paragraph: Pace University is starting a performing arts school, which the university said will be Manhattan’s first new such school in nearly 50 years. The new school, Pace School of Performing Arts, grew out of Pace’s performing arts program.

headline: A Meal Schedule for Diabetes
abstract: For people with Type 2 diabetes, two large meals a day may be better than the same number of calories consumed in six small meals.
lead_paragraph: For people with Type 2 diabetes, eating two large meals a day may be better than consuming the same number of calories in six small meals.

headline: Sommeliers Decanting the Madness of Cannes
abstract: A shortage of female directors in competition, the film “Timbuktu,” the return of Jean-Luc Godard, and a young director’s suicide were part of the opening-day buzz at the Cannes Film Festival.
lead_paragraph: CANNES — They know how to put on a good show at the Cannes Film Festival, even when forced to make do with an opening-night dud and the lack of a closing-night selection. No matter how serious and aesthetically high-minded, the festival always banks on its stars. This year Quentin Tarantino will help wrap up the proceedings by introducing a restoration of Sergio Leone’s 1964 red-sauce western, “A Fistful of Dollars.” It’s a celebrity event that will bookend the one delivered on Wednesday, when Nicole Kidman — the star of the widely derided “Grace of Monaco” — drifted down the red carpet, reprising her familiar role as a supernova who transcends her every stinker.

headline: A Balanchine Double Bill, With Heart-Stopping Pauses
abstract: New York City Ballet presented “Robert Schumann’s ‘Davidsbündlertänze’ ” and “Union Jack,” with the curtain falling on radically different notes.
lead_paragraph: The choreographer George Balanchine is seldom listed among the 20th century’s great dramatists, and yet many of his ballets take us as close to the essence of drama as any playwright. What’s more, few theater artists have anything of his vast expressive range.

headline: Events in Westchester for May 18-24, 2014
abstract: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley.
lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in the Hudson Valley. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to westweek@nytimes.com.

headline: Reading Experience May Change the Brains of Dyslexic Students
abstract: Recent research suggests that the difficulties dyslexia creates with reading may not be hard-wired. Instead, experience may play a big role in exacerbating reading problems and, potentially, in easing them.
lead_paragraph: Among the many challenges faced by children with dyslexia (and by their parents and teachers) is the nagging fear that their difficulties with reading are entirely hard-wired: predetermined by their genes and impossible to change. Recent research offers a balm for that fear. It suggests that experience plays a big role in dyslexia, both in exacerbating reading problems and, potentially, in easing them.

headline: Arrests Made in Assault on Park Redwood Trees
keywords: ['Crime and Criminals', 'Forests and Forestry', 'Poaching (Wildlife)', 'Vandalism', 'Wood and Wood Products']
abstract: Two men are arrested and charged in connection with wood poaching from giant redwood trees in a California park.
lead_paragraph: Earlier this year I wrote about a spate of criminal assaults on redwood trees in a California park — all targeting the bulbous growths called burls that are prized by woodworkers and furniture makers.

headline: Challenging Authority and Taking the Heat
abstract: “Ai Weiwei: The Fake Case” is Andreas Johnsen’s documentary about Mr. Ai, a Chinese artist long at odds with his government.
lead_paragraph: Part of the reason the Chinese artist Ai Weiwei — the subject of a current exhibition at the Brooklyn Museum and of the Danish filmmaker Andreas Johnsen’s new documentary, “The Fake Case” — is such an intriguing figure is that his recent career feels like the latest battle in the very old war between the imagination and the state. Especially since 2008, when the aftermath of the Chengdu earthquake in Western China awakened his conscience and made him a determined critic of his government, Mr. Ai has taunted, mocked and passionately denounced the authoritarianism, corruption and incompetence that he sees around him. He has made more-or-less conventional works of art reflecting these concerns, and made deft use of social media and his own celebrity.

headline: Ireland’s Troubled Peace
abstract: Cracks are beginning to appear in the country’s 16-year calm.
lead_paragraph: FORTY years ago this Saturday, three no-warning bombs ripped through Dublin. Less than an hour later, another bomb shattered the rural quiet of the town of Monaghan. In all, 33 people were killed and more than 300 injured. In Dublin, sheets of newspaper were laid over the dismembered bodies to hide them from view. The headlines soaked up the blood: the news in advance.

headline: Theater Listings for May 16-22
abstract: A critical guide to productions in New York City, including shows in previews.
lead_paragraph: Approximate running times are in parentheses. Theaters are in Manhattan unless otherwise noted. Full reviews of current productions, additional listings, showtimes and ticket information are at nytimes.com/theater. A searchable, critical guide to theater is at nytimes.com/events.

headline: Hapless Meal Tickets, Plucked From India
abstract: “Million Dollar Arm” centers on a self-centered sports agent who recruits potential major league pitchers in India.
lead_paragraph: “Baseball isn’t just about business. You should have fun, too.”

headline: Attending Life’s First Breath and Its Last
abstract: The documentary “The American Nurse,” a tribute to the profession, focuses on five who work across life’s spectrum, from labor and delivery to hospice.
lead_paragraph: Frankly, “The American Nurse” sounded unpromising. When Carolyn Jones, the director, had breast cancer, she was so touched by the nursing care she received that she wanted to pay tribute to the profession. Sweet, understandable, admirable. But you sort of want to say, Why not just send them a card? Ms. Jones, however, has delivered a solid, worthwhile documentary. If the film is workmanlike at times, it is also elegantly cleareyed.

lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.
