lead_paragraph: A scene from the film directed by Justin Schwarz.

headline: At SALT Conference, Stocks Induce Anxiety
abstract: At the hedge fund industry’s annual gathering in Las Vegas, managers voiced concerns about the direction of the stock market.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — At the the SkyBridge Alternatives Conference here, hedge fund managers are gathering at the Bellagio hotel to exchange views and ideas.

headline: What Lewis and Clark Inspired
abstract: In “The Discoverers,” a history professor takes his children on a family-fraught trip with historical re-enactors.
lead_paragraph: On paper, “The Discoverers” sounds like “National Lampoon’s Vacation” crossed with a self-help manual. Lewis (Griffin Dunne) is a struggling history professor in Chicago who, à la Grady Tripp in “Wonder Boys,” is preparing to publish a nearly 7,000-page tome. In the sort of excursion that might generously be described as a getaway, he piles his teenage kids, Zoe (Madeleine Martin) and Jack (Devon Graye), into the car, bound for a conference in Portland, Ore. The road trip’s destination suddenly changes when Lewis’s mother takes a turn for the worse.

headline: Coke and McDonald’s, Growing Together Since 1955
abstract: The beverage maker and the fast-food chain have had close ties since 1955, to the point where Coca-Cola even has a McDonald’s division.
lead_paragraph: It was early 1955 when Ray Kroc, an ambitious milkshake equipment salesman who had bought the right to expand McDonald’s throughout the country, was opening his first restaurant, in Des Plaines, Ill.

headline: Alzheimer’s, a Neglected Epidemic
abstract: Alzheimer’s, which has been linked to far more deaths than AIDS, has failed to garner the same national outrage and attention, even as AIDS deaths have begun to fall.
lead_paragraph: The opening shots of “The Normal Heart,” HBO’s adaptation of Larry Kramer’s 1985 play about the early days of the AIDS crisis in New York, reveal a crew of sinewy and amorous young men disembarking from a ferry on Fire Island on a beautiful July day in 1981. The tableau is meant to suggest the final hour of unburdened desire, the moment before so much youth and beauty would be sacrificed to the cruelest attacks of physiology and cultural indifference.

headline: Remastering, Reflecting: Everything Still Turns to Gold
abstract: Jimmy Page, the founder of Led Zeppelin, has been remastering the group’s entire catalog and says he would love to be onstage playing music again.
lead_paragraph: In Boston last week to deliver the commencement address at the Berklee College of Music, Jimmy Page, the founder of Led Zeppelin, learned to his surprise that the school had a course in which his guitar licks were minutely analyzed. “They go into all these things and deconstruct them,” he said, “the harmonies and the voicings and the progressions, the arrangements.”

headline: It Was Open Mike at the Upfront Events
abstract: The professional comics were out, but so were network executives and actors who tried out their own bits.
lead_paragraph: HERE is a look at some highlights, lowlights and sidelights of upfront week, which took place from Monday through Thursday as television executives offered Madison Avenue previews of their schedules for the 2014-15 season.

headline: In Nigeria, the Personal and the Political Clash
abstract: Chiwetel Ejiofor and Thandie Newton star in “Half of a Yellow Sun,” set during the 1960s in a newly independent Nigeria.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the greatest challenge faced by literary adaptations that juxtapose a small group of characters against a seismic backdrop — “Doctor Zhivago,” say, or “The Leopard” — is one of proportion. “Half of a Yellow Sun,” adapted from the 2006 novel by Chimamanda Ngozi Adichie, emerges on screen as a well-acted, finely wrought epic that nevertheless struggles to balance the requirements of melodrama with its drive to capture a historical moment. The movie could easily have been a mini-series, but at just under two hours, it plays like a highlight reel.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Quirky, discerning picks for interesting things to do in Texas this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Pepsi Challenges Coke in the Race to Design a More Tappable Soda Fountain
abstract: With soda sales sliding in grocery and convenience stores and other retail outlets, new equipment offers the companies a means of introducing consumers to their products.
lead_paragraph: Thanks to new weaponry built with touch screens, Italian design and the latest technology, the cola wars are returning to an old battleground, the soda fountain.

headline: Providing for the Dead
abstract: Gary Gotlin, the Staten Island public administrator, arranges burials of unclaimed bodies, saving them from mass graves in a potter’s field.
lead_paragraph: Gary Gotlin emerged from his black BMW on Monday at a Staten Island cemetery and approached 10 small white coffins, each topped with a bouquet.

headline: Searching for Quality in Assisted Living Care
abstract: A Place for Mom, a company that helps with placement in assisted living centers, now offers an online guide to the information each state provides.
lead_paragraph: FINDING the right assisted living option for a family member can be a daunting task, and it’s not always easy to find data about the quality of various facilities.

headline: Texas Chases New Business but Worries About Water
abstract: A recent effort to lure a maker of the hot sauce sriracha from California came despite the challenges farmers face in a state where they have been given low priority for dwindling water supplies.

headline: Obamas Had Up to $7 Million in Assets in ’13, Records Show
abstract: The president’s main source of income continues to be his publishing career. But Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. earned less than $201 in royalties from his book in 2013.
lead_paragraph: The assets of President Obama and his wife, Michelle, were valued as high as $7 million last year, according to a financial disclosure form released by the White House on Thursday.

headline: Mourners Attend a Mass Burial
keywords: ['Accidents and Safety', 'Mines and Mining', 'Soma, Turkey, Mining Disaster (2014)']
abstract: Hundreds of mourners attended a mass burial for some of the miners killed in the Turkey coal mine disaster.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of mourners attended a mass burial for some of the miners killed in the Turkey coal mine disaster.

headline: On the Range, With a Conscience
abstract: Kirk Hanna, the focus of the documentary “Hanna Ranch,” appeared in “Fast Food Nation.”
lead_paragraph: As Kirk Hanna did in life, Mitch Dickman’s documentary “Hanna Ranch” wrestles with ecological concerns. But the biggest problems for Mr. Hanna were very, very human. This Colorado cattle rancher — a featured personality in Eric Schlosser’s 2001 best seller “Fast Food Nation” — was a forward-thinking cowboy who embraced Holistic Resource Management, a fruitful approach that, among other things, encourages herding methods less stressful to cattle and a more frequent rotation of livestock through pastures. Mr. Hanna used earth-friendly natural fertilizer; to attack weeds, he employed hungry goats.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 16, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Godzilla,” “The Immigrant” and “Million Dollar Arm.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Godzilla,” “The Immigrant” and “Million Dollar Arm.”

headline: A Menace Who Chops Up Bodies and Enjoys a Good Singalong
abstract: The director Greg McLean reminds viewers of a perilous destination for tourists in “Wolf Creek 2,” a sequel.
lead_paragraph: With “Wolf Creek 2,” the director Greg McLean returns once more to remind us that the back of beyond — in this case, the Australian outback — is a perilous destination for unwary tourists. But those of us who championed its 2005 precursor, the artfully petrifying “Wolf Creek,” neither need nor want reminding. Like Neil Marshall’s “The Descent,” another crazy-good frightener released in America the following year, “Wolf Creek” deserved to stand alone, a uniquely moody and melancholy blood bath.

headline: Foreclosed, Cantankerous and Heading South
abstract: Robert Duvall plays a down-on-his-luck rancher who chooses a wild adventure over giving in to failure.
lead_paragraph: Robert Duvall won his Oscar for his finely calibrated portrayal of a recovering alcoholic country singer in “Tender Mercies,” and much of his best work is in service to nuanced roles. Yet his most memorable performances also include some where he goes big, as in, for example, the napalm-loving Lt. Col. Bill Kilgore in “Apocalypse Now.” When he has fun, he lets us in on it.

headline: A Depressed Writer, Distracted by His Ailing Parents
abstract: A floundering Brooklyn writer decamps to Florida to help his ailing parents and makes new friends and tighter family ties.
lead_paragraph: Though he’s played a committed writer on television (“October Road”), Bryan Greenberg doesn’t always come across as one in Michael Maren’s “A Short History of Decay.” That makes some sense, as Mr. Greenberg’s 30-something character, Nathan, just switched from being a struggling novelist to being an inactive playwright. But the best parts of Mr. Maren’s well-observed film aren’t always to be found in its accessible setup.

headline: After an Accident, a Test of Forgiveness
abstract: A widowed factory worker ends up working alongside the man who accidentally caused her husband’s death in the Japanese film “Cold Bloom.”
lead_paragraph: Atsushi Funahashi’s gloomy drama takes place in a depressed industry town in the aftermath of the 2011 earthquake and tsunami. But the hand of misfortune has yet one more blow in store, as Shiori, who works in a small factory, loses her husband, Kenji, to an accident. A pall is cast over life, felt in her stunned grief and in a dim workplace resembling a cluttered supply closet.

headline: The Thin Line Between a Pest and a Reformer
abstract: As the Texas House moves closer to impeaching Wallace Hall, a University of Texas System regent, the focus moves closer to what he has dug up about how the system operates.
lead_paragraph: Ross Ramsey, the executive editor of The Texas Tribune, writes a regular column for the Tribune.

headline: Reports of Gas Odors Surge After East Harlem Blast
abstract: The number of calls to Consolidated Edison has led to a backlog of pipe repairs nearly twice as big as state regulators consider acceptable.
lead_paragraph: After an explosion leveled two apartment buildings in East Harlem in March, killing eight people, officials of Consolidated Edison were exasperated that nobody had sounded an alarm until it was too late.

headline: The Case for ‘Soft Atheism’
abstract: It is possible to reject all religious doctrines as false without dismissing religion itself.
lead_paragraph: This is the sixth in a series of interviews about religion that I am conducting for The Stone. The interviewee for this installment is Philip Kitcher, a professor of philosophy at Columbia University and the author of the forthcoming book “Life After Faith: The Case for Secular Humanism.”

headline: Telling the Gypsies’ Tale Beyond the Stereotype
abstract: “A People Uncounted” focuses on how Gypsies, as people known as the Roma are called, have been disenfranchised and persecuted.
lead_paragraph: The subtitle to the documentary “A People Uncounted” — “The Untold Story of the Roma” — might lead you to expect a historical overview of the people known as the Roma, or Gypsies. It’s a fascinating culture, which migrated to Europe from Northern India 1,000 years ago. The word “Gypsy,” derived from “Egyptian,” is a misnomer; equally misleading is a stereotype of joyfully itinerant musicians, dancers and petty thieves that persists in opera, literature, pop hits and movies.

headline: N.B.A.’s Replay Controversies Could Lead to a Review
abstract: Incidents in Nets-Heat and Clippers-Thunder playoff games are the latest to call attention to what officials are allowed to review.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Clippers forward Matt Barnes was parked in front of the television at home Wednesday night, watching the end of the Nets-Miami Heat game while his twin 5-year-old boys busied themselves wrestling.

headline: Travelers Move Past Their Own Limits
abstract: The documentary “Next Year Jerusalem” tells the story of eight pilgrims from a Jewish nursing home as they tour Israel.
lead_paragraph: Traditions may vary, but Passover Seders typically end with the wish that the participants might celebrate again “next year in Jerusalem.” For eight pilgrims from the Jewish Home for the Elderly in Fairfield, Conn. — average age, 91 — next year was 2011, when they toured Israel, along with nursing aides, administrators and a film crew.

headline: Divergent Paths
abstract: As economies in Northern Europe show signs of improvement, the southern rim nations continue to struggle. The uneven nature of the recovery has weighed on the overall European economy, which will probably take years to truly recover.
lead_paragraph: As economies in Northern Europe show signs of improvement, the southern rim nations continue to struggle. The uneven nature of the recovery has weighed on the overall European economy, which will probably take years to truly recover.

headline: Full Recovery Still Years Away for Many in Euro Zone
keywords: ['Economic Conditions and Trends', 'European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )']
abstract: The uneven nature of the recovery — between a group of strong countries in the north and a larger swath of weak nations in the southern rim — has made it difficult for the overall economy to gain momentum.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Despite recent optimism that Europe’s economy is finally turning a corner, a stark reality remains: The situation is still fragile.

headline: F.C.C. to Help Small Firms Buy Airwaves
abstract: The agency said it would set aside certain portions of the airwaves for purchase in auctions by smaller wireless companies.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Federal Communications Commission on Thursday adopted new rules governing coming auctions of airwaves for use in mobile broadband, and the agency said it would set aside certain portions of the airwaves for purchase by smaller wireless companies.

headline: News Groups Sue for Data on Missouri’s Executions
abstract: The lawsuit charges that prisoners are routinely executed using “a secret drug formulation obtained from secret sources,” denying the public its rightful access to important information about the criminal justice system.
lead_paragraph: A group of news organizations sued the Missouri Department of Corrections on Thursday, arguing that the department is violating the First Amendment by refusing to identify the sources of lethal drugs used in its executions.

headline: Points of No Return
abstract: False doctrines on climate science have become badges of identity for Republicans, and that’s more frightening than some of the environmental change underway.
lead_paragraph: Recently two research teams, working independently and using different methods, reached an alarming conclusion: The West Antarctic ice sheet is doomed. The sheet’s slide into the ocean, and the resulting sharp rise in sea levels, will probably happen slowly. But it’s irreversible. Even if we took drastic action to limit global warming right now, this particular process of environmental change has reached a point of no return.

headline: M.T.A. Expanding Weekend Service on the L Line to Handle Growing Crowds
abstract: The Metropolitan Transportation Authority plans to increase service on the L subway line this fall, adding 33 round trips on Saturdays and 22 round trips on Sundays.
lead_paragraph: The math problem of the New York City subway system is no secret, its remainders spilling onto the platforms where luckless travelers watch full trains come and go.

headline: For 160 Years, Always Something New
abstract: The Brooklyn Women’s Exchange, a shop selling handmade wares, was founded in Brooklyn Heights in 1854, helping women in need sell needlework and handicrafts without resorting to factory work.
lead_paragraph: At the Brooklyn Women’s Exchange, a nonprofit, volunteer-run shop selling handmade wares, the atmosphere is instantly soothing. Rows of baby sweaters in Jordan almond colors hang neatly on a rack. A gangly trio of stuffed rabbits shares table space with a stack of crocheted blankets. Nat King Cole music plays softly in the background. Two volunteers murmur to each other as they sort through a pile of tiny hand-knit bootees in pastel green, lemon and pink. The scent of lavender wafts delicately from the soap display. Call it retail tonic.

headline: AIDS Groups Back Anti-H.I.V. Pill Amid Concerns Doctors and Patients Will Resist
keywords: ['Truvada (Drug)', 'Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Preventive Medicine', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: In interviews and in a flood of online comments, experts and others on the front lines of the battle against H.I.V. made it clear that the regimen could be slow to take hold.
lead_paragraph: Despite new federal guidelines urging gay men and others to take a daily pill to prevent AIDS, the idea may prove a tough sell to many doctors and patients.

headline: Times Seeks to Reassure Its Staff After Abramson’s Ouster
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'News and News Media', 'Executive Compensation', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: Senior editors met with employees to reiterate that Jill Abramson’s departure did not reflect sexism and was not about pay disparity, but about a style of leadership.
lead_paragraph: A day after The New York Times Company announced that it had dismissed Jill Abramson, The Times’s first female executive editor, it found itself mired in controversy, having to reassure employees and rebut reports that her removal was related to her complaints about receiving less pay than her male predecessors.

headline: The Man in a Red Bandanna
abstract: The opening of the National September 11 Memorial Museum was a day for remembering extraordinary people and their acts of compassion.
lead_paragraph: Among the many moving moments at the dedication of the National September 11 Memorial Museum in Lower Manhattan on Thursday was a story President Obama told about the man in a red bandanna. Seeking to calm residents, the unspecified number of troops began patrolling cities, including Recife, one of the hosts of the World Cup soccer tournament in June. The police strike in Pernambuco is part of a broader wave of strikes and protests in several large cities around Brazil this month as labor unions representing teachers, bus drivers and street cleaners seek wage increases. Police unions across the country said they were considering a one-day strike next week. Separately, protests against Brazil’s spending on World Cup stadiums drew thousands into the streets on Thursday in São Paulo and other cities.

headline: Iran: Oil Exports Continue to Decline
keywords: ['Nuclear Weapons', 'Oil (Petroleum) and Gasoline', 'International Trade and World Market']
abstract: Iran’s oil exports declined in April for the second consecutive month, the International Energy Agency reported Thursday, moving much closer to levels permitted under a temporary accord on the Iranian nuclear dispute that is set to expire in July.
lead_paragraph: Iran’s oil exports declined in April for the second consecutive month, the International Energy Agency reported Thursday, moving much closer to levels permitted under a temporary accord on the Iranian nuclear dispute that is set to expire in July. Monthly data compiled by the energy agency, a 29-member group of oil importers, showed that Iran’s exports were 1.11 million barrels a day in April, down from 1.29 million barrels a day in March and 1.58 million barrels a day in February. The temporary accord specified that Iran’s monthly oil exports are not to exceed one million barrels a day on average for the six-month duration, and the excesses raised concern among critics of the accord that Iran was violating its terms. Obama administration officials have said they believe that Iran’s May, June and July exports will be lower. Under the accord, some Western economic sanctions were eased in exchange for a freeze on most of Iran’s nuclear activities, for the purpose of giving negotiators more time to reach a permanent agreement. Negotiators for the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council plus Germany are seeking guarantees that Iran’s nuclear fuel cannot be used to make bombs.

headline: Afghanistan: U.S. Repatriates Pakistanis
keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Detainees', 'Prisons and Prisoners', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The American military has repatriated 10 Pakistani prisoners whom it had held at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: The American military has repatriated 10 Pakistani prisoners whom it had held at Bagram Air Base in Afghanistan. The transfer of the detainees to Pakistani custody was announced by the Justice Project Pakistan, which represents Pakistani detainees at Bagram. It said the International Committee of the Red Cross had told the men’s families about the move. An American official familiar with the matter confirmed Thursday that the transfers had taken place. The military has already transferred to Afghan control the bulk of Afghan prisoners at Bagram but has retained custody of “third country nationals,” whom the Afghan government does not want to deal with. The transfers reduce the number of those prisoners to 39, according to the official. More than two dozen of them are Pakistani. Some of those just released will be detained in Pakistan, while others will be released but subject to monitoring, the official said.

Barkhad Abdi, a first-time actor who received an Oscar nomination, plays Muse, their leader, whose actions lead to the arrival of the American military and its warships. “The existential realities that inform contemporary Somali piracy turn out to be one of the unexpected themes of ‘Captain Phillips,’ which begins as something of a procedural about men at work and morphs into a jittery thriller even as it also deepens, brilliantly, unexpectedly, into an unsettling look at global capitalism and American privilege and power,” Manohla Dargis wrote in The New York Times about this best picture nominee, adapted by the director Paul Greengrass from Mr. Phillips’s book, “A Captain’s Duty: Somali Pirates, Navy SEALS, and Dangerous Days at Sea.” “Phillips is unambiguously a heroic figure, but he’s scarcely the sole point of interest in a movie that steadily and almost stealthily asserts the agonized humanity of his captors.”

Given that we are covering books, which generally have a set publishing date, the “news” in the book world is known well in advance. This gives us the luxury of time in planning what we think will be the most powerful and compelling cover for each issue.

lead_paragraph: BIG BREAKS FOR BANKS  |  If, as expected, two banking giants ‒ Credit Suisse and BNP Paribas ‒ plead guilty to criminal charges in the next few weeks, they will probably pay large fines and officially be felons, Floyd Norris writes in the High & Low Finance column. But, he asks, does it matter that these will be criminal, not civil, punishments? The issue is not that banks may be “too big to jail,” but that, big or small, banks and other corporations are “too inanimate to jail,” Mr. Norris writes.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — One by one, the boulders had been stacked upon their shoulders in recent weeks. If it was not listening to the racist rant by their owner, Donald Sterling, it was wondering what to do about it — were black socks enough? Then there were the camera crews from CNN and TMZ at their practices.

headline: Actress, Artist, Sometimes Both at Once
abstract: In the romantic comedy “Words and Pictures,” Juliette Binoche plays a painter and is a painter: All of the original artwork in the film is hers.
lead_paragraph: In the new romantic comedy “Words and Pictures,” a rolling office chair becomes a tool for art creation. Juliette Binoche, playing an art teacher whose rheumatoid arthritis affects her ability to paint, lies on her stomach across the chair, grabs a paintbrush and swivels from one part to another of the canvas on the floor. Passion and pain become a part of each stroke, as Ms. Binoche both plays a visual artist and is one.

lead_paragraph: For months now, Amazon has been trying to put the screws on Hachette, the smallest of the Big Five publishers, by discouraging people from buying its printed books. Amazon’s goal: force Hachette to give it better terms on e-books.

headline: Unrest Poses a Risky Choice for Vietnam
abstract: As Vietnam’s government deals with the fallout from a week of violence aimed at foreign businesses, it risks angering both residents and investors.
lead_paragraph: HA TINH PROVINCE, Vietnam — The hundreds of men on motorbikes who roared into Lee Hsueh Ying’s factory compound north of Ho Chi Minh City were bent on revenge against China. Some clung to red-and-gold Vietnamese flags while they careened around overwhelmed security guards. And in a scene repeated elsewhere in the country’s industrial heartland, they destroyed the building, smashing furniture, snatching computers and shouting “Long Live Vietnam.”

lead_paragraph: FULLERTON, Calif. — Eleven a.m. on a Tuesday: time for business to begin at Burger Records, if it ever really ends. The nerve center of fourth-wave garage rock — a record label and a store — is in a small, square space, slotted along with a vaping emporium and a tattoo parlor in a strip mall along a four-lane artery, near industrial parks, a food-service-equipment manufacturing plant and the Anaheim town line. It’s Orange County industrial suburbia, where most of what is visible — parking lots, buildings, grass allotments, signage, Dumpsters — has been city-planned into rectangles.

headline: A History of New York Traffic Lights
abstract: But for a few traffic officers, regulation until 1920 amounted to “Hey, watch out!”
lead_paragraph: Tired of cars — and bikes — running red lights? How about no lights at all? That’s the kind of traffic system New York had until 1920, when a series of tall bare-bones towers went up down the middle of Fifth Avenue, flashing red and green lights to the growing onslaught of automobiles. Two years later they were replaced with formidably elegant bronze and granite towers, sumptuous contributions to the City Beautiful, but destroyed within a decade, victims of increasing traffic.

headline: TV Critics Buddy Up for New Book
abstract: Alan Sepinwall and Matt Zoller Seitz will collaborate on a book of essays for Grand Central Publishing about “the most artistically and culturally significant American dramas, comedies, miniseries, variety shows and more.”
lead_paragraph: Whether it’s Felix and Oscar, Bert and Ernie, Cagney and Lacey or Simon and Simon, television has consistently provided a home for memorable duos. Now a pair of veteran television critics are partnering up to write a book that will examine various series while chronicling the six-decade history of the medium. Alan Sepinwall, of HitFix.com, and Matt Zoller Seitz, of New York magazine and Vulture.com, will collaborate on a book of essays for Grand Central Publishing about “the most artistically and culturally significant American dramas, comedies, mini-series, variety shows and more,” including hits like “Seinfeld” and “The Sopranos,” as well as cult favorites like “Freaks and Geeks” and “My So-Called Life,” the publisher said in an email.

headline: Upstate, and Back in Time
abstract: Retracing an ancestor’s steps, I found that two centuries changes only so much.
lead_paragraph: I followed the man off the river and into a labyrinth of creeks behind town, heading deeper into a thickening haze of marsh grass and listing trees. He paddled ahead in his green canoe while I trailed in my rowboat, picking my way around old dredging pipes and doubting that I’d find my way back out of this fractal backwater. Through the trees, worlds emerged: a tiny island of R.V.s, a string of vacation cottages, a far bank of empty-eyed concrete houses.

headline: Always Hungry? Here’s Why
abstract: Are we fat because we overeat, or do we overeat because we’re fat?
lead_paragraph: FOR most of the last century, our understanding of the cause of obesity has been based on immutable physical law. Specifically, it’s the first law of thermodynamics, which dictates that energy can neither be created nor destroyed. When it comes to body weight, this means that calorie intake minus calorie expenditure equals calories stored. Surrounded by tempting foods, we overeat, consuming more calories than we can burn off, and the excess is deposited as fat. The simple solution is to exert willpower and eat less.

headline: Itinerary | Cartagena’s Burgeoning Style Scene
abstract: Thanks to an influx of chic restaurants, high-end shops and elegant hotels — and a new, direct JetBlue flight from New York — the Colombian city is more vibrant than ever.
lead_paragraph: The sultry city of Cartagena has for some time been a weekend destination for wealthy Colombians and in-the-know international globetrotters. They come to stroll the cobblestone streets lined with faded colonial homes, dance and drink rum at the always bustling Club Havana, and then sleep off their hangovers on the postcard-perfect beaches on the nearby islands. Recently, though, Cartagena has seen an influx of more stylish restaurants, shops and hotels (the Ritz Carlton and Four Seasons are coming soon), which can make the city worthy of a longer stay. And with a new, direct JetBlue flight available from New York, it’s more convenient than ever.

abstract: Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, will make his New York Philharmonic debut on Wednesday, conducting two colorful works.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra, will make his New York Philharmonic debut on Wednesday, conducting two colorful works. The excellent young violinist Janine Jansen will be the soloist in Szymanowski’s shimmering and sumptuous Violin Concerto No. 1, inspired by Tadeusz Micinski’s poem “May Night.” Also on the lineup are selections from Prokofiev’s ballet “Cinderella.” (7:30 p.m. Wednesday and Thursday, 2 p.m. Friday, 8 p.m. Saturday, Avery Fisher Hall, Lincoln Center, 212-875-5656, nyphil.org.)

headline: Prime-Time Slice of ‘Baloney!’
abstract: “Judge Judy Primetime,” on Tuesday night at 8 on CBS, deciphers the guilty pleasure to be found in her courtroom drama by serving up classic Judyisms.
lead_paragraph: Fess up: who hasn’t gawked in awe as Judge Judith Sheindlin slaps sense into a freak show of ne’er-do-wells with rejoinders we only wish we had queued up: “Are you trying to justify to me that you are an idiot?” “Don’t try to teach a pig to sing. It doesn’t work, and it irritates the pig.” “Beauty fades. Dumb is forever.”

headline: A Polish Town, Before Its Infamy
abstract: Most people associate Auschwitz with the death camp. But it is also a town, Oswiecim, once home to a vibrant Jewish community in Poland.
lead_paragraph: Most people associate Auschwitz with the death camp. But it is also a town, Oswiecim, once home to a vibrant Jewish community in Poland. Now, the Museum of Jewish Heritage — A Living Memorial to the Holocaust in Lower Manhattan is examining that history in “A Town Known as Auschwitz: The Life and Death of a Jewish Community,” which explores how Jews and non-Jews coexisted peacefully in Oswiecim (Auschwitz was its German name) for centuries before World War II.

headline: Dance Music, With a Warning
abstract: Next Saturday and Sunday, the New York incarnation of the Electric Daisy Carnival takes over MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J.
lead_paragraph: Last August, two deaths from drug overdoses at the annual Electric Zoo dance-music festival on Randalls Island caused the cancellation of the event’s final day, a reminder of the difficulty of adequately overseeing these sprawling, loosely supervised events. Next Saturday and Sunday, the New York incarnation of the Electric Daisy Carnival, the signature brand in American dance music festivals, takes over MetLife Stadium in East Rutherford, N.J., and will face the challenge of keeping tens of thousands of revelers safe. The music will take care of itself: The lineup includes pop-minded D.J.-producers like Calvin Harris and Afrojack; Steve Angello, one-third of the disbanded arena-house champs known as the Swedish House Mafia; the Chicago house legend Green Velvet; the pop aspirants Krewella; the teenage phenom Martin Garrix; and the French abrasionist DJ Snake. The festival’s website warns of “zero tolerance for drug use or possession.” Fingers crossed. (201-559-1515, electricdaisycarnival.com/newyork.)

headline: Long-Form Narratives, Without Words
abstract: The choreographers Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky and Christopher Wheeldon are making imaginative dances from challenging sources, from Shostakovich to Shakespeare.
lead_paragraph: We may be witnessing one sea change or several in full-length dance-theater productions. In the last 12 months, three of the world’s leading choreographers — Mark Morris, Alexei Ratmansky, Christopher Wheeldon — have staged new, important, mold-breaking, all-evening works. All three are flawed. But so are the ballets of “Swan Lake” and “Romeo and Juliet” (no matter which version you watch). The full-length “Swan Lake” took over 70 years before it became a mainstay of the international repertory. At what point does a new production turn into a hit, a war horse or a classic?

headline: Temptress Returns to Tweak His Cowl
abstract: Hey, fanboys, before the superhero glut implodes, toast those who set the 1990s standard.
lead_paragraph: Hey, fanboys, before the superhero glut implodes, toast those who set the 1990s standard: the crew behind “Batman: The Animated Series“ (and its spinoffs “Superman” and “Justice League”), in various TV incarnations from 1992 to 1999. Call it the Bruce W. Timm brain trust, after its producer and character designer; members included the writer Paul Dini and the voice director Andrea Romano. (And salute its writer Dwayne McDuffie, who died in 2011, and its composer Shirley Walker, who died in 2006.)

headline: Trolling the Past for Fresh Insights
abstract: The latest round of Danspace Project’s Platform series, which explores dance through the lens of a particular idea or theme, is dedicated to the work of the choreographer DD Dorvillier.
lead_paragraph: The latest round of Danspace Project’s Platform series, which explores dance through the lens of a particular idea or theme, is dedicated to the work of the choreographer DD Dorvillier, who helped define contemporary dance beginning in the 1990s. For more than a decade Ms. Dorvillier lived and worked out of the Matzoh Factory, a loft she shared with the dancer and choreographer Jennifer Monson in Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Stealth Lessons Sneak Up on Viewers
abstract: Karga Seven Pictures has emerged as a go-to production company for TV science programs blending special effects with a strong scientific foundation.
lead_paragraph: A tornado slams into Washington with winds exceeding 260 miles per hour. It topples the five-ton bronze statue at the Jefferson Memorial. It churns the roof of the Lincoln Memorial into a Cuisinart of broken glass and tile. It swiss-cheeses the Washington Monument. What will become of the Capitol? “The dome,” one expert predicts, “is toast.”

headline: His Music, Entwined With His Faith
abstract: Arvo Pärt’s compositions are not only universally spiritual, but specific to the Eastern Orthodox Christian Church, though he prefers to remain vague on that topic.
lead_paragraph: “Religion guides all the processes in our lives, without us even knowing it,” the Estonian composer Arvo Pärt said in a recent phone interview. “It is true that religion has a very important role in my composition, but how it really works, I am not able to describe.”

lead_paragraph: On a recent afternoon, the chef Tom Colicchio was sitting with his staff in his office, on East 19th Street in Manhattan, hashing out the details of the high-end hotel restaurant he plans to open this winter in Miami. What would he name the lobby bar? Would he serve small plates to bathers at the pool?

headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE SAVAGE WARS OF PEACE: Small Wars and the Rise of American Power,  by Max Boot. (Basic Books, $19.99.) Beginning with Thomas Jefferson’s expedition against the Barbary pirates, Boot, the author of “Invisible Armies,” traces America’s long history of bloody military operations in the name of nation-building and peacekeeping — in the Philippines, Haiti, Cuba and elsewhere. This revised edition includes a discussion of Iraq, Afghanistan and the lessons of the post-9/11 world.

headline: Today in Small Business: ‘Let’s Take This Offline’
abstract: Meet the Drone Dudes. Even your happy employees are job hunting. A McDonald’s worker in Denmark makes $21 an hour.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: In Brooklyn, Union Avenue Gets Built Up
abstract: Condos and rental buildings are rising where factories and garages once stood.
lead_paragraph: Once a desolate strip hugged by slightly forbidding warehouses, factories and garages, Union Avenue just north of the Brooklyn-Queens Expressway has seen a significant transformation in recent years into the sort of glass-lined thoroughfare more typically found in trendier parts of Williamsburg, Brooklyn.

headline: Editors’ Choice
abstract: Recently reviewed books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: BOMBAY STORIES,  by Saadat Hasan Manto. Translated by Matt Reeck and Aftab Ahmad. (Vintage International, paper, $16.) Manto wrote most of these stories out of a longing for his old city, having moved to Pakistan after partition in 1947.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Charlaine Harris, whose “Midnight Crossroad” is No. 12 on the hardcover fiction list, says her character Sookie Stackhouse is not coming back despite protests from fans: “I had death threats, and people putting curses on me. All the usual stuff.”
lead_paragraph: Something Different: Fans of long-­running series can have a hard time letting go. When Arthur Conan Doyle tried to kill off Sherlock Holmes in 1893, readers objected so strenuously that Doyle — after trying to mollify them with a prequel — finally gave in and resurrected the character as a cross-dressing mixed martial artist played by Robert Downey Jr. More recently, Charlaine Harris has heard from readers livid at her 2013 novel “Dead Ever After,” which ended her beloved Sookie Stackhouse urban fantasy series (the basis for the HBO show “True Blood”). “I had death threats, and people putting curses on me,” she said in a recent phone conversation. “All the usual stuff.” But Sookie is well and truly finished, Harris insists: “She’s in my rearview mirror. It was not a hard choice. Of course, it’s a little scary when you’re making such and such dollars a year because of a character. But when I’ve told the story I had to tell, it’s time to start something different.”

headline: The Preakness Dartboard
keywords: ['Preakness Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']

lead_paragraph: The horses for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes are listed in order of post position with comments provided by Joe Drape and Melissa Hoppert of The New York Times. Both have also selected their win-place-show horses. The morning-line odds were set by Keith Feustle of Pimlico Race Course.

headline: Cell Lit
abstract: A look at some memorable literary evocations of imprisonment.
lead_paragraph: This week, David Cole reviews Robert A. Ferguson’s “Inferno: An Anatomy of American Punishment,” about what Cole calls our “proclivity for incarceration.” The most enduring literary evocations of imprisonment have been written by those with firsthand experience; books like Aleksandr Solzhenitsyn’s “One Day in the Life of Ivan Denisovich” and Dostoyevsky’s “The House of the Dead.”

headline: One Step at a Time
abstract: In this novel, a man who can’t stop walking seeks psychiatric help in 19th-century Bordeaux.
lead_paragraph: First, a confession: Words like “liminal” or “luminous” in a novel’s blurbs or flap copy work for me like flashing hazard lights. Generally, I set the book back down on the new releases table and reach for something else. Experience has taught me that novels so described favor style over story, and I’m an old-school reader who values well-wrought plot and highly developed character more than exquisite voice and stylistic gymnastics.

headline: Digging Out
abstract: In Kaui Hart Hemmings’s new novel, a woman struggles with grief over her son’s death in an avalanche.
lead_paragraph: I have a friend, the mother of twin boys, who recently confessed that the only way she had survived those early parenting years was by pretending she was someone else: a long-distance athlete in training, say, while jogging behind a double stroller before work; or a sexy, spaced-out au pair at the playground diddling on her iPhone during lengthy afternoons; or a bearded Bushwick mixologist whenever the clock struck 5. Any of these roles felt more endurable than her own.

headline: Scandalous Women
abstract: Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary” and Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin” get the star treatment in new audiobooks.
lead_paragraph: The publication of Gustave Flaubert’s “Madame Bovary” in 1857 and of Émile Zola’s “Thérèse Raquin” 10 years later roused the French literary establishment against two previously unknown authors who had gone beyond the bounds of all that was held to be morally admissible in fiction with their portraits of adulterous women starved by marriage of sex and romance. The state prosecuted Flaubert for gross indecency, despite the terrible punishment he metes out to his wayward heroine. Zola was not subjected to the same ordeal, but critics treated him as a rogue purveying smut in the name of realism. Both novels have appeared in countless editions since the 19th century. Both have been adapted to the screen. Now they are available as audiobooks, read by two gifted English actresses: “Madame Bovary” by Juliet Stevenson and “Thérèse Raquin” by Kate Winslet.

headline: Talk of the Town
abstract: Actors read works by John O’Hara and Truman Capote set in a bygone Manhattan.
lead_paragraph: It would be hard to think of two writers less alike — stylistically and, for that matter, personally — than Truman Capote and John O’Hara, yet they shared many pre­occupations. Both were fascinated by society high and low, by how people climbed or toppled from one rank to the other, and by how sex and money underpinned the entire system. “Breakfast at Tiffany’s,” Capote’s charming 1958 novella about a self-invented cafe society girl and the admiring writer who lives upstairs, is set during World War II. Most of the stories assembled in the recent Penguin anthology of O’Hara’s New York stories were written in either the ’30s or the ’60s, but some are set decades earlier. And yet in the newly released audio recordings of the two books, maybe even more than on the page, the versions of New York that are evoked seem virtually interchangeable: It’s a city of people on the make or else clinging to their former reputations, where everyone drinks too much, and where you can easily wake up in bed next to someone you barely remember meeting.

headline: Acting the Part
abstract: Celebrities, from Rob Lowe to Diane Keaton, narrate the audiobooks of their memoirs.
lead_paragraph: Let’s be honest: Celebrities don’t usually write great memoirs. But the best ones offer up dish and dirt and some sensationally bizarre yarns.

headline: The Long, Long Road Ahead
abstract: Thousands of miles to go? A World War I history (or two) can be an ideal companion.
lead_paragraph: In my home state, California, we listen to audiobooks mostly while driving. When stuck in freeway traffic, I sometimes wonder whether the guy in my rearview mirror is secretly absorbed in “Harry Potter,” or if the smiling woman in the next lane is hearing Mr. Darcy woo Elizabeth Bennet. When it comes to immersing yourself in the First World War by audio, however, you’ll need more than a short commute. The war was very long, the books about it tend to be very long, and about this cataclysm that so thoroughly changed our world for the worse, surely you don’t want to listen to merely one book? So I suggest you reserve this listening for some road trip of epic length, like that drive you’ve always wanted to take from Alaska to Tierra del Fuego, or from Rotterdam to Vladivostok. Here are some suggestions for the journey:

headline: The Unpossessed
abstract: A collection that reinterprets classic stories from the perspective of women who are emotionally adrift.
lead_paragraph: In 2008, Rivka Galchen published her first novel, “Atmospheric Disturbances,” about a man who believes his wife has been replaced by a replica of herself. Enfolded into the story was also one Dr. Tzvi Gal-Chen, who shares his name (down to the hyphen) with Galchen’s own father, a meteorologist who died in 1994. Combining aspects of her own biography, the physical sciences and psychiatry — Galchen is herself a medical doctor, trained in psychiatry — she created a vertiginous narrative about the nature of love and loss. Even if the book’s momentum ultimately flagged, it showed Galchen to be a bold, inventive and smart young writer.

headline: Doctor Doubt
abstract: A dentist reconsiders his beliefs when an online impersonator promotes an obscure religion in his name.
lead_paragraph: Asked to create a list of brain-­shatteringly dull topics for fiction, you might be tempted to include the following things that appear in Joshua Ferris’s “To Rise Again at a Decent Hour”: modern ­dentistry, pseudobiblical esoterica, the death rattle of a relationship, insomnia, shopping malls, other people’s spiritual anomie, other people’s use of social media, the perils of said social media, and baseball.

headline: Every Little Byte Counts
abstract: The ubiquity of data gathering has staggering implications for understanding, predicting and influencing human behavior.
lead_paragraph: In “On What We Can Not Do,” a short and pungent essay published a few years ago, the Italian philosopher Giorgio Agamben outlined two ways in which power operates today. There’s the conventional type that seeks to limit our potential for self-­development by restricting material resources and banning certain behaviors. But there’s also a subtler, more insidious type, which limits not what we can do but what we can not do. What’s at stake here is not so much our ability to do things but our capacity not to make use of that very ability.

headline: Punitive Damage
abstract: A law professor looks at our criminal justice system and sees an “out-of-control punishment regime.”
lead_paragraph: As freedom advances, the severity of the penal law decreases. Or so argued Montesquieu, an Enlightenment philosopher whose work profoundly influenced the drafters of our Constitution. Were he alive today, Montesquieu might need to reconsider. The United States may or may not be the leader of the free world, but it is indisputably the world leader in locking up human beings behind bars. We are less than 5 percent of the world’s population, but we warehouse 25 percent of the world’s incarcerated population. Our per capita incarceration rate is seven times greater than France’s, 14 times greater than Japan’s and 24 times greater than India’s.

headline: Tell No One
abstract: In Julia Dahl’s “Invisible City,” a young reporter for a tabloid newspaper investigates a murder.
lead_paragraph: The first thing we learn about New York tabloid journalism from INVISIBLE CITY (Minotaur, $24.99) is that a body in Gowanus takes precedence over a brothel in Chinatown. Rebekah Roberts, the narrator of Julia Dahl’s first novel, is fresh out of college and considers herself lucky to be working as a stringer for a bottom-feeding tabloid. Amateur sleuths with day jobs on a newspaper’s staff are usually battle-weary veterans, so it’s a treat to hear Rebekah and her friends trade horror stories about fighting for entry-level positions.

headline: Bruno, Ex-State Senate Chief, Is Acquitted of Fraud in Retrial
abstract: Joseph L. Bruno, the majority leader of the New York Senate until his resignation in 2008, said after the verdict, “This system, it works.”
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Standing in a federal courthouse in a city he long called his political home, Joseph L. Bruno, the once-powerful majority leader of the New York State Senate, was found not guilty on federal fraud charges on Friday. The verdict put an end to a legal battle nearly a decade in the making.

headline: Popcast: Checking In on Burger Records
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss Burger Records, the label, store and cultural phenomenon.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s Popcast, we look at the scene around Burger Records, based in Fullerton, Calif. — a teen-centered, low-budget, hyper-productive explosion of the new garage rock, though it isn’t exactly the scholarly, record-obsessed, semi-antiquarian kind we’ve seen in the past. Lee Rickard and Sean Bohrman, former bandmates in Thee Makeout Party!, started the Burger Records label in 2007 and opened a record store two years later; in that time they’ve become the center of a scene that’s generating excitement, loyalty and a sense of identity, especially among an Orange County contingent that’s under the legal drinking age and hungry for local culture. Burger’s pace has become manic lately — it released 300 items last year, between cassette-only editions or reissues and original albums on LP and CD — but it seems to be working: Burgerama, its annual two-day festival in Santa Ana, sold 10,000 tickets this year, and its bands (including Cherry Glazerr, Together Pangea, Audacity, the Garden and Gap Dream) have started to move onto the national radar. (Although if all Burger records ever did was to produce the wild, messy, energetic weekly videos for its YouTube channel, BRGRTV, it might have served its purpose on earth.)

States were divided into red or blue, then shaded from light to dark. Only in this case, the color did not indicate political preference; it indicated duration of sexual encounter.

headline: Summer Burgers, Hold the Meat
abstract: The secret to the wonderful consistency of these vegetable-packed burgers is potatoes. They can all be frozen before or after browning, and don’t require buns.
lead_paragraph: I come back to burgers in this column every year or two. My quest for good vegetarian burgers has nothing to do with wanting to create something that resembles a hamburger or turkey burger. Why try to mimic meat? Rather, my vegetarian cooking is about produce, which, it turns out, can be the foundation for a great burger.

lead_paragraph: LAST month a 16-year-old child was placed in solitary confinement at the York Correctional Institution for Women in Niantic, Conn. She has never been charged, tried or convicted. What is her crime? That she has survived.

headline: All Aboard, for a Trip to the Past
abstract: Riding between Chicago and New Orleans in restored Pullman rail cars evokes a chapter of travel history.
lead_paragraph: It was the tail end of winter, and the trees outside the train car window were spindly twigs. Behind the bare branches, the sky was alight. To my half-asleep, hardly focusing, hung-over eyes, it was a blurry layer cake of blueberry, raspberry and tangerine. I had boarded the train in Chicago at dusk on Friday, three days before, and had rolled down 926 miles of rail. I’d spent 20 frivolous, indulgent hours in New Orleans, where I’d had fried oysters and fried green tomatoes at Upperline, midnight cocktails at the bar Cure and a hedonistic jazz brunch at Commander’s Palace. Then, before I could acclimate to the warmth and the green, the music and the food, I was on the next northbound train.

lead_paragraph: It is again time to spin the Upshot’s Senate wheels, in our weekly demonstration of just how much uncertainty remains with six months until the election.

headline: Death of a Hospital
abstract: The Goldwater Hospital for chronically ill patients, on Roosevelt Island, was shuttered in December to make room for a science and technology campus.
lead_paragraph: In 1935, with the last inmates from the century-old penitentiary transferred to Rikers Island, a site south of the Queensboro Bridge was cleared for the modern Welfare Hospital for Chronic Diseases, which would become known as Goldwater Hospital.

headline: Forgoing Sunrise for Sunset on Maui’s Volcano
keywords: ['Volcanoes', 'Bicycles and Bicycling', 'National Parks, Monuments and Seashores', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: After twice failing to catch a stunning early morning vista on Haleakala, the author finally finds her view at the other end of the day.
lead_paragraph: I was standing at the top of Mount Haleakala at 6 o’clock on a March morning, bleary-eyed and nauseated. During the three-hour journey from sea level to 10,000 feet, a group of wretchedly jet-lagged adventurers and I had scissored through almost 40 miles of hairpin turns holding on to our coffee cups and stomachs, stopping to help a disoriented elderly woman, navigating through herds of cows and glumly watching as rain began to splatter the van’s windshield.

headline: An Intimate View of America, From Above
abstract: Flying in a small plane offers scenes of life below that are otherwise hard to find.
lead_paragraph: We are rolling down the runway, increasing speed. At 70 knots, my husband lifts the nose of our small plane and we are suddenly airborne. Looking down, I can see the treetops, then the diagram of the town, and soon a panorama of hills and highways. We are heading south and west, toward Mississippi.

headline: Hotel Review: Brewhouse Inn & Suites in Milwaukee
keywords: ['Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Hotels and Travel Lodgings', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: An 1882 Pabst Brewery building has been recycled to house this year-old 90-suite inn.
lead_paragraph: Rates

headline: Restaurant Report: Joseph’s of Santa Fe
abstract: The chef behind this new spot offers a restrained take on classic New Mexican ingredients while managing to avoid cliché.
lead_paragraph: At 7 on an early winter evening, the buzz about Joseph Wrede’s new restaurant, Joseph’s of Santa Fe, had translated into an in-the-flesh dinner rush. The stranger dining next to me, a local who confessed he’d eaten there seven times since the restaurant opened in October, offered me a duck-fat French fry. “You didn’t order them and you have to try one,” he said.

headline: David Balding, Producer Who Adopted an Elephant, Dies at 75
abstract: Mr. Balding staged Broadway and Off Broadway plays but may have been best known for Circus Flora, which starred an orphaned baby African elephant.
lead_paragraph: David Balding, a producer of Broadway and Off Broadway plays who may have been best known as a circus showman who acted as a parent to an elephant, died on May 9 in Weldon Spring, Mo. He was 75.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: A Clash of Ideals and Investments at Swarthmore
abstract: A student-led movement aimed at ridding college endowment funds of fossil fuel investments got its start at Swarthmore College, which has yet to sign on to the cause.
lead_paragraph: Kate Aronoff didn’t arrive at Swarthmore College in fall 2010 expecting to be an environmental activist. Nor did she know much about the stock market. She knew even less about asset management and college endowments.

headline: Black-Throated Blue Warbler: Listen, Stop and Watch
abstract: Most warblers have lovely plumage, but the black-throated blue (Setophaga caerulescens) is something special.
lead_paragraph: It has become clichéd to call warblers the butterflies of the bird world, but it is a fair description of these tiny, colorful birds. In breeding plumage, male warblers are decked out in fluorescent reds, brilliant yellows, greens and metallic blues. A long look at a warbler as it flits from branch to branch may last just a few seconds, but even in that brief time, its colors astound.

headline: Elaine Sturtevant, Who Borrowed Others’ Work Artfully, Is Dead at 89
abstract: Ms. Sturtevant, an American in Paris, made deliberately inexact likenesses of work by Andy Warhol, George Segal and Jasper Johns, among others.
lead_paragraph: Elaine Sturtevant, an American Conceptual artist whose work resembled that of Andy Warhol — and Roy Lichtenstein and Robert Rauschenberg and Marcel Duchamp and Jasper Johns and Keith Haring and a spate of other emblematic figures from the annals of contemporary art — died on May 7 in Paris. She was 89.

headline: Think of Him as a Wingman for Hire
abstract: For $1,000 a month, a social development coach, Anthony Recenello, helps men talk to women and excel in what he calls “meditative mingling.”
lead_paragraph: All the lonely people, the Beatles sang — identifying a consumer market of vast scale and almost limitless need. Which is to say, an opportunity. On a recent Monday night in the meatpacking district, that marketplace was in full swirl: stylish men and women circling one another, offering a line, a joke, a meeting of cellphones.

headline: Former Executive Sues for Stake in Beats Electronics, Object of Apple’s Desire
abstract: The founder of a company bought by Beats says he was fired unfairly before his shares could vest.
lead_paragraph: A week after reports on its negotiations were first published, Apple’s pending $3.2 billion deal for Beats Electronics has still not been completed. But Beats is already finding itself defending a lawsuit against a former executive over what could be a lucrative stake in the company.

headline: Russian Rocket Crashes After Takeoff
abstract: A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a communications satellite crashed in Kazakhstan after what appeared to have been an engine malfunction, an official said.
lead_paragraph: MOSCOW — A Russian Proton-M rocket carrying a sophisticated communications satellite crashed after takeoff early Friday morning, reviving questions over Russia’s space program after a series of failed launches in recent years.

headline: The Freedom of Boundaries
abstract: Tony Schwartz, in the Life@Work column, writes about the need to create boundaries — time when you can work or rest without interruption — to make up for the fact that technology has made it so difficult to have any.
lead_paragraph: What I remember about boundaries when I was growing up is that I always wanted to violate them. Today, I’m frustrated that I don’t have more boundaries. I say that even though I have consciously built numerous boundaries in recent years, specifically to make up for the fact that technology has made it so difficult to have any.

headline: Kenyans Describe Twin Blasts in Nairobi
abstract: The Kenyan president, Uhuru Kenyatta, urged citizens to help prevent any future attacks, and witnesses described the scene after two explosions at a packed market in Nairobi.
lead_paragraph: The Kenyan president, Uhuru Kenyatta, urged citizens to help prevent any future attacks, and witnesses described the scene after two explosions at a packed market in Nairobi.

headline: A Mixture for Geithner: The Moral Hazard
abstract: Given how much ink we spilled on him and his new book this week, it seems appropriate that we dedicate this week’s drink to Timothy Geithner.
lead_paragraph: Central bankers and finance ministers are a famously sober bunch. That may explain why Timothy Geithner, despite being a senior federal policy maker through the better part of two decades of financial crisis, from Mexico to Thailand, Lehman Brothers to Greece, has, as far as we know, never had a cocktail named for him.

headline: Drama League Honors ‘Gentleman’s Guide’ and ‘All the Way’
abstract: The association named “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” best musical and “All the Way” best play.
lead_paragraph: The Drama League, an association of thousands of theatergoers nationwide, announced on Friday that “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love & Murder” has won its 2014 award for best musical and “All the Way” has won for best play. At a ceremony to present its 80th annual awards, the league also named “Hedwig and the Angry Inch” best revival of a musical and “The Glass Menagerie” best revival of a play.

headline: Q. and A. | Marion Cotillard on Her New Role and the Pursuit of Happiness
abstract: The actress, whose first starring role in an American film takes the big screen today with “The Immigrant,” discusses her costar Joaquin Phoenix and her strategy for getting in character.
lead_paragraph: When Marion Cotillard is presented with the notion that after more than 40 films, an Oscar for Best Actress (for “La Vie en Rose”), and roles in some of the last decade’s defining blockbusters, she’s only now leading her first American film, even she seems surprised. Yes, that’s true,” she says with a laugh. “I didn’t even think about it.” But “The Immigrant,” an operatic melodrama directed by James Gray that opens today, hardly feels like it belongs in a 21st century American multiplex. It’s a grandiose throwback to an era when movies dealt with big emotions, not big explosions.

headline: Transition in Leadership for BAM’s DanceAfrica
abstract: Abdel R. Salaam of the Forces of Nature company will run the DanceAfrica festival at the Brooklyn Academy of Music when Chuck Davis steps down in 2016.
lead_paragraph: Part lively dance performance and part spirited homage to ancestors, the DanceAfrica festival, founded at the Brooklyn Academy of Music in 1977 by Chuck Davis — who made it the largest such festival in the country — is getting a new artistic director.

headline: Student Loan Calculator
abstract: A guide to student loans at various universities, and what it takes after graduation to repay that debt.
lead_paragraph: A guide to student loans at various universities, and what it takes after graduation to repay that debt.

headline: Fantasy Football: Analyzing the N.F.L. Draft Picks, Part 2
abstract: Continuing our look at the rookies who will have the most fantasy impact this season, focusing on players from the N.F.C. South and West.
lead_paragraph: Continuing our look at the rookie on each team who will have the most fantasy impact this season, whether for him or for the players around him, we turn our attention to the N.F.C. South and West.

headline: Known for Films Like ‘Ran,’ a Japanese Actor Turns to the Stage
abstract: Tatsuya Nakadai, in New York for a screening of his 1966 film “The Face of Another,” says he no longer enjoys watching Japanese movies as much as he used to.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:09 p.m. | The last and most indelible image most American moviegoers have of the actor Tatsuya Nakadai probably dates from 1985: haunted, haggard, desolate, more ghost than man, wandering the battlefield at the end of his stupendous performance in “Ran,” Akira Kurosawa’s adaptation of “King Lear.”

headline: A Las Vegas Boutique Hotel With Star Power
abstract: The Cromwell, a new boutique hotel on the Strip in Las Vegas, will feature a restaurant from the Food Network chef Giada De Laurentiis.
lead_paragraph: In a market defined by size, the Cromwell checks into Las Vegas this month as the underdog, competing on style rather than scale.

headline: Driven | Bentley GT Speed Convertible
abstract: Transportation that says you’ve arrived.
lead_paragraph: Transportation that says you’ve arrived.

headline: Video: The Bentley Continental GT Speed Is a Terrestrial Space Shuttle
abstract: With a launch speed and a price that call to mind NASA’s space shuttles, the Continental GT Speed will wow anyone who can afford it.
lead_paragraph: I was lucky enough to see a space shuttle launch before NASA retired the fleet. On television, the shuttle seems to leave the ground at a slow, majestic pace. In person, it left the planet at the same violent velocity as the Estes model rockets I shot into the sky during my Cub Scout days. Whoosh! Just like that, it was gone.

headline: Mark Ryden: Drawing a Dividing Line
abstract: A new exhibition attracted stars and moneyed collectors, but Mr. Ryden’s celebrity following also tends to send art-world noses skyward.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Leonardo DiCaprio is an ardent collector of his macabre paintings. Katy Perry refers to his imagery in Twitter posts, and Amanda Seyfried has practically begged to be his muse. (“I’d love for him to paint a caricature of me with blood trickling down my throat and me holding a dead cat,” she told W magazine.) That gown of raw meat that Lady Gaga donned on MTV a few years ago? Derived from one of his best-known works.

headline: Rhubarb Shake
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a refreshing rhubarb shake with rosewater and Greek yogurt garnished with chopped pistachios.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a refreshing rhubarb shake with rosewater and Greek yogurt garnished with chopped pistachios.

headline: Yogurt Drinks, Not Too Smooth
abstract: Once you start thinking beyond the typical smoothie formula, it’s pretty easy to come up with your own yogurt-laced combinations.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to yogurt drinks, we’ve gotten ourselves into a smoothie rut. Smoothies are everywhere, at every juice bar, street cart and deli, and premixed in bottles lining supermarket shelves.

headline: When Shingles Is Just the Beginning
abstract: A new study links shingles to a higher risk of stroke.
lead_paragraph: You don’t really need another reason to get the shingles vaccine, for yourself (if you’re over 60) or your older relatives. A painful rash, possible damage to vision and a substantial risk of the condition called postherpetic neuralgia, which can hurt for a long time — aren’t those enough?

headline: Some Wines Are Worth Not Drinking
keywords: ['Wines', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: The top five Bordeaux producers have been a smart investment over the last century.
lead_paragraph: MANY people who collect fine wine talk about it as an investment. But is something that pairs nicely with rack of lamb really an investment — or just a way to justify paying tens of thousands of dollars for a single bottle?

headline: Partnerships That Blend the Skills of Two Generations
abstract: Multigenerational ventures defy the stereotype about younger and older people battling over jobs in the still-shaky economy.
lead_paragraph: IN her late 50s, Wickham Boyle left her job as an editor to pursue a project she was passionate about, producing an opera about 9/11 based on a book she wrote. A few months later, when she was ready to go back to work, she discovered it wasn’t so easy to find her next gig. “Our play closed on the day Lehman crashed, and my world dissolved,” she said, recalling the start of the financial crisis in 2008.

headline: For India’s Persecuted Muslim Minority, Caution Follows Hindu Party’s Victory
abstract: After a landslide electoral triumph by Bharatiya Janata Party, a Hindu nationalist party, some Muslims said they were worried their place in India could become even more tenuous.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Like real estate agents the world over, Rahul Rewal asks his clients if they have children or pets, since both limit options. But there is another crucial but often unspoken question: Are they Muslim?

headline: Facts & Figures: California’s Drought
abstract: The whole state is in “severe drought” or worse.
lead_paragraph: All of California is in “severe drought” or worse, according to the U.S. Drought Monitor, with much of the state in “exceptional drought” — the most extreme level. The National Drought Mitigation Center writes that a heat wave hitting the West “will only serve to exacerbate and accelerate drought impact concerns across the state. Increases on water demand and the increased risk of fire will ramp up as the heat does.”

headline: The Row’s New Home, a Frieze Frenzy and Moschino’s Plans for Men
abstract: Plus, the social media response to anorexic mannequins, John Galliano’s next steps and more from the week in style.
lead_paragraph: All the fashion news of the week that’s fit to reprint.

headline: Finding the Right Note, Pure and Easy
abstract: A bikini designer and a pianist marry.
lead_paragraph: It’s funny what makes a hit: that often once-in-a-lifetime connection between an artist and an audience, or a piece of music and a specific moment in time.

headline: Planners Adapt as Gay Unions Become More Common
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: As same-sex marriages become more common, wedding planners are changing their game.
lead_paragraph: Not very long ago, having a same-sex wedding was noteworthy enough, and those looking to wed often sought comfort and support in wedding websites and party planners whose orientation closely matched their own.

headline: A Beginner’s Guide to Repaying Student Loans
abstract: A road map to help those with student loans steer clear of common repayment mistakes and protect their credit scores.
lead_paragraph: Too many people, including plenty of brand-new college graduates, fall far behind on their student loan payments for no good reason.

headline: Weekend Reading: The Hero and the Wall St. Puppet
abstract: Timothy F. Geithner’s new book defending his role in the financial crisis is drawing out his detractors and defenders on both sides of the political aisle. A look back on our reporting of the past week’s highs and lows in finance.

headline: Rainout Puts Yanks in Old-Time 2-Game Set
abstract: The Yankees-Pirates game on Friday night was washed away, so now the teams will play an old-fashioned, single-admission doubleheader Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees and the Pittsburgh Pirates might as well wear throwback uniforms this weekend. The opener of their three-game series, scheduled for Friday night, was rained out, and now they are scheduled to play an afternoon game Saturday and an old-fashioned, single-admission doubleheader Sunday afternoon at Yankee Stadium.

headline: So You’re Not Desirable ...
abstract: In romance, it may not actually matter.
lead_paragraph: IT is one of the hard truths of romance: Desirable people attract other desirable people, while the rest of us — lacking in attractiveness, charisma or success — settle for the best partner who is willing to consider our overtures. In the scientific literature, this idea is enshrined in the concept of mate value, which determines who gets to mate with whom. In popular culture, it is reflected in the choice of comely contestants to vie for the equally comely spouse-to-be on TV shows like “The Bachelor.” Pairing off, it seems, is just one more example that life isn’t fair.

headline: A Southern Crossroads
abstract: The El Conejo bus depot in Laredo, Tex., serves as a crossroads for immigrants entering the United States.
lead_paragraph: The El Conejo bus depot in Laredo, Tex., serves as a crossroads for immigrants entering the United States.

headline: Chipotle Experiments With Disposable Literature
abstract: The fast-food chain has enlisted prominent writers like Toni Morrison, Judd Apatow and George Saunders to write essays and notes for its cups and bags.
lead_paragraph: The fast-food chain Chipotle announced on Thursday that it had enlisted 10 A-list writers to provide original notes and essays for the cups and bags in their restaurants as a way to foster thoughtfulness, without pushing a coporate agenda. The reviews for these new works of literature have ranged from enthusiastic to harsh.

headline: Friday Night Music: Arcade Fire, Joan of Arc
abstract: If you shoot you’d better hit your mark.
lead_paragraph: Various stuff keeping me frantic, so not much time to seek out new music. But I keep finding new gems from the latest AF album — or actually from the live performances, especially the stripped-down versions, which I often prefer. In this case the final violin dissonance really does it …

headline: Why G.O.P. Will Shift to Talking About Fixing the Heath-Care Law
keywords: ['Elections, Senate', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Elections, House of Representatives']
abstract: The Affordable Care Act has become more popular, a prominent Republican pollster says, so expect Republicans to give up talk about repealing it.
lead_paragraph: In response to polling data showing that the Affordable Care Act has become more popular, a prominent Republican pollster said that he expected Republicans to change how they talked about the law.

headline: Brooklyn Cantor Pleads Guilty in Sexual Abuse Case
keywords: ['Child Abuse and Neglect', 'Jews and Judaism', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Baruch Lebovits, whose prosecution divided the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in New York, received a two-year sentence in a molestation case.
lead_paragraph: A sexual abuse case that divided the ultra-Orthodox Jewish community in Brooklyn and created rifts in the borough’s district attorney’s office ended on Friday as a once-prominent cantor pleaded guilty to molestation.

headline: The Gun Report: May 16, 2014
abstract: A day in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: In the Carolinas, guns are allowed in bars. In Arkansas, you can take a gun into some churches and religious schools. In Indiana, you can keep a gun in your car on school property. In West Virginia, residents with concealed-carry permits can bring firearms into public recreation facilities such as tennis courts and swimming pools. Since the massacre in Newtown, 18 states have passed laws allowing guns in more places—but in only four states can you bring a gun into state legislative chambers.

headline: Brightening the Night With a Spring Palette
abstract: At “Lightscapes,” a garden of more than 7,500 fantastical sculptures animated by light covers 10 acres on the grounds of Van Cortlandt Manor.
lead_paragraph: Walk beneath an animated rainbow, and then head through a tunnel of swirling fog. Meander past luminescent flowers, gigantic glowing mushrooms and a praying mantis towering more than 12 feet tall. Listen to the beat of a backdrop that blends natural noises with music. Welcome to “Lightscapes,” a fantastical garden of light, color and sound on the grounds of Van Cortlandt Manor.

headline: Atelier de Troupe Shows Two Collaborations at Its I.C.F.F. Debut
abstract: The lighting and furniture studio run by the Los Angeles-based designer Gabriel Abraham will fill its first booth with three new sets of designs.
lead_paragraph: Atelier de Troupe, the three-year-old furniture and lighting studio founded by the Los Angeles-based designer Gabriel Abraham, is exhibiting at the annual International Contemporary Furniture Fair in New York for the first time this year. Abraham will introduce several new styles as well as two new collaborations: Core, created in tandem with the San Francisco-based ceramist Ian McDonald, and a collection of lighting designed alongside Roman Alonso of Commune.

headline: A Dose of Top-Down Tonic to Drive the Winter Blues Away
abstract: The Corvette Stingray convertible is a worthy sibling to the coupe model. Engineers designed both cars simultaneously, using a lightweight aluminum chassis and carbon-fiber hood like those usually found on more expensive cars.
lead_paragraph: WOODSTOCK, N.Y. — Cabin fever is bad enough. But when you share your extended winter quarters with 8.4 million people, as one does in New York City, it’s no wonder the roommates get a little testy.

headline: Spirited Sedan Inhabited by Pontiac’s Ghost
abstract: The 2014 Chevrolet SS is a strange beast. It’s a Chevy performance sedan that used to be a Pontiac and a thoroughly American car that’s built in Australia.
lead_paragraph: General Motors has a long history of killing off worthy cars. The Pontiac Fiero is the most infamous example, an initially mundane two-seater that developed into a capable performance machine just in time for production to cease forever. A more recent casualty was the 2008-9 Pontiac G8, a rear-drive performance sedan that was canceled when its brand fell under the ax as G.M. approached bankruptcy.

headline: Chevy SS: What Lies Beneath
abstract: A defunct General Motors division’s last hurrah has returned from Australia wearing a bow-tie disguise.
lead_paragraph: A defunct General Motors division’s last hurrah has returned from Australia wearing a bow-tie disguise.
