lead_paragraph: Photos from India, Ukraine, Serbia and Palestine.

headline: Nuclear Talks With Iran Fail to Yield Pact, Officials Say
abstract: Both sides call the talks slow and difficult, and say that gaps remain on the size of enrichment capability Iran would be permitted.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The latest round of nuclear talks between Iran and six world powers ended on Friday in Vienna, with Iranian and American officials saying that progress was slow and difficult, with serious gaps between the two sides on basic issues like the size of any nuclear enrichment capability Iran would be permitted to retain.

headline: Leave the Car at Home This Weekend
abstract: Just about every corner of the city will have some street closed for a period of time.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers who were thinking about hopping in a car to get about town this weekend might want to think twice. Not only is the annual AIDS walk on Sunday, but between food fairs and street fairs, Norwegian pride parades and dance parades, half marathons and awareness walks, just about every corner of the city will have some street closed for a period of time.

headline: Civilized Without Compromise
abstract: The 2014 Stingray convertible is simply the best Corvette in the nameplate’s 61-year history, as purely capable as a Porsche 911 Carrera S, but at barely half the price.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 Stingray convertible is simply the best Corvette in the nameplate’s 61-year history, as purely capable as a Porsche 911 Carrera S, but at barely half the price.

headline: Clyde Snow, Sleuth Who Read Bones From King Tut’s to Kennedy’s, Dies at 86
abstract: Dr. Snow was a master of extracting the secrets of the dead from skeletal remains and a leader in using forensic anthropology in human rights cases.
lead_paragraph: With ghoulish geniality, Clyde Snow liked to say that bones made good witnesses, never lying, never forgetting, and that a skeleton, no matter how old, could sketch the tale of a human life, revealing how it had been lived, how long it had lasted, what traumas it had endured and especially how it had ended.

headline: From the International Desk: The Thinking on Ukraine
abstract: Kyle Crichton, an International Desk editor, discusses coverage of the Ukraine crisis.
lead_paragraph: We talked to Kyle Crichton, who is coordinating coverage of the Ukraine crisis for The Times, about the news that steelworkers and miners are taking control of the streets from separatists and pro-Russian militants in Mariupol and some other cities.

headline: On-Site Fixes for What Winter’s Potholes Wrought
abstract: The potholes left by the harsh winter have brought an increase in business to wheel repair shops, some of which make house calls.
lead_paragraph: Jennifer Franz of Sacramento scraped a wheel on her three-year-old Honda Accord last August in an encounter with a curb. To keep her mother from finding the damage, she made an appointment with a local business, Kelly Wheel Repair, that travels to its customers.

headline: Serious Rock Star Fantasies, Fueled by Athletic Footwork
abstract: Pierre Rigal’s “Micro” is being performed at the Joyce Theater as part of the French-American Danse festival.
lead_paragraph: Imagine a teenage boy in his bedroom, pretending to be a rock star. He tries out postures. He swings his shirt around his head. It could be cute, right? Now imagine that the boy is actually a grown man and that he makes you watch him fantasize about being a rock star for 95 minutes. Not so cute.

headline: A Scaleback in Die-Cast Cars
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Collectors and Collections', 'Toys', 'Models and Replicas']
abstract: The Danbury Mint and Franklin Mint have both abandoned the market.
lead_paragraph: The decision by the Danbury Mint last month to stop selling die-cast model cars was symptomatic of a more serious shrinkage in a market where the vehicles are already pretty small.

headline: GreenTech Scatters New Seeds

lead_paragraph: In its five-year existence, GreenTech Automotive has manufactured far more headlines than cars. Now, after a merger with another fledgling auto company, VL Automotive, GreenTech promises to deliver an eclectic mix of electric city cars, plug-ins converted into muscle machines and performance-tuned cars for the Chinese market.

headline: Goldman Shareholders Give Pay Plan a Thumbs Up
abstract: A proxy advisory firm, Glass Lewis, has questioned the Wall Street firm’s compensation practices.
lead_paragraph: Since the financial crisis, Wall Street has faced pressure to disclose more about how it rewards its top executives.

headline: The Fruit of Feminist Mothers and Michael Jackson
abstract: Works by SuperGroup and Laurie Berg dealing with generational change close the Joyce Unleashed series in Brooklyn.
lead_paragraph: After decades of radical questioning and cycles of reaction, which term is more difficult to define neatly these days: “feminism” or “contemporary performance”? That was one question raised by the Minneapolis collective SuperGroup in its smart and inventive New York debut on Thursday.

lead_paragraph: What should you serve when you serve drinks?

headline: Did Regulators Break the Internet or Did They Save It? Yes.
abstract: The Federal Communications Commission’s proposal on network neutrality tries to please every side. And when you try to please everyone, you often please no one.
lead_paragraph: Ten years from now, we’ll look back on this week as the moment federal regulators broke the Internet as we know it.

headline: Feminism, One Conference at a Time
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', "Women's Rights"]
abstract: Women’s events aren’t just about consciousness-raising anymore. They’re a business.
lead_paragraph: It was a month before Gloria Steinem’s 80th birthday, but on a Saturday evening in February, on the cliffs at a resort in Southern California, 500 women were helping her celebrate early. Ms. Steinem, the guest of honor, was flanked by her longtime friends Marlo Thomas and Jane Fonda. The three hugged, and then Ms. Thomas raised a glass. “To Gloria,” she said. “The absolutely perfect leader to our revolution.”

headline: Mahler, Together With an Old Friend
abstract: The Dutch conductor Bernard Haitink is leading the New York Philharmonic in Mahler’s Third.
lead_paragraph: It is always a pleasure to check in on a happy marriage of musical artist and repertory after many years and find that it still thrives.

headline: True Crime, With an Analytic Leaning
abstract: “The System,” Al Jazeera America’s new eight-part series, which begins Sunday night, examines criminal justice in the United States.
lead_paragraph: There are several issues to consider regarding the premiere of “The System,” Joe Berlinger’s new eight-part series, which begins on Sunday night on Al Jazeera America. The most obvious and probably most pertinent is that the channel is trying to keep up with one of its cable news rivals: It’s bringing in a recognizable figure (Mr. Berlinger is known for feature documentaries like the “Paradise Lost” series about the West Memphis 3 case and “Metallica: Some Kind of Monster”) to do original documentary-style programming before CNN gets its new shows with Lisa Ling, Mike Rowe and John Walsh on the air.

headline: Kids Are Icebound by ‘Frozen’ Fervor
abstract: Girls and boys alike sing out and dress up, parents say, obsessed with the Disney film.
lead_paragraph: If any parent doubts the power of the Disney animated film “Frozen,” perhaps they should talk to Willie Geist, a “Today” show host.

headline: Within a Ship’s Walls, Songs of War in High Voices
abstract: The Collegiate Chorale and the Manhattan Girls Chorus performed a collection of choral songs about war at the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Human fragility is a recurring theme in the music of David Lang, and “battle hymns,” an almost hourlong collection of choral songs about war, is no exception. On Thursday, this often moving but occasionally precious work received its New York premiere, sung by the Collegiate Chorale and the Manhattan Girls Chorus under the direction of James Bagwell in the 12,000-square-foot Hangar 3 inside the Intrepid Sea, Air & Space Museum. The performance also included six singers from the Veteran Artist Program, a nationwide initiative to engage former service members in the arts. Mr. Lang sets repurposed Civil War texts by Stephen Foster, Abraham Lincoln and Maj. Sullivan Ballou in his trademark spare vocal lines and crystalline textures. The result is a portrait of the soldier as sleepwalker, caught in a no man’s land between patriotism and private longing.

headline: Parents Respond to the ‘Frozen’ Frenzy
abstract: “Frozen” has gone from movie to phenomenon, at least in part because the passion at its heart is one children of both genders can relate to.
lead_paragraph: We have just a touch of “Frozen” fever at our house. Our spring break trip involved three long plane journeys, and my youngest daughter watched “Frozen” in every available language on the seat-back television screen. We are not big singers of “Let it Go”; we prefer the sprightly “Do You Want to Build a Snowman?”— but my older daughter and the girls we visited over break did engage in vigorous debate over whose version of “Let It Go” was better (“vigorous agreement” might be a better phrase for their passionate preference for the Idina Menzel version over the Demi Lovato one). And anyone, anywhere, can get a laugh at any moment by declaring, “Hi, I’m Olaf, and I like warm hugs.”

headline: Night Out With Emilie and Mika Brzezinski
abstract: A Tina Brown cocktail party for a sculptor and author with an assist from the artist’s better-known daughter.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday night, Tina Brown held a cocktail party in her Sutton Place apartment for Emilie Brzezinski, an 82-year-old artist from Switzerland who carves monumental wooden sculpture using chain saws and chisels.

headline: Hong Kong Cocoons
abstract: Buildings in Hong Kong are sheathed in colored nets and bamboo while being renovated. Peter Steinhauer tracks these cocoons on the urban skyline.
lead_paragraph: Buildings in Hong Kong are sheathed in colored nets and bamboo while being renovated. Peter Steinhauer tracks these cocoons on the urban skyline.

headline: Where the Sylvan Settings Enhance the Art
abstract: An installation surrounds Philip Johnson’s Glass House in New Canaan, sculptures abound in Old Lyme and a farm festival takes place in Stamford.
lead_paragraph: Spring blossoms, clement breezes and some newborn farm animals make this a particularly delightful time to visit three outdoor sites where artwork is surrounded by the splendors of nature.

headline: Sweetly Taking on Kanye and Double Standards
abstract: In her first New York City show since 2009, Lily Allen sang wryly of media expectations about pop divas.
lead_paragraph: Lily Allen paused in her set at the Highline Ballroom on Thursday night — her first New York City show since 2009 — to autograph an audience member’s eagerly proffered copy of “Sheezus,” her new CD. “You guys think I’m just being a really nice person,” she said. “But actually this is a really good advertising plan!”

headline: Cannes Film Festival 2014, Part I
abstract: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benoît Peverelli.
lead_paragraph: Scenes from the Cannes Film Festival photo diary of Benoît Peverelli.

headline: With Narendra Modi, a Change in India
abstract: The new prime minister has the chance to revitalize the economy and shape how his country engages with the world.
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi, India’s presumed next prime minister, and his opposition Bharatiya Janata Party made history by delivering a crushing defeat to the ruling Indian National Congress party, which has controlled Indian politics for most of the past 60 years. Winning more than 272 parliamentary seats, the B.J.P. received the strongest mandate of any party in 30 years.

headline: Recycling the Leftovers
keywords: ['Recycling of Waste Materials', 'Food', 'Compost', 'Restaurants', 'Sustainable Living', 'Waste Materials and Disposal']
abstract: Food waste has become a hot-button issue, with cities and companies adopting strategies for reducing it.
lead_paragraph: Every week, some 14,000 households in Austin, Tex., dutifully roll not just one, or two, but three garbage bins to the curb.

headline: Veterans Secretary Ousts Health Care Official Amid Criticism
abstract: The removal of the the department’s soon-to-retire under secretary for health comes amid allegations that Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide treatment delays.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — One day after deflecting calls from unhappy senators to shake up his leadership team, Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, ousted the department’s soon-to-retire head of health care. The move came amid snowballing allegations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide long delays many patients faced to see physicians.

headline: Semifinals in the Bridge Trial for the Bermuda Bowl
abstract: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship is nearing its conclusion.
lead_paragraph: In Phoenix, the trial to select the USA-1 team for next year’s Bermuda Bowl world championship is nearing its conclusion.

headline: For Sandra Tsing Loh, Change Is Good
abstract: Radio, stage, the printed page: For Ms. Tsing Loh, it’s the message that counts. So what’s this thing called Twitter?
lead_paragraph: PASADENA, Calif. — “I just joined Twitter,” the writer and performer Sandra Tsing Loh announced into a good old-fashioned microphone. She was deep in the warren of the KPCC-FM public-radio station (wall-to-wall carpeting, office kitchen copiously stocked with herbal teas, a sound engineer who keeps bees), recording a segment for “The Loh Life,” one of her two long-running broadcasts here. Ads for Gold’s Gym flashed noiselessly, reprovingly, on a television screen overhead.

headline: Swiss Prepare to Vote on World’s Highest Minimum Wage
abstract: The minimum would be set at $24.65 an hour in an effort to address inequalities.
lead_paragraph: BASEL, Switzerland — While Switzerland’s booming economy has made the country synonymous with a superlative standard of living, the government estimates that approximately one worker in 10 struggles to pay rent, despite working full time.

headline: Racially Themed Work Stirs Conflict at Whitney Biennial
keywords: ['Whitney Biennial', 'Art', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: The art collective known as YAMS has withdrawn a video it created from the Whitney Biennial to protest work in the show centering on a fictional black female character created by a white artist.
lead_paragraph: The YAMS, a collective of artists who made a video on race and black identity for the current Whitney Biennial, have withdrawn the work to protest a project in the show that they contend is racially insensitive.

headline: The Entire Audience Dozed Off? Perfect!
abstract: A new breed of production invites spectators to bed down in an immersive performance space, exploring their perceptions of their surroundings in a half-awake state or in their dreams.
lead_paragraph: It’s the unspoken fantasy of so many theatergoers: a highbrow cultural outing that, somewhere between the opening and the ovation, includes a nap. But most directors and performers conspire to, at the very least, keep their audiences awake.

headline: Greek Bank’s Return to Risky Investment
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: The chairman of Piraeus spent half the amount the bank raised in an oversubscribed bond offering in April to acquire a stake in the Marfin Investment Group.
lead_paragraph: Investing in Greece’s banks was never for the cautious. But for the parade of hedge fund managers who have piled into the Greek financial giant Piraeus Bank, the bank’s latest deal has surely resulted in a dose of heartburn.

headline: Icons at Leisure in Long-Ago Summers
abstract: Photos of a young Jacqueline Bouvier and of Gary Cooper are among those taken by Bert Morgan from 1930 to 1960, and are now on display in an exhibition in Southampton.
lead_paragraph: A self-possessed little girl named Jacqueline Bouvier walking with her pony. Diana Vreeland wearing striped shorts with matching striped earrings. Gary Cooper impeccably dressed in a sport jacket and trousers as he enters a fashionable beach club. These are among the 30 black-and-white images of the rich and famous in “Southampton Blue Book, 1930 to 1960: Photographs by Bert Morgan,” on view at the Rogers Mansion of the Southampton Historical Museums and Research Center through Oct. 18.

headline: A Pioneer Says Goodbye, Unfiltered
abstract: On her last day as co-host of “The View,” toasted by Hillary Rodham Clinton and other celebrities, Barbara Walters was still her old self.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Walters got out while the gets were still good.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
abstract: The fashion note at the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy “hat luncheon” was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the suit.
lead_paragraph: The fashion note at the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy “hat luncheon” was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the suit.

headline: Bill Cunningham | Turning Heads
abstract: The fashion note at the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy “hat luncheon” was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the suit.
lead_paragraph: On May 7, the Women’s Committee of the Central Park Conservancy held its annual “hat luncheon” for 1,200 guests. The event, which garnered $3.5 million and honored Michael Bloomberg, featured whimsical headdresses masking a serious dedication to the restoration of the park and to the judicious spending of the money raised. Lela Rose arrived on her bike, with Gillian Miniter in the sidecar. The fashion note was a one-piece fitted dress with a full skirt, replacing the luncheon suit, and a lovely surprise to the women in orange was the hue of the traditional umbrellas handed out.

headline: Portland, Ore., Sheds Its Walmart Bonds
abstract: The city of Portland, Ore., said it had started divesting itself of holdings in the retail store because of its labor practices.
lead_paragraph: The city of Portland, Ore., announced this week that it had begun divesting itself of its holdings in Walmart, citing concerns over the company’s ethics and labor practices.

headline: Evening Hours | A Blossoming Calendar
abstract: It’s a busy time, with benefits of all types.
lead_paragraph: It’s a busy time, with benefits of all types.

headline: Ask Well | Downsides of Taking Truvada?
abstract: Readers asked Well about the preventative drug Truvada following a C.D.C. recommendation that all Americans at risk for H.I.V. take this daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection.
lead_paragraph: Readers asked Well about the preventative drug Truvada following a C.D.C. recommendation that all Americans at risk for H.I.V. take this daily pill that has been shown to prevent infection.

headline: Ask Well: AIDS and Truvada
keywords: ['Acquired Immune Deficiency Syndrome', 'Medicine and Health', 'Sexually Transmitted Diseases', 'Truvada (Drug)']
abstract: Donald G. McNeil Jr. responds to reader questions about new recommendations to prevent H.I.V. infection with daily doses of the drug Truvada.
lead_paragraph: New federal guidelines urge gay men and others who have unprotected sex to take a daily dose of the drug Truvada to curb H.I.V. infections and AIDS. Donald G. McNeil Jr. responds to reader questions.

lead_paragraph: In this week’s video, Times critics share their thoughts on ““Godzilla,” “The Immigrant” and “Million Dollar Arm.” See all of this week’s reviews.

headline: Coaxing Lyrical Voices From the Withdrawn
abstract: Two music institutes in New York use music and creative expression to try to improve the well-being of their clients, many of whom are autistic.
lead_paragraph: The Institute for Music and Health in Dutchess County occupies a big house in a deserted clearing at the end of a long and winding road. The main feature of the house is a room with two grand pianos, each with a so-called reflector — an obelisk-like plywood device that, placed under the piano’s soundboard, is said to direct the sound waves back toward the pianist, easing feelings of isolation.

headline: Bridging the Racial Divide in Tuscaloosa Schools
abstract: A ProPublica project in Tuscaloosa, Ala., had teenagers document the realities of resegregated schools.
lead_paragraph: A ProPublica project in Tuscaloosa, Ala., had teenagers document the realities of resegregated schools.

headline: Wheelies: The Top-Shelf Kia Edition
abstract: Kia announces nationwide rollout of its K900 luxury sedan; 1999 Packard Twelve prototype to go up for sale in July auction.
lead_paragraph: ■ Michael Sprague, executive vice president for sales and marketing at Kia Motors America, said on Thursday that the automaker’s K900 luxury car, currently on sale in California, would be available in the Midwest this month. The $66,000 rear-wheel drive sedan is equipped with a 420-horsepower 5-liter V8 engine. (The Detroit Free Press)

headline: Uncanny Representations of Humans in Distress
abstract: An exhibition at the Princeton University Art Museum showcases 26 of Edvard Munch’s etchings, lithographs and woodcuts, from the Museum of Modern Art.
lead_paragraph: Two events from the last decade demonstrate how Edvard Munch (1863-1944) remains relevant in widely varying contexts today. One is the $119.9 million price paid in 2012 for a pastel version of “The Scream” (1895), which made it briefly the most expensive artwork ever sold at auction. The other is a proposal to use a version of “The Scream” to label a nuclear waste storage site, warning future generations — or visitors from other planets — of the toxic dangers lurking within.

headline: Expanding Hydropower

lead_paragraph: To the Editor:

headline: Spain, With a Touch of Denmark
abstract: Alban Lendorf, a star of the Royal Danish Ballet, danced the part of Basilio on Wednesday in the American Ballet Theater production of “Don Quixote.”
lead_paragraph: American Ballet Theater has settled in at the Metropolitan Opera House, and the guest artists have started rolling through. Nearly a dozen, some well known here, some not, will appear in the next two months. At best, the system brings to New York world-class dancers we might not otherwise get to see. On Wednesday, the choice was especially welcome: Alban Lendorf, a young star of the Royal Danish Ballet.

headline: Abbas Meets in London With Israeli Negotiator
abstract: The president of the Palestinian Authority spoke with Israel’s justice minister in the first known face-to-face talks between the two sides since peace negotiations collapsed last month.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority met Thursday in London with Israel’s justice minister, Tzipi Livni, the first known face-to-face talks between the two sides since the American-brokered peace negotiations collapsed last month.

headline: Bringing Star Power From the Windy City
abstract: The two chefs in charge at Greenwich’s new Primary Food & Drink, are Graham Elliot, a Chicago restaurateur, and Merlin Verrier, who has run the kitchen since the restaurant opened in December.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard not to have great expectations when a celebrity chef comes to town — never mind a pair of celebrity chefs, who together have racked up culinary awards, made dozens of television appearances and cooked at most of the country’s top food and wine festivals.

headline: U.S. Setting Up Emergency Shelter in Texas as Youths Cross Border Alone
abstract: Border authorities in South Texas have been overwhelmed by a recent surge of young illegal migrants traveling by themselves, leading the Department of Homeland Security to call for resources from other agencies.
lead_paragraph: With border authorities in South Texas overwhelmed by a surge of young illegal migrants traveling by themselves, the Department of Homeland Security declared a crisis this week and moved to set up an emergency shelter for the youths at an Air Force base in San Antonio, officials said Friday.

headline: Clinton Calls for Expanding Economic Opportunities
abstract: The former secretary of state said that many are struggling to enter, or stay in, the middle class.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Hillary Rodham Clinton weighed in on the debate over income inequality on Friday, calling for policies intended to help the struggling middle class, in a speech that seemed suited to a campaign.

headline: In Sparse Space, Flair for the House-Made
abstract: At L’inizio in Ardsley, the owners have saved the frills for the inventive neo-Italian dishes and finely tailored desserts.
lead_paragraph: When L’inizio took the place of the short-lived Italian Kitchen in January, I thought, here goes, another neo-Italian storefront run by young pioneers conversant in cavatelli, romanesco and semifreddo, with the usual local sourcing and “house-made” this and that. But the new owners, Scott and Heather Fratangelo, are making so many good things to eat with so much confidence that there’s little room left for skepticism. L’inizio means “the start” in Italian and the Fratangelos are off to a promising one.

headline: Slowly Producing a Spirit England Can Call Its Own
abstract: A small-scale distiller is part of a revival of whisky making in England.
lead_paragraph: ROUDHAM, England — Made with barley from a family farm and water from a local borehole, the slightly nutty-tasting single-malt whisky from a small distillery can cost more than similar products from Glenmorangie or Glenlivet. Matured for at least three years in bourbon casks, it is shipped around the world to the United States, Sweden, Russia, Hong Kong and China.

headline: Apple and Google End Patent Fights
abstract: Apple and Google, fierce rivals in mobile software, agreed to dismiss patent lawsuits related to smartphone technology between the two companies.
lead_paragraph: Updated with more reporting on the two companies as targets of so-called patent trolling.

headline: Next Week on Retro Report
abstract: Before DNA testing, prosecutors often relied on microscopic hair analysis to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was it? Visit nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.
lead_paragraph: Before DNA testing, prosecutors often relied on microscopic hair analysis to put criminals behind bars. But how reliable was it? Visit nytimes.com on Monday for the full story.

headline: Rangers and Montreal Revive Historic Rivalry
abstract: The Rangers are 7-7 in playoff series against the Canadiens since 1930, or 10-9 against Montreal teams, including the long-defunct Maroons.
lead_paragraph: Over nearly a century of coexistence, the Montreal Canadiens and the Rangers are at opposite ends of the Stanley Cup spectrum. The Canadiens have celebrated a record 24 Cups, though none since 1993. The Rangers have won only four — one in the last 74 years, in 1994.

headline: Italian Food, the American Way
abstract: Marie’s Italian Specialties in Chatham is a source of traditional dishes in which even the simplest steps are executed with precision.
lead_paragraph: When Carl and Marie Ruiz opened Marie’s Italian Specialties in 2011, their intention was to maintain the sane hours of a deli-style restaurant, closing precisely at 6 p.m. Their intention was foiled on Day 1, when a well-dressed man entered the restaurant right at 6 and without even looking at a menu, said he wanted rigatoni with sausage and meatballs.

headline: Mining Disaster Grows Into Political Crisis for Turkish Leader
keywords: ['Soma, Turkey, Mining Disaster (2014)', 'Mines and Mining', 'Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to the deadly mine explosion has fueled antigovernment sentiment.
lead_paragraph: Prime Minister Recep Tayyip Erdogan’s response to the deadly mine explosion has fueled antigovernment sentiment.

headline: His Future and Fortune at Stake, Formula One Chief Keeps It Breezy
abstract: Bernie Ecclestone is on trial in a German court on bribery charges, and a conviction would almost certainly end the auto-racing reign that has allowed him to amass billions.
lead_paragraph: MUNICH — For a man at risk of being rudely unseated from his position as one of the world’s most powerful sports moguls, Bernie Ecclestone seems improbably relaxed as the defendant in a criminal trial accusing him of bribery in the deal that ensured his continued control of grand prix motor racing.

headline: Mother Accuses Doctors of Forcing a C-Section and Files Suit
abstract: In a case that raises questions about pregnant women’s rights, a woman is suing her doctors and a hospital after they overrode her decision to give birth naturally.
lead_paragraph: After two cesarean sections, Rinat Dray wanted to give birth naturally.

headline: Colombia and Rebels Agree on Drug Fight
abstract: Negotiators for the government and the FARC guerrillas announced their pact, part of broader talks, just a week before a presidential election.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — Negotiators for the Colombian government and the country’s largest guerrilla group said Friday that they had reached an agreement on ways to fight drug trafficking as part of broader talks aimed at ending five decades of war. The announcement came barely a week before a presidential election that could hinge on how voters view the peace talks.

headline: The Name Is New, the Flavors are Familiar
abstract: The building on Jericho Turnpike in Syosset that houses Din Din, which has been an Asian restaurant for decades, has had a series of name changes recently.
lead_paragraph: When I announced, “We’re going to Din Din,” my dining companions responded, laughing, with baby talk. In fact, the name of the restaurant comes from the “Chinese baby name” of its owner, Sophia Kang, Ms. Kang told me on the telephone after my visits.

headline: Concerns Fade Over Weather and the Favorite’s Health
abstract: Storms cleared ahead of the Preakness Stakes, and California Chrome’s trainers said that he was ready and that worries over a scratchy throat were overblown.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — California Chrome galloped in the rain, took his medicine — a glycerin rinse for a small blister in his throat — and was declared fit, fast and ready for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes by his father-son training team.

headline: The Preakness Draw
abstract: Post positions for Saturday’s 139th running of the Preakness Stakes.

headline: Yearning for a Bigger (Apple) Smartphone
abstract: While I’ve owned an Apple iPhone for the past seven years, seeing a lot of larger Android devices on the market has caused me to have big phone envy.
lead_paragraph: I have big phone envy.

headline: As 9/11 Museum Opens, These New Yorkers Will Stay Away
abstract: Hesitation about visiting the place, or outright refusal, seems particularly acute among those who were in the city during the attacks or lost someone close to them.
lead_paragraph: The National September 11 Memorial Museum is meant to be an exercise in the cathartic power of memory. At its formal unveiling on Thursday, President Obama gave a somber speech, remarking that the lives of those who died in the terrorist attacks in 2001 would be honored by the stories told “in the footprint of two mighty towers.”

headline: Times Co. Chief Addresses Executive Editor’s Firing
abstract: Mark Thompson, the company’s chief executive, reasserted the paper’s position that compensation issues played no role in the departure of Jill Abramson.
lead_paragraph: The controversy over the firing of Jill Abramson, the former executive editor of The New York Times, continued on Friday as the company’s chief executive sent a letter to senior editors in an effort to further address the reasons for her dismissal.

headline: Beware the City Dolls
abstract: Growing up should never be easy.
lead_paragraph: COMMENCEMENT season is upon us again. In a tenuous economic recovery, many of the 1.6 million graduates at American colleges and universities will be listening intently for a bit of practical wisdom from their commencement speakers.

headline: Producing Goals and Gall for Canadiens
abstract: Controversy always seems to trail P. K. Subban, a defenseman for Montreal, and he is bound to be in the middle of the action against the Rangers in the Eastern Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: BROSSARD, Quebec — Pernell Karl Subban thrives on being the center of attention. And that is what he has been in the N.H.L. playoffs, especially when his Montreal Canadiens faced the top-seeded Boston Bruins in the second round.

headline: Ex-Duke Lacrosse Coach Rebuilds Shattered Career
abstract: Fired in the wake of a sexual-assault case involving Blue Devils players that turned out to be bogus, Mike Pressler has the lacrosse program at tiny Bryant University rolling in Division I.
lead_paragraph: SMITHFIELD, R.I. — There is more salt in the salt-and-cinnamon beard, but otherwise, Mike Pressler is about the same these days, eight years after he left Duke as the most infamous lacrosse coach in the nation.

headline: Michelle Obama Cites View of Growing Segregation
keywords: ['Segregation and Desegregation', 'Race and Ethnicity', 'Brown v Board of Education (Supreme Court Decision)', 'Discrimination', 'Education (K-12)', 'Blacks', 'Black People']
abstract: Marking the anniversary of the landmark Brown v. Board of Education decision, civil rights advocates say American schools are increasingly split along racial lines.
lead_paragraph: TOPEKA, Kan. — Sixty years after the Supreme Court outlawed “separate but equal” schools for blacks and whites, civil rights advocates say American schools are becoming increasingly segregated, while the first lady, Michelle Obama, lamented that “many young people are going to schools with kids who look just like them.”

headline: Passes Are No Longer Needed at 9/11 Memorial
abstract: Beginning on Thursday afternoon, visitors were permitted simply to enter the eight-acre National September 11 Memorial without having to buy a ticket or make a reservation.
lead_paragraph: The National September 11 Memorial is now truly open — unimpeded and permanently — to the public.

headline: British Candidate Clarifies Just Which Immigrants Disturb Him
abstract: In a contentious radio interview, a British nationalist politician from an anti-immigrant party denied being racist.
lead_paragraph: In a contentious radio interview that sounded at moments like Absurdist theater, the leader of the anti-immigrant U.K. Independence Party, Nigel Farage, denied on Friday that his attacks on foreign-born migrants were racist.

headline: City Now Expects to Authorize More Green Cabs by the Fall
keywords: ['Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Elections, Mayors', 'Lobbying and Lobbyists']
abstract: The Taxi and Limousine Commission said it hoped to issue new permits for the street-hail livery service outside Manhattan by summer’s end.
lead_paragraph: One day after signaling that it would slow indefinitely the expansion of street-hail livery cab service outside Manhattan, Mayor Bill de Blasio’s administration said on Friday that it expected to issue new permits for the popular green taxis at the end of the summer.

headline: No Reason to Delay Fair Wages
abstract: A request for further study of a new federal rule on pay for home care workers should be denied.
lead_paragraph: Come Jan. 1, 2015, a new federal rule will require that home care workers be paid at least the minimum wage and time and a half for overtime. This rule would undo an indefensible policy, dating from 1974, that denied home care workers basic labor protections by deeming them “companions” rather than employees.

headline: The Slippery Slope of Secrecy
keywords: ['Espionage and Intelligence Services', 'Classified Information and State Secrets', 'Editorials']
abstract: A new prepublication review policy would constrain the ability of officials to comment informally when issues are stirred by leaked information.
lead_paragraph: “If you want to keep a secret,” George Orwell advised in “1984,” “you must also hide it from yourself.” So the latest stricture seems to demand from the Office of the Director of National Intelligence, the federal uber-agency of all things secret. The office, which oversees 16 government intelligence agencies, issued a new policy in April that will seriously constrain the existing practice by which officials comment informally to the press and public when obvious issues are stirred by leaked information and unauthorized disclosures.

headline: Little Time Left for Campaign Reforms
abstract: What Albany needs is competition, and now may be the right moment for Gov. Andrew Cuomo to pass a full reform package that could provide it.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Andrew Cuomo is busy running for re-election, but he has yet to make good on a campaign promise from 2010: to clean up New York’s abysmal campaign finance system. He can do that by coaxing the Legislature into passing a reform package that provides public matching funds for small donations.

headline: California Wildfires Spread Across Hills, Leveling Homes
abstract: Residents and officials are just beginning to assess the damage and determine the causes, even as fire crews continued struggling to get five of the blazes under control.
lead_paragraph: ESCONDIDO, Calif. — With fire rolling swiftly down the hill toward their houses on Thursday, Jeff Brown, his brother and his grandmother were forced by sheriff’s deputies to flee the two homes here that the family has occupied since the 1960s.

headline: Robbery Suspect Tracked by GPS and Killed
keywords: ['Robberies and Thefts', 'Drugstores', 'Drugs (Pharmaceuticals)', 'Global Positioning System', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings']

headline: Pakistan: Boy Kills a Jailed Man Who Was Accused of Blasphemy
abstract: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy.
lead_paragraph: A teenage Pakistani boy walked into a police station on Friday and shot dead a 65-year-old man accused of blasphemy. The boy, a student in the 10th grade, entered the station in Sharaqpur, 15 miles west of Lahore, wearing a fake police uniform and carrying a gun, the police said. He demanded to see Khalil Ahmad, a member of the minority Ahmadi community who was being held at the station. Mr. Ahmad had been arrested Monday after a dispute with a Muslim shopkeeper escalated and the shopkeeper sought help from local clerics, who accused Mr. Ahmad and three other Ahmadis of blasphemy. When the boy was taken to the detainee’s cell, he shot Mr. Ahmad, who died instantly, the police said. The boy was arrested.

headline: Germany: The Flight of the Iguana
abstract: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week.
lead_paragraph: A bizarre cargo of more than 80 exotic reptiles, including four horned vipers and an iguana, attracted the attention of an alert customs official at Frankfurt Airport this week. During a routine inspection of luggage in transit, the official found 50 turtles, 30 arboreal alligator lizards, the snakes and the iguana in one suitcase. Several reptiles were stuffed into cloth bags or boxes, and the snakes were entangled in women’s stockings, said Hans-Jürgen Schmidt, a customs spokesman. The owner of the bag, traveling from Mexico City to Barcelona, was detained Tuesday before boarding his flight to Spain, Mr. Schmidt said. The passenger, a 44-year-old Mexican, who cannot be named under German privacy laws, is under investigation to determine whether he violated laws on the protection of endangered species and the treatment of animals. Three turtles have died, and most of the reptiles, which have been moved to the Frankfurt zoo, were in bad shape, Mr. Schmidt said. The potential sale value of the cargo was as much as $82,000, he said.

headline: What’s on Saturday

lead_paragraph: 8 P.M. (Lifetime) RETURN TO ZERO (2014) Maggie (Minnie Driver) and Aaron (Paul Adelstein, above with Ms. Driver) try to resume their picture-perfect existence after their son is stillborn, but can’t escape their grief in this drama based on the personal experiences of the writer and director, Sean Hanish. They cope through denial, escape and alcohol, but when Maggie discovers that Aaron is having an affair with a colleague (Sarah Jones), she decides to end the marriage. But just as she believes that she is ready to move on, she discovers that she’s pregnant. Alfred Molina portrays Aaron’s brusque father and boss; Kathy Baker is Maggie’s mother. headline: Cannes Film Festival:  ‘Timbuktu’ Director on Africa and Fundamentalism

lead_paragraph: Eric Shinseki, the secretary of veterans affairs, fired the department’s head of health care in response to a growing controversy that veterans hospitals in Arizona, Colorado, Texas, Wyoming and elsewhere were concealing the wait time for patients. Last year, Veterans Affairs set a goal for new patients seeking primary care to be seen within 14 days of requesting an appointment.

headline: The Square People, Part 2
abstract: From the town square to the virtual square the globe over, what happens after the protest march?
lead_paragraph: IN a famous 1995 interview about her dysfunctional marriage and the infidelity of Prince Charles, Princess Diana noted that “there were three of us in this marriage, so it was a bit crowded.” I find myself thinking of that quote lately to describe the new politics and geopolitics that have been produced by “The Square People” — all those newly connected and aspiring middle classes who have gathered in the squares from Cairo to Kiev, Istanbul to Tehran, and Tunis to Moscow to demand a greater voice in their future and better governance. A lot of leaders are discovering that these Square People are like a spontaneous third party that has emerged between themselves and their tame traditional opposition and, as a result, their politics is getting a bit crowded — and a lot more interesting.

headline: Grading Obama’s Foreign Policy

A few minutes later, he nervously confessed that he had also thought of giving stand-up comedy a whirl.

headline: The House Ducks on Defense
keywords: ['Federal Budget (US)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: Congress seems frightened of the political fallout that would come from making much-needed cuts in the defense budget.
lead_paragraph: The Pentagon has for too long been in denial about the changes it will have to make in a world of declining resources, skyrocketing personnel costs and changing global threats. This year, however, Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel presented a more realistic, though still insufficient, cost-saving budget. Yet Congress seems firmly stuck in the past, loyal to campaign donors and frightened, as always, about local political fallout from closing excess military bases, modifying military compensation, reducing troop levels and cutting nonessential or older weapons.

abstract: Baseball’s regular season reached its quarter pole on Friday.

It dislocated his right shoulder and fractured his scapula and ended his collegiate career and, for a few hours, sent his world tumbling down, as he put it. But he did not pout, and he did not sulk, and he did not withdraw from his teammates, who needed him as much he needed them.

headline: Mapping Our Interiors

lead_paragraph: Sure, that’s your office cubicle. Your corner store. Maybe even the layout of your furniture in your living room. But that doesn’t mean that soon we won’t all be peering at it, too.

headline: ‘You’re Not My Real Mother’
abstract: “You’re not my real mother.” True words in one sense, but words that are still hard for an adoptive mother to hear.
lead_paragraph: In so many ways, my daughter Julia is a young soon-to-be 12-year-old. Though she’s in middle school, she’s unconcerned with fashion, boys or other pre-pubescent experimenting. Julia, adopted from a Siberian orphanage at 8 months old, is on track intellectually but is still catching up emotionally. She is a wonderful violinist and artist and an honor student, but she hasn’t yet learned how to make a BFF, nor (and I suppose I should be thankful) has she attached herself to a clique. My husband and I are her whole world.

(Or at least roar.) “Godzilla,” powered in part by strong Imax and 3-D screenings, cost a reported $195 million to make, with tax credits bringing the net cost closer to $160 million. Legendary Pictures and Warner Brothers collaborated on the picture, but Legendary put up 75 percent of the budget and will thus reap an outsize share of the profits.

headline: Short Pieces That, Together, Span Centuries
abstract: In an Emanuel Ax piano recital at Carnegie Hall, intermezzos by the Australian composer Brett Dean got their New York premiere, paired with intermezzos by Brahms.
lead_paragraph: In his late 50s, Brahms kept threatening to quit composing. But he could not help himself. Among the works he wrote during his last years were four collections of shorter pieces for piano, composed in 1892 and 1893. (He died in 1897, a month before turning 64.) Though these late piano pieces are ingenious, consequential and even experimental compositions, displaying a bit of impishness, Brahms called many of them intermezzos — a category that implies a short piece meant to be performed between longer ones.

headline: First, Voices, Then Bodies
abstract: In Emmanuelle Huynh’s “A Vida Enorme/épisode 1,” disembodied voices, male and female, converse in Portuguese and French; the couple appears later, shirtless, in a restive dance.
lead_paragraph: If you don’t speak Portuguese or French, it’s hard to understand, in the conventional sense, the first half of Emmanuelle Huynh’s “A Vida Enorme/épisode 1.” For about 20 minutes, two disembodied voices, male and female, converse in those voluptuous languages, broadcast from a stack of speakers in the middle of the otherwise empty space. The only activity happens in the form of light, which slowly fades and intensifies, singling out features of the sanctuary at St. Mark’s Church. The program contains English translations of the text, by the Portuguese poet Herberto Hélder, but how necessary are these? The sensuousness of the voices, their texture, say a lot in themselves.

A loud mechanical noise had begun whirring near Mr. Fetisov as he was being interviewed about “Red Army,” Mr. Polsky’s documentary about the rise and fall of Soviet hockey that is playing at the Cannes Film Festival. headline: AT&T Shareholders on Hold in DirecTV Deal
abstract: The unexpectedly robust $1.6 billion of cost savings from the acquisition do not quite cover the 30 percent premium AT&T is paying, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: AT&T is putting its shareholders on hold to buy DirecTV. Its acquisition of the satellite TV operator, announced on Sunday, brings with it an unexpectedly robust $1.6 billion of cost savings. Even so, those savings will not quite cover the cost of the premium. In any case, AT&T says it will use the money to roll out rural broadband service. Customers and regulators are getting the first call.

headline: At Kartell, There’s Still a Great Future in Plastics
abstract: A group of American creative talents, including Pharrell Williams, Kelly Wearstler and Rafael de Cárdenas, created their own versions of the iconic Bourgie table lamp, which are on view at the Italian design brand’s SoHo store this week.
lead_paragraph: After 65 years producing plastic furniture, lighting and accessories, it’s safe to say that the Italian company Kartell knows a thing or two about how to elevate the utilitarian material into fashionable design. The trick? Balancing plastic’s cold and industrial characteristics with familiar, classic silhouettes. Philippe Starck’s Ghost chairs for the brand — shaped in the style of French Louis XVI — have reportedly sold over 1.5 million units. Another historically inspired icon, Ferruccio Laviani’s Bourgie table lamp featuring a baroque base and a corrugated shade, celebrates 10 years in production this year. It has also been a best seller in transparent, colored and metallic versions.

abstract: It would be nice if we could tackle inequality with a growth approach and without some sacrifices from the wealthy, but that path simply doesn’t exist.
lead_paragraph: It’s tempting to think — and hope — that attacking inequality doesn’t mean we have to hurt those at the top. This idea has become a central response from conservatives to the current debate inspired by Thomas Piketty’s book and proposal for a wealth tax.

headline: First Wolverine Comic Art Is Sold for Nearly $660,000
abstract: The original Herb Trimpe art for the comic page that introduced Wolverine, one of the most popular heroes of Marvel Comics, sold on Friday for $657,250, part of which will benefit a charity.
lead_paragraph: The original art for the comic book page that introduced Wolverine, one of the most popular heroes of Marvel Comics, sold on Friday for $657,250 at Heritage Auctions. The superhero is introduced in the final moments of issue no. 180 of “The Incredible Hulk,” from 1974, which finds the green Goliath wreaking havoc in Canada. Wolverine is called in to stop the Hulk’s rampage. As he makes his appearance in the final panel, he proclaims: “If you really want to tangle with someone – why not try your luck against – the Wolverine!” (His first full appearance would be in the following issue of “The Incredible Hulk.”)

headline: Blueberry or Blackberry Compote With Yogurt or Ricotta
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: An easy compote can transform plain yogurt or ricotta into a substantial breakfast or even a dessert.
lead_paragraph: Modeled on Deborah Madison’s recipe in her lovely book “Seasonal Fruit Desserts,” this simple compote will transform a plain bowl of yogurt or ricotta cheese into a dessert or a very nice breakfast.

headline: Whole-Grain Blueberry Buckle
abstract: Topped with oats and quinoa flour, this old-fashioned cake is no longer traditional at all.
lead_paragraph: A buckle is an old-fashioned cake that has a crumble topping and fruit that makes the batter buckle, or sink, as it bakes. Or at least that’s what all the recipes I’ve read say is supposed to happen. When I made the cake the blueberries didn’t really cause it to buckle at all, they just formed a layer on top of the cake. This is now a favorite dessert. It’s not traditional at all, as I use whole-wheat flour, and oats and quinoa flour in the topping.

headline: Resentment of China Spreading in Myanmar
abstract: Anger over what local residents call the mine’s unbridled expansion represents the latest instance of hostility toward China by Asian neighbors.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — A flare-up of resilient hostility toward China among its neighbors has infected central Myanmar, where a Chinese company operating a copper mine has local residents seething over what they call the operator’s arrogance and the project’s seemingly unbridled expansion plans.

headline: Beet and Arugula Salad With Berries
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The sweet-tart flavor of berries make a lovely contrast to the pungency of arugula and the earthy sweetness of beets.
lead_paragraph: Berries and beets: a salad of dark green, blue and purple hues if there ever was one. I threw this together because I had these ingredients on hand – beets that I’d roasted several days earlier, arugula that was bolting in my garden, and berries from the market – and it worked. The sweet-tart flavor of the berries contrasts beautifully with the earthy sweetness of the beets and the pungent arugula.

headline: Cornmeal and Buckwheat Blueberry Muffins
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: These muffins are the antithesis of the blueberry muffins on the counter in coffee shops, with plenty of fruit.
lead_paragraph: Buckwheat contributes a rustic, earthy flavor to these not-too-sweet muffins. They are the antithesis of the cakey blueberry muffins you find in coffee shops. The berry quotient is generous here. If you find the buckwheat flavor too strong, swap the amounts of whole-wheat and buckwheat flours (that is, use 125 grams whole-wheat and 65 grams buckwheat).

headline: Berry Clafoutis
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Fruit', 'Recipes', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Not very sweet, this clafoutis works for either breakfast or dessert.
lead_paragraph: Clafoutis, as you may know by now, are among my favorite vehicles for seasonal fruit. I love the way blueberries and blackberries bleed into the batter as this bakes. Let it cool for about a half-hour, or completely, before you serve it, and be careful when you cut into it, as the berries can splatter when they’re warm. My clafoutis are not very sweet, and I enjoy them for breakfast as well as for dessert.

headline: With Spy Charges, U.S. Draws a Line That Few Others Recognize
abstract: The administration is drawing a distinction between espionage for national security and the commercial spying that it says China’s military carries out.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — By indicting members of the People’s Liberation Army’s most famous cyberwarfare operation — called Unit 61398 but known among hackers as the “Comment Crew” — the Obama administration has turned to the criminal justice system to reinforce its argument that there is a major difference between spying for national security purposes, something the United States does daily, and the commercial, for-profit espionage carried out by China’s military.

headline: Louis Vuitton Comes to Monaco, Celebrities in Tow

In came Carine Roitfeld wearing a snake-skin Givenchy jacket and a tight-as-could-be Rick Owens skirt. After that came Charlotte Gainsbourg and Adèle Exarchopoulos, who were decked out in leather pants and shimmering tops by Nicolas Ghesquière, Louis Vuitton’s recently anointed head designer.

headline: Weekend Gun Report: May 16-18, 2014
abstract: A weekend in the life of armed America.
lead_paragraph: Last month, Gama Droiville, 13, was shot twice in the head after getting caught in the crossfire of a gang-related gun battle while he waited for a bus in the East Flatbush section of Brooklyn, N.Y.. Eduardo Dolphy, 24, the intended target, was shot in the leg. Police arrested Kareem Potomont, 21, who has 13 prior arrests. Weeks earlier, 39-year-old Angel Rojas was caught in gang crossfire on a bus and killed in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn. His assailant, 14-year-old Kahton Anderson, was aiming for another teenager.

headline: Art Matters | The Hudson Valley’s Newest Art Destination
abstract: Jack Shainman Gallery opened the doors to the School on Saturday, when the artist Nick Cave helped inaugurate the space with a live performance.
lead_paragraph: The last time artwork adorned the walls of the Martin Van Buren school in Kinderhook, N.Y., it had been commissioned at the request of elementary school teachers. On Saturday, however, both new and retrospective pieces by the artist Nick Cave were installed throughout the newly converted 30,000-square-foot building, while dancers costumed in Cave’s idiosyncratic Soundsuits performed outside for a crowd of art-world cognoscenti and local residents. The early evening celebration feted both the opening of what is simply being called The School, Jack Shainman Gallery‘s colossal addition to two gallery spaces in Chelsea, as well as the 30th anniversary of the gallery itself.

lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD — Beating expectations, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki secured the largest number of seats in last month’s parliamentary elections, the first since the withdrawal of American forces at the end of 2011, putting him in a strong position to secure a third term as Iraq’s leader as negotiations begin to form a new government.

lead_paragraph: Yankees pitcher C. C. Sabathia, who received a cortisone shot with stem cells Thursday as treatment for a degenerative condition in the cartilage in his right knee, will be out for at least six more weeks, General Manager Brian Cashman said Monday.

headline: Chinese Vessel Will Map Ocean Floor in Search for Missing Jet
abstract: Experts from Malaysia, China and Australia agreed that an extensive survey of the sea floor near Australia’s coast would be done by a Chinese Navy vessel.
lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — The Malaysian government announced late Monday night that a Chinese vessel would survey the ocean floor at the last suspected location of Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.

headline: It’s a Must-Have Book, Even if You Never Read It
abstract: People may buy Thomas Piketty’s “Capital in the Twenty-First Century” just to say they have a copy. How many will read and understand all 698 pages?
lead_paragraph: I confess that for a stretch of time, I convinced myself that having The Economist lying around would make me smarter, even if I never picked it up. Just by being in the same room, I’d somehow learn by osmosis about the news in each issue. Also, I liked having people think of me as the kind of person who read The Economist. But the osmosis thing didn’t happen, and I finally stopped my subscription when I realized I’d probably never read it on a regular basis.

headline: Monday Motorsports: Ed Carpenter Wins Another Indy 500 Pole
abstract: Carpenter collected a $100,000 prize for his second consecutive Indy pole; Jamie McMurray won a $1 million prize at the Nascar Sprint All-Star race.
lead_paragraph: Ed Carpenter hasn’t run an IndyCar race since last October, but was back in top form Sunday as he posted a 231.067 mile per hour qualifying average that earned him the pole position for the 98th Indianapolis 500. Carpenter, who also was the fastest qualifier for last year’s Indy 500, collected a $100,000 prize for his wild ride around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway’s 2.5-mile oval.

headline: Legacy of Hamas-Fatah Killings Complicates Palestinian Unity Efforts

lead_paragraph: GAZA — For 14-year-old Aseel Radi, the promised reconciliation between warring Palestinian political factions is viewed through a forlorn fountain in a crowded market on the eastern side of Gaza City.

lead_paragraph: On Saturday night, Vanity Fair (the American edition) hosted a party at the Hotel du Cap-Eden-Roc, just outside Cannes, for a star-packed party that ran until 2 a.m.

headline: Station That Mirrors East Village’s Spirit Is Signing Off

lead_paragraph: For more than a decade, East Village Radio has operated out of a tiny storefront studio on First Avenue near First Street.

headline: ‘Wicked’ Writer Is Among Those Winning Lilly Awards
abstract: The composers behind “Fun Home” and “Frozen” will also receive prizes, for women in theater, at a ceremony on June 2.
lead_paragraph: Winnie Holzman, who wrote the book for the blockbuster musical “Wicked” and has been a prolific television and film writer as well, will receive a lifetime achievement prize at the fifth annual Lilly Awards ceremony at Playwrights Horizons on June 2. She is one of 12 winners of a 2014 Lilly, a prize named for Lillian Hellman, and meant to honor women in the theater.

headline: Cleric Convicted of All Terrorism Charges
abstract: Mostafa Kamel Mostafa, a former imam who prosecutors said had “devoted his life to violent jihad,” was convicted of 11 terrorism-related charges on Monday.
lead_paragraph: The fiery British cleric who prosecutors said had “devoted his life to violent jihad” and sent young men around the world to train and fight was convicted Monday of all 11 terrorism-related charges against him.

headline: Bookshelf | A Collection of Recipes Meant to Inspire Foodie Gatherings
abstract: The cult-favorite culinary whiz Diana Yen of the Jewels of New York releases a mouth-watering new cookbook, “A Simple Feast.”
lead_paragraph: Speaking to Diana Yen about food, it instantly becomes clear that she’s a sucker for not just the fresh and seasonal — the Union Square farmer’s market is her first and favorite stop for groceries — but also for ingredients made great by attention to the smallest of details. “My second stop would be Eataly. I love the way that they take care of their lettuce,” she begins to explain, breaking into a fit of laughter as she realizes how neurotic this sounds. “They have this really sophisticated sprinkling system, so the lettuce never gets too drenched, and it’s never dry — it’s just perfect. I see them pamper their vegetables, so I trust them.”

headline: Anti-Europe Parties at Odds, Despite Shared Cause
abstract: Infighting among the contending euro-skeptic groups could dilute their collective strength if they make big gains in the European Parliament elections.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Geert Wilders, the leader of the populist Freedom Party in the Netherlands, told cheering supporters two months ago that he wanted fewer Moroccans in the country. One of his party’s most prominent and charismatic figures, Laurence Stassen, a former television reporter and a member of the European Parliament, promptly quit in protest.

headline: Options for Rivals in Wake of AT&T’s Bid for DirecTV

lead_paragraph: Few industries have been as deeply embroiled in merger mania as the telecommunications industry, particularly after AT&T’s $48.5 billion bid for DirecTV.

headline: Beyond Pretzel Logic
abstract: The bar snacks of yore can’t hold a peanut to the brisket tots and fried fish skins of today.
lead_paragraph: For years, lingering at the bar came with a penance: a bowl of stale peanuts or soggy pretzels. Even if you didn’t start out wanting to drown your sorrows, the food made you want to. Bar snacks were meant to lace your mouth with plenty of salt, leading you to reach more often for your thirst-slaking gimlet.

headline: Justices Reinstate Copyright Lawsuit Over ‘Raging Bull’

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Monday revived a copyright lawsuit against the owners of “Raging Bull,” the acclaimed 1980 movie for which Robert De Niro won an Academy Award as best actor for his portrayal of the boxer Jake LaMotta.

headline: Creation, in the Eye of the Beholder
abstract: For some of us, the apparent perfect symmetry of nature suggests an inventor. But evolution is messier and more roughshod than our own machines.
lead_paragraph: I remember the chill I felt, 27 years ago, when I picked up the latest edition of Scientific American magazine. Pictured on the cover was an object of unnerving beauty — a cutaway of a perfect blue sphere meticulously assembled from tiny identical parts and studded around the circumference with precisely placed green antennas. Inside this flawlessly honed outer shell was a smaller inner sphere, reddish tan in color, and suspended at its center was an ivory capsule, built from hundreds of still tinier spheres.

headline: With World Cup in Brazil, Risk of Spreading a Virus
abstract: Officials fear that some soccer fans will carry dengue fever, now an epidemic in Brazil, back to their home countries.
lead_paragraph: Public health authorities are worried about a confluence of events set to happen soon: Brazil is suffering the world’s worst epidemic of dengue fever, with 1.4 million cases last year. And the country is about to play host to the World Cup, which attracts tourists by the millions.

headline: Met Plans a Gut Renovation of Its Modern Wing
abstract: Following a gift of Cubist artworks valued at more than $1 billion, the Metropolitan Museum of Art is looking to improve its layout.
lead_paragraph: The Metropolitan Museum of Art is planning to rebuild its wing for Modern and contemporary art — possibly from scratch — to create new, showcase galleries for its expanded collection from those periods, Met officials have confirmed.

headline: Mille Miglia Celebrates Cars From Motorsports History
keywords: ['Automobiles', 'Antique and Classic Cars', 'Automobile Racing', 'Collectors and Collections']
abstract: The endurance race began in 1927, and while the Mille Miglia is no longer a race, it still brings cheering crowds to roadsides all over Italy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — From 1927 to 1957, with time off during World War II, the Mille Miglia was an important race that dazzled motorsports fans around the world, elevating drivers to godlike status and proving what was possible when new technology was pushed to its limits on treacherous mountain roads in Italy. The race planted the seeds of legend, particularly in the parts of Northern and Central Italy where the 1,000-mile race was run.

headline: The Airline Lounge Gets Competition
abstract: Lounges not directly affiliated with an airline are common outside the United States, but the independent concept has started to catch on.
lead_paragraph: MY first encounter with an airline lounge was in the early 1970s at the Philadelphia airport when I noticed an oak door with a small brass plaque that said “Admirals Club.” I figured it had something to do with the Navy.

headline: Police Official in New Hampshire Resigns Amid Uproar Over Slur Against Obama
abstract: Robert Copeland, a police commissioner in Wolfeboro, N.H., acknowledged using the slur but initially refused to apologize or resign.
lead_paragraph: BOSTON — With a terse letter of resignation, a police commissioner in Wolfeboro, N.H., has stepped down after a cascade of complaints objecting to his use of a racial slur to describe President Obama. The commissioner, Robert Copeland, 82, who is also a lawyer, confirmed that he had made the statement. He had said he was exercising his First Amendment right of free speech.

headline: People With Chronic Illness Fare Worse Under Cost-Sharing
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Medicaid', "State Children's Health Insurance Program (S-CHIP)", 'Medicare']
abstract: Prevention and maintenance are keys for illnesses like asthma, but higher levels of cost-sharing cause people to delay or avoid treatment.
lead_paragraph: Most health care plans ask that you spend some money out of your pocket whenever you use the health care system. This is known as cost-sharing, and it exists because research has shown us that people are, in general, less likely to spend their own money than someone else’s. Cost-sharing works its way into insurance today through co-pays, deductibles and co-insurance.

headline: Cubs’ Last Link to a World Series
abstract: Shortstop Lennie Merullo, 97, who has been invited back to Wrigley Field to be honored in June, is the only person alive to have worn a Cubs uniform in a World Series.
lead_paragraph: READING, Mass. — With a sweep of his arm, Lennie Merullo rolled up the sleeve of his cardigan sweater to reveal a faint scar on his left forearm. He was in the dining room of his Victorian house, scrapbooks full of old newspaper clippings from his baseball career spread on the table before him.

lead_paragraph: In the Miller Theater’s enticing Bach, Revisited series, his works are paired with relevant pieces by living composers. A program on Thursday evening offering Bach’s Cantata “Christ lag in Todes Banden” (BWV 4) and Steve Reich’s “Tehillim,” inspired by this cantata, seemed a natural pairing.

lead_paragraph: The San Diego Opera, which was left for dead in March when its board of directors voted to shut it down after 49 years, citing dwindling ticket sales and philanthropic support, will live to see its 50th-anniversary season after all, the company announced on Monday.

headline: Pop Music Recital With a Classical Veneer
abstract: On Saturday, the Tribeca New Music Festival presented an evening of polished pop that featured the soprano Mellissa Hughes.
lead_paragraph: The Tribeca New Music Festival is one of the most clearly defined brands in New York’s teeming new-music scene. The festival’s preferred label is “avant pop,” defined as the merging of pop culture taste and classically honed craft. Saturday’s “Poetry in Motion,” an evening of new vocal music presented as part of a five-concert series at the Cell in Chelsea, was in many ways a typical sample. The songs by Andrew Norman, Christopher Cerrone, Jacob Cooper, Eric Shanfield and Ted Hearne were compact, direct and elegant; the soprano Mellissa Hughes performed them with grace and razor-sharp emotional acuity.

headline: How to Censor a PDF File
abstract: Plus, a quicker way to delete duplicate iTunes items.

lead_paragraph: The new Politico poll of likely voters in swing states and competitive districts isn’t all that bad for Democrats. Yes, the poll found that respondents would prefer to vote for a generic Republican over a generic Democrat, 41 percent to 34 percent. It also found that they’re not happy with Barack Obama: 59 percent said they disapproved of his job performance as president.

That possibility was broached on Friday evening at 54 Below, where Ms. Baldwin opened her new cabaret show with bright, peppy rendition of Ian Axel’s “Rockstar!,” an insanely catchy “what if?” song whose narrator gazes fancifully into the future.

headline: When Polar Bears Said Goodbye to Brown
abstract: After they diverged from brown bears, polar bears quickly evolved to survive in their frigid environment, researchers say.
lead_paragraph: Polar bears diverged from brown bears less than 500,000 years ago, researchers who sequenced the polar bear’s genome reported in the journal Cell. The researchers also discovered several genes related to fatty acid metabolism and cardiovascular function in the polar bear. These genes may explain how the bear subsists on a high-fat diet without suffering from clogged arteries and cardiovascular disease.

headline: A Victory Lap for a Heretical Neurologist
keywords: ['Mad Cow Disease (Bovine Spongiform Encephalopathy)', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner offers an entertaining account of the obstacles and skepticism he faced in his discovery of prions, which won him a Nobel Prize in 1997.
lead_paragraph: Sweet revenge comes in many delectable forms, among them the receipt of accolades for work long scorned. And then to get to tell the whole story at length and without a single interruption — small wonder that the Nobel laureate Dr. Stanley B. Prusiner, a renowned neurologist at the University of California, San Francisco, writes with a cheerful bounce. Once disparaged, his scientific work is now hailed as visionary, and his memoir takes the reader on a leisurely and immensely readable victory lap from then to now.

headline: Big City Book Club Discusses ‘Brooklyn’
abstract: The Big City Book Club talks about Colm Toibin’s acclaimed 2009 novel, the story of a young Irishwoman who leaves a fragile mother behind to find herself in Dodgerland in the early 1950s.
lead_paragraph: That concludes the live conversation on “Brooklyn.” Thank you all who participated, and for those who were unable to make it, feel free to posts comments all week. The book club’s next selection will be announced shortly. Colm Toibin’s novel “Brooklyn” is at once a classic narrative of the immigrant’s conflicted passions and allegiances and a story of female self-questioning that transcends the immigrant-lit genre. It offers a New York that is both a grand escape and a small town. “Brooklyn” is the story of a young Irishwoman named Eilis Lacey whose bookkeeping classes in an Irish village are interrupted when a priest living across the Atlantic sponsors her passage to New York, a voyage that submerges her in the world of Bartucci’s department store on Fulton Street and an Italian-American culture that slowly tempts her away from her own.

headline: A Troupe and Its Leader, Bodies Willing, Try to Gain a Foothold
abstract: The ballet company MorDance began its second season at the Sheen Center, and rose above a space that was less than ideal.
lead_paragraph: From the outside, the Sheen Center, a new arts complex in the West Village, looks inviting, its sleek gold awning standing out along a quiet, leafy block of Bleecker Street. Step inside, though, and the antiseptic interior makes you wonder if you’ve walked into a hospital. Descend the stairwell, and it deposits you in the gloomy black-box theater, where MorDance, a fledgling contemporary ballet company directed by Morgan McEwen, presented a triple bill on Saturday.

headline: Skewering Britain’s High-Tone Scribblers
abstract: In “Lost for Words,” Edward St. Aubyn takes a break from painful autobiographical novels for a thinly veiled satire of the Man Booker Prize.
lead_paragraph: In recounting the story of his semi-autobiographical hero, Patrick Melrose, in a series of interlinked novels (“Never Mind,” “Bad News,” “Some Hope,” “Mother’s Milk” and “At Last”), Edward St. Aubyn established himself as a dazzling writer with an utterly distinctive voice. The harrowing story of Patrick’s life — from being raped at 5 by his monstrous father, to his years as a heroin addict, to his achievement of a measure of perspective and peace in middle age — was simultaneously heartbreaking and funny, devastatingly sad and cuttingly acerbic: painful experience transmuted into art through beautifully hammered, aphoristic prose.

headline: Pastoral Voyage Turns Into White-Water Rafting
abstract: The Bavarian Radio Symphony found a wild side to Brahms’s Second Symphony at Carnegie Hall on Sunday in a program that also included Ligeti and Berg.
lead_paragraph: In historical accounts and program notes, you read that of the four Brahms symphonies, the second is the sunny one. After struggling for some 20 years to write his first symphony, a turbulent work that ends in hard-won triumph, Brahms wrote his Symphony No. 2 in D during a few months of summer vacation in 1877. The music, overall, is thought to be genial and, despite some mysterious moments, affirming.

His newest book, “Another Great Day at Sea: Life Aboard the USS George H. W. Bush,” recounts two weeks he spent embedded on an American aircraft carrier, a life for which he was almost comically ill-suited.

headline: Listen Up | In This New Video From Walter Martin, Lily McMenamy Acts Like an Animal
abstract: The in-demand model shakes her thing for the amused pedestrians of Lower Manhattan in this clip for “We Like the Zoo (‘Cause We’re Animals Too),” a new song for children of all ages from the longtime member of the Walkmen. The video premieres exclusively here.
lead_paragraph: After the indie-rock stalwarts the Walkmen went on hiatus last year, the Brooklyn-based group’s multi-instrumentalist and co-songwriter Walter Martin consulted his inner child about what to do next. And also his actual children: He had recently become a dad to two girls, who influenced his musical direction. “I had to step up to the plate and write my own album after being in a band my whole life,” Martin says. “It was hard to figure out what I wanted to do. I went through different styles, and they all seemed kind of phony. Then I wrote the first song that appears on my first solo record, and it didn’t feel phony.”

Its structure is unusually egalitarian, with equal billing given to composers, choreographers, filmmakers, writers and designers. Friday’s program at BAM Fisher featured two multimedia dance works, a stop-motion film, musical performances and a dramatic poetry reading. It was about 11 hours into the second New York Hot Jazz Festival, and the energy was far from flagging.

headline: ‘Wiring the Amazon’
abstract: This short documentary chronicles a remote Peruvian village’s complicated path to getting connected to the outside world.
lead_paragraph: This Op-Doc video chronicles the four-year struggle to get a remote Peruvian village connected with the outside world. I began filming the project in 2009, while making a feature-length documentary film about the global spread of information technology. I was following the work of One Laptop per Child (O.L.P.C.), a United States-based nonprofit that has designed inexpensive laptops for primary education. The organization is particularly active in Peru, where the government has purchased and distributed hundreds of thousands of O.L.P.C.'s laptops to its poorest communities. One such village is Palestina, deep in the Amazon rain forest. It has only 65 people.

headline: Writing About a Life of Ideas

abstract: When writing biographies of intellectuals, the life is secondary to the thinking.
lead_paragraph: When an intellectual dies, there are no heaps of flowers or public mournings. The odd wistful editorial will be written in upmarket newspapers; colloquia organized in ivy-clad colleges. Few Americans will know, for instance, that Ronald Dworkin, a formidable figure in American liberal philosophy, died last year.

headline: For Workers, Less Flexible Companies
abstract: Many employers say they offer telecommuting and flexible work hours to employees, but in fact are cutting back on time for child leave or to care for an ill parent.
lead_paragraph: He calls it one of the bright spots of his week: Before Jared Dalton, 32, starts his workday as a manager at Ernst & Young, the big accounting firm, he dresses his 5-month-old daughter, Olivia, and then places her on her tummy to play. Since he works from home on Mondays and Tuesdays, he can spend an extra hour with Olivia and an extra hour working — time that would otherwise be lost commuting into Manhattan.

headline: Now Not Batting for the Mets, a Sorely Needed Designated Hitter

lead_paragraph: The Mets’ Bartolo Colon swung and missed, his body twisting so violently that his helmet fell off and he nearly toppled over. He sheepishly fetched his headgear from the dirt a few feet away, and then he returned to the batter’s box to take another hack. He feebly struck out swinging to end the embarrassment.

lead_paragraph: New York University issued an apology on Monday to any workers on its newly completed Abu Dhabi campus who were “not treated in line with the standards we set,” after The New York Times reported widespread abuses among a labor force that numbered about 6,000 at its peak.
