headline: Primary Day on the Far Side
keywords: ['Primaries and Caucuses', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: Republican primaries around the country have largely degenerated into self-parodies, with the radicalism of 2010 and 2012 very much alive in 2014.
lead_paragraph: Wearing a black leather vest that barely covered the cigar tucked into his pocket, a man named Harley Brown was allowed to join the debate among candidates for governor of Idaho last week, holding forth on discrimination against bikers and the presidential seal tattooed on his shoulder after God told him he would one day occupy the White House. Another candidate, Walt Bayes, railed against “a bunch of eastern idiots” pushing the country toward Sodom and Gomorrah. If you thought that this was nothing but a stunt designed by Gov. Butch Otter to distract attention from his real opponent, you’d be right. But you’d also be missing the larger point: Republican primaries around the country have largely degenerated into self-parodies. They may lack the flowing beards of Mr. Brown and Mr. Bayes, but many of the other candidates in the party’s primaries — a large number of which will take place on Tuesday — are running on ideas only slightly less extreme.

headline: English League Won’t Act on Chief’s Sexist Emails

lead_paragraph: LONDON — The chief executive of England’s Premier League, Richard Scudamore, escaped dismissal Monday after a panel controlled by Britain’s top 20 professional soccer clubs ruled that “no further disciplinary action” was necessary in respect to emails he exchanged with others that were laced with coarse sexual innuendo about women.

headline: In California, Climate Issues Moved to Fore by Governor
abstract: Gov. Jerry Brown is at the forefront of state leaders who are grappling with ways to deal with climate change through legislation and infrastructure changes, rather than waiting for coordinated efforts from the federal government.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Portraying California as the front line of climate change, Gov. Jerry Brown said Monday that the effects of man-made global warming were devastating the state, drawing a direct link between climate change and both the record-setting drought that has left the state parched and the early-season wildfires that broke out across California last week. He declared that people must find a way “to live with nature, not collide with it.”

lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Citing a century-old law, the head of Thailand’s Army declared what he described as nationwide martial law early Tuesday and urged protesters who have paralyzed the government and blocked elections to “stop their movement.” The order also appeared to apply to pro-government demonstrators who are leading a separate protest.

headline: Disabled Boy Found Safe, Days After Leaving School

But Eliceo, a ninth-grader, never made it home on Friday because he vanished before boarding the yellow bus that usually takes him there.

abstract: GoPro is an unusual specimen for a Silicon Valley I.P.O., a hardware company without the flash of a social network or e-commerce start-up. The company said in the filing that it planned to raise up to $100 million in an initial public offering, a figure that could change later.
lead_paragraph: The action camera maker GoPro filed paperwork on Monday to sell shares to the public, offering clues about how it navigated the treacherous waters of the digital photography business.

headline: The Big Debate
keywords: ['Democracy (Theory and Philosophy)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Only by returning to its roots can American democracy prevail against the efficiency of new, booming autocracies.
lead_paragraph: It’s now clear that the end of the Soviet Union heralded an era of democratic complacency. Without a rival system to test them, democratic governments have decayed across the globe. In the U.S., Washington is polarized, stagnant and dysfunctional; a pathetic 26 percent of Americans trust their government to do the right thing. In Europe, elected officials have grown remote from voters, responding poorly to the euro crisis and contributing to massive unemployment.

headline: Economic Recovery Yields Few Benefits for the Voters Democrats Rely On
keywords: ['United States Economy', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'Voting and Voters', 'Unemployment', 'Blacks', 'Black People', 'Women and Girls']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Signs that a long-awaited economic recovery may finally be gaining steam should be welcome news for President Obama and his party as they try to stem losses in this year’s midterm elections. But rising payrolls, lower unemployment and a buoyed stock market, while lifting the fortunes of the rich, are leaving behind major Democratic constituencies, including young women and blacks, just as the party tries to motivate them to turn out to vote in November.

headline: Hibbert’s Turnaround Helps Stabilize the Erratic Pacers

headline: Savoring the Magic, One Run at a Time
abstract: At the post-Preakness news conference, California Chrome’s co-owner, trainer and jockey were buoyant, clearly having fun and enjoying their fairy-tale run.
lead_paragraph: In the Kentucky Derby and the Preakness, California Chrome dazzled on the racetrack. Afterward, though, his team stole the show. The fairy-tale run of his working-class owners, Steve and Carolyn Coburn and Perry and Denise Martin, has captured even the most casual fan’s attention. At 77, the trainer Art Sherman finally made it to the sport’s biggest stage. His 41-year-old jockey, Victor Espinoza, battled back from a slump to partake in his second Triple Crown run. Most important, they are all having fun. Following are excerpts from their post-Preakness news conference, where they were cracking jokes as if they were part of an improv show.

headline: The Netherlands: Heroin Seized

lead_paragraph: Nearly 1,700 pounds of heroin was smuggled into the Netherlands last week hidden in a shipment of Iranian raisins, Dutch police investigators said Monday. The heroin, valued at about $23 million, was seized by the investigators last Thursday after the raisin shipment had been transported from Rotterdam to Hagestein. Two men were arrested. Iran is a major transit point for heroin from Afghanistan. Iran also is believed to be the world’s third-largest exporter of raisins, behind Turkey and the United States.

Now it’s back for spring, thanks to ribbon belts, and utilitarian pockets and a Sahara-inspired color palette of dusty neutrals — all design elements adopted by the likes of Bottega Veneta, Alexander McQueen and Givenchy this season. Worn together in a tonal mix or simply paired with a white linen shirt, these neutral, rugged looks for the city set are investment pieces that won’t go out of style.

headline: Food Matters | An L.A. Chef’s Guide to Adventurous Backyard Cooking
abstract: To celebrate the release of his new cookbook, “Taming the Feast,” Ben Ford of Ford’s Filling Station offers T readers tips on pulling off the perfect barbecue.
lead_paragraph: “You’ve heard the term ‘food orgy,’ ” says Ben Ford. “I love the loss of inhibition when people get in a big group and enjoy a feast. That’s why I did this cookbook.” The chef and owner of Los Angeles’s Ford’s Filling Station gastro pub (and son of Harrison Ford) has authored “Taming the Feast” (Simon and Schuster, $34.99), a how-to guide for bringing “Game of Thrones”-size banquets to your own kitchen table, whether you’re serving a phalanx of friends or just a family of four. “The idea of working with whole animals, trying to close that proximity between the back door of my kitchen and the farmland, the book came out of that,” says Ford. Readers will have a difficult time finding another cookbook with both instructions for “rigging a pig for vertical roasting” and everyday backyard fare, like grilled beer-braised bratwurst or a simple safflower oil aioli. Alternative, more manageable recipes are offered for each feast — in case you, or your landlord, prefers that your paella come from a Weber or stovetop and not an inferno in the backyard. While such projects as sourcing cedar planks on which to roast sturgeon may sound complicated, for Ford the book is actually about getting back to basics; for instance, he teaches techniques like using one’s hands for testing not only the doneness of meat, but also the temperature level over a fire. Says Ford, “I’m very much a touch, feel, smell kind of chef.”

headline: Cannes Film Festival: The Dogs of ‘White God’

Directed by Kornel Mundruczo, 39, the movie is being presented in Un Certain Regard, a section of the Cannes Film Festival for work that tends to be more adventurous than that in the main competition. Such is the case with “White God,” which goes from melodrama to hallucination after the girl’s father throws the dog into the streets. As she searches for the male dog, Hagen, he takes up with other strays (including a scene-nipping Jack Russell), escapes from dog-pound baddies and ends up doped up with sharpened teeth in a fighting pit.

headline: An Old Flame Reignited
abstract: After a museum-quality restoration in the wake of Hurricane Sandy, the River Café is casting its romantic spell once more.
lead_paragraph: Back in the 1960s, when nobody except rats, longshoremen and gangsters needing to dispose of a wayward bookie saw much value in the Brooklyn waterfront, Michael O’Keeffe saw romance. He saw enough flowers for a year of proms, he saw a piano player massaging a Steinway, he saw a curtain of glass framing the Brooklyn Bridge and the lights of Fortress Manhattan on the other side. All of this he saw floating on a barge in the East River. After pleading for permits for 12 years, he persuaded City Hall to see it, too, and in 1977 the River Café dropped anchors.

lead_paragraph: For nearly his last five years as mayor of New York City, Michael Bloomberg and the United Federation of Teachers failed to agree on a contract for the city’s public schoolteachers. By the time Bill de Blasio took office as mayor in January, the teachers were demanding billions in retroactive pay increases for the years they didn’t have a contract and therefore didn’t get base pay increases.

headline: A Cross-Atlantic Collaboration Results in Striking, Sculptural Jewelry
abstract: The conceptual New York-based designer Mary Ping and the Paris-based jeweler of Pièce à Conviction have teamed up for a five-piece capsule collection.
lead_paragraph: The spare, witty jewelry of Pièce à Conviction is little-known in the United States, but the New York-based designer Mary Ping has been collecting it for a decade, ever since she first discovered the ahead-of-its-time “floating”-style rings in a shop in Paris. “I don’t remember the name of the store,” says Ping, who designs Slow and Steady Wins the Race as well as a namesake line. “Which is a testament to how struck by the rings I was, because I remember everything.” After years spent wearing the jewelry daily in her Manhattan studio — and getting asked about it “all the time” — Ping worked up the courage to approach the line’s designer, Ghislain Ryckebusch, about collaborating. Ryckebusch invited her to his home and studio in Fontainebleau to work together, and the striking, sculptural results — a five-piece capsule collection including rings, bracelets and a necklace — will debut Thursday evening at Creatures of Comfort in New York, with more designs to follow in future seasons. “These really are pieces that hum and breathe. There is a rhythm, a balance,” Ping says. “They are unique punctuation marks.”

headline: Do Not Resuscitate: What Young Doctors Would Choose

lead_paragraph: The researcher was presenting her findings to a room full of geriatricians, at the American Geriatrics Society annual scientific meeting last week in Orlando, Fla. So a slide revealing one particular statistic didn’t cause an audible gasp or murmur. Talking to geriatricians about end-of-life treatment practically defines preaching to the choir, as a member of the audience told me later.

headline: Florida State Holds Hearing Connected to Jameis Winston Allegations
abstract: Jameis Winston, the Heisman Trophy winner who has been accused of rape by a former student, did not attend the hearing, which focused on two of his teammates who witnessed part of the sexual encounter.
lead_paragraph: Nearly a year and a half after a student at Florida State accused the future Heisman Trophy winner Jameis Winston of rape, the university on Tuesday held its first student disciplinary hearing in connection with the matter.

headline: Not Enough Room at the Democratic Cash Trough

lead_paragraph: Organizing for Action, the ill-conceived support group for the Obama administration, is finally scaling back its fundraising efforts, and promising to move to the political sidelines.

headline: Bound for the World Cup? Tips to Save You Money
abstract: From packing to tipping, booking flights to buying beverages, here’s some budget-friendly advice for those going to Brazil for the giant soccer tournament that kicks off next month.
lead_paragraph: The monthlong, 32-country soccer tournament known as the World Cup kicks off on June 12 in Brazil. And guess where the most tickets have been sold, outside of Brazil that is? Defying all logic, it’s the United States, the only country in the world you have to start an article about the World Cup by explaining what it is, when it starts and where it’s being played.

headline: Soccer as Spectacle in the Pacific Northwest
abstract: Can’t make it to the World Cup this summer? A soccer trip to Vancouver, Seattle or Portland could be a fine substitute.
lead_paragraph: The last thing I remember clearly, sometime around 4 a.m., was wondering how many people had fallen down the vertiginous back-hallway stairs that are the only way in or out of the Railway Club, the oldest continuously operating bar in Vancouver, British Columbia, a drinking and former gambling establishment that has seen its share of idiots and drunkards since it opened in 1931.

headline: Obama’s Indecision Points
abstract: Toward a unified theory of this White House’s foreign policy struggles.
lead_paragraph: I wrote my Sunday column on President Obama’s foreign policy, which seems to be failing to achieve its objectives just about everywhere one might reasonably look. (And the column went to press before the latest turn of events in post-Qaddafi Libya, the latest sour news on the Iranian nuclear talks, and the acknowledgment from administration officials that actually, in its latest incarnations, al Qaeda may not actually be on “the path to defeat” after all.) In limning these failures, however, I diagnosed without prescribing: I’m not sure I have a grand unified theory of what’s going wrong  — “events, dear boy, events” probably doesn’t count — so it’s hard to offer a clear account of everything the president should be doing differently.

No one was there to talk shop. Instead, they had come to an exclusive dinner to celebrate the beginning of the Collector’s Committee weekend to benefit the Los Angeles County Museum of Art. The annual fundraising event brings together heavy-hitter donors (who pay a minimum of $15,000 to $60,000 for the privilege of attending) to hobnob and help the museum acquire new works.

headline: Mutual Admiration, Across the Sea, Across the Years
abstract: Lorde and Conor Oberst, singer-songwriters who know and respect each other’s work, speak to each other for the first time and compare notes on how they approach their music.
lead_paragraph: Ella Yelich-O’Connor, better known as Lorde, the New Zealand-born teenage pop star, and Conor Oberst, the solo artist and frontman for Bright Eyes, are separated by 17 years and several continents. But in many ways they cover the same ground as confessional singer-songwriters. Mr. Oberst, now 34, started young, too, releasing an album on tape at 13 in his native Omaha, and earning accolades as a musical prodigy before he graduated from high school. His latest solo record, “Upside Down Mountain,” was released on Tuesday. For a time, Lorde had a quotation from him in her Twitter bio: “No, I am not singing for you.” “It’s my mantra in life,” she said.

headline: 2 Explosions Kill Scores at Central Nigeria Market
abstract: The blasts in the city of Jos detonated within minutes of each other, leaving at least 58 people dead, and the second explosion might have been timed to kill rescuers.

abstract: Privacy is over. Local is over. Average is over. Later is over.

And those words are “privacy,” “local,” “average” and “later.” A lot of what drives today’s news derives from the fact that privacy is over, local is over, average is over and later is over.

headline: New York Fed President Sees Inflation Drifting Up
abstract: Speaking at an event in New York, William Dudley said the trajectory of economic growth continues to disappoint.
lead_paragraph: William Dudley, the president of the New York Federal Reserve, said on Tuesday he expected inflation to drift higher over the remainder of the year, though “excess capacity” in the economy is helping to moderate price pressures. Mr. Dudley’s remarks come as the Fed grapples with several major issues, including when to raise interest rates, and when to start scaling back its more than $4 trillion balance sheet.

headline: Pay Up or Go to Jail

abstract: It is unjust to dump administrative fees on people caught up in the criminal justice system, often some of the poorest in society.

For people with the ability to pay, they are an irritation. But such fees are increasingly being levied on people caught up in the criminal justice system, who are overwhelmingly among the poorest members of society.

headline: For Third Time in 4 Years, Cavs Win Lottery

They all had a crack at the grand prize: the opportunity to select a player like Duke’s Jabari Parker or Kansas’ Andrew Wiggins, elite prospects who are expected to be among the top picks when the draft is held at Barclays Center on June 26.

abstract: The collision between a freight train collided and a passenger train near Moscow on Tuesday also injured 25.

Russian officials said the crash occurred near the town of Naro-Fominsk, southwest of Moscow, when the train carrying about 400 passengers was on its way to Chisinau, Moldova. Russian television said the Moscow-bound freight train was operated by an unidentified Ukrainian company. The poor state of the tracks or the freight train is considered a possible cause of the crash, investigators said.

headline: Iran: More Than One Million Said to Defy Alcohol Ban
abstract: A study showed that 30 percent of the drinkers are women, despite an officially enforced Islamic prohibition on alcoholic beverages, a medical toxicologist said Tuesday.
lead_paragraph: Despite an officially enforced Islamic prohibition on alcoholic beverages, more than one million Iranians are drinkers, a medical toxicologist said Tuesday. The toxicologist, Dr. Reza Afshari, president of the Asia Pacific Association of Medical Toxicology, was quoted by the Iranian Students’ News Agency as saying the finding was based on a yearlong study that ended in March 2013. It also showed that 30 percent of the drinkers are women. Dr. Afshari spoke at what the news agency called the first conference on alcohol abuse in Iran, a reflection of the government’s acknowledgment of the problem. Alcohol consumption, possession and production have been illegal since the 1979 Islamic Revolution, but smuggled and homemade liquor is said to be widely available. Government officials have said at least 200,000 Iranians are alcoholics.

headline: Winning the Cup, and Starting to Win Over Critics

headline: As an Enigmatic Tension Mounts
abstract: The choreographer Liz Santoro draws on her neuroscience background as she stimulates many parts of the mind.
lead_paragraph: It’s been two years since Liz Santoro presented “We Do Our Best” at St. Mark’s Church, and still, sounds and images from that spartan trio linger in the mind: the repetitive, echoey click of high heels on a wooden floor; an interminable drone that enveloped everyone in the room, locking us into one tense, protracted moment. There was a peculiar placelessness to this world, only intensified by the exacting placement of everything within it.

headline: Massachusetts: 3-Year Sentence for Theft From Marathon Fund

State prosecutors said Audrea Gause, 27, had falsely claimed that she sustained a brain injury in the blasts and collected $480,000 from the fund. On Tuesday, Ms. Gause pleaded guilty to one count of larceny over $250 in Suffolk Superior Court; Judge Carol Ball signed an order to return the money, which has been recovered, to the fund.

headline: What’s on Wednesday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (MSG) RAGING BULL (1980) Robert De Niro, above, packed on nearly 60 pounds for his Oscar-winning portrayal of Jake LaMotta, the New York City boxer who pummeled his way to the world middleweight championship in 1948 before self-destructing, in this drama directed by Martin Scorsese. Joe Pesci plays Jake’s brother and manager, Joey, who tries to help him battle his demons; Cathy Moriarty is Vickie, Jake’s second wife, who fuels his sexual rage. “Though it’s a movie full of anger and nonstop physical violence, the effect of ‘Raging Bull’ is lyrical,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. “To witness Jake’s fury is to swing through the upper atmosphere of the emotions. headline: Thane of Cawdor Plays the Armory
abstract: It’s hard to believe that Kenneth Branagh is only now making his acting debut on a New York stage, in “Macbeth” at the Park Avenue Armory.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to believe that Kenneth Branagh is only now making his acting debut on a New York stage. Then again, much about Mr. Branagh’s career is difficult to process. He wrote a memoir at the age of 28 (called, to be fair, “Beginning”), and he directed a very silly comedy on Broadway (“The Play What I Wrote”) inspired by the double act Morecambe and Wise. Perhaps the strangest shift is that Mr. Branagh, the wunderkind once considered Laurence Olivier’s heir, is now directing Hollywood action movies (“Thor”). His is a complex, playful career that dabbles in many forms but always returns to what made him famous: Shakespeare. So it’s no surprise that his first starring role here is as Macbeth, in a critically acclaimed production from England, which he directed with Rob Ashford. Ben Brantley of The New York Times called it “utterly assured and intelligent.” “Macbeth” begins performances May 31 in the Park Avenue Armory’s enormous Drill Hall. (Through June 22. 643 Park Avenue, at 67th Street; 212-616-3930, armoryonpark.org.)

abstract: The release of 21 of the idiosyncratic jazz pianist and composer’s albums mark the centenary of his birth.
lead_paragraph: Sun Ra, the idiosyncratic jazz pianist and composer, used to say that he did not believe in birth or death, and he was able to keep his date of birth – May 22, 1914 – a secret until shortly before his death in 1993. So presumably, he would look askance at celebrations of his centenary. For admirers of his often theatrical, sometimes experimental music who want to mark the occasion, however, the Sun Ra Music Archive on Tuesday released 21 of the musician’s albums on iTunes, many of them in digital form for the first time (and others remastered).

headline: Reactions to Mubarak Sentencing
abstract: Not all residents agree with the Egyptian court ruling that sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to three years on charges of stealing public funds.
lead_paragraph: Not all residents agree with the Egyptian court ruling that sentenced former President Hosni Mubarak to three years on charges of stealing public funds.

abstract: Janet L. Yellen, chairwoman of the Federal Reserve, told the graduates that her predecessor, Ben Bernanke, did not let setbacks during the financial crisis deter his effort to revive the economy.
lead_paragraph: Janet L. Yellen has long occupied a front-row seat as Washington grappled with the financial crisis and the weak economy that has plagued the nation. Standing over second base at Yankee Stadium, where she delivered a commencement speech on Wednesday, Ms. Yellen suggested that playing the game is a lot harder than it looks from the stands.

headline: Painless Shipping In a Few Easy Steps
abstract: To ship through Shyp, you first download the firm’s iPhone app and enter in your payment data.
lead_paragraph: PACKAGING and shipping an item isn’t the worst task in the world, but it isn’t exactly fun, either. Say you’re sending a gift to your grandmother. First, you have to find a box. Then you need tape, one of those household items that is almost never where you thought you’d put it. You might also need to weigh and measure the box, and research which shipper fits your budget and delivery preferences. Then you either have to go to the web to order a shipping label or hurry over to the post office to wait in line.

headline: Q. and A.: Conor Oberst and Lorde Find Common Ground
abstract: Excerpts from a conversation with the two singer-songwriters.
lead_paragraph: Growing up in the suburbs of Omaha turns out not to have been much different than growing up in the suburbs of Auckland, at least to hear Conor Oberst, a Nebraskan, and Lorde, a New Zealander, tell it: both had to make their own fun. The two musicians and mutual fans bonded over their similarly forthright lyrical styles, in a conversation on Monday. They also shared a love for the debut albums of the British acts the Arctic Monkeys and the Streets, a certain distaste for social media (although Lorde, born Ella Yelich-O’Connor, has more than 1.6 million Twitter followers), and discussed the high and low points of touring. Here are more excerpts from their conversation.

headline: Statement Socks in Brooklyn
abstract: Meet Madison Krekel wearing a bolo tie she bought at a flea market, socks with sushi printed on them and a Cramps T-shirt.
lead_paragraph: Getting off at the Morgan Avenue stop on the L train in Brooklyn is like stepping into a vintage version of New York City. The area is home to fledgling artists, industrial-looking buildings dripping in street art and the sounds of musicians practicing from nearby studios. Madison Krekel blends in easily wearing a bolo tie she bought at a flea market, socks with sushi printed on them and a Cramps T-shirt. Originally from Oakland, Calif., she moved to the area four years ago and recently dyed her hair green as a way to welcome spring. This interview has been edited.

headline: Candidates Ace Geography in Their Ads

headline: Delightful Difference
abstract: Two new picture books explore the amusing idea of animals having the kind of free will humans enjoy.
lead_paragraph: “When is a moose not a moose?" could be the first line of an elementary-school joke. In Richard T. Morris’s “This Is a Moose,” illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld, a moose is not a moose when he wants to be an astronaut. And in “Froodle,” written and illustrated by Antoinette Portis, a little brown bird causes revolution — or is it evolution? — among her avian friends when she decides to say something other than “Peep!” Both books explore the amusing idea of animals having the kind of free will humans enjoy. By playing up the contrast between people and wildlife, Morris and Portis subtly encourage children to make their own choices, even when told they can’t.

headline: Loudon Wainwright to Join Father in ‘Posthumous Collaboration’ for Stage Show
abstract: For a one-man show in Manhattan, Loudon Wainwright III will draw on the writings of his father, a magazine columnist who died in 1988.
lead_paragraph: Loudon Wainwright III has always been a first-class storyteller, but in the 44 years since his eponymous debut album, his métier has mostly been the four-minute, folk-tinged pop song. Now he is broadening his canvas. In “Surviving Twin,” an 80-minute one-man show that opens at the Westside Theater in Manhattan on June 9, Mr. Wainwright will sing favorites from his catalog, as well as several new songs that he plans to include on his next album, “Haven’t Got the Blues (Yet),” due in September.

headline: 9/11 Museum Opens to a Somber Crowd
abstract: After the National September 11 Memorial Museum opened to the general public on Wednesday, visitors described it as “overwhelming” and “gut-wrenching.”
lead_paragraph: Alone or in groups they emerged from the dark exhibition halls and the even darker subject matter of the National September 11 Memorial Museum, reaching for words like “overwhelming,” “shock” and “gut-wrenching.”

headline: Study Sees Bigger Role for Placenta in Newborns’ Health
abstract: Placental bacteria may affect the timing of births and the makeup of an infant’s gut, researchers say, including that of babies born by cesarean.
lead_paragraph: The placenta, once thought sterile, actually harbors a world of bacteria that may influence the course of pregnancy and help shape an infant’s health and the bacterial makeup of its gut, a new study has found.

headline: 36 Hours in Montevideo, Uruguay
abstract: During a weekend in the capital city, sample everything from meat to music to museums.
lead_paragraph: Uruguay has made a splash in the news in recent months: Lawmakers allowed same-sex couples to marry less than a year ago, marijuana became legal in December and the country’s folksy president, José Mujica, has appeared in many magazine profiles. While some developments can be seen as a continuation of the country’s track record of economic and social liberalism, they also point to a new, bolder attitude, which can be easily glimpsed in Montevideo, the capital. New hotels, cultural spaces, restaurants and a residential building boom have quickened the city’s tranquil pace. Still, the appeal of Montevideo lies not in novelty but in its timeless backdrop of fin-de-siècle architecture, shady plazas and riverside promenades bordered by sandy beaches — places where laid-back residents indulge in life’s simple pleasures.

headline: The Collaboration as Wrestling Match: Is It a Draw, or Must Someone Prevail?
abstract: The French dancers Cédric Andrieux and Christophe Ives presented the American premiere of “Les Communs,” an exploration of their long friendship, on Friday.
lead_paragraph: The French dancers Cédric Andrieux and Christophe Ives met each other in the 1990s, when they were both studying at the national conservatory in Paris. I don’t know how chummy they were back then, but a few years ago, they decided to make a duet embodying their relationship and their process of collaboration. That duet, “Les Communs,” does not look like a reunion of old drinking buddies or an expression of fraternité. It looks rivalrous, like a wrestling match.

headline: Against Walter Kasper (I)
keywords: ['Christians and Christianity', 'Divorce, Separations and Annulments', 'Marriages', 'Religion and Belief', 'Weddings and Engagements']
abstract: Thoughts on the proposition that 50 percent of Catholic marriages are invalid.
lead_paragraph: I’ve referred a couple of times to Cardinal Walter Kasper’s very interesting interview with Commonweal Magazine, in which the prelate/theologian discussed the proposals on communion for remarried Catholics that (apparently with a papal blessing) he’s been promoting in advance of the looming Synod of Bishops, which is dedicated to family life and scheduled for this fall. This is going to be the first of two posts on his argument; the second — which won’t be forthcoming till next week at the earliest, I expect — will deal with the communion-for-the-remarried proposal itself, but first I want to address the frame he puts around his ideas, and particular his claim that a truly remarkable number of contemporary marriages may actually be, in the eyes of the Catholic Church, invalid.

As we noted in an editorial last month, the cynically named Transparent Airfares Act of 2014 would allow airlines to advertise base fares that do not include taxes and fees. lead_paragraph: “Who needs more things? I think that we all want more experiences,” says David van der Leer, the director of the Van Alen Institute, the public architecture think tank, which hosts its gala benefit tonight. The accompanying online auction, which accepts bids through the end of the week on Paddle 8, features offerings that will occupy space in your memory (and Instagram feed), rather than your home: winning bidders will have the chance to take journeys with 30 noteworthy figures in the architecture and design world.

headline: Browsing in Boutiques Near Venice’s Grand Canal
abstract: The Cannaregio area is filled with a diverse range of local shops.
lead_paragraph: When it comes to shopping, travelers to Venice tend to stick to the big-brand Italian chain stores near touristy San Marco Square, but the city’s homegrown boutique scene warrants far more attention than it gets. The Cannaregio area, for example, is filled with a diverse range of local shops along narrow alleys and in small piazzas. Situated off the Grand Canal and a 10-minute walk from the Rialto Bridge, this is a residential enclave where middle- and upper-class families have lived for generations and to which Venetians regularly flock for retail excursions.

headline: Exploring Cafes and Culture in Downtown Newark
abstract: Over the past six years, a number of cafes and art collectives have opened along Halsey Street, giving the city a denser downtown culture district.
lead_paragraph: The ceramic fire-breathing dragons in the window of Gifts East West, a curio shop owned by Ing and John Watts, have seen neighbors come and go during their 40-year tenure at 57 Halsey Street in Newark. Today the dragons look out to an empty lot and a mural painted on a wall of a shuttered department store, Hahne & Company, which last saw customers in the late 1980s. In two years the building will house a Whole Foods Market, with mixed-income rental apartments stacked above it. Another construction site across the street is for the Prudential Tower, which will give the financial services giant a new home next year, with room for retail as well.

lead_paragraph: Over the last two decades, Ron Suskind has been known as a hard-hitting, Pulitzer Prize-winning political reporter, a thorn in the side of the Bush administration, a chronicler of the Obama White House. In private, though, Mr. Suskind was Iago the parrot, Baloo the bear, Merlin the wizard: Disney characters whose dialogue, songs and even “wisdom” he borrowed to communicate with his autistic son, Owen.

headline: His Peers’ Views Are in the Details
abstract: Much of the literary world (not all, but a lot) is enthralled by the Norwegian writer Karl Ove Knausgaard and his multipart novelistic memoir of minutiae, titled “My Struggle.”
lead_paragraph: Karl Ove Knausgaard, a handsome, rangy, brooding Norwegian author (and father of four young children) has held much of the literary establishment in thrall ever since his 3,600-page, six-part autobiographical novel, “My Struggle,” started appearing in English in 2012. Direct and unguarded in tone, the books combine a micro-focus on the granular detail of daily life (child care, groceries, quarrels with friends) with earnest meditations on art, death, music and ambition. The novelist Jeffrey Eugenides, calling these two elements “auto-fiction” and “rumination,” said that blending them in the way Mr. Knausgaard does is something “nobody’s done before.”

headline: Worries Turn to Disease as Waters Recede in Balkans
abstract: Contaminated water has covered homes, towns and fields, leading to fears of intestinal ailments, respiratory infections, skin diseases, hepatitis and perhaps worse.
lead_paragraph: OBRENOVAC, Serbia — For five days, as rain pelted the Balkans and the waters rose, Jovanka Sreckovic, 85, waited in bed in her tiny house, barely a hut, beside the Sava River. Ms. Sreckovic, unable to walk, had no food, no water, no medicine and no electricity, and felt herself sinking into sickness with nothing but a children’s book about Jesus to pass the time.

headline: Deceit, Madness and Love, Imported Directly From Russia
abstract: This week, the Bolshoi plays the Kennedy Center Opera House in Washington for a week of “Giselle,” with staging by Yuri Grigorovich.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Is it better to see the Bolshoi Ballet at home or abroad? For decorative splendor, few opera houses can compare with the rebuilt Bolshoi Theater in Moscow — which I visited recently — and fewer with the immensity of its stage. Yet too many performances in Moscow and St. Petersburg are ruined by the partisan clamor of balletomanes and claques who overapplaud individual sections (sometimes individual steps) of each work, turning ballet into a competitive sport.

headline: In Paris, A Sexy New Swimming Hotel Is Making Waves
abstract: The just-opened Molitor is a five-star renovation of a legendary Art Deco public pool in the 16th Arondissement.
lead_paragraph: The just-opened Molitor hotel is making a splash (quite literally) in Paris this season. Even in its new incarnation as a nautically themed 124-room luxury hotel, the site of the mythic Piscine Molitor — a vintage Art Deco public swimming pool — hasn’t entirely lost the aura of erotic possibility that made it beloved, in a tongue-in-cheek sort of way, by generations of Parisians. The three-story cement complex with sleek ocean-liner-like architecture and two pools — one indoor and heated, one outdoor — was originally designed by the architect Lucien Pollet and inaugurated in 1929 in the heart of the silk-stocking 16th Arrondissement, Paris’s Upper East Side, by the American Olympic gold medalists Aileen Wiggin and Johnny Weissmuller — who spent a summer here working as a lifeguard and giving swimming lessons before he went on to win the role of Tarzan in the film of the same name a few years later.

headline: The Parisian Life Beckons, Waiting to Become Unforgettable
abstract: “Gaîté Parisienne,” a ballet set in 19th-century Paris, returned to the Metropolitan Opera House for the first time since 1999.
lead_paragraph: In 1988, when American Ballet Theater debuted a new production of Leonide Massine’s “Gaîté Parisienne,” one of the most popular ballets of the 1940s and ’50s, some people were shocked by the cartoonish sets by Zack Brown and the clashing colors in the costumes by Christian Lacroix. But the designers had the right idea. If a modern production of this comical character ballet is not to become a quaint evocation of mid-19th-century French cafe culture, it must not be afraid of being vulgar.

headline: For Cannes’s Man on the Red Carpet, a Fade-Out

lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — Each year, as stars ascend the red-carpeted steps here, a reserved gentleman in a bespoke Agnès B tuxedo is there to receive them. He is Gilles Jacob, and after more than 35 years at the Cannes Film Festival, the last 15 as president, he is alighting from those steps and retiring.

headline: Art School Creates a New Reality
abstract: The New York Academy of Art, long an organizational mess, torn by internal dissent, has been slowly digging its reputation out of the ditch.
lead_paragraph: Andy Warhol, who knocked painting off its pedestal by introducing it to mass production, is not the first person who might spring to mind as a defender of art’s academic traditions, particularly fusty-sounding ones like cast drawing and anatomical study. But he was a classically trained draftsman. And in the late 1970s, he helped found what became the New York Academy of Art, a bastion of figurative training that was swimming decidedly against the current, even at a time when Neo-Expressionism had brought painting the human form back into vogue.

Opened in January by a longtime Astoria resident, Nick Lion, Icon occupies a former Greek bar that has been given a makeover, with Swarovski-bedazzled lamps, studded black banquettes and swirly wall accents. One thing missing are big TV screens. “I don’t want a Britney Spears video to be the star,” he said. “I want the crowd to be the main attraction.”

headline: In the Houses Where He Lived
abstract: A show on Cecil Beaton’s country estates opens at the Salisbury Museum in England.
lead_paragraph: From the 1930s until his death in 1980, Cecil Beaton was a pivotal figure in design and fashion, thanks to his photography for Vogue and sets and costumes for “My Fair Lady.” There have been many exhibitions about his work, but none about how he lived. This will change Friday when “Cecil Beaton at Home” opens at the Salisbury Museum in England’s Wiltshire district. The exhibition will be on view through Sept. 19. For Beaton, two homes counted: his Wiltshire country estates Ashcombe, where he lived from 1930 to 1945, and Reddish, which he occupied from 1947 until his death. (The 1950s magazine ad, right, was photographed there.) The show’s curator, Andrew Ginger, has recreated parts of two rooms from those houses, installing Beaton’s Circus Bed, complete with unicorns, sea horses and barley-twist posts. Information: salisburymuseum.org.uk. For a total Beaton immersion, head down the road to “Cecil Beaton at Wilton,” a show of his photos from the 1930s, which runs through Sept. 14. Information: tourism@wiltonhouse.com.

headline: Because Buildings Need Seats
abstract: William Pedersen, a founder of the architectural firm Kohn Pedersen Fox, takes on the ultimate challenge.
lead_paragraph: William Pedersen, 76, a founder of the architecture firm Kohn Pedersen Fox, has designed some of the world’s most notable skyscrapers, including the cluster of leaning towers under construction at Hudson Yards. Even so, he staffed his own booth at the recent International Contemporary Furniture Fair, presenting his new group of carbon-steel chairs that curve through space like line drawings. In what may look to the observer like a counterintuitive career move, Mr. Pedersen, after 50 years of designing buildings, is diversifying by taking on furniture. The line, called Loop de Loop after the stunts performed by small aircraft, includes a side chair, dining chair, chaise and lounge chair with ottoman. Eventually there will be a rocker. With their knit polyester mesh, they are for outdoor or indoor use. (This interview was edited and condensed.)

headline: The Civil War and P.T.S.D.
abstract: The psychological devastation of the Civil War was much more widespread than we think.
lead_paragraph: Edson Bemis was a hard man to kill. Rebel soldiers tried three times, and three times they failed. At the Battle of Antietam, a musket ball ripped through his left arm. Two years later, in the horrible fighting in the Wilderness, he was shot in the abdomen, just above the groin. The ball was never extracted, remaining in his body until the day he died.

headline: Depressed, but Not Ashamed
abstract: Teenagers should be able to talk openly about mental health.
lead_paragraph: ANN ARBOR, Mich. — MOST of our closest friends didn’t know that we struggled with depression. It just wasn’t something we discussed with our high school classmates. We found that we both had taken Prozac only when one of us caught a glimpse of a prescription bottle in a suitcase during a journalism conference last November. For the first time, we openly discussed our feelings and our use of antidepressants with someone who could relate. We took a risk sharing our experiences with depression, but in our honesty, we found a support system. We knew we had to take the idea further.

headline: Ageless Veterans Are Still Giving Spurs Extra Kick

Journalists, including the legendary U Win Tin, who passed away last month and who was jailed for more than 19 years by the military junta, began working freely again. lead_paragraph: For the Health Issue this week, Julia Scott tested the claim by AOBiome that a living bacterial skin tonic composed of billions of cultivated Nitrosomonas eutropha, an ammonia-oxidizing bacteria, would make her skin feel cleaner and more hydrated. Part of her experiment included these headshots she took of herself. Scott recently talked about what it was really like not to shower with soap products for a month.

lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — Taliban insurgents captured 27 of 40 police officers and officials who had taken refuge in a bunker, the government and the insurgents said on Thursday, as the Taliban continued to besiege a district government complex in a remote corner of northern Afghanistan that until last year had been considered one of the safest parts of the country.

headline: Violence and Doubts About Credibility as a Troubled Ukraine Election Nears
abstract: An attack on a Ukrainian military checkpoint that left at least 16 soldiers dead complicates a presidential vote Sunday, when few polling centers are expected to be open.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — When two armed men on Thursday afternoon barged into the small yellow schoolroom that has served as Inna Mashenskaya’s makeshift election office, she stood up straight and began to argue. But when one of them, wearing sunglasses, patted the knife that was hanging from his belt, she stopped talking and surrendered control of her polling center.

headline: My No-Soap, No-Shampoo, Bacteria-Rich Hygiene Experiment
abstract: What happens when you leave cleanliness up to your microbiome?
lead_paragraph: For most of my life, if I’ve thought at all about the bacteria living on my skin, it has been while trying to scrub them away. But recently I spent four weeks rubbing them in. I was Subject 26 in testing a living bacterial skin tonic, developed by AOBiome, a biotech start-up in Cambridge, Mass. The tonic looks, feels and tastes like water, but each spray bottle of AO+ Refreshing Cosmetic Mist contains billions of cultivated Nitrosomonas eutropha, an ammonia-oxidizing bacteria (AOB) that is most commonly found in dirt and untreated water. AOBiome scientists hypothesize that it once lived happily on us too — before we started washing it away with soap and shampoo — acting as a built-in cleanser, deodorant, anti-inflammatory and immune booster by feeding on the ammonia in our sweat and converting it into nitrite and nitric oxide.

headline: A Revolutionary Approach to Treating PTSD
keywords: ['Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Anxiety and Stress', 'Memory']
abstract: Bessel van der Kolk wants to change the way we heal a traumatized mind — by starting with the body.
lead_paragraph: Bessel van der Kolk sat cross-legged on an oversize pillow in the center of a smallish room overlooking the Pacific Ocean in Big Sur. He wore khaki pants, a blue fleece zip-up and square wire-rimmed glasses. His feet were bare. It was the third day of his workshop, “Trauma­ Memory and Recovery of the Self,” and 30 or so workshop participants — all of them trauma victims or trauma therapists — lined the room’s perimeter. They, too, sat barefoot on cushy pillows, eyeing van der Kolk, notebooks in hand. For two days, they had listened to his lectures on the social history, neurobiology and clinical realities of post-traumatic stress disorder and its lesser-known sibling, complex trauma. Now, finally, he was about to demonstrate an actual therapeutic technique, and his gaze was fixed on the subject of his experiment: a 36-year-old Iraq war veteran named Eugene, who sat directly across from van der Kolk, looking mournful and expectant.

Shares in JD.com will begin trading on the Nasdaq stock exchange on Thursday under the symbol JD.

abstract: Although Obama’s critics often measure him unfavorably against Johnson, it’s important to recognize how much has changed since 1964.

headline: All the Rage | Four Design Trends of the Moment, on View at Last Weekend’s International Contemporary Furniture Fair
keywords: ['Ceramics and Pottery', 'Conventions, Fairs and Trade Shows', 'Design', 'Lighting', 'Tables']
abstract: The annual design trade show in New York revealed a few noteworthy trends, including a new wave of midcentury revivalism, warm materials, simple geometries and smart lighting treatments.
lead_paragraph: Design insiders often take a jaundiced view of New York’s International Contemporary Furniture Fair, the less glamorous cousin to the Salone del Mobile in Milan, which took over the Javits Center last weekend, with satellite operations around the city. But while it may be true that there is nothing new under the sun, a survey of items on view revealed four compelling trends worth noting, including a renewed interest in midcentury modern design; an emphasis on materials with warmth and character like copper, brass and marble; the bold use of basic geometric forms; and lighting that explored the limits and possibilities of new technology.

headline: Raging Amid Tears in a Gathering Storm
abstract: HBO’s version of Larry Kramer’s play “The Normal Heart” has shortcomings, but it benefits from what film can do for a story written for the stage.
lead_paragraph: “The Normal Heart,” Larry Kramer’s impassioned j’accuse about the early years of the AIDS crisis, is an entirely different thing from what it was when first staged as a play at the Public Theater in 1985. Back then, it was, above all, a political statement about continuing indifference toward the gathering storm of AIDS; those strident speeches that the central character, Ned Weeks, delivered onstage could just as appropriately have been shouted on the sidewalks outside City Hall or the White House.

headline: To Greeks, the Parliamentary Vote in Europe Is a Test of Their Own Direction
abstract: As Greece returns to the polls for European parliamentary elections, the vote has become a test of whether citizens believe the government’s assertion that the country is on the upswing.
lead_paragraph: ATHENS — This time, there are no predictions of doom, no anguished fretting out of Washington or Berlin that Greek national elections could unravel the European economic order. That was the mood in 2012, when the fate of the euro seemed to hang on the whims of an angry Greek electorate that, in the end, voted to stay the course in the euro zone.

headline: Detroit’s Police Chief Stands His Ground
abstract: What, precisely, did James Craig have in mind when he spoke favorably of citizens arming themselves as an extra protection against violence?
lead_paragraph: What, precisely, did Detroit police chief James Craig have in mind when he spoke favorably of citizens arming themselves as an extra protection against violence in his battered city? The chief wound up on the cover of a National Rifle Association magazine this month after he stressed his pro-gun position, telling America’s 1st Freedom: that he was celebrating the rise of “good Americans, good Detroiters” carrying firearms because they were “fed up with being victims.”

headline: Poetry Pairing | ‘Letter to Brooks: Spring Garden’

headline: JD.com Has Rousing Start in Trading Debut

lead_paragraph: Updated, 4:04 p.m. | The online Chinese retailer JD.com started life as a publicly traded company with a rousing start, closing up 10 percent on the Nasdaq on Thursday. At that price, shareholders valued the company at more than $28.6 billion, more than other American technology names like Twitter and LinkedIn.

headline: A Big Pile of Fantastic Ideas to Get Kids Outside Making and Doing This Summer
abstract: A different kind of summer reading: books and project links to inspire children to head outside and make, do and create.
lead_paragraph: It’s May, time for teachers to revisit their bookshelves and think about summer reading selections. This year, I’m considering a different kind of summer reading for my kids, books that will inspire them to head outside and make, do and create. My younger son, Finn, likes these sorts of projects, and while I can provide him with scrap lumber, nails, a drill and some screws, he and I wanted to find some additional inspiration.

lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Wayne Gretzky appeared on a national radio show Wednesday afternoon, and the subject of the conversation was dynasties. Gretzky, of course, knows a thing or two about the topic, having won four Stanley Cups in five years with the Edmonton Oilers during the 1980s. He said if the Chicago Blackhawks won another title this year — it would be their third in five years — they could qualify for the exclusive club.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In a rare moment of bipartisan agreement between the White House and Congress on a major national security issue, the House passed legislation on Thursday that aims to end the National Security Agency’s bulk phone records program that had prompted intense domestic debate about privacy and civil liberties.

headline: Pastiche, Parody, Homage and Theft

Songs from Jeanine Tesori’s “Violet,” starring the amazing Sutton Foster, like the jaunty “Surprised,” owe an obvious debt to country and gospel.

headline: A Critic Picks Songs of the Broadway Season

lead_paragraph: As someone who thinks a lot about the musical component of musical theater, I wrote an Arts & Leisure piece offering my impressions of some scores from recent shows in New York. I was particularly interested in the technique of pastiche, in which composers, and lyricists, too, evoke older song styles and genres in their new scores.

headline: Door by Door, India Strives to Know More About Death

The only person present was his wife, Sushilamma, 48, who spent the day of his death trying to get him admitted to a government hospital where he could be treated for abdominal pain.

headline: The Thai Army Repeats History
abstract: Military rule is not the answer to the country’s problems.

headline: Yelp Reviews Help Track Food Illnesses

headline: Even Fruit Flies Need a Moment to Think It Over

headline: A Theory on How Flightless Birds Spread Across the World: They Flew There
abstract: DNA analysis in a new study suggests that the common ancestor of ratites continued to fly even after the supercontinent Gondwana split into pieces.
lead_paragraph: Just a few centuries ago, Madagascar was home to a monstrous creature called the elephant bird. It towered as high as nine feet. Weighing as much as 600 pounds, it was the heaviest bird known to science. You’d need 160 chicken eggs to equal the volume of a single elephant bird egg.

headline: Totokaelo’s Jill Wenger on Seattle’s Best Culture
abstract: The founder of the agenda-setting Pacific Northwest boutique shares her favorite spots in her home city.
lead_paragraph: The fashion and design emporium Totokaelo — pronounced Toh-toh-KYE-oh — may be the most innovative boutique in Seattle, but it’s more than just a local institution. The store’s founder, Jill Wenger, has discovered and championed some of the most influential independent designers anywhere, while her elegant e-commerce site is a shopping resource bookmarked by stylish men and women around the world.

headline: There’s No Such Thing as a Free Tax Cut
abstract: A Republican proposal fails to solve a basic math problem: Cutting taxes for someone means raising them for someone else, or raising the deficit.
lead_paragraph: It’s a recurring problem for conservatives: If you propose a tax plan, and it cuts taxes on somebody, it has to raise taxes on somebody else, or raise the deficit. Since conservatives have long been focused on cutting the top marginal tax rate on income without raising the deficit, their tax plans usually involve cutting taxes on the rich — and therefore raising taxes on some nonrich group.

headline: Parents of Victim in Film Set Accident Plan Safety Campaign
abstract: The parents of Sarah Jones, who was killed as she worked on the movie “Midnight Rider” in February, have filed a wrongful death lawsuit.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Speaking by telephone from a lawyer’s office in Atlanta on Thursday morning, the parents of Sarah Jones, who was killed in a film set accident on Feb. 20, said they were planning to create a permanent film safety campaign dedicated to her memory and built around the phrase “Safety for Sarah.”

Hall as a man who has killed a burglar who broke into his home. That act sets off a series of events in this twisty thriller. Here, Mr. Hall’s character appears at the funeral of the man he killed, with surprising results.

headline: A Belgian Sculptor Takes Antwerp by Storm
abstract: John Creten shares with T the processes and inspirations behind some of the pieces in his new outdoor sculpture installation.
lead_paragraph: A storm is brewing at Middelheim Museum, a sculpture park outside of Antwerp, Belgium. “The Storm,” to be exact. It’s the Belgian sculptor Johan Creten’s newest show, an outdoor installation of 25 monumental works cast in bronze, clay and resin. Creten’s work speaks to the storm within us all, as individuals and as a society, and deals with his usual themes: nature, the female form, power, politics and spirituality. As a preview to what is, to date, his largest and most ambitious exhibition, which opens this Saturday under the moody Flemish sky, the Paris-based artist talks to T about the processes and inspiration behind some of the works on view.

lead_paragraph: In the news: extreme weight loss, superior memory and swimming ability. Test your knowledge of this week’s health news.

headline: Small on Space, Big on Flavors
abstract: The tasting menu at Box Kite, a speck of a coffee shop in the East Village, is more summer playlist than “Ring” cycle.
lead_paragraph: Lately, the restaurants I visit seem to have ever tinier and more makeshift kitchens, from which nevertheless issue ornate, ambitious, semi-avant-garde meals. It’s as if a clandestine “Top Chef” challenge were in progress, with young-gun chefs goading one another into using the fewest, crudest tools possible to create spectacle and wonder.

headline: Gavin Schmidt on Why Climate Models are Wrong, and Valuable
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Space and Astronomy', 'TED Conference']
abstract: Two takes on climate science by Gavin Schmidt, who explains while computer models, while highly imperfect, are valuable.
lead_paragraph: I’m overdue to draw your attention to two fresh, and very different, discussions of climate science by Gavin Schmidt, the longtime climate modeler at NASA’s Goddard Institute for Space Studies.

headline: Is Work Your Happy Place?
abstract: New research shows that men and women feel more stressed out at home than when they are at work.
lead_paragraph: Do you feel more stressed out at work or at home?

headline: Preserving a New York Jewelry Legacy
abstract: Henry Dankner & Sons, known for its gold mechanical charms, is donating its jewelry molds and sketches to the Fashion Institute of Technology.
lead_paragraph: The roster of small jewelry workshops in Manhattan’s diamond district keeps shrinking, but at least one company that’s winding down is preserving the history of its designs. After six decades of making jewelry at various addresses in the West 40s, Henry Dankner & Sons is closing and donating its paperwork and molds to the jewelry design department at the Fashion Institute of Technology.

headline: Cuomo Boasts of New York’s Rebirth, but Hits Snags
abstract: As Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo vies for re-election, some of the bolts on his juggernaut of an administration have seemed to loosen.
lead_paragraph: MELVILLE, N.Y. — For three years, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo dominated New York State politics like no other chief executive in decades.

headline: A Boy Lost in the Underworld
abstract: “Stand Clear of the Closing Doors,” set largely in New York City’s subway system, observes the world through the eyes of a boy with autism.
lead_paragraph: “Stand Clear of the Closing Doors,” a small miracle of a film, captures the grass-roots swirl of New York City with an extraordinary sensory attuning to urban life. Set largely inside the city’s subway system, it observes the world through the eyes of Ricky (Jesus Sanchez-Velez), a bright but easily distracted 13-year-old boy with midrange autism who gets lost underground. Mr. Sanchez-Velez, the untrained actor who plays him, has Asperger’s syndrome and is a hauntingly plaintive screen presence.

headline: F.H.A. Loans Get Better with Credit Counseling
abstract: The F.H.A. offers to lower mortgage insurance premiums for borrowers who complete counseling before and after they receive a home loan.
lead_paragraph: Tight mortgage lending conditions have largely shut out the millions of borrowers with credit scores below 640. In response, the Federal Housing Administration, which insures low-down-payment loans, has taken on the tricky task of trying to expand access to credit without increasing the rate of default.

headline: Minnesota Orchestra Names Interim President
abstract: Kevin Smith, a former president of the Minnesota Opera, will take over after the departure of Michael Henson, the orchestra’s president and chief executive.
lead_paragraph: The Minnesota Orchestra, which is rebuilding after a long lockout, said Thursday that it had chosen an interim leader to take over after its president and chief executive, Michael Henson, steps down this summer: Kevin Smith, a former president of the Minnesota Opera.

abstract: Parsons the New School for Design honored one of its graduates, Jason Wu.
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday night at a black-tie dinner in Greenwich Village, Parsons the New School for Design honored Jason Wu, one of its graduates. The event attracted a crowd of fashion notables, including Donna Karan, Chris Benz and Tracy Reese.

headline: Intellectual Dueling at a Prep School
abstract: “Words and Pictures,” a comedy of ideas couched in the format of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, depicts dueling academics at a New England prep school.
lead_paragraph: Because “Words and Pictures” is a comedy of ideas couched in the format of a Spencer Tracy-Katharine Hepburn movie, the temptation for some critics faced with a film that dares to be ostentatiously smart is to blast it to smithereens. Which more or less describes the critical reaction to the movie when it was shown last year at the Toronto Film Festival.

headline: Yo, Beau. What’s Up?
abstract: Addressing questions of relationships and running into your boss outside of work.
lead_paragraph: My boyfriend and I have been together for about two years. Last week, I overheard him on the telephone telling a good friend that he would like to break up with me. (Literally: “Bro, I want to dump her.”) He thought I was out of the apartment, so I haven’t said anything about it. It felt like eavesdropping to me. But he’s not acting as if he wants to break up. In fact, he’s been incredibly sweet lately. I’m afraid I’m being delusional. Should I say something to him? And if so, what?

headline: Attack Kills More Than 30 in Western China Market
abstract: The attack in the capital of the restive Xinjiang region highlights the growing challenge to Chinese rule in the heavily Muslim area, home to the Uighur ethnic minority.
lead_paragraph: URUMQI, China — Assailants driving two sport utility vehicles and tossing explosive devices plowed through a crowded vegetable market on Thursday in this city, the capital of the Xinjiang region in far western China, killing 31 people and wounding 94. It was the single deadliest attack here since ethnic bloodletting claimed hundreds of lives five years ago.

headline: 2 Cities Withdraw Bids to Host 2016 G.O.P. Convention
keywords: ['Republican National Convention', 'Presidential Election of 2016', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Cleveland, Dallas, Denver and Kansas City remain as finalists for the event.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Las Vegas and Cincinnati have informed the Republican National Committee that they are withdrawing from the competition to host the party’s 2016 convention. The other four finalists, Cleveland, Dallas, Denver and Kansas City, will receive official site visits from the committee’s 2016 site selection delegation, according to a news release.

headline: What I Learned on Paternity Leave: I’m Glad to Be Back at Work
abstract: I served as my daughter’s sole caregiver long enough to know that I was ready for it to be over. Realizing that I felt that way was one of the best things about my paternity leave.
lead_paragraph: I was my daughter’s sole caregiver long enough to know that I was ready for it to be over. That doesn’t mean I regret taking paternity leave. In fact, realizing that I felt that way was one of the best things about it.

headline: Tasting France Through 5 Signature Dishes
abstract: Go on a French regional food tour, sampling essential dishes from Brittany, Provence, Alsace — and beyond.
lead_paragraph: I’ve always felt that a map of France reads like a menu. The very names of regions can incite ravenous pangs. Each has a signature dish, from Brittany’s butter-crisped crepes, to the generous cuts of pork draped over mounds of tangy sauerkraut in the eastern reaches of Alsace. Provence bursts with a rich soup of Mediterranean fish; the bounty of Languedoc’s flat, dry plains comes alive in the warmth of simmering cassoulet.

headline: A Young Violinist’s Lucky Concerto? First, a Prize; Now, the Philharmonic
abstract: The violinist Nicola Benedetti, filling in at the New York Philharmonic this week, returned to a showpiece by Szymanowski that won her a BBC award 10 years ago.
lead_paragraph: Two dominant figures from the British music scene made their Avery Fisher Hall debuts with the New York Philharmonic on Wednesday evening. The fiery Russian conductor Vladimir Jurowski, principal conductor of the London Philharmonic Orchestra and music director, for over a decade, of the Glyndebourne Festival Opera, led the Philharmonic for the first time, drawing a strong performance that was especially memorable for the raw power of the music’s climaxes. The 26-year-old Scottish violinist Nicola Benedetti, who had previously appeared only in a parks concert with the orchestra, stepped in to perform Szymanowski’s Violin Concerto No. 1 at a moment’s notice when the Dutch star violinist Janine Jansen had to withdraw on doctor’s orders.

headline: An Intellectual and His Lofty Contempt
abstract: “Gore Vidal: United States of Amnesia” is a documentary about the life and times of the stubbornly liberal author.
lead_paragraph: When Gore Vidal declared in an old television debate with William F. Buckley Jr. that 5 percent of Americans had 20 percent of the income and the bottom 20 percent had 5 percent, he was raising an alarm. That observation may be the most shocking moment in “Gore Vidal: The United States of Amnesia,” Nicholas Wrathall’s admiring documentary portrait of Vidal, who died in 2012 at 86.

headline: Philip Roth to Appear on ‘Colbert Report’
abstract: Mr. Roth agreed to appear on the show with Stephen Colbert as part of “cOlbert’s Book Club.”
lead_paragraph: So where on television can you get a really substantial discussion of the great American novel?

headline: With Border Reopened, Crossing the Rio Grande to Mexico
abstract: After a crossing between Texas and Mexico opened again in April 2013, the author made the short trip across the river to see the tiny village of Boquillas.
lead_paragraph: On a May afternoon several years ago, my friend Drew and I took a day trip from Marfa, Texas, where we both lived at the time, to Big Bend National Park, about 100 miles away. Temperatures often reach into the 90s and 100s in the late spring in Far West Texas, so we were called to the water that day, and headed for the edge of the Rio Grande, at the east end of the park.

Peter and Kirsten Abitz, from Denmark, were on vacation, as was Linda Christeaen from Belgium. The 40 or so students at Greenwich High School in Connecticut had taken a bus down for the day thanks in part to money raised by the PTA.

headline: Library Reveals President’s Salary
abstract: Anthony W. Marx, president and chief executive of the New York Public Library, earned $781,000 — including housing, tuition and other compensation — in his first full year.
lead_paragraph: Anthony W. Marx earned $781,000 — including housing, tuition and other compensation — in his first full year as president and chief executive of the New York Public Library, according to the library’s most recent tax returns. According to the library’s Form 990, Mr. Marx’s base salary for 2012 was $491,000, considerably lower than that of his predecessor, Paul LeClerc, who was making $667,000 when he left the library, in 2011. More recent salary figures are not available. Library salaries have been a topic of discussion in recent months as New York City officials review the salary of Thomas W. Galante, who gets about $391,000 as the director of the Queens Library system. Mr. Marx and other officers are paid with private funds.

headline: Family Memoir in a Dreamscape
abstract: The arrival of Alejandro Jodorowsky’s new feature would be grounds for excitement even if the movie, “The Dance of Reality,” were not something very close to a masterpiece.
lead_paragraph: The Chilean-born filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky has recently been the subject of a revelatory documentary — “Jodorowsky’s Dune,” directed by Frank Pavich — about a movie he never made. There are a lot of those: Since his heyday in the early ’70s as a midnight cult-film pioneer with “El Topo” and “The Holy Mountain,” Mr. Jodorowsky’s semimythic status as a cinematic wild man has outstripped his productivity as a director. So the arrival of a new feature — his first since 1990 — would be grounds for excitement even, if the movie in question, “The Dance of Reality,” were not something very close to a masterpiece.

headline: In Fields and Stadiums, Like One Long Concert
abstract: Music festival season is here, beginning at MetLife Stadium on Memorial Day weekend and ending just before Labor Day on Randalls Island.
lead_paragraph: New York brims with summer entertainment, and that includes more choices than ever for those whose idea of it is to escape into a “lost weekend” of music festival revelry. Nearby options include the freewheeling Mountain Jam at Hunter Mountain (June 5-8), the folk and singer-songwriter hub Clearwater’s Great Hudson River Revival in Croton-on-Hudson (June 21-22), the hip-hop- and rock-centric Made in America weekend in Philadelphia (Aug. 30-31) and many more. Here are six of the most-anticipated destination festivals in the region.

headline: Golden Line Adds Tarnish to Sprawling Subway System
abstract: Mexico City’s Metro, fast and cheap at less than 40 cents a ride, has hit a speed bump with a new line that has major flaws.
lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — There is music on the trains of Mexico City’s newest subway, the Golden Line, piped in at just the right volume to be pleasantly audible over the rumble. One recent morning, the playlist came to a classic: “Midnight Train to Georgia.”

headline: 2 Major Time Inc. Magazines Will Run Cover Advertising
abstract: The ads, tiny strips running along the mailing label area, are to appear on the covers of Time and Sports Illustrated.
lead_paragraph: Time magazine and Sports Illustrated have started selling advertising space on their covers, breaking with a longstanding magazine industry tradition of keeping covers free of ads.

headline: A Confederacy of Mavericks
abstract: The question of what is innate and what can be learned arises in the exhibition “Self-Taught Genius: Treasures From the American Folk Art Museum.”
lead_paragraph: Is there such a thing as artistic genius? In high-culture circles, it used to be taken for granted that there was, and there was a well-established canon of great artworks to prove it, from Leonardo’s “Mona Lisa” to Jackson Pollock’s drip paintings. Then, at the end of the 1960s, scholars like Linda Nochlin, author of “Why Have There Been No Great Women Artists?,” began to wonder why the canon consisted almost exclusively of works by male Caucasians. Is genius something that only white men are capable of? After that, belief in genius pretty much disappeared from serious art-historical discourse, except when it was disparaged as a patriarchal myth.

headline: The Joys of Judging a Book by Its Cover
abstract: “Gatsby to Garp,” an exhibition of first editions, galleys and letters at the Morgan Library & Museum, focuses on a literary period when the modern American bookstore and inventive book jackets were in their prime.
lead_paragraph: A woman’s melancholic eyes, heavy-lidded with desire, float in the nocturnal sky over a brashly lit skyline and amusement park.

lead_paragraph: If our French and global food roundups didn’t get your mouth watering, this might. “Street Chef of Gulshan,” produced by Fred Grace and Gemma Atkinson for Fat Rat Films, is part of the Hidden Lives series that we occasionally run. It takes you on a virtual trip to Bangladesh, and explores the idea that food is a means of understanding a place and its people.

lead_paragraph: The young man in a Taiwan military uniform, a clear plastic bag over his head, stood before an array of paper tombstones along Ketagalan Boulevard in Taipei holding a sign that read: “I am a soldier. I am gay. I passed the physical. I’m not allowed to give blood.”

headline: Gleeful Museums Unpack a Bequest
abstract: The final group of paintings, drawings and sculptures bequeathed to museums by Paul Mellon have at last begun to arrive. Many are rarities curators had never seen.
lead_paragraph: The final group of paintings, drawings and sculptures bequeathed to museums by Paul Mellon before his death in 1999 have at last begun to arrive. Hidden away for decades, many are rarities that had never been seen by curators.

headline: Women With Diabetes Face Greater Heart Risks Than Men
abstract: Type 2 diabetes substantially increases the risk for heart disease, but a large review of studies has found that women with diabetes are at much higher risk than men.
lead_paragraph: Type 2 diabetes substantially increases the risk for heart disease, but a large review of studies has found that women with diabetes are at much higher risk than men.

headline: Transference? I’ll Take It
keywords: ['Dating and Relationships', 'Therapy and Rehabilitation', 'Psychology and Psychologists', 'Love (Emotion)', 'Modern Love (Times Column)']
abstract: How one shortish, balding Jewish therapist led to another shortish, bald Jewish guy.
lead_paragraph: I was in my early 40s, and my life was finally swinging into shape. I had a steady stream of work and warm, generous friends. But I had yet to find a viable, committed love. I kept falling for handsome artistic narcissists and their beautiful myths, while ordinary guys with decent looks, good jobs and kind natures simply didn’t register on my radar.

headline: Understanding the Thai Coup
abstract: Thomas Fuller, who is covering the coup for The Times, recommends what to read on the political dynamics of Thai society.
lead_paragraph: The Thai military overthrew the country’s elected government on Thursday. It was the second time in a decade that the military has seized control. We asked Thomas Fuller, who is covering the coup for The Times, to recommend what to read on the political dynamics of Thai society. Here is his suggestion:

headline: Architecture for the Upper East Side Horse
abstract: 69th Street, from Lexington to Third, is notable among surviving stable streets — where the smells and noise of horses were isolated their owners.
lead_paragraph: The legacies of the horse in New York include the stable street, where the well-to-do isolated their private stables to avoid the smells and noise, inflicting them instead on their lesser neighbors. Although the mansions they served are in most cases gone, a few of these stable streets survive, and one of the most significant is 69th Street, from Lexington to Third Avenues.

headline: Lost in the Past
abstract: It’s not just students who don’t know history. Opinion leaders, corporate titans, politicians, media personalities and educators — dunce caps for all.
lead_paragraph: Ask a high school senior what the Great War was all about and you’re likely to get a shrug or a stab based on a recent episode of “Game of Thrones.” Hint: its 100th anniversary is this year. Hint: globe-straddling old empires collapsed and new horrors, from genocide to slaughter by poisonous gas, were ushered in. Hint: its repercussions are with us still, from Syria to Russia to the American role as international cop.

headline: Donovan Dropped From U.S. World Cup Team
abstract: Landon Donovan, considered the greatest male player in the history of United States soccer, was cut from the team as Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed his final roster to 23 players.
lead_paragraph: Landon Donovan, widely considered the best male player in the history of United States soccer, was cut from the World Cup team on Thursday as Coach Jurgen Klinsmann trimmed his roster to 23 players.

headline: Sounds of All but Silence
abstract: Six exhibitions at the New Museum rely heavily on ears, including pieces by the Icelandic artist Ragnar Kjartansson, the Italian Roberto Cuoghi and the French Camille Henrot.
lead_paragraph: The New Museum is alive with the sound of music, as well as talking, chanting, spitting, electronic tics and sputters and, occasionally, the tinkling of 47 small bronze bells. Its six current exhibitions all involve sound. One is almost nothing but sound. This loose, fluctuating connection illuminates some of the many roles sound plays in contemporary art while allowing the shows to, well, amplify one another in unexpected ways. It also mitigates the museum’s dark, awkwardly proportioned galleries.
