headline: A Summer of TV Time Travel
abstract: “Freedom Summer” on PBS will be a moment of high seriousness in a summer TV season largely populated by the likes of pirates, musketeers and vampires.
lead_paragraph: For proof that summer is no longer the silly season of television — or at least not solely silly — just take a look at names involved in some notable shows from Memorial Day to September. Steven Soderbergh, Guillermo del Toro, Michael Bay, John Malkovich and Halle Berry are among the A-listers we’re not used to seeing attached to summer TV, or to TV shows at all.

headline: Excavating the Past to Reshape the Present
abstract: DD Dorvillier culls hundreds of choreographic fragments from videos of her work from 1990 to 2004 in “A Catalogue of Steps,” at Danspace Project.
lead_paragraph: From now until June 14, Danspace Project is all about DD Dorvillier, with programs exploring the work of that influential choreographer from multiple angles. In June comes a forward look, as Ms. Dorvillier debuts a solo. Starting on Friday are various sideways views, as longtime collaborators present solos of their own, examining shared connections. And the backward glance, befitting such an inveterate questioner of convention as Ms. Dorvillier, is nothing as standard as a remounting of past pieces.

headline: Sunny Cannes Gets Lightning
abstract: Jean-Luc Godard, 83, sent a letter to the Cannes festival as his new film, “Goodbye to Language,” was met by cheering audiences.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — On Wednesday afternoon, the 83-year-old rock star Jean-Luc Godard shook up the Cannes Film Festival with his latest, a 70-minute 3-D extravaganza, “Goodbye to Language.” Finally, the competition lineup had something it has desperately needed all week: a thrilling cinematic experience that nearly levitated the packed 2,300-seat Lumière theater here, turning just another screening into a real happening. You could feel the electric charge — the collective effervescence — that can come when individuals transform into a group. “Godard forever!” a voice boomed out to laughter and applause, as the congregated viewers waited for their brains to light up with the screen.

headline: Grabbing the Good Songs From Sources All Over
abstract: Marissa Mulder’s romantic new show, “Living Standards,” includes songs about breakups, illusion, fantasies and humiliation as well as the lighter side of the search for love.
lead_paragraph: In contemporary songwriting, how true is the commonly voiced adage “They don’t write ’em like they used to”? That received wisdom is powerfully challenged in the singer Marissa Mulder’s wonderful new show, “Living Standards,” which had its first performance on Wednesday evening at the Metropolitan Room.

headline: They Want Your Blood
abstract: Lampreys, in “Blood Lake,” on Animal Planet, and controlling, vaguely humanoid woodland creatures in “Deep in the Darkness,” on Chiller, are among the monsters coming to the small screen.
lead_paragraph: Can you judge the state of an actor’s career based on how he is required to die on camera? If so, Christopher Lloyd has cause for concern.

headline: Ronaldo’s Toughest Move
abstract: Cristiano Ronaldo, who helped lead Real Madrid to the Champions League title, had to be nudged into leaving the insulation of Madeira for a better opportunity.
lead_paragraph: FUNCHAL, Portugal — The roads of Madeira twist together like licorice ropes, their spindly curves beginning at the seashore and rising up the steps of this steep island in a maze reminiscent of Rio de Janeiro’s favelas. The slow climb here comes with a similar feeling to the Brazilian shanties, too: one of utter insulation, a complete removal from the tourist areas that lie below.

headline: Ex-Leader Embodies a German Divide on Russia

lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was an image that provoked consternation abroad and in an instant captured Germany’s long-conflicted place between East and West: former Chancellor Gerhard Schröder embracing President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia as he arrived last month at a party in St. Petersburg for the German’s 70th birthday.

headline: Japanese Food Firm That Popularized Sushi Looks Globally for Growth
abstract: In the 1700s, Mizkan popularized sushi by figuring out how to make inexpensive rice vinegar. Now, it is buying global food brands like Ragu and Bertolli.
lead_paragraph: The Mizkan Group’s $2.15 billion purchase of Unilever’s Ragu and Bertolli pasta sauce brands is the latest overseas foray by a storied and gutsy vinegar maker, one that helped transform sushi from an obscure delicacy into a global culinary phenomenon.

headline: Saving Their Future, in Bell-Bottoms
abstract: In “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” Wolverine is sent back to the 1970s to round up his young colleagues to help prevent an apocalyptic battle a half-century away.
lead_paragraph: Even compared with other self-serious superhero franchises — the brooding “Dark Knight” saga, the agonized “Amazing Spider-Man,” the hectic “Avengers” house party — the X-Men series wears its allegorical heart on its sleeve. In chronicling the adventures of a despised minority with extraordinary powers, the movies, like the Marvel comic books before them, poke around in some interesting social and political hot zones. The central conflict is the endless moral and political argument between Professor X and Magneto: in other words, between the accommodationist idea that the mutants should fight for the moral redemption of the humans, and the militant insistence that they should defend their own interests by any means necessary.

headline: Monsters (the Human Kind) Slithering Through East Texas
abstract: In “Cold in July,” Michael C. Hall, Sam Shepard and Don Johnson are unlikely amigos, banding against evil.
lead_paragraph: The pulpy neo-noir “Cold in July” should propel the filmmaking team of Jim Mickle and Nick Damici further up the blood-spattered, zombie-infested hierarchy of B-movie auteurs with Hollywood ambitions. Last year, they advanced a few feet with their remake of the 2011 Mexican cannibal fest, “We Are What We Are,” which followed two microbudget cult favorites: the post-apocalyptic “Stake Land” (2011), and “Mulberry St.” (2007), a medical horror flick.

headline: What to Do in New York City in Summer 2014
abstract: No matter the temperature, New York is the place to be. Here’s a summer guide to make the most of it.
lead_paragraph: Winter was no picnic, but the amnesia that summer provides is just around the corner. The season’s lodestar, Macy’s Fourth of July fireworks show, is moving back to the East River, guided by the wishes of the Brooklynite mayor, Bill de Blasio. To witness another spectacle, find the camping gear and clear your calendar to ensure a ticket to “King Lear,” starring John Lithgow and Annette Bening, the Public Theater’s free Shakespeare in the Park production. No matter the temperature, New York is the place to be. Here’s a summer guide to make the most of it.

headline: Former Defense Secretary Gates Is Elected President of the Boy Scouts
abstract: Robert M. Gates, who supported the repeal of the “don’t ask, don’t tell” policy on gay men and lesbians serving openly in the military, formally takes leadership of an organization that continues to be roiled by its policy on gay Scouts and leaders.
lead_paragraph: Robert M. Gates, the former secretary of defense and director of the Central Intelligence Agency, was elected president of the Boy Scouts of America on Thursday, formally taking leadership of an organization that continues to be roiled by its policy on gay Scouts and leaders.

headline: When Single Parents Collide on a Safari
abstract: In “Blended,” the third pairing of Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore, Mr. Sandler once again proclaims himself both über-doofus and ultimate mensch.
lead_paragraph: Because life is short and I have other things to be upset about, I will not dwell on the offensive aspects of “Blended,” the new Adam Sandler comedy: its retrograde gender politics; its delight in the humiliation of children; its sentimental hypocrisy about male behavior; its quasi-zoological depiction of Africans as servile, dancing, drum-playing simpletons; its ... I’m sorry. That’s just what I said I wouldn’t do.

headline: Hit by Rivals, Hewlett-Packard Will Cut Jobs
abstract: The chief executive said she would lay off 11,000 to 16,000 employees, as quarterly results released on Thursday underlined that a recovery was still in the distance for the company.
lead_paragraph: Meg Whitman, the chief executive of Hewlett-Packard, has said that it will take a long time to get the company on the right course. The quarterly results released Thursday underlined that a recovery was still in the distance.

headline: Maintaining Hopes of Starting, Jets’ Vick Grapples With Backup Role
abstract: Michael Vick, 33, was signed in March to compete for the starting quarterback job, but is now expected to sit behind Geno Smith on the depth chart.
lead_paragraph: FLORHAM PARK, N.J. — Michael Vick is accustomed to being either the unquestioned starting quarterback or, at worst, knowing he would be given every opportunity to vie for that role. But on Thursday, he sounded very much like a proud but aging star intent on doing whatever necessary to extend a once-brilliant career.

headline: Inside the Ropes, McIlroy Keeps It Together
abstract: Rory McIlroy is six strokes behind the leader, Thomas Bjorn, after the first round of the BMW PGA Championship.
lead_paragraph: VIRGINIA WATER, England — All Rory McIlroy wanted to do was take refuge on the golf course, inside the ropes, and play the first round of the rest of his life at the BMW PGA Championship, the European Tour’s flagship event.

headline: An 18th-Century Korea, Swarming With Assassins
abstract: A Korean ruler known as the king of misfortune faces enemies at every turn in “The Fatal Encounter.”
lead_paragraph: The title of Lee Jae-kyoo’s “The Fatal Encounter” is a misnomer: The film teems with fatal encounters. It is 1777, in the Joseon dynasty in Korea, and King Jeong-jo (Hyun Bin) — known historically as the king of misfortune — is surrounded by enemies. Two factions, the Noron and Soron, are at each other’s throats, and everyone, it seems, has it in for him. Even his trusted clerk, Sang-chaek (an effectively understated Jung Jae-young), a quiet minder of this philosopher-king’s library, was trained in childhood at a kind of assassin school for slaves. He has positioned himself to strike but discovers that the monarch is a benign ruler and a friend.

headline: Dominican Republic Passes Law for Migrants’ Children
keywords: ['Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Immigration and Emigration', 'Law and Legislation']
abstract: The law would create a path to citizenship for people who were born to illegal migrants, many of them Haitian, but who have Dominican identification papers.
lead_paragraph: Under international pressure, the Dominican Republic is poised to create a path to citizenship for tens of thousands of people of Haitian descent whose legal right to reside in the country had been thrown in doubt by a court ruling last year.

headline: Crisis of the Eurocrats
keywords: ['European Sovereign Debt Crisis (2010- )', 'Elections', 'Economic Conditions and Trends', 'Fringe Groups and Movements']
abstract: The European project is in deep trouble. The Continent still has peace, but it’s falling short on prosperity and, in a subtler way, democracy.
lead_paragraph: A century ago, Europe tore itself apart in what was, for a time, known as the Great War — four years of death and destruction on an unprecedented scale. Later, of course, the conflict was renamed World War I — because a quarter-century later Europe did it all over again.

headline: Too Much Looking, Not Enough Listening?
abstract: Anthony Tommasini, the chief classical music critic of The New York Times, and Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim, a classical music critic for The Times, respond to the attention the opera singer Tara Erraught has gotten for her size, not her voice.
lead_paragraph: The reviews of the production of “Der Rosenkavalier” that opened this year’s Glyndebourne opera festival in England have gone viral, but not in a way that either the performers or the critics who wrote them probably expected. At issue: the way several prominent male critics harped on the shape, and not just the sound, of the young mezzo-soprano portraying Octavian: Tara Erraught.

headline: Status Quo Gets a Nod, but Arizona Is Changing
abstract: After being hired as the Diamondbacks’ chief baseball officer, Tony La Russa is learning the organization from the ground up.
lead_paragraph: The Arizona Diamondbacks started so poorly this season that their management team had reason to worry. With only five wins in their first 23 games, after consecutive .500 seasons, some kind of change seemed inevitable.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

abstract: The New York Times film critics review “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” “Cold in July” and “Blended.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “X-Men: Days of Future Past,” “Cold in July” and “Blended.”

headline: Finding Central Park’s Hidden Gems
abstract: The recently redesigned app from the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit that runs the park, is more informational than functional, full of historical trivia about the park’s many attractions.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been visiting Central Park regularly since I moved to New York three years ago, but I remain a total novice when it comes to navigating within it. I’ve only intermittently been able to find a beautiful fountain I once stumbled upon, and I was hoping that the recently redesigned app from the Central Park Conservancy, the nonprofit group that runs the park, could help.

headline: Family of Detained Egyptian Journalist Says Leaked Images of Him Were Staged
keywords: ['Hunger Strikes', 'News and News Media', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: The family of an Egyptian journalist detained for nine months without charge expressed outrage that images of him were leaked to a Facebook page run by Interior Ministry sympathizers.
lead_paragraph: The family of an Egyptian journalist who has been detained for nine months without charge expressed outrage on Thursday that images of him were leaked to a Facebook page run by sympathizers of the Interior Ministry.

headline: Televising Sizzling Meat to Bump Up Sales of a Brisket Sandwich
abstract: Arby’s filmed a brisket being smoked for 13 hours at the smokehouse in Texas that cures its brisket, and that footage will be one long commercial.
lead_paragraph: TELEVISION commercials have  grown shorter over the decades, with 60-second spots the norm at the dawn of the medium, 30-second spots growing popular in the 1970s, and 15-second spots catching on in the 1980s. The number of 15-second ads grew more than 80 percent between 2008 and 2012, according to Nielsen, which notes the popularity of mobile devices, where commercials must impress quickly as users toggle among apps.

headline: Competing Visions for Russia’s Economic Future
abstract: The St. Petersburg International Economic Forum aims to woo foreign investment, but the event is under a cloud this year as Russia stands on the verge of recession.
lead_paragraph: ST. PETERSBURG, Russia — A panel at an annual economic forum here was deeply divided over the direction of the Russian economy. The isolationists in the group favored relying on state banks for its financing needs. Others called for Russia to deepen its ties with China, while a different contingent said global trade and commerce remain critical.

headline: Near-Average Hurricane Season Is Predicted for U.S. as El Niño Develops in the Pacific
abstract: Experts at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration said they anticipated three to six hurricanes — one or two of them major storms — this year.
lead_paragraph: The Atlantic Ocean and the Gulf of Mexico are highly likely to experience an average or below-average number of hurricanes and tropical storms this year, including fewer of the most dangerous hurricanes with winds above 110 miles per hour, government forecasters said Thursday.

headline: Old Mystery for Clippers’ Fill-In C.E.O.
abstract: Richard Parsons, who was named the interim chief executive of the Los Angeles Clippers, faces claims that he exaggerated or falsified his college basketball record at the University of Hawaii.
lead_paragraph: For years, as the business résumé of Richard Parsons swelled, a bit of his early life remained unexplored or ignored: his college basketball career at the University of Hawaii nearly 50 years ago.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in Connecticut. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com.

headline: $200 Million Could Curb Pension Cuts in Detroit
abstract: The Michigan State House on Thursday agreed to contribute nearly $200 million in state money for a deal to spare Detroit’s retirees from larger pension cuts.
lead_paragraph: In a series of votes that could be critical for Detroit’s emergence from bankruptcy, the Michigan State House on Thursday agreed to contribute nearly $200 million in state money for a deal to spare Detroit’s retirees from larger pension cuts and to avoid selling artworks from the city’s museum.

headline: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, Rolling Stones Money Manager, Dies at 80
abstract: The Bavarian aristocrat helped the band with matters as varied as financial oversight, divorces, drug charges and tours.
lead_paragraph: Prince Rupert zu Loewenstein, a Bavarian aristocrat and money manager who guided the Rolling Stones to riches and through financial crises — helping to elevate them to an economic behemoth — without ever acquiring a taste for rock music, died on Tuesday in London. He was 80.

headline: A Hedge Fund Highflier Comes Back to Earth
abstract: Crispin Odey, whose hedge fund’s fortunes have risen and fallen in recent years, drew attention with extravagant plans for a chicken coop.
lead_paragraph: ENGLISH BICKNOR, England — The chickens of the one percent could roost comfortably here.

headline: Really Good Books, Part I
abstract: Some of my favorite books are about the deep limitations we face in life, from circumstances that defy comprehension to passions we cannot control.
lead_paragraph: People are always asking me what my favorite books are. I’ve held off listing them because it seems self-indulgent. But, with summer almost here, I thought I might spend a couple columns recommending eight books that have been pivotal in my life.

headline: Wade Is Flourishing in Playoffs Despite His Worrisome Knees
abstract: Dwyane Wade had an up-and-down regular season for Miami because of his chronic knee problems, but his postseason performance has been solid.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Dwyane Wade objected — in unquestionably polite and good-natured ways — to the wording of two questions posed to him by reporters after the Miami Heat’s workout here Thursday morning.

headline: No Gap to Mind
abstract: In France, brand new trains, it turns out, are too fat to squeeze into many train stations, which at least proves that bureaucratic dysfunction knows no boundaries.
lead_paragraph: French commentators are scrambling to find just the right words to describe a costly bureaucratic blunder that came to light on Wednesday, thanks to some digging by the satirical weekly Le Canard Enchaîné. Was the foul-up only “comically tragic,” as a French transportation minister sheepishly described it, a “vaudeville farce,” as a rail worker’s union saw it, or a howler verging on madness as a leading French newspaper suggested.

headline: Path to an Asylum Request, From Egypt Jail to California Fair
keywords: ['Asylum, Right of', 'Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )']
abstract: After attending a science event, Abdullah Assem refused to leave Los Angeles after his chaperones refused to give him assurances that he would be safe back in Egypt.
lead_paragraph: ANAHEIM, Calif. — As he walked out of a Cairo electronics store the night of April 24, Abdullah Assem, 17, was met by several police officers who told him he was under arrest for creating an antigovernment rebel group and for shooting at a government security building.

headline: Misdiagnosis? You’d Be Angry, Too
abstract: In “The Angriest Man in Brooklyn,” Robin Williams plays a lawyer who reappraises his life when told he has 90 minutes left to live.
lead_paragraph: From the director of “Field of Dreams” comes one of those movies about someone who learns he has a terminal diagnosis and desperately tries to take stock. In Phil Alden Robinson’s “The Angriest Man in Brooklyn,” Robin Williams plays an irascible New York lawyer who gains a sudden window of self-awareness when a doctor says he has 90 minutes left to live. The movie is predictably sentimental at its root, but it’s also meant to be comedy, partly resting on Mr. Williams’s energetic but failed attempt to play a jerk.

headline: The Secret Shame of the Death Penalty
abstract: If capital punishment weren’t carried out behind closed doors, its barbarity, whatever the methods, would be made clear to the public.
lead_paragraph: Sooner or later, someone like Russell Bucklew was going to come along and throw a big wrench into the predictable back-and-forth debate over the constitutionality of executing people by lethal injection.

headline: Evacuation at Sept. 11 Museum Is Revealed
abstract: Last week, five days before it opened to the public, the National September 11 Memorial Museum was briefly evacuated, sending dozens of startled visitors scrambling up seven stories to daylight.
lead_paragraph: Last week, five days before it opened to the public, the National September 11 Memorial Museum was briefly evacuated, sending dozens of startled visitors scrambling up seven stories to daylight.

headline: Fans in Spain Reveal Their Prejudices, and Social Media Fuels the Hostilities
abstract: A spate of racist and anti-Semitic abuses has set off a fresh round of chagrin and soul-searching — and even a government clampdown — that raises broad questions about why such behavior seems so hard to combat.
lead_paragraph: MADRID — Spain’s sports fans have given Europe a version of the Donald Sterling racism scandal roiling America.

headline: A Surveillance Bill That Falls Short
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Editorials']
abstract: It’s up to the Senate now to fix the flaws in a House bill and protect Americans from the abuses of government spying.
lead_paragraph: A year ago, it would have been unimaginable for the House to pass a bill to curtail the government’s abusive surveillance practices. The documents leaked by Edward Snowden, however, finally shocked lawmakers from both parties into action, producing promises that they would stop the government from collecting the telephone data of ordinary Americans and would bring greater transparency to its domestic spying programs.

headline: I.R.S. Delays New Rules on Taxation for Activists
keywords: ['Tea Party Movement', 'Federal Taxes (US)', 'Tax Credits, Deductions and Exemptions', 'Internal Revenue Service Political Profiling', 'Nonprofit Organizations', 'Political Action Committees']
abstract: The Internal Revenue Service said it would revamp new rules to curb political activity by tax-exempt groups that were proposed after the agency was accused of targeting Tea Party groups.
lead_paragraph: The Internal Revenue Service said Thursday that it has delayed and is revamping new rules intended to curb political activity by tax-exempt groups and that were proposed after the agency was accused last year of targeting Tea Party groups.

lead_paragraph: Marriage Equality Advances

headline: Twitter Agrees to Block ‘Blasphemous’ Tweets in Pakistan
keywords: ['Censorship', 'Social Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Muslims and Islam']
abstract: This month, Twitter agreed for the first time to block messages deemed “blasphemous” or “unethical” from Pakistani users.
lead_paragraph: At least five times this month, a Pakistani bureaucrat who works from a colonial-era barracks in Karachi, just down the street from the former home of his country’s secularist founder, Mohammed Ali Jinnah, asked Twitter to shield his compatriots from exposure to accounts, tweets or searches of the social network that he described as “blasphemous” or “unethical.”

headline: Officials Cast Wide Net in Monitoring Occupy Protests
keywords: ['Demonstrations, Protests, and Riots', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Police']
abstract: Records show federal and state authorities scrutinized a broad range of Occupy protests in 2011 and 2012.
lead_paragraph: When the Occupy protests spread across the country three years ago, state and local law enforcement officials went on alert. In Milwaukee, officials reported that a group intended to sing holiday carols at “an undisclosed location of ‘high visibility.’ ” In Tennessee, an intelligence analyst sought information about whether groups concerned with animals, war, abortion or the Earth had been involved in protests.

headline: The Politics of Breastfeeding
abstract: Why does the nursing versus formula debate incite so much anxiety and competition among women?

headline: Facebook’s New Privacy Mascot: The Zuckasaurus
abstract: On Thursday, Facebook showed off a blue dinosaur character that will become the privacy ambassador on the social network. But the dinosaur could follow in the path of Microsoft’s Clippy, and Twitter’s Fail Whale, both of which were meant to help users and ended up being hated by people.
lead_paragraph: So why a dinosaur?

headline: Baseball Lords Vexed by Plan for a New King
abstract: Bud Selig’s succession plan for commissioner of Major League Baseball is meeting opposition from some team owners, including Jerry Reinsdorf of the Chicago White Sox.
lead_paragraph: The search for Major League Baseball’s next commissioner has been unusual for an organization that has $8 billion in annual revenue and regards itself as a Fortune 500-caliber company. A search firm has not been hired, and there has been no attempt to vet a wide-ranging list of internal or external candidates.

headline: A Prisoner’s Unflagging Claim of Innocence Meets an Unexplained Intrusion
keywords: ['Prisons and Prisoners', 'Informers', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Crime and Criminals', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: According to Everton Wagstaffe, a corrections officer methodically searched his prison room for three hours, going through every page of his legal papers, a mighty stack reflecting years of litigation.
lead_paragraph: How does time pass for a person in prison who says he is innocent?

headline: Clip: ‘The Angriest Man in Brooklyn’
abstract: A scene from the film.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film.

headline: From Virginia, Chasing Down Credit Suisse
keywords: ['Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Securities and Commodities Violations', 'Tax Evasion', 'United States Attorneys']
abstract: The long arm of United States prosecutors in Alexandria, Va., has led to cases against banks and other financial players across the country and the globe.
lead_paragraph: Hundreds of miles from Credit Suisse’s Madison Avenue office tower and an ocean away from its headquarters in Zurich, the bank found an unlikely opponent in Alexandria, Va.

headline: U.S. Case Offers Glimpse Into China’s Hacker Army
abstract: Many of the hackers employed by the Chinese government are men in their 20s and 30s who have been trained at universities run by the People’s Liberation Army.
lead_paragraph: BEIJING — One man accused of being a hacker for the Chinese military, Wang Dong, better known as UglyGorilla, wrote in a social media profile that he did not “have much ambition” but wanted “to wander the world with a sword, an idiot.”

headline: Life With, and Without, Father
abstract: Two brothers in France deal with the physical and cognitive decline of the previous generation, as well as their own discord, in “Grand Départ.”
lead_paragraph: Nicolas Mercier’s reassuring “Grand Départ” explores relationships painfully familiar to anyone who has dealt with an aging parent’s declining health and mental faculties. Often, in such situations, fraught connections with siblings — rivalries and unforgiven childhood slights — can be as stressful as tending to a dying loved one.

headline: Nets’ Deron Williams to Have Ankle Surgery
abstract: Nets point guard Deron Williams will have surgery on both of his troublesome ankles next week.
lead_paragraph: Nets point guard Deron Williams will have surgery on both of his troublesome ankles, the team said Thursday.

headline: After Prison, a Life on the Ropes
abstract: A young man, fresh out of prison, tries to rebuild his life as a kickboxer but is noticed by a Mob boss who has other plans.
lead_paragraph: “Wolf” follows Majid — a second-generation Dutchman of Moroccan descent recently released from prison and back living with his disapproving family — as he works in a warehouse and begins to make a career as a kickboxer in prize fights. His best friend, though, keeps involving him in robberies that grow bigger and bolder, and Majid eventually draws the interest of Hakan, a mob boss who sees potential in him.

headline: Northern Ireland Police Sue for Boston College Interviews
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The police said on Thursday that they were taking legal action to obtain all transcripts and recordings of interviews with paramilitary members who took part in an oral history project.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The police in Northern Ireland said on Thursday that they were taking legal action against Boston College to obtain all transcripts and recordings of interviews with paramilitary members on both sides of the sectarian divide who took part in an oral history project there.

headline: Government Surveillance of the Occupy Protests
abstract: The following documents are a selection from among about 4,000 pages of unclassified emails and reports about the Occupy protests distributed by people working with counterterrorism and intelligence-sharing offices known as “fusion centers.”
lead_paragraph: The following documents are a selection from among about 4,000 pages of unclassified emails and reports about the Occupy protests distributed by people working with counterterrorism and intelligence-sharing offices known as “fusion centers.”

headline: ‘Home’ for the Summer, in a Refugee Camp
abstract: In “A World Not Ours,” the director, Mahdi Fleifel, interviews generations of family in the crowded Palestinian refugee camp where he lived before moving to Denmark.
lead_paragraph: Exiles at home, the generations of family depicted in the documentary “A World Not Ours” live in Lebanon without completely being part of it. This affecting, humor-tinged debut feature from Mahdi Fleifel goes back to the old neighborhood in southern Lebanon: the refugee camp Ain al-Helweh, a Palestinian pocket of hemmed-in buildings and stifled hopes.

headline: Felony Charges Are Filed in Case of 2004 Disappearance
abstract: Prosecutors say that Isidro Medrano Garcia abducted the 15-year-old daughter of his girlfriend and that she spent the next decade as his wife and the mother of his child.
lead_paragraph: SANTA ANA, Calif. — Ten years after absconding with his girlfriend’s 15-year-old daughter, Isidro Medrano Garcia was charged by prosecutors on Thursday with raping and kidnapping the girl, who subsequently became his wife and the mother of his child and who lived with him for the past decade.

headline: Indictment Details 3 Kidnappings Linked to Coerced Divorces
abstract: Several rabbis and ultra-Orthodox men were accused in October of being a part of a ring that kidnapped and tortured Jewish husbands who refused to grant divorces to their wives.
lead_paragraph: When several rabbis and ultra-Orthodox men were accused in October of being a part of a ring that kidnapped and tortured Jewish husbands who refused to grant divorces to their wives, the top federal prosecutor in New Jersey said the number of victims might run into the dozens.

headline: Jersey City Sues Port Authority Over Taxes on Property
abstract: Jersey City is seeking more than $300 million in unpaid taxes from the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey.
lead_paragraph: After months of threatening and some grudging negotiations, Jersey City sued the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey on Thursday, seeking more than $300 million in unpaid taxes.

headline: If Life Gives You Baloney, Make a Sandwich
abstract: The workers of a sandwich franchise try to keep the shop afloat after the owner mysteriously disappears in Bess Wohl’s new comedy, “American Hero.”
lead_paragraph: As the stacks of cold cuts and the sliced Cheddar dwindle, so do the prospects of staying financially afloat for the three beleaguered central characters in “American Hero,” a sweet and sour new comedy by Bess Wohl that opened on Thursday night at the McGinn/Cazale Theater in the annual Uptown series from Second Stage Theater. Cast adrift when the owner of the new sandwich franchise where they work mysteriously disappears, the store’s employees alternate between despair at the latest dead end in their lives and fragile hope that by keeping calm and carrying on making sandwiches, somehow things will turn out all right.

headline: Inside Opening
abstract: A grid that contains more than meets the eye, by David Steinberg.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — This puzzle by David Steinberg is an optical illusion, a feature I’ve never seen in a puzzle before. It reminds me of this illusion, where two different pictures can be seen, depending on how you look at it. Can you see the two visual aspects of the grid? At first glance, you might see two arrows running in opposite directions, but as you fill in the puzzle — especially as you get to the center of it — you will begin to realize that there is more than meets the eye with Mr. Steinberg’s grid.

headline: We Feel Your Vibe
abstract: “Frequencies,” written and directed by Darren Paul Fisher, is a sci-fi film with a surreal twist on real life.
lead_paragraph: Before summer tent poles are fully erected, and science fiction is dominated by spaceships, superheroes and special effects, “Frequencies” arrives to remind us that all sci-fi truly requires is a slightly surreal twist on life.

headline: Assad’s Forces Break Yearlong Rebel Siege of Prison
abstract: Government forces broke through a protracted rebel siege of one of Syria’s largest prisons on Thursday, revealing emaciated prisoners and dealing yet another blow to opponents of President Bashar al-Assad.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Government forces broke through a protracted rebel siege of one of Syria’s largest prisons on Thursday, dealing yet another blow to their opponents and highlighting the suffering that the country’s war has brought to those caught between the warring parties.

headline: Poll Finds Only Narrow Majority Supports Egypt’s Expected Big Winner

headline: Sanctions Imposed Against Boko Haram
abstract: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday added Boko Haram, the Nigerian extremist group, to its Al Qaeda Sanctions List, a blacklist of individuals and organizations affiliated with Al Qaeda.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council on Thursday added Boko Haram, the Nigerian extremist group, to its Al Qaeda Sanctions List, a blacklist of individuals and organizations affiliated with Al Qaeda. The designation subjects Boko Haram members to penalties that include a freeze on assets, a travel ban and an arms embargo. Nigeria had sought the designation as part of a broader response to a wave of attacks on schools and other targets by the group and its kidnapping of nearly 300 schoolgirls last month. The Security Council designation announcement cited the group’s avowed affinity and collaboration with Al Qaeda and its “violent insurgency utilizing terrorist tactics.” The designation was welcomed by Samantha Power, the United States ambassador, who said the Council’s action had “helped to close off important avenues of funding, travel and weapons to Boko Haram, and shown global unity against their savage actions.”

headline: Iraq: Bombings Kill at Least 35 Pilgrims
abstract: Suicide bombers and car bombs killed at least 35 Shiite pilgrims and wounded dozens more in attacks in Baghdad on Thursday, security officials said.
lead_paragraph: Suicide bombers and car bombs killed at least 35 Shiite pilgrims and wounded dozens more in attacks in Baghdad on Thursday, security officials said. The pilgrims were on their way to the shrine of a Shiite saint in Kadhimiya, in northern Baghdad, to commemorate the anniversary of his death. A day earlier, Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki urged the security forces to protect pilgrims traveling to the shrine. The deadliest attack took place in the Ur neighborhood of eastern Baghdad, where a car bomb exploded near a tent for pilgrims, killing 14 people, including four children, security officials said. “We need a new government that is able to protect us from those terrorists that are the enemies of God,” said a man wounded in the Ur bombing, Jafar al-Musawi. An attack in central Baghdad by a suicide bomber killed 12 pilgrims and wounded 26, and in the western Baghdad neighborhood of Mansour, a car bomb killed nine people and wounded 20, officials said.

headline: What’s On Friday

(LMN) WINTER’S BONE (2010) Jennifer Lawrence received her first Oscar nomination for her role as Ree Dolly, a teenager living in the Ozarks of southwestern Missouri who goes in search of her meth-cooking father after he puts up the family home to cover his bail and disappears. But her efforts to find him place her in a terrible dilemma: either betray the code of silence that keeps her clan proudly on the wrong side of the law or face destitution. (Above from left, Ashlee Thompson, Ms. Lawrence and Isaiah Stone in the film.) John Hawkes plays her uncle, whose silent menace soon erupts into violence, though he’s more compassionate than most. The harshness in Debra Granik’s “regional-realist morality tale,” based on the novel by Daniel Woodrell, “is not there to illuminate a sociological condition,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “Something more primal, almost Greek in its archaic power, is at stake in ‘Winter’s Bone,’ and its visual and emotional starkness do not feel like simple badges of authenticity.”

abstract: Tata Motors is trying to resurrect sales of the Nano with a new model that has modern features, but a higher price tag.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — When Tata Motors rolled out a supercheap compact vehicle in 2009, the automaker heralded the car saying it would change the lives of millions of Indians, particularly its aspirational middle class. But the egg-shaped car, the Nano, failed to impress and sales have been sluggish, undercut by an image of poor quality and underwhelming power.

headline: Back to Normal Swedish Teenage Angst
abstract: The director Lukas Moodysson, whose new film is about a teenage punk band, says he is caught between his younger self and “the old guy” he has become.
lead_paragraph: Ingmar Bergman, Sweden’s most celebrated auteur, anointed his countryman Lukas Moodysson “a young master.” Mr. Moodysson was a published poet at 17 and, thanks to his first film, “Show Me Love,” was widely considered the new voice of Swedish cinema before he hit 30. Yet he has reacted with a kind of overgrown teenage disdain for the establishment: He has berated and made obscene gestures toward audiences and critics at awards receptions, avoided the press and once declared himself the most hated man in his native country. The guy was a stone punk.

headline: Terrorists With Familiar Faces
abstract: Kelly Reichardt’s new drama, “Night Moves” joins a potent list of films about American terrorists.
lead_paragraph: Explosions and mayhem are a staple of summer blockbusters, whether brought about by hundred-foot robots or averted by superheroes. But what if the people blowing things up have a political agenda — like the radical environmentalists of Kelly Reichardt’s new drama, “Night Moves”? And what if they’re homegrown, not the stereotypical accented villains? Then it gets trickier: Everyone from moviegoers to producers to politicians can become sensitive when the characters are plausible, their politics real and their tactics deadly.

lead_paragraph: Frank O’Hara, a founder of the New York School of poets, died at age 40 in the summer of 1966, after being hit by a dune buggy on Fire Island. Now, his reputation only burnished by posthumous publications of several collections of his work, the Fire Island Pines Arts Project is sponsoring the first national poetry festival in his honor.

headline: Must the Captain Always Go Down With the Ship?
keywords: ['Maritime Accidents and Safety', 'Writing and Writers', 'Ethics (Personal)', 'Drownings', 'Evacuations and Evacuees', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: Plus: The ethics of ethnicity-bending pen names.
lead_paragraph: In light of the South Korean ferry tragedy, I have been thinking about the maxim that the captain goes down with the ship. I find it outdated and in need of re-evaluation. Clearly the captain has a duty and responsibility to ensure the safety of his passengers, and he should do everything in his power as the ship is sinking to save the lives of others. But should he be morally obligated to effectively commit suicide because he made a mistake, even if it was a result of gross negligence and leads to hundreds of deaths? RYAN CAIN, NEW YORK

headline: The MacGyver Cure for Cancer
keywords: ['Cervical Cancer', 'Tests (Medical)', 'Women and Girls', 'Third World and Developing Countries']
abstract: To prevent a disease that kills a woman every two minutes in the developing world, start with a headlamp.
lead_paragraph: Two decades ago, David Walmer went on a volunteer mission with his church to Haiti. He was sent to paint walls at a hospital in the seaside town of Léogâne, but when the people there learned that Walmer was a doctor — he was a fertility specialist at Duke University — they asked him to spend the week with a local obstetrician-gynecologist named Jean-Claude Fertilien. Walmer was shocked by what he saw: Fertilien finishing a hysterectomy with the aid of a flashlight when the hospital generator failed to restart, for instance, or when an anesthesiologist wasn’t available for an emergency C-section, the doctor just numbing the skin and cutting. At one point, Walmer was called to the bedside of a young woman in her mid-20s with undiagnosed cervical cancer who had gone into septic shock. There was nothing to be done for her, and she died right in front of him. Walmer was appalled. In the United States, cervical cancer is considered a preventable disease.

headline: Who Made That Weather Icon?
abstract: Evolving beyond dots for rain, asterisks for snow and triangles for rain showers.
lead_paragraph: As a design student at the Norwich School of Art in the early 1970s, Mark Allen watched the weather broadcast every afternoon on the BBC. Back then, TV presenters slid magnetic symbols around a metal map: dots for rain, asterisks for snow, lines to mark off areas of equal pressure. “They were just hieroglyphics as far as everybody was concerned,” Allen says. “Why was a triangle a rain shower?”

headline: On Lockdown
abstract: Students prepare for the threat of school shootings.
lead_paragraph: The “duck and cover” drills of the 1950s, when American schoolchildren crawled under their desks in preparation for a nuclear bomb, have given way to regular lockdown drills in many states to counter the threat of school shootings. The photographer Alec Soth recently visited the Belle Plaine public high school, an hour outside Minneapolis, to witness its routine. When the principal announced that a lockdown was in effect, classroom doors were quickly locked; students who were in the middle of gym class moved to locker rooms and secured the doors behind them. For several minutes, they sat on the floor, heads lowered. “It was pretty silent,” Soth says. “They were fairly nonchalant about the whole routine.” Julie Bosman

headline: Can the Nervous System Be Hacked?
abstract: Welcome to the brave new world of bioelectronics: implants that can communicate directly with the nervous system in order to try to fight everything from cancer to the common cold.
lead_paragraph: One morning in May 1998, Kevin Tracey converted a room in his lab at the Feinstein Institute for Medical Research in Manhasset, N.Y., into a makeshift operating theater and then prepped his patient — a rat — for surgery. A neurosurgeon, and also Feinstein Institute’s president, Tracey had spent more than a decade searching for a link between nerves and the immune system. His work led him to hypothesize that stimulating the vagus nerve with electricity would alleviate harmful inflammation. “The vagus nerve is behind the artery where you feel your pulse,” he told me recently, pressing his right index finger to his neck.

headline: On the Road Again
abstract: A 40-something rock singer looks to revive a career she had long abandoned.
lead_paragraph: Much like smell (it’s all very well to say that something smells “like an orange,” but how do you describe the smell of an orange?), music is notoriously difficult to evoke on the page. The fact that language has musical attributes — rhythm, melody, tone — isn’t much help when you’re trying to express Bartok or Captain Beefheart in words. Even when music has lyrics, its essence is antilanguage, or at least in another language — and an inability to translate explains why so many album and concert reviews are unreadable. Thus Stacey D’Erasmo’s most impressive accomplishment in her fourth novel, “Wonderland,” is to write about music well.

headline: By the Booker
abstract: In a change of pace, Edward St. Aubyn’s novel satirizes the awarding of a British literary prize.
lead_paragraph: Edward St. Aubyn is that thing beloved by heritage series from the BBC, a man of ancient and aristocratic pedigree. He writes of an upper-class world so central to the English novel of the 19th and early 20th centuries, it has shaped the modern imagination: You might think we all sprang from big houses with handmade wallpaper and quietly smoldering servants. St. Aubyn cuts through the fantasy of privilege, however, with lacerating precision; once you have read his Melrose cycle of novels, there is no going back. These books — “Never Mind,” “Bad News,” “Some Hope,” “Mother’s Milk” and “At Last” — set a marker in the English tradition by changing our view of what preceded them. The narrator, Patrick Melrose, is raped at the age of 5 by his sadistic, patrician father and later partially disinherited by his cold and foolish mother. After Melrose, the aristocratic novel, from Richardson’s swooning “Pamela” to the affectless cruelties of Waugh, can never look the same again.

headline: Please Turn to the Chapter on Obscurity . . .
abstract: Some humiliations experienced by writers are more in-your-face than others.
lead_paragraph: The woman at the counter in Barnes & Noble had silver hair in a bun and a smile like breakfast. I was with a friend, for whom I was buying a copy of my latest book. I do this often — buy my own books for friends, then wonder why I’m broke. “May I take a moment to sign it?” I asked the smiling woman. “Did you write it?” she asked. “No,” I said. “I just like signing books.” Unmoved, she asked, “Is this your first book?” I shook my head no, and continued inscribing. “It must be fun to write books,” she said. “Superfun,” I said.

headline: Billionaire Boys Club
abstract: A journalist looks at the business, social and political ambitions of one of America’s most powerful dynasties.
lead_paragraph: In 2010, two of the Koch brothers, Charles of Wichita, Kan., and David of New York, rather suddenly became the top-of-mind conservatives for American liberals. That was partly because at that moment the Democratic Party controlled the White House and both houses of Congress, so there wasn’t a dominant conservative politician to focus on; partly because of a wave of news media attention, notably an influential story on the Kochs’ political activities by Jane Mayer in The New Yorker; and partly because of the rise of the Tea Party movement, of which the Koch political apparatus was a primary backer. The conservative victories in the Congres­sional elections that fall looked like conclusive proof of the Kochs’ power. The very first television ads the Obama re-election campaign ran in 2012 were attacks on the Kochs, not on the Republican Party.

headline: Wielding the Knife
abstract: Behind the scenes at a fictional restaurant with a sadistic chef.
lead_paragraph: At its best, food is a sensory pleasure that also fosters less tangible joys. At its worst, to paraphrase one of the many vivid characters in Simon Wroe’s first novel, “Chop Chop,” watching someone eat is like watching a body convert food to waste right in front of your eyes. The character phrases it less delicately, but many of the book’s funniest moments — and they are plentiful — are also its most unprintable.

headline: Hive Mentality
abstract: In this novel, a curious and courageous bee makes her way in an authoritarian world.
lead_paragraph: Laline Paull’s ambitious and bold first novel, “The Bees,” follows Flora 717, a sanitation worker doomed by her birth to the lowest caste of her community. She is large and ugly and — oh, yes — a bee. What could feel gimmicky or cute never does; Flora 717 is a brave and spirited soul, and it is a pleasure to follow her through the hive and the air. The brief prologue and epilogue are the only sections of the book with humans, aside from a single scene halfway through in which a man harvesting honey comes off something like Godzilla. Truly, who needs people when bees provide this much pathos?

headline: Man With Many Qualities
abstract: The third installment of Karl Ove Knausgaard’s six-volume autobiographical novel.
lead_paragraph: On Page 92 of the slate-gray third volume of the six-part Norwegian novel “My Struggle,” by Karl Ove Knausgaard — an autobiographical work that offers detailed accounts of events like the teenage Karl Ove trying to sneak alcohol to a New Year’s party (Book 1), the paternal Karl Ove attending a children’s birthday party (Book 2) and the child Karl Ove eating, on two different occasions, cornflakes (Book 3) — we learn that the headmaster of Karl Ove’s grade school was a diver who discovered a slave ship sunk off Norway’s coast in 1768.

headline: Writer’s Retreat
abstract: A student moves to her parents’ cabin to finish a dissertation.
lead_paragraph: A doctoral dissertation not getting written is never just a doctoral dissertation not getting written. It’s always a stand-in for something more consequential (take it from a former grad student who knows). But when we encounter Cressida (Cress) Hartley, the protagonist of Michelle Huneven’s fourth novel, “Off Course,” she doesn’t realize this yet. In fact, she has just persuaded her parents to allow her to live in their vacation cabin in California’s Sierra Nevada for “three months free and clear,” so that she can “bang . . . out” her dissertation in economics. The 28-year-old, high-achieving Cress comes from cautious, stingy stock, a foundation that gives her a natural aptitude for her field: Her father is a “traumatized victim of the Great Depression,” and his “fears and obsessions had imprinted her with thought patterns that, superficially at least, were indistinguishable from the mind-set of a trained economist: What is given up to get this? What is the true cost? Whose self-interest is going to ­prevail?”

headline: Problem Child
abstract: A “novel-from-life” by the author of “Girl, Interrupted.”
lead_paragraph: It’s not that the protagonist of Susanna Kaysen’s novel “Cambridge,” a 1950s elementary-school student also named Susanna, is trying to be difficult. It’s just that getting in the way of herself and others comes so naturally. Bright, sensitive and deeply neurotic, Susanna sees “malevolence” in certain toilets and thinks, as she shucks corn in advance of a dinner with adored family friends, “Something about corn was sad.” Visiting famous monuments sends her into an existential tailspin, and by the time she’s 9 she’s already mourning her lost youth. At school, she’s bored and disdainful. When her sixth-grade teacher gives examples of solids, liquids and gases, Susanna raises her hand to ask, “What about mayonnaise?”

headline: The Transformative Power of Transparency
abstract: Dov Seidman, in an Apology Watch Q. and A., discusses with Richard Boothman of the University of Michigan Health Systems, how its approach to apologies has helped transform the medical culture.
lead_paragraph: Doctors don’t traditionally apologize for medical errors; in fact, they usually don’t even disclose them. That is why I have long been interested in how the University of Michigan Health Systems has bucked tradition with its Michigan Model, a collaborative and transparent approach to patient safety and medical mistakes.

headline: An Inconvenient Past
abstract: Two books on China examine a rapidly transforming society and its relationship to an often censored history.
lead_paragraph: During the night of June 3-4, 1989, when the Chinese Army was slaughtering demonstrators in Tiananmen Square, Wang Nan, a young student, was shot in the head. As he lay dying at the side of the road, soldiers threatened to kill anyone, even some young doctors, who tried to help him. In the morning, finally dead, he was buried in a shallow grave nearby. A few days later, the smell of Wang Nan’s body was so great that it was dug up and moved to a hospital.

lead_paragraph: There’s a scene in “My Accidental Jihad” in which Krista Bremer visits her husband’s relatives in Libya and sees a wheezing, skeletal old woman lying on a hospital bed in their living room.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Jeffery Deaver, whose thriller “The Skin Collector” is No. 8 on the hardcover fiction list, breeds show dogs and once passed up dinner with Angelina Jolie to tend to a dog’s matted coat.
lead_paragraph: Dog Days: Jeffery Deaver’s new Lincoln Rhyme thriller, “The Skin Collector,” makes its debut on the hardcover fiction list at No. 8. Part of the perverse allure of this series — which now numbers some dozen books — has always come from the demented nature of its villains, and “The Skin Collector” is no exception: It features a ­serial-killing tattoo artist who makes his own ink out of a slow-acting and painful poison. But a person can spend only so many hours a day inventing gruesome murder schemes, and one of the ways Deaver likes to unwind is by breeding show dogs with a business partner near his North Carolina home. “I’m not as creepy as the things I write about,” he told The Associated Press in 2007. That doesn’t mean you can’t question his priorities — he once passed up dinner with Angelina Jolie to tend to a dog’s matted coat. But Deaver knows what he’s doing: His briards have won Best of Breed more than once at the Westminster Kennel Club show in New York. “Your heart’s pounding,” he told a reporter in 2005, comparing the experience to that of a father watching a Little League game. “You’ll still love the dog just as much if he doesn’t win. But I can’t help it. I hope he wins.” Given the elaborate plot twists and psychological head games in his novels, is Deaver ever tempted to mess with his dogs’ minds, just a little? “I couldn’t possibly do that,” he told The Sun Herald newspaper in Australia in 2006. “The dogs are much cleverer than me.”

headline: Ghosts of Hanoi
abstract: Vietnamese folklore shapes a collection of otherworldly tales.
lead_paragraph: In “Boat Story,” the first offering from “The Frangipani Hotel,” Violet Kupersmith’s subversively clever debut collection, a teenage girl in Houston, from a family of Vietnam War refugees, asks her grandmother to recount her sea journey to the United States for a school assignment. “Communists! Thai pirates! Starvation!” the girl says. “That’s an A-plus story.”
