headline: Baseball’s Role in J.F.K.’s Life
abstract: He was identified with touch football, but the national pastime was woven through John F. Kennedy’s political career.
lead_paragraph: Here a frail 28-year-old John F. Kennedy, still not fully recovered from injuries sustained in 1943 when his PT-109 was struck by a Japanese destroyer in World War II, poses at Fenway Park in Boston in April 1946 with Ted Williams and Eddie Pellagrini of the Red Sox and Hank Greenberg of the Detroit Tigers. The neophyte J.F.K. is about to face nine opponents in a Democratic congressional primary — and he is seeking the reflected glory of being seen in the proximity of baseball stars.

headline: Strangers Come to the Village
abstract: Abbas Kiarostami’s lovely, oblique movie “The Wind Will Carry Us” is being shown at IFC Center in honor of its 15th anniversary.
lead_paragraph: Great film stylists still roam the earth. For evidence, look no further than the Iranian director Abbas Kiarostami, whose lovely, oblique movie “The Wind Will Carry Us” is being shown at IFC Center, beginning Friday, in honor of its 15th anniversary.

headline: A Desperate Mother’s Search Leads to a Fight Against Sex Trafficking
abstract: Desperate for answers about her daughter’s disappearance in 2002, Susana Trimarco started the Fundación María de los Ángeles, an organization that rescues and rehabilitates sex slaves in Argentina.
lead_paragraph: SAN MIGUEL DE TUCUMÁN, Argentina — HERE in the impoverished north of Argentina, sex traffickers search among the vulnerable for targets. Typically, they lure women with deceitful job offers and then traffic them to big cities, mining towns and agricultural regions, where they are forced into sex slavery.

headline: Judge Rules That Harper Lee Can Renew Suit Against Museum
abstract: A lawsuit by Harper Lee against a museum in Alabama, which appeared to have been settled, has been scheduled to go to trial in November.
lead_paragraph: The wheels of justice apparently turn quickly in Alabama. When lawyers for Harper Lee filed to reinstate her lawsuit against the Monroe County Heritage Museum for what she says is the unauthorized marketing of merchandise based on her 1960 novel, “To Kill a Mockingbird,” a federal judge said that he needed more information. (The lawyers sought to reinstate the suit because, they said, the museum was backtracking on an out-of-court agreement reached in February.)

headline: No MetroCard Needed
abstract: New Yorkers on bicycles can go beyond the boundaries of the subway map when searching for a place to live.
lead_paragraph: It was cheaper rent that initially drew Jesse Warner-Levine, 34, and Hallie Nickelson, 33, to Wallabout, a fairly isolated Brooklyn neighborhood on the fringe of Clinton Hill near the Brooklyn Navy Yard. But it was bicycling that made them stay.

headline: Hague Court Sentences Congolese Warlord to 12 Years for Role in Tribal Massacre
keywords: ['War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Child Soldiers']
abstract: Germain Katanga is only the second person to be convicted by the International Criminal Court in the decade since its work began.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The International Criminal Court in The Hague sentenced a Congolese militia leader, Germain Katanga, on Friday to 12 years in prison for his role in an attack on a village in 2003 where, within hours, more than 200 civilians were shot or hacked to death, limb by limb.

headline: After Hours | A Family-Style Fete to Honor Robert Longo
abstract: Since the night was hosted by the arts space the Kitchen, some of the guests, including Longo, Tunde Adebimpe of TV on the Radio and Monica Lewinsky, revealed secrets about their own kitchens.
lead_paragraph: The New York artist Robert Longo may be most famous for his black-and-white Men in the Cities images of the early ’80s — which became such icons of yuppiedom that they appeared in Patrick Bateman’s apartment in the film adaptation of “American Psycho.” Like other New York art-world royalty, including Cindy Sherman, Philip Glass, Bill T. Jones, Laurie Anderson and Vito Acconci, he has long been a champion of the 43-year-old arts space The Kitchen, where he worked as a video curator for four years beginning in 1977.

headline: New Online Magazine Honors the Mighty Schwa
abstract: Schwa Fire is a new online magazine about language and life.
lead_paragraph: The schwa — the vowel sound at the end of the word “America,” represented in dictionary pronunciation guides with a backward and upside down “e” (ə) — is the most common vowel sound in the English language. And now it is also the namesake of a new online magazine about language and life.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: A Movie That Challenges Putin
abstract: The director of “Leviathan” said he had shown the film to Russia’s culture minister, who didn’t like it but who did not rule out government money for future projects.
lead_paragraph: CANNES — The Russian director Andrey Zvyagintsev’s latest film, “Leviathan,” tells the story of Kolia, a man fighting to keep his seaside house in a justice system all but beholden to a corrupt local mayor. The family drama can be read as the story of Job filtered through Chekhov, but also as a scathing indictment of Russia under President Vladimir Putin.

headline: In Chicago, a Dramatic Expansion of the Riverwalk
abstract: New sections of Chicago’s Riverwalk will include gardens, fountains, and docks.
lead_paragraph: In an effort to bring people together near the city’s “second shoreline,” Chicago has begun updates to its original Riverwalk with certain sections expected to be completed by summer 2015.

headline: Feeding the Financial District
keywords: ['Restaurants', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Historic Buildings and Sites', 'Real Estate (Commercial)']
abstract: Building a multimillion-dollar hospitality business, the Poulakakos family has managed to create an ecosystem that also saves city landmarks.
lead_paragraph: If you’ve spent any time in Lower Manhattan and had a cappuccino at a patisserie, a 10-inch pie at a pizza place, or a pint of Guinness in a wood-paneled pub, chances are you were patronizing an establishment owned by Peter Poulakakos.

headline: Traveling with Elderly Parents
abstract: Val Grubb, blogger, shares tips she’s gathered from vacationing with her octogenarian mother.
lead_paragraph: Caring for an aging parent can be stressful. And one thing that could help — a long-needed vacation — sometimes only adds to the stress.

headline: Never Mind Stocks. Just Buy the Company.
keywords: ['Stocks and Bonds', 'Private Equity', 'High Net Worth Individuals', 'Personal Finances']
abstract: Directly investing in companies or private equity funds carries plenty of risks, but the rewards can be substantial.
lead_paragraph: AFTER years of litigation against the side of his family that controlled his grandfather’s coffee business, Steven D. Crowe woke up on New Year’s Day 2004 with a lot of money in the bank — $111 million, according to reports at the time. Having developed and managed real estate for decades, he said he knew little about the stock market, so he invested the money broadly for his mother and sister and his own family.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
abstract: This week, Nicholas Lemann discusses “Sons of Wichita”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Louisa Lim talks about “The People’s Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.
lead_paragraph: This week, Nicholas Lemann discusses “Sons of Wichita”; Parul Sehgal and John Williams on the week’s literary news; Louisa Lim talks about “The People’s Republic of Amnesia: Tiananmen Revisited”; and Gregory Cowles has best-seller news. Pamela Paul is the host.

headline: Blueberries for All
abstract: If there are such things as “super foods,” the blueberry would be among them. With domestic berries now showing up in supermarkets, here are recipes – some for dessert, some not – that put them to good use.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been saving up blueberry recipes. I know that blueberries won’t show up in farmers’ markets in northern states until mid-June, but there are plenty now available in supermarkets from places like Georgia, which grows 10 percent of the nation’s crop. In California, where blueberry production is a recent thing, begun successfully only in the 1990s, the harvest started in February. So I’ve been biding my time.

headline: Women Alert to Travel’s Darker Side
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Sex Crimes', 'Sexual Harassment', 'Americans Abroad', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Assaults']
abstract: Calculating the risk of violence against female travelers abroad.
lead_paragraph: Between sun-seared shrubs and the collapsed remains of Istanbul’s Byzantine city walls, police found the body of an American tourist, Sarai Sierra, 33, in February 2013. Ms. Sierra, a New Yorker and a first-time traveler abroad, disappeared after near-constant contact with her family for two weeks. What happened to her is still a little unclear, but a Turkish man has reportedly confessed to killing her after supposedly trying to kiss her.

headline: U.N. Panel Says Vatican Is Lax Over Abusive Priests
abstract: The panel criticized the Roman Catholic Church, saying it failed to report sexual abuse to civil authorities or to compensate victims.
lead_paragraph: GENEVA — The Vatican on Friday faced criticism from a United Nations panel for the second time this year over failures to report priests accused of sexually abusing children to civil authorities or to ensure redress for victims.

headline: Inside The New York Times Book Review: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
abstract: This week, Nicholas Lemann and Louisa Lim.
lead_paragraph: This week, Nicholas Lemann and Louisa Lim.

headline: Amazon Unveils Children’s Show
abstract: “Tumble Leaf” is a stop-motion animated series featuring a blue fox named Fig and a little yellow bird whose mouth looks a lot like a certain logo.
lead_paragraph: Amazon’s deliberate rollout of original online series — comedy series in November, drama pilots in February — continued Friday with the posting of six episodes of its first children’s series, “Tumble Leaf.” The initial episode is free from Amazon Instant Video while the other five require a Prime membership.

headline: At French Open, a Rare Early Meeting Is Possible for the Williams Sisters
abstract: Serena Williams and Rafael Nadal, the No. 1 seeds for the Paris tournament, received tricky routes to the final at the draw ceremony on Friday.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Rafael Nadal, an eight-time winner of the French Open, cringed and smiled nervously as the 25th chip he pulled at the draw ceremony for the women’s singles tournament at Roland Garros set up 29th-seeded Venus Williams into a possible third-round meeting with her sister Serena, the top seed and defending champion.

headline: A Health Nominee Who Can Disarm Republicans
abstract: The full Senate should promptly confirm Sylvia Matthews Burwell.
lead_paragraph: Now that Sylvia Mathews Burwell, President Obama’s nominee to head the embattled Department of Health and Human Services, has been endorsed by a bi-partisan majority of one Senate committee and treated cordially by another, the full Senate ought to vote promptly to confirm her nomination. She is extremely well-qualified to handle the department’s most pressing administrative tasks and seems able to reach consensus with, or at least disarm and charm, Republican opponents who are often adamantly opposed to cooperating in any way with the Obama administration.

headline: Pea Salad With Creamy Cheese
abstract: Melissa Clark makes a salad that is the perfect balance between freshness and richness, featuring crunchy sugar snap peas, pea shoots and ripe, runny cheese.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Clark makes a salad that is the perfect balance between freshness and richness, featuring crunchy sugar snap peas, pea shoots and ripe, runny cheese.

headline: Peas Love Cheese, and Vice Versa
abstract: In this refined salad, tender pea shoots and crunchy sugar snap peas are a fresh counterpart to the unctuous creaminess of Camembert.
lead_paragraph: File this under the easiest party recipes you’ll ever make: Take a runny, stinky, washed-rind cheese, scrape the top off with a spoon, then serve the oozing disk as a dip with raw sugar snap peas on the side. It requires about five minutes of effort if you trim the peas (fancy), two minutes if you don’t (rustic). It’s a dish more about shopping than cooking, but the result is voluptuous, unexpected and impossible to stop eating.

headline: Your Turn: A Weekend Thread, Open for Comments
abstract: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to Motherlode’s weekly open thread. Do you have thoughts about the news this week, and how it affects families? A question to ask? A rant to share? This is your place. Go.

headline: A Rare Capitol Hill Sighting: The Legislative Process
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: The Senate held a roll-call vote on a conference report, something that has happened only once before this Congress.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday the Senate did something remarkable: it passed a conference report to a bill.

headline: Book Review Podcast: The Saga of the Koch Brothers
abstract: Nicholas Lemann discusses Daniel Schulman’s “Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became America’s Most Powerful and Private Dynasty.”
lead_paragraph: In The New York Times Book Review, Nicholas Lemann reviews Daniel Schulman’s “Sons of Wichita: How the Koch Brothers Became America’s Most Powerful and Private Dynasty.” Mr. Lemann writes:

headline: Image of the Day: May 23
abstract: Sikhs celebrated the 535th anniversary of the birth of Guru Amardas, the third master of the Sikhs.

headline: Together Again to Go the Distance
abstract: Thirty-three years after the first proposal, Tina Rozzi and Ray “Boom Boom” Mancini married on Santa Monica Beach.
lead_paragraph: On a summer day in 1981, Ray Mancini attended a pool party at the home of Tina Rozzi in Campbell, Ohio.

headline: Apax Partners Selling Majority Stake in Travelex Group
abstract: The stake in Travelex, which trades in more than 80 currencies and operates currency exchange stores around the world, will be bought by a group led by the billionaire B.R. Shetty.
lead_paragraph: LONDON – Funds advised by the private equity firm Apax Partners are selling their majority stake in the Travelex Group, a foreign exchange specialist, to a group led by the billionaire Bavaguthu Raghuram Shetty, Apax said Friday.

headline: European Regulators to Start Inquiry Into eBay Data Breach
abstract: Regulators will begin an investigation into the online market after hackers gained access to the personal data of 145 million customers.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The fallout from the data breach at eBay has reached Europe.

headline: Residential Sales Around the Region
abstract: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.
lead_paragraph: Information on sales in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: HP’s Whitman on PC Decline and Job Cuts
keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Layoffs and Job Reductions']
abstract: Meg Whitman, Hewlett-Packard’s chief executive, took to CNBC on Friday morning to discuss the company’s prospects, noting how cutting thousands of jobs would help it be more efficient in transitioning into what is looking to be a post-PC world.
lead_paragraph: Hewlett-Packard, until recently the world’s largest technology company in terms of revenue, released tepid quarterly results on Thursday. They showed a once industry-leading computer maker continuing to limp along in a world increasingly defined by smartphones and cloud computing.

headline: In Era of Humble Pope, Earth Shifts Under Cardinal Dolan
abstract: Timothy M. Dolan, the archbishop of New York and once the go-to American cardinal for many in the Vatican, is navigating changes in the Roman Catholic world wrought by the election of Pope Francis.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan lives in a 19th-century Madison Avenue mansion that connects to St. Patrick’s Cathedral. A cook and two housekeepers serve him and three other priests. A driver chauffeurs him around, though in a Chrysler minivan.

headline: Praise Poems: Ellen Bass Talks About ‘Like a Beggar’
abstract: Ms. Bass discusses the poets who inspire her, the role of compassion in her work and more.
lead_paragraph: Ellen Bass’s new poetry collection, “Like a Beggar” (Copper Canyon), pulses with sex, humor and compassion. Ms. Bass takes her cues as a poet, and as a person, from Rilke, whom she quotes to open “Beggar”: “But those dark, deadly, devastating ways,/how do you bear them, suffer them?/— I praise.” Her poetry, and this book in particular, fairly bursts with such praise. Below are edited excerpts from an email conversation with Ms. Bass about poetry and more.

headline: U.N. Chief Urges Aid Delivery Without Syria’s Consent
abstract: The request by Secretary General Ban Ki-moon, in a report to the Security Council, is his strongest push to bypass Syria’s government to deliver aid.
lead_paragraph: UNITED NATIONS — The Syrian government is “failing in its responsibility to look after its own people,” the secretary general of the United Nations has said in a confidential report to the Security Council, in which he urged it to authorize the delivery of food and medicine to Syria without the government’s consent.

headline: A Farewell, With Beer and Pizza
abstract: The latest outpost of Fornino, the Brooklyn pizza franchise, has already proved popular with visitors to Brooklyn Bridge Park.
lead_paragraph: Some people’s version of culinary heaven is tournedos of beef with a supple cabernet at a white-clothed table under candlelight. Others might prefer the offerings at the new Fornino restaurant in Brooklyn Bridge Park: thin-crust pizza and local beer at a picnic table with a view of New York Harbor. On a roof deck, just across the water from Manhattan, this latest outpost of the Brooklyn pizza franchise — its sister shops are in Williamsburg and Greenpoint — has already proved popular with visitors to the park, which opened its manufactured beach and pop-up pool on May 22. On a recent evening, the place was crowded with frolicking families, post-work drinkers and a large party from the Brooklyn Bridge Park Corporation celebrating the imminent departure of one its workers.

headline: Alibaba’s American Aspirations
abstract: The web giant is backing start-ups in Silicon Valley and introducing an online marketplace, 11 Main, aimed at U.S. shoppers and meant to compete with eBay.
lead_paragraph: Herb and Martha Oberman have made a good living on eBay for 17 years, selling paper collectibles like a $5,000 limited-edition menu from the Hotel Bel-Air, the Los Angeles hotel once frequented by Marilyn Monroe.

headline: A Quick Take on Ukraine From the International Desk
abstract: “In stark contrast to the Orange Revolution of 2004, few people in Ukraine are in a celebratory mood,” said Kyle Crichton, the editor in charge of coverage there. He went on to explain why.
lead_paragraph: What’s the likely takeaway from the presidential election in Ukraine on Sunday? We asked Kyle Crichton, the editor in charge of coverage there, to weigh in.

headline: With a New Exhibition, the Mexican Artist Gabriel Kuri Makes His Home in L.A.
abstract: His show at his new West Coast gallery, Regen Projects, includes his signature folded wall-mounted pieces and sculptures made with Angeleno rocks that remind him of his native country.
lead_paragraph: New Yorkers might recognize the work of Gabriel Kuri from the wheat-pasted posters that were plastered around town in 2011, when his signature repurposed tickets and receipts were the graphic identity of that year’s Armory Show. The Mexican artist is known for incorporating a range of detritus and found objects into his practice, combining man-made and organic materials to hint at a borderless global economy of objects. Eight months ago, he became one of a number of prominent artists to relocate to Los Angeles, moving from Brussels, where he’d spent the last decade. His first show at Regen Projects, his new West Coast gallery, opens Saturday.

headline: Report of the Secretary General on Security Council Resolution 2139
abstract: The strongest push to date for a resolution that would enable United Nations agencies to deliver aid inside Syria.
lead_paragraph: The strongest push to date for a resolution that would enable United Nations agencies to deliver aid inside Syria.

headline: Fire Engulfs Historic Building at Glasgow School of Art
abstract: A treasured building by Charles Rennie Mackintosh faces destruction.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Firefighters in Scotland were battling to control a blaze on Friday that engulfed large parts of the Glasgow School of Art, one of Scotland’s most treasured buildings. There were no reports of any casualties, the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service said.

headline: Hagel’s Sex-Assault Remarks Resonate for New Navy Officers
abstract: A young woman at the center of a highly publicized rape case at the Naval Academy shook the hand of Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel on Friday and received her diploma.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, speaking to the graduating class at the United States Naval Academy on Friday, told the new officers he was counting on them to “lead in helping eliminate sexual harassment and sexual assault of your sisters and brothers in uniform.”

headline: Go Shop? Go Fish.
abstract: The tactic of seeking bids after signing up a buyer is intended to ensure top dollar. More often, writes Reynolds Holding of Reuters Breakingviews, it leads to low offers and sale prices, new research shows.
lead_paragraph: Shopping till you drop doesn’t really work for merger targets. The so-called “go shop” strategy of seeking higher bids after signing up a buyer is designed to ensure top dollar is paid. More often, it leads to final prices that are lower than they otherwise would be, new research suggests. Tweaks to deals like Media General’s buyout of Lin Media may mean sellers are wising up, though, portending better value for shareholders.

headline: Safety Agency Investigates Ram Pickups; Suzuki Recalls 184,000 Cars
keywords: ['Automobile Safety Features and Defects', 'Sports Utility Vehicles and Light Trucks', 'Recalls and Bans of Products']
abstract: The N.H.T.S.A. receives a report of a child killed by a Ram pickup; some Suzuki cars may catch fire; BMW recalls 6,400 X5 crossovers.
lead_paragraph: After receiving a report that a child was struck and killed, federal regulators have opened an investigation into whether 2004-6 Dodge Ram heavy-duty pickups equipped with manual transmissions can be started without the driver depressing the clutch pedal, causing the vehicle to move. The investigation covers about 110,000 Ram 2500 and 3500 pickups, according to a report posted on the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration website.

headline: Country Experiments With Rap
abstract: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff talk about the overlap of hip-hop and country.
lead_paragraph: Jon Caramanica and Ben Ratliff talk about the overlap of hip-hop and country.

headline: Dick Zigun: Surveying His Coney Island Realm
abstract: The unofficial mayor of Coney Island, Mr. Zigun spends his Sundays strolling the boardwalk, greeting people and tasting the fare.
lead_paragraph: As the unofficial mayor of Coney Island, Dick Zigun, 61, craves the craziness of summer. He is the founder of Coney Island USA, which runs the Coney Island Museum, the Coney Island Circus Sideshow and the Mermaid Parade. He spends Sundays strolling the boardwalk, chatting with locals and tourists, eating hot dogs and checking out the rides. He also spends time with his wife, Patience Mukoro White, 50, who performs in the sideshow as an escape artist, as a glass walker and as Madame Twisto, a contortionist. They live with their cat, Buddy, in a Coney Island loft that is being renovated, a project that was delayed by Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright and Norah Jones to Perform at the Clearwater Festival
abstract: This year’s festival will be the first since its founder, Peter Seeger, died in January.
lead_paragraph: Lucinda Williams, Rufus Wainwright, Richard Thompson and Norah Jones are among the musicians who will perform at the Clearwater Festival – or, more formally, the Great Hudson River Revival – at Croton Point Park, Croton-on-Hudson, on June 21 and 22.

headline: Cardinal Dolan Reflects on the ‘Pope Francis Effect’ in his Life and Work
abstract: The New York Times asked Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, New York’s archbishop, how the election of Pope Francis has changed the diocese and his personal life.
lead_paragraph: Cardinal Timothy M. Dolan, New York’s archbishop, traveled to Rome for the canonization of two popes, stayed on to speak at a communications conference there, jetted to Jordan to see the work of a Catholic charity he chairs, and once home, spoke at two graduations in the diocese — all in the past month. In other words, it was a typically busy month for him. So when The New York Times asked him, through a spokesperson, how the election of Pope Francis had changed the diocese and his own personal life, he asked that we submit a series of written questions.

headline: Sympathy for the Working Mother
abstract: Families that can flee New York City’s brutal summers by escaping to the beach or the mountains can engender ill will in those who cannot.
lead_paragraph: One morning recently I received a call from a friend who told me she had decided to leave her job after many years, one in which she commanded a lot of authority and was very well paid, to begin a new and as yet undetermined phase; she was taking advantage of a lucrative buyout her company had offered. I pointed out the fortuitous timing — it was May, which meant she would have the summer off, which meant she could leave the city, which meant she would be envied by a great number of people (arguably this year more than others because The Farmers’ Almanac is predicting a summer so hot, wet and muggy that New York will essentially feel like Biloxi, Miss.).

headline: Kerry Agrees to Testify on Benghazi, as Republicans Squabble Over Rival Inquiries
keywords: ['Benghazi Attack (2012)', 'United States International Relations', 'Diplomatic Service, Embassies and Consulates']
abstract: The State Department appeared to go out of its way to pit one investigation into the Benghazi attacks against a new one being conducted by a select committee.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Secretary of State John Kerry agreed on Friday to testify before the House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform over the 2012 attacks on the American diplomatic mission in Benghazi, Libya, possibly exacerbating tensions between Republicans over competing inquiries.

headline: A Better Way to Measure Fund-Raising? It Depends
abstract: The costs of direct mail are important to count in a more localized race, but national campaigns are a different matter.
lead_paragraph: My recent article offering a more accurate way of judging campaign fund-raising drew several responses, one from Bob Biersack, a former Federal Election Commission employee now with the Center for Responsive Politics. When journalists have needed to understand campaign finance during the past 30 years, Mr. Biersack has often supplied the answer, so his opinion is worth noting.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
abstract: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical.
lead_paragraph: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical.

headline: William Forsythe to No Longer Run Forsythe Dance Company
abstract: Starting in September 2015, William Forsythe, widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, will no longer run the company that is named for him. He will continue to be associated as an artistic adviser, a press statement announced on Friday, naming Jacopo Godani as the new artistic director.
lead_paragraph: Starting in September 2015, William Forsythe, widely recognized as one of the most important choreographers working today, will no longer run the company that is named for him. He will continue to be associated as an artistic adviser, a press statement announced on Friday. Jacopo Godani, a former dancer with Mr. Forsythe’s Ballet Frankfurt who is now a freelance choreographer, was named as the new artistic director.

headline: Speaking of Identity: Choosing Between Latino and Hispanic
abstract: It’s a challenging question, but people from Latin America have a slight preference for the term Hispanic.
lead_paragraph: Writers who cover demographics and politics are often confronted with the tricky matter of describing racial and ethnic groups. One particularly challenging question is whether to refer to people from Latin America as Hispanics or Latinos.

headline: Cuban Talks His Way Onto a Limb Occupied by Sterling
abstract: Mark Cuban, the owner of the Mavericks, sounded somewhat tone deaf while admitting that he harbors prejudice.
lead_paragraph: For nearly a month, Adam Silver, the commissioner of the N.B.A., has managed to isolate Donald Sterling, the owner of the Los Angeles Clippers, on an island. With one salvo of explosive comments, Mark Cuban, the owner of the Dallas Mavericks, has put his fellow team owners on that island as well.

headline: Bill Cunningham | The Winning Number Is
abstract: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical.
lead_paragraph: In a year when fashion accessories are the stars, the see-through bag shaped like a Chanel No. 5 bottle is the most whimsical. It seemed to sell out immediately and is now a collector’s item. Shown here, it is carried in daytime by all but two of the women. And for those who can’t get enough of the perfume bag, there’s a smartphone cover. We haven’t seen a novelty like this since Schiaparelli’s Surrealist accessories in the late 1930s. There are even Chanel sunglasses, with mademoiselle perched atop the frame.

headline: Weekend Reading: Grading Credit Suisse’s Plea and Memorial Day Travel Spots
abstract: Reaction to Credit Suisse’s guilty plea and 15 overlooked travel locations for Memorial Day.
lead_paragraph: Credit Suisse pleaded guilty this week to helping American account holders hide their wealth. The Swiss bank agreed to pay about $2.6 billion in penalties, but it kept its license to operate. The bank’s clients and shareholders welcomed the deal, but the Justice Department has been criticized for not pursuing a harsher penalty.

headline: Plan B: Open a Country Hotel in Upstate New York
abstract: Some New Yorkers, many of them from Brooklyn, are remaking themselves as hoteliers in a more pastoral corner of New York State.
lead_paragraph: When Rebecca Bales, a real estate agent in Brooklyn, and her husband, Kiley Thompson, assessed their financial and vocational prospects in 2012, they realized how hard it would be to get ahead. “We were either going to double down in our careers to do more than just pay the rent on our Park Slope apartment, or do something else,” said Mr. Thompson, an art director, sommelier and record label owner.

headline: Phone Swindlers Tap Into Fear and a Sense of Duty
abstract: Fraudsters leverage older people’s sense of responsibility, posing as relatives in need of help, or law enforcement officials.
lead_paragraph: BEFORE Betty Bell, 88, even got out of bed, the telephone jolted her awake at 7 a.m. The male voice on the line said that a police officer was coming to arrest her for shirking her civic duty.

headline: Game 3 Fallout: Stepan’s Jaw Is Broken, and Suspensions Are Issued
abstract: Montreal right wing Brandon Prust was suspended for two games, while Rangers left wing Daniel Carcillo drew a 10-game suspension for bumping an official after going after Prust following the hit.
lead_paragraph: There will be no need to manufacture animosity between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens heading into Game 4 of the Eastern Conference finals on Sunday. After Brandon Prust’s hit on Derek Stepan in Game 3 on Thursday night, the hostility is there for all to see and hear, and the question is how much it will shape a series that the Rangers now lead by two games to one.

headline: The AmfAR Gala: A Night for Movie Stars, Supermodels and Billionaires
abstract: AmfAR hosts its 21st annual Cinema Against AIDS gala at Cannes.
lead_paragraph: AmfAR hosts its 21st annual Cinema Against AIDS gala at Cannes.

headline: Times Minute | Pope Visits the Holy Land
abstract: Pope Francis embarks on a three-day trip to the Middle East. Jodi Rudoren, the Times’s Bureau chief, on what to watch from the visit.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis embarks on a three-day trip to the Middle East. Jodi Rudoren, the Times’s Bureau chief, on what to watch from the visit.

headline: A Creationist’s Influence on Darwin
abstract: Decades before “On the Origin of Species,” a theologian proposed — and rejected — a version of natural selection, and Darwin read about it in college.
lead_paragraph: In my last column, about the eerie machine-like nature of the AIDS virus, I mentioned William Paley, the 19th-century theologian best known today for his argument supporting creationism: Something as complex as a mechanical watch clearly would not exist without a creator. Thus we can infer that the intricacy of our bodies — and those of all creatures — is the work of God.

headline: Popcast: Country Embraces Hip-Hop
abstract: Ben Ratliff and Jon Caramanica discuss the increasing overlap between country music and rap.
lead_paragraph: On this week’s Popcast: the slow and circuitous loosening of modern country music. The perpetual story of the country music industry, our critic Jon Caramanica explains, is always how well it polices its own borders, how it maintain its core identity and resists assimilation into the rest of popular culture. But his cover story in Arts and Leisure this weekend analyzes how things may be decisively shifting right now, especially around rapping in country songs. The power of hip-hop reached critical mass across the country a long time ago; there are, he writes, “a generation of stars — mostly in their mid-late 30s, old enough to have grown up with hip-hop as a fact of life, even in the small towns they hail from, who think nothing of sprinkling a little bit of it into their music.”

My friend pulls her minivan in beside mine. “We’re late!” yell the four children between us and we hurry in, pay the $6 per child and head to the skate checkout line. headline: Author Changes His Mind on ’70s Manifesto
abstract: On the 43rd anniversary of his leftist manifesto “Open Veins,” the Uruguayan writer Eduardo Galeano says, “Reality has changed a lot, and I have changed a lot.”
lead_paragraph: For more than 40 years, Eduardo Galeano’s “The Open Veins of Latin America” has been the canonical anti-colonialist, anti-capitalist and anti-American text in that region. Hugo Chávez, Venezuela’s populist president, even put a copy of the book, which he had called “a monument in our Latin American history,” in President Obama’s hands the first time they met. But now Mr. Galeano, a 73-year-old Uruguayan writer, has disavowed the book, saying that he was not qualified to tackle the subject and that it was badly written. Predictably, his remarks have set off a vigorous regional debate, with the right doing some “we told you so” gloating, and the left clinging to a dogged defensiveness.

lead_paragraph: Some good news going into what will undoubtedly be a violent holiday weekend: A new report from Everytown for Gun Safety found that the number of mental health records submitted to the National Instant Criminal Background Check System (NICS) has tripled since 2011, preventing 65 percent more mentally ill people from purchasing firearms through licensed dealers. The reason? Increased federal funding and stronger record collection laws in 18 states.

headline: The Closest of Strangers
abstract: What happens when twins meet for the first time?
lead_paragraph: EARLIER this month, I helped reunite the fraternal twins Ann Hunt and Liz Hamel, who had been apart for 78 years. Born in England in 1936, they were separated at birth when their unmarried mother decided she could not care for both. Ann, the “prettier” sister, was given away, while Liz, the “less adoptable” baby marked by scoliosis, remained at home. Ann Hunt was unaware that she was a twin until last year, when her daughter made the discovery while researching their ancestry.

headline: King Richard III to Be Reburied in Leicester, British Court Says
abstract: The court ruled that the king, who died in 1485, should be reburied in a cathedral in Leicester,​ the city​ where his remains were found in a parking lot in 2012, and not in York.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — A British court ruled on Friday​ that King Richard III should be ​re​buried in a cathedral in Leicester,​ the city​ where his remains were found in a parking lot two years ago. The ruling was a defeat for the king’s descendants​ who wanted his remains to be reburied in York,​ arguing that he had spent ​much of his life there. But archaeologists who discovered the king’s remains decided to keep the body in Leicester, a decision backed by Britain’s Justice Ministry. The judges said, ​"There were no public law grounds for the court interfering with the decisions in question.”

Some grew up Catholic, some Jewish, some Protestant — but nearly all described journeys of acknowledging atheism first to themselves, then to loved ones. headline: Gender Imbalance in the Lab
abstract: It will take a concerted effort to ensure that drug treatments are tested in groups that reflect the patients who will be using them.
lead_paragraph: Federal health officials are taking steps to correct a longstanding gender imbalance in laboratory research on potential drug treatments. For the past two decades, federal law has required that women be included in clinical studies funded by the National Institutes of Health in recognition of the fact that drugs often have vastly different effects in men and women. As a result, more than half of the participants in N.I.H.-funded clinical research are women. But there has been no similar requirement to eliminate the sex bias from more basic laboratory research that can lead up to a clinical trial or doom a drug to the discard pile if it seems not to work.

headline: Pfizer’s Ploy and the Porous Tax Laws

It is a ploy made possible by porous tax laws in the United States that encourage corporate tax avoidance and by laws in Britain and elsewhere that abet it.

headline: What’s on Saturday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 10 P.M. (Cinemax) THE WORLD’S END (2013) In the summer of 1990, five British teenagers set out on a pub crawl in the town of Newton Haven, vomiting, fighting and having drunken sex along what is known as the Golden Mile. But they failed to make it through the 12 requisite watering holes, the last of which was called the World’s End. Twenty years later, they give it a second try in this comedy directed by Edgar Wright, the final installment in his Cornetto Trilogy, following “Shaun of the Dead” and “Hot Fuzz.” Nick Frost, Simon Pegg and Paddy Considine, along with Martin Freeman and Eddie Marsan, play the Golden Milers. Four have traded their wild youth for adult respectability; the fifth decidedly has not. Then the robots show up, and these men just may be humanity’s only hope for survival. “The Cornetto Trilogy is named after a popular ice cream treat, and the buzz of ‘The World’s End’ is more like an antic sugar high than a reeling, drunken stupor,” A. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times. “There are no headaches, dry mouth or crushing shame at the end — no ‘Hangover,’ in other words. I’ll drink to that.”

The few positions for restaurant servers, grocery stockers and cashiers were filled mostly by older women who needed that work to get by. Strangely, the job readily available to me was at the town bowling alley, where I worked one night a week as a pin boy.

Often, these are books I’ve not even read a review or essay about, yet I freely hold forth on the grandiosity of Cheryl Strayed or the restrained sentimentality of Edwidge Danticat. headline: Poet vs. Novelist
keywords: ['Books and Literature', 'Poetry and Poets', 'Writing and Writers']
abstract: How the two writers within me made peace.
lead_paragraph: The word novel carries for me a weight as ominous, all-consuming and unforgiving as any Job encountered. I was 17 when I decided to write stories as big as cathedrals, overflowing with the kind of memorable and audacious characters Walker Percy, Ernest Hemingway and Saul Bellow created. I stayed up all night, writing description, dialogue, plot curlicues, stories within stories, convinced that anything fewer than 10 pages was wasted time. One wrote the way Thomas Wolfe did, I thought, with fury and hubris, translating everything one read, experienced and felt into glistening, unswerving prose. I didn’t need drugs, cigarettes or caffeine; writing was my drug of choice. And the novel was the high point of literary achievement.

headline: Kurt Busch Intends to Drive 1,100 Miles in a Day
abstract: After the Indianapolis 500, Busch aims to fly in a carefully organized sequence of helicopters and private planes to the 600-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event in North Carolina.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Kurt Busch, discussing why he was planning to race Sunday in the Indianapolis 500 and then in the 600-mile Nascar Sprint Cup event in North Carolina, recalled a week in 1997 “that was kind of my fork in the road.”

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, May 25
abstract: Over this Memorial Day weekend, veterans’ care will dominate conversations on the Sunday talk shows.
lead_paragraph: President Obama made it clear in a conversation on Wednesday with the veterans affairs secretary, Eric Shinseki, that there will be “accountability” for the revelations that veterans hospitals manipulated waiting lists to hide the long delays many patients experienced in getting primary care. Many Republicans and a few Democratic lawmakers have called for Mr. Shinseki to resign.

headline: Lebanon’s Political Standoff Leaves Leadership Vacancy
abstract: President Michel Suleiman’s term ended Saturday before the country’s political powers could agree on a successor, creating a vacuum of power in the deeply divided nation.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Waving to television cameras and assembled dignitaries, President Michel Suleiman departed the presidential palace on Saturday, the last day of his six-year term, leaving behind a political vacuum caused by the failure of the country’s political powers to agree on a successor.

headline: A Wins-First Mentality Has Not Lifted Nascar
abstract: If Nascar was looking for a resurgence in fans as a result of all the changes it has made, that has not followed.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — Marcos Ambrose, the Tasmanian Nascar driver and road course ace who has raced for small and midsize teams throughout his six-year Sprint Cup career, has never qualified for the annual playoff. But this may be his year. With a new qualifying format putting stronger emphasis on winning, Ambrose figures he has perhaps his best shot at making the expanded 16-team field for the playoff, the Chase for the Sprint Cup.

headline: Sinn Fein Benefits as Ireland Moves Left
abstract: Early election results showed the government coalition parties, Fine Gael and Labour, had each lost significant levels of support.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN — Ireland has taken a decisive step to the left in local and European elections, where early returns on Saturday showed that the big winners were Sinn Fein, formerly the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, and Socialist independent candidates.

headline: Obama to Detail a Broader Foreign Policy Agenda
keywords: ['Commencement Speeches', 'United States International Relations', 'Global Warming', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: The president is expected to chart in a speech at West Point a middle course between isolationism and military intervention in international conflicts, from Syria’s civil war to Russia’s incursions in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, seeking to answer criticism that he has forsaken America’s leadership role, plans to lay out a retooled foreign-policy agenda on Wednesday that could deepen the nation’s involvement in Syria but would still steer clear of major military conflicts.

headline: Kings’ Coach Says Plenty With Little
abstract: Los Angeles Coach Darryl Sutter usually speaks in succinct phrases, often punctuated with lengthy, almost awkward pauses.
lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Kings have reached three consecutive Western Conference finals, and that means we hear more from Kings Coach Darryl Sutter.

headline: 3 Shot Dead at Brussels Jewish Museum
abstract: An unidentified gunman opened fire at the Jewish Museum in central Brussels, killing at least three people.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An unidentified gunman opened fire on Saturday at the Jewish Museum in the center of Brussels, killing at least three people in what officials said appeared to have been an anti-Semitic attack.

headline: Composers Struck by Homeland Fever
abstract: A program of rarely performed works investigates the fervent embrace of belligerent nationalism by composers after the outbreak of World War I.
lead_paragraph: A century after the outbreak of World War I, the fervent embrace of belligerent nationalism by educated Europeans continues to puzzle and fascinate historians. The conductor and scholar Leon Botstein investigates this question in a fascinating program of rarely performed works by composers swept up in nationalist movements. The American Symphony Orchestra will be joined by the Collegiate Chorale Singers and three fine soloists: the pianist Blair McMillen, the bass Denis Sedov and the tenor Corey Bix.

headline: One More Round for a Wartime Soap
abstract: “Bomb Girls: Facing the Enemy,” being shown on Reelz on Monday night, is about women working at a munitions plant during World War II.
lead_paragraph: It’s common these days for a made-for-television movie to serve as a test run for a possible series; if the movie draws a decent audience, a series will be created from its characters and setting. The Canadian series “Bomb Girls” received the opposite treatment: an exit movie.

headline: For a Cuban Troupe, a Gift of Rootedness
abstract: The Joyce Theater has given the fledging Cuban dance troupe MalPaso a commissioned work by Ronald K. Brown, a Brooklyn-born choreographer.
lead_paragraph: Danza Contemporánea de Cuba, the national modern dance company, first performed in the United States in 2011. The date is noteworthy, since the troupe was founded more than 50 years earlier, in the same year that Fidel Castro came to power. The 2011 visit offered a look, long delayed by American policy toward Cuba, at the official version of modern dance in a dance-mad culture. New York critics praised the Cubans for their virtuosity, versatility and charm. Too bad, more than one wrote, that the choreography was not up to the same level.

headline: When Seascapes Left Stodgy Behind
abstract: The British painter Joseph Mallord William Turner revolutionized the stodgy tradition of marine painting.
lead_paragraph: Whether you agree with the Victorian critic John Ruskin that the British painter Joseph Mallord William Turner was a talent on par with Shakespeare, you have to acknowledge that Turner revolutionized the stodgy tradition of marine painting. On Saturday, more than 100 of his seascapes — including his frothy, experimental renderings of wind-whipped oceans — will go on view at the Peabody Essex Museum in Salem, Mass.

headline: Leaping to Honor a First-Name Guy
abstract: Frederic Franklin, who died at 99 last May, was one of modern ballet’s most irrepressible figures.
lead_paragraph: Almost everyone involved with dance knew him, and they all just called him Freddie. Frederic Franklin, who died at 99 last May, was one of modern ballet’s most irrepressible figures. He was always onstage, performing mime roles in his later years. Blessed with an amazing memory and an ability to communicate, he also staged ballets, including American Ballet Theater’s “Coppélia,” the 19th-century comic classic, which the company will dance in his honor. (7:30 p.m. Friday, 2 p.m. and 8 p.m. Saturday, Metropolitan Opera House, Lincoln Center; 212-362-6000, abt.org.) From the Horse’s Mouth, a group that brings dance people together, is presenting three evenings dedicated to Franklin, featuring reminiscences, films and videos. Participants will vary from night to night, and presentations will emphasize his contributions to male dancing. (7:30 p.m. Friday through Sunday, Schimmel Center for the Arts, Pace University, 3 Spruce Street, between Park Row and Gold Street, Lower Manhattan; 212-346-1715, schimmel.pace.edu.)

headline: Young Man With a Horn
abstract: Theo Croker has a new album, “Afrophysicist,” showing his breadth, with plush funk and rock idioms.
lead_paragraph: The jazz trumpeter Theo Croker is the grandson of Doc Cheatham, who played the same instrument with great beauty and economy until his death at the age of 91 in 1997. In a reverse of the typical trumpeter’s story, Cheatham seemed to reach his peak in the last phase of his life. Mr. Croker, 29, may have learned something from his grandfather’s pacing. He started with plenty of promise and made a very good record in his early 20s (“The Fundamentals,” on Left Sided), but rather than speed-track his career, he worked in Shanghai for seven years, in clubs and on TV. He has a new album, “Afrophysicist” (DDB/Sony), showing his breadth, with plush funk and rock idioms, some subtle and complex new-jazz ones, a ballad standard (“Moody’s Mood for Love”) and high-wire soloing. He’ll play this week with his band DVRK Funk, including the pianist Sullivan Fortner and the drummer Kassa Overall, with the singer Dee Dee Bridgewater as guest. (7:30 and 9:30 p.m. Tuesday and Wednesday, Jazz Standard, 116 East 27th Street, Manhattan, 212-576-2232, jazzstandard.com.)

headline: Prepping for Indy 500 and Awaiting World Cup
abstract: Tony Kanaan met recently with New York Times editors to discuss the aftermath of winning the 2013 Indianapolis 500, the new season and his interests outside racing.
lead_paragraph: Last year, the veteran Brazilian driver Tony Kanaan won his first Indianapolis 500 in 12 attempts. This year, Kanaan, who won with the KV Racing team, is part of the IndyCar giant Target Chip Ganassi Racing, replacing the retired Dario Franchitti. Kanaan met recently with New York Times editors to discuss the aftermath of his victory, the new season and his interests outside racing. The interview was edited and condensed.

lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — The shootout that was expected between the high-powered offenses of Duke and Denver took about three quarters to develop Saturday in their N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse Final Four matchup at M&T Stadium.

headline: Final Word on U.S. Law Isn’t: Supreme Court Keeps Editing
abstract: The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, a secretive process that has led judges, lawyers and scholars astray.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court has been quietly revising its decisions years after they were issued, altering the law of the land without public notice. The revisions include “truly substantive changes in factual statements and legal reasoning,” said Richard J. Lazarus, a law professor at Harvard and the author of a new study examining the phenomenon.

headline: Debussy, Wine and B.Y.O.M. at a Fund-Raiser in Denver
abstract: While the musicians stuck to the classics, a fund-raiser for the Colorado Symphony included a new marijuana theme.
lead_paragraph: DENVER — The musicians stuck to the classics at the Colorado Symphony’s first-ever “Classically Cannabis” fund-raiser on Friday night. They played Strauss and Wagner, not Marley and Garcia. Their only concessions to the evening’s marijuana theme, it seemed, were the bright green ties they wore with their black suits.

headline: As Wars End, Military Gives Its Trademarks New Vigilance
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Trademarks and Trade Names', 'Slogans and Mottoes']
abstract: Returning soldiers-turned-entrepreneurs aiming to capitalize on their military service are keeping the Pentagon’s lawyers busy.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — United States Marine G-string underwear. The Starfleet Marine Corps Academy. And the motto from a human resources company: “The Few. The Proud. The Well-Paid.”

headline: The Fight Against the Slot Parlors Around the Corner
abstract: Dotty’s Gaming and Spirits lounge is locked in a political and legal fight for its survival against the casino industry and its backers in local government.
lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Five miles from the flashing lights and scantily clad dancers of the Las Vegas Strip, Dotty’s Gaming and Spirits lounge on Tropicana Avenue hardly resembles a casino. Decorated with red-and-white checkered tablecloths, plastic flowers, knickknacks and old clocks, the place, like most of the other 64 Dotty’s outposts scattered across this metropolis, looks more like your grandmother’s living room — if your grandmother happened to be an avid gambler.

headline: Two Extra Sets, Little Added Drama
abstract: The best-of-five format in the men’s draw of Grand Slam tournaments creates extra hours of tennis that have little effect on outcomes in the first week of play.
lead_paragraph: The N.B.A. continually fights the perception that fans do not need to tune in to games until the second half, or the fourth quarter. At the four Grand Slam tennis events, the opposite is true, especially in the early rounds.

lead_paragraph: As governor of Florida, Jeb Bush flew in Ivy League social scientists for daylong seminars with his staff and carved out time for immersive brainstorming sessions he called “think weeks.”

headline: In the N.B.A., a Billion-Dollar Distressed Sale of the Clippers
abstract: The forced sale of the Los Angeles Clippers could bring a sale price of $1 billion in an overheated market for N.B.A. teams.
lead_paragraph: Six weeks ago, no one would have suggested that the Los Angeles Clippers could sell for as much as $1 billion. The Lakers, yes. The Clippers, absolutely not.

headline: Will Faint for School
abstract: Readers comment on my column about a girl who starved herself to get a degree.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column is about an inspiring young woman who personifies grit—and also underscores the power of girls’ education. Since the Nigerian schoolgirls’ kidnapping, I’ve been thinking about the issue (and writing about it here, here and here). It’s obviously important to educate boys too, but I do think that there’s evidence that the returns for focusing on girls’ education are particularly high.

headline: Gareth Bale’s Goal Helps Lift Real Madrid to Its 10th Champions League Title
abstract: Bale scored the first of three extra-time goals on a header, after Sergio Ramos tied it in the 93rd minute, as Real Madrid beat city rival Atlético Madrid.
lead_paragraph: LISBON — Real Madrid Manager Carlo Ancelotti was in the midst of giving a calm, measured response to a question about his team’s tactics when the door to the news conference room burst open. Suddenly, seven of Ancelotti’s players were on the dais with him, jumping around, singing and spraying Champagne.

headline: Phil Jackson Has at Least Three Great Choices to Lead Knicks

lead_paragraph: Does Phil Jackson want a coach or does he want a marionette?

headline: Change of Program

lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — This must have been a tough theme set to pull together. Besides the letter count symmetry, Dan Schoenholz is working with the constraint of having all of his entries be well-known television programs, and then on top of that, he tries to change the names using soundalike words and clue them in a punny way.

headline: Turkish Film ‘Winter Sleep’ Wins Top Honor at Cannes
keywords: ['Cannes International Film Festival', 'Movies', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors', 'Festivals']
abstract: Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the film explores life and death, good and evil, the beauty of the natural world and the art of conversation.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — The 67th Cannes Film Festival came to a restrained close Saturday night when the Palme d’Or was awarded to the Turkish film “Winter Sleep.” Directed by Nuri Bilge Ceylan, the 3 hour and 16 minute philosophical talkfest about life and death, good and evil, the beauty of the natural world and art of conversation, had been a critics’ favorite in a competition lineup many deemed solid if lacking in revelations.

headline: Hitters Erase Deficit, Closer Erases Memory, and Yanks Escape With Win
abstract: After the Yankees scored three runs to tie the score in the ninth and Jacoby Ellsbury homered in the 10th, closer David Robertson shook off the sting of failure from one night earlier.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — As much as every closer claims a short memory and a tough skin as part of his skill set, the sting of a blown save can be agonizing, especially if it lingers for days. When a closer gives up a two-run homer on the road to instantly lose a game, as David Robertson did Friday night, the agony can be intense.

headline: Pope Francis Visits Jordan
abstract: Pope Francis, while visiting Amman, Jordan, called “urgently” for a “peaceful solution” to the Syrian crisis, and a “just solution” to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
lead_paragraph: Pope Francis, while visiting Amman, Jordan, called “urgently” for a “peaceful solution” to the Syrian crisis, and a “just solution” to the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.

headline: Disney Executive Gains Supporters
abstract: A small group of team owners has reached out to Robert A. Iger, Disney’s chief executive, to gauge his interest in becoming the next baseball commissioner.
lead_paragraph: Robert A. Iger began his career as a local television weatherman in upstate New York. Concerned that he was not good enough, he took a job behind the camera at ABC, ultimately climbing to the top of its parent, the Walt Disney Company, as Michael Eisner’s deputy.

headline: Derision and Suspicion Abound Entering Game 4
abstract: The Rangers and Canadiens are set for Game 4 of a fiery Eastern Conference finals, with the Rangers leading the series two games to one.
lead_paragraph: Gamesmanship and mutual mistrust between the Rangers and the Montreal Canadiens ruled at Madison Square Garden on Saturday as the teams prepared for Sunday night’s continuation of the increasingly prickly Eastern Conference finals.

headline: Egypt’s New Strongman, Sisi Knows Best
keywords: ['Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )', 'Elections', 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi’s cunning path to power and his paternalistic conviction that the people must be prepared to suffer are illuminated in interviews and leaked recordings.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army officer soon to be Egypt’s president, promises to remedy Egypt’s crippling fuel shortage by installing energy-efficient bulbs in every home socket, even if he has to send a government employee to screw in each one.

headline: YouTube Removes Video Posted by Shooting Suspect
keywords: ['Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming', 'Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)']
abstract: Citing violation of its rules against intimidating behavior, the website took down a clip titled “Elliot Rodger’s Retribution,” which the police have connected to a shooting attack in Santa Barbara, Calif.
lead_paragraph: As news spread of a shooting in California that left at least seven people dead, YouTube on Saturday afternoon took down a video clip that the police have connected to the rampage. The website was seemingly caught between its mission and its morals, between making information available to all and spreading material that could be construed as offensive, even dangerous.

headline: Czar’s Winery Faces New Era: Annexation
abstract: A winery in the Crimean seaside resort of Yalta has been around since Nicholas II. It has survived the 1917 revolution, two world wars and the fall of the Soviet Union. Now it faces new uncertainty.
lead_paragraph: A winery in the Crimean seaside resort of Yalta has been around since Nicholas II. It has survived the 1917 revolution, two world wars and the fall of the Soviet Union. Now it faces new uncertainty.

headline: Down to the Sea Again
abstract: Americans may rhapsodize about their cars or amber waves of grain, but when it comes to putting wind in their sails, nothing does it quite like wind and sails.
lead_paragraph: In the opening pages of “Moby-Dick,” the narrator, assessing the “insular city of the Manhattoes,” notes how even the landlocked are driven to stand and stare out to sea. “But look!” he says, “here come more crowds, pacing straight for the water, and seemingly bound for a dive. Strange! Nothing will content them but the extremest limit of the land.”

headline: For Crimea, It’s Russian Troops In, Tourists Out
abstract: With its economy flatlining, Crimea desperately needs a banner year in tourism. But with the violent portrait Russian television has painted of Ukraine, few seem likely to come.
lead_paragraph: YALTA, Crimea — When choosing the idyllic setting for an extramarital affair, Anton Chekhov opted for Yalta, and this seaside resort proved so grateful that it erected a bronze statue of the fictional enchantress with her Pomeranian on the main boardwalk.

headline: Wheeler Shakes Off Early Trouble, but Mets Fall to Arizona
abstract: At the plate, Lucas Duda failed three times against the Diamondbacks to cash in with runners on base; on the mound, Zack Wheeler shook off early trouble to pitch ‘a heck of a game.’
lead_paragraph: Lucas Duda stood at his locker with a blank stare on his face and his hands on his hips. He had come to bat in three crucial moments of the Mets’ 3-2 home loss to the Arizona Diamondbacks on Saturday, with the game close and men on base, and had failed each time. He finished the game 0 for 4, with seven runners left on base.

headline: A Met Finds a Place on the Diamond: Everywhere
abstract: Eric Campbell has been a reliable hitter so far for the Mets and could serve in several defensive positions, if necessary.
lead_paragraph: Eric Campbell had planned to go golfing with his father. It was June 2008, and as a tall, athletic third baseman from Boston College, Campbell was expected to be selected before the 15th round of the baseball draft. But instead of obsessing over where he would be taken, he decided to ignore the thing.

headline: Hacker Helped Disrupt 300 Web Attacks, Prosecutors Say
keywords: ['Cyberattacks and Hackers', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Cyberwarfare']
abstract: Hector Xavier Monsegur, a prominent hacker set to be sentenced this week on federal charges, has provided a trove of information to the authorities, according to a newly filed court document.
lead_paragraph: A prominent hacker set to be sentenced in federal court this week for breaking into numerous computer systems worldwide has provided a trove of information to the authorities, allowing them to disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks on targets that included the United States military, Congress, the federal courts, NASA and private companies, according to a newly filed government court document.

headline: Hacker Group Lashes Out Against Informant

lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — While Hector Xavier Monsegur awaited sentencing for charges that could bring him a lengthy prison term, his former partners in the hacker collective Anonymous and the group’s sympathizers expressed their feelings online.

headline: Using Jailed Migrants as a Pool of Cheap Labor
keywords: ['Immigration Detention', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Illegal Immigration', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: As the federal government cracks down on immigrants in the country illegally and forbids businesses to hire them, it is relying on tens of thousands of those immigrants each year to provide essential labor.
lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The kitchen of the detention center here was bustling as a dozen immigrants boiled beans and grilled hot dogs, preparing lunch for about 900 other detainees. Elsewhere, guards stood sentry and managers took head counts, but the detainees were doing most of the work — mopping bathroom stalls, folding linens, stocking commissary shelves.

headline: Concerns Over Police Brutality After a Bronx Arrest Goes Awry

lead_paragraph: Last Saturday, just before midnight, Javier Payne and a friend stood handcuffed outside a hookah store on a street corner in the Bronx. The teenagers had been arrested, accused of assaulting a 49-year-old man who refused to give them cigarettes.

headline: U.S. Champs Retain Titles in Playoffs After Late Rallies

headline: ‘Orphan Black’ Recap: So a Clone Walks Into a Bar…
abstract: Put a few primary “Orphan Black” characters in a normal environment, with regular people, and see what kind of shenanigans ensue.
lead_paragraph: One of the highlights from the first season of “Orphan Black” came in Episode 6, when Sarah (Tatiana Maslany), Felix (Jordan Gavaris), Paul (Dylan Bruce) and Victor (Michael Mando) crashed a neighborhood potluck at Alison’s home. In the midst of this suburban party — while guests congregated in the living room and kitchen, laughing, drinking and listening to ’90s pop hits like “Lovefool” by The Cardigans — the clones and their associates engaged in and/or tried to cover up various forms of torture in the basement and the garage. The resulting juxtaposition from that setup illustrated how different the clones’ lives are from the rest of the general populace. It was also a goldmine for both comedy and dramatic tension.

headline: Francis T. Purcell, Three-Term Nassau County Executive, Dies at 95
abstract: Mr. Purcell, who was a three-term Nassau County Executive, promoted the development of downtown business areas and the transformation of Mitchel Field.
lead_paragraph: Francis T. Purcell, a three-term Nassau County executive who in the late 1970s and ’80s promoted the development of downtown business areas and the transformation of Mitchel Field, a former air base, into a recreational and educational center, died May 18 at his home in Palm Beach Gardens, Fla. He was 95.

headline: Robert J. Flynn, Shot Down in Vietnam War and Held in China, Dies at 76

abstract: Downed over southern China, a badly injured Lieutenant Flynn spent five and a half years in a Chinese prison, mostly in solitary confinement.
lead_paragraph: Navy Cmdr. Robert J. Flynn, who spent five and a half years in a Communist Chinese prison during the Vietnam War, almost always in solitary confinement, after he was shot down on a bombing mission, died on May 15 in Pensacola, Fla. Commander Flynn, one of only two American servicemen known to have been held by the Chinese during the war, was 76.

headline: Melissa Saiontz, Jeffrey Luse
abstract: The bride is a vice president for a real estate investment firm; the groom just completed his first year of the graduate M.B.A. program at Harvard.
lead_paragraph: Melissa Ann Saiontz, a daughter of Leslie Miller Saiontz and Steven J. headline: ‘X-Men’ Thrives at Holiday Box Office
abstract: “X-Men: Days of Future Past” took in about $90.7 million over the first three days of the holiday weekend, while Adam Sandler’s “Blended” opened to lackluster ticket sales.
lead_paragraph: The strongly reviewed “X-Men: Days of Future Past” gave 20th Century Fox its best opening-weekend result since “Avatar” in 2009, ending a bumpy box office stretch for the studio and demonstrating the ongoing strength of superhero movies. But as strong as ticket sales were – “Days of Future Past” took in about $90.7 million over the first three days of the holiday weekend – Memorial Day 2014 will also be remembered for the crash of yet another Adam Sandler vehicle, “Blended,” which arrived with a dismal $14.2 million.

headline: Making Bach’s ‘Symphony for Solo Cello’ Look Easy
abstract: Istvan Vardai performed Bach’s Cello Suites Nos. 1, 5, and 6 at the Park Avenue Armory’s recently renovated Board of Officers Room.
lead_paragraph: One of the many enjoyable aspects of concerts in small spaces like the Park Avenue Armory’s recently renovated Board of Officers Room is the chance to enjoy the intimacy of the music making and to see the players up close. Watching Istvan Vardai’s slender fingers dance over the strings during his superb performance of Bach’s Cello Suite No. 6 on Thursday added a fascinating visual component to the experience.

headline: Daring Pass Produces Narrow Victory at Indy
abstract: Ryan Hunter-Reay became the first American to win the Indianapolis 500 since 2006, making a dramatic pass of Helio Castroneves on the final lap.
lead_paragraph: INDIANAPOLIS — Ryan Hunter-Reay nearly ran into the infield grass to pass Helio Castroneves with one lap to go and then held on to win by 0.06 of a second in the 98th Indianapolis 500 on Sunday.

headline: Cannes Film Festival: Director Asia Argento on Giving Up Acting
abstract: The filmmaker says her life as an actress was a “construction.”
lead_paragraph: CANNES – It’s no surprise that many viewers here saw “Misunderstood,” a funny, free, tough-minded film by Asia Argento, through the lens of autobiography. Set in the 1980s, it centers on a 9-year-old, Aria (Giulia Salerno), the underloved daughter of two monstrous narcissists, an actor (Gabriel Garko) and a pianist (Charlotte Gainsbourg). Soon after it opens, the parents separate and Aria – Ms. Argento’s original name – starts toggling between them even as they reject her, often brutally. Cast aside, she takes refuge in her love of a cat and in her imagination, which soars movingly both in her writing and in some wild fantasies.

headline: A Young Soldier Feels Encouraged, Then Disillusioned, Singing All the While

headline: Bunny Yeager, Pinup Portraitist, Dies at 85
abstract: Ms. Yeager, a former model herself, produced famed innocently sexual images of the pinup era.
lead_paragraph: Bunny Yeager, a model-turned-photographer whose images of a scarcely clad Bettie Page, embodying feral sexuality and winsome naïveté all at once, helped propel Ms. Page to international stardom as a midcentury pinup queen, died on Sunday in North Miami, Fla. She was 85.

headline: Surrounding a Love Triangle With Spectacle
abstract: While American Ballet Theater’s rendering of “La Bayadère” had plenty of ballet-as-sport spectacle, the leads in the story’s love triangle imbued it with rich dramatic purpose.
lead_paragraph: During American Ballet Theater’s spring season, with its panoply of full-length ballets, the business of telling a story can feel more or less urgent, depending on the night. There are works in which the narrative seizes you and sweeps you along, investing you in the fate of each character. And there are others in which the plot, if you could call it that, seems like mere scaffolding for spectacular dancing, an excuse for putting on an extravagant show.

headline: Striving for Wealth and Truth in China, in Face of Monolithic Government
abstract: Two new books take a look at change and pressure in China.
lead_paragraph: Evan Osnos appears to be almost as entrepreneurial, intrepid and creative as the strivers whose linked portraits underpin his book “Age of Ambition: Chasing Fortune, Truth, and Faith in the New China.” During eight years of remarkable reporting from China, much of it for The New Yorker, Mr. Osnos ferreted out interesting people to interview, from the billionaire “Queen of Trash” Cheung Yan to a poet sweeping the street outside Mr. Osnos’s home in Beijing. His network included the popular blogger Han Han, whose website has had more than a quarter of a billion visitors, and the dissident and Nobel Peace Prize winner Liu Xiaobo. Others were unknowns, like Michael, who hopes to make his fortune by writing English textbooks; his dreams and self-doubt capture China’s historical moment.

headline: Drawn Back, Again and Again, to the Flame
abstract: “The Essential Straight & Narrow,” a play by the Mad Ones, is about creating art and how people are pulled back to vital moments in their lives.
lead_paragraph: “The Essential Straight & Narrow,” by the Mad Ones at the New Ohio Theater, is very funny. Then suddenly it isn’t. Created by the company and directed by Lila Neugebauer, the show melds folk-rock, the game show “The $10,000 Pyramid,” schlocky cop dramas and the Nietzschean concept of the eternal return. Ingenious and tricksy, its story lines tantalize and confound. But just when you’re ready to dismiss it as a postmodern goof, it shoots straight at your heart. With excellent aim.

headline: A City’s Simple Joy
abstract: Bocce, the perfect city sport for a holiday weekend, has been part of the New York landscape since the 1800s.
lead_paragraph: If there was ever a perfect warm-weather, holiday-weekend city sport, bocce may be it. It requires only a set of bocce balls, which are traditionally made of metal but come in a plastic version these days, and a flat, rectangular space to use as the court. The rules are complicated enough to keep the game interesting, but the skill is simple enough to require no athletic ability. As a bonus, it is a traditional Italian game, commonly played with one hand while the other holds an espresso or a glass of wine.

headline: Rhinebeck Retreat Selects Musicals
abstract: Nine musicals have been selected for the 2014 Rhinebeck Writers Retreat.
lead_paragraph: Nine musicals have been selected for the 2014 Rhinebeck Writers Retreat, which provides a weeklong residency in Rhinebeck, N.Y, for the writing team behind each project. A total of 26 musical theater writers are to participate, including Mindi Dickstein (“Little Women”), Nathan Tysen (“The Burnt Part Boys”) and Peter Mills (“Illyria”). Among the works to be developed are “Alexander Supertramp,” by Janet Allard and Niko Tsakalakos, a musical based on Jon Krakauer’s book “Into the Wild”; “Stillwater,” a rock theater piece by John Jobson, Ryan McCall and Mr. Tysen, about the residents of a trailer park in Oklahoma; and “At the Beck,” by Chantal Bilodeau, Ms. Dickstein, and Peter Melnick, about two British girls who claim to have taken real pictures of fairies.

lead_paragraph: The shopkeeper at the small Hong Kong bookstore recognized the author Chan Koonchung right away. The People’s Recreation Community — its initials are a play on People’s Republic of China — specializes in books that are banned on the Chinese mainland, but not in the relatively free territory of Hong Kong. Mr. Chan found his own volumes on the shelf across from the cashier, while the shopkeeper brought over mugs of milk tea.

headline: A Film About Film Divides Cannes
abstract: Olivier Assayas discusses his film, “Clouds of Sils Maria,” which stars Juliette Binoche and Kristen Stewart and explores the questions of time, youth and the slipping away of each.
lead_paragraph: CANNES, France — There’s a scene in “Clouds of Sils Maria” in which a young American played by Kristen Stewart delivers a beautifully sincere defense of blockbusters to a French star played by Juliette Binoche. They’re talking about movies in a multilayered film from the French director Olivier Assayas that is itself partly an inquiry into cinema. The star, Maria Enders, has become famous in big movies, yet she also voices contempt for them. Given how closely Mr. Assayas cuts to a central tension that plays out yearly at the Cannes Film Festival — a temple of auteurist worship that rolls out the red carpet for industrial cinema — it isn’t surprising that “Sils Maria” wasn’t wholly embraced here.

headline: For American Men, Long Road to Dominance
abstract: Tennis coaches in the United States, which had six men ranked in the top 10 in May 1984 but has only one in the top 60 today, are facing a complex problem.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Believe it or not, American men’s tennis may not have struck bottom. Look at the once-dominant Australians, who have no men in the top 40 of the ATP rankings. Look, if you can bear it, at the once-dominant Swedes, who have no men in the top 300.

abstract: Yankees shortstop Derek Jeter had four hits for the first time since August 2012, a day after catcher Brian McCann predicted as much, while Masahiro Tanaka bounced back from his first loss in a 7-1 road win over the White Sox.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — Brian McCann’s prediction was off by a day, but fairly clairvoyant nonetheless. On Saturday, he told Derek Jeter that Jeter would get four hits in that game.

headline: I.R.S. Bars Employers From Dumping Workers Into Health Exchanges
keywords: ['Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Patient Protection and Affordable Care Act (2010)']
abstract: Employers have been told they cannot give their workers a tax-free lump sum to cover their health insurance costs, a change that could disrupt arrangements in many industries.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Many employers had thought they could shift health costs to the government by sending their employees to a health insurance exchange with a tax-free contribution of cash to help pay premiums, but the Obama administration has squelched the idea in a new ruling. Such arrangements do not satisfy the health care law, the administration said, and employers may be subject to a tax penalty of $100 a day — or $36,500 a year — for each employee who goes into the individual marketplace.

headline: Banner Day Disappoints Before Mets Win Game 2
abstract: Sloppy play and poor hitting cost the Mets the first game against the Diamondbacks on Sunday, but a solid outing by Daisuke Matsuzaka, making a spot start, salvaged the second.
lead_paragraph: Somber and quiet and shaking their heads, hordes of fans filed out of Citi Field and trudged toward the subway station. The second game of the day’s single-admission doubleheader was about to start, but they had better plans for the rest of their Sunday afternoon. The Mets had found a new way to lose, and their fans had seen enough.
