headline: Jacob’s Pillow Prize Is Announced
keywords: ["Jacob's Pillow Dance Festival", 'Dancing', 'Awards, Decorations and Honors']
abstract: The contemporary choreographer John Heginbotham will receive the eighth annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award.
lead_paragraph: The contemporary choreographer John Heginbotham, above, will receive the eighth annual Jacob’s Pillow Dance Award. Mr. Heginbotham is to accept the award, which comes with a cash prize of $25,000, on June 14, the opening night of this year’s Jacob’s Pillow Dance Festival. His company, Dance Heginbotham, will also perform a new work called “Chalk and Soot” at the festival, from July 30 to Aug. 3. Jacob’s Pillow, in Becket, Mass., established the award in 2007 to recognize outstanding contributions to dance. Previous recipients include last year’s winner, Michelle Dorrance; Crystal Pite; and Bill T. Jones.

headline: Adopt a Dog With a Southern Drawl
abstract: Shelters in the rural South are crowded with pets that are in danger of being euthanized, and that would be in high demand up North.
lead_paragraph: IF I could be reincarnated as anyone, I’d pick my dog, Landon. He leads a charmed life. Most mornings he gets scrambled eggs for breakfast, which he prefers to hard-boiled. Every afternoon, he takes a long run. Landon sleeps with my husband and me — he’s a 60-pound retriever mix, but seems to expand to five times that size in our bed. In summer, we take him on vacation to Maine, where he frolics on the beach. Not that he cares, but his picture has appeared in the online edition of Vogue.

headline: A Mysterious Map of Louisiana
abstract: Think mapping data is new? The Union Army was doing it in Louisiana 150 years ago.
lead_paragraph: These days the intersection of cartography and Big Data is all the rage: Using information from the 2010 census, countless news outfits, including The New York Times, have created tools allowing readers to make customized maps of everything from trends in ethnic and racial composition to the dynamics of housing development. Indeed, we have come to expect that any large body of data will be visualized through maps and infographics. Such tools help to transform information into knowledge, and at their best allow us to see patterns that might otherwise be lost.

headline: Europe’s Secret Success
abstract: It turns out that those welfare states, with their generous social benefits, are beating America at job creation hands down.
lead_paragraph: SINTRA, Portugal — I’ll be spending the next couple of days at a forum sponsored by the European Central Bank whose de facto topic — whatever it may say on the program — will be the destructive monetary muddle caused by the Continent’s premature adoption of a single currency. What makes the story even sadder is that Europe’s financial and macroeconomic woes have overshadowed its remarkable, unheralded longer-term success in an area in which it used to lag: job creation.

lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Basketball players call it winning time, the last quarter in a game, when legs and minds are tired, when all the plays have been called and all the individual tricks and tendencies have been laid bare.

headline: The Pitch of America’s Voice
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'United States International Relations', 'News and News Media', 'Editorials', 'Propaganda']
abstract: Sponsors of a bill to overhaul Voice of America should guarantee that journalistic standards won’t be sacrificed.
lead_paragraph: Vladimir Putin’s aggressive return to Cold War propaganda is feeding congressional momentum for a bipartisan overhaul of Voice of America, the federal broadcast outlet that has long jockeyed between providing independent, credible news and meeting its statutory mission as official supporter of the United States. This is not always an easy balance, and a measure approved last month by the House Foreign Affairs Committee would explicitly tighten the definition of the V.O.A.’s mission so that its news “is consistent with and promotes the broad foreign policies of the United States.”

headline: Gov. Christie’s Pipeline
abstract: The governor is pushing for a natural gas route through New Jersey’s Pinelands, but his state would be the loser.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, Gov. Chris Christie proposed a natural gas pipeline that would run right through the environmentally sensitive Pinelands of southern New Jersey. It was a faulty plan, and the guardians of that area — the Pinelands Commission — wisely rejected the pipeline in January. Now Mr. Christie and his allies are trying to pack the commission with people who will see things his way.

Mr. Williams is sitting in an office here a mile up the road from Twitter, where he is a founder and is still a board member, working on Medium, an amorphous-sounding company that could be one more curio of the Internet age or might end up taking over the world.

headline: Treasury Auctions for the Week of May 26
abstract: The following tax-exempt fixed-income issues are scheduled for pricing this week.
lead_paragraph: The Treasury’s schedule of financing this week includes auctions of new three- and six-month bills on Tuesday, after the market closure on Memorial Day, as well as an additional auction of two-year notes on Tuesday. There will also be auctions of four-week bills, one-year bills, two-year floating rate notes and five-year notes on Wednesday, and seven-year notes on Thursday.

headline: Even in a State With Restrictive Laws, Gunman Amassed Weapons and Ammunition
keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Gun Control']

lead_paragraph: ISLA VISTA, Calif. — Even in California, with some of the strictest gun control laws in the country, Elliot O. Rodger was able to amass a stash of weapons and ammunition, despite having struggled with mental health issues for years.

headline: Muslims and the N.Y.P.D.
abstract: The Police Department is running another counterterrorism program that singles out Muslims in a problematic way, this time to recruit them as informants.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s police commissioner, William Bratton, made the right decision last month when he said he would disband a unit used by his predecessor, Raymond Kelly, to spy on law-abiding Muslims as they worshiped or patronized businesses in their communities. Beyond proving useless for intelligence purposes, the Demographics Unit undermined the fight against terrorism by alienating Muslims who were understandably angry about being singled out, not for illegal conduct but because of their religious affiliation.

headline: Options Dwindle for Bronx Residents Trying to Escape to the Movies
abstract: Two multiplexes in the Bronx were closed to be converted to retail space in the past year, leaving a borough of 1.4 million inhabitants with only two theaters.
lead_paragraph: If the Bronx were a city, it would rank about sixth in population in the United States, its 1.4 million inhabitants making it near the same size as Philadelphia, Phoenix or San Antonio. But one glaring difference is especially relevant with the arrival of Memorial Day, the semiofficial start of the summer movie season: Film lovers there have to plan more and travel farther to see their favorite blockbuster.

lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — The clock showed 3:17 p.m. when Kurt Busch’s No. 26 Honda crossed the finish line at Indianapolis Motor Speedway. He had just completed the Indianapolis 500, racing 500 miles at more than 220 miles per hour in a grueling event that left his back and hands aching.

headline: Political Ad Man Finds the Personal in Democratic Hopefuls

He has cajoled one to sling luggage on the tarmac at the Baltimore-Washington airport (Senator Ben Cardin of Maryland). And more recently, he persuaded another to ride a snowmobile in subzero temperatures (Senator Mark Begich of Alaska).

headline: Beautiful Day at Citi Field, Except for Action on the Field
abstract: The Mets’ familiar offensive futility has continued this season, and the doubleheader against the Diamondbacks on Sunday epitomized some of the problems.
lead_paragraph: My dad called from Philadelphia late Sunday afternoon. He was leaving Citizens Bank Park, where Josh Beckett of the Los Angeles Dodgers had just pitched a no-hitter against the Phillies. For fans used to more mundane defeats, it was a good day.

headline: Fantasia, Albino Burmese Python Who Inspired ‘Absolute Awe,’ Dies at Staten Island Zoo
abstract: Fantasia arrived at the Brooklyn Children’s Museum in 1998 at age 4 and went on to become a visitor favorite, impressing all with her colossal size and calm demeanor.
lead_paragraph: Like more than a few of the creatures who make their way to the city’s institutions, the python known as New York’s largest snake began public life as an oversize pet.

headline: In Egyptian Town, Cheers for Sisi but Murmurs of Discontent
abstract: In Banha, north of Cairo, the presidential campaign banners for Abdel Fattah el-Sisi are everywhere but some have been defaced, illustrating both the certainty of his election and the challenges he will face.
lead_paragraph: BANHA, Egypt — His face smiles down from campaign banners everywhere, but splashes of red paint have bloodied a few.

headline: Peace-Talk Critic Takes Lead in Colombia Presidential Vote
abstract: Óscar Iván Zuluaga failed to earn the majority needed to be declared the winner and will face President Juan Manuel Santos in a June runoff.
lead_paragraph: CARACAS, Venezuela — A harsh critic of peace talks between the Colombian government and the country’s largest rebel group led in presidential voting Sunday but lacked the majority needed to avoid a runoff.

headline: Frank M. Woods, Vintner and Ambassador for Sonoma, Dies at 81
abstract: Mr. Woods, a marketer and lifelong entrepreneur, put Sonoma County grapes on the map with his Clos du Bois winery.
lead_paragraph: Frank M. Woods, who founded the Clos du Bois winery in Sonoma County, Calif., and was instrumental in raising the profile of that region’s wines around the world, died on May 8 in San Francisco. He was 81.

headline: ‘Penny Dreadful’ Recap: Frankenstein’s Monster Wants a Partner. Now.
abstract: The third episode stirs into the plot a bit of “Sweeney Todd” and the “A-Team.”
lead_paragraph: John Logan, the creator of “Penny Dreadful,” has a reputation for not repeating himself, with a resume that includes the screenplays to “Rango,” “Gladiator” and “Hugo” as well as this dependably lurid series. But in “Resurrection,” the third episode, Mr. Logan nods to another of his successes, the film adaptation of “Sweeney Todd,” even at the expense of historical accuracy.

headline: How Nadal Dominates the French Open
abstract: Rafael Nadal’s eight titles at Roland Garros are unmatched, and his 59-1 record there is a product of his clear dominance in several statistical categories.
lead_paragraph: Rafael Nadal has dominated the French Open as no man has ever dominated a Grand Slam tennis tournament.

headline: Dog Reported Beaten to Death in Front of Owner in Beijing
keywords: ['Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Dogs', 'Pets', 'Police Brutality, Misconduct and Shootings', 'Rabies']
abstract: Beijing will probably see a harsher-than-usual drive against unregistered pet dogs this year because of rising rabies infections, vets are warning.
lead_paragraph: City management officers in Beijing beat a small dog to death in front of his horrified owner, a Briton working at an international school in Beijing, over the weekend, a magazine reported. The officers, known as chengguan, who are a regular feature of Chinese news reports for using violence to enforce regulations like where fruit sellers can ply their trade, attacked the dog because the owner did not have registration papers for his pet, according to the magazine, The Beijinger.

headline: First Win of Year for Johnson
abstract: Jimmie Johnson won the Coca-Cola 600 after overtaking Matt Kenseth during the closing laps, virtually locking up a spot in the season-ending playoff.
lead_paragraph: CONCORD, N.C. — The six-time series champion Jimmie Johnson failed to win in the first 11 races of the Sprint Cup season. If his fans were panicked, Johnson surely wasn’t.

headline: Return of Brassard Proves Crucial
abstract: Derick Brassard, who missed the last two games with an upper-body injury, scored in the second period of Game 4 on Sunday night to give the Rangers the lead.
lead_paragraph: The puck, passed tape to tape from 100 feet away, reached Derick Brassard’s stick on the blue line.

headline: Speaking Up About an Uncomfortable Condition
abstract: With more awareness about the risk factors of inflammatory bowel diseases like Crohn’s and ulcerative colitis, those with a genetic predisposition can take precautions.
lead_paragraph: Bowels, especially those that don’t function properly, are not a popular topic of conversation. Most of the 1.4 million Americans with inflammatory bowel disease — Crohn’s disease or ulcerative colitis — suffer in silence.

headline: St. Louis Lifts Rangers in Overtime
abstract: Martin St. Louis scored in overtime to give the Rangers a 3-1 series lead in the Eastern Conference finals, and a chance to clinch a berth in the Stanley Cup finals for the first time in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Martin St. Louis added another chapter to his remarkable playoff journey with a goal in overtime Sunday to give the Rangers a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens, and a 3-1 lead in the best-of-seven Eastern Conference finals.

headline: What’s On Monday
abstract: Television highlights.
lead_paragraph: 9 P.M. (Lifetime) PETALS ON THE WIND (2014) This sequel to “Flowers in the Attic” (shown at 7) finds Cathy (Rose McIver), Christopher (Wyatt Nash) and Carrie (Bailey Buntain) Dollanganger struggling to put their sordid past behind them a decade after escaping from their grandparents’ attic. But forbidden desire isn’t easily forgotten, and when tragedy strikes again, Cathy returns to Foxworth Hall to confront her grandmother (Ellen Burstyn) and seek revenge on her mother (Heather Graham, above).

headline: With Ibaka Back in Lineup, Thunder Cut the Spurs’ Lead to a Game
abstract: After missing the first two games of the Western Conference finals with a calf injury that was expected to end his season, Serge Ibaka returned and helped Oklahoma City to its first win.
lead_paragraph: OKLAHOMA CITY — Years from now, the story will no doubt have Serge Ibaka crawling off his death bed rather than the training table. He will have rescued a cat from a tree on the way to the arena and handed out free tickets at a homeless shelter.

headline: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 26, 2014
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Monday, May 26, 2014.
lead_paragraph: “If you look around the world, there are very few political leaders who are relatively untainted. People want to believe there is somebody good and charismatic, and a good authority figure, out there.”

headline: Mass on Mount Zion Stirs Ancient Rivalries
abstract: Opposition has grown in ultra-Orthodox and nationalist religious Jewish circles to a deal between Israel and the Vatican on increased Christian prayer times at the Cenacle.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — The intimate Mass celebrated by Pope Francis on Monday in the Cenacle, the hall on Jerusalem’s Mount Zion venerated by Christians as the room of the Last Supper, capped a Holy Land pilgrimage meant to promote peace and tolerance.

headline: Chinese Blogger Says He Was Fired After Meeting With Kerry
keywords: ['Blogs and Blogging (Internet)', 'Censorship', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Freedom of the Press', 'International Relations', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Zhang Jialong says Tencent, a Chinese Internet giant, objected to his comments on censorship and his request that the United States pay attention to the cases of prominent dissidents.
lead_paragraph: A Chinese blogger says he was fired from his job at one of China’s leading Internet companies for his comments during a February meeting in Beijing with the American secretary of state, John Kerry.

headline: Beijing Seems to Be Warming Toward Aung San Suu Kyi
abstract: There are new signs that a long-awaited visit to Beijing by Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, the Myanmar opposition leader, may be getting closer.
lead_paragraph: After some courteous flirtation between the Chinese Communist Party and Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, a long-awaited visit by the Myanmar opposition leader to Beijing may be getting closer. The well-traveled Nobel Peace laureate has been to Western Europe, the United States and Australia, but not to China.

headline: Pope Lays Wreath at Tomb of Zionism’s Founder
abstract: Francis’ visit to the grave of Theodor Herzl came after several symbolic signals the day before that lent a spiritual lift to Palestinian aspirations for sovereignty.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — A conflict largely defined by dueling narratives became a battle of competing imagery during Pope Francis’ sojourn through the Holy Land, with Palestinians and Israelis both seizing on the pontiff’s strong symbolic gestures to promote their perspectives.

headline: E.C.B. Plots Strategy for Staving Off Deflation
abstract: As the bank’s president, Mario Draghi, acknowledged to a group of experts that the euro zone might slide into deflation, good options are scarce.
lead_paragraph: SINTRA, Portugal — The European Central Bank was basically intended to do one thing: keep inflation in a cage. But its mission has turned out to be a lot more complicated than that.

headline: After Coup, General Vows to Create A ‘Genuine Democracy’ in Thailand
abstract: Gen. Prayuth Chan-ocha said he had the backing of King Bhumibol Adulyadej, though the king has not been seen in public since Thursday’s takeover.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta said Monday that it would stay in power “indefinitely” and that its rule had been endorsed by King Bhumibol Adulyadej, the monarch for nearly seven decades who has semi-divine status in the country.

headline: Ukraine Forces Appear to Oust Rebels From Airport in East
abstract: Ukrainian soldiers used fighter jets and fought a ground battle against the pro-Russian forces, who had seized the airport in Donetsk after elections that seemed to marginalize them.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — The new Ukrainian government struck the separatists in this eastern province with a major military offensive on Monday, battling them over an important provincial airport in ground fighting that lasted for hours. The rebels were left scattered and shaken, just one day after a successful national election they had tried to disrupt.

headline: Pistorius Arrives at Hospital for Psychiatric Assessment
keywords: ['Mental Health and Disorders', 'Olympic Games (2012)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']

lead_paragraph: Oscar Pistorius traveled on Monday to a state psychiatric hospital in Pretoria for the first day of a mental health evaluation ordered last week by the judge at his murder trial.

headline: Chinese Developer’s Fake Sphinx Has Egypt Seething
abstract: A copy of the Great Sphinx of Giza in a Hebei Province cultural park has prompted official protests from the Egyptian antiquities minister.
lead_paragraph: They say imitation is the sincerest form of flattery, but a Chinese replica of one of Egypt’s most famous icons has gone too far in the eyes of the Egyptian government.

headline: Tiananmen Comment Eyed After Professor’s Microblog Vanishes

lead_paragraph: The popular microblog of a prominent nationalist professor at Peking University has been blocked, possibly in response to a comment he posted about the military suppression of the 1989 Tiananmen protest movement.

abstract: There is a growing feeling that FIFA and the Olympic committee are taking the parent act a bit too far.
lead_paragraph: SÃO PAULO, Brazil — By now, Brazil should probably have been grounded for life, without video games or dessert.

headline: Bucking E.U. Tide, Italians Endorse Prime Minister
abstract: Matteo Renzi had the best showing of any European leader in parliamentary voting, reaching a level no party has seen in an Italian election since 1958.
lead_paragraph: ROME — If there was one bright spot for mainstream political parties in the elections for the European Parliament, it came, to the surprise of many, in Italy, where Prime Minister Matteo Renzi and his Democratic Party received more than 40 percent of votes cast, a level no party has reached in any Italian election since 1958.

headline: Voting Opens in Egyptian Election Lacking Suspense
abstract: Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the former army field marshal who led the ouster of President Mohamed Morsi, seems certain to sweep to victory in a contest where turnout will be crucial.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Rasha Hazem has brought her two daughters to 10 national votes in the last three years, letting the girls ink their own fingers each time to practice at democracy.

headline: Maintaining a Classical-Music Miracle in Cleveland
abstract: The Cleveland Orchestra is trying to attract the youngest audience of any in America by its 100th birthday in 2018.
lead_paragraph: CLEVELAND — When Milton Maltz looked down from his box seat in Severance Hall — the stately home of the Cleveland Orchestra — he used to fear for its future. “I saw gray hair and no hair,” said the longtime orchestra benefactor. “And I said, ‘Where are the young people?’”

headline: Firefighters Salvage Most of Glasgow School of Art
abstract: The cause of the fire, which began on Friday and was extinguished a day later, remained unknown.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Firefighters in Scotland were able to salvage most of the Glasgow School of Art from a fire last week, except for its iconic library located at the top of the building, said Duncan McKenzie, a press officer for the Scottish Fire and Rescue Service on Monday. The cause of the fire, which began on Friday and was extinguished a day later, remained unknown, he said.

headline: Renovation and Controversy at the Roof of the World
abstract: Andrew Jacobs reports from Yushu, a town in Qinghai Province in China’s west that was flattened by an earthquake four years ago, that the vast rebuilding effort has alienated many there.
lead_paragraph: Four years and $7.2 billion later, Yushu, a city high on the Tibetan Plateau that was leveled by a calamitous earthquake, has been largely made whole, as I reported from there recently. There are thousands of new homes, dozens of schools and impressive-looking museums. The reconstruction effort was made all the more challenging by the city’s isolation and thin air.

headline: Beijing Levels New Attack at U.S. Cyber-Spying
keywords: ['Computer Security', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: In a lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, a Chinese government agency has accused the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.
lead_paragraph: A week after United States prosecutors  indicted  five People’s Liberation Army officers on charges of cyber-theft, a Chinese government agency has issued its own lengthy, political indictment of American cyber-espionage, accusing the Obama administration of spying on the Internet on a scale far greater than that of other countries.

headline: Populists’ Rise in Europe Vote Shakes Leaders
abstract: In France, Britain and elsewhere, voters turned against traditional parties to support anti-immigrant groups opposed to the European Union.
lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — An angry eruption of populist insurgency in the elections for the European Parliament rippled across the Continent on Monday, unnerving the political establishment and calling into question the very institutions and assumptions at the heart of Europe’s post-World War II order.

headline: Astrologers Check Modi’s Stars to Offer Advice to New Prime Minister
abstract: Astrologers, who see a boom in business before every election season, warn Narendra Modi of treacherous colleagues and a possible war with an enemy country.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI – Before the parliamentary elections began in April, opinion polls had pointed to a likely victory for the Bharatiya Janata Party and its candidate for prime minister, Narendra Modi.

headline: ‘Mad Men’ Recap: In the Season 7 Finale, Small Steps and Great Leaps
abstract: One major character is gone and a host of others change in ways unexpected for them and the series itself.
lead_paragraph: Season 7, Episode 7, FinaleWhen Don and Peggy danced cheek-to-chest to “My Way” at the end of last week’s “Mad Men,” it was the capper to an episode so thoroughly satisfying it couldn’t help but make the show’s most diehard fans worry. Already, the final season had been broken into two — for network strategy, not artistic integrity or audience demand — and plenty fretted that it could be followed only by a plot-heavy teaser setting up the real final season: the seven episodes that will run sometime in 2015.

headline: After Much Talk, Rangers Quiet Canadiens With Their Play
abstract: Martin St. Louis’s overtime goal Sunday night gave the Rangers a 3-1 series lead in the Eastern Conference finals, leaving Montreal’s coach more subdued than he had been in recent days.
lead_paragraph: Montreal Coach Michel Therrien’s recent bravado was missing when he met the news media Sunday night after Martin St. Louis and the Rangers put the Canadiens on the verge of elimination.

headline: Modi Is Sworn In as Prime Minister of India
abstract: In a message on Monday on his official website, Narendra Modi called on the country to “script a glorious future for India.”
lead_paragraph: Narendra Modi became India’s 14th prime minister on Monday, taking the oath of office and addressing foreign dignitaries, supporters of his party, political rivals and corporate leaders in front of the presidential palace in New Delhi.

headline: After Major Title, Wawrinka Exits in Paris Stunner
abstract: After winning his first major in Melbourne in January, third-seeded Stan Wawrinka of Switzerland tumbled in the first round at Roland Garros to Guillermo García-López of Spain.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Before the French Open began, Stan Wawrinka was asked how different it was to enter a major after winning one, as he did at the Australian Open in January.

headline: Thomas Piketty and Spreadsheets
abstract: Did the French economist, in using a simple spreadsheet program, use the right tool for the job of analyzing economic inequality over time?
lead_paragraph: Like Carmen Reinhart and Kenneth Rogoff before him, Thomas Piketty has had questions  raised about his analysis; in his case, his work on wealth inequality. Though I can’t knowledgeably comment on the questions or the analysis, I can comment on the technology that Ms. Reinhardt, Mr. Rogoff and Mr. Piketty chose to do their work: the spreadsheet. This choice can increase the chances of error in complex analysis, but it also can make finding errors by nonexperts easier.

headline: ‘In Eighteen Hundred Sixty Four the Burying Began’ – Arlington Cemetery at 150
abstract: One hundred fifty years after the first burial at Arlington, the national cemetery is running short of room.
lead_paragraph: Where will they go when there’s no more room in Arlington?

headline: Pfizer Abandons Bid for AstraZeneca
abstract: Pfizer said it “does not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca” in the wake of AstraZeneca’s rejection of a $119 billion bid.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:36 p.m. | On the final day for Pfizer to decide whether to abandon the plan, it said it did not intend to make an offer for AstraZeneca. Last week, the British company rejected what Pfizer had called its final offer. The cash-and-stock bid, which valued AstraZeneca at about $119 billion, would have created the world’s largest drug company.

headline: ‘Ant-Man’ Movie Loses Its Director
abstract: Marvel said it had parted ways with Edgar Wright, whose films include “Shaun of the Dead” and “Scott Pilgrim Vs. the World,” due “to differences in their vision of the film.”
lead_paragraph: The creative team of “Ant-Man,” the Marvel movie based on that size-shifting superhero, has gotten a bit smaller. Marvel Studios announced that Edgar Wright, the British director of “Scott Pilgrim vs. the World” and “Shaun of the Dead,” would no longer be directing “Ant-Man,” about a costumed adventurer who can reduce himself to microscopic size and communicate with insects.

headline: Members of Japanese Pop Group Are Attacked
abstract: Two performers from AKB48, an all-female group, as well as a male staff member who works with the band, were attacked at an event on Sunday by a man wielding a foldable saw.
lead_paragraph: The Japanese pop group AKB48 canceled planned appearances on Monday after two of its band members were attacked at an event on Sunday, The Associated Press reported.

headline: Selling Democrats in Red States
abstract: Mark Putnam specializes in emotionally appealing TV ads for Democrats trying to get re-elected in primarily Republican states. Ken Goldstein, a professor of politics, explains why they work.
lead_paragraph: Mark Putnam specializes in emotionally appealing TV ads for Democrats trying to get re-elected in primarily Republican states. Ken Goldstein, a professor of politics, explains why they work.

headline: European Green Lanterns
abstract: Can willpower save Europe?
lead_paragraph: Sitting in a room listening to EU officials reacting to the European Parliament elections — and it seems to me that they’re deep in denial. Barroso just declared that the euro had nothing to do with the crisis, that it was all failed policies at the national level; a few minutes ago he said that Europe’s real problem is a lack of political will.

headline: Health Care Cost-Sharing Works — Up to a Point
abstract: Deductibles and co-pays keep health spending down while not harming health for most people, but in this area, more may not be better.
lead_paragraph: My colleague Aaron Carroll wrote last week that directly charging consumers for part of their health care costs (the practice known as cost-sharing) can harm the health of poorer or sicker people. But for the rest of us, it seems to reduce spending without harming health. This is the basic conclusion of a famous 1970s experiment funded by the RAND Corporation that randomly assigned families to different levels of responsibility for medical costs.

headline: Turbines Popping Up on New York Roofs, Along With Questions of Efficiency
abstract: Two new wind turbine installations have gone up recently, and at least half a dozen more are on the horizon, though it remains to be seen how popular they will become.
lead_paragraph: A dozen construction workers gathered around a flatbed truck in Long Island City, Queens, one recent Tuesday, marveling at the final piece of a new 15-story apartment building they had just finished assembling. As a mobile crane hoisted the 20-foot-long black contraption over Pearson Street, many of the workers used their phones to film its ascent.

headline: Arcade Fire Addresses Criticism of Video With Transgender Character
abstract: The Arcade Fire frontman, Win Butler, said the band had put careful thought into its video for “We Exist,” which depicts Andrew Garfield as a transgender woman.
lead_paragraph: The rock group Arcade Fire has responded to criticism of a recent video that some viewers felt was insensitive to transgender people, saying that the band put careful consideration into casting and creating the video.

headline: Dave Auckly’s Crunched Charms
abstract: Can you restore these crunched charms? A short introduction to knot theory by mathematician Dave Auckly.
lead_paragraph: Our challenge this week was suggested by Kansas State professor of mathematics Dave Auckly. Dr. Auckly was inspired to create this puzzle while writing his recent paper Two-Fold Branched Covers, which appears in the current issue of the Journal of Knot Theory and its Ramifications.

headline: Victoria & Albert Museum Starts ‘Rapid Response Collecting’
abstract: A new gallery opening this summer will include an Ikea soft today, a 3-D printed gun and a pair of jeans acquired after the collapse of a factory in Bangladesh.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Museums tend to take the long view when it comes to acquiring works, but the Victoria & Albert Museum here has announced that a new gallery opening this summer will be dedicated to “rapid response collecting.” That means the kind of items that can mostly be bought without having an acquisitions committee meeting.

headline: Technology Companies Are Pressing Congress to Bolster Privacy Protections
keywords: ['Electronic Communications Privacy Act', 'Privacy', 'Cloud Computing', 'Law and Legislation', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: Cloud computing companies fear that a Reagan-era law governing access to email and other data is causing an image problem in the United States and hurting business.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A law that allows the government to read email and cloud-stored data over six months old without a search warrant is under attack from technology companies, trade associations and lobbying groups, which are pressing Congress to tighten privacy protections. Federal investigators have used the law to view content hosted by third-party providers for civil and criminal lawsuits, in some cases without giving notice to the individual being investigated.

headline: Grilled Gorgonzola and Beet Green Sandwich
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Cheese', 'Sandwiches', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: A satisfying dinner that can be put together in 10 minutes.
lead_paragraph: This dish is the one that inspired me to devote a week of Recipes for Health to toaster-oven vegetable and grilled cheese sandwiches. I made it one night after a day preparing enough quiche to feed 80 for a book signing. When I got home I had still more quiches to make in my own kitchen, and the last thing I wanted to do was cook dinner for myself.

headline: Grilled Feta and Roasted Squash Sandwich
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Cheese', 'Sandwiches', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The sweet and earthy flavors of roasted squash are a tasty contrast to salty feta.
lead_paragraph: I had a hunk of butternut squash lingering in my refrigerator, and it turned out to be the perfect ingredient for a grilled cheese and vegetable sandwich. I roasted it to bring out its sweetness, and paired it with chopped fresh sage, my favorite herb to use with winter squash. The rest came together quite naturally. The sweet and earthy flavors against the salty feta are perfect. You’ll have more mashed roasted squash than you need for one sandwich. Use it in another, or freeze it for another night when you’re too tired to cook.

headline: Grilled Goat Cheese and Broccoli Sandwich
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Cheese', 'Sandwiches', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: The Middle Eastern nut and spice mix called dukkah is the surprise touch in this sandwich.
lead_paragraph: I’ve been finding all sorts of uses for finely chopped broccoli crowns lately (see my burgers from a couple of weeks ago). I make a broccoli and goat cheese spread for this sandwich. I briefly steam the broccoli, chop it finely and mash it with the goat cheese. Then I spread it on country bread, sprinkle with the nut and spice mix known as dukkah and top with the other slice of bread. The dukkah adds the surprise touch. You’ll only use half the chopped steamed broccoli in one sandwich. But you’ll want to use up the rest in another.

headline: Roasted Mushroom and Gruyère Sandwich
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Cheese', 'Sandwiches', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Mushrooms add a somewhat meaty essence to this quick vegetarian sandwich.
lead_paragraph: For this sandwich, you can also pan-fry the mushrooms, which give this sandwich a somewhat meaty quality. But in this case I used the toaster oven to roast the mushrooms. You’ll need only half of the roasted mushrooms for 1 sandwich but you’ll find a good use for the rest of them, I’m sure.

headline: Grilled Goat Cheese, Roasted Pepper, and Greens Sandwich
keywords: ['Cooking and Cookbooks', 'Recipes', 'Cheese', 'Sandwiches', 'Diet and Nutrition', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Roasted artichoke hearts are an optional addition to this vegetable-filled sandwich.
lead_paragraph: The title of this recipe was getting very long, so I left the last option – roasted artichoke hearts – out of it. I included them in my sandwich because I had some shriveling artichokes in my produce bin (along with the shriveling red pepper I used) and it didn’t take very long to trim and roast them. But it’s not a must; the peppers and goat cheese with the greens are what really stand out. I stir everything together and spread it on the bread. It’s always a good idea to have a roasted pepper on hand for quick dinners like this.

headline: Herb Jeffries, ‘Bronze Buckaroo’ of Song and Screen, Dies at 100 (or So)
abstract: Mr. Jeffries sang with Duke Ellington and starred in early black westerns using a nickname that evoked his malleable racial identity.
lead_paragraph: Herb Jeffries, who sang with Duke Ellington and starred in early black westerns as a singing cowboy known as “the Bronze Buckaroo” — a nickname that evoked his malleable racial identity — died on Sunday in West Hills, Calif. He was believed to be 100.

headline: Podcast: Crowd-Constructing Retinas, World Science Festival, Genetics of Beer
abstract: Sebastian Seung wants you to help trace the connections in a mouse’s eye — a step toward understanding its brain, and ours. The World Science Festival opens in New York City this week and there’s a little something for every mind. To understand why beer varies in taste, you need to know its yeasts.

headline: Strange Brews: The Genes of Craft Beer
abstract: While brewing yeast is one of the best-studied organisms in molecular and cell biology, exactly how its genes translate to varied beers is still poorly understood.
lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — Troels Prahl, a brewer and microbiologist at the Southern California yeast distributor White Labs, sits at his company’s tasting room bar with four half-pints of beer. He describes each between thoughtful sips.

headline: Image of the Day: May 26
abstract: Narendra Modi took oath as India’s prime minister at the Rashtrapati Bhawan in New Delhi.

headline: Obama, Honoring the Fallen, Says V.A. Problems Must Be Faced
keywords: ['Memorial Day', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Veterans']
abstract: President Obama, just back from a surprise visit to the troops in Afghanistan, said, “We must do more to keep faith with our veterans and their families.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, just back from a surprise visit to the troops in Afghanistan, honored America’s fallen warriors in a solemn Memorial Day ceremony on Monday and acknowledged the need to confront the widening scandal at the nation’s veterans hospitals.

headline: E.U. Debates Which Nation Will Regulate Web Privacy
keywords: ['Law and Legislation', 'Privacy', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Surveillance of Citizens by Government']
abstract: As the European Union nears agreement on a law for information privacy, some expect one nation’s regulators to enforce the rules throughout the union.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The new European Parliament that was voted into office over the weekend, despite having a different political makeup, is widely expected to reach a final agreement this year on stricter online privacy rules that have long been in the works.

headline: Guarding Against Disease Among Pilgrims to Mecca
keywords: ['Meningitis', 'MERS (Middle East Respiratory Syndrome)', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Medicine and Health']
abstract: Saudi and European scientists outline steps that will be taken to prevent outbreaks of MERS and other illnesses when the hajj starts in October.
lead_paragraph: Going all the way back to a malaria epidemic in A.D. 632, the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca has been vulnerable to infectious disease. Last year the number of pilgrims fell below two million, from the expected three million, because of fears over the Middle East respiratory syndrome virus, or MERS.

headline: Welcoming the Newly Discovered
abstract: An annual top-10 list celebrates species still here while underscoring those that have gone extinct.
lead_paragraph: Amid the discouraging headlines about the extinction of wildlife species around the world, there is this bright spot: So many new species of animals and plants are discovered every year that no one knows the number.

headline: U.S. Doctor Is Killed by Gunman in Pakistan
abstract: Mehdi Ali Qamar, a cardiologist based in Ohio and a follower of the minority Ahmadi faith, was shot in Punjab Province, where he was volunteering at a hospital.
lead_paragraph: LAHORE, Pakistan — An American doctor volunteering at a hospital in eastern Pakistan was shot to death on Monday in front of his wife and 3-year-old son in the latest attack on a follower of the minority Ahmadi faith at a time of rising intolerance across the country.

headline: An Amphibian’s Best Friend
abstract: A museum curator works on behalf of declining species.
lead_paragraph: Darrel R. Frost, the chief herpetology curator at the American Museum of Natural History, has done fieldwork in Ethiopia, Guatemala, Mexico, Namibia, Peru, South Africa and Vietnam. He is also a sort of gatekeeper for amphibians.

headline: Veterans Fire Back at Letter by Senator
abstract: Senator Richard M. Burr’s letter that said leaders of veterans groups were defending the status quo at the V.A. drew fierce responses.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An “open letter” from a senior Republican senator to the nation’s veterans in which he castigates the leadership of veterans’ organizations prompted a brutal war of words over the Memorial Day weekend, including a promise from the Veterans of Foreign Wars that its “hat in hand” approach to Congress will turn more combative.

headline: Finding Lightness in the Dark
keywords: ['Blindness', 'Disabilities', 'Eyes and Eyesight', 'Medicine and Health', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The author Rosemary Mahoney went from equating blindness to “being buried alive” to a realization, over time and around the world, of what she hadn’t seen.
lead_paragraph: Life without sight seems unimaginably bleak to the sighted. No matter that literate guides from Diderot to Oliver Sacks have confirmed that the blind thrive in their separate reality; the gulf between the light world and the dark one persists.

headline: How to Win the Lottery (Happily)
abstract: The key to winning the lottery and remaining happily may simply be to first win the jackpot. The “curse” part is being debunked.
lead_paragraph: If you have won the lottery, or if you plan to do so, please keep reading this column. The information is vital not just to your happiness but also to the progress of social science.

headline: Freud’s Intellectual Wellspring
abstract: Adam Phillips’s “Becoming Freud: The Making of a Psychoanalyst” comments on the first 50 years of Freud’s 83-year life.
lead_paragraph: “Becoming Freud: The Making of a Psychoanalyst,” by the English psychoanalyst, editor and writer Adam Phillips, is about the first 50 years of Freud’s 83-year life. This short, dense book is partly a group of abbreviated biographical commentaries, partly about Freud’s career and writings until 1906. It uses both ordinary language and literary terminology to replace traditional psychoanalytic terms and jargon, although Mr. Phillips’s understanding and theorizing are familiar and generally conformable. It is also a less-than-perfect performance.

headline: Young, but Willing to Take On a Challenge
abstract: The New York Youth Symphony closed its 51st season on Sunday by playing Copland’s Third Symphony at Carnegie Hall.
lead_paragraph: The gifted, hard-working and game musicians of the New York Youth Symphony have played some formidable scores over the years, even Mahler’s mighty Sixth Symphony. In some ways, though, Copland’s Symphony No. 3 is harder to pull off in performance than many pieces that may sound a lot more difficult.

headline: Fear Persists in a Divided Ukraine
abstract: In eastern Ukraine, fear of armed separatists led to low voter turnout in the election that propelled Petro O. Poroshenko to victory as the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: In eastern Ukraine, fear of armed separatists led to low voter turnout in the election that propelled Petro O. Poroshenko to victory as the president-elect.

headline: Syndergaard, a Top Prospect, Is Put on the Disabled List
abstract: Noah Syndergaard, a powerful right-hander, planned to be examined by team doctors in New York after sustaining an injury the team described as mild.
lead_paragraph: Noah Syndergaard, the Mets’ top pitching prospect, was placed on the disabled list with “a mild flexor-pronator strain” in his arm, the team said Monday.

lead_paragraph: Peter van Agtmael’s new book is a personal look at America’s recent wars, as well as his own struggles to experience and explain conflict.

lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Jordan ordered Syria’s ambassador to leave the country within 24 hours on Monday after accusing him of “repeated insults to Jordan and its leadership, institutions and citizens.”

headline: Protecting Newborns Against Whooping Cough
keywords: ['Babies and Infants', 'Medicine and Health', 'Vaccination and Immunization', 'Whooping Cough']
abstract: Research suggests that pregnant women who get a vaccination to protect against tetanus, diphtheria and whooping cough are helping their babies, too.
lead_paragraph: All pregnant women are advised to get the Tdap vaccine, which protects against tetanus, diphtheria and pertussis, or whooping cough. A small study suggests the vaccine may have benefits for newborns as well.

headline: An Alien In His Body
abstract: Gideon Glick talks about playing Matthew, a chronically anxious 19-year-old who finds refuge in the grungy office of a newsletter aimed at long-haul truckers, in the play “The Few.”
lead_paragraph: Gideon Glick talks about playing Matthew, a chronically anxious 19-year-old who finds refuge in the grungy office of a newsletter aimed at long-haul truckers, in the play “The Few.”

headline: Vision Training to Boost Sports Performance
abstract: Recent studies show that vision training has helped athletes improve performance, though it has more to do with the brain than with the eyes.
lead_paragraph: The baseball hurtles toward the batter, and he must decide from its rotation whether it’s a fastball worth a swing or a slider about to drop out of the strike zone.

keywords: ['Automobile Racing', 'Nascar Sprint Cup Series', 'Monaco Grand Prix (Auto Race)', 'Indianapolis 500 (Auto Race)']

lead_paragraph: Ryan Hunter-Reay made a breathtaking pass of Helio Castroneves with one lap to go and held on to win Sunday in one of the closest and fastest Indianapolis 500 races ever.

headline: Ukraine’s Next President Vows to Restore Order and Mend Russia Ties
abstract: After his decisive election victory on Sunday, the pro-European billionaire Petro O. Poroshenko said he would not negotiate with armed rebels.
lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — The president-elect of Ukraine, Petro O. Poroshenko, vowed on Monday to restore order in the country’s east, which is besieged by pro-Russian separatist violence, but said he would not negotiate with armed rebels and instead would demand swifter results from a military campaign that has achieved only limited success.

headline: Pain Medications Can Lose Their Punch
abstract: A phenomenon called tolerance and other factors, a pain medicine specialist says, help explain why a pain pill doesn’t work as well after a while.
lead_paragraph: Q. WHY WOULD A PAIN MEDICATION LOSE ITS EFFICACY AFTER WORKING WELL FOR SEVERAL YEARS?

abstract: Francis made his first visit to the Holy Land, making strong symbolic gestures to promote the perspectives of the Palestinian and Israeli leaderships.
lead_paragraph: Francis made his first visit to the Holy Land, making strong symbolic gestures to promote the perspectives of the Palestinian and Israeli leaderships.

headline: Those Mannerisms, Not So Off-Putting Now
abstract: Gideon Glick, starring in the Off Broadway drama “The Few,” believes in bringing a lot of himself to his characters, even his physical tics.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to imagine that the word “yeah” has ever yielded more laughs or more heartbreak than it does in the Off Broadway drama “The Few,” as performed by the actor Gideon Glick.

headline: Waggling Bees Give Their Verdict on a Landscape
abstract: By observing bees’ waggle dances, scientists found that a program to make cropland more attractive for foraging wasn’t a resounding success.
lead_paragraph: European officials have spent more than $56 billion over the past decade in a program to mitigate landscape change and encourage environmentally friendly practices by farmers. But there is little evidence on how effective these vast expenditures have been. So researchers at the University of Sussex in Brighton, England, decided to seek the opinion of some discriminating judges of environmental quality: bees.

headline: Barbara Walters Gives Archives to Sarah Lawrence College
abstract: A collection from the pioneering broadcast journalist Barbara Walters includes papers, recordings and photographs from her television career.
lead_paragraph: Barbara Walters may no longer be on view to television audiences on a regular basis, but some day it will be possible to review the materials she accumulated in her pioneering journalism career with 20/20 hindsight (give or take the prescription in your corrective lenses).

headline: Lessons of Old Are Still in the Air at the School of American Ballet
abstract: Dance is an oral tradition, and stories are passed from one generation to the next at the School of American Ballet, established by George Balanchine and Lincoln Kirstein in 1934.
lead_paragraph: How does a teenager turn into a cowboy at the School of American Ballet? It’s all in the chest.

headline: Duke Holds Off Notre Dame to Win Third Lacrosse Title in Five Years
abstract: A face-off victory late in the game was critical in helping the Blue Devils’ John Danowski become the ninth men’s lacrosse coach to win three N.C.A.A. Division I championships.
lead_paragraph: BALTIMORE — After 59 minutes, the N.C.A.A. men’s lacrosse championship was, in essence, coming down to a face-off, and hobbling in a hurry down Duke’s sideline on crutches, his right leg wrapped in a black cast, was Josh Dionne.

headline: A Diverted Flight Offers Lessons on Keeping Cool
abstract: A design executive learns to relax by watching a famous pilot handle a crowd, and seeing how fellow passengers responded to landing in the wrong city.
lead_paragraph: I DO a lot of international travel. I used to be annoyed by long flights, and now I look forward to them since I have time to read, work or catch up on some TV I never get to watch, like “Game of Thrones.” I travel so much, I blew through three seasons and am now caught up with Season 4.

headline: De Blasio, at Memorial Day Events, Pays Tribute to Veterans
abstract: In two emotional speeches, Mayor Bill de Blasio drew on memories of his father, a World War II veteran, and noted the importance of sharing stories of the fallen.
lead_paragraph: In a day of honoring the fallen, Mayor Bill de Blasio focused on veterans, noting in two emotional speeches that through their stories and tributes they kept alive the memories of those who died at war.

lead_paragraph: About once a month, Therese Hampton flies from Portland, Ore., where her home office is based, to the Seattle-Tacoma International Airport, a 35-minute flight, to meet with co-workers.

keywords: ['Computers and the Internet', 'Science and Technology', '3-D Devices and Effects', 'Brain', 'Crowdsourcing (Internet)', 'Games', 'Eyes and Eyesight']
abstract: Players of Eyewire, an online neuroscience puzzle, are scoring scientific successes.
lead_paragraph: Crowd-sourced science has exploded in recent years. Foldit enlists users to help solve scientific puzzles such as how proteins are put together. Zooniverse hosts dozens of projects, including searching for planets and identifying images of animals caught on automatic cameras.

headline: All Circuits Are Busy
abstract: A brain researcher conveys a sense of unlimited possibility in brain mapping, predicting it may be achieved in 20 to 30 years.
lead_paragraph: H. Sebastian Seung is a prophet of the connectome, the wiring diagram of the brain. In a popular book, debates and public talks he has argued that in that wiring lies each person’s identity.

headline: No Real Hurry to Tell the Joke
keywords: ['Television', 'Comedy and Humor', 'Video Recordings, Downloads and Streaming']
abstract: Bob Newhart, whose 1970s series, “The Bob Newhart Show,” is being released this week in a boxed set, has always been a gentle minimalist, earning laughs by doing nearly nothing.
lead_paragraph: Abbott set up Costello, and Burns relied on Gracie to finish the joke, but Bob Newhart is the rare straight man who gets laughs all on his own.

headline: Information Not on the Label
abstract: The F.D.A. still does not require that food products made with genetically modified plants be identified, despite public backing of such labels, but food buyers have options.
lead_paragraph: If you want to know whether the bread you’re about to buy was sweetened with corn syrup, you can check the label. The same is true if you’re concerned about preservatives, caramel coloring or artificial flavoring. By law, all of these ingredients must be listed on food labels.

headline: Behind the Cover Story: Michael Behar on ‘Star Trek,’ Acupuncture and Bioelectronics
abstract: Michael Behar, a science and technology writer, discusses why his love for Star Trek led him to discover the growing field of bioelectronics.
lead_paragraph: Michael Behar, a science and technology writer, wrote the May 25 cover story about the emerging field of bioelectronics.

headline: Southern Rock, Proudly Revised
abstract: New releases include albums by Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires, Sleaford Mods and Owen Pallett.
lead_paragraph: From Lynyrd Skynyrd to the Black Crowes to the Drive-By Truckers, Southern rockers have been acutely self-conscious about where they come from, writing songs steeped in history, local color, memories, everyday life, expectations and paradoxes. Lee Bains III & the Glory Fires, a four-man band from Alabama, proudly join the Southern-rock tradition of wild-eyed music hitched to serious deliberation. “Dereconstructed,” the band’s second album, ponders Southern identity in a welter of cranked-up guitars, bristling drums and rasping, hollering vocals. It’s pandemonium with a conscience.

headline: A Performer Leaves His Company, With Jewels in His Wake
abstract: Jonathan Stafford, a principal with New York City Ballet, bade farewell on Sunday in George Balanchine’s classic “Jewels.”
lead_paragraph: Hail and farewell. George Balanchine’s “Jewels” (1967) — the first big hit he created for New York City Ballet after the company moved to Lincoln Center in April 1964, and now a mainstay of international repertory — returned to the David H. Koch Theater for four performances this weekend as part of the troupe’s 50th-anniversary season. (It will not be danced there in 2014-15.) At its Sunday performance, the principal dancer Jonathan Stafford bade goodbye to the company.  Mr. Stafford, who studied with the renowned Pennsylvania teacher Marcia Dale Weary and then School of American Ballet, joined City Ballet in February 1999; he has been a principal since May 2007. He has been among the most discreet, unshowy of dancers: a true but self-effacing gentleman.

headline: G.E. Chief to Meet With Hollande on Alstom Deal
abstract: The meeting comes as the American company and Siemens of Germany both try to persuade the French government that it is making the best offer.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — General Electric and Siemens are going all out this week to woo France as they compete to acquire the energy business of Alstom, the struggling French conglomerate that makes high-speed TGV trains.

headline: If Chairs Could Talk? These Can
abstract: “The Chairs,” at La MaMa, is the director Theodora Skipitares’s puppet theater response to Eugene Ionesco’s absurdist play.
lead_paragraph: Even when I wasn’t sure what I was seeing in “The Chairs,” I always liked what I saw. This “puppet theater response” to Eugene Ionesco’s absurdist play is by turns potent, perplexing, inspiring and weird. Consistently, though, it’s quite engaging to watch.

headline: Battlefield Skills at Work in a City Hospital
abstract: The medical crises are rapid-fire and improbable, and the doctors who deal with them are easy-to-grasp cutouts in “The Night Shift,” a new medical drama on NBC.
lead_paragraph: The medical crises are rapid-fire and improbable, and the doctors who deal with them are easy-to-grasp cutouts in “The Night Shift,” a medical drama starting on Tuesday night on NBC that is akin to beach reading. There is plenty here to get your adrenaline flowing but not much to tax your brain.

headline: Amazon Strategy Raises Hackles in Germany
abstract: The U.S. company's tough tactics with one of the country's publishers have been taken as an indication of its moves in the future.
lead_paragraph: BERLIN — It was German authors, carefully monitoring their Amazon rankings, who were among the first to notice something was amiss.

headline: In a Choreographer’s Series, a Moment to Showcase Her Influences
abstract: In “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier,” Ms. Dorvillier is honoring those who have influenced her, with a lineup of solos they’ve created and performed.
lead_paragraph: Walk into St. Mark’s Church in the East Village between now and June 14, and look up. About a dozen handmade flags hang from the rafters, each emblematic of a different project by DD Dorvillier, the choreographer and thoughtful iconoclast at the center of Danspace Project’s latest platform, “Diary of an Image by DD Dorvillier.”

headline: Mets Have a Trying Day From Beginning to End

lead_paragraph: Ike Davis bounded through the visitors’ dugout at Citi Field on Monday, wearing all black, a Pirates hat and a shirt that read, “Men of Steel.”

headline: Signs of Diplomacy as Indian Leader Is Sworn In
abstract: Narendra Modi was sworn in on Monday as India’s prime minister. Among those attending the ceremony was Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif of Pakistan, hinting that the two countries may revive a moribund peace process.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — Outside the sandstone palace that was built for the viceroy of British-ruled India, before a crowd that included corporate titans, Bollywood heartthrobs and saffron-robed Hindu holy men, Narendra Modi, the son of a provincial tea-seller, was sworn in on Monday as India’s prime minister.

headline: Advocates Seek to Make Courthouses Off Limits for Immigration Officials
abstract: In a series of cases, immigrants have been questioned and detained in courthouses, eroding their willingness to participate in the judicial system, advocates and politicians say.
lead_paragraph: Rosario Socope, a Guatemalan immigrant in the country illegally, had an unwelcome surprise waiting for her when she attended a pretrial hearing on a felony charge at a courthouse in Brooklyn this month. As she stepped out of the courtroom into a public hallway, she was approached by immigration agents seeking to deport her.

headline: Applying the Lessons of Politics to Green Power
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Electric Light and Power', 'Customer Relations']
abstract: Ethical Electric, a start-up founded by a former Washington political operative, allows customers to sign up for electricity from renewable sources.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the years, Tom Matzzie — by working as a political operative on John Kerry’s 2004 presidential campaign and on building the antiwar movement that helped usher President Obama into office — became convinced that the key to creating change was to make it easy for people to participate.

headline: To Prepare for the World Cup, a Host City Could Use Extra Time
abstract: When the World Cup begins next month, many of the $1.4 billion-worth of projects in Cuiabá, one of the 12 Brazilian host cities, will be far from completion.
lead_paragraph: CUIABÁ, Brazil — The four-day annual rodeo here draws about 80,000 fans, almost twice as many as the state soccer league attracted all of last year. No local team has played in the Brazilian first division since the 1980s.

headline: Djokovic’s Greatest Motivation Isn’t on Court
abstract: Novak Djokovic, one of the best men’s players never to win the French Open, often plays his best when inspired by something off the court, and his homeland, Serbia, might provide some inspiration this year at Roland Garros.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Novak Djokovic was safe and dry after his first-round victory at the French Open on Monday, and it was noted that he often seems to play his best when he is playing for a cause higher than tennis.

headline: Dairy Queen Finds a Summer Love: The S’more
abstract: The company’s new ad campaign focuses on limited-time offers, including the S’mores Blizzard, returning from last summer, and a second item, the Chips Ahoy Blizzard, new for this summer.
lead_paragraph: THEY are not long, the days of wine and roses. Nor, as Madison Avenue knows, are the days of summer selling, which are vital to companies in areas like fast food, beverages and tourism that must gather their rosebuds — and revenue — while they may. For marketers, summer typically runs from Memorial Day through Labor Day; this year, that makes 99 days to wheel and deal.

headline: Really Good Books, Part II
abstract: A few more book recommendations: Athenian books to invigorate the audacious spirit, and religious and literary books to probe the conscience and heart.
lead_paragraph: On Friday, I offered some of my favorite books, as possibilities for summer reading. The books of Part Two come in two baskets, which we’ll call Athens and Jerusalem. The Athens books fire external ambition; the Jerusalem books focus on the inner spirit.

headline: Leadership on Transgender Civil Rights
keywords: ['Transgender and Transsexual', 'Civil Rights and Liberties', 'Discrimination', 'Law and Legislation', 'Editorials']
abstract: If New York is to fill a gap in its civil rights protections, the governor will have to work on the recalcitrant State Senate.
lead_paragraph: “We are closer today to creating that open, respectful, inclusive world that we want for all of our children,” Maryland’s Democratic governor, Martin O’Malley, said of the law making Maryland the 18th state to extend civil rights protections to transgender people.

headline: In a New Role, a Champion of the Homeless Looks to Prove His Critics Wrong
abstract: Steven Banks, the commissioner of the Human Resources Administration, wants to take the nation’s largest municipal poverty agency in a new direction.
lead_paragraph: Not long after Mayor Bill de Blasio appointed him as commissioner of the nation’s largest municipal poverty agency, Steven Banks got a fat raspberry of a hello from The New York Post.

headline: Super Secure, Super Late
abstract: The headquarters of the Department of Homeland Security was supposed to be completed this year. Instead, it has become a ghostly lesson in the ways of Washington.
lead_paragraph: In the feverish early months of the war on terror, the administration of President George W. Bush thought big when it came to displaying the nation’s muscle and resolve. The White House created the Department of Homeland Security superagency from an archipelago of 22 federal departments with more than 200,000 workers.

headline: Nigerian Military Says It Knows Location of Abducted Girls
abstract: The military commander said he would not disclose further details out of concern for the girls’ safety.
lead_paragraph: Nigeria’s military knows the location of nearly 300 girls abducted from school seven weeks ago by Boko Haram extremists, the top commander of the country’s armed forces said Monday. The assertion by the commander, Air Chief Marshal Alex Badeh, was the first time the Nigerian government had publicly claimed to know the whereabouts of the missing girls, whose abduction has provoked global outrage and criticism of the Nigeria military for having failed to find and rescue them.

headline: In Complaint, Activists Seek Audit of New York Police Surveillance
keywords: ['Surveillance of Citizens by Government', 'Search and Seizure', 'Espionage and Intelligence Services']
abstract: After reports that the Police Department secretly monitored political groups, several are requesting a review of its intelligence-gathering operations.
lead_paragraph: Several groups plan to file a formal complaint on Tuesday seeking an audit of the New York Police Department’s intelligence gathering operations, after recent revelations that the department had been monitoring political activists, sending undercover officers to their meetings and filing reports on their plans.

headline: The C.I.A.’s Deadly Ruse in Pakistan
abstract: A sham vaccination program produced a lethal backlash in the country, leaving dozens of murdered workers and fearful parents shunning polio vaccine.
lead_paragraph: The use of a sham vaccination program in the government’s hunt for Osama bin Laden has produced a lethal backlash in Pakistan where dozens of public health workers have been murdered and fearful parents are shunning polio vaccine for their children.

headline: A Cable Merger Too Far
keywords: ['Mergers, Acquisitions and Divestitures', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Cable Television', 'Computers and the Internet', 'Telephones and Telecommunications', 'Editorials']
abstract: Regulators should block Comcast’s acquisition of Time Warner Cable because it would control too much of what consumers watch, read and listen to.
lead_paragraph: There are good reasons the Justice Department and the Federal Communications Commission should block Comcast’s $45 billion acquisition of Time Warner Cable. The merger will concentrate too much market power in the hands of one company, creating a telecommunications colossus the likes of which the country has not seen since 1984 when the government forced the breakup of the original AT&T telephone monopoly.

headline: Governments Await Obama’s Move on Carbon to Gauge U.S. Climate Efforts
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States International Relations', 'Global Warming', 'Coal', 'Law and Legislation', 'Air Pollution', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Clean Air Act']
abstract: Governments across the world are watching for a new regulation targeted at coal-fired power plants that is expected to be the United States’ most forceful effort yet to address climate change.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama is expected to announce on Monday an Environmental Protection Agency regulation to cut carbon pollution from the nation’s 600 coal-fired power plants, in a speech that government analysts in Beijing, Brussels and beyond will scrutinize to determine how serious the president is about fighting global warming.

headline: What Did the Framers Really Mean?
abstract: It’s no secret: The Second Amendment was about the common defense.
lead_paragraph: Three days after the publication of Michael Waldman’s new book, “The Second Amendment: A Biography,” Elliot Rodger, 22, went on a killing spree, stabbing three people and then shooting another eight, killing four of them, including himself. This was only the latest mass shooting in recent memory, going back to Columbine.

headline: Ouster at Rap Genius Over Comments on Shooting Manifesto
abstract: Notes about a document related to a California killing rampage led to an online backlash against Mahbod Moghadam, a founder of a website that tries to let people decipher hip-hop lyrics.
lead_paragraph: The authorities say that before Elliot O. Rodger killed six people near the campus of the University of California, Santa Barbara, on Friday night, he left behind a 140-page manifesto.

headline: Reining In the N.S.A.

headline: Spain: Village Votes for New Name
abstract: Residents of Castrillo Matajudíos, which loosely translates as Little Fort of Jew Killers, have voted to change the name of their village.
lead_paragraph: The residents of Castrillo Matajudíos, which loosely translates as Little Fort of Jew Killers, have voted to change the name of their village to erase any links to the persecution of Jews and a dark chapter in Spain’s history. The name change was approved by 29 residents and opposed by 19, Mayor Lorenzo Rodríguez Pérez said Sunday. The village has only 56 registered inhabitants. The village will be renamed Castrillo Mota de Judíos, or Little Hill Fort of Jews. Historical records have so far failed to yield a definitive answer about how the village got its name. One possible explanation is that Jewish converts to Catholicism in the 17th century switched to a name that would clearly distance them from their Jewish past and reduce the risk of further persecution. Another is that a local clerk mistakenly changed “mota,” or hill, into “mata,” or kill.

headline: Li Na Ousted in First Round of French Open
abstract: Kristina Mladenovic of France beat Li Na on Tuesday, 7-5, 3-6, 6-1, which means the Australian Open’s two singles winners, Li and Stan Wawrinka, have both been eliminated.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — On Monday night Stan Wawrinka, the men’s singles champion at the Australian Open in January, lost in the first round at the French Open.

headline: Another Reason to Consider Renting
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)']
abstract: The latest housing numbers show a big jump in home prices in the 12 months leading up to March 2014. Those gains aren’t likely to continue.
lead_paragraph: Today’s new house-price numbers are another reason for people in many markets to think seriously about renting. Home prices in the 20 largest metropolitan areas rose a whopping 12.4 percent between March 2013 and March 2014, according to the the S&P/Case-Shiller Home Price Indices. That’s clearly unsustainable, and it’s a reminder of how strongly home prices have rebounded in many markets.

headline: When a Family Move Falls Through: ‘Who Died and Made Me Not Boss?’
abstract: When finances fall through, a planned move home to the United States falls through as well.
lead_paragraph: Matt and I found out that income we were depending on — related to his books — fell through. We sat for hours going over the figures. A day earlier, we had asked a real estate agent in Rockland County, N.Y., to visit a property. “Can you hear the noise from the Palisades Parkway?” we wrote. The rent was a little higher than we had wanted, but it was on a cul-de-sac, and after apartment living I imagined the kids being in heaven there.

headline: Podcast: Genetics of Beer
abstract: To understand why beer varies in taste, you need to know its yeasts.
lead_paragraph: To understand why beer varies in taste, you need to know its yeasts.

headline: Have You Seen Filming in New York City?
abstract: If you have observed something unusual while a film or TV series was shot in New York City, tell us about your experience.
lead_paragraph: The film industry is increasingly turning to Brooklyn for production locations, expanding its reach into boroughs outside Manhattan. While more films have been shot in Manhattan than any other borough, half of the 29 television series produced in New York City last season were based in Brooklyn. “The Good Wife,” “The Carrie Diaries,” “Blue Bloods” and “Hostages,” to name a few, have embraced Brooklyn, as have recent feature films like “The Amazing Spider-Man 2″ and “Cymbeline.”

headline: Pope Francis to Meet Victims of Sexual Abuse
abstract: The pope discussed his plans during an impromptu news conference with reporters aboard his plane. He also answered questions on papal retirement and priestly celibacy.
lead_paragraph: ROME — Pope Francis says he plans to meet soon with abuse victims to underscore the Vatican’s determination to move forward with “zero tolerance” toward clergy members accused of abusing minors.

lead_paragraph: Stuart Elliott, the advertising columnist, answers questions from readers each week. Questions can be sent to stuarte@nytimes.com.
