headline: Bookshelf | A Surrealist Ode to a Radical Era in Furniture Design
abstract: The artist and provocateur Maurizio Cattelan and his frequent co-conspirator, the photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari, release a book capturing avant-garde furniture from the late ’60s in often-outrageous tableaux.
lead_paragraph: There’s a photograph in “1968: Radical Italian Furniture” — the new book (out May 31) by the artist and provocateur Maurizio Cattelan and his frequent collaborator, the photographer Pierpaolo Ferrari — of a woman dressed in pink trousers, standing on top of a desk. Crouched down expertly in heels, she stares blankly into the camera and urinates — quite deliberately, it seems — onto the piece of furniture beneath her.

headline: Letterman to Moderate Seinfeld Discussion
abstract: The talk-show host will make a rare appearance outside his television show.
lead_paragraph: Now that David Letterman is staring retirement in the eye, he’s suddenly considering all kinds of opportunities he probably thought he’d never agree to before – like appearing at public events.

headline: Intersection | Fashion in Eastern Congo
abstract: In Goma, Sunday is the day that people dress up and Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-professed sapeur who designed his own unique tie skirt, is no exception.
lead_paragraph: In Goma, Sunday is the day that people dress up and Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-professed sapeur who designed his own unique tie skirt, is no exception.

headline: Pharrell Williams and Spike Lee to Team Up at the Apollo
abstract: Spike Lee will be the director of a Pharrell Williams concert at the Apollo Theater on June 3.
lead_paragraph: Pharrell Williams’s debut at the Apollo Theater on June 3 is bound to be an occasion. After working behind the scenes for more than two decades as a songwriter and producer, the 41-year-old singer is having his moment, with a hit album (“G I R L”), a single that has been at or near the top of the chart for weeks (“Happy”), a Vivienne Westwood mountain hat that has been an unmistakable trademark ever since he turned up at the Grammy Awards wearing it in January, and a children’s book – plus an online interactive game – in the works.

headline: Complaints and Warnings About Plan to Replenish Fire Island’s Dunes
abstract: Critics of the $170 million project, scheduled to start after Labor Day, go beyond the homeowners who will be affected.
lead_paragraph: DAVIS PARK, N.Y. — As a longtime summer resident of Fire Island, Robert Spencer was in favor of the federal government’s $170 million effort to replenish the dunes washed away during the ravages of Hurricane Sandy.

headline: Rolling Stones Resume Performing in Norway Following Death of L’Wren Scott
abstract: The band performed in Oslo on Monday, its first concert since the death of the fashion designer L’Wren Scott, who was Mick Jagger’s girlfriend.
lead_paragraph: Was there any doubt that the Rolling Stones would be rolling again? On Monday night, the Stones played the first concert of their European tour at the Telenor Arena in Oslo. It was the group’s first concert since the death of the fashion designer L’Wren Scott, who was also the girlfriend of the band’s singer, Mick Jagger. At the time of Ms. Scott’s death, which was ruled a suicide, the Stones were about to begin a tour of Australia and New Zealand. Those concerts were postponed until October and November.

headline: U.S. Troops to Leave Afghanistan by End of 2016
keywords: ['United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'International Relations']
abstract: The withdrawal of combat troops from Afghanistan will allow the United States to confront an emerging terrorist threat from the Middle East and Africa, President Obama said.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Obama, declaring that it was “time to turn the page on a decade in which so much of our foreign policy was focused on the wars in Afghanistan and Iraq,” announced on Tuesday that he planned to withdraw the last American troops from Afghanistan by the end of 2016.

headline: Americans’ Varied Views of ‘Global Warming’ and ‘Climate Change’
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Politics and Government', 'Polls and Public Opinion', 'United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change']
abstract: Global warming appears to have more salience than “climate change” in the views of many Americans.
lead_paragraph: Anthony Leiserowitz, the director of the Yale Project on Climate Change Communication, has distributed a note summarizing the findings of “What’s In A Name? Global Warming vs Climate Change,” an interesting new study of Americans’ perceptions of the two dominant shorthand phrases used to describe the building human influence on the climate system.

headline: The Lessons of a Drug Maker’s Failed Deal
abstract: Pfizer looks foolish for the way it handled a $119 billion bid, yet it is AstraZeneca that remains under pressure, Christopher Hughes of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: The failure of Pfizer’s $119 billion bid for AstraZeneca leaves the frustrated buyer no worse off. But AstraZeneca has much to prove. Some of its shareholders welcomed a possible takeover – and could again.

headline: Simple Sour: Easy Summer Drinking
abstract: A beautifully balanced beer; after that, things get complex.
lead_paragraph: Almost by accident I discovered a perfect summer beer, light and refreshing yet packed with tangy flavor. Nursing a thirst on one of the first hot days of the season, I had stepped into the Pony Bar, which always has a great selection of American craft beers on tap at its two Manhattan locations. Examining the list, I was intrigued by Peekskill Brewery’s Simple Sour.

headline: Once Allies, Ex-Obama Aides Face Off in British Campaign
abstract: Jim Messina, who managed President Obama’s re-election campaign, has crossed an ideological divide to do the same for Prime Minister David Cameron.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — David Axelrod stood on a stage in the Buckingham Room of the Labour Party headquarters this month, rallying British progressives who are hoping, and paying, for Barack Obama’s message maven to help lead them back into power.

headline: Hacker Who Helped Disrupt Cyberattacks Is Allowed to Walk Free
abstract: Hector Xavier Monsegur, who prosecutors said helped the F.B.I. take down an aggressive group of hackers, was given a greatly reduced sentence of time served.
lead_paragraph: The New York man whose cooperation helped the authorities infiltrate the shadowy world of computer hacking and disrupt at least 300 cyberattacks on targets that included the United States military, courts and private companies was given a greatly reduced sentence on Tuesday of time served and allowed to walk free.

headline: Q. and A. | Fujiko Nakaya on Making Sculptures Out of Fog
abstract: The 82-year-old Japanese artist, who created the ephemeral installation currently on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., talks about her preferred material and the relationship between art and nature.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 40 years, the Japanese artist Fujiko Nakaya has been installing sculptures made of fog throughout the world—in fields and forests, in public plazas and atop parking garages, even in a park designed for kids. A new fog sculpture called “Veil” is on view at the Glass House in New Canaan, Conn., through Nov. 30. To create it, the 82-year-old artist spent nearly a year testing wind patterns and carefully calibrating the 800 mist-generating nozzles that are now installed across the landscape. The temporary sculpture alternately envelops and reveals Philip Johnson’s iconic modernist structure, creating an effect that is at once romantic and contemporary.

headline: So Many Pharmacies, Too Few Doctors

lead_paragraph: Most schools have a soccer field. Khin Nilar Myint’s school has a pharmacy.

headline: Luggage Brand Unpacks New Theme and Ads
abstract: Briggs & Riley stresses its durability in the new campaign.
lead_paragraph: A line of high-end luggage is introducing a campaign that seeks to burnish its brand image by promoting its products as designed for travel in a real world of harried travelers, packed airplanes and fierce scrums for space in overhead bins.

headline: Court Extends Curbs on the Death Penalty in a Florida Ruling
abstract: The Supreme Court said the state was being too rigid when it said anyone with an I.Q. of 71 or over is not eligible to be spared the death penalty on account of intellectual disabilities.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court on Tuesday continued a trend to limit capital punishment, ruling that Florida’s I.Q. score cutoff was too rigid to decide which mentally disabled individuals must be spared the death penalty.

headline: Massimo Vignelli, Visionary Designer Who Untangled the Subway, Dies at 83
abstract: A self-styled “information architect,” Mr. Vignelli gave Modernist shape to book covers, shopping bags, furniture, corporate logos and, famously, a subway map.
lead_paragraph: Massimo Vignelli, an acclaimed graphic designer who gave shape to his spare, Modernist vision in book covers and shopping bags, furniture and corporate logos, even a church and a New York City subway map that enchanted aesthetes and baffled straphangers, died on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 83.

headline: At London's Heathrow, a New Terminal and an Uncertain Future

lead_paragraph: With the arrival of United Airlines flight 958 from Chicago, scheduled at 5:55 a.m. on June 4, Heathrow Airport will inaugurate a consumer-conscious Terminal 2, replacing another of its ramshackle hubs and giving the Star Alliance a modern, unified London presence that can compare with the home team’s Terminal 5, devoted to British Airways. That is, unless UA918, taking off from Washington, D.C., gets better tailwinds and lands first.

headline: Egypt Scrambles to Raise Turnout in Presidential Vote
abstract: Fearing damage to the rule of Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, the government took the extraordinary step of extending the voting by an additional day.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — After Egypt’s revolution three years ago, so many voters eager for democracy turned out for elections that officials had to scramble to accommodate the throngs.

headline: S.E.C. Vows More Use of a Little-Used Tool
abstract: Mary Jo White said that the agency would make greater use of a federal law that allows it to pursue people who use others to engage in illegal conduct, writes Peter J. Henning in the White Collar Watch column.
lead_paragraph: It is rare that the Securities and Exchange Commission announces a new approach to pursuing violations. Mary Jo White, the agency’s chairwoman, did just that last week when she pointed to a seldom-used provision of the federal securities laws that the S.E.C. will employ against people who use others to do their bidding.

headline: New Curbs Sought on the Personal Data Industry

abstract: The Federal Trade Commission said consumers should have access to information collected about them, along with the ability to suppress information.
lead_paragraph: The Federal Trade Commission on Tuesday called on Congress to protect consumers against the unchecked collection and sharing of their digital data — from websites visited to their marital status — by providing people with tools to view, suppress and fix their information.

But this season the Los Angeles Kings have turned the tables to take a three-games-to-one lead on the Blackhawks, who eliminated them in five games last season.

lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Sitting on his sofa in the Venice section of this city, Matt Geller let out an exasperated sigh as he spoke to a familiar official from the county health department. Food trucks represented by Mr. Geller’s group, the Southern California Mobile Food Vendors Association, had been caught dumping waste water down storm drains. “That’s absolutely disgusting,” he said. “A state, federal and county violation.”

abstract: Jurgen Klinsmann will take the United States national team out for a test drive on Tuesday night with a game against Azerbaijan in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. The Times is counting down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Art and Fashion Stars Toast a Pharrell-Curated Exhibition in Paris
abstract: The ubiquitous multihyphenate kicked off his “G I R L” show at Emmanuel Perrotin’s new space with a party and not-so-secret performance.
lead_paragraph: WhoPharrell Williams was in Paris last night to fete the exhibition he curated at the new Emmanuel Perrotin space there: “G I R L,” inspired by Williams’s new album of the same name. The multitasking man of the moment referred to the process of putting the exhibition together as “another day of school for Pharrell Williams.” The artists Daniel Arsham, Sophie Calle, Marina Abramovic, JR, Mr. and Laurent Grasso, who contributed works to the show, were on hand, as were the fashion-world luminaries Haider Ackermann, Peter Lindbergh, Alber Elbaz and Vanessa Bruno. The Korean superstar rapper G-Dragon arrived with his entourage, including the stylist Xin Yang, who will be launching his own line of too-cool-for-school men’s wear in Paris next year.

headline: The Bad Father, and Other Childhood Memories
abstract: In the third book in his six-volume autobiographical series, Karl Ove Knausgaard focuses on growing up with a father who terrified him.
lead_paragraph: Karl Ove Knausgaard, the powerful Norwegian novelist, is a weeper. Life gets to him. He cries all over the place in the first three volumes of his six-part autobiographical novel, “My Struggle,” especially in Books One and Three. His emotions are right on the surface.

headline: Stepan Returns to Lineup And Has Immediate Effect
abstract: The status of the Rangers’ Derek Stepan, whose jaw was broken on a late hit in Game 3 and who missed Game 4, remained a game-time decision for Game 5 against the Canadiens on Tuesday night.
lead_paragraph: MONTREAL — Derek Stepan, wearing a full plexiglass face shield to protect his broken jaw, returned to practice with the Rangers on Tuesday morning at Bell Centre before Game 5 of the N.H.L.’s Eastern Conference finals. Stepan then returned to the ice after the team’s medical staff gave him the go-ahead to play in the game.

headline: Unit Testing With Block Captures
abstract: We recently added read-only comments to our iPhone and iPad apps. We have been striving to add as much test coverage as we can to these pods, and the comments pod was no exception. We’ve detailed the approach we took while writing tests for the comments pod.
lead_paragraph: We recently added read-only comments to our iPhone and iPad apps. We have started writing features that can be shared across our apps as CocoaPods, and the comments feature was an excellent candidate for a pod. Going forward, all of our iOS apps will be able to use this feature. We have been striving to add as much test coverage as we can to these pods, and the comments pod was no exception.

headline: Kinsley, Greenwald and Government Secrets
abstract: A book review kicks up a storm about the role of the press in a democracy.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 9:22 p.m. Michael Kinsley’s review of Glenn Greenwald’s new book, “No Place to Hide” hasn’t even appeared in the printed Book Review yet – that won’t happen until June 8 – but it’s already infuriated a lot of people. After the review was published online last week, many commenters and readers (and Mr. Greenwald himself) attacked the review, which was not only negative about the book but also expressed a belief that many journalists find appalling: that news organizations should simply defer to the government when it comes to deciding what the public has a right to know about its secret activities.

headline: Donmar Warehouse to Present All-Female ‘Henry IV’
abstract: Harriet Walter will play the title role in the second installment of a trilogy of productions set in a women’s prison.
lead_paragraph: London’s Donmar Warehouse, which attracted considerable attention with its all-female staging of Shakespeare’s “Julius Caesar” set in a high-security prison, will take a similar approach with “Henry IV,” the theater announced on Tuesday.

headline: Now You See It, Then You Don’t
abstract: When perturbed, Hippopodius hippopus will blanche milky white to make its presence known. It can take a half hour for all of the color to drain from the creature’s skin.
lead_paragraph: When perturbed, Hippopodius hippopus will blanche milky white to make its presence known. It can take a half hour for all of the color to drain from the creature’s skin.

headline: A Breath of Fresh Air From the I.M.F.
abstract: In a speech, the head of the I.M.F. dared to chastise certain banks for violating “basic ethical norms.”
lead_paragraph: Some lawmakers in Washington have been exhibiting symptoms of amnesia when it comes to the causes of the financial crisis, as David Firestone wrote last week in Taking Note. Thankfully, another senior Washington-based policy maker – the managing director of the International Monetary Fund — has not forgotten what caused the crisis and why we are still a long way from making sure it doesn’t happen again.

headline: A Designer’s Legacy
abstract: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.
lead_paragraph: Massimo Vignelli, who died Tuesday in Manhattan, created a distinctive, Modernist aesthetic.

headline: Ukraine Faces Hurdles in Restoring Its Farming Legacy
abstract: Once the breadbasket of the Soviet Union, the country is looking to agricultural production to help fix its economy and reduce its dependence on Russia.
lead_paragraph: ZIBOLKY, Ukraine — Like many of her neighbors in this old Soviet collective farm, Maria Onysko prefers to be paid in grain instead of cash for the modest plot of land she rents out.

headline: Detroit Urged to Tear Down 40,000 Buildings
abstract: A task force recommended that the bankrupt city spend nearly $2 billion to stem the spread of blight.
lead_paragraph: DETROIT — A task force convened by the Obama administration issued the most detailed study yet of blight in Detroit on Tuesday and recommended that the city spend at least $850 million to quickly tear down about 40,000 dilapidated buildings, demolish or restore tens of thousands more, and clear thousands of trash-packed lots.

headline: Chilling Images of Gunman at Brussels Jewish Museum
abstract: As investigators released images of the gunman who carried out a deadly attack on Saturday at the Jewish Museum, Israeli commentators speculated about his motives.
lead_paragraph: The gunman who killed at least three people at the Jewish Museum in Brussels on Saturday has yet to be identified, but investigators have released images of the attacker, captured on security cameras before, during and after the shooting.

headline: A Man Is Missing, and the Toll Is Ever-Present
abstract: In “Gebo and the Shadow,” a family struggles with a relative’s long disappearance.
lead_paragraph: The family in “Gebo and the Shadow,” Manoel de Oliveira’s 2012 film adaptation of a play by the early-20th-century Portuguese writer Raul Brandão, has been stuck in a limbo of anguish and tedium. A young man named João (Ricardo Trêpa) has been missing for eight years, and every evening his father, Gebo (Michael Lonsdale), loses himself in ledgers and business documents. João’s mother (Claudia Cardinale) and wife (Leonor Silveira) bring Gebo coffee and pester him for news of the prodigal. João’s fate is ambiguous, which makes the grief and anxiety of his wife and mother all the more acute, and his father’s evasiveness all the more troubling.

headline: When Assessing Investment Advice, Consider the Source
abstract: Don’t make the mistake of evaluating all guidance equally.
lead_paragraph: It can be very difficult to separate the good advice from the questionable and the questionable from the downright irresponsible. Unfortunately, good advice doesn’t always walk around wearing a sign, but there are some red flags to help you avoid the so-called advice that’s actually irresponsible.

headline: 70 Years After the Date, Still So Much to Recall
abstract: Two new documentaries, “D-Day’s Sunken Secrets” and “America’s Secret D-Day Disaster,” feature veterans recalling the invasion as well as a rehearsal operation staged by the military.
lead_paragraph: The 70th anniversary of D-Day isn’t until next week, but the commemorative programming has already begun. Two offerings in the next few days do a nice job of incorporating some of the few remaining veterans who took part and also remind us just how complex the invasion was.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The landmark 1899 post office tower on Pennsylvania Avenue — the second-tallest building in Washington — looked out of place in the Federal Triangle of neoclassical government buildings constructed mostly in the 1930s.

headline: The Insider | Kris Kim, Founder of the Online Boutique La Garçonne, on Her Offline Style
abstract: The founder of the beloved web store, which opened its first brick-and-mortar outpost in TriBeCa last weekend, shares a few of her favorite things.
lead_paragraph: Too often, online clothes shopping is a task — find your size, pick a color, point, click, buy — rather than a pleasure. One notable exception, however, is La Garçonne — the thinking woman’s e-tailer, whose spare design, offhandedly cool styling and mussed-haired, makeup-free models make its minimalist merchandise come alive.

headline: Holiday Weekend Gun Report: May 23-26, 2014

lead_paragraph: Fleet-fingered jewel thief, compulsive liar, one-woman race crusader, parasite, parent, performer: Doris Payne could be identified in many ways (in addition to her multiple aliases). But she has also clearly had the time of her life. “The Life & Crimes of Doris Payne,” a rough-edged, brief documentary about this octogenarian career criminal, sketches a peppy and beguiling portrait of a convict whose defiant streak of independence has a way of outshining her wrongdoing.

headline: Who Wants Free Love Anyway?

abstract: How online dating explains the truth about the digital economy.
lead_paragraph: When Misty Terrell turned 28, she happened to see an ad for a special deal on the dating site eHarmony­ and decided it was time to get serious about her love life. Terrell felt pretty optimistic. The site claims responsibility for 542 marriages a day through its “scientific approach” to finding soul mates: an exhaustive questionnaire, the trademarked “29 dimensions of compatibility” algorithm and its clinical labs where psychologists spend hours analyzing couple interactions. For this sort of comprehensive matchmaking, the company charges $60 a month, which is far more than most dating sites, but perhaps something of a bargain when it comes to finding true love. Terrell signed up to receive five potential matches a day for six months.

He died of an undiagnosed diabetic condition in Berlin in June 1964, at 36, old enough to consolidate his experience and wisdom but perhaps too young to settle his reputation, which had by then taken some knocks from those who found his music abstract or abrasive.

headline: For Middle East, Region of Religious Conflict, Pope Suggests a Respite in Prayer
abstract: Betting on breakthroughs, or even positive developments, is always perilous in the Middle East, but Francis exhibited a deft touch during his visit.
lead_paragraph: JERUSALEM — Pope Francis returned home from his three-day sojourn in the Holy Land with the typical bag of ceremonial gifts, including, from the children of Bethlehem’s refugee camps, a mock-up of an identification card in the name of Jesus that lists family members as Mohandas K. Gandhi, Nelson Mandela, Yasir Arafat and Martin Luther King Jr. But the pope also carried with him a promise from the Israeli and Palestinian presidents to come soon to the Vatican for a joint peace prayer, an unprecedented effort to lend a spiritual lift to a desperate political stalemate.

headline: The Value of College: It’s Not Just Correlation
abstract: A long line of academic research, comparing otherwise similar people, finds that those who graduate from college do better.
lead_paragraph: Comparing the earnings of college graduates and nongraduates is an imperfect way of measuring the value of a degree, as I noted in my Tuesday column. Hypothetically, college graduates could earn more because they’re innately smarter — and would have earned just as much if they had never attended college or even any school. As a reader named Shawn posted in the comments section of the column, “The useful comparison is not between those who do and do not attend college but, rather, between equally intelligent students who do and do not choose to attend college.”

headline: Libya: State Dept. Urges Americans to Leave
abstract: The State Department cited the fighting among militias in urging Americans against traveling to Libya and asking those already there to leave.
lead_paragraph: The State Department issued a travel warning on Tuesday urging Americans against traveling to Libya and asking those already there to leave. The department cited the continuing fighting among militias, including an attack on the Parliament building 10 days ago; the Tripoli government’s inability to stop the violence; and repeated threats against American interests. The United States Embassy, the State Department said, “is only able to offer very limited emergency services to U.S. citizens in Libya.”

headline: South Sudan: U.N. Shifts Focus of Its Mandate
abstract: The United Nations Security Council passed a resolution on Tuesday that shifts its peacekeeping operations in South Sudan toward safeguarding civilians.
lead_paragraph: The United Nations Security Council unanimously passed a resolution on Tuesday that shifts its peacekeeping operations in South Sudan away from nation-building and toward safeguarding civilians threatened by ethnic violence and political instability. The resolution, which extended the mission until Nov. 30, retains its size but authorizes “all necessary means” to protect civilians, to police rights abuses, to ensure aid delivery and to enforce cease-fires among rival factions in the country, which became independent in 2011. Thousands have been killed, and more than 1.3 million people have fled their homes since December, when fighting erupted between loyalists to President Salva Kiir, an ethnic Dinka, and his former vice president, Riek Machar, a Nuer. A recent United Nations report described atrocities “on a massive scale” by both sides. The United Nations refugee agency reported Tuesday that 76,000 South Sudanese had fled fighting since the latest cease-fire was signed on May 9.

headline: Sierra Leone: Ebola Virus Spreads From Guinea
abstract: One death in a village near the border with Guinea has been confirmed by a laboratory as Ebola, and four other deaths are considered suspect.
lead_paragraph: West Africa’s Ebola outbreak appears to have spread to Sierra Leone, the World Health Organization said Monday. One death in a village near the border with Guinea has been confirmed by a laboratory as Ebola, and four other deaths are considered suspect. Sierra Leone health officials told the Voice of America that the confirmed case was a woman who had just returned from the funeral of an Ebola victim in Guinea; the suspect cases included her relatives. The outbreak began in Guinea in March and spread to Liberia; of the 259 cases reported to the W.H.O., 175 have been fatal.

headline: Monsters, Updated
abstract: Two new picture books imagine alien landscapes inhabited by monstrous creatures.
lead_paragraph: Are today’s children really afraid of monsters? Movies like “Hotel Transylvania” and “Monsters, Inc.” and even shows like “Sesame Street” have made them more sweet than threatening, more funny than ferocious. My own kids, who’ve never mentioned being scared of anything supernatural, fear the same things I do: eels, sharks and home invasion. Try writing a picture book about that! But monsters are a literary commonplace, embodiments of whatever dark and unexpected things lurk in children’s imaginations. “Big Bad Bubble," by Adam Rubin with illustrations by Daniel Salmieri, and “Rules of Summer,” by Shaun Tan, imagine alien landscapes inhabited by monstrous creatures. Whether they strike a chord with — or terrify — children depends very much upon the child.

headline: A Return to Rural France, and to Childhood Memories
abstract: Decades after childhood trips to Nièvre, a province two hours south of Paris, the author reconnects with the French family who folded her into their household.
lead_paragraph: Last summer, for the first time in decades, I turned off a French country road into an allée of tall trees that led to an old brick farmhouse where I spent some of the most joyous moments of my childhood. The farm was in the province of Nièvre, two hours south of Paris, and the family that had lived there years ago had raised Charolais cattle. They had five children; but in the summer of 1979, when I was 12, and again in 1981, they folded me into their household as if I were an honorary sixth. The kids closest to my age, Virginie, Éric and Benoît, treated me like a sister, not like a tourist from Indiana, where I came from. Together we gathered eggs, rode on Mobylettes to the village candy store, set the table when the curé came to lunch, watched the French version of “The Avengers,” and squabbled over who got to ride shotgun on car trips.

headline: Rules of Style | Jenna Lyons on Modern-Day E-Card Etiquette
abstract: To mark a new collaboration between J. Crew and Paperless Post, the creative guru offers advice on the best approach to sending online stationery.
lead_paragraph: Since Jenna Lyons took the reins as creative director at J. Crew, the brand has launched a seemingly endless stream of covetable designer collaborations in clothing, accessories and beauty products. Now, the brand is bringing its casual-chic aesthetic to the realm of digital correspondence. In a project launched this week with Paperless Post, Lyons has overseen a line of electronic stationery that includes thank-you notes, invites and greetings. The overall tone of the language is one Lyons deems essential for any e-card: “humor and a touch of sarcasm.” A birthday card reads, “Happy… Whatever Age You Wish You Were”; another says, “Thinking of You… But Not in a Creepy Stalker Kind of Way.” The design is quintessentially J. Crew, too, with neon hues, bold prints and carefully chosen fonts that are as tasteful yet playful as the looks in the catalog.

headline: Style in Goma, the Democratic Republic of Congo
abstract: Recently, Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-proclaimed sapeur (the Congolese term for a dandy), was wearing a skirt made out of ties.

Recently, Kwame Lebon Ekumali Longange, a self-proclaimed sapeur (the Congolese term for a dandy), was wearing a skirt made out of ties. He said he rejects the idea that only Sundays are a day to dress up. This interview has been edited.

abstract: The Department of Veterans Affairs reported Wednesday that at least 1,700 veterans at a medical center in Phoenix were not registered on the proper waiting list, putting them at risk in the scheduling process.
lead_paragraph: In the first confirmation that Department of Veterans Affairs administrators manipulated medical waiting lists at one and possibly more hospitals, the department’s inspector general reported on Wednesday that 1,700 patients at the veterans medical center in Phoenix were not placed on the official waiting list for doctors’ appointments and may never have received care.

headline: The CerviScope in the Field
abstract: Kristina McCain, a gynecologist, has used the CerviScope to treat poor women in other countries, many of them former sex slaves. Her stories hint at how the product can be useful in the field.
lead_paragraph: You don’t often hear about cervical cancer killing women in the United States, where Pap smears are routine, but in the developing world, it is one of the most lethal cancers for women. While reporting my article that appeared in the May 25 magazine — about how David Walmer, a fertility specialist, created a device to help prevent cervical cancer despite knowing next to nothing about the disease — I spoke to a gynecologist named Kristina McCain. Her experience abroad using a field-test model of the CerviScope to treat poor women, many of them former sex slaves, hints at how the finished product can be useful.

headline: Antidepressant May Ease Hot Flashes of Menopause
abstract: Venlafaxine, or Effexor, was as effective as estrogen for the relief of the hot flashes and night sweats of menopause.
lead_paragraph: The hormone estrogen is the recommended treatment for menopausal night sweats and hot flashes, but some women are unable or unwilling to use it. Now a clinical trial suggests that the antidepressant venlafaxine, often used as an alternative, is equally effective.

headline: Valeant’s Latest Move Disappoints
abstract: In its pursuit of the maker of Botox, Valeant Pharmaceuticals has more work to do to reclaim the role of aggressor, writes Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews.
lead_paragraph: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International comes off oddly defensive in its latest advance on Allergan. A sweetened, $49 billion bid for Allergan, the Botox maker, disappointed investors in both companies. The use of a messy financial instrument probably didn’t help, especially after the target pushed back hard on the deal math and compared its suitor to Tyco. Valeant has more work to do to reclaim the role of aggressor.

headline: Andromeda and the Milky Way: A Merger of Galactic Proportions
keywords: ['Stars and Galaxies', 'Space and Astronomy', 'Milky Way Galaxy']
abstract: News of two stars in the Andromeda galaxy colliding turned out to be a false alarm, but we’re going to have an encounter ourselves with Andromeda one day.
lead_paragraph: The Andromeda nebula, which rarely feels the pull of the social media orbit, had a moment in the spotlight on Wednesday. Astronomers operating NASA’s Swift satellite spied what looked like a giant burst of radiation from Andromeda, the nearest big galaxy to our own Milky Way, about 2.5 million light-years from here. They tentatively diagnosed it as the collision of two neutron stars, the dense remnants of dead stars. Such collisions are among the most violent known conflagrations in the universe, but they rarely occur so close to our own neck of the cosmic woods.

headline: Classical Playlist: Bang on a Can All-Stars, Meredith Monk, Kojiro Umezaki and More
abstract: Times critics share what they’ve been listening to lately.
lead_paragraph: JULIA WOLFE: ‘Steel Hammer’Bang on a Can All-Stars; Trio Mediaeval(Cantaloupe)There’s grit in Julia Wolfe’s “Steel Hammer.” No, really. The blue-collar song cycle is scored for the versatile forces of the Bang on a Can All-Stars and the ethereally pure female voices of Trio Mediaeval, but a recurring sound is that of sand, pouring down the inside of wooden tubes. The result is a fiercely beautiful homage to manual labor, its endless repetitions and occasional moments of magical transformation. (Corinna da Fonseca-Wollheim)

headline: Health Officials Reverse Diagnosis of MERS in Illinois Man
abstract: Federal health officials said Wednesday that an Illinois man who met with an Indiana man who later fell ill with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome did not pick up the virus from him.
lead_paragraph: Reversing an earlier announcement, federal health officials said Wednesday that an Illinois man who met with an Indiana man who later fell ill with Middle East Respiratory Syndrome, or MERS, did not pick up the virus from him. Officials from the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said a first lung sample from the Illinois man had tested negative for the coronavirus that causes MERS, but two preliminary blood samples had then tested positive for antibodies to it. That led the C.D.C. to announce on May 17 that the man had been infected but had not fallen ill; this would have been the first transmission of the virus within the United States. On Wednesday, they said that a more sensitive blood test that takes at least five days to produce results showed that he never had the virus. The most likely explanation, one of the officials said, is that the preliminary test had cross-reacted with antibodies the man had to a previous coronavirus infection. At least six coronaviruses are known to infect humans: Four normally cause common cold symptoms, while the other two, MERS and SARS, are more serious. Only two MERS cases have been found in the United States — the Indiana man and another in Florida. Both had recently arrived after working in Saudi hospitals where there have been hundreds of cases since March. Thus far, C.D.C. officials said, extensive testing indicates that the two men did not pass on the virus to any family members or health care workers treating them.

According to the World Health Organization, 636 laboratory-confirmed cases of MERS have been reported, including 193 deaths. Most of the deaths have been in Saudi Arabia. Iran is the 20th country to report MERS.

(Starz Cinema) BEFORE MIDNIGHT (2013) Nine years after rekindling a romance (“Before Sunset”) in Paris that began nine years before that (“Before Sunrise”) in Vienna, Celine (Julie Delpy) and Jesse (Ethan Hawke, above with Ms. Delpy) are now in Greece, at the end of a summer vacation with their twin daughters (Jennifer and Charlotte Prior) and Hank (Seamus Davey-Fitzpatrick), the son he left behind in Chicago. Jesse wonders if they could move from Paris to the United States to spend more time with Hank. Celine sees his question as a demand to make it happen. O. Scott wrote in The New York Times of this trilogy from the director Richard Linklater. lead_paragraph: As Paris, the capital of wine-loving France, wraps up its beer week festival, London, more known for ales and pubs, is uncorking its first wine week.

headline: Elisabeth Moss in Talks to Star in ‘The Heidi Chronicles’ on Broadway
abstract: Producers aim to get Ms. Moss to play Heidi in a Broadway revival of Wendy Wasserstein play, which won a Tony and a Pulitzer Prize.
lead_paragraph: On Sunday’s finale of the 2014 episodes of “Mad Men,” the copy chief Peggy Olson was single (but making eyes at the repairman), childless (yet loving to the neighbor boy, Julio) and newly 30 (though only Don knew). Her concerns and conflicts called to mind the life choices of Heidi Holland, the brilliant, lonely art historian in “The Heidi Chronicles,” the beloved Wendy Wasserstein play that won the Pulitzer Prize and the Tony Award in 1989, with Joan Allen as Heidi. If a group of Broadway producers have their way, Peggy and Heidi will have something else in common: the actress Elisabeth Moss.

headline: In Our Pages: May 30
keywords: ['Cold War Era', 'Defense and Military Forces', 'Maritime Accidents and Safety']
abstract: Highlights from the International Herald Tribune archives: An ocean liner sinks in 1914; the Soviet Union photographs military installations in 1964.
lead_paragraph: 1914: Liner Empress of Ireland Sinks

headline: Rape Allegations in a Haryana Village Underscore a Social Fracas
abstract: Long-simmering tensions between low-caste residents of a village in North India and their upper-caste, largely landowning neighbors have boiled over after four girls said they were raped.
lead_paragraph: BHAGANA, India — On March 23, M., a 13-year-old girl in this Haryana village, said that she performed a nightly ritual with three of her friends.  She joined them outside their neighboring houses and walked to the middle of the harvest-ready wheat fields belonging to the majority Jat community, where the girls relieved themselves.

headline: Brad Pitt Punched at ‘Maleficent’ Premiere
abstract: Los Angeles police arrested a Ukrainian man after he struck Mr. Pitt in the face, they said.
lead_paragraph: Brad Pitt was signing autographs outside the El Capitan Theater in Hollywood on Wednesday evening, on his way to the premiere of “Maleficent,” which stars his partner, Angelina Jolie, when suddenly, for a few seconds, it seemed as if he were back in “Fight Club.” While Mr. Pitt was signing and Ms. Jolie was posing for photographs, someone jumped over a metal barrier and took a swing at Mr. Pitt, striking him in the face. The alleged assailant, whom the police identified as Vitalii Sediuk, 25, was led away in handcuffs. Gus Villanueva, a spokesman for the Los Angeles Police Department, told Reuters that he was being held in lieu of $20,000 bail.

headline: Sebastian Junger on His Companion Film to ‘Restrepo’
abstract: The writer talks about why he revisited footage shot with his friend, the photojournalist Tim Hetherington, who was later killed in Libya.

headline: Urban Renewal, No Bulldozer
keywords: ['ARCHITECTURE', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Restoration and Renovation', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Building (Construction)', 'Area Planning and Renewal', 'Social Media']
abstract: Businesses are planting themselves in existing buildings in San Francisco, while residents are getting little relief from the high housing costs, and new construction faces obstructions.
lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — It has gone widely unremarked, maybe because it’s so obvious to people here, that tech firms in San Francisco have not (yet) been moving into new buildings; they’ve been taking over old ones. Twitter has leased a onetime furniture mart on Market Street, and AirBnB has renovated a century-old industrial warehouse south of Market. Yelp occupies part of 140 New Montgomery downtown, the magnificent Art Deco former Pacific Telephone tower from the 1920s, lovingly revamped by Cathy Simon, an architect with Perkins & Will, and the developers Wilson Meany Sullivan.

headline: It Rocks When Girls Go Punk
abstract: Three Stockholm girls set out to make a name for themselves in the late punk period in “We Are the Best!,” from Lukas Moodysson.
lead_paragraph: There is hardly a shortage of movies about rock ’n’ roll, but there are few as perfect — which is to say as ragged, as silly, as touching or as true — as “We Are the Best!,” Lukas Moodysson’s sweet and rambunctious new film. The setting is Stockholm in 1982, hardly a legendary place or moment in the annals of modern music, but that’s kind of the point. Rock ’n’ roll glory is wherever you find it, and whatever you make of it.

headline: Thomas Piketty Responds to Criticism of His Data
abstract: The economist doesn’t give an inch on the methodology for his book on inequality.
lead_paragraph: Six days after The Financial Times launched an attack on the data behind Thomas Piketty’s much-debated tome on inequality, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Mr. Piketty has offered his first detailed response to the newspaper’s criticism.

headline: Delaying Vaccines May Increase Seizure Risk
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Medicine and Health', 'Seizures (Medical)', 'Vaccination and Immunization']
abstract: Some parents delay their children’s vaccinations because they believe that vaccination may decrease seizure risk. But a new study finds the opposite may be true.
lead_paragraph: Childhood vaccinations like those for measles–mumps–rubella carry a small risk of seizures. Some parents postpone their children’s vaccinations because they believe the delay decreases the risk. But a new study finds the opposite may be true.

headline: Laverne Cox: ‘Blending In Was Never an Option’
abstract: The actress on the burdens of representing the transgender community, both on-screen and off.
lead_paragraph: The actress talks to Eric Spitznagel about growing up in the South, the difficulties of writing a memoir and the fortuitous casting decision that landed her on "Orange Is the New Black."

headline: Today in Small Business: A Square Deal?
abstract: Helping brick-and-mortar stores go online. Gary Vaynerchuk explains how to sell anything. Chief executives share their favorite interview questions.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Whoever Gets the Tony, He Wins
abstract: The press agent Rick Miramontez is thick in the campaign for all four nominees for best musical in this year’s Tony Awards.
lead_paragraph: As campaign stunts go in this spring’s race for the Tony Award for best musical, Operation Liza went like clockwork.

headline: A Chicago Hotel Honors a Street Photographer
abstract: The Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel in Chicago is showcasing work by the street photographer Vivian Maier.
lead_paragraph: A street photographer who worked in obscurity from the mid-’50s until her death in 2009, Vivian Maier is now the subject of a theatrically released documentary, a BBC special and, most recently, the lobby of the Radisson Blu Aqua Hotel, Chicago.

headline: Director of ‘Happy in Tehran’ Video Is Reportedly Freed
abstract: The director of a YouTube remix that offended Iran’s judiciary was released on bail Thursday, a rights group said.
lead_paragraph: Sassan Soleimani, the director of “Happy in Tehran,” a viral YouTube tribute to Pharrell Williams that offended Iran’s conservative judiciary, was released on bail Thursday, according to the International Campaign for Human Rights in Iran, a New York-based advocacy group.

headline: Italy Seeks $1.6 Billion in Damages From Roche and Novartis
abstract: The government says the national health service suffered losses from the drug companies’ efforts to restrict competition in ophthalmic drugs.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — The Italian government is seeking $1.6 billion in damages from two of the world’s biggest drug companies — Novartis and Roche — for losses that it says the national health service incurred from the companies’ efforts to restrict competition in ophthalmic drugs.

headline: Fund Within a Fund Creates a Conflict
abstract: Blue Crest Capital Management, a $30 billion hedge fund in Guernsey, has a $1.5 billion internal hedge fund designed to attract top talent. Outside investors wonder whether they are missing out.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 3:00 p.m. |

headline: White House Stresses Widespread Energy Progress Ahead of New Climate Rule
keywords: ['Alternative and Renewable Energy', 'Carbon Dioxide', 'Coal', 'Energy and Power', 'Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Hydraulic Fracturing', 'Natural Gas', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Solar Energy', 'United States Economy', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Wind Power']
abstract: The White House hawks its energy policies ahead of a move to restrict carbon dioxide from power plants.
lead_paragraph: The White House has released a report charting progress on several energy fronts that is clearly aimed at setting the stage ahead of President Obama’s expected announcement next Monday of the first regulations restricting carbon dioxide from existing power plants. (It’s been a very long journey — abetted by an important Supreme Court decision — since President George W. Bush tried to restrict carbon dioxide from such plants and quickly reversed course.)

headline: House Panel Advances Bill on School Lunch Options
keywords: ['Lunch and Breakfast Programs', 'Obesity', 'Law and Legislation', 'Education (K-12)', 'United States Politics and Government', 'Diet and Nutrition']
abstract: A bill includes a provision for a waiver process for local school districts that found it too expensive to comply with the White House nutritional guidelines passed in 2012.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The House Appropriations Committee on Thursday passed an agriculture budget bill that included nearly $21 billion for child nutrition that would allow schools to opt out of White House nutritional guidelines passed in 2012. The vote was 31 to 18.

headline: A Special Tony Awards ‘In Performance’
abstract: Scott Heller, theater editor and deputy editor for Arts & Leisure, discusses this year’s Tony Awards-themed “In Performance” videos.
lead_paragraph: Scott Heller is the theater editor and deputy editor for Arts & Leisure at The New York Times.

headline: To Young Minds of Today, Harvard Is the Stanford of the East
keywords: ['Colleges and Universities', 'Engineering and Engineers', 'Science and Technology']
abstract: Riding a wave of interest in technology, Stanford University has risen to the top of measures that Harvard once dominated.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — In academia, where brand reputation is everything, one university holds an especially enviable place these days when it comes to attracting students and money. To find it from this center of learning, turn west and go about 2,700 miles.

headline: Listen Up | Roisin Murphy’s Electronic Covers of Italian Pop Standards
abstract: The unpredictable Irish artist — soon to release her first album in seven years — surprises fans in the meantime with a delightful EP of reinterpreted lost classics. T debuts a remix of one of the tracks.
lead_paragraph: “Now is the time for me to make a record only I could make,” says the inimitable Roisin Murphy. The 40-year-old singer is speaking in a charming Irish brogue over Skype, with birds singing in the background, about the full-length album of original material she plans to release later this year after a seven-year absence. But the comment could just as easily refer to her current project, “Mi Senti” — an EP of electronic covers of Italian pop standards made famous by ’60s and ’70s icons like Mina and Patti Pravo, plus one Italian-language original. A remix of a track from the release, “Ancora Ancora Ancora,” debuts here.

headline: Silicon Valley May Be in a Bubble, but It’s Not 2000
abstract: Mary Meeker, the renowned technology analyst, says technology valuations today are rational. Are they?
lead_paragraph: Mary Meeker says Silicon Valley is not in a bubble.

headline: Lawmakers’ Modest Proposal: To Pass Spending Bills on Time
abstract: Senator Barbara A. Mikulski of Maryland and Representative Harold Rogers of Kentucky are trying to deliver many, if not all, of the 12 appropriations bills for the 2015 fiscal year by Sept. 30.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The state of Congress is such that the performance of its most basic task — the orderly passage of annual spending bills that fund the government — has become this year a test of whether it can function at all.

headline: International Observers Find Egypt’s Presidential Election Fell Short of Standards
abstract: Two teams of foreign observers said the presidential election was marred by irregularities and a repressive political environment.
lead_paragraph: CAIRO — Egypt’s presidential election fell short of international standards of democracy, two teams of foreign observers said Thursday, a day after the former military officer who led last summer’s military takeover won a landslide victory with more than 95 percent of the vote.

headline: Turning Sturgeon Into High-Tech Sensors
abstract: Sturgeon in the Hudson River are being fitted with transmitters to see if noise from pile driving and construction on the new Tappan Zee Bridge is harming imperiled Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon.
lead_paragraph: Sturgeon in the Hudson River are being fitted with transmitters to see if noise from pile driving and construction on the new Tappan Zee Bridge is harming imperiled Atlantic and shortnose sturgeon.

lead_paragraph: On a charter flight from Toronto to New York for the Yankees’ home opener, on April 7, Derek Jeter called Danilo Valiente to the back of the plane.

headline: An Offer to Let the Mind Wander
abstract: Spicy Lanka, which opened in February in Jamaica, Queens, transports diners to a faraway land.
lead_paragraph: The shiny black table reflects blue sky, banana fronds and distant birds with eyelash wings. Outside, signs for mortgages and driving lessons loom over this tired stretch of Hillside Avenue in Jamaica, Queens. But inside Spicy Lanka, clouds drift, as does the mind.

headline: Scientists Report Finding Reliable Way to Teleport Data
abstract: It’s not “Star Trek,” but the physicists say they can send quantum information from one electron to another 10 feet away with perfect accuracy.
lead_paragraph: Scientists in the Netherlands have moved a step closer to overriding one of Albert Einstein’s most famous objections to the implications of quantum mechanics, which he described as “spooky action at a distance.”

headline: Rapes in India Fuel Charges of Conspiracy by a Caste
keywords: ['Women and Girls', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sex Crimes']
abstract: Two girls, cousins ages 15 and 14, were found dead, their bodies hanging from mango trees in Uttar Pradesh State.
lead_paragraph: NEW DELHI — The rape and murder of two teenage girls in an Indian village threatened to touch off wider strife on Thursday, when the father of one of the girls said the crime was the product of a conspiracy among Yadavs, members of the dominant caste in the area.

headline: As Liberal Leaders Test Cuomo, de Blasio Stands by Him
abstract: Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo, at a news conference with Mayor Bill de Blasio, stopped short of vowing to help turn the State Senate over to Democratic control.
lead_paragraph: They smiled at each other, trading gentle jokes and the political equivalent of sweet nothings. (“The mayor was exactly right.” “I give the governor a lot of credit.”) There was a high-five, and a manly half-hug.

lead_paragraph: TARRYTOWN, N.Y. — Call him the sturgeon surgeon.

headline: When Union Membership Was Rising
abstract: Not long after The Times reported an increase in the percentage of workers belonging to unions, the trend turned firmly in the other direction.
lead_paragraph: The Times has converted all of its 1964 issues into a digitized, searchable format. Each week, The Upshot will unearth an item from 50 years ago and put it in the light of today. “U.S. Finds Unions Gaining Members, Reversing Trend” appeared on May 25, 1964, and can be seen in its original format on TimesMachine.

headline: ‘Lionboy’ a Highlight of New Victory Theater Season
abstract: The theater will present seven American premieres from around the world.
lead_paragraph: As a house specializing in works for families and young audiences, the New Victory Theater may seem an unlikely place for Complicite, the British company known for shows that combine surreal imagery and psychological intensity. But the 2013 production of “Lionboy,” Marcelo Dos Santos’s adaptation of material from Zizou Corder’s “Lionboy” novels – Complicite’s first family production in its 31-year history – will be coming to the New Victory in January. “Lionboy,” a highlight of the New Victory’s 2014-15 season, will run from Jan. 23 to Feb. 1.

headline: North Korea Will Investigate Fate of Abducted Japanese
abstract: Japan, in return, said it would start lifting sanctions it had imposed on the North, which in 2002 admitted the abductions.
lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea has agreed to open a new investigation into the fate of Japanese citizens abducted by its agents during the Cold War, the two countries said Thursday, signaling a possible diplomatic breakthrough in an emotional issue that has divided Japan and the North.

headline: Surviving at the Poker Tables: Colson Whitehead Talks About ‘The Noble Hustle’
abstract: Mr. Whitehead’s new memoir is about his participation in the World Series of Poker.
lead_paragraph: Colson Whitehead’s new memoir, “The Noble Hustle: Poker, Beef Jerky and Death,” began as an assignment for the online magazine Grantland, which commissioned him to compete in and write about the World Series of Poker in Las Vegas. In the book, Mr. Whitehead writes about his anhedonic personality (“I have a good poker face because I am half dead inside,” it begins), his training with the help of a coach named Helen Ellis and his fate at the high-stakes tables. I recently spoke to Mr. Whitehead in a phone interview. Below are edited excerpts from the conversation.

headline: F.D.A. Announces Stricter Rules on Tanning Beds
abstract: The agency said that it would require manufacturers to put its sternest warning on the devices explicitly stating that they should not be used by anyone under the age of 18.
lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Thursday announced stricter regulation of tanning beds that are used by millions of Americans. The agency said that it would require manufacturers to put a black-box warning — one of its sternest — on the devices stating that they should not be used by anyone under the age of 18, but stopped short of banning their use by minors.

headline: French Will Host Putin at D-Day Rites
abstract: With 70th anniversary commemorations of D-Day as a backdrop, the meeting will constitute the French president’s most prominent diplomatic foray into the Ukrainian crisis since it began.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — President François Hollande of France will use D-Day commemorations next week as an opportunity to assume a more direct diplomatic role in the Ukraine crisis, becoming the first European leader to meet face to face with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia since the Western effort to isolate him for his annexation of Crimea.

abstract: So far this year, Ford has recalled more than 2.9 million vehicles in the United States, far surpassing last year’s 1.2 million vehicles. Other automakers are reporting higher recall numbers as well.
lead_paragraph: The growing number of recalls is spreading beyond General Motors.

headline: Danspace Project to Showcase a New Generation of Artists
abstract: Six surprising pairings, putting major ballet figures with a new generation of New York dance artists, form the cornerstone of Danspace Project’s Platform 2015.
lead_paragraph: Six surprising pairings, putting major ballet figures with a new generation of New York dance artists, form the cornerstone of Danspace Project’s Platform 2015, curated by the critic and poet Claudia La Rocco. Ms. La Rocco, who was a dance critic at The New York Times between 2005 and 2013, has named the platform after Edwin Denby’s seminal compilation of dance writings: “Dancers, Buildings and People in the Streets.” (Ms. La Rocco still contributes articles and reviews on theater for The Times.)

headline: Kevin Reilly, Head of Fox’s Programming, Is Stepping Down
abstract: Mr. Reilly is stepping down as head of entertainment programming after three consecutive years of steep declines in ratings for “American Idol,” a show crucial to the network’s profits.
lead_paragraph: The drastic falloff of “American Idol” has cost the Fox network dearly in terms of ratings and profits, and now it has contributed to the loss of its top entertainment executive, Kevin Reilly.

abstract: A day in the life of armed America.

lead_paragraph: Dr. Phyllis Hollenbeck, a primary care physician, took a job at the Veterans Affairs medical center in Jackson, Miss., in 2008 expecting fulfilling work and a lighter patient load than she had had in private practice.

abstract: Seven scupltors will take part in the Model to Monument program, which places sculpture in Riverside Park South on the Hudson River and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.
lead_paragraph: Seven sculptors from the Art Students League have been chosen to take part in this year’s edition of the Model to Monument program, a joint venture between the league and the Department of Parks and Recreation that places public sculpture in Riverside Park South on the Hudson River and Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx.

headline: Rules of Style | The Founders of Juicy Couture on How to Succeed in Business
abstract: Pamela Skaist-Levy and Gela Nash-Taylor share advice from their new business book, “The Glitter Plan.”
lead_paragraph: “Not only are we designing 1o collections a year now,” Pamela Skaist-Levy says, “but there’s a crazy big-player bidding war to turn our book into a TV show.” She’s referring to “The Glitter Plan,” out today. It’s the first memoir from the designer and her longtime business partner, Gela Nash-Taylor, the co-founders of Juicy Couture. Written in collaboration with the journalist Booth Moore, the book tells the story of two best friends who took a simple idea and turned it into one of the most successful fashion companies in history. “We didn’t go to Harvard Business School,” Nash-Taylor says. “Or any business school, for that matter. But we wanted to inspire and work off of an idea that came from a real passion to empower.”

headline: Moving Toward ‘Digital First': A Talk With the Day Editor
abstract: Karron Skog, the head of the news desk and home page during the day, discussed a recent memo announcing more emphasis on the digital report.
lead_paragraph: Pitching and evaluating news. Deciding when to release stories. Planning the front page and the home page. This is the stuff of two daily news meetings held at 10 a.m. and 4 p.m. by The Times’s masthead in the Page One conference room on the third floor.

headline: Measles Cases in U.S. Reach a 20-Year High
abstract: As of May 23, there were 288 confirmed cases so far this year, 85 percent of which were in people not vaccinated because of religious, philosophical or personal objections.
lead_paragraph: Largely because of resistance to vaccination, cases of measles have reached a 20-year high in the United States, federal health officials said on Thursday.

headline: New Appraisal of Detroit Institute Art Collection Is Underway
abstract: A bankruptcy team wants a more sweeping review of a museum’s collection.
lead_paragraph: Officials handling Detroit’s federal bankruptcy proceedings, who have been accused by creditors in recent months of underestimating the value of works held by the city-owned Detroit Institute of Arts, told a judge on Wednesday that a comprehensive appraisal of the value of the collection is now underway.

headline: Tiny Hot Rods Will Get Your Letters to Their Destination
abstract: The Postal Service is issuing the latest in a series of stamps aimed at auto enthusiasts.
lead_paragraph: Even as politicians debate ending Saturday mail delivery, the Postal Service is commemorating one of the enduring symbols of Saturday night youth rituals, the American hot rod, with a new stamp issue on June 6.

headline: Concussions and an N.F.L. Paradox
abstract: The N.F.L. is increasingly being forced to confront how to make football safer, essentially worrying the same audience that it is seeking to assure.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In 2009, Roger Goodell, the commissioner of the N.F.L., was skewered by lawmakers on Capitol Hill for denying the severity of concussions and failing to do more to help retired players with brain injuries.

headline: Navigating Medicare Policy on Physical Therapy and Other Services
abstract: An updated policy applies to therapy provided in nursing homes, in outpatient clinics and at home.
lead_paragraph: For years, some people on Medicare had difficulty getting insurance coverage approved for physical therapy, occupational therapy and other treatments. The prevailing approach was that if the therapy was not helping to improve a patient’s condition, then it was not eligible for coverage.

headline: So Potent, They Were Fated to Be Smashed
abstract: “Object of Devotion,” an exhibition of medieval English alabaster sculptures at the Museum of Biblical Art, prompts reflection on why so many objects of this kind were willfully destroyed.
lead_paragraph: A hotly debated issue among theologians in medieval Europe concerned what has since been called “the cult of images.” The controversy turned on beliefs about how people related to and used images of Christian subjects rendered by painters and sculptors. Proponents of images argued that they were educational and edifying. Iconoclasts feared that people would become enthralled by images and fall into the sin of idolatry.

headline: A Chef in Search of a New Food Chain
abstract: In “The Third Plate: Field Notes on the Future of Food,” the chef Dan Barber calls for a new organizing principle for cuisine that goes beyond “farm to table.”
lead_paragraph: Not long ago, Dan Barber, the chef and a co-owner of Blue Hill in Manhattan, and the animating force behind the Stone Barns Center for Food and Agriculture in Westchester County, came up with a dish he calls Rotation Risotto. It’s a manifesto on a plate, a tricky play on the Italian classic that uses, instead of rice, a medley of lesser-known grains: rye, barley, buckwheat and millet.

headline: Friendship Was Their Medium
abstract: “Degas/Cassatt,” at the National Gallery of Art in Washington, looks anew at a relationship between two painters.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The friendship between Mary Cassatt and Edgar Degas is one of the few remaining mysteries of Impressionism. She was a wealthy, independent American suffragist who painted upper-class women tending children and taking in the opera; he was a Frenchman, a decade older, who spied on nudes in brothels and once said that women couldn’t understand style.

headline: Your Evening Briefing
abstract: Your nightly briefing is ready for you.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to NYT Now, the new app from The New York Times. (Download us for iPhone.)

headline: His Airness
abstract: A biography of the man widely considered to be the greatest basketball player who ever lived.
lead_paragraph: Michael Jordan is the greatest basketball player who ever lived. Of that, there is very little dispute. He was also, at the apex of his career, a global ambassador for the game and for Nike (not necessarily in that order), a veritable A.T.M. for various corporate partners, a hero to millions, if not billions, of fans, and very likely the most famous person in the world. I know this because everyone knows it, and also because I witnessed at least a little bit of it all. I covered Jordan and the Bulls for an all-sports radio station in Chicago for four years while he was at the height of his power and fame.

headline: Ex-Canadien Welcomes Chance to Play
abstract: The Rangers’ Raphael Diaz played for the first time in the conference finals against Montreal, his former team, after John Moore was suspended for two games.
lead_paragraph: Rangers defenseman Raphael Diaz was all smiles hours before Game 6 on Thursday at Madison Square Garden, thanks to a chance to re-enter the playoff fray and deny his former team, the Montreal Canadiens, a trip to the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: 65-Story Tower Planned Near Grand Central Terminal
keywords: ['Buildings (Structures)', 'Grand Central Terminal (NYC)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Relocation of Business', 'Area Planning and Renewal']
abstract: The skyscraper, to be TD Bank’s corporate home, would be taller than the landmark Chrysler Building, under a proposal being negotiated by the de Blasio administration.
lead_paragraph: A developer plans to build a 65-story tower directly west of Grand Central Terminal in Midtown Manhattan that would soar 1,200 feet above 42nd Street, 150 feet taller than the landmark Chrysler Building, under a proposal by the de Blasio administration.

headline: Gardening
abstract: The season’s reading for gardeners includes a bumper crop of excellent reference books.
lead_paragraph: It may be that, like the feckless Candide, we should quit tormenting ourselves about the terrible things over which we have no control — and just cultivate our gardens. Except we have very little control over what’s happening there either. Plants inexplicably wilt, rot and shrivel; they suffer the depredations visited upon them by voles, moles and deer. And then there’s global warming, giving booster shots to the poison ivy and generally wreaking havoc with droughts, downpours, blue northers and scalding heat waves.

headline: Diffa Marks 3 Decades of Designers Fighting AIDS
abstract: At its latest fund-raiser, a panel including Ruben and Isabel Toledo and Terrence McNally spoke of how the disease had affected their industries in the early, terrifying years.
lead_paragraph: The charity known as the Design Industries Foundation Fighting AIDS, or Diffa, turned 30 in April.

headline: Our Shakespeare
abstract: The Library of America chronicles the history of American responses to Shakespeare from 1776 to the present day.
lead_paragraph: Who is the American Shakespeare? The question has an odd, anxious quality that it wouldn’t quite have if applied to Germany, say, or Russia. It’s not just that in those cases, there is an answer ready at hand (Goethe, Pushkin), but that in the international context we know what the question means. Who is the founding poet to whom all subsequent writers must relate? Who established the parameters of the language within or against which all subsequent writers labor? Understood that way, the answer to the question for America isn’t an American at all: It’s ­William Shakespeare himself.

headline: A Sister in the Shadow of Georgia O’Keeffe
abstract: A curator is seeking information about Ida O’Keeffe, a painter and younger sister of Georgia O’Keeffe, for the exhibition about the sister in the shadows planned for the Dallas Museum of Art.
lead_paragraph: Georgia O’Keeffe was disappointed in her painter sister Ida O’Keeffe. “A wasted life,” she told the family when Ida died in 1961, at 71. The Dallas Museum of Art will tell Ida’s side of the story with an exhibition scheduled for 2017, “Ida O’Keeffe: Escaping Georgia’s Shadow.”

headline: Ghana Seeks More Than Just Another Cup Win Over U.S.
abstract: Because Ghana eliminated the Americans from the past two World Cups, its fans expect it to win again in their Cup opener, but Coach Kwesi Appiah is after much more.
lead_paragraph: ACCRA, Ghana — The questions poured out of the official from the United States Embassy at the mere mention of a visit to Ghana’s World Cup training camp.

headline: Illusion
abstract: Steven Galloway’s novel is about a man who believes he killed Houdini.
lead_paragraph: Magic, as Martin Strauss, the narrator of Steven Galloway’s novel “The Confabulist,” tells it, has four elements: An effect, which is one element, is achieved by way of the magician’s method, which is another; method is hidden in misdirection, and a reconstruction is attempted afterward, by the audience. “A magician seeks to choreograph a way through the trick with these component parts,” Strauss explains. “If he does so he will have achieved magic. If not, he is a failure.”

headline: Lenders Easing Up on Jumbo Mortgages
abstract: Lenders are becoming more accommodating on nonconforming, or jumbo, loans.
lead_paragraph: Underwriting guidelines remain rigid on the conforming loans guaranteed by Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, but lenders are becoming more accommodating on nonconforming, or jumbo, loans.

headline: A Stonehenge for the Modern Age
abstract: “Carl Andre: Sculpture as Place,” a retrospective at Dia:Beacon, presents a half-century’s worth of his protean Minimalist works, which helped redefine the sculpture genre.
lead_paragraph: BEACON. N.Y. — Minimalism was the late 20th century’s great hope for a heroic American art on the Abstract Expressionism model. Even after an upstart movement, Conceptualism — “idea art” — wafted in and blew old notions of “heroic” and “art” to bits, tradition-minded art lovers stayed loyal, and still do, to the Minimalist paradigm of greatness: abstract work that’s commanding in scale, cleanly made and destined for expensive rooms.

headline: An Art Weekend in Bushwick
abstract: With this weekend’s Bushwick Open Studios, New York’s most artist-centric neighborhood is opening its doors to the masses. Here, the galleries and group shows not to miss.
lead_paragraph: Bushwick Open Studios, a free art event organized by a group of local volunteers, will run from tomorrow until Sunday in the Brooklyn neighborhood that’s been lauded (and in some cases, decried) as the next coolest thing. What began as a midsize festival in 2006 with 85 studios has become an enormous, hectic jumble with more than 600 participants. For the duration of the weekend, galleries, studios, warehouses, basements, parking lots and other locales will be open to the public daily, with artists (such as Samantha French, whose work is pictured above) milling around to discuss their works. There will also be music, panel discussions and local food. Even with an online directory, an app and printed maps that can be found at one of B.O.S.’s nine hubs, it’s an overwhelming amount of art to take in, so here is a shortlist of galleries and group shows not to be missed.

headline: Following the Smoke Trail
keywords: ['Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Marijuana', 'Asthma', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Noise']
abstract: Subjects include locating the source of marijuana smoke; raising rent ethically; and dealing with annoying building sounds.
lead_paragraph: Ask Real Estate is a weekly online column that answers questions from across the New York region. Submit yours to realestateqa@nytimes.com.

abstract: A selective tasting expedition with Michael Ruhlman, author of “Egg: A Culinary Exploration of the World’s Most Versatile Ingredient.”
lead_paragraph: I never stopped eating eggs.

headline: Bulletproof Jacket On
abstract: A bail bondsman in Brooklyn becomes a bounty hunter to search for missing clients.
lead_paragraph: A bail bondsman in Brooklyn becomes a bounty hunter to search for missing clients.

headline: To Get an A in Philanthropy Class, Give Away $50,000
abstract: Some colleges are offering a real-world experience of philanthropy by requiring students to investigate nonprofit organizations and give them a portion of grant money.
lead_paragraph: EVANSTON, Ill. — Vinay Sridharan must make it through microeconomic theory and the writings of Proust before the end of his senior year at Northwestern in June. But in one course, the final project is far less abstract: give away $50,000.

headline: 85 Degrees, 100 Percent Free
abstract: Summer may not be endless, but the number of free offerings in New York City almost seems to be.
lead_paragraph: Summer sure sneaked up on the Miser, who was looking forward to a nice long public whine about the brutality of the winter just past. But here we are, a couple of days from June, and there’s no time for looking back. Not with months of fun FREE events on the way. Herewith, a summer Miser’s guide to New York City.

headline: Wanted: Backup for Iron Man and Captain America
abstract: Prospective agents can sign up for training at “Marvel’s Avengers S.T.A.T.I.O.N.,” a scientific training center at Discovery Times Square.
lead_paragraph: IT has been two years since the Avengers stopped alien forces in New York, preventing the Chitauri army from invading the planet. Now, they need backup to defend against the next attack. This is your opportunity to join the elite support network of S.H.I.E.L.D. agents that helps superheroes like Captain America, Iron Man and Thor protect Earth.

lead_paragraph: A scene from “Maleficent,” featuring Angelina Jolie.

headline: Working to Upend His Own Identity
abstract: John Jasperse, who has been choreographing in New York for almost 30 years, ventures to deflect his own voice in “Within between,” at New York Live Arts.
lead_paragraph: For a young artist, finding “your voice” is the ultimate quest. By the time midcareer rolls around — should the artist make it so far — that voice, long established, risks calcifying into something more like habit, what once seemed novel now overused, tired from repeated exertion.

headline: WilmerHale Partner Named as S.E.C. Deputy Enforcement Director
abstract: Stephanie Avakian, a 44-year-old partner in the New York office of WilmerHale, will become the agency’s deputy director of enforcement.
lead_paragraph: The Securities and Exchange Commission filled a hole in its enforcement roster on Thursday, naming a senior white-collar lawyer to the enforcement division’s No. 2 spot.

headline: Artifacts With a Life All Their Own
abstract: From a calling card left by John Wilkes Booth to a soccer jersey signed by Iraq’s national team, some objects at four different museum exhibitions in Washington bear the weight of history.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — What magic do museum artifacts wield? What gives these objects, documents, books, recordings and images such power? They aren’t artworks but are often encased in humidity-controlled vitrines. They aren’t amusements but are often offered up for visitors’ pleasures. They can be haunting, mysterious, resonant, provocative.

headline: Dumped by Her Prince, So Watch Out
abstract: As the title character in “Maleficent,” Angelina Jolie is the focus of a rethinking of the 1959 Disney animated film “Sleeping Beauty.”
lead_paragraph: Angelina Jolie makes a fabulous monster. As the title character in “Maleficent” — a divertingly different rethink of an awfully old story — she breezes through the movie, part superstar, part superfreak.

headline: Letters: American Punishment
abstract: Readers respond to recent reviews of Robert A. Ferguson’s “Inferno,” Fred Kaplan’s “John Quincy Adams” and more.
lead_paragraph: American Punishment

headline: Inner Child’s ‘Cuss Words’ and Zany Sondheim
abstract: Katie Finneran’s show, “It Might Be You — A Funny Lady’s Search for Home,” puts the focus on her inner child, a comedy voice just below the surface, clamoring to be heard.
lead_paragraph: Katie Finneran has that look in her eye. You know, the one in which a slightly crazed glint of mischief announces a personality that just can’t help injecting a zany sense of the absurd into the most unlikely situations. “I have a fast brain,” she announced at Wednesday’s opening-night performance of her cabaret show “It Might Be You — A Funny Lady’s Search for Home,” at 54 Below.

headline: Of Missed Connections and Missteps Taken
abstract: “One With Others,” a dance-theater piece by Karen Sherman, focuses on missteps, shaky relationships and the need for community among artists.
lead_paragraph: The Chocolate Factory’s white-walled performance space looks as if a bunch of drunken carpenters had competed in building eccentric structures with scrap lumber, wires and light bulbs. This setting reinforces the ideas that drive Karen Sherman’s “One With Others,” a dance-theater piece that opened Wednesday night about missed connections, inappropriate strategies, shaky relationships and the need for community among artists.
