abstract: Anxiety and an odd imitation derail a couple’s experiment with role-playing and fantasy.
lead_paragraph: UPDATED: You can now hear this essay read by the actress Kimberly Hébert Gregory in Modern Love: The Podcast. Look for the “play” button below or subscribe on iTunes or Google Play Music.

headline: Poe’s Lost Lenore Lives in Song and Dance
abstract: “The Raven” opens the NY Phil Biennial with the singer Fredrika Brillembourg and the dancer Alessandra Ferri.
lead_paragraph: Last year, in announcing the inaugural NY Phil Biennial — an 11-day festival of contemporary music with 21 performances of 13 programs — Alan Gilbert, the music director of the New York Philharmonic, unabashedly invited comparisons with similar events in the visual arts. Not just the Whitney Biennial in New York, which focuses on American artists, but also the Venice Biennale, perhaps the world’s most prestigious showcase of international contemporary art.

headline: If the Size Fits
abstract: Addressing matters of fashionable aging, friends with slurs, spoiled party plans and enlistment blues.
lead_paragraph: I am a man of a certain age. (Let’s just say I remember World War II.) I have a closet full of suits and ties when the occasion calls for them. But my true tastes run to the tightest, skinniest jeans I can find, fine wool sweaters, flip-flops or boots, and long colorful scarves. I am in pretty good shape for an old guy and like to think I look good packaged this way. But friends have criticized me for not dressing my age. Is there a cutoff at which men should burn their skinny jeans and opt for pleated khakis?

headline: A Producer and His Pulsating, Rhythmic Ways
abstract: Hudson Mohawke, an electronic music producer with ties to Kanye West, displayed his brand of remixes and original work during a set at Webster Hall.
lead_paragraph: The event on Wednesday night at Webster Hall was billed Hudson Mohawke & Friends, and certainly, this Scottish producer who meshes thunderous dance music with tense hip-hop has plenty. Most notable: Kanye West, whom he worked with last year on Mr. West’s corrosive, rumbling, outstanding album “Yeezus” (Roc-A-Fella/Def Jam). But also plenty of others: He is a frequent remixer and collaborator, spreading his monster-truck sound widely.

headline: Church-State Clash in China Coalesces Around a Toppled Spire
abstract: In ordering a church in Wenzhou torn down, Chinese officials said it violated zoning regulations, but an internal document describes a strategy to reduce Christianity’s public profile.
lead_paragraph: WENZHOU, China — For nearly a year, the Sanjiang Church was the pride of this city’s growing Christian population. A landmark in the fast-developing northern suburbs, its 180-foot spire rose dramatically against a rocky promontory. Wenzhou, called “China’s Jerusalem” for the churches dotting the cityscape, was known for its relaxed ties between church and state, and local officials lauded the church as a model project.

headline: Experimental Interludes
abstract: The Flux Quartet shared a sample of the broad spectrum of its repertoire during its residency at the Stone. On Wednesday night the program revolved around the viola and piano.
lead_paragraph: In 12 concerts during a six-day residency at the Stone, the intimate East Village space for experimental and avant-garde music, the Flux Quartet is presenting a range of pieces, including electroacoustic works, scores by drone pioneers and jazz. At the 10 p.m. show on Wednesday, Max Mandel, the Flux’s violist, was joined by the pianist Eric Huebner for a one-hour program featuring five works that spanned an array of moods and textures.

headline: Land, Ho! A Cerebral Blackbeard
abstract: “Crossbones,” an NBC adventure series, features John Malkovich as Blackbeard, a fearsome/eccentric/possibly psychopathic character.
lead_paragraph: In “Crossbones,” an adventure series that NBC rolls out on Friday night, John Malkovich makes his delightful Blackbeard considerably more cerebral than pirates generally are. And “cerebral” takes on a hilarious new connotation in one scene in the premiere: Blackbeard turns up with a porcupine’s worth of needles sticking out of his bald head, an effort to relieve headaches.

headline: A Very Difficult Crosstown Move
abstract: The journey in 1880 of Cleopatra’s Needle from the Hudson River at West 96th Street to Central Park was one of the sights of New York.
lead_paragraph: At 220 tons, Cleopatra’s Needle appears to be the heaviest piece of stone brought into Manhattan since the time of the glaciers. Its journey in 1880 from Alexandria to America was routine, but its progress from the Hudson River at West 96th Street to Central Park was one of the sights of New York.

Thousands of donated books, records and CDs can be scooped up for $1 each at a street fair, a fund-raiser for outreach programs run by Housing Works, on Sunday from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.

headline: Saving the Earth With a Big Kaboom
abstract: Kelly Reichardt’s “Night Moves” stars Jesse Eisenberg, Dakota Fanning and Peter Sarsgaard as young Oregonians plotting to blow up a dam.
lead_paragraph: Realism is too imprecise a term for Kelly Reichardt’s filmmaking. She is a more of a materialist, determined to capture how the world looks, how it feels and, at a granular level of detail, how it works. Her stories tend to be simple and starkly told. In “Old Joy,” two friends take a camping trip that tests their intimacy and raises painful, unspoken questions about their identities as 21st-century American men. In “Wendy and Lucy,” a young woman and her dog are stranded by car trouble en route to Alaska. In “Meek’s Cutoff,” settlers in mid-19th-century Oregon lose their way.

headline: This Week’s Movies | May 30, 2014
abstract: The New York Times film critics review “Maleficent,” “Night Moves” and “A Million Ways to Die in the West.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Times film critics review “Maleficent,” “Night Moves” and “A Million Ways to Die in the West.”

headline: Canadiens Defend Handling of Head Hit
abstract: The Canadiens’ Dale Weise was ruled out of Game 6 against the Rangers with “a body injury.” The Rangers’ John Moore was suspended for two games after an illegal check to Weise’s head.
lead_paragraph: Whether or not the Montreal Canadiens properly followed the N.H.L.’s concussion protocol in dealing with forward Dale Weise was at issue Thursday before Game 6 of the Eastern Conference finals. At times, the controversy over Weise, an important fourth-line forward, seemed to overshadow the elimination game itself.

headline: Storme DeLarverie, Early Leader in the Gay Rights Movement, Dies at 93
abstract: For decades, Ms. DeLarverie roamed Greenwich Village and areas nearby, looking for any form of intolerance as a self-appointed guardian of lesbians.
lead_paragraph: Storme DeLarverie, a singer, cross-dresser and bouncer who may or may not have thrown the first punch at the 1969 uprising at the Stonewall Inn in Greenwich Village, but who was indisputably one of the first and most assertive members of the modern gay rights movement, died on Saturday in Brooklyn. She was 93.

headline: De Blasio Children to Be Saluted at Coney Island Mermaid Parade
abstract: Dante and Chiara de Blasio, called “the perfect representation of the next generation of New Yorkers,” will be crowned King Neptune and Queen Mermaid at a summer kickoff.
lead_paragraph: New York City’s first family is officially becoming royalty.

headline: Employee’s Suit Accuses Tiffany of Racial Bias
abstract: A senior manager at Tiffany & Company has accused the jewelry retailer of having a “systemic, nationwide pattern and practice of racial discrimination.”
lead_paragraph: A group director for the jewelry retailer Tiffany & Company sued the company in federal court on Thursday, accusing his employer of a “systemic, nationwide pattern and practice of racial discrimination.”

headline: Quoting Victim’s Mother, Judge Sentences Killer to 24 Years to Life
abstract: Markeece Dunning did not dispute that he had killed Jomali Morales, who was found dead in 2011 in the elevator of a public-housing project on the Lower East Side.
lead_paragraph: Over three days of testimony, detectives and a medical examiner had spoken of the crime’s brutality, and a forensic psychiatrist had said that the admitted killer had a history of mental illness, and had stabbed the victim to death because he believed she was the Devil.

headline: With a Little Bit of Pluck, a Mandolin Orchestra Revives
abstract: New York City’s last traditional mandolin orchestra has a number of things going for it. But for the group to survive another 90 years, changes inside the orchestra will be required.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Tuesday evening, members of the New York Mandolin Orchestra crammed their music stands into a sitting room at the Atria Assisted Living Residence on the Upper West Side and played for an audience of two: an old man tapping his orthopedic shoes, and a woman in a wheelchair who appeared to be sleeping.

headline: For Palestine, a Final May Be Just the Start
abstract: The national team of Palestine faces the Philippines in the final of the Asian Football Confederation Challenge Cup in the Maldives on Friday.
lead_paragraph: As an ambitious college student in Memphis, Omar Jarun dreamed of one day playing for the United States in the World Cup. But Jarun, a 6-foot-4 central defender who plays for the Ottawa Fury in the North American Soccer League, never made it onto the roster, and he is not headed to the 2014 tournament in Brazil.

headline: Cutting Back on Carbon
keywords: ['Global Warming', 'Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'United States Economy', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry']
abstract: Saving the planet would be a lot cheaper than you’d think.
lead_paragraph: Next week the Environmental Protection Agency is expected to announce new rules designed to limit global warming. Although we don’t know the details yet, anti-environmental groups are already predicting vast costs and economic doom. Don’t believe them. Everything we know suggests that we can achieve large reductions in greenhouse gas emissions at little cost to the economy.

headline: Teaching an Old Law New Tricks
keywords: ['Greenhouse Gas Emissions', 'Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Energy Efficiency', 'Clean Air Act', 'Law and Legislation', 'Global Warming', 'Energy and Power']
abstract: On climate, Obama and the courts step in where Congress has failed.
lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — PRESIDENT OBAMA is expected to announce his much anticipated rule for power plants on Monday, requiring for the first time that older and dirtier plants reduce their carbon dioxide emissions, which account for a sizable share of the nation’s carbon pollution.

headline: Obama Calls for Concussion Awareness
abstract: The president, representatives of professional sports leagues and young athletes at a White House summit called for more robust research into youth concussions.
lead_paragraph: The president, representatives of professional sports leagues and young athletes at a White House summit called for more robust research into youth concussions.

headline: The Price of a Sex-Slave Rescue Fantasy
keywords: ['Human Trafficking', 'Prostitution', 'News and News Media', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations']
abstract: An anti-trafficking icon’s stories led to policies that harmed women.
lead_paragraph: WITH a sensational story of surviving child sex slavery in Cambodia, Somaly Mam became a worldwide icon, the best-selling author of a memoir and the head of a foundation raising millions in the name of saving girls and women from the sex trade, victims she recounted rescuing in dramatic brothel raids. Last year, introducing the State Department’s annual “Trafficking in Persons” report, Secretary of State John Kerry called Ms. Mam “a hero every single day.”

headline: After Crisis, a New Spirit of Reining In the Banks
keywords: ['Regulation and Deregulation of Industry', 'Banking and Financial Institutions', 'Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act (2010)', 'United States Politics and Government']
abstract: Many people believe there is not enough regulation of banks and they want tougher rules and more stringent enforcement of those rules.
lead_paragraph: It is widely believed that there has long been something that could be called a regulator-banker complex. People with similar views on the proper level of regulation move back and forth between the two groups. Their hats change, but not their policy preferences.

headline: Searching for Her Sister, as Well as for Herself
keywords: ['Movies', 'Documentary Films and Programs', 'ACTORS AND ACTRESSES', 'Suicides and Suicide Attempts']
abstract: In the documentary “Elena,” Petra Costa explores the life of her sister, who moved from Brazil to New York, and later committed suicide.
lead_paragraph: The title character of Petra Costa’s poetic, intensely personal documentary essay, “Elena,” is her older sister, a Brazilian dancer and aspiring actress who settled in New York City and eventually committed suicide when Petra was 7. Years later, Petra, also an aspiring actress, followed in Elena’s footsteps and moved to New York to study theater at Columbia. “My mother always said I could live anywhere in the world, except New York,” she recalls. “I could choose any profession, except actress.”

headline: Underscoring Success of Live TV, Music Specials Will Make a Return
abstract: The revival dovetails with a growing programming trend: a desire among networks to give viewers more shows deemed worth watching — and discussing on social media — in real time, making it likelier that commercials will be seen.
lead_paragraph: A MEDIA executive who has had a high profile on Madison Avenue is returning to the spotlight by reviving a pair of music-centered television specials he developed, signing sponsors and partners like AOL, Cumulus, L’Oréal, Macy’s, Mazda, Time Inc. and Verizon.

headline: GTT ★
abstract: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.
lead_paragraph: Our quirky, discerning picks for the most interesting things to do around the state this week.

headline: Council Passes Bills Aiding de Blasio’s Quest to End Traffic Deaths
keywords: ['Traffic Accidents and Safety', 'Taxicabs and Taxicab Drivers', 'Motorcycles, Motor Bikes and Motorscooters', 'Law and Legislation', 'Deaths (Fatalities)']
abstract: Rules governing cabbies, motorcyclists and other drivers were among the changes approved as part of a package of bills framed as a piece of Mayor Bill de Blasio’s Vision Zero plan.
lead_paragraph: Cabbies who strike pedestrians in New York City can be prohibited from driving a taxi.

headline: Clip: ‘Filth’
abstract: A scene from the film, directed by Jon S. Baird and featuing James McAvoy.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film, directed by Jon S. Baird and featuing James McAvoy.

headline: Public Defender System for Immigrants Facing Deportation Would Pay for Itself, Study Says
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Immigration Detention', 'Public Defenders and Court-Appointed Lawyers (Criminal)', 'Legal Aid for the Poor (Civil)', 'Deportation']
abstract: A program offering legal counsel for every indigent immigrant would be cost-effective by reducing waste in courts and jails, a New York City Bar Association report says.
lead_paragraph: Every year, tens of thousands of people appear in immigration court to fight deportation orders without a lawyer to assist them. Many are poor and adrift, unable to speak English or understand the laws determining their fate.

headline: A Dirty Cop. No, Really Dirty.
abstract: In “Filth,” James McAvoy plays an over-the-top Scottish police detective who is going insane while looking for a promotion.
lead_paragraph: James McAvoy goes whole hog in “Filth,” an adaptation of a 1998 novel by Irvine Welsh, the Scottish author of “Trainspotting.” And by whole hog, I mean exactly that. His character, Bruce Robertson, who narrates the film, is an Edinburgh police detective sergeant on a catastrophic downward spiral. As he loses his sanity, he suggests a wounded wild boar on the rampage, dragging his entrails behind him as he charges around in circles. Compared with this maniac, the rotten policeman of two “Bad Lieutenant” films is a garden-variety bad boy.

headline: An Island Marred by a Ferry Disaster and Sustained by Dogs
abstract: Before a deadly ferry sinking in April, the South Korean island of Jindo was known largely for one thing: its dogs, famous for their loyalty and homing instinct.
lead_paragraph: DONJI-RI, South Korea — This hamlet of cinder-block huts with blue and red roofs slumbered in a drowsy repose. Weeds with yellow flowers grew in the corners of dusty front yards and through cracks in the pavement of deserted alleys. The town’s only “hagwon,” a private cram school, stood empty, because so many families with school-age children had moved away.

headline: A World War II Veteran Works to Help Comrades
abstract: Jack Lombardi served in World War II and now sells imitation poppy flowers, which are made by disabled veterans, to honor the war dead and to raise money for disabled and hospitalized service members.
lead_paragraph: Jack Lombardi served his three years in the Pacific in World War II, repairing Navy ships and manning gun stations when Japanese planes appeared overhead.

headline: Pacers’ Stephenson Gets in James’s Ear, but Not in His Head
abstract: Indiana stayed alive by winning Game 5 of the Eastern Conference finals as Miami’s LeBron James was limited to 7 points.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — While LeBron James was preaching the importance of forward thinking, his coach, Erik Spoelstra, was acknowledging the value of addressing past issues.

headline: Common Core School Standards Face a New Wave of Opposition
abstract: The governors of Oklahoma and South Carolina are considering signing bills to replace the Common Core standards with locally written versions, and Missouri is considering a related measure.
lead_paragraph: Opposition to the Common Core, a set of reading and math standards for elementary, middle and high school students that were originally adopted by 46 states and the District of Columbia, has gathered momentum among state lawmakers in recent weeks.

headline: With Main Parties in Disarray, France’s Far Right Benefits
abstract: In her recent election campaign, Marine Le Pen portrayed mainstream politicians as corrupt. As if on cue, the main conservative party acknowledged using false invoices in 2012.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Marine Le Pen, the leader of France’s far-right National Front, could not have come up with a better script if she had written it herself.

headline: Jack Walsh: Brooklyn Without an Exclamation Point
abstract: This is Mr. Walsh’s 21st year as executive producer of the Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival run by BRIC, a nonprofit arts and media organization where he is also the director of performing arts.
lead_paragraph: Born and raised in Park Slope, Brooklyn, Jack Walsh, 54, grew up playing roller hockey behind the Prospect Park band shell. And he hasn’t really left the neighborhood. This is Mr. Walsh’s 21st year as executive producer of the Celebrate Brooklyn! Festival run by BRIC, a nonprofit arts and media organization where he is also the director of performing arts. The festival, which opens June 4 with a concert by Janelle Monáe, presents music, movies and dance parties at the band shell — all free, without reservations (except for benefit performances). He lives in Windsor Terrace with his wife, Trilby, who works at the Maurice Sendak Community School in Park Slope, and their son Colin, 17, a junior in high school. Another son, John, 20, is a student at the State University of New York at New Paltz.

headline: Diego Cordovez, U.N. Envoy and Conflict Mediator, Dies at 78
abstract: Mr. Cordovez, an Ecuadorean, negotiated the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan in the 1980s.
lead_paragraph: Diego Cordovez, an Ecuadorean diplomat who, as a United Nations under secretary general, negotiated the withdrawal of Soviet troops from Afghanistan in the 1980s, died on Saturday in Quito, Ecuador. He was 78.

headline: Take a Man’s Horses, Expect a Reckoning
abstract: The French film “Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas,” adapted from a 19th-century German novella, pits Mads Mikkelsen, in the title role, against an unjust baron.
lead_paragraph: Brooding and intransigent, “Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas” undertakes a brave and foolhardy act, not unlike the prideful horse merchant of the title. Its striking story of rebellion in an age of aristocracy is set in 16th-century France, adapted from a 19th-century novella by Heinrich von Kleist, a text ripe for reappraisal. But the severely beautiful film is painted in a dauntingly austere manner, as if lost in a war against itself, with confrontations underplayed and the rural landscapes making more of an impression than the detoured drama.

headline: A Lifeline for Veterans Waiting for Care
abstract: In response to the backlog problem, the Department of Veterans Affairs has a new plan to make it easier for veterans to use private facilities.
lead_paragraph: In the wake of revelations that patients have waited for months to see a primary care doctor at a veterans’ medical center in Phoenix, the Obama administration announced in the past few days some reasonable steps to mitigate the problems. One important measure will move veterans who have been stuck too long up the waiting list. Another will offer those still facing waits of more than 30 days the option of using private hospitals and clinics.

headline: Can Therapists Prevent Violence?
abstract: Do laws regarding mental health professionals' duty to warn authorities of a threat need to be toughened to make them more effective?

headline: Time to Move on Dangerous Tank Cars
abstract: There has been a surge in trains carrying combustible crude oil, and it is up to the federal government to protect everyone in their path.
lead_paragraph: The main railway lines in New York have become superhighways for railroad tank cars filled with combustible crude oil. They rumble by the hundreds across the state as part of a surge in shipments from booming oil fields in North Dakota to terminals and refineries in the Northeast. It is up to the Obama administration to make those cars safer for everyone in their path.

headline: At Belmont, No Bets on Race Weather
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Horse Racing', 'California Chrome (Race Horse)', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)']
abstract: The weather may be the biggest challenge facing California Chrome as he tries to become the first Triple Crown winner since 1978.
lead_paragraph: California Chrome has continued to train with ease at Belmont Park, and after a routine two-mile gallop Thursday, he schooled in the paddock for the first time since his arrival 10 days ago.

headline: Sliding Toward Autocracy in Thailand
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'United States International Relations', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Freedom of Speech and Expression', 'Editorials']
abstract: Despite promises of establishing a “genuine democracy,” the military seems intent on silencing all forms of dissent after taking power in a coup last week.
lead_paragraph: After taking power in a coup last week, Thailand’s top army general said the military would establish a “genuine democracy” in the country. But in practice, the military is operating an increasingly authoritarian government intent on silencing all forms of dissent or disobedience.

headline: Maya Angelou Often Left New York, but She Always Came Back
abstract: Wherever Ms. Angelou lived — California, Cairo, Ghana, North Carolina — what she called her “extended family” of friends and her literary roots kept pulling her back to New York.
lead_paragraph: Maya Angelou’s first New York City apartment was a modest place in Brooklyn. But when she left the city behind about a year ago, she also left behind a capacious brownstone in Harlem that she had transformed into a kind of salon, mixing dancers with activists, musicians with writers.

headline: Clip: ‘The Grand Seduction’
abstract: A scene from the film featuring Brendan Gleeson and Taylor Kitsch.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film featuring Brendan Gleeson and Taylor Kitsch.

headline: The Arms Struggle in Chicago
abstract: Mayor Rahm Emanuel’s sensible proposals are rooted in proven reforms that Congress should be considering nationally.
lead_paragraph: The city of Chicago, bedeviled by street gang violence, refuses to give in to ever more restrictive court rulings against enactment of sensible gun safety laws. The Supreme Court’s misguided 2010 decision ended the nearly 30-year-long ban on handguns in Chicago. In January, a federal judge ruled that the city’s ban on retail gun shops was unconstitutional.

headline: Brooklyn Yankee; Lonely Island; Food City
abstract: In one book, Willie Randolph provides insights into colleagues; another book captures the character of North Brother Island; and another book traces the evolution of public markets that served a seaport city in 1800 into a radically different system of demand and supply.
lead_paragraph: Willie Randolph played for almost as many New York professional sports teams as Gladys Gooding (the organist for the Dodgers at Ebbets Field and the Rangers and Knicks at Madison Square Garden). A graduate of Brooklyn’s Samuel J. Tilden High School, Randolph spent most of his playing career with the Yankees, capped it with the Mets, returned to coach for the Yankees and then managed the Mets.

headline: Village, Suffering From Cuteness, Seeks a Doctor
abstract: Tickle Head, a down-on-its-luck fishing village, wants to lure a recycling plant so everyone can get jobs.
lead_paragraph: Ah, those wacky foreigners and their impossibly charming villages. If they’re not posing naked for fund-raising purposes (“Calendar Girls”), they’re trying to collect a dead man’s lottery winnings (“Waking Ned Devine”). The latest entry in this tradition is “The Grand Seduction,” and it’s adorable.

headline: Major Reports and Testimony on V.A. Patient Wait Times
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: Problems with waiting times for veterans seeking medical care have been documented dozens of times by federal agencies over the past 15 years.
lead_paragraph: Problems with waiting times for veterans seeking medical care have been documented dozens of times by federal agencies over the past 15 years.

headline: Who Would Want to Be Powerless Sleeping Beauty When Maleficent Roars?
abstract: Other little girls may have wanted to be Sleeping Beauty; I was always drawn to Maleficent. Now I know the attraction was more about vulnerability than villainy.
lead_paragraph: Is every little girl born with a set of wings? That’s what I found myself wondering while watching Disney’s new feature film “Maleficent,” which stars Angelina Jolie as the title character, also known as the “mistress of all evil,” first introduced to fans in the animated 1959 Disney classic “Sleeping Beauty.”

headline: Steve Ballmer Said to Sign $2 Billion Deal to Buy Clippers
abstract: Rochelle Sterling agreed Thursday night to sell the Los Angeles Clippers to Steve Ballmer, the former chief executive of Microsoft, for $2 billion, which would be the largest price ever for an N.B.A. franchise.
lead_paragraph: The former Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer has agreed to pay $2 billion for the Los Angeles Clippers, according to a person briefed on the negotiations. If approved by the National Basketball Association, the sale would end a troubling situation for the league and rank as one of the largest deals in sports history.

headline: Global Investors Looking for Real Estate Bargains Flock to Spain
abstract: Private equity firms and banks are descending on Spain, teaming up and competing for huge loan portfolios left over from 2008’s market collapse.
lead_paragraph: As one of the most moribund housing markets in Europe, Spain has become a magnet for global bargain hunters. Real estate prices are down as much as 50 percent from their peak during a housing bubble, and investors from Asia to the United States and Britain are flocking to Spain to try to catch the uptick.

headline: The Autocracy Challenge
keywords: ['United States International Relations', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Commencement Speeches', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: President Obama laid out his approach to dealing with aggressive autocratic rulers this week, but his vision is ill-suited for the challenge.
lead_paragraph: It’s hard to remember, but back in the early 1990s there was a debate about how nations should emerge from Communism — the Russian way or the Chinese way. The Russians did political and economic reform together. The Chinese just did economic reform.

headline: When ’70s Guys Hit Their 70s
abstract: P J Raval’s documentary “Before You Know It” follows three gay men — in New York, Florida and Texas — as they deal with the common issues of aging.
lead_paragraph: There’s much sympathy but little tension in P J Raval’s new documentary, “Before You Know It,” a gentle portrait of three gay men of a certain age. As it hops across the country, the film depicts a generation that has seen profound advances in gay rights but struggles with common issues of aging.

headline: Right to Be Forgotten? Not That Easy
abstract: A recent court ruling in Europe has accelerated requests that Internet search companies remove links to individuals’ data. Once a contested item is online, however, the genie will not easily go back in the bottle.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Eoin McKeogh knows how hard it can be to make the Internet forget.

headline: Clip: ‘Lucky Them’
abstract: A scene from the film featuring Toni Collette and Thomas Haden Church.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the film featuring Toni Collette and Thomas Haden Church.

headline: No Boys Allowed (but Pageboys Abound)
abstract: Crops for Girls, a salon in the East Village, specializes in above-the-shoulder styles for women. If the salon had a motto, it might be “No men, no ponytails, no exceptions.”
lead_paragraph: To passers-by, Crops for Girls, a salon on East Ninth Street, resembles any of the dozens of chic beauty parlors in the neighborhood. The paint is rosy and bright, the mirrors are gilded and portraits of starlets dot the walls. But look closer and a subtle theme emerges. Each of those women — Audrey Hepburn, Louise Brooks, Jean Seberg — has short hair.

headline: Tracking Down a Rock God, Despite the Emotional Risk
abstract: In “Lucky Them,” a journalist tries to give her career a lift by catching up with a long-missing musician.
lead_paragraph: In “Lucky Them,” a seen-better-days critic, Ellie Klug (Toni Collette), writes for a seen-better-days magazine that covers alternative rock as if it were the only music in the pop universe. Ellie ignores deadlines and the marketplace, and is burdened by the kind of integrity that looks more like self-destructiveness. (In the real world, she would have been fired years ago.)

headline: N.S.A. Releases Email That It Says Undercuts Snowden’s Whistle-Blower Claim
abstract: The message made no reference to government collection of data of the former contractor’s privacy concerns. Instead, he was seeking clarification of the laws governing the agency.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The National Security Agency on Thursday released what it said was the sole internal email from Edward J. Snowden before he fled with a trove of agency secrets, and officials asserted that the message undercut his argument that he protested the legality of surveillance programs before he released any of the documents he stole to journalists.

headline: Teaching Landowners to Get Their Due
abstract: The state’s surge of oil and gas production can mean windfalls for landowners and mineral owners, so lessors are looking to new programs to learn how to be savvy.
lead_paragraph: LIVE OAK, Tex. — At the front of a cramped classroom at the Alamo University Center, George Wilson, in a singsong voice, lectured about two dozen students on the finer points of the state’s laws on oil and gas royalties, spouting terms like “Mother Hubbard clause,” “habendum clause“ and “force majeure.”

headline: Winning Lottery Numbers for May 29, 2014
abstract: Lottery numbers for New York, New Jersey and Connecticut.

headline: Obama’s Conference on Concussions Was Too Long in Coming
abstract: The White House conference on sports-related concussions, while a big step in the fight for awareness, came too late for many athletes.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Not a single seat was empty in the East Room of the White House on Thursday during a conference, organized by President Obama, on the dangers of sports-related concussions.

headline: Clip: ‘Korengal’
abstract: A scene from the documentary directed by Sebastian Junger.
lead_paragraph: A scene from the documentary directed by Sebastian Junger.

headline: Haunted by Combat, Yet Missing the Brethren
abstract: In “Korengal,” a sequel to the documentary “Restrepo,” American soldiers contemplate their past battle experiences in a valley in Afghanistan.
lead_paragraph: How boring is a soldier’s life in the mountains of Afghanistan during the lulls between firefights? A serviceman interviewed in “Korengal,” the sequel to the 2010 documentary “Restrepo,” recalls that one day he and his Army buddies spent “five or six hours” arguing who would win in a fight between George Clooney and Fabio.

headline: In Report, State Comptroller Is Cautious About Benefits of Casinos
abstract: Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli says in a report to be released on Friday that the economic benefits from expanded gambling in New York may be uneven.
lead_paragraph: ALBANY — Sounding a cautionary note about expanded gambling in New York State, Comptroller Thomas P. DiNapoli warns in a new report that casino complexes planned for upstate will face stiff regional competition and that much of the new revenue anticipated from the casinos will come from New Yorkers, not necessarily from out-of-state visitors.

headline: At Core of Church-State Clash, Unease Over Christianity’s Rising Influence in China
abstract: As Christianity continues its rapid rise in China, some believers feels discriminated against by public policies and say the government favors traditional Chinese religions.
lead_paragraph: “Buddhism and Daoism are embedded in Chinese traditional culture,” the Rev. Matthew Zhen said after an early morning mass in Latin at the Church of the Immaculate Conception in Beijing. “But Islam, Christianity and Catholicism have a relatively short history in China. People need time to accept them.”

headline: Under Pressure, Hagel Promises to Act on Guantánamo Transfers
keywords: ['Detainees', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Shutdowns (Institutional)', 'Prisons and Prisoners']
abstract: Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel has told reporters that he would decide soon whether to accept a months-old offer to resettle six prisoners in Uruguay.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel, who is under pressure from within the Obama administration to step up his pace in approving the transfer of low-level Guantánamo Bay detainees, has told reporters that he would decide soon whether to accept a months-old offer to resettle six prisoners in Uruguay.

headline: Going Into a Taliban Stronghold
abstract: “The Hornet’s Nest” follows Mike Boettcher, a broadcast journalist, embedded with American troops in Afghanistan during Operation Strong Eagle III.
lead_paragraph: When the history of the long war in Afghanistan is written, Kunar Province, the mountainous region near the Pakistan border that has been a Taliban stronghold, will fill more than one chapter. It is already a film source: “Lone Survivor,” the Mark Wahlberg feature, and “Restrepo,” the Oscar-nominated 2010 documentary, both take place there. (Another new film, “Korengal,” revisits the “Restrepo” troops.)

headline: Songs, Jokes and Twirls? Just Don’t Tell Ayn Rand
abstract: Ayn Rand’s pedantic novella “Anthem” gets a goofy, spoofy and exuberant musical adaptation at the Culture Project.
lead_paragraph: It would be folly to adapt Ayn Rand’s pedantic novella “Anthem“ as a straight stage drama, though some have recently tried. Far better to give that belabored paean to individualism a goofy, spoofy spin, as “The Anthem,” an exuberant musical adaptation at the Culture Project, does. The source material may be hopelessly schematic, but the show pours on dazzling trimmings, including a critical element absent in Rand’s didactic prose: humor.

headline: Will Jonny Be Good? Hell and Heaven Wager
abstract: In David Van Asselt’s “A Fable,” a devil figure and an angel figure place a bet on whether a young soldier will lead an exemplary life or be tempted into evil.
lead_paragraph: Once upon a time, Rattlestick Playwrights Theater and Rising Phoenix Repertory mounted “A Fable,” a saggy, perplexing parable by Rattlestick’s artistic director, David Van Asselt. Imagine shredding the scripts of August Strindberg’s “A Dream Play” and Bertolt Brecht’s “A Man’s a Man” and forcing them into a Vitamix with the Book of Job, Voltaire’s “Candide” and a couple of Occupy Wall Street blog posts. Bottoms up?

headline: Songs of Devotion, Songs of Rapture
abstract: In “Early Shaker Spirituals,” the genre-bending Wooster Group pays plain-spoken tribute to the Shakers, inflection for inflection.
lead_paragraph: The gift of being simple has never been widely associated with the Wooster Group, whose austere and profoundly affecting “Early Shaker Spirituals” opened on Thursday night at the Performing Garage in SoHo. Throughout its almost 40, unceasingly fertile years of existence, this genre-bending troupe has taken theatergoers through twisting labyrinths of productions, in which reality and its representations are splintered by technology and irony.

headline: Star of Bombay
abstract: Friday fun with James Mulhern.
lead_paragraph: FRIDAY’S PUZZLE — There are cross-referenced clues in puzzles that are there for no apparent reason, and there are cross-referenced clues in puzzles where you wind up learning something new. Today’s puzzle by James Mulhern contains the latter.

headline: Love Is Out of This World. Far Out.
abstract: You could call John Cariani an absurdist, but his work so far is distinguished equally by another factor: shortness. “Love/Sick,” his latest, is being staged now through June 22 at TheaterWorks Hartford.
lead_paragraph: People who fall in love actually physically fall down, weak-kneed, repeatedly. A woman with a broken heart carries it around in a brown paper bag. That’s the way the world works in John Cariani’s plays.

headline: Billy Crystal Wins Top Audiobook Prize
abstract: “Still Foolin’ ‘Em: Where I’ve Been, Where I’m Going, and Where the Hell Are My Keys?” by Billy Crystal is named audiobook of the year.
lead_paragraph: The publishers and performers of audiobooks celebrated with a gala dinner and awards ceremony in New York on Thursday night. The big winner: Billy Crystal, whose recording of his best-selling book on turning 65, “Still Foolin’ ‘Em: Where I’ve Been, Where I’m Going, and Where the Hell Are My Keys?,” won the prize for audiobook of the year and two other categories.

headline: Feeling Tongue-Tied? Send a Manic Selfie
abstract: In “Emoticon ;),” about a woman trying to get to know her boyfriend’s children, social media applications help surmount the communication problems.
lead_paragraph: Adoption, unexpected pregnancies, blended-family tensions, May-December relationships: “Emoticon ;)” is stuffed with complexities. So why does it feel as facile as that irksome title?

headline: Sweep Coincides With Delay on Deportation Policy Changes
abstract: The timing of President Obama’s decision to delay any policy changes with a roundup in Milwaukee has intensified an angry rift over strategy among groups fighting for an immigration overhaul.
lead_paragraph: On the same day that White House officials revealed that President Obama had delayed for two months making any decisions on changing his deportations policy, enforcement agents fanned out in immigrant neighborhoods in Milwaukee, detaining 21 foreigners in homes and workplaces.

headline: Working Families Party Warns Cuomo of a Possible Opponent
abstract: Late Thursday, a co-chairwoman of the party said it expected to put its support behind a little-known academic with scarcely any chance to defeat Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo in the November race.
lead_paragraph: For weeks now, Gov. Andrew M. Cuomo of New York, a Democrat seeking re-election this year, has been working behind the scenes to soothe misgivings by the leadership of a small but influential political party made up of labor unions and liberal activists who believe his policies have veered too far to the right.

headline: Manning’s Quick Recovery Speeds Up Giants’ Transition to a New Offense
abstract: Eli Manning opted for surgery on his sprained left ankle during the off-season and is fully participating in organized team activities this spring.
lead_paragraph: EAST RUTHERFORD, N.J. — Eli Manning, who sustained a high left ankle sprain in the Giants’ regular-season finale, against the Washington Redskins on Dec. 29, faced a hard decision when his ankle was slow to heal.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events on Long Island. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to lical@nytimes.com.

headline: In Puerto Rico, Cocaine Gains Access to U.S.
keywords: ['Drug Abuse and Traffic', 'Smuggling', 'Cocaine and Crack Cocaine']
abstract: Increasingly thwarted by scrutiny on the United States-Mexico border, drug smugglers are opting to move their merchandise through Puerto Rico instead.
lead_paragraph: SAN JUAN, P.R. — With its navigation lights off, the 35-foot speedboat raced north toward Puerto Rico one night this month, its two large engines at full throttle. Above, a Coast Guard helicopter chased it and then let loose a few warning shots. But the boat roared ahead. Then, thwack, the crew on the copter shot out one of engines.

headline: Clinton-Obama Lunch Hints at Continuing and Close Ties
keywords: ['United States Politics and Government', 'Presidential Election of 2016']
abstract: President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton shared a private lunch, a meeting that was acknowledged only after People magazine posted on Twitter about it.
lead_paragraph: President Obama and Hillary Rodham Clinton shared a private lunch on Thursday, a meeting that never appeared on any official schedule and that White House officials acknowledged only after People magazine posted on Twitter about it.

headline: Mets Prevail Where Boos Aren’t Meant for Them
abstract: Chris Young crushed a two-run homer Thursday, as the Mets beat the Phillies, 4-1, at Citizens Bank Park, where they were able to escape the displeasure of their home fans.
lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — Over the last few weeks, as Chris Young fell into a funk and his average dipped below .200, he was booed mercilessly at Citi Field, and it felt as if the boos grew louder, deeper and meaner each time he walked back to the dugout.

headline: Times Minute | America’s New ‘It’ School
abstract: How Stanford passed Harvard as to become the top ranked university in the US. Also on the Minute, a White House concussion summit and Manohla Dargis reviews ‘Maleficent’.
lead_paragraph: How Stanford passed Harvard as to become the top ranked university in the US. Also on the Minute, a White House concussion summit and Manohla Dargis reviews ‘Maleficent’.

headline: Lundqvist Leads Rangers Back to Finals for First Time Since '94
abstract: The Rangers beat the Canadiens and will play for the Stanley Cup for the first time in 20 years.
lead_paragraph: Henrik Lundqvist leapt into the air as the final horn sounded, almost levitating with joy. He had just won the most important hockey game at Madison Square Garden in 20 years. The Rangers were headed to the Stanley Cup finals.

headline: Foreign Jihadis Fighting in Syria Pose Risk in West
abstract: As many as 3,000 Westerners are believed to have gone to Syria to fight, prompting more aggressive efforts by governments to take action against domestic threats.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — Two years ago, a young man who now calls himself Abu Muhajir slipped into Syria with a few friends and $80,000, forsaking what he said was a job as a high school science teacher in North America to wage jihad.

headline: U.S. Strategy to Fight Terrorism Increasingly Uses Proxies
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Colleges and Universities']
abstract: Even before President Obama’s speech on a shift in antiterrorism strategy, the military began relying more on allied or indigenous troops to combat Al Qaeda and its affiliates.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — During the height of the wars in Iraq and Afghanistan, the United States military often carried out dozens of daily operations against Al Qaeda and other extremist targets with heavily armed commandos and helicopter gunships.

lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational events in New Jersey. Items for the calendar should be sent at least three weeks in advance to njtowns@nytimes.com.

headline: Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles Selects New Chief Curator
abstract: Helen Molesworth, a widely respected scholar and writer, is the first major hire by its director, by Philippe Vergne.
lead_paragraph: The Museum of Contemporary Art in Los Angeles – which has climbed back from the brink of financial dissolution and secured donations and pledges of more than $100 million for its endowment in recent months – has selected Helen Molesworth, a widely respected scholar and writer, to be its next chief curator.

headline: North Carolina: Another Death Investigated at Army Hospital
keywords: ['Emergency Medical Treatment', 'Hospitals', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Babies and Infants']
abstract: The Army is investigating the death Thursday of an 11-month-old baby who had been treated and released less than a week earlier at the emergency room at Womack Army Medical Center at Fort Bragg for a viral infection.
lead_paragraph: The Army is investigating the death Thursday of an 11-month-old baby who had been treated and released less than a week earlier at the emergency room at Womack Army Medical Center at Fort Bragg for a viral infection. In the past two weeks, two patients in their 20s died shortly after treatment at the hospital’s emergency room. The hospital commander was stripped of his post on Tuesday and three deputies were suspended after those deaths. headline: Online Chats Between Sexes Denounced in Saudi Arabia
abstract: A senior Saudi Arabian cleric has issued an edict against online chatting between the sexes.
lead_paragraph: A senior Saudi Arabian cleric has issued an edict against online chatting between the sexes, equating such activity to the prohibitions on the physical mingling of unrelated men and women, the news agency Al Arabiya  reported Thursday. It said the cleric, Sheikh Abdullah al-Mutlaq, a member of the Saudi Committee of Senior Scholars, had warned that such conversations were religiously forbidden and might lead to sin. Al Arabiya quoted the cleric as saying “the devil would be present when women talk to men” on social media network sites. It was unclear how seriously the cleric’s declaration would be enforced in Saudi Arabia, where roughly half the population of 27.3 million are Internet users, an estimated six million use Facebook, and online chat forums appear to be common. Social media for political messaging in Saudi Arabia is strictly forbidden, however. Reporters Without Borders, a press freedom advocacy group, has classified Saudi Arabia as among the most repressive countries in a global ranking on news and information censorship.

headline: Iraq War Inquiry Gets Bits of Leaders’ Talks in Britain
abstract: The British government agreed on Thursday to give the “gist” of conversations between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President George W. Bush while they were in office to an inquiry panel looking into the Iraq war.
lead_paragraph: The British government agreed on Thursday to give the “gist” of conversations between Prime Minister Tony Blair and President George W. Bush while they were in office to an inquiry panel looking into the Iraq war. The agreement between the government and the inquiry, led by John Chilcot, will allow publication of some selected quotations from Mr. Blair’s exchanges with Mr. Bush, but will not include any of Mr. Bush’s replies, Mr. Chilcot said in a letter to Jeremy Heywood, the British government’s top civil servant. “Detailed consideration of gists and quotes requested by the inquiry” has now begun, and quotations will be kept to “the minimum necessary to enable the inquiry to articulate its conclusions,” Mr. Chilcot said. The deal comes after months of deadlock over what would be released; the report is expected to be published before the end of the year. At issue are about 25 written notes from Mr. Blair to Mr. Bush and more than 130 records of conversations. The inquiry was set up in 2009 and was expected to report in 2010. The last public hearings took place in 2011.

(TV5Monde) MONSIEUR HIRE (1989) When a young woman is killed in a Paris suburb, the police immediately suspect the resident loner (Michel Blanc), a tailor who was once jailed for indecent exposure, and whom nobody seems to like. Sandrine Bonnaire plays his pretty neighbor, who never thinks to pull down the shades on the windows facing his, whether she’s dressing or undressing or even making love to her ne’er-do-well boyfriend. This French melodrama, directed by Patrice Leconte from a novel by Georges Simenon, “has the makings of a first-rate psychological study,” Vincent Canby wrote in The New York Times. headline: Turkish Court Says YouTube Ban Is Unconstitutional
abstract: Turkey’s highest court ruled Thursday that a government ban on the video-sharing site YouTube was unconstitutional and a violation of freedom of expression.
lead_paragraph: Turkey’s highest court ruled Thursday that a government ban on the video-sharing site YouTube was unconstitutional and a violation of freedom of expression. The Constitutional Court sent its ruling to the Telecommunications Authority, but it was not immediately clear whether the agency would lift the ban. Last month, the government removed a ban on Twitter a day after the court issued a similar ruling. YouTube was blocked in Turkey on March 27 after recordings from a secret meeting between Foreign Ministry officials detailing plans for possible military intervention against Syria were leaked to the site. The telecommunications agency said the ban was a “precautionary administrative measure” amid concerns over national security.

headline: Horror

Or worse, something you never wanted to understand.” Although it’s always risky to attribute the thoughts of a fictional character to its creator, it’s a reasonably safe bet that this bloodsucker’s sentiments aren’t far from those of the novelist, who has made a habit of writing books about things most of us would rather not understand too well.

lead_paragraph: Cookbooks come in all sorts. Some offer new twists on old recipes or update a familiar cuisine. Others are lavishly tricked out, with production values worthy of “Masterpiece Theatre.” Still others have the brute functionality of car-repair manuals. There are star-vehicle cookbooks, travelogue cookbooks, definitive magnum-opus cookbooks and “I love America” cookbooks, not to mention quasi-­religious farm-to-table, vegan and vegetarian manifestoes.

headline: $2 Billion for Clippers? In Time, It May Be a Steal for Steve Ballmer
abstract: Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief, agreed to pay three times what the franchise was recently valued at, but the team’s bottom line should benefit from television deals.
lead_paragraph: Men with vast fortunes who have bought professional teams as toys are not uncommon. Whether they considered the franchises sound investments is almost beside the point.

headline: More Cookbooks
abstract: An additional selection of some of the season’s notable cookbooks.
lead_paragraph: This season, there’s a cookbook to suit every possible taste, including some from authors whose names will be familiar to regular readers of The Times:

headline: Damon Lindelof Promises You His New Show Won’t End Like ‘Lost’
abstract: For a long time, the ending of the series was all anyone could talk about. Now, as Lindelof prepares to debut a new show, “The Leftovers,” it’s all he can think about.
lead_paragraph: A few months ago, inside a house in Douglaston, Queens, Justin Theroux, the star of the new HBO show “The Leftovers,” was in the kitchen, having his feet blow-dried. Theroux had been shooting a scene in which he had to run outside in the snow in bare feet, jump a fence, then put out a fire — over and over. When he retreated to the living room between takes, a conversation about the limitations of human feet ensued among the various people assembled, which led seamlessly to a vigorous and enthusiastic discussion about the magician David Blaine, who was once frozen in a giant block of ice.

headline: The Mark of Cane
abstract: The legal, social, sometimes comic hazards of losing your eyesight — while pretending you’re not.
lead_paragraph: “Take off your jacket; everything out of your pockets,” the officer said. “Now. Everything.” I stripped my jacket inside out and fumbled through my jeans, torn receipts fluttering to the carpet as I emptied my pockets. I dumped everything on the table in front of me: wallet, phone, eyedrops, matches, lighter.

abstract: Readers respond.
lead_paragraph: WHO GETS TO GRADUATE?

abstract: A melding of forms; graduation groaners.
lead_paragraph: A melding of forms; graduation groaners.

headline: Slaughter for Hire
keywords: ['Ethics (Personal)', 'Meat', 'Fashion and Apparel', 'Law and Legislation', 'Animal Abuse, Rights and Welfare', 'Legal Profession', 'Ethicist, The (Times Column)']
abstract: Eating meat; dressing the part.
lead_paragraph: I have recently been worrying about eating meat, but not for health, religious or even environmental reasons. I worry about whether it is ethical for another reason: Could I kill an animal myself? And eat it? Would I have the “stomach” to do that? If the answer is yes, then I am paying for the service out of convenience. But if the answer is no, then am I a hypocrite for paying someone else to do my “dirty work”? Is it ethical to pay someone else to kill an animal because I can’t, or don’t want to know what’s involved? M. R., NORTH CAROLINA

headline: Who Made That French Press?
abstract: No, not the biceps exercise. The other one.
lead_paragraph: “From the beginning, the French devoted more attention than any other people to coffee brewing,” William Harrison Ukers wrote in “All About Coffee,” published in 1922. The first French coffee maker appeared around 1800, Ukers claimed, and the first one made of glass followed 40 years later. Though Ukers’s encyclopedic work defined dozens of devices, it never mentioned the simple plunger-style vessel that we’ve come to call the “French press.”

headline: The Moat, the Millions and the $50 Timex Watch
keywords: ['Families and Family Life', 'High Net Worth Individuals']
abstract: From Lex Luthor to J. R. Ewing, pop culture had always taught me that rich guys were total jerks. Then my little brother made a fortune.
lead_paragraph: For the last four years, my brother and his family lived in a house with a moat. The house — a four-bedroom French villa in Bel Air previously owned by Jennifer Lopez and Marc Anthony — is pretty impressive even without the moat, but that unnecessary protective trench gives the house a certain surreal charm. It’s nice to know that when you visit your family for the holidays, you don’t have to worry about Spanish conquistadors.

headline: Reading Goals for the Dog Days
abstract: People at The Times share their summer reading plans.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year for guilty reading, but the leisurely months also offer an opportunity for more ambitious projects. I asked people at The Times if they had any goals for the coming weeks.

headline: Comic Relief
abstract: Bob Mankoff, The New Yorker’s cartoon editor, has written a book of memoir, cartoon history and shoptalk.
lead_paragraph: Bob Mankoff is The New Yorker’s cartoon editor as well as a cartoonist himself. “I may not have the best job in the world, but I’m in the running,” he writes in the introduction to his book “How About Never — Is Never Good for You? My Life in Cartoons,” which is not just a charming memoir but also a charming grab bag of cartoon history, cartoon theory (nothing too woolly) and shoptalk. The title is taken from Mankoff’s best-known drawing. Businessman on phone, consulting datebook: “No, Thursday’s out. How about never — is never good for you?” As its author points out — false modesty is not one of his faults — that line has entered the vernacular, alongside other classics from the magazine such as “I say it’s spinach, and I say the hell with it” (drawing by Carl Rose, caption by E. B. White); “Well, back to the old drawing board” (Peter Arno); and “On the Internet, nobody knows you’re a dog” (Peter Steiner).

headline: Drawn From Life
abstract: The cartoonist Roz Chast’s graphic memoir is about her parents’ final years.
lead_paragraph: (This book was selected as one of The New York Times Book Review’s 10 Best Books of 2014. For the rest of the list, click here.)

headline: Housing on the Mend, Ever So Gradually
abstract: Though banks still lead, the gap is narrowing between sales of new homes by builders and of foreclosed houses by banks.
lead_paragraph: ONE way to tell the housing market is beginning to show signs of health would be that builders of new homes are selling more houses than banks do.

headline: They Love Paris
abstract: Four new books about Europe’s most beguiling city.
lead_paragraph: Cole Porter isn’t the only American to have fallen in love with Paris in the springtime, which may explain why four books about Europe’s most beguiling city have appeared all at once. By pure serendipity, their four authors have independently succeeded in producing a chronological quartet.

headline: The Dark Side
abstract: In “Hyde,” Daniel Levine tells Robert Louis Stevenson’s “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” from the monster’s perspective.
lead_paragraph: Robert Louis Stevenson’s “The Strange Case of Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde” is an oblique and artful Gothic tale framed as a detective story. The truth seeker is Jekyll’s lawyer, Utterson, the book’s most prominent character. Jekyll — the ­gentleman who dabbles in chemical self-­transformation — appears only ­intermittently, never fully speaking for himself until the end, when he discloses the details of the disastrous experiments that unleashed his primitive alter ego. The novel isn’t a conventional horror story, lingering on the macabre for its own sake, but an allegory of the divided self, perhaps also a meditation on addiction. Stevenson dramatizes human duality but doesn’t analyze its causes, treating it as pervasive and fundamental. For him, the Jekyll-Hyde split is the split in all of us, between the animals we evolved from and the angels we aspire to be.

headline: Life Out Loud
abstract: Brittney Griner, the second-leading career scorer at the top level of women’s college basketball, writes about her life as an athlete and a gay woman.
lead_paragraph: When Brittney Griner was a senior in high school, a 6-foot-8 center on her way to an all-­American basketball career at Baylor University, she feared telling her father that she was a lesbian. His explosive, curse-filled response upon finding out, Griner writes in a painful, searing and ultimately liberating memoir, “In My Skin: My Life on and Off the Basketball Court,” was exactly what she had dreaded.

headline: Science Fiction
abstract: New books include Jeff VanderMeer’s “Authority,” the second novel in a trilogy about an ecological danger zone.
lead_paragraph: In “Annihilation,” the first book of Jeff VanderMeer’s Southern Reach trilogy, readers were introduced to Area X, a stretch of coastal wetland whose conspiracy-theory name is the icing atop a mille-feuille of layered, slow-building, deliciously creepy horror. Twelve teams of ­researchers, stripped of names to somehow protect them from the identity-warping effects of the danger zone, have traveled into Area X; “Annihilation” followed “the biologist” as she seemingly became the only survivor to actually understand what was happening.

headline: Thrillers
abstract: New thrillers include Mo Hayder’s “Wolf” and Jo Nesbo’s “The Son.”
lead_paragraph: I had the wrong idea about beach books. It came from “Goodbye, Columbus,” where Neil Klugman tells Brenda Patimkin that his cousin Doris always has “War and Peace” by the pool: “That’s how I know it’s the summer, when Doris is reading ‘War and Peace.’ ” Pool and beach being the same to me back then — an idiot kid forced to sit outside with no TV, uncomfortable with my shirt off as my grandfather paraded around to show off he still had a body — I didn’t see that Philip Roth was mocking Doris, and so for years protected myself from the water and sand I resented and feared by lugging along a classic. This is how I read “Swann’s Way” at the Mamaroneck Beach Club as a guest of Uncle Marty and Aunt Lee. It took many visits. Here I would like to thank them personally.

headline: Success Is in the Eye of the Beholder
abstract: Win, lose or draw, professional players cherish support from their fans.
lead_paragraph: I smile and sign autographs no matter what. Most fans don’t seem to care much if we won or lost. They don’t know if I had the game of my life or a complete shocker. They say, “Great game! You were awesome!” Sometimes they even tell me I was wonderful when I didn’t play a single minute. I thank them whether I feel on top of the world or have a lump of disappointment in my throat.

headline: Travel
abstract: New travel books include John Waters’s “Carsick,” in which the director hitchhikes from one of his homes in Baltimore to another of his homes in San Francisco.
lead_paragraph: Paul Bowles observed that an important difference between a tourist and a traveler “is that the former accepts his own civilization without question; not so the traveler, who compares it with the others, and rejects those elements he finds not to his liking.” This difference also separates writers about travels from “travel writers.” Is the voyaging writer telling us canny stories from a romping trip or using his peregrinations to relocate his place in the world? Sometimes it’s difficult to tell. D. H. Lawrence knocked off travel essays about places in which he had arrived only a few hours before, but he was writing about himself and his intuitions. Bowles, for his part, lived for years in Morocco but traveled through the desert with a suitcase filled with his favorite neckties. Do we read either man for profound and meticulously earned insights about Sardinia or the Sahara, or for their ability to convey something about themselves as they pass through those places? Most writers are “passing through,” and we expect no more of them. It’s part of their charm, if they have any. And part of the sometimes dubious premise of travel writing itself.

headline: Pop Music
abstract: New books from inside and around the world of pop music, including the journalist Lisa Robinson’s memoir “There Goes Gravity.”
lead_paragraph: All rock biographies/memoirs agree on one point. As Gregg Allman tells it in “One Way Out,” an exhaustive oral history of the Allman Brothers Band by Alan Paul, escaping the workaday lot of “a shock-absorber washer-jammer in Detroit . . . is why I became a musician in the first place.” Or as Joey Ramone sang: “It’s not my place in the 9-to-5 world.”

headline: Humor
abstract: New books about the science of why we laugh, the references of Monty Python, the art of writing comedy and more.
lead_paragraph: Writing seriously about humor is a tricky proposition. If you approach the subject too analytically, you risk losing sight of what made it worth writing about in the first place. If you try to leaven your analysis with a little humor of your own, there’s a good chance you’ll end up reminding your readers why making people laugh is best left to the people who do it for a living.

headline: One Man, Two Wives and Many Accepted Forms of Violence in Pakistan
keywords: ['Honor Killings', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Women and Girls']
abstract: An uncle and two cousins were among those accused of beating to death a pregnant woman who married against her family’s wishes.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — The murder case of Farzana Parveen, it seemed, could hardly have turned more tragic or gruesome: a 25-year-old pregnant woman, bludgeoned to death with a brick by family members on a busy street, for having married the man she loved.

headline: Shall We Dance?
abstract: Richard Barrios surveys the extensive world of movie musicals.
lead_paragraph: All movies are musical, film being as reliant on rhythm and tempo as sonatas are. Only a few movies are musicals, though, and the fewness isn’t going away. Live-action musicals are nearly as endangered a movie species as westerns. Whether you think those few are too many or nowhere near enough will go a long way toward determining your response to Richard Barrios’s “Dangerous Rhythm: Why Movie Musicals Matter.” The subtitle indicates which side Barrios comes down on. The fact of his having written the exhaustively researched and exuberantly argued “A Song in the Dark: The Birth of the Musical Film” (1995) should settle any doubts.

headline: Street Life
abstract: Two new books explore the possibilities of street photography.
lead_paragraph: The flâneur, that feature of the 19th-century urban landscape, stood apart from the city as a wide-eyed wanderer. But when he had a camera in his hands, he became the archetypal street photographer, a curious observer who captured his environment in what Henri Cartier-Bresson called its "decisive moments”: spontaneous, serendipitous, intuitive, singular. In “Unfamiliar Streets: The Photographs of Richard Avedon, Charles Moore, Martha Rosler, and Philip-Lorca diCorcia,” the art historian Katherine A. Bussard explores the genre of street photography, beginning with this dominant definition and then expanding it. The photographers she investigates, whose work here spans the 1940s through 2001, manipulate the viewer’s imagination of the city, or change the way viewers act within it. According to Bussard, accurately representing experiences of city streets “involves addressing issues of gender, commerce, race, collectivity, class, dispossession, sexuality and spectacle.” In other words, street photography isn’t only the magic of capturing a well-composed slice of life; it’s the more complex task of recapitulating or intensifying the economic, class and gender tensions of the city street within an image. The image should galvanize the viewer or, ideally, alter street life as it’s lived simply by the fact of the image having been made.

headline: Minnesota Nice
abstract: A collection of stories, essays, poems and reminiscences from the creator of the public radio show “A Prairie Home Companion.”
lead_paragraph: Some writers define themselves by contrasting their talents or sensibility with those of another writer. “Well, I’m no Joyce Carol Oates,” they’ll tell you, false modesty oozing from their pores like musk. “I publish a book every eight years.” Or, “You wouldn’t confuse me with Thomas Merton,” they’ll say, referring to the Trappist monk and mystic. “Kneeling bags my nylons.” The best of these self-conscious comparisons may come from James Thurber, who was once asked to review Salvador Dalí’s autobiography. Comparing his own golden-hued Columbus, Ohio, upbringing with young Dalí’s chiaroscuro of ermine capes and necrophilia, Thurber wrote, “The naked truth about me is to the naked truth about Salvador Dalí as an old ukulele in the attic is to a piano in a tree, and I mean a piano with breasts.”

headline: Appetites
abstract: The plucky heroine of the food writer Ruth Reichl’s first novel goes on working for a magazine after it folds.
lead_paragraph: Ruth Reichl is known for many things, among them her best-selling memoirs, including “Tender at the Bone” and “Comfort Me With Apples,” as well as her years of reviewing restaurants for both The Los Angeles Times and The New York Times, and as the editor in chief of the seemingly immortal Gourmet magazine — until it folded. With the arrival of Twitter, Reichl added another genre to her résumé: haiku-like paeans to breakfast in any weather: “Sunny in Charlotte. Returned to rain. Gray New York morning. Big bowl of ginger strewn congee. Chiles. Soy. Scallion. So consoled.” The next day, it was still raining, but once again food came to the rescue: “Gray drizzle. Umbrellas up. Sidewalks sloppy. Rye bread, still warm. Herring: pungent, rich. Sour cream. Onions. Solace in the city.”

headline: Five-Card Studs
abstract: In their new memoirs, Colson Whitehead and Brooks Haxton use poker to expand our sense of how human beings work.
lead_paragraph: Art is the deliberate transformed by the accidental. If you’re a writer, you brew a pot of coffee, adjust the lights, go over your notes and get started, though you know that something — a phone call, a memory, a random image — is likely to barge in and change everything. Instead of “art,” of course, you could say “science,” “making gumbo” and even “romance”: You show up at Veronica’s apartment with your hair slicked back and a bouquet in your hand, and who answers the door? Betty.

headline: Get Down
abstract: In their new books, Nelson George and Questlove chart the rise and reign of the African-American dance show “Soul Train.”
lead_paragraph: When I was growing up in Chicago, there was no rowdier time in our house than Friday night, when my mother, my three siblings and I stayed up to watch “Red Hot and Blues” on Channel 26, Chicago’s first UHF station. Part advertisement and part dance spectacle, it was our chance to celebrate the end of the week, listen and dance to our favorite R & B songs and howl at the cheesy commercials delivered by pitchmen selling used cars and ugly furniture: “You’ll do well to see Dell’s — Dell’s Furniture.” (Even hearing the voice was enough to send us all into fits of laughter.) Just as attractive as the music was the lineup of shabbily dressed kids from the West Side who gathered in front of the camera to dance — a great counterpart to us shabbily dressed kids from the South Side. The show was the highlight of our week.

headline: Hit Man
abstract: “Here Comes the Night,” about the producer and songwriter Bert Berns, is grounded in the New York City rhythm and blues recording scene of the 1960s.
lead_paragraph: Bert Berns the producer is the Phil Spector you’ve never heard of. Bert Berns the songwriter is the Leiber and Stoller you’ve never heard of. Bert Berns the label exec is the Jerry Wexler you’ve never heard of.

headline: Dress-Up
abstract: Linda Przybyszewski unearths fashion advice from a forgotten group of 20th-century sartorial experts.
lead_paragraph: Five years ago Ruth Bader Ginsburg, associate justice of the Supreme Court of the United States, flung open her closet to Brian Lamb, the founder of C-SPAN.

headline: Captured Obsessions
abstract: A collection of Mary Ellen Mark’s photos from Mexico and India.
lead_paragraph: Over the last 50 years, Mary Ellen Mark has photographed twins, clowns, patients in a mental hospital, Ku Klux Klan members and Liza Minnelli. She likes to look at people who are used to being looked at, and she uses her camera like Wonder Woman’s golden lasso — as a truth-telling device that peels performance from personality. In one of her most famous photographs, “Tiny” (1983), a Seattle street kid poses in her Halloween costume: a little black dress, little black gloves and a hat with a netted veil. It’s the daintiness of Tiny’s dress combined with her defiance that gives the photograph its charge. Tough Tiny looks afraid.

headline: Disillusion
abstract: Susan Rieger’s epistolary first novel tells the story of a bitter uncoupling.
lead_paragraph: According to the oft-repeated statistic, roughly half of all marriages in this country end in divorce — which makes “The Divorce Papers,” Susan Rieger’s epistolary first novel about one couple’s messy split, certainly relatable. But how many people want to relive the emotions of a marriage’s demise, from the initial shock to the ensuing despair, fury and vengeance?

headline: Today in Small Business: The Cost of Paper Checks
abstract: Clean-air regulations on the way. And the founder of Reputation.com exposes micromanagement in Silicon Valley.
lead_paragraph: What’s affecting me, my clients and other small-business owners today.

headline: Letters From London
abstract: “Love, Nina” consists of the author’s letters home to her sister while working as a live-in nanny and rubbing elbows with London’s literary royalty.
lead_paragraph: This book seems to have been written specifically for me. Which is not quite the same as saying it was written for you. There is a chance, of course, that you too lived in London in the 1980s while studying for a degree in English literature, in which case you will get every cultural and political reference it contains. It’s possible you are actually English yourself. If that is so, you (like me) will laugh aloud at the understated humor while enjoying the nostalgic mentions of TV shows and sporting events of years gone by.

abstract: Jen Doll’s first book is a memoir about weddings she has attended.
lead_paragraph: Jen Doll is Emily Post’s worst nightmare.

headline: Journey by Rail
abstract: Tom Zoellner sets off on a series of railway adventures in an attempt to recapture the power and poetry of train travel.
lead_paragraph: In an era of railway mediocrity, epitomized by Amtrak, it’s easy to forget that train travel was once a romantic adventure. Riding the rails to Boston in 1924, George Gershwin listened to the roar of the steam engine and the turn of the wheels and found the inspiration for “Rhapsody in Blue,” his hymn to urbanizing, Jazz Age America. “It was on the train, with its steely rhythms, its rattle-ty bang, that is so often so stimulating to a composer,” he told a biographer, describing the moment of creation. “I frequently hear music in the very heart of the noise.” W. C. Handy and other African-American musicians heard a similar sound on the Illinois Central, the Midwestern line that spirited them away from the Deep South on the Great Migration that began during World War I. They married the whistle and drone of the locomotive to the plaintive chants of sharecroppers and invented the “city blues.” Steve Goodman, a little-known composer, was inspired by a ­journey on the same line to write a dirge that became one of the anthems of the Vietnam War era — “The City of New ­Orleans.”

headline: Not Just Laughs
abstract: A collection of Christopher Buckley’s work includes historical spoofs, riffs about family life and literary criticism.
lead_paragraph: Christopher Buckley begins his new collection, “But Enough About You,” with an essay about the perils of being known as a humorist, the fear that people brand him as “trivial” and believe that what he and his literary forebears do is easy. “Well, only five paragraphs in and already wallowing in self-pity,” he writes. “We just can’t get no respect.”

headline: Countdown to 2014 World Cup in Brazil: Day 13
abstract: Britain’s ambassador to Cuba has appealed to soccer fans in that country to support England in the World Cup.
lead_paragraph: The 2014 World Cup begins on June 12, when Brazil plays Croatia in the opening match. Reporters and editors for The Times will count down to the start of the tournament each day with a short capsule of news and interesting tidbits.

headline: Inside the List
abstract: Daniel Schulman, whose biography of the politically influential Koch brothers is No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list, says, “I think it’s important, historically, to know who they are.”
lead_paragraph: Hemingway on the Stoop: Near the beginning of “Sons of Wichita,” his biography of the politically influential Koch brothers — it’s No. 17 on the extended hardcover nonfiction list — Daniel Schulman describes the conservative beliefs of the family patriarch, the industrialist Fred Koch. “Father was paranoid about Communism, let’s put it that way,” his son David Koch once told New York magazine, in a quote Schulman cites. Fred’s views filtered down to at least one of his four sons: Charles, the second-oldest and now the chief executive of Koch Industries, spent most of a blind date in the early 1960s railing against the evils of Communism, according to the biography. (“I ended up leaving early and walking home,” his date says.) Charles also let his politics spill over into literary criticism. Schulman, a senior editor at Mother Jones, reports that when a family friend showed up at the Koch house in the 1960s with a copy of “The Sun Also Rises,” Charles eyed the book apprehensively and finally asked the visitor to leave it outside.

headline: Snooping Around
abstract: In Mona Simpson’s sixth novel, a young boy’s spying yields knowledge about the precarious state of his family.
lead_paragraph: The word “spying” now brings to mind boundless digital nets trawling the ether for millions of emails at a time, but Miles Adler-Hart, the young protagonist of Mona Simpson’s sixth novel, practices snooping the old-school way. He plants a walkie-talkie in his parents’ bedroom. He eavesdrops on therapy sessions through a heating vent. He listens to phone conversations by carefully picking up a landline in the next room.

headline: How Sandy Koufax’s Motel Helped Lead to Baseball’s Big-Money Era
abstract: Off-season work was common for baseball stars in an earlier era, but a holdout by Koufax and his Dodgers teammate Don Drysdale helped change that.
lead_paragraph: In 1962, the star Los Angeles Dodgers pitcher Sandy Koufax invested in a West Hollywood motor inn, which was renamed “Sandy Koufax’s Tropicana Motel.” Down Santa Monica Boulevard from the famed Troubadour club, these “74 luxurious air-conditioned rooms” — rented at “popular prices” — came to lodge some of the biggest musical acts of the period: Alice Cooper, Bob Marley, the Mamas and the Papas, Led Zeppelin, Janis Joplin, Jim Morrison and the Doors. “I don’t know which made me more excited,” said one guest, “to be in Sandy’s motel or to be in a room right beside Sly Stone, from Sly and the Family Stone.”

abstract: Researchers teleported quantum information between two distant atoms for the first time in 2009.
