headline: Paperback Row
abstract: Paperback books of particular interest.
lead_paragraph: THE CIRCLE,  by Dave Eggers. (Vintage, $15.95.) Orwell’s Ministry of Truth is transformed into a powerful tech company in Eggers’s dystopian satire. In a not-too-distant future, human existence flows through the Circle, a Google-like, Facebook-like behemoth that aspires to record and quantify everything that happens to everybody, everywhere in the world. Into this digital wonderland steps Mae Holland, an ambitious new hire eager to comply with the Circle’s demands for transparency.

lead_paragraph: STRESS TEST: Reflections on Financial Crises,  by Timothy F. Geithner. (Crown, $35.) The former Treasury secretary’s memoir offers an inside look at the government’s response to the financial crisis.

headline: Everything You Need to Know About Thomas Piketty vs. The Financial Times
abstract: A review of the controversy over issues a newspaper took with an influential book about economic inequality.
lead_paragraph: Last Friday afternoon, The Financial Times released an expansive report accusing Thomas Piketty of doing shoddy analysis of data on wealth inequality for his best-selling book, “Capital in the Twenty-First Century.” In the six days since, economists and writers around the world have produced many thousands of words on the controversy. Outsiders have weighed in on the newspaper’s case, the newspaper responded, and Mr. Piketty, on Thursday, provided his first detailed defense.

headline: $5 Million to Endow Yale Poetry Chair
abstract: Frederick Iseman, the founder of a private equity firm, gave the money to endow a poetry chair and to support student access to opera.
lead_paragraph: Yale University has received a $5 million gift from Frederick Iseman, the founder and chief executive of CI Capital Partners, a private equity firm, to be used partly to endow the school’s first chair in poetry and partly to extend a program that gives Yale students free access to the Metropolitan Opera’s HD broadcasts as well its Met on Demand archives, the university announced.

headline: Q. and A. on the Syrian Presidential Election
abstract: The disputed vote to be held on Tuesday, amid a three-year conflict that has killed more than 160,000, is virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a third seven-year term.
lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — Syria will hold a presidential election on Tuesday amid a three-year conflict that has killed more than 160,000 people and driven nine million from their homes. The disputed vote is virtually certain to give President Bashar al-Assad a third seven-year term. Opponents of the Assad administration have dismissed the election as a sham, given the government’s violent crackdown on a movement for political rights that began in 2011 and morphed into civil war.

headline: A Cruise to Catch Autumn Leaves
abstract: Crystal Cruises will offer a 10-day trip to see fall foliage in New England and eastern Canada.
lead_paragraph: Car trips are a popular way to see the picturesque fall foliage in New England and the eastern coast of Canada, but this year, Crystal Cruises has a new sailing in the region that will give travelers a different way to take in the season’s colors.

headline: At Disney Concert Hall, Hadid Picks Up on Gehry’s Tune
abstract: Zaha Hadid’s set for the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s “Così Fan Tutte” harmonizes with the surrounding architecture.
lead_paragraph: It was an artistic collaboration delayed by some 25 years: The London architect Zaha Hadid responded as much to Frank Gehry’s Walt Disney Concert Hall in Los Angeles as she did to “Così Fan Tutte” when she designed her undulating all-white set for the Los Angeles Philharmonic’s performance of Mozart’s opera this week (it closes on Saturday). “We were responding to the context, to Frank’s design,” Ms. Hadid said in a telephone interview from London.

headline: Middle-Class Lament: Rent
keywords: ['Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)', 'Income']
abstract: In New York, middle-income households that pay at least 30 percent of earnings for housing are on the rise. And there are fewer and fewer places for them to live.
lead_paragraph: Michael and Melanie Bellanger Boyer, transplanted Parisians who live in a snug one-bedroom in the West 90s, are members of what social scientists sometimes call the “forgotten middle.”

headline: The Art of Setting the Senses on Edge
abstract: A critic explores the myriad forms of musical dissonance, from pummeling chords in Stravinsky’s “Rite of Spring” to the pungent stacked pitches in Stephen Sondheim’s “Sweeney Todd.”
lead_paragraph: An often-quoted phrase from Milton’s “Comus,” a masque about the god of festivities, describes a roar that emerged from the woods and “fill’d the Air with barbarous dissonance.”

headline: Suicide Bomber Is Identified as a Florida Man
abstract: An American who blew himself up in a suicide attack in Syria was identified by officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, who has lived in Fort Pierce and Vero Beach.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An American who blew himself up in an attack in Syria on Sunday has been identified by law enforcement officials as Moner Mohammad Abusalha, a man in his early 20s who grew up in Florida and traveled to Syria late last year.

headline: Sam Greenlee, Writer, Producer, Government Agent, Dies at 83
abstract: “The Spook Who Sat by the Door,” a film based on Mr. Greenlee’s novel about a black power revolution, was pulled from theaters after three weeks.
lead_paragraph: Sam Greenlee, a novelist and poet best known for a low-budget 1973 movie made from his novel “The Spook Who Sat by the Door,” which envisioned a black power revolution led by a militant black ex-C.I.A. agent — it was pulled from theaters after a brief box office success — died on May 19 in Chicago. He was 83.

This usually happens when I’ve been cooking all day, as I’ve been doing a lot lately because I’m not only testing recipes for this column but also preparing food for book-tour cooking demonstrations.

keywords: ['Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'Iraq War (2003-11)', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder', 'Traumatic Brain Injury', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Veterans']
abstract: Over all, military caregivers today are younger than those of previous generations, have fewer support networks and are at a much higher risk for depression and suicide, a study shows.
lead_paragraph: For Ivonne Thompson, 36, pulling her husband from his wheelchair to bathe him is a way to find time for their marriage. “It is the only intimacy we have left,” she says.

lead_paragraph: Up, up and up. That is the answer to the question I have been posing lately: Where is the luxury condominium market headed?

headline: Douglas Adams Biography to Include Unseen ‘Hitchhiker’s Guide’ Material
abstract: Jem Roberts’s biography of Adams, coming this fall, will include previously unpublished excerpts from the writer’s archive at Cambridge.
lead_paragraph: There are very few things that Douglas Adams did not touch on in his “Hitchhiker’s Guide to the Galaxy” novels, a peculiar blend of science fiction and comedy that began life as a BBC radio series and later had life on television and film as well. Apart from disquisitions on the destruction of Earth, as well as its creation (with special attention to fjords), space travel, alien life forms, depressive robots, celestial bureaucracy, animals that beg you to slice off and eat bits of them, the crucial role of mice and the universe’s loudest rock band, the book asks and answers (well, kind of) the Big Question: What is the meaning of “life, the universe and everything?”

headline: Gallery | Dzine Offers an Artistic History of Boxing, From the Greeks to Pay-Per-View
abstract: “Boxed,” a book which grew out of an exhibition by the artist at Paul Kasmin Gallery earlier this year, is the follow up to his previous cultural-study-cum-art-project, “Nailed,” which told the story of nail adornment.
lead_paragraph: The artist Carlos Rolón, better known as Dzine, has long been a boxing fan, if not a practitioner. “My father took me for boxing lessons when I was 13,” he says. “I was more scared then excited. I developed a hernia.” The injury didn’t dampen his passion, which has led him to produce “Boxed: A Visual History and the Art of Boxing,” an image-driven compendium of the sport, from the Grecian Olympiads to bare-knuckle fighting to today’s megabucks stadium battles.

headline: The Evolving World of Gay Travel
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Families and Family Life']
abstract: The number of places where L.G.B.T. travelers can be themselves has grown exponentially and same-sex marriage laws are transforming cities into travel destinations.
lead_paragraph: In the 1970s gay tours took men rafting in the Grand Canyon and to Rio de Janeiro for Carnival. Gay hotels began opening in Key West, Fla. And destinations like Provincetown, Mass., were creating some of the first marketing to gay and lesbian travelers.

headline: For Gay Destinations, Thinking Outside the Obvious
keywords: ['Same-Sex Marriage, Civil Unions and Domestic Partnerships', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: Six lesser-known or up-and-coming spots that may be easy to overlook when making travel plans.
lead_paragraph: Despite the fact that a sea gull once pooped on me while I was relaxing on a Fire Island beach, I do understand the allure of the place, and that of other idyllic destinations like Provincetown, Mass., and Key West, Fla., which have long been known as gathering spots for gay and lesbian vacationers. Many who identify anywhere along the L.G.B.T. spectrum simply want to go somewhere that is packed with kindred spirits, to relax without having to worry about fitting in with a straight crowd — or, in some places, about the potential perils involved when you don’t fit in. But of course a lot of people who enjoy travel, regardless of sexual orientation or gender identity, want to continuously add new cities to their “places I’ve been” list, so I asked a few gay travel experts to suggest a lesser-known or up-and-coming L.G.B.T. hot spot that we may overlook when making travel plans. Here are some of their suggestions.

headline: Finding Comfort and Safety as a Gay Traveler
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Discrimination']
abstract: The value of doing your homework before you go.
lead_paragraph: Nearly every same-sex couple has experienced that awkward moment on vacation. It usually comes at hotel check-in, when you find yourself on the receiving end of a quizzical or disapproving look as you explain that yes, you did intend to book just one bed for you and your “friend.”

headline: Maya Angelou Exhibition Opens at Schomburg Center
abstract: The exhibition, which will be on display through June 30, showcases materials from Ms. Angelou’s private archive, including her handwritten manuscript of “I Know Why the Caged Bird Sings.”
lead_paragraph: The New York Public Library is celebrating the life and work of the poet Maya Angelou, who died on Wednesday at age 86, in a free exhibition, “Phenomenal Woman,” at the library’s Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture in Harlem.

headline: Celebrating Gay Pride All Over the Map
keywords: ['Homosexuality and Bisexuality', 'Transgender and Transsexual', 'Parades', 'Festivals', 'Travel and Vacations']
abstract: From the Gay Games in Ohio to Gay Days Orlando to Pride parades and festivals across the country, here’s a guide to coming events.
lead_paragraph: Ten years ago, my gay friends and I found the perfect spot for watching New York’s gay pride parade. It was near the entrance of a building near Fifth Avenue and 10th Street, with an awning to keep out the sun and a doorman who laughed along with our catcalls to bouncy go-go boys.

headline: V.A.’s Acting Chief: West Point Graduate and Ex-Leader of U.S.O.
abstract: The acting secretary, Sloan D. Gibson, joined the Department of Veterans Affairs just three months ago as the deputy to Eric Shinseki, who resigned on Friday.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The man who is temporarily replacing Eric Shinseki as secretary of veterans affairs is a West Point graduate, a onetime banker and a former chief executive of the United Service Organizations (known to most Americans as the U.S.O.) who joined the Department of Veterans Affairs just three months ago.

headline: Books to Blankets: Travel Tips for Parents
keywords: ['Children and Childhood', 'Parenting', 'Travel and Vacations', 'Homosexuality and Bisexuality']
abstract: Lucas Grindley, the editorial director of Here Media, offers suggestions for smoothing out trips with small children.
lead_paragraph: Traveling on a plane with 1-year-old twins would be nerve-racking for any parent. But it was all the more so for Lucas Grindley, the editorial director of Here Media, before he and his husband took their daughters on their first flight. A crying baby is not just a crying baby for a gay parent like him, he said; he feared it would be seen as a commentary on his ability to be a parent.

headline: In Rwanda, Looking to Art to Soothe
keywords: ['Travel and Vacations', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Culture (Arts)', 'Hutu Tribe', 'Art']
abstract: A flourishing arts scene in the capital city, Kigali, is bringing healing and reconciliation 20 years after the genocide.
lead_paragraph: “There’s no way you’ll find it yourself,” the artist Strong Karakire told me on the phone, when I asked for directions to his studio in Nyamirambo, a lively neighborhood in the Rwandan capital of Kigali where dirt roads climb the steep hills past modest dwellings. “Just wait at the petrol station, and I’ll come get you.”

lead_paragraph: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s inductees and the challenges of creating a rock canon.

headline: Rethinking the Traditional Retirement Community
keywords: ['Retirement Communities and Assisted Living', 'Real Estate and Housing (Residential)']
abstract: Instead of building traditional Sun Belt retirement communities, developers seek to lure older people who want to remain active or continue to work.
lead_paragraph: WHEN Rikki Selby began shopping for a retirement home, the 66-year-old sought a community where she could make friends with people her own age. But Ms. Selby had no interest in the kind of sprawling Sun Belt development that offers thousands of houses to older people. “In those places, everybody is old, and you don’t see young faces in the supermarket,” said Ms. Selby, who recently retired as a financial planner.

headline: What the Beats Deal Says About Apple: It Loves Tastemakers
abstract: If Silicon Valley is bent on replacing human judgment with algorithmic efficiency, the Beats deal shows that Apple wants to hold itself up as the one tech company that stands proudly against that trend.
lead_paragraph: There’s one thing executives at Apple would like you to know about their decision to buy Beats Music: Apple really loves humans. It loves us in the general sense — the company believes we’re better than computers at deciding what kinds of music we like — and it loves the specific humans who run Beats, especially the company’s founders, the music impresarios Dr. Dre and Jimmy Iovine.

headline: Artifacts and History, Steeped in Brine
abstract: Reasons to visit City Island include the City Island Nautical Museum and, about four blocks away, Artie’s Steak & Seafood Restaurant, where the locals go.
lead_paragraph: The white paint is peeling and the cement steps are chipped at the old public school that houses the City Island Nautical Museum. Inside it’s shipshape. Four Barbaras and a Jane are among the can-do volunteers who maintain the collection of deftly crafted tenders and canoes, photos of sea captains and yachtsmen, models of minesweepers and tools for sail-making and boatbuilding.

headline: Dandelion: A Tenacious Beauty
abstract: The dandelion’s success in flourishing among humans should earn it some grudging admiration.
lead_paragraph: The common dandelion is a reproductive superstar. Though it is hard to remain objective about a plant so familiar as a pesky weed, the little yellow flowers dotting lawns, parks, neglected window boxes or just about any place left unmown for a week have a certain untamed beauty.

headline: Drug Saves Fertility for Women With Cancer
abstract: The new treatment would be a less invasive way to safeguard a woman’s chances of having babies than the current method.
lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — A commonly used drug can help young women with breast cancer retain the ability to have babies, apparently protecting their ovaries from the damage caused by chemotherapy, researchers reported here on Friday.

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Jay Carney, the journalist-turned-press-aide who jousted daily with his former colleagues over issues from the Benghazi terrorist attack to the glitch-ridden health care website, stepped down as the White House press secretary on Friday.

headline: Japan Offers Support to Nations in Disputes With China
abstract: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe said he wanted Japan to shed its postwar passiveness and discourage China’s assertive territorial claims.
lead_paragraph: TOKYO — Saying that his nation will play a larger role in regional security, Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan said on Friday that his government would support Vietnam and other nations that have territorial disputes with China by providing patrol ships, training and military surveillance equipment.

lead_paragraph: Rajat K. Gupta, a former director at the Goldman Sachs Group who was convicted on insider trading charges, has lost a last-minute attempt to stay out of prison.

lead_paragraph: Jeff Kinney, author of the best-selling children’s series “Diary of a Wimpy Kid,” said Friday morning that he is opening a bookstore in his home town of Plainville, Mass.

headline: Rock Relics With a Signature Swagger
abstract: The Parquet Courts, a band with a new album due out on Tuesday, revel in New York rock ’n’ roll tradition.
lead_paragraph: After a recent dinner at a restaurant in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, Andrew Savage, the 28-year-old guitarist and vocalist of Parquet Courts, reached into his pocket to check his text messages. The device he pulled out, a beat-up old clamshell model, seemed a pointed rejection of modernity, even among nonconformist New Yorkers.

headline: A Pair of Dreams to Compare and Savor
abstract: The two most poetic Shakespeare ballets will be performed this month at Lincoln Center: George Balanchine’s “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” and Frederick Ashton’s “The Dream.”
lead_paragraph: This month, the two most poetic and endlessly rewatchable Shakespeare ballets are to be performed on two sides of Lincoln Center: George Balanchine’s two-act “A Midsummer Night’s Dream” (1962) from New York City Ballet at the David H. Koch Theater (opening on Tuesday) and Frederick Ashton’s one-act “The Dream” (1964) from American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House (starting June 30). You might suppose this is to commemorate the 450th anniversary of Shakespeare’s birth this year, but no. The same juxtaposition happened in 2010 and 2012. It’s just the happiest symptom of Lincoln Center’s Ballet Madness each spring, whereby America’s two leading companies play on different sides of the same plaza.

headline: Tips for Those Who Set Their Own Salaries
keywords: ['Freelancing, Self-Employment and Independent Contracting', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Wages and Salaries']
abstract: For the 42 million American workers who are self-employed, a critical skill is knowing what their work is worth.
lead_paragraph: TAYLOR JOHNSON works as a graphic designer, Mary-Kay Demetriou as a marketing consultant and Debra Kling as a color consultant. And they all work as negotiators.

headline: A Spoonful of Spring Asparagus, Green as Can Be
abstract: When making the most out of fresh asparagus, don’t neglect your soup pot.
lead_paragraph: In my frenzy to eat enough asparagus every spring, I inevitably take the speedy route to dinner: steaming, sautéing, broiling, roasting. The aim is to get the stalks from raw to cooked as quickly as possible so I can gobble them up.

headline: All Paths Lead to Illumination
abstract: “Mastering Light: From the Natural to the Artificial” at Vassar’s Frances Lehman Loeb Art Center in Poughkeepsie is a quirky, thought-provoking show that divides its subject into three sometimes overlapping areas.
lead_paragraph: A young woman hangs sheer white linens on a clothesline. A refulgent angel descends from the heavens while shepherds tend their flocks by night. And an early motion-picture camera captures the fairyland allure of a world’s fair, slowly panning its illuminated buildings.

headline: Popcast: The Rock Hall’s New Class and the Revenge of Kiss
abstract: Jon Pareles and Ben Ratliff discuss this year’s inductees and the challenges of creating a rock canon.
lead_paragraph: The 29th annual induction ceremony for the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame happened at the Barclays Center in Brooklyn mid-April; Jon Pareles was there to report on it for The Times, and the filmed version of the evening will be broadcast on HBO this weekend. The new class includes Nirvana, Peter Gabriel, Cat Stevens (now Yusuf Islam), Kiss, the E Street Band, Linda Ronstadt and Hall and Oates.

headline: On Our Walls

lead_paragraph: The walls of The New York Times headquarters on Eighth Avenue are decorated with news images from the past. Prints by photojournalists hang throughout the building. In this Insider series, On Our Walls, we’ll take you inside the building to see the photographs — many of them rich in history — and the stories behind them.

headline: Dolan Spraying Champagne? It Could Happen With the Rangers
abstract: In the 17 years since Cablevision took over Madison Square Garden, James L. Dolan has not won an N.B.A. or N.H.L. title. Now, he and the Rangers are four victories away.
lead_paragraph: In the 17 years since Cablevision took over at Madison Square Garden, James L. Dolan has been an owner without a championship, with no photo of him giddily holding aloft a gleaming trophy.

headline: Big Ticket | A Duplex Above the Park for $48 Million
abstract: A penthouse at 15 Central Park West, with a 392-square-foot terrace facing the park and just beneath a record-setting unit, was the most expensive sale of the week.
lead_paragraph: A duplex penthouse perched near the pinnacle of the coveted park-side “House” portion of 15 Central Park West, the twin-towered limestone condominium where resale residences are appreciating in value much like vintage wine, sold for $48 million and was the most expensive sale of the week, according to city records.

headline: After the Guests Have Left
abstract: A filmmaker decides to chronicle couples’ relationships after finding out some surprising things about his parents’ marriage.
lead_paragraph: Love, romance, infidelity and commitment are only some of the themes that propel “112 Weddings,” an HBO documentary in which 10 couples are asked what they expected of marriage and how they thought their partnerships turned out.

headline: Just Like Taco Trucks, Art Takes to the Road
abstract: Mobile art galleries are gaining traction across the United States as owners and artists shun the cultural establishment.
lead_paragraph: On a recent Saturday, Elise Graham and her 23-year-old son, Aaron, pulled a 12-foot van into a parking spot on West 14th Street in Greenwich Village, swung open the back doors, lowered the aluminum stairs, and welcomed visitors inside their mobile Rodi Gallery.

headline: Rio Violence Spikes Ahead of World Cup
abstract: In the months before the World Cup, violence in Rio has spiked despite pacification tactics that have drawn criticism from some who live in the favelas.
lead_paragraph: In the months before the World Cup, violence in Rio has spiked despite pacification tactics that have drawn criticism from some who live in the favelas.

headline: Rio Grapples With Violence Against Police Officers as World Cup Nears
abstract: At least 110 officers have been shot in Rio so far this year, an increase of nearly 40 percent from the same period last year.
lead_paragraph: RIO DE JANEIRO — Alda Rafael Castilho dreamed of being a psychologist, and joined the police force to pay for her studies. Her dream ended at age 27 when gunmen stormed the outpost where she was on duty in Complexo do Alemão, a sprawling patchwork of slums. A bullet pierced her abdomen, and she bled to death.

headline: In a Surprise Move, Valeant Again Raises Its Bid for a Rival, Allergan
abstract: Valeant raised its takeover bid for the maker of Botox for the second time in three days on Friday, offering more than $53 billion.
lead_paragraph: Updated, 7:45 p.m. | As a rule, deal makers try not to bid against themselves. But Valeant Pharmaceuticals, exasperated in its pursuit of fellow drug maker Allergan, showed little hesitation in doing just that.

headline: Fine Legal Point Poses Challenge to Appraisal Rights
abstract: The question of whether a shareholder can prove it did not vote in favor of a takeover before asserting its appraisal rights could present a significant hurdle to hedge funds that have adopted such rights as a business strategy, Steven M. Davidoff writes in the Deal Professor column.
lead_paragraph: The hedge fund Merion Capital might have hit a roadblock in its multimillion-dollar appraisal proceedings involving the $1.6 billion buyout of Ancestry.com. And it’s a roadblock that just might slow the trend toward exercising appraisal rights.

lead_paragraph: The town of Greenwich, Conn., seems proud that its annual Town Party has drawn some top talent during the four years it’s been held in Roger Sherman Baldwin Park, which overlooks the harbor. headline: Sterling to Reap 15,900 Percent Return on Sale of Clippers
abstract: The team owner has enjoyed a remarkable investment since 1981. But Steve Ballmer puts him to shame.
lead_paragraph: Whether he likes it or not, Donald Sterling is poised to sell the Los Angeles Clippers to Steve Ballmer, the former Microsoft chief executive. And, for $2 billion, what’s not to like about it? Sterling bought the Clippers for $12.5 million in June 1981, according to some reports, and he’ll get a tidy 15,900 percent return over 33 years, an annualized rate of 16.6 percent. In fact, he’s probably done even better than that, because of the distributions of profits during the years of ownership.

lead_paragraph: After night falls in the theater district, a burly bouncer takes his post in front of an unmarked red door, revealing nothing about the secret attraction that lurks behind him.

headline: Many Shades of Sorcery
abstract: Jen Rosenblit’s “a Natural dance,” at the Kitchen, includes a monologue about color.
lead_paragraph: Jen Rosenblit’s “a Natural dance”  induces a kind of morning-after haziness, its images revisiting you in the hours after you’ve seen it like scenes from a fitful dream. None of it quite makes sense: Why is Justin Cabrillos wearing that “Where’s Waldo” costume? What are Effie Bowen and Addys Gonzalez doing with all of those microphones? What is the meaning of this monologue about colors?

headline: Keep Handguns Away From Teenagers

lead_paragraph: In response to the Isla Vista rampage, legislators in California are introducing a bill that would let the police and private individuals ask a court for a restraining order to deny guns to those who pose a threat to themselves or others.

headline: Works of Dvorak, via Budapest
abstract: On the heels of a recent Dvorak-filled concert, Ivan Fischer offers two more immersions.
lead_paragraph: Some of the finest performances in New York in recent years — from creative concert stagings of Mozart operas to Beethoven symphonies — have arrived courtesy of the vibrantly theatrical Hungarian conductor Ivan Fischer and his powerful Budapest Festival Orchestra. On the heels of a recent Dvorak-filled concert with James Levine and the Met Orchestra, Mr. Fischer offers two more immersions in that Czech composer, both at Avery Fisher Hall.

headline: Going, Going, Gone to Sleep
abstract: Baseball on radio and television is the classic sport to nap to — especially on a drowsy Sunday afternoon.
lead_paragraph: I’m glad that another baseball season is once again blooming — gathering meaning and texture now as spring deepens — for all of the usual reasons: the crack of the bat, the smack of ball into leather and the heartening prospect of the unpredictable ramble from the optimism of spring, through the grueling summer, to the iron-hard realities of autumn.

headline: Music Makers Invade an Island
abstract: The Governors Ball Music Festival will feature a reunited Outkast and dozens of other acts spread across four stages.
lead_paragraph: Three years ago, at the inaugural Governors Ball Music Festival, the Atlanta rapper Big Boi played a set peppered with tunes by his former group, Outkast. He’ll be back this year as part of a sprawling and well-monetized Outkast reunion tour.

headline: 50 Cent Makes TV His Turf
abstract: Curtis Jackson — a.k.a. 50 Cent — might very well have inspired the leading character in “Power,” the Starz series of which he is an executive producer.
lead_paragraph: A former crack dealer turned rapper who survived a shooting, a stabbing and run-ins with the law, Curtis Jackson — a.k.a. 50 Cent — might very well have inspired the leading character in “Power,” the Starz series of which he is an executive producer.

headline: Small Comfort to a Young Queen
abstract: In 16th-century Europe, smaller was considered better — more beautiful, more precious — when it came to hand-illustrated books.
lead_paragraph: In 16th-century Europe, smaller was considered better — more beautiful, more precious — when it came to hand-illustrated books. A high value indeed must have been attached to a 2 ¾-by-2-inch prayer book created around 1517 for Claude de France, the first wife of the King François I. The book, made on commission from a young queen at her coronation by an artist now anonymous, is the centerpiece of “Miracles in Miniature: The Art of the Master of Claude de France” at the Morgan Library & Museum.

headline: ‘Subtle’ Inspiration
abstract: Al-Latif is one of the many names of Allah; it means “the Subtle One.” That inspired the title of a new work by the choreographer Ronald K. Brown.
lead_paragraph: Al-Latif is one of the many names of Allah; it means “the Subtle One.” That inspired the title of a new work by the choreographer Ronald K. Brown that is receiving its world premiere in the first of two Brown programs that are running Tuesday through June 8 at the Joyce Theater.

headline: The Longtime Lure of Shiny Objects
abstract: The documentary “The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne,” playing through June 10 at Film Forum, tells the story of a real jewel thief.
lead_paragraph: Jewel thieves come in many varieties. Smash-and-grab thugs. The type of dapper gents favored by makers of heist films. But Doris Payne may be in a class by herself. She is a real-life thief, not a Hollywood creation, though Hollywood is interested in making a drama based on her life. For now, though, there’s the documentary “The Life and Crimes of Doris Payne,” playing through June 10 at Film Forum.

headline: A Private Equity Perennial That May Flourish
abstract: Kohlberg Kravis Roberts’ $1.6 billion acquisition of the landscaping company Brickman Group may show how the sale of a company by one private equity firm to another can be successful, Jeffrey Goldfarb of Reuters Breakingviews writes.
lead_paragraph: Henry Kravis, a co-founder of Kohlberg Kravis Roberts, is cultivating private equity perennials. Buyout shops like his are selling companies to each other at a breakneck pace. It’s easy to be skeptical about these so-called secondaries. But K.K.R.’s $1.6 billion acquisition of the landscaping company Brickman Group may turn out to be an example of how such deals can flourish.

headline: Sisters Strumming in the Darkness
abstract: The Swedish duo Klara and Johanna Soderberg, who have a new album due out on June 10, talk about their musical childhood and their affinity for the raw directness of country songs.
lead_paragraph: It’s just another modern-day discovery story: two Swedish sisters, harmonizing since childhood in perfect twangy English, introduced to the rest of the world via YouTube thanks to their covers of indie ballads and Johnny Cash classics. Klara and Johanna Soderberg were 15 and 17 when that happened, in 2008, and since then, they have toured the globe with their own spare guitar-driven songs, impressing the likes of Jack White (who produced a single for them) and Conor Oberst (who included them on his latest album). The sisters, now 21 and 23, record as First Aid Kit; their third album, “Stay Gold,” a major-label debut that adds the Omaha Symphony Orchestra to their lovelorn country-folk, will be released June 10 on Columbia Records, with a sold-out show on June 11 at Webster Hall.

headline: New Refugee Camp in Jordan Tries to Create a Community for Syrians
abstract: Officials say the Azraq camp for Syrian refugees, in a remote, dusty expanse of Jordan, could grow even bigger than the Zaatari camp, which shelters more than 100,000 Syrians.
lead_paragraph: AL AZRAQ REFUGEE CAMP, Jordan — His face was bright red from the desert sun, and his son’s eyes, blank with exhaustion, gazed into the distance. Bahjat Sheikh, 58, and his family had crossed the Jordanian border to safety after an arduous two-and-a-half-day journey, mostly on foot, from the central Syrian city of Hama.

headline: Pan-Roasted Duck Shows Off a Cherry-Sweet Side
abstract: Muscovy duck breast is as easy to cook as steak, and makes for an elegant dinner any night of the week.
lead_paragraph: Classic French duck recipes, the kind Julia Child swooned for, are now considered old-fashioned, bringing to mind starched white napery and middle-aged waiters in black vests carving tableside.

headline: Print Matters | An Erudite, Fashion-Forward Magazine About Black Gay Culture
abstract: The Tenth — named for W.E.B. DuBois’s concept of “the talented tenth” as well as for a term in voguing — has made waves since its release last month.
lead_paragraph: In 2009, Khary Septh, Kyle Banks and André Verdun Jones founded the Brooklyn creative agency Pink Rooster Studio. But as they made work for clients such as Swarovski and L’Oréal, they also found themselves longing for a project with which they could express the full flower of talent and ideas among gay black men from all cultural walks of life — fashion, art, performance, letters and politics. “We wanted to see what the image of ourselves would look like if we controlled it,” says Septh.

headline: A Preview of Volvo’s Heart-Healthy Future
abstract: The latest Volvo XC60 crossover has become a stylish stalking horse for Volvo’s new family of 4-cylinder engines.
lead_paragraph: Like a New York City mayor tilting at supersized sodas, several automakers have tried to forcibly wean Americans off their big, bad-for-you V8s. Six-cylinder engines are also being downsized in favor of 4s.

headline: A Swede That’s Not Square to Be Hip
abstract: Volvo fights the S.U.V. tide by bringing back its station wagon, giving it outstanding fuel economy with a new line of engines.
lead_paragraph: Say “Volvo,” and what image springs to mind? A station wagon, right? And not just any wagon, but one as square and imperishable as a Saltine, and as much a staple of the suburbs.

headline: Reviving the Coming-of-Age Movie
abstract: The screenwriters Scott Neustadter and Michael H. Weber are bitingly clever, a little off-kilter, big hearted with a melancholy undercurrent. Just like their movies.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Confident yet vulnerable, adorable yet wearing an unfortunate trench coat, John Cusack hoisted a boombox over his head in “Say Anything” and, as Peter Gabriel’s “In Your Eyes” reverberated through the trees, delivered a scene that defined a genre: the great 1980s-era coming-of-age movie.

headline: Parents on the Rebound and Looking for Love
abstract: There’s a spate of television movies this weekend with one theme — parents without partners — and interpretations ranging from slightly trashy to subtly religious.
lead_paragraph: It’s as if someone threw down a challenge to cable outlets of a certain ilk: “Interpret the theme ‘Suddenly Without a Spouse’ in a made-for-television movie.” Lifetime, the Hallmark Movie Channel and Up all unveil films this weekend that seem as if they were responding. One is trashy and stupid. One is weepy and harmless. And one is uplifting and rather good for its type.

headline: Reading Genesis, the Jazz Piano Edition
abstract: The pianist Jon Weber presents a musical tutorial with his show “From Joplin to Jarrett: 115 Years of Piano Jazz,” at the Metropolitan Room.
lead_paragraph: And Scott Joplin begat Jelly Roll Morton, who begat James P. Johnson, who begat Fats Waller, who begat Earl Hines, and on and on. That is a rough sketch of the jazz piano genealogy described by the pianist Jon Weber in his fascinating and essential show “From Joplin to Jarrett: 115 Years of Piano Jazz,” at the Metropolitan Room on Thursday evening.

Over the last dozen years, this has made him a superb ensemble player in the expressionist wing of modern jazz, someone who raises the bar for group cohesion without drawing much attention to himself.

abstract: “Beyond Recall,” the latest installment of Contact! and part of the NY Phil Biennial, spread out in the soaring Agnes Gund Garden Lobby at the Museum of Modern Art on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: New music is thankfully a preoccupation of the New York Philharmonic under Alan Gilbert, but glamour isn’t always part of the equation. The orchestra’s new-music series, Contact!, has spent most of its time in no-frills, functional halls like the Metropolitan Museum of Art’s Grace Rainey Rogers Auditorium; the basement space SubCulture; and Symphony Space, as oppressively shoeboxy as the much-maligned Avery Fisher Hall.

abstract: With the help of a little get-together called Coachella, Palm Springs is recapturing its Hollywood glory.
lead_paragraph: It was Dinah Shore Weekend in Palm Springs — or the Dinah, as it’s known — five days of Sapphic revelry that every April draws some 15,000 women from around the country to this sun-washed city 90 miles southeast of Los Angeles. On Saturday evening, however, the hottest ticket in town may not have been the L Word Pool Party, but a relatively low-key cocktail reception hosted by the Palm Springs Art Museum to benefit its new Architecture and Design Center.

headline: Introducing | Brooke Candy, Pop’s Next Superstar
abstract: The master of high-fashion disguise — and brashly talented M.C. — talks with T in advance of her new major-label debut, co-written with the hitmaker Sia.
lead_paragraph: To many citizens of the Internet, the rise of Brooke Candy, 24, will sound familiar. A former stripper, Candy’s image proliferated through likes and retweets when a 2012 music video she appeared in — Grimes’s “Genesis” — went viral. A sword-wielding Barbarella for the Tumblr generation, Candy, clad in cyberpunk princess body armor and neon pink braids — then her trademark look — postured and snarled with primal confidence. The mysterious Candy then revealed her true self several months later, when she uploaded the video to “Das Me,” an abrasive yet empowering hip-hop churner that introduced her as a brash, talented M.C.

lead_paragraph: A selection of images from our latest round of automotive book reviews.

headline: For Jefferson Mays: After the Show, the Stairs Await
abstract: Mr. Mays has a Tony nomination, and a sixth-floor walk-up.
lead_paragraph: At 10 p.m. on Thursday, a couple of dozen people were waiting outside the Walter Kerr Theater in Midtown for Jefferson Mays, an old-fashioned theater type who is a nominee for a Tony Award as best actor in the musical “A Gentleman’s Guide to Love and Murder.”

headline: Malcolm Gladwell ‘Surprised’ to Become an Amazon Bargaining Chip
abstract: One of Hachette’s biggest authors says he wonders if writers need to act together to protest the retailer’s behavior in its dispute with his publisher.
lead_paragraph: In the dispute between Amazon and Hachette, neither side is blinking.

headline: A Japanese Buzz in the Bronx
abstract: The Yankees have three prominent Japanese players, led by Masahiro Tanaka, who is creating a stir in his first year in the majors. As a result, a large Japanese media contingent is often present.
lead_paragraph: The Yankees have three prominent Japanese players, led by Masahiro Tanaka, who is creating a stir in his first year in the majors. As a result, a large Japanese media contingent is often present.

headline: Quantum Teleportation
abstract: Scientists reported that they were able to teleport quantum information reliably across a distance of about 10 feet.
lead_paragraph: Scientists reported that they were able to teleport quantum information reliably across a distance of about 10 feet.

headline: Higher Scores on Crash Avoidance
abstract: Automakers are improving systems that aim to keep drivers from colliding with vehicles ahead, says the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.
lead_paragraph: New test results suggest that automakers are quickly improving the safety systems intended to keep a distracted driver from rear-ending another vehicle or colliding with an object ahead. The tests of 24 models were released Thursday by the Insurance Institute for Highway Safety.

headline: Mapping Apps Follow the Crowd
abstract: Telenav, a navigation services company, is switching from maps that are professionally produced to ones that are crowdsourced, using data and updates provided by contributors.
lead_paragraph: Think of it as the hive approach to car navigation systems: One driver, like a worker bee, finds the quickest way from Point A to Point B and then shares that route with all the other drivers. It’s the basic idea behind all crowdsourcing, the sharing of free user-generated content to create information like restaurant ratings and contractor recommendations.

headline: Unappreciated Love, the Russian Variety
abstract: The Vakhtangov State Academic Theater’s “Eugene Onegin” at City Center is a play with music and dance, composed of scenes from the Pushkin novel in verse.
lead_paragraph: Regret haunts the memories of men who’ve outgrown their brash younger selves, but oh, what pretty pictures torment makes. A glossy, mirrored wall as dark as anthracite looms over the action in the Vakhtangov State Academic Theater’s arrestingly beautiful “Eugene Onegin,” at City Center, and a cloud of white mist floats above the stage.

headline: Collected Wisdom From This Year’s Crop of Fashion-Industry Graduation Speakers
abstract: Several design luminaries, including Tory Burch and Christian Louboutin, spoke at commencement ceremonies recently. T rounds up their words, which are worth listening to no matter your age.
lead_paragraph: It’s that time of year again, when the world’s most successful people travel around the country to give university commencement speeches. This year, a handful of fashion-industry heavy-hitters joined in the tradition. From the shoe designer Christian Louboutin’s address to the student body at F.I.T. to the lecture given by Steven Kolb of the C.F.D.A. at Kendall College of Art and Design, the speeches of several design luminaries suggested that slow and steady, more often than not, wins the race. Here, some of their collected words of wisdom.

headline: In Way Over His Head
abstract: In “Deepest Man,” a play by James Scruggs, a man whose wife drowns confronts his traumas by submerging them.
lead_paragraph: “The Twilight Zone” meets media critique meets psychological portraiture in James Scruggs’s “Deepest Man,” a thought-provoking experiment at the 3LD Art & Technology Center. Given that the show comes from 3-Legged Dog — a company known for integrating performance, video and effects — it is unsurprising that the piece, loaded with abstraction and supernatural traces, is a visual marvel.

headline: A Prime View of Sunset
abstract: The view from the many vantage points at Half Moon in Dobbs Ferry is inspiring. But the experience with the food and the service can vary.
lead_paragraph: Particularly dramatic and romantic at sunset, the view from the Half Moon restaurant’s many vantage points is inspiring. As one of my dining companions observed, there is something about sunset on water that makes one wax Hallmarky. The promenade deck is so close to the Hudson River that when the wind is up, guests might be refreshed by the spray from a crashing wave.

headline: Goodbye, Steinbeck; All Hail, Shelley
abstract: A move by the British education minister Michael Gove to ensure that students read more British literature comes at the expense of American works.
lead_paragraph: LONDON — When government shapes a nation’s literary education, politics inevitably plays a role. That has come clear in the case of the influential and controversial British minister of education, Michael Gove, who was accused of jingoism this week for new syllabus requirements that have led to the removal of classic American works like “To Kill a Mockingbird” and “The Crucible.”

headline: Blackbeard as a Geek: Plundering in High-Tech
abstract: A new AMC drama about the computer industry, “Halt and Catch Fire,” feels odd in going back to the 1980s to glorify imitation, not innovation.
lead_paragraph: There are absolutists who still believe that everything on the Internet should be free and see themselves as partisans, not parasites. Their motto might as well be “intellectual property is theft.”

headline: Beauty Is in the Eye of Your Fellow Swine
abstract: H K Gruber’s opera “Gloria — A Pig Tale” opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday as part of the 11-day NY Phil Biennial.
lead_paragraph: Before conducting the staged production of H K Gruber’s anarchic opera “Gloria — A Pig Tale” that opened at the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Thursday night, the second event of the 11-day NY Phil Biennial, Alan Gilbert told the audience that he had thought a lot about what to say to prepare people for the wild piece they were about to hear. But, he explained, he had decided to say nothing, other than to warn audience members that this opera might not sound like anything else they had ever heard.

headline: Two New Books on Porsche and Muscle Cars
abstract: Porsche by Design is tied to an exhibition at the North Carolina Museum of Art; Steve Magnante’s 1001 Muscle Car Facts is a thoughtfully assembled collection of trivia.
lead_paragraph: In this week’s Automobiles section, readers will find reviews of a selection of books that delve into topics including design, history, motor sports and vintage motoring advice. Choosing the books to be reviewed is always a hand-wringing task here, a pleasant chore of sorting through publishers’ offerings to provide a balance of interests and formats.

headline: After Losing Time Inc. Business, Distributor Is to Close
abstract: Time Inc. last weekend decided to stop using Source Interlink as the distributor for its magazine because of unpaid fees.
lead_paragraph: The second-largest magazine wholesaler in the country, Source Interlink Distribution, which employs about 6,000 workers, will soon cease operations.

headline: Lit Class Field Trip, Movie Star Edition
abstract: When teenagers in the Broadway audience “Of Mice and Men” have a chance to talk to the production’s stars, some of the questions are actually about the play and its meaning.
lead_paragraph: O.K., so one smart aleck asked James Franco to take off his shirt during the question-and-answer session that followed Wednesday’s matinee of “Of Mice and Men.” At that point, the audience at the Longacre Theater was full of teenagers, a lot of them girls, and they were in unusual proximity to a full-fledged movie star.

headline: Under Cover: Paolo Pellegrin on Photographing Srebrenica, 20 Years After the Genocide
keywords: ['Death and Dying', 'Funerals and Memorials', 'Photography', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity']
abstract: Paolo Pellegrin, a photojournalist who has been documenting efforts to uncover mass graves in Srebrenica for the past three years, talks about what it was like photographing the annual Srebrenica memorial ceremony and burial of the dead.
lead_paragraph: The June 1 cover story by Scott Anderson about efforts to uncover mass graves in Srebrenica, Bosnia, is accompanied by a series of haunting photographs by Paolo Pellegrin, who has been documenting the process for the past three years. Some of his pictures capture the scale of the genocide; others examine in extreme close-up the people affected by the tragedy — the man searching for remains, the Dutch soldier with PTSD who can’t seem to leave Bosnia. Pellegrin recently shared with me what it was like photographing the annual Srebrenica memorial ceremony and burial of the dead.

headline: Boehner on Shinseki’s Resignation

lead_paragraph: The House speaker, John A. Boehner, addressed the resignation of the secretary of the Department of Veterans Affairs, Eric Shinseki, at a press conference Friday.

lead_paragraph: One of the songs in “42nd Street,” the popular 1980 musical based on a famous 1933 movie, asks, “What do you go for, Go see a show for?”

headline: In the Temple Dancer’s Story, 3 Important Russian Debuts
abstract: Three Russian artists made first appearances with American Ballet Theater in Natalia Makarova’s production of “La Bayadère.”
lead_paragraph: Three Russian artists made important first appearances on Wednesday and Thursday with American Ballet Theater at the Metropolitan Opera House. The vehicle was Natalia Makarova’s production of “La Bayadère,” which all three had already danced in their native land. Though none of them were new to New York, most people in the audience were watching them for the first time.

headline: Junta Sets Year’s Goals for Its Rule in Thailand
keywords: ["Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat", 'Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: In a proclamation tightening control, the leader said that if “peace, order and reform” are achieved, democracy could return.
lead_paragraph: BANGKOK — Thailand’s military junta tightened its control on Friday with a far-reaching plan to appoint an interim government, write a new constitution and carry out large-scale public works projects. The junta also disclosed for the first time how long it intended to remain in charge — at least into the second half of 2015.

headline: Prison Program Turns Inmates Into Intellectuals
abstract: For too long we have thought about prison education almost exclusively in terms of reduced recidivism. But in some sense this is an inadequate metric, neglecting opportunities available to prisoners who pursue and complete higher learning.
lead_paragraph: Otisville Correctional Facility is a medium-security state prison, 79 miles northwest of Manhattan, on the site of a former tuberculosis sanitarium — with an equalizing element of portent, near the town of Mount Hope. Many of its prisoners are serving life sentences; they are men whom time, as one guard put it “has mellowed out.” Nearby, but unrelated, is the Otisville federal prison, named by Forbes Magazine as one of America’s “cushiest” incarcerators. Observers have likened it to a college, which is not an analogy you would easily draw at the state prison, where inmates rely largely on encyclopedias for the retrieval of information, in volumes that look as if they were last current when the nation was debating the merits of Dan Quayle.

lead_paragraph: When J. A. Heneghan’s Tavern opened in Point Lookout in September, I put off visiting it. I thought the restaurant would have the most appeal in warm weather, given its location on the same barrier island as Long Beach. I need not have waited; Heneghan’s is a place for all seasons.

headline: Walesa Among Ex-Leaders at Funeral of Political Enemy
abstract: Three of the country’s presidents attended services for Gen. Wojciech Jaruzelski, who declared martial law in 1981 amid labor unrest and a pro-democracy movement.
lead_paragraph: WARSAW — With demonstrators chanting on the streets outside and the three surviving Polish presidents in attendance, perhaps the most polarizing figure in modern Polish history was honored on Friday at a funeral Mass in the Field Cathedral of the Polish Army.

headline: Latest Port Authority Roadblock Delays Legislation, Not Traffic

lead_paragraph: The lawmakers planned to gather where it was once, infamously, time for some traffic problems — a symbolic show of bistate unity to help repair a wounded agency.

headline: Medicare to Now Cover Sex-Change Surgery
abstract: A government appeals board said the exclusion was no longer reasonable because the surgery is safe and effective and can no longer be considered experimental.
lead_paragraph: Medicare may no longer exclude sex-reassignment surgery from coverage, a government appeals board ruled Friday. It said the current exclusion was “no longer reasonable” because the surgery is safe and effective and can no longer be considered experimental.

headline: Far From Greece, Yet Bringing Its Flavors Alive
abstract: At Olive Restaurant in Freehold, recreating the cuisine of their native island of Karpathos has required a few tweaks from a pair of brothers.
lead_paragraph: Recreating Greek island cooking in New Jersey takes a bit of creativity and compromise. On the island of Karpathos, you would tenderize a freshly caught octopus by beating it about 50 times and rubbing it for about 15 minutes on the sea rocks, says Nikolas Mastrominas, the proprietor of Olive Restaurant. Here, he concedes, you must buy a good imported octopus and boil it — but not for long. If it gets too soft, it will lose its flavor.

headline: Conviction in Terrorism Case in Canada
abstract: A jury on Friday convicted a former security guard from Toronto of attempting to join a foreign terrorist organization, a first for Canada.
lead_paragraph: A jury on Friday convicted a former security guard from Toronto of attempting to join a foreign terrorist organization, a first for Canada. Prosecutors and the police said that the man, Mohamed Hassan Hersi, a Canadian born in Somalia, was heading to join the Somali extremist group Shabab when he was arrested at Toronto’s airport in 2011. Mr. Hersi, who was holding a one-way ticket to Cairo, has maintained that he was going overseas to study Arabic. Long before his arrest, Mr. Hersi had been the subject of an extensive police investigation after the company that employed Mr. Hersi as a guard found in one of his uniforms a USB memory stick that contained what were described as extremist materials. Mr. Hersi was also convicted of encouraging an undercover police officer to participate in terrorism.

lead_paragraph: CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa — Nothing about Joni Ernst’s Senate campaign here has been conventional.

abstract: The life of George Rose, a veteran of the London and Broadway stages who was murdered in 1988, was filled with eccentricities and mystery.

headline: How Book Publishers Can Beat Amazon
keywords: ['E-Books and Readers', 'Prices (Fares, Fees and Rates)', 'Antitrust Laws and Competition Issues', 'Book Trade and Publishing', 'Suits and Litigation (Civil)']
abstract: They may have to control their own online marketplace.
lead_paragraph: AMAZON has caused no small controversy of late by refusing to accept presale orders on books to be released by the publisher Hachette and by understocking Hachette’s titles. These punitive maneuvers, which follow a dispute between Amazon and Hachette about e-book contracts, have led to significant delays in shipments of Hachette’s books to Amazon’s customers.

headline: With Sale Pending, N.B.A. Cancels Its Vote on Sterling
abstract: The N.B.A. will not decide whether to take the Clippers away from Donald Sterling, the current owner.
lead_paragraph: One day after the former Microsoft chief executive Steve Ballmer agreed to pay $2 billion for the Los Angeles Clippers, the N.B.A. on Friday said that it would not vote to take away the team from Donald Sterling, the owner of the team, who received a lifetime ban for making racist comments.

lead_paragraph: A compilation of the White House press secretary Jay Carney’s quips to “ridiculous” questions from reporters in the briefing room.

headline: How South Jersey Shaped Glass, and Vice Versa
abstract: An exhibition at the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Arts and Cultural Center explores both New Jersey’s glassmaking heritage and how the skills have been passed on.
lead_paragraph: There are those who come away from “NJ350: Through the Lens of Glass,” a new exhibition at the Museum of American Glass at Wheaton Arts and Cultural Center, wondering how they knew so little about New Jersey’s role in the history of glassmaking.

headline: Fed Debate Over Future Beyond End of Stimulus
abstract: The debate reflects both the stability of current Fed policy and the considerable uncertainty about what the Fed should do next — and how.
lead_paragraph: STANFORD, Calif. — The combination of a persistently weak labor market and evidence of a little more inflation is prompting an increasingly vigorous debate among Federal Reserve officials about the future of the central bank’s stimulus campaign.

keywords: ['News Sources, Confidential Status of', 'News and News Media', 'Freedom of the Press', 'Television']

lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A former Fox News journalist disclosed on Thursday that he had been subpoenaed in 2011 for notes and testimony identifying his confidential sources in a leak investigation, adding a new public chapter to the Obama administration’s crackdown on unauthorized disclosures.

headline: Around Seattle, Ballmer’s Other Title Is Superfan
abstract: The former Microsoft chief, who has a well-known competitive streak, is a boisterous presence at youth sports events in the Seattle area.
lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — For a taste of the kind of team owner Steve Ballmer will be if his $2 billion offer for the Los Angeles Clippers is approved, it is worth considering his almost legendary status around youth sports games in his hometown.

headline: Dr. Melvin J. Glimcher, Prosthetics Innovator, Dies at 88
abstract: His insights from the fields of orthopedics and engineering led to major scientific breakthroughs, including an artificial limb called the “Boston Arm.”
lead_paragraph: As a second-year student at Harvard Medical School, Melvin J. Glimcher was assigned to use textbooks to prepare a report on the mechanics of the foot. He quickly concluded that the textbooks were wrong, and his report said so.

headline: Lopsided Games Translate to a Tight Series Between Spurs and Thunder
abstract: With his team leading, 3-2, in the Western Conference finals, Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich said he could not explain why such a compelling series had consisted of five routs.
lead_paragraph: SAN ANTONIO — The Western Conference finals have largely been what one may have expected from the teams with the two best records in the N.B.A. this season. The series between the San Antonio Spurs and the Oklahoma City Thunder has been rife with plot twists, mood swings and accusations of subterfuge.

headline: In Spanish Riots, Anguish of Those Recovery Forgot
abstract: Four nights of demonstrations in Spain’s tourism capital have highlighted the country’s persistent social tensions and belied signs of relief from years of austerity.
lead_paragraph: BARCELONA, Spain — Four nights of rioting here in Spain’s tourism capital have highlighted the country’s persistent social tensions and belied signs of relief from a fragile economic recovery, which has yet to alleviate rampant joblessness.

headline: Albany Pressed to Honor Coldblooded Flip-Flopper
abstract: Following a request from a fourth-grade class, Senator John A. DeFrancisco hopes to place on the legislative agenda a bill to name the wood frog as the state amphibian.
lead_paragraph: Ostensibly, the goal was to teach students a lesson about democracy, a lesson that can sometimes seem lost on the New York State Legislature.

headline: Dealing With Boko Haram
abstract: The militants have been wreaking havoc for years. It is time for Nigeria to take responsibility for the well-being of its citizens.
lead_paragraph: It has been more than six weeks since nearly 300 schoolgirls were kidnapped by the Boko Haram extremist group in Nigeria. The militants have spent the last five years wreaking havoc and killing civilians — about 4,000 have died — in the northeastern section of the country. But it took a horrifying mass abduction to touch hearts around the world and persuade Nigeria — whose president, Goodluck Jonathan, initially rejected outside help — to join with other countries to try to find them.

keywords: ['Musical Instruments', 'Renting and Leasing (Real Estate)', 'Real Estate (Commercial)', 'Relocation of Business']
abstract: Leslie Ross is swapping her crammed Lower East Side studio, where she has spent years building bassoons and inventing unusual instruments, for a sprawling factory in Maine.
lead_paragraph: There are not many places to sit amid the jumble of metal tools, piles of maple and boxwood boards, and bassoons crowding — and even hanging from the ceiling of — Leslie Ross’s studio on the Lower East Side.

keywords: ['Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Sentences (Criminal)', 'Muggings', 'Confessions', 'False Arrests, Convictions and Imprisonments']

headline: Mr. Shinseki Takes the Fall
keywords: ['Appointments and Executive Changes', 'Veterans', 'Hospitals', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Editorials']
abstract: The secretary’s resignation is just the beginning of much-needed process of change at the Department of Veterans Affairs.
lead_paragraph: The resignation of Secretary Eric Shinseki from the Veterans Affairs Department was probably unavoidable, under the principle that a leader should accept full responsibility for a great scandal. But the department’s problem was not Mr. Shinseki. It has been broken for years. No one should expect his removal to be anything but the beginning of a much-needed process of change.

headline: Book Guiding Border Agents on Force Is Released

abstract: The Rev. Emil J. Kapaun’s heroics in World War II and the Korean War, as well as some recent events have inspired those who have long sought his canonization.

With his holy vows imminent, he still sounded like a farmer’s son from a pinprick in the Kansas prairie called Pilsen, a 24-year-old persuaded mostly of his own inadequacy.

headline: Veterans’ Crisis Put Obama on the Defensive as Others Failed to Do
keywords: ['Veterans', 'Appointments and Executive Changes', 'United States Politics and Government', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: For a president who came to office hoping to restore public faith in government as a force for good in society, the situation at the V.A. threatens to undercut his reputation for effectiveness.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — This time, President Obama did not wait. Confronted by reports of mismanagement and besieged by members of his own party, he gave in to the pressure and performed the sort of ritual Washington sacrifice he has resisted in other times of crisis over the last five years.

headline: Bird’s-Eye View

lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA — As he walked through the Mets’ clubhouse Friday, Tim Teufel paused and politely entertained a hypothetical situation. Imagine it was the 17th inning, he was told, and imagine the Mets were locked in a tight game and were suddenly out of shortstops. Would he be comfortable playing Jacob deGrom at shortstop?

lead_paragraph: Rarer than a Rangers berth in the Stanley Cup finals — they have been there only four times since 1950 — is the team’s having to wait for its opponent.

headline: Few Top Players Can Say Tennis Is Family Business
abstract: In tennis, it has been stunningly rare for sons and daughters of top players to replicate the success of their parents, even as families in other sports have made it look easy.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — Back into the second week for the first time in 24 Grand Slam events, Ernests Gulbis was asked Friday if his feats might one day be equaled by two younger racket-wielders in his family, his sisters Laura Gulbe, 19, and Monika Kavace, 15.

headline: On Death Row With Low I.Q., and New Hope for a Reprieve
abstract: After a ruling that says states can no longer rely on a fixed I.Q. cutoff to decide intellectual competency, the likelihood increased that some inmates will have a chance to avoid execution.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — For Ted Herring, who has spent 32 years on Florida’s death row for murdering a store clerk, signs of intellectual disability arose early and piled up quickly: He repeated first grade and got D’s and F’s through fourth grade. He read like a fourth grader at 14 and did not know that summer followed spring.

lead_paragraph: Even as excitement builds around California Chrome’s bid to become the 12th Triple Crown winner and the first in 36 years, there may be growing momentum to radically alter the grueling three-races-in-five-weeks format that helps make the feat so rare.

headline: Iran Hackers Dangle a Familiar Name to Fish for Data
abstract: Hackers seeking information about Washington’s elite posed as John R. Bolton, a former American ambassador to the United Nations, to friend online users through social media.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the years, John R. Bolton has played many roles in Washington. He was American ambassador to the United Nations, where he famously suggested the place could lose many of its floors — and the bureaucrats who worked on them. He was the State Department’s combative counterproliferation chief during George W. Bush’s first term, and these days he regularly appears on Fox News to denounce the Obama administration as weak and feckless.

lead_paragraph: PHOENIX — The Obama administration has moved to drop its legal fight against what is arguably the most controversial provision of Arizona’s sweeping immigration law, the so-called show-me-your-papers provision permitting police officers to pull over people based on the suspicion that they are in the country illegally.

This was a teaching moment, a reminder that Montero still had a way to go. It was his first major league start on the road, and there would be more moments like this to come.

lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — North Korea said on Saturday that it had sentenced a South Korean Baptist missionary to a labor camp for life for allegedly trying to build underground churches in the country, where the government considers such religious activities an attempt to sabotage its rule.

headline: Financial Hazards of a Fugitive Life
keywords: ['Fugitives', 'Income Inequality', 'United States Economy', 'Books and Literature', 'Crime and Criminals']
abstract: Offering a different take on income inequality, “On the Run,” a sociologist’s new book, examines the many burdens faced by those hiding from the law.
lead_paragraph: “Capital in the Twenty-First Century,” Thomas Piketty’s new book, has received a great deal of attention. But we shouldn’t neglect another important new book on income inequality, from a much different perspective. Titled “On the Run: Fugitive Life in an American City,” and written by Alice Goffman, a sociologist at the University of Wisconsin, Madison, it offers a fascinating and disturbing portrait of the economic constraints and incentives faced by a large subset of Americans: those who are hiding from the law.

headline: Quantifying Privacy: A Week of Location Data May Be an ‘Unreasonable Search’
abstract: A new research paper concludes that a week’s worth of location data can reveal so much about a person it amounts to an “unreasonable search,” prohibited by the Fourth Amendment.
lead_paragraph: When does the simple digital tracking of your location and movements — the GPS bleeps from most of our smartphones — start to be truly revealing? When do the data points and inferences that can be drawn from it strongly suggest, say, trips to a psychiatrist, a mosque, an abortion clinic, a strip club or an AIDS treatment center?

headline: Joe on WNYC’s Money Talking

lead_paragraph: June 4 marks the 25th anniversary of the uprising in Tiananmen Square, when student-led protests in China were ruthlessly put down by the country’s government. Today, China is poised to surpass the United States as the world’s largest economy. Perhaps that’s not too surprising for a country of 1.3 billion people that has embraced capitalism and seen its economy boom.

Abdel Fattah el-Sisi, until recently the military chief and controlling force behind the government, always had the upper hand — the army’s loyalty, the subservient media and the lack of real competition after he jailed or intimidated all serious opposition. He got more than 95 percent of the vote.

lead_paragraph: Late in the afternoon of Aug. 5, 1949, 15 young men working for the United States Forest Service parachuted into a remote area near the Missouri River north of Helena, Mont., on the eastern side of the Rockies, prepared to battle what they thought to be an easily manageable forest fire. headline: Our Flinching State of Mind
keywords: ['Deaths (Fatalities)', 'Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Murders and Attempted Murders', 'Books and Literature']
abstract: The world isn’t more dangerous than it was before. But we are more afraid.
lead_paragraph: ON Feb. 26, 1972, 132 million gallons of black coal sludge broke through a dam above the Appalachian hollow of Buffalo Creek, W.Va., and spewed onto the 5,000 people who lived in the scattered villages below. “It was a wall of water and debris,” one survivor remembered. “It looked like it was about 25 or 30 foot high coming running at us. And it was just black-looking. It was just rumbling and roaring and the houses was popping and snapping and they was breaking up.” In the end, 125 people lost their lives and more than 4,000 lost their homes.

headline: Bob Bailey, Entertainer Who Helped Integrate Las Vegas, Dies at 87

lead_paragraph: Bob Bailey, a Las Vegas entertainer, television personality and civil rights activist who helped break down racial barriers for decades, beginning when he arrived in 1955 to serve as an M.C. and singer at the Moulin Rouge, the city’s first integrated hotel and casino, died on May 24 in Las Vegas. He was 87.

headline: This Fugitive Life

abstract: For many poor black men, the threat of capture and confinement looms.
lead_paragraph: WE have begun to pay attention to the harmful effects that America’s extremely high levels of incarceration have on former prisoners and their families, particularly in African-American neighborhoods, but we’re still missing part of the story. Our get-tough turn didn’t just send millions of African-American men to prison and return them home with felony convictions. It expanded the scope of policing and court supervision in poor black neighborhoods, radically altering the way life is lived there.
