keywords: ['Rohingya (Ethnic Group)', 'War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity', 'Human Rights and Human Rights Violations', 'Apartheid (Policy)']
abstract: On this year’s “win-a-trip” journey, one man living under an ignored apartheid sends out a message to the world: We are suffering. Will anyone respond?
lead_paragraph: MRAUK U, Myanmar — AS we hiked on a bamboo bridge over a river, past a police checkpoint, by water buffalo, over abandoned rice paddies, and past a hamlet where 28 Muslim children had been hacked to death, word raced ahead of us. Farmers poured out to welcome us from two besieged villages that for two years have been mostly cut off from the world.

headline: Kings and Blackhawks Build a Series of Thrills
abstract: Patrick Kane’s goal late in the third period gave Chicago the victory Friday night and forced a Game 7 against Los Angeles on Sunday in the Western Conference finals.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Magic Johnson and the Los Angeles Lakers gave the sporting world “Showtime,” but this year, it has been Chicago Blackhawks right wing Patrick Kane who has put on a show.

headline: Lessons From the Smoke Shop
abstract: Ask first, don’t grab, be fair and say thank you.
lead_paragraph: MY 30-year-long subscription to The New Yorker ran out a few months ago — pure absent-mindedness on my part — and since then I buy a copy each week at the smoke shop around the corner from my apartment.

headline: Triple Crown Bid Is a Long-Awaited Anniversary Gift
keywords: ['Belmont Stakes', 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Horse Racing', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers']
abstract: It is thought that the final leg of the Triple Crown requires a special style and “a high cruising speed.” No horse has won all three races since 1978.
lead_paragraph: When a caller to a 1986 sports talk radio show that I co-hosted asked why no horse had won the Triple Crown in a while, the jockey Eddie Arcaro, a guest on the show, said, “You’ll never see another.”

headline: Letters to the Editor
abstract: Readers sound off on the latest headlines.
lead_paragraph: To the Sports Editor:

headline: A Past Not Past
abstract: As Leon Uris wrote in “Trinity,” “In Ireland there is no future, only the past happening over and over.”
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As I walk up to Bobby Van’s Steakhouse to meet Gerry Adams, I’m surprised to see him sitting alone outside. Wearing a dark three-piece tweed suit with a green ribbon on the lapel, the alleged terrorist on the terrace is calmly reading some papers.

headline: French Crowds Love and Hate Their Own
abstract: Although the French public set high expectations for French players they perceive as potential title contenders, they can be equally uncompromising when it comes to on-court behavior.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — It has been many years since a French teenager with no Grand Slam experience captivated the Roland Garros crowd the way Laurent Lokoli did last week.

headline: An Unflashy Player Has Numbers That Sparkle
abstract: Now an elder statesman of baseball, Bobby Abreu has career statistics that are worthy of Hall of Fame consideration, even if he and Cooperstown are rarely mentioned in the same breath.
lead_paragraph: He’s 40, a part-time outfielder in New York and among the best in history at reaching base. You are probably thinking of Ichiro Suzuki, but you would be off by more than 500 times on base.

headline: Authorities Find Insider Trading Case Tied to Phil Mickelson Is Slow to Take Shape
abstract: Nearly three years after the trades flashed some telltale signs of possible insider trading, a case has yet to materialize.
lead_paragraph: In the summer of 2011, a series of winning stock trades raised immediate red flags for financial regulators.

headline: As Ties With China Unravel, U.S. Companies Head to Mexico
keywords: ['Factories and Manufacturing', 'International Trade and World Market', 'Labor and Jobs', 'Foreign Investments']
abstract: With costs rising rapidly in China, American manufacturers are looking to Mexico with an eagerness not seen since the early years of the North American Free Trade Agreement.
lead_paragraph: SALTILLO, Mexico — Jason Sauey calls them lemmings — all the American companies that rushed to China to make things like toys and toilet brushes, only to be searching now for alternatives in Mexico and the United States. His own family-owned plastics company, Flambeau, nearly made the same mistake around 2004, he said, when competitors contracting with China undercut prices and seized market share.

headline: Stars, and Nonstars, Keep Aligning for the Miami Heat
abstract: The interplay of the superstars and the supporting cast is behind the success of the Heat, who are making a fourth straight trip to the N.B.A. finals.
lead_paragraph: MIAMI — Shane Battier, a 13-year N.B.A. veteran and two-time champion with the Miami Heat, was the perfect player to provide a bit of context to the happenings late Friday. Although some of his teammates said they would need time to gain perspective on their latest accomplishment — a playoff series win over the Indiana Pacers, a fourth straight trip to the finals — Battier seemed to possess a good deal.

headline: View, Interrupted: The Spoiling of Manhattan’s Skyline
abstract: Buildings rising along the Lincoln Tunnel helix are blocking my good-night kiss to the twinkling city across the Hudson.
lead_paragraph: MANHATTAN is an island of serious wealth, endless ambition and impossibly expensive real estate.

headline: In Ukraine War, Kremlin Leaves No Fingerprints
abstract: Eastern Ukraine is becoming the setting of a subtle game in which Russian freelancers, not soldiers, are shaping events.
lead_paragraph: DONETSK, Ukraine — Not long ago, Alexander Borodai, a fast-talking Muscovite with a stylish goatee, worked as a consultant for an investment fund in Moscow. Today he is prime minister of the self-declared Donetsk People’s Republic, zipping around town in a black S.U.V. with tinted windows and armed guards and commanding what he says are hundreds of fighters from Russia.

headline: Sunday Breakfast Menu, June 1
abstract: Turmoil continues to rock the Department of Veteran’s Affairs, heightened by the resignation of Eric K. Shinseki on Friday. The Sunday talk shows will examine what’s next for the department, but first, guests will dive into the United States’ foreign policy blueprint, outlined in President Obama’s commencement speech at the Military Academy at West Point.
lead_paragraph: Turmoil continues to rock the Department of Veteran’s Affairs, heightened by the resignation of Eric K. Shinseki on Friday. The Sunday talk shows will examine what’s next for the department, but first, guests will dive into the United States’ foreign policy blueprint, outlined in President Obama’s commencement speech at the United States Military Academy at West Point.

headline: Watson Holds Lead at Memorial, but Mickelson Garners More Attention
abstract: Phil Mickelson said in a statement on Saturday that he had no involvement in an insider trading investigation being conducted by the F.B.I., and reiterated that sentiment after his round.
lead_paragraph: DUBLIN, Ohio — It is less than two weeks before the United States Open, and Tiger Woods is sidelined with a back injury, Phil Mickelson is involved in a federal insider trading investigation, and Rory McIlroy is dealing with the fallout from breaking off his engagement to the tennis star Caroline Wozniacki after their wedding announcements were mailed.

headline: In Obama’s Speeches, a Shifting Tone on Terror
keywords: ['Terrorism', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Afghanistan War (2001- )', 'United States International Relations']
abstract: After five and a half years and dozens of addresses, the trail of President Obama’s foreign policy pronouncements has grown muddier.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Few leaders place more weight than President Obama on the power of the spoken word to clarify a messy world. But after five and a half years and dozens of speeches — most recently at West Point last week — the trail of Mr. Obama’s pronouncements has grown muddier.

headline: You Can’t Tell the Tennis Stars’ Coaches Without a Scorecard
abstract: Entourages have been expanding for years in professional tennis, but the latest expansion, particularly among the elite, is coming in the coaching ranks.
lead_paragraph: PARIS — In the French Open players’ lounge this year, Stefan Edberg notices a change from his glory days.

headline: With the Rohingya in Myanmar
abstract: Readers comment on my column about the crimes against humanity targeting the Rohingya of Myanmar.
lead_paragraph: My Sunday column, from some remote villages in Myanmar, looks at the ethnic cleansing and crimes against humanity being perpetrated against the Rohingya minority there. Some scholars call it genocide, and it arguably does meet the definition in the 1948 convention. But it’s not comparable to the mass murders in Rwanda, Darfur, Armenia or of course the Holocaust, so maybe ethnic cleansing is a better term in this case.

headline: The Race Not Run
keywords: ["I'll Have Another (Race Horse)", 'Triple Crown (Horse Racing)', 'Jockeys, Drivers and Trainers', 'Horse Racing']
abstract: I’ll Have Another has settled in at a Japanese breeding farm, two years after an injury cost him a shot at a Triple Crown.
lead_paragraph: NIIKAPPU-GUN, Japan — It was just after noon on a recent day at Big Red Farm, one of Japan’s largest horse breeders, time for Hiroshi Kimura to take the 5-year-old stallion I’ll Have Another for a walk.

headline: Many Veterans Praise Care, but All Hate the Wait
keywords: ['Veterans', 'United States Defense and Military Forces', 'Health Insurance and Managed Care', 'Hospitals']
abstract: Veterans have expressed frustration with delayed access to health care and an impenetrable and unresponsive bureaucracy at Veterans Affairs hospitals and clinics.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Marc Schenker, an Air Force veteran in Fort Lauderdale, Fla., is having surgery this month to remove a golf-ball-size hernia — but not at a veterans hospital. Mr. Schenker, 67, said he had given up on the Veterans Affairs hospital in Miami after waiting months to get the procedure scheduled and had turned to a private surgeon instead, using Medicare.

headline: What Veterans Tell Us About Their Care
abstract: The New York Times asked veterans around the country to share their experiences at V.A. hospitals and clinics.
lead_paragraph: Amid reports of delayed access to care at Department of Veterans Affairs hospitals, The New York Times asked veterans and others to share their stories about the quality of care at the agency’s facilities across the country. A selection of submissions appears below. We invite you to share your story here.

headline: After Tanaka’s Eighth Victory, Most See Him as an Ace. He Doesn’t.
abstract: Masahiro Tanaka remained modest after allowing four hits in eight innings and lowering his earned run average to 2.06 as the Yankees beat the Twins.
lead_paragraph: Shortly after Masahiro Tanaka signed a seven-year, $155 million contract in January, Yankees General Manager Brian Cashman said in a radio interview that Tanaka, a 25-year-old pitcher, had a ceiling as a No. 3 starter.

headline: Russia’s Reach Into Ukraine’s East
abstract: While Russian tanks never crossed the border with Ukraine, many of its civilians did, bolstering a pro-Russian agenda that has destabilized the divided east.
lead_paragraph: While Russian tanks never crossed the border with Ukraine, many of its civilians did, bolstering a pro-Russian agenda that has destabilized the divided east.

headline: Anger for ‘Jesus Christ Superstar’ Cast, and a Black Eye for Its Promoter
abstract: The tour of the star-studded rock opera, which was canceled with no warning on Friday, would have been a big break for the actor in the lead role.
lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS — Ben Forster, a 33-year-old British actor, was preparing for the biggest break of his career as he rehearsed the title role for an ambitious arena tour of “Jesus Christ Superstar” that was to have its first performance here at the Lakefront Arena on June 9.

headline: U.S. Counts on Altidore to End His Drought
abstract: Striker Jozy Altidore had a disappointing season in the Premier League, scoring one goal, but United States Coach Jurgen Klinsmann said he expected Altidore to have a “very special” World Cup.
lead_paragraph: For several years, Jozy Altidore has carried expectations of becoming the United States’ next great, or perhaps first great, goal-scoring striker. Yet at the very moment he appears ready to reach his potential, he is in a confounding scoring slump.

headline: Harrah’s Tunica Casino to Close, Hinting at Gambling Glut
abstract: A disquieting reality that underlines the deeper threat facing Mississippi and other states with legalized gambling: There may be too many casinos chasing too few gambling dollars.
lead_paragraph: TUNICA RESORTS, Miss. — At the height of a recent dinner hour at Mississippi’s largest casino, fewer than two dozen patrons were seated in the buffet’s dining room. A nearby jewelry display sat aglow but bare. The hallways were mostly empty.

headline: Aladdin
abstract: Tom McCoy’s puzzle contains wordplay galore.
lead_paragraph: SUNDAY’S PUZZLE — How long did it take you to figure out how the title of Tom McCoy’s puzzle related to the puzzle itself? Hands up if you studied it and pored over it and it still didn’t sink in. Then, just as you were about to walk away, it trickled through your gray matter, hit the right brain cell, and you said “Ooooooohhhhh …”

headline: Grandmaster’s Death Recalls Era of Risks and Rewards
abstract: Dragoljub Velimirovic, who died May 22, was one of the last players to develop a system or strategy that bears its creator’s name, a feat unlikely to happen again.
lead_paragraph: The Serbian grandmaster Dragoljub Velimirovic, who died May 22 at age 72, was one of the last players to develop a system or strategy that is so inventive it bears its creator’s name.

headline: Before Syrian Suicide Blast, a Quiet Life in the Suburbs
abstract: An American man who a militant group said detonated 16 tons of explosives was remembered in the Florida subdivision where he grew up for his love of basketball.
lead_paragraph: VERO BEACH, Fla. — An American suicide bomber who a militant group said detonated 16 tons of explosives at a mountaintop restaurant in Syria last week was remembered in the suburban Florida subdivision where he grew up for a single thing: his love of basketball.

headline: Spurs’ Experimentation With Lineups Pays Off
abstract: After Serge Ibaka’s return helped the Thunder even their playoff series, Gregg Popovich used Boris Diaw to draw him outside.
lead_paragraph: With two resounding wins at home, the Oklahoma City Thunder seemed to have the momentum going their way. But San Antonio Spurs Coach Gregg Popovich had been preparing his team for this moment all season.

headline: After Deadly Rampage, Sheriff’s Office Faces Concerns About Conduct
keywords: ['Isla Vista, Calif, Massacre (2014)', 'Police', 'Mental Health and Disorders', 'Murders and Attempted Murders']
abstract: The Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s Office followed a call from Elliot O. Rodger’s mother by visiting Mr. Rodger’s and determining that he was not an immediate threat. Three weeks later, he killed six people.
lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — A week after Elliot O. Rodger’s violent rampage in Isla Vista, Calif., that left six college students dead and 13 other people wounded, state lawmakers are now calling for an investigation of the Santa Barbara County Sheriff’s Office’s previous contact with Mr. Rodger. Some are calling for wholesale changes to how law enforcement officers respond to calls that someone could be a threat to himself or to others.

headline: Bergdahl in Taliban Video (2009)
abstract: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl recounted his capture and desire to rejoin to his girlfriend and family in the United States in a video released by the Taliban a month after he was taken prisoner.
lead_paragraph: Sgt. Bowe Bergdahl recounted his capture and desire to rejoin to his girlfriend and family in the United States in a video released by the Taliban a month after he was taken prisoner.

headline: The Rangers’ March to the Finals, Step by Step
abstract: It has been a long, strange trip for the 2013-2014 Rangers. Here is a look back at some of the events of the last year that defined their journey to the Stanley Cup finals.
lead_paragraph: The Rangers were still celebrating their Eastern Conference title late Thursday night when someone asked Coach Alain Vigneault how he would have reacted in October if someone had told him his team would be in the Stanley Cup finals come June.

headline: The Politics of Obama’s Climate Move
abstract: Assessing the political landscape as President Obama prepares to introduce a new regulation to get states to cut carbon emissions and reduce pollution.
lead_paragraph: Assessing the political landscape as President Obama prepares to introduce a new regulation to get states to cut carbon emissions and reduce pollution.

headline: Pentagon Plan to Enlist Young Immigrants Is Delayed at White House’s Request
keywords: ['Immigration and Emigration', 'Citizenship and Naturalization', 'Draft and Recruitment (Military)', 'Dream Act (Development, Relief and Education for Minors Act)', 'Illegal Immigration', 'United States Defense and Military Forces']
abstract: The White House delayed a plan to allow the recruitment of young, skilled immigrants with deportation deferrals.
lead_paragraph: A Pentagon plan to allow a small number of young immigrants who grew up in the United States without legal status to enlist in the military has been delayed by the White House, senior officials there said Saturday, to avoid any conflict with House Republicans considering whether to move on immigration legislation.

headline: Tracing the Origin of Handshake Lines in the N.H.L.
abstract: Handshake lines are a league custom, and a recent online memoir asserts the first instance was in 1908.
lead_paragraph: One moment Thursday encapsulated the special nature of the N.H.L.’s traditional handshake line after playoff series: The Montreal Canadiens’ Brandon Prust placed his hand gently on the side of Derek Stepan’s head, smiling as he spoke to Stepan, his affection bound with remorse and best wishes as the Rangers were headed to the Stanley Cup finals.
